column583:
I:And ah, why, where do those views, um, where do your views of right and wrong come from?
R:I guess my religious beliefs.
I:Okay.  Is there anything that you think makes something inherently right or wrong?
R:Um.
I:In other words, how do you decide what is kind of right and wrong in life?
R:Just a feeling I get and influence and just talking to um, people who have been there and stuff like that.
I:Okay, ah any specific examples come up from your life about when you confronted a situation and you really knew something was maybe very right or very wrong to do and you had that feeling that you were talking about?
R:Um, I can’t really think of anything off the top of my head right now.
column584: I guess my religious beliefs. Um. Just a feeling I get and influence and just talking to um, people who have been there and stuff like that. Um, I can’t really think of anything off the top of my head right now.
column585: The respondent believes that morality is influenced by their religious beliefs and intuition, feels guilty when they hurt others, and actively works to improve their behavior, while also opposing friends' wrong actions without facing repercussions, and maintains a clear stance against substance abuse, viewing it as morally wrong.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:Things I’m taught or the way I feel about things.
I:Has it gotten easier or harder to decide between right and wrong over the past few years?
R:I would say easier.
I:How so?  Can you tell me an example?
R:Well I think probably because my priorities in high school and stuff like that weren’t the same as they are now like I guess I found the more important things in life and focused on those even if it is like religion and family and things like that.
I:So your views have changed in the past couple of years about what’s right and wrong?
R:No.  I think they are just maybe become more solidified and a little less gray area.
I:So what kind of gray areas like?
R:Maybe the type of music I listen to, the things that I watch, even just like tinny little things morally.
I:Like what?
R:I don’t know… how intense your kissing gets or that kind of thing.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Maybe is it going to make you happy in the long run not necessarily momentary pleasure and commitments with God, whether your…it wouldn’t harm somebody else or make them happier.
I:Where do you think you have gotten your morals views from?  Where did it come from?
R:My religion.
column590: Things I’m taught or the way I feel about things. I would say easier. Well I think probably because my priorities in high school and stuff like that weren’t the same as they are now like I guess I found the more important things in life and focused on those even if it is like religion and family and things like that. No.  I think they are just maybe become more solidified and a little less gray area. Maybe the type of music I listen to, the things that I watch, even just like tinny little things morally. I don’t know… how intense your kissing gets or that kind of thing.  Maybe is it going to make you happy in the long run not necessarily momentary pleasure and commitments with God, whether your…it wouldn’t harm somebody else or make them happier.  My religion.
column591: The respondent emphasizes the importance of tithing and education, influenced by a desire for self-sufficiency and family support, while also highlighting that their moral decisions are guided by religious teachings, parental advice, and a commitment to doing what is right according to eternal values, rather than succumbing to societal pressures or momentary pleasures.

column583:
I:Okay.  I was gonna ask next, then, where do your own beliefs about right and wrong come from?  You’ve already spoken to that, it sounds like.
R:Yeah, yeah.
I:So religion you would say?
R:Christian, yeah.
I:Christian religion, okay.
R:And just common sense, most of the time.
I:Okay, okay.  Um, so the, then the thing says, can you give me some specific examples of what would be kind of right and wrong, like from a Christian viewpoint, do you think?  In other words, something that shows like what makes something right or wrong for you, given your beliefs?
R:Well I think most of it would be common sense and knowledge about it, so what would be right or wrong, like, like some things like sharing it’s just, it’s just right and then there’s keeping everything to yourself or stealing, which is wrong.  Stealing is just wrong, it’s just common sense.
I:Okay.  Um, so do you, so when you decide how something is good or bad or right or wrong, you, you apply common sense it sounds like?
R:Yes, and religion, as well.
I:Okay and religion.
R:What I’ve learned mostly.
column584: I disagree with that, being brought up in a Christian household and having a firm belief in God and, and um, what is right and wrong, so I disagree with that. Yeah, yeah. Christian, yeah. And just common sense, most of the time. Well I think most of it would be common sense and knowledge about it, so what would be right or wrong, like, like some things like sharing it’s just, it’s just right and then there’s keeping everything to yourself or stealing, which is wrong.  Stealing is just wrong, it’s just common sense. Yes, and religion, as well. What I’ve learned mostly.
column585: The respondent, raised in a Christian household, relies on religious beliefs and common sense to determine right from wrong, acknowledges occasional mistakes, and feels no peer pressure regarding substance use, while also recognizing the importance of parental discipline and guidance in their life decisions.
column586:
I:All right.  Um, so, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, and right and wrong in life?
R:Most the time, I would use my religion to determine what’s right and wrong, however, in certain situations, I have my own beliefs concerning it, you know, that I may not find the direct answer and specific answer to in the scriptures, then I, I look at life experience and determine what’s right on my own.  My parents have always told me that I’ve had this innate sense of right and wrong, so I think I’m doing something—
I:Yeah, you said innate sense of right and wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.  All right, is it generally pretty easy or kind of hard for you to decide in those situations?
R:Generally, it’s not so black and white, like with some of the more controversial issues going around that I mentioned before, that’s why I’ve talked to so many people about it, you know, I’m trying to find it, figure out what’s right and wrong and I see what other people have beliefs of, regarding, so it’s probably not so easy for me.  You know I have a lot to live, I’ve only seen a little bit of this world and so far, most of it has been contained in West Bend* for about 10 years.
I:Contained in West Bend*, yeah, yeah.  Gotcha.
R:Yeah, so, haven’t experienced a lot yet.  So I’m still probably gonna change some of my beliefs or opinions depending on the situation or what more I experience.
I:Okay, okay.  Do you think that deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or harder in these past two years?
R:Probably harder in the past two years, but that just comes along with being a teenager.  Because you’re starting to experience more life around you and you’re meeting all these new people that have different opinions than you, and so you have a lot more to take into consideration and you know, you feel lost in who you are, and stuff like that.
I:Okay.  So, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:That’s a tough question.  Well one of the easiest, but this doesn’t encompass them all, easiest place to determine if something is right or wrong, is if it hurts another person or it hurts yourself.  Another way to determine it would be, you know, ah, take the Bible into consideration, you know, what it says would be right or wrong.  Not so significant, is what other people think, you know.  You can always, just can, you can consolidate  on anybody on what they believe is right or wrong.  So that’s pretty much it, the church and other influences.
I:Okay.  So, so you said, one of those, one of the keys is to think about if it hurts you or hurts anybody else, and another key is looking at the Bible, what the Bible says, less important is, you know what other people might think.  How would you weigh or consider those first two parts of the, what’s right and wrong, together?
R:This gets complicated.  Because this is a question of underlying faith and the foundation of the church, you know, disagreeing with the church on some issues or not.  I guess it really depends on your interpretation of the Bible.  So that the Bible would be the most important.  But, ah, and then comes the, talking to other people.  So I would say, yeah, the Bible is probably more important.  Not necessarily the church.
I:Okay, okay.  Um, all right.  And so, when you say that the Bible is really important, um, what are you, when you look at something in the Bible, do you feel like, um, the guidance in there is literal or bad  there’s some cultural differences or how, how do you go in to interpreting the right and wrong decisions through the Bible, yourself?
R:Well there are a lot of little nuances in the scripture, but I do think there are cultural differences, and I do think that some things are meant literally and then some are meant figuratively, that are not to be taken literally.  I guess, but it really depends on your individual interpretation of the scripture and how it affects your life and that’s probably the best way to interpret it.
I:Okay.  Are there some interpretations that are better or worse?
R:This is also complicated.  Because I believe that some interpretations would be good for other people and not necessarily myself.  Um, an example would be, you know who, people who read the scripture and _______
I:I’m just ah, I’m trying to get a sense of how you would use the Bible to interpret what’s right and wrong?
R:Okay, like I said, I would read it, I would look for the little, the nuances in scripture.  I would look, what would make the most sense, probably, between the literal and the figurative, the figurative translations and interpretations.
I:Okay.  Are there any, any things that are always in themselves wrong, or not?
R:If by ___________   I just lost my train of thought again.
I:Oh, that’s okay, that’s okay.  I was just, I was trying to get at if there were some things that are in and of themselves wrong.
R:I would say yes.
I:You would say yes, okay.
R:There are some things that are just wrong, and they should probably be pretty easy to tell, whether they’re wrong or not.
I:Okay.   And, ah, I mean, what would--could you give me some examples, maybe?
R:Well, nothing good comes from jealousy and nothing good comes of greed, hate.  So those things are wrong because you know, they drive, drive the person to do things you normally wouldn’t.
I:Okay, all right.  From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Well, like I said, mostly from scripture and most of it is from church, but being a teenager now myself and being a little more intellectual than I was as a child, you know, I’ve started to critique and look at my own beliefs and the only reason I’ve kept them is because I still believe them.  You don’t even have to look _____________  and double check it.
I:Okay.  Do you feel like you’ve been looking into these views and ideas more in these past two years than you had before?
R:Yes.
I:Yes, a lot more?  I mean, has it really changed for you, is that something you did two years or more ago, as well?
R:Well, like I said, I just started talking a lot more to people about them and learning as much as I can.

My parents have always told me that I’ve had this innate sense of right and wrong, so I think I’m doing something— Yeah. So I’m still probably gonna change some of my beliefs or opinions depending on the situation or what more I experience. If by ___________   I just lost my train of thought again. I would say yes. There are some things that are just wrong, and they should probably be pretty easy to tell, whether they’re wrong or not. column588: The respondent primarily relies on their religious beliefs to determine right and wrong, acknowledges the influence of their parents and personal experiences, and expresses a desire to help others while recognizing the complexity of moral issues, particularly in light of social influences and changing perspectives.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Parents.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:It’s against the law.
I:Okay so if something’s illegal, it’s wrong?  But other than that?
R:Yeah.
I:It would be okay?  Um, how do you make a decision about how, how do you know or decide what is good or bad, or right or wrong in life?  Just based on what your Mom and Dad say, or do you?
R:Yeah.
I:Or are there other things?
R:No, just what my Mom and Dad say.
I:Can you maybe give me an example of something, where you’ve had to make a decision between something right and wrong and rely on what your Mom and Dad have said?
R:Get in a fight.
I:And you decided not to?
R:Mm-mm (yes).
I:Why, what was, what would be wrong with getting in a fight.
R:I’d get to spend it in grounded for a long time.
I:So you’d be in trouble at home and at school?
R:Mm-mm (yes).
I:Mm-mm.  And so do you think that that would be the only reason that it would be wrong is because of what would happen to ya?
R:Yeah.
I:Are there other reasons that it would be wrong?
R:No.
I:No?  So it would be okay to have a fight with somebody if you know you would be in trou—get in trouble?  Okay.  Why, why do you think that is?
R:Because.
I:Just because?
R:Yeah.
I:Cause why?
R:Ah,  if somebody really got too mad you really wanna punch them in the face but then if they told then you’d get in trouble.
column584: Parents. It’s against the law. Yeah. Yeah. No, just what my Mom and Dad say. Get in a fight. Mm-mm (yes). I’d get to spend it in grounded for a long time. Mm-mm (yes). Yeah. No. Because. Yeah. Ah,  if somebody really got too mad you really wanna punch them in the face but then if they told then you’d get in trouble.
column585: The respondent believes that their views of right and wrong primarily come from their parents, acknowledges that morality is subjective and influenced by personal desires, and feels guilty when failing to fulfill promises, but does not see cheating or lying to parents as wrong, viewing such actions as acceptable under certain circumstances.

column586:
I:Ok.  So how do you decide or know what is good or bad or right and wrong in life?
R:Just, like, well my parents have taught me a lot.  And then, in school we had to take, like, leaderships classes and they taught us a lot about morals and stuff.  So, just like, deciding whether it’s an ethical dilemma or a moral decision and, I think that, really, gives you a lot of good ways to figure out what you are feeling and how you think you should approach situations.
I:What kind of principals did you feel you learned there?
R:A lot about honor and just keeping your honor.  And, um, that was kind of our biggest thing, I guess.
I:In general, do you feel like it is easy or hard to make those decisions about what is right and wrong?
R:I think it’s pretty easy I guess, as long as you, but I think it’s more like how you feel about yourself and then how feel your decision will make a difference.
I:OK.  Do you think deciding between right and wrong have gotten easier or harder over the past couple of years?
R:I think kind of both.  Like, I think it’s harder because you are set up with more situations and you have to make them.  And I think it’s easier because you are more aware of right and wrong.
I:Ok.  So how, specifically, (interrupted by waitress)  Um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Probably consequences.  What it can do to effect you and what it can do to effect other people.
I:Um, so what kinds of consequences would make something wrong?
R:I guess if it would hurt someone else, or, going to potentially hurt you.
I:Ok.  Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves?
R:I don’t know.    I guess, like, illegal things are actions that are wrong.  I guess something said to be illegal it’s not my kind of values.
I:Is there any situation when something illegal, can you just do something illegal to help someone, or?  Or, do you then have to rethink it, or is it always whatever is illegal is wrong?
R:It’s hard to say like, what if.  Because everything can change.  But, I think it does at certain times though, you go thru certain, like, tests, to figure out…I don’t know, we always talked about like tests to figure out what happened, which was you should go, and it’s, like, I think you can figure out yourself whether it’s right or wrong.  So, even if it’s, like, potentially could be wrong, you yourself might need to do it for your conscience and stuff.
I:Uh hum.
R:And sometimes bad consequences can be under weighed by good consequences.
column587: Just, like, well my parents have taught me a lot.  And then, in school we had to take, like, leaderships classes and they taught us a lot about morals and stuff.  So, just like, deciding whether it’s an ethical dilemma or a moral decision and, I think that, really, gives you a lot of good ways to figure out what you are feeling and how you think you should approach situations. A lot about honor and just keeping your honor.  And, um, that was kind of our biggest thing, I guess. I think it’s pretty easy I guess, as long as you, but I think it’s more like how you feel about yourself and then how feel your decision will make a difference. I think kind of both.  Like, I think it’s harder because you are set up with more situations and you have to make them.  And I think it’s easier because you are more aware of right and wrong.  Probably consequences.  What it can do to effect you and what it can do to effect other people. I guess if it would hurt someone else, or, going to potentially hurt you. I don’t know.    I guess, like, illegal things are actions that are wrong.  I guess something said to be illegal it’s not my kind of values. It’s hard to say like, what if.  Because everything can change.  But, I think it does at certain times though, you go thru certain, like, tests, to figure out…I don’t know, we always talked about like tests to figure out what happened, which was you should go, and it’s, like, I think you can figure out yourself whether it’s right or wrong.  So, even if it’s, like, potentially could be wrong, you yourself might need to do it for your conscience and stuff. And sometimes bad consequences can be under weighed by good consequences.
column588: The respondent emphasizes the importance of parental guidance and moral education in shaping their understanding of right and wrong, believes that consequences play a crucial role in moral decision-making, and values personal integrity over relative morality, while also acknowledging the influence of societal changes on moral perspectives.
column589:
I:Okay.  And how do you normally decide what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I think I base a lot off instincts.  I think that I was brought up with a good idea of what was right and wrong, and if it was okay, which goes with my head and heart telling me.
I:So, in general, how easy or hard is it for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I don’t think it’s very hard.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder in the over the last few years?
R:I don’t think it’s really changed, so that took away from the good concept.
I:So, in general, how do you decide what’s right or wrong?  What’s the instinct based on?
R:It would be based on really just the kind of values that I’ve grown up with and the people I think I would refer people around me a lot to people with guidance, or to look at what they’re doing in similar situations.
I:What kinds of people do you turn to for guidance?
R:Normally I go to my friends, or my mom, or my brother.
I:And has there ever been a situation that you’ve needed to get their advice on, or get their guidance?
R:The last thing I went to get advice was I had to figure out what internship to take.  That’s not really a right or wrong.
I:Okay.  And, what would you say basically makes something right or wrong?  Is it a consequence, a feeling?
R:I think you’re happy what you get right.  I would go with a feeling or not.  You feel okay with it after it’s said and done, then it’s an okay decision.
I:Okay.  So, is there anything in the situation that before it’s over that tells you?
R:I don’t know.
I:No?  Okay.  How about, well if you were really stuck on trying to make a decision, what would be the deciding factor for you, like how it affects you, how it affects, maybe rules or laws, or consequences?
R:I don’t know.  I’m not very good at this like crises, like I would call the problem.  It just depends on circumstance, if it only affected then I’m in it, like how it affects me, it affects other people, lay out pros and cons and how does it affect me or other people, and then decide.  I would, I don’t know.
I:And from where do you think that you’ve acquired your views on morality?
R:From my friends and my family.
I:So, how does, cuz you mentioned that your mom is religious, and you know, goes to church and all that, so is that, have you acquired your views from there?  You mentioned that you thought you were maybe more like your dad in that respect.
R:I don’t know.  I think that, I don’t know.  I really don’t think that there is a legitimate claim to much into like, strict morality.  I don’t think that her being more religious has made her more moral, so I don’t think that’s really changed any of my values that I’ve taken from her.
column590: I think I base a lot off instincts.  I think that I was brought up with a good idea of what was right and wrong, and if it was okay, which goes with my head and heart telling me. I don’t think it’s very hard. I don’t think it’s really changed, so that took away from the good concept. It would be based on really just the kind of values that I’ve grown up with and the people I think I would refer people around me a lot to people with guidance, or to look at what they’re doing in similar situations. Normally I go to my friends, or my mom, or my brother. The last thing I went to get advice was I had to figure out what internship to take.  That’s not really a right or wrong.  I think you’re happy what you get right.  I would go with a feeling or not.  You feel okay with it after it’s said and done, then it’s an okay decision. I don’t know. I don’t know.  I’m not very good at this like crises, like I would call the problem.  It just depends on circumstance, if it only affected then I’m in it, like how it affects me, it affects other people, lay out pros and cons and how does it affect me or other people, and then decide.  I would, I don’t know.  From my friends and my family. I don’t know.  I think that, I don’t know.  I really don’t think that there is a legitimate claim to much into like, strict morality.  I don’t think that her being more religious has made her more moral, so I don’t think that’s really changed any of my values that I’ve taken from her.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on their upbringing and instincts to determine right and wrong, often seeking guidance from family and friends, while also acknowledging the influence of societal norms and expressing a belief that moral standards are subjective and can change over time.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Typically, I try to base it off of what would my dad think.  You just know if something is wrong.  I don’t know.  It’s just what my parents instilled in me, like, how you raise your kids is how they’re gonna be or whatever.
I:So you said you normally would, I mean, it’s your parents influence would be the main thing that you strive for, and for them, how did they figure out what’s right and wrong, like, what was their basis for them?
R:I guess how they were raised, too, which with the church and everything that gives you a good guidelines as to –
I:Okay.  And for you, is it generally easy or hard to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s not too hard at all.
I:Okay.  And has it become easier or harder over the last few years?
R:Not at all.
I:Like, is it the same or is it getting easier or getting harder?
R:Maybe it seems a little harder because I’m 20 or whatever, but I still can’t drink – that’s kind of weird, but –
I:Okay.  Right.  Do you think that will be a concern once you can drink –
R:No.
I:– whether you’re worried about it?
R:No.  I wouldn’t see myself in the bar.  I don’t have an addictive personality.  I can’t see myself hammered on a barstool, “Hey,”  or whatever.
I:Yeah.  Do think your right and wrong has changed in any way in the last few years?
R:Not really.  No.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think there would be personal views or value is.  How you feel on a situation.
I:Is it your feelings mainly or is it the results of the action or –
R:I think it is personal views, mainly in results of actions too because – I don’t know – those crazy serial killers that think what they’re doing is right, but obviously it’s not –
I:So how do you – what basis do you determine that?
R:I guess you have to go by if anybody is being physically abused or hurt or something is being taken away from them.  I guess that’s what’s wrong.
I:That’s absolutely wrong at all times?
R:I don’t know.  That’s a difficult question.
I:Okay.  Okay.  So you’re not sure what would be the basis for –
R:Well, I know personally with me, if my personal views, like, I’m not gonna want to kill someone, that’s wrong on –
I:But is it wrong for you or is just plain wrong and no one should do it even if someone thinks it’s right, it’s – they’re, you know, they’re mistaken?
R:I think it’s just plain wrong because, I mean, even if someone is on death row or something, I don’t think we have the right to kill them.
I:Okay.
R:I mean, I don’t know.
I:But why – do you have any reason for why that’s wrong or –
R:It kind of puts us in the same – it doesn’t make us any better than them.
I:Okay.
R:And they say that God’s the only one who can really just judge you or justify what goes on, but yeah, I just think we don’t have the right to take someone’s life –
I:Okay.
R:– especially even if they killed someone.  I mean, that doesn’t make us any better than them.  It kind of lowers us down to their standards.
I:Would you say it’s God’s – the final – has the final word on what’s right and wrong or do you think it’s simply your culture or –
R:For me, I think God does, but obviously other cultures believe in other things.
I:Right, but you can disagree with them and think they’re mistaken if some cultures want to kill people or –
R:Yeah.  I would just think that – I guess with ethics they would think that that would be wrong, but I guess you can’t really judge them.  I don’t know.  That’s just like cannibalism.  I don’t know why somebody would want to do that or anything, but I don’t know.   or whatever, that’s what they believed in, but I guess it would be an honored sacrifice back then, but I don’t know.
I:Would you say that that’s wrong or would you say that –
R:Now, if that was to happen in today’s standards I guess you could, but I don’t know, it’s difficult.
I:Where do you think you’ve acquired your moral views from?  Is it mainly your parents or are there other things that influenced how you think about this?
R:Mainly my parents and probably from what sermons have been taught, like, when I’d go to church.
I:Okay.
R:Yeah.
column590: Typically, I try to base it off of what would my dad think.  You just know if something is wrong.  I don’t know.  It’s just what my parents instilled in me, like, how you raise your kids is how they’re gonna be or whatever. I guess how they were raised, too, which with the church and everything that gives you a good guidelines as to – It’s not too hard at all. Not at all. Maybe it seems a little harder because I’m 20 or whatever, but I still can’t drink – that’s kind of weird, but – No. No.  I wouldn’t see myself in the bar.  I don’t have an addictive personality.  I can’t see myself hammered on a barstool, “Hey,”  or whatever. Not really.  No.  I think there would be personal views or value is.  How you feel on a situation. I think it is personal views, mainly in results of actions too because – I don’t know – those crazy serial killers that think what they’re doing is right, but obviously it’s not – I guess you have to go by if anybody is being physically abused or hurt or something is being taken away from them.  I guess that’s what’s wrong. I don’t know.  That’s a difficult question. Well, I know personally with me, if my personal views, like, I’m not gonna want to kill someone, that’s wrong on – I think it’s just plain wrong because, I mean, even if someone is on death row or something, I don’t think we have the right to kill them. I mean, I don’t know. It kind of puts us in the same – it doesn’t make us any better than them. And they say that God’s the only one who can really just judge you or justify what goes on, but yeah, I just think we don’t have the right to take someone’s life – – especially even if they killed someone.  I mean, that doesn’t make us any better than them.  It kind of lowers us down to their standards. For me, I think God does, but obviously other cultures believe in other things. Yeah. Yeah.
column591: The respondent primarily bases their moral decisions on the influence of their parents and their upbringing in the church, believing that actions are right or wrong based on personal views and the consequences of those actions, while also emphasizing the importance of accountability to God for one's choices.

column583:
I:Okay.  So what makes something right, what makes something wrong?
R:Right is positive, like if you do something positive, and wrong is negative.  Like if you do something negative, like you know you would regret.
I:That you know what you would regret.  Ah, okay, so where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:What do you mean, what do you mean by that?

R:My mind.
I:Your mind?  So what, I mean, your mind just tells you what’s right and what’s wrong, or?
R:And I, I should know what’s right and wrong, too.
I:Why?
R:Cause um, I did some wrong and I did some  right, but you know, everybody know what, what wrong or right is.

I:Yeah.  How do you decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong?
R:Um, how do I decide?

I:You’d rather not discuss.
R:Yeah.  I’ll keep that personal.

My mind. And I, I should know what’s right and wrong, too. Cause um, I did some wrong and I did some  right, but you know, everybody know what, what wrong or right is. Could you say that again? column585: The respondent makes decisions based on whether an action would be helpful or cause trouble, believes that right and wrong are clear concepts derived from personal experience and societal observations, feels pressured by peers at times, and seeks forgiveness from God for wrongdoings, while also expressing a desire to avoid actions that could jeopardize their future aspirations, such as becoming an NBA player.
column586:
I:All right.  And how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:How I decide?
I:Yeah.
R:Well I look at it from different angles, because maybe some people don’t treat, we have different points of view.  I say, they say trouble you usually get into hard to get out, but not me, my life ain’t based on trouble, I don’t look for trouble.  I may hang with the wrong crowd at times, you know, do little teenager things but you know, I know how far to go, I know my limit.
I:Okay.  And then in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide what’s right and wrong?
R:Easy.  I make my own decisions.
I:And what do you base your decisions on, now?
R:By what my Mom would think and what would my Dad think, that’s why, I try to put a positive to it, you know what I mean, trying to overdo it
I:Okay, all right and over the past two years, has it gotten easier for you to make the right decisions or has it gotten more difficult to make the right decisions?
R:It got more, it became more difficult, I mean, you know, just different times, you know what I mean, you know, everywhere you look you see bad.  You see trouble.  So you know I try to avoid it, in every way I can.  ________________
I:Okay.  And what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:The action.  Your action.  If you, you choose to do the right thing, that’d be the best thing.  When you choose to do the wrong thing, you know you could do the right thing and avoid that, and not the, you know, that’s wrong.
I:But what makes it wrong or right?
R:What makes it wrong?  I don’t really understand.
I:Yeah, well like is it, is it because something is against the rules or the law or is it because there’s some consequences?
R:Oh, yeah, yeah, because, yeah.
I:Or is it because of um, something that they, someone tells you what’s right and wrong, or?
R:Oh yeah.  Well, really you know, the law, you know the law real bad  I mean you got to think about it, you do a crime, you got to do the time.  I mean, you got to think about it before you do it, you know what I mean.  Don’t think too hard, either, because you might end up doing it and you might not like the consequences but it always, consequences behind everything you do.
I:All right.  And are there any actions, um, that are always right or wrong in themselves, is there anything that you can think of that’s always wrong?
R:Selling drugs.  That’s always wrong because you hurting people.  That’s always wrong.
I:Okay.  And from where have you got your moral views from?
R:Well, I list--.
I:Who, so who are these people that you listen to?  Friends, relatives or, just people in the community?
R:Well, a lot, relatives, friends, baseball players, that I play baseball with.  You know.
I:Okay.
R:Different types of people.

column588: The respondent makes decisions based on the influence of their parents' opinions, prioritizing education and family, while also considering the consequences of their actions, such as avoiding trouble to maintain good grades, and believes that some actions, like selling drugs, are always wrong.

column583:
I:Okay.  Um, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Ah.  A lot of them I’ve developed from myself, just observing people and saying, okay what are the consequences of what he’s doing and I figure out, you know, I see if the consequences are worth it to me and that’s how I go with, and my parents have told me all of the, all of the basic right and wrong, do this, don’t do that.
I:Like what kinds of things?
R:Like,  just don’t go out and stab yourself in the arm with a fork or something
I:Okay
R:Something like that, um, ah.
I:Did they talk to you about drugs and things like that, or not.
R:Ah, when it comes to drugs I think they knew that I could make the decisions for myself, I’m a smart kid.
I:Okay.  Um, why do you think there are, there is such, why, you said that there’s um, that there is a right and wrong in situations.  Why, why do you think that?
R:Ah, I don’t know, there’s just a basic nature to everything and there’s a, um,  right and wrong um, oh man, how do I put this? Ah,  just, at the very like core of everything, I mean, everything, like once when I was bad like when it’s not a, as a serious, as serious of a thing as like  ah, it’s just different, I think, man it’s, it’s kind of a weird thing, it’s, I think it’s just different degrees of seriousness, um, determine right and wrong.  If that makes sense, I don’t know.
I:Okay, can you give me an example of like things, things with different degrees of seriousness?
R:Um, like,  like if you like raped a girl or if you like I don’t know, took like a candy bar or something from the store or something.  If you rape a girl, it’s like  there, there’s nothing good about that, there’s, the girl doesn’t come out very well and the, the guy is, obviously out there, but I mean, if you like took a candy bar or something because you were like, really hungry or something, as opposed to like just taking it, just to take it, that’s wrong, but like if you’re like hungry, that wouldn’t, I don’t think a wrong thing.  But it, it depends on who you are, too, just how you think.
I:Like what, what, do you mean it depends on who you are, what does that mean?
R:Um, how you were brought up and stuff like that.  What, what your parents taught you was right and wrong, what your different experiences throughout your life were.
I:Okay, um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Ah,  I really, I don’t know, it’s just a, an automatic thought in your head.
I:Okay.
R:It clicks.  It either clicks or it doesn’t click in your head, what’s right and wrong.

Everyone deserves to have basic normal thought and things like that. Ah,  I really, I don’t know, it’s just a, an automatic thought in your head. It clicks.  It either clicks or it doesn’t click in your head, what’s right and wrong. Um, for some things with some people it just doesn’t click, some people think, why is this wrong?  Why? column585: The respondent often feels unsure about right and wrong in relationships, particularly with girls, and tends to rely on intuition and personal experiences to make decisions, while also acknowledging the influence of parents on his understanding of morality and observing the consequences of actions in others.

column583:
I:What do you think makes things right or wrong?
R:Depending on how, like, I don’t know.  Cause, I mean, it’s just as an example, robbing a bank would be wrong.
I:Why would that be wrong?
R:Well, it’s taking people’s money, I mean, they’re breaking the law, and they’re, unless they’re concealed weapons, pointing at people, if that’s how they do it, I mean, threatening--
I:So what’s wrong about that?  I’m not saying it’s right, I’m just wanting to know what’s wrong about it?
R:Threatening, threatening people and stealing, taking something that’s not yours.
I:So stealing is wrong?  What makes stealing wrong?
R:Cause it’s not theirs to begin with, it’s someone else’s.
I:So what?
R:It’s wrong!
I:Okay.  Where do your own views of right and wrong come from, I mean, what do you think most influences your views about morality?
R:I don’t know, I guess it’s just how I was brought up.
I:So, your parents?
R:I guess, yeah.  Cause they’ve told me what’s right and what’s wrong, what I should do, what I shouldn’t do, and so I guess I’ve based it on that and that I don’t--
I:Are you much influenced by what your friends say or do they all agree with what you think?
R:Sometimes, I mean, I’ll ask, I’ll say well what are you gonna do, like, if we’re doing a certain thing in homework or we’re doing a report, I’ll ask them what they’re gonna do theirs on and sometimes I’m like, well, that’s a good idea and I’ll do what they do, I’ll do my report like on something like them, I get influenced by what they’re doing, but I mean--
I:Do you think that’s okay, or does that bother you?
R:I don’t know, I think it bothers me, like I can’t, I always have to ask somebody else what they’re going to do so I’ll know what I wanna do, it’s like, why don’t I know what I wanna do?  It’s like I have to have somebody else’s opinion before I know what I wanna do.
I:Why do you think that’s the case?
R:Do I think it’s okay?
I:Why do you think that’s the case, sorry, I got food in my mouth.
R:I don’t know, I guess I’m not, I guess I think I won’t make the right decision, and then I wanna have somebody else’s opinion so maybe they might, there’ll be somebody else in that situation with me, if it’s not the right decision, I guess, I don’t know.
I:How much of how you’ve been raised about morality would you say is based in your religion, or not?
R:What was the question?
I:How much, if any, of how you were raised, about what’s right and wrong, comes from your religious background, or doesn’t it, really?
R:I don’t know.  I really don’t know.
I:You’re not sure about that.
R:I’m not sure.
I:Did you, growing up, go to Sunday School?
R:Yes, I went to church a lot when I was little, well at one point we didn’t, and then when I was little my Mom got us into going and I’ve been going ever since, I can’t remember an exact age, but…
I:Okay.  So, you never you don’t, it sounds like, correct me if I’m wrong, you don’t get in situations where you don’t know what you’re going to do, or if it’s good or bad, you pretty much know what you should do, or not?
R:Sometimes, like when I went on my mission trip this summer, or last summer, I really didn’t know if I wanted to do it or not, or, if I should do it, or, that was a real big decision because I wasn’t really sure what to do.  And I don’t like it when I don’t know what to do, it scares you.
column584: Depending on how, like, I don’t know.  Cause, I mean, it’s just as an example, robbing a bank would be wrong. Well, it’s taking people’s money, I mean, they’re breaking the law, and they’re, unless they’re concealed weapons, pointing at people, if that’s how they do it, I mean, threatening-- Threatening, threatening people and stealing, taking something that’s not yours. Cause it’s not theirs to begin with, it’s someone else’s. It’s wrong! I don’t know, I guess it’s just how I was brought up. I guess, yeah.  Cause they’ve told me what’s right and what’s wrong, what I should do, what I shouldn’t do, and so I guess I’ve based it on that and that I don’t-- Sometimes, I mean, I’ll ask, I’ll say well what are you gonna do, like, if we’re doing a certain thing in homework or we’re doing a report, I’ll ask them what they’re gonna do theirs on and sometimes I’m like, well, that’s a good idea and I’ll do what they do, I’ll do my report like on something like them, I get influenced by what they’re doing, but I mean-- I don’t know, I think it bothers me, like I can’t, I always have to ask somebody else what they’re going to do so I’ll know what I wanna do, it’s like, why don’t I know what I wanna do?  It’s like I have to have somebody else’s opinion before I know what I wanna do. Do I think it’s okay? I don’t know, I guess I’m not, I guess I think I won’t make the right decision, and then I wanna have somebody else’s opinion so maybe they might, there’ll be somebody else in that situation with me, if it’s not the right decision, I guess, I don’t know. What was the question? I don’t know.  I really don’t know. I’m not sure. Yes, I went to church a lot when I was little, well at one point we didn’t, and then when I was little my Mom got us into going and I’ve been going ever since, I can’t remember an exact age, but… Sometimes, like when I went on my mission trip this summer, or last summer, I really didn’t know if I wanted to do it or not, or, if I should do it, or, that was a real big decision because I wasn’t really sure what to do.  And I don’t like it when I don’t know what to do, it scares you.
column585: The respondent generally feels confident in their understanding of right and wrong, attributing their moral views primarily to their upbringing by their parents, while acknowledging some influence from friends, and expressing discomfort when unsure about decisions, particularly regarding a significant choice like going on a mission trip.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t know I guess it’s based on how I was raised, what my mom and dad taught me what was right and wrong.  I guess you get that instinct, you know what’s right or wrong, so.
I:And do you think that it’s easy or hard for you to decide those things, like what is right and wrong?
R:Sometimes I think it’s hard because it’s something that I would like to do for myself, but- but then I think of how my mom would feel about something that I do and I know she wouldn’t like it.  Like, do you want me to give an example?
I:Yeah, that would be great.
R:Spending the night at my boyfriend’s house.  It’s something that I want to do but she doesn’t really want me to do but I do it anyway.  So.
I:So you make that decision based on?
R:What I want.
I:Your personal feeling about it?
R:Yeah, and I feel bad, but can we eat while we’re doing this?
I:Oh, yeah definitely, I'm eating.
R:Be crunching in the microphone.
I:And do you feel that as you get older the deciding between right and wrong gets easier or harder?
R:I’d say it’s gotten easier, kind of, yeah.
I:Any reason?
R:Wow, how do I give a reason for that?  No, I guess not, no reason.
I:Like compared to when you were eighteen and were trying to make decisions?
R:Yeah, exactly, compared to when I was a teenager, I’d ask my mom to help me make decisions but now I'm twenty-two so I can, I'm an adult so I can do it myself.  Sorry, you got the answer flowing until I figured out what to say.
I:Okay, and then what do you think that it is that makes something a right or a wrong thing?
R:I guess how it would make you feel after you do it.
I:So like feelings-
R:If you lie about something you’re going to feel bad after you do it, yeah how you’re going to feel, exactly.

No, I guess not, no reason. Yeah, exactly, compared to when I was a teenager, I’d ask my mom to help me make decisions but now I'm twenty-two so I can, I'm an adult so I can do it myself.  Sorry, you got the answer flowing until I figured out what to say.  I guess how it would make you feel after you do it. If you lie about something you’re going to feel bad after you do it, yeah how you’re going to feel, exactly.
column591: The respondent primarily bases their decisions on their upbringing and parental guidance regarding right and wrong, while also considering their personal desires, as seen in their struggle between wanting to please their mother and their own wishes, and they acknowledge social influences from friends that can lead them to make choices contrary to their better judgment.

column589:
I:How do you say you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:The feeling I get. Or you can just… sometimes you can do something you know is bad and with no doubt in your mind it’s just bad, that should be the one. But you just what feels good…
I:Is it generally easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Sometimes. Like for example, I…was it wrong for me to tell that person, you know, how rude they are or something like that or should I just keep it in or stuff like that? Was it right? Was I wrong? Should I just leave it alone?
I:So those are situation in which you weren’t sure but generally is it easy or hard for you to decide? Do you feel like you pretty much know what’s right and wrong most of the time?
R:Same with me not being able to bite my tongue. I said sometimes would be wrong but sometimes it just happened so fast and I’m like, dang! I really feel bad about that. I think it was wrong for me to do that.
I:All right, and deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past couple of years?
R:Over the past couple of years had gotten harder because like, the older you are the more findings you have to deal with, and so when you’re younger it doesn’t really just… your parents just usually take up, you know, whatever is or is not right or wrong is just usually, if I take this pen, that’s wrong, you know and that’s the only thing, when we was younger that’s what you had to deal with, now you have to deal with bigger things.
I:Now, would you say your moral views have changed in the past couple of years?
R:My what?
I:Your moral views?
R:No, not really.
I:Fair enough. Now, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:That makes something right or wrong?
I:Right.  You had mentioned before that, you know, it’s the feeling you get… like what did you mean by that?
R:You just get this… you know,  like if you do something right, you’re going to get this good feeling; you know what I’m saying? About what you did, but if you’re doing something wrong, you won’t … you’re going to get a bad feeling. You’re going to go like, “this is not right” you know, and it’s going to be a conscience that’s going to eat in at you when you do something wrong.
I:So you feel like those feelings come from your conscience?
R:Yeah. My parents probably. My grandma.
column590: The feeling I get. Or you can just… sometimes you can do something you know is bad and with no doubt in your mind it’s just bad, that should be the one. But you just what feels good… Sometimes. Like for example, I…was it wrong for me to tell that person, you know, how rude they are or something like that or should I just keep it in or stuff like that? Was it right? Was I wrong? Should I just leave it alone? Same with me not being able to bite my tongue. I said sometimes would be wrong but sometimes it just happened so fast and I’m like, dang! I really feel bad about that. I think it was wrong for me to do that. Over the past couple of years had gotten harder because like, the older you are the more findings you have to deal with, and so when you’re younger it doesn’t really just… your parents just usually take up, you know, whatever is or is not right or wrong is just usually, if I take this pen, that’s wrong, you know and that’s the only thing, when we was younger that’s what you had to deal with, now you have to deal with bigger things. My what? No, not really.  That makes something right or wrong? You just get this… you know,  like if you do something right, you’re going to get this good feeling; you know what I’m saying? About what you did, but if you’re doing something wrong, you won’t … you’re going to get a bad feeling. You’re going to go like, “this is not right” you know, and it’s going to be a conscience that’s going to eat in at you when you do something wrong. Yeah.  My parents probably. My grandma.
column591: The respondent expresses a desire to leave their small town for a fresh start, relies on feelings and intuition to determine right from wrong, acknowledges the influence of their parents on their moral views, and believes in seeking advice from trusted adults when unsure about decisions.

column583:
I:Okay.  Um, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, let’s see.  My parents, kind of.  And kind of my own morals.
I:And do you um, do you think of like what makes something right or wrong, if you had a kind of moral code, could you define that or you know, just curious about that.
R:Well, I mean, it, it kind of comes like naturally though, really.  Like I mean, like I don’t know how to explain it, it just kind of ah, like you just know somehow, like that’s not cool or you know.  I don’t really know how to explain it I guess people wouldn’t admire that as a good trait, you know, think if an adult saw you do that, or I mean, it grows with like maturity, though.

column585: The respondent reflects on a past incident involving vandalism where they faced a moral dilemma about loyalty to a friend versus potential consequences from the police, ultimately deciding to apologize for their actions, while attributing their sense of right and wrong to parental influence and personal morals, and expressing a belief that moral decisions often depend on individual intentions rather than absolute standards.
column589:
I:Well in this life, how would you decide what’s good and bad, right and wrong in life?  I mean, in general, how do you figure that out?
R:I think about it as if someone themselves gets hurt, if one individual is hurt themselves, it’s kinda hard to think about it.
I:I mean, your own decisions every day, like when you want to figure out what’s right and wrong, how do you, what do you base that on?
R:I’ve had friends who’ve told me a lot of things about like, oh well they’ve gone into store and put things in their pockets and don’t care- and I just kind of laugh at that and go like “Hah, well I don’t care either ‘cause Target* or so and so’s a big corporation, they have money.”  Whereas if you were stealing from me or my neighbor who doesn’t have that much money, then you’re kind of hurting them more, whereas you just steal a DVD from Wal-Mart, they got 10 of the DVDs.  They’re not gonna be really hurting.  They have like a lawyers and things like that, funds that will cover them for these kind of situations.  So it’s like, yeah my friend told me “Yeah I stole a DVD” it’s like I laugh and go “I don’t care.  That’s cool.”  You know, it’s not that cool, but it’s funny ‘cause your putting something that I don’t care about, whereas people as individual, I would never want to steal, or hurt someone as an individual I feel like they’re more vulnerable as one person.  Whereas like a corporation like a gas station or something is not one person, even though in reality, in essence it is.  It’s probably like a family owned business or whatever, eventually it’ll trickle down to one person or a few CEOs or shareholders or whatever, but I think of it in terms of if it’s hurting one individual it’s wrong.  If it’s not hurting an individual, it’s not really wrong.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to figure out what’s right and wrong and has that changed over the last few year-?
R:I would say yes, it is.  And yes that has changed over the past few years.  Yes it has gotten easier to distinguish what’s right and wrong in my own mind.  But I also think that one has to acquire those thoughts throughout a series of significant experiences in life, and that right and wrong, there’s not an exact information.  If that is in one mind what is right and wrong and one should decide for themselves what is right and wrong and how to live their lives.  I feel.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right and wrong?  Like what’s, why is something right?  Why is something wrong?
R:Well I, could easily put it, something right would be, someone’s benefiting then it seems to be right.
I:So like consequences?  Good consequences for people?
R:If there’s more for the bad then obviously it’s not a good thing.  If there’s more consequences that are good and that do benefit people then yeah it’s probably a better thing and it probably leans more towards the better things of the spectrum than the, then the more than wrong you know, probably it’s more better, you know, obviously, if people are dying and getting hurt, it’s probably not a good thing, ever, in any situation.  I look at things like war as a complete waste of time and money.  Why go over to Iraq and Afghanistan and kill these innocent kids when they’re just trying to live a life like we are?  In fact, they’re more in a hardship than we are, you know, they have a harder time just ‘cause they’re economy is in more of a stronghold than we are, we’re more open and we have all this money, whereas people over there, they’re no different than I am just ‘cause their skin is a little darker doesn’t mean they think different than I do.  You know, thinking like that has basically opened my mind up to what is right and what’s wrong and how do people benefit and could they not benefit, could they suffer because of this.  So, you know, I feel like people like our President George Bush probably doesn’t think about that and maybe has a different idea of what I do of what’s right and wrong.
I:Where do you get your ideas of right and wrong from?  Like what influences your thinking?
R:Basically, I would have to say my parents and what they’ve taught me.  Some things, like speeding, things like that, I’ve kinda just formed my own brain into thinking well I’m doing it so it’s probably wrong but I don’t really care because I’m getting to work quicker and no one’s necessarily being hurt by me speeding, so is it wrong?  Well illegal, the government says it’s wrong, but in my mind I don’t believe because I’m getting to work faster.  Yes, it’s dangering, endangering the life of me and others at the same time but who’s benefiting?  I’m benefiting and who’s not benefiting, or should I say, what’s the opposite of benefit?  To lose?
I:Sure.
R:Yeah, no one’s losing by me speeding, but if I do get in an accident, that’s when someone is losing and it’ll probably be me and them.  So I don’t think of it as a right or wrong, but I think, after all those years, all the speeding without thinking about it, has just formed that thought in my mind, just naturally of growing up and thinking it might be wrong but I don’t want to put to much thought into it because I’m going to be late to work if I do.  So it’s like, I don’t really care if it’s wrong.  I gotta get to work on time, you know, so be it.  Just things like that.

I’ve had friends who’ve told me a lot of things about like, oh well they’ve gone into store and put things in their pockets and don’t care- and I just kind of laugh at that and go like “Hah, well I don’t care either ‘cause Target* or so and so’s a big corporation, they have money.”  Whereas if you were stealing from me or my neighbor who doesn’t have that much money, then you’re kind of hurting them more, whereas you just steal a DVD from Wal-Mart, they got 10 of the DVDs. column591: The respondent reflects on decision-making by emphasizing the importance of considering the feelings and wishes of deceased loved ones, the impact of social influences such as parental teachings, and the moral implications of actions, ultimately believing that right and wrong are determined by the consequences for individuals rather than corporations.

column583:
I:Okay.  Um, so what do you think makes something right or wrong?
R:Like, like robbing a bank, that’s just, that’s just wrong, but somebody, in their eyes, that they’d be right, they, but they need it or something like that, but there is other ways of coming by money like that, I guess.
I:So why did you say robbing a bank is right or wrong?  You, well why did you say it was wrong, why, why in your eyes is it wrong?
R:Cause like all the people in the banks, they work, all the people that put money in the bank, they work for what they, what they have and it’s just not fair for them to do all that kind of, do work and work hard for their money and then somebody just come and take it, who just, who doesn’t want to do anything.
I:Okay so, you’re saying though that there are some who may not see that as wrong, but that’s okay for them?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.  Um, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?  How do you come to that decision?
R:I just think, I just like play it in my mind, if I do this, what would happen, if I don’t do this, what’s gonna happen, I guess that’s how I face things like that.
I:So the consequences is what, what makes it right and wrong in your eyes?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay anything else you use to discern if something is right or wrong?
R:Mm-mm, that’s pretty much it.
column584: Like, like robbing a bank, that’s just, that’s just wrong, but somebody, in their eyes, that they’d be right, they, but they need it or something like that, but there is other ways of coming by money like that, I guess. Cause like all the people in the banks, they work, all the people that put money in the bank, they work for what they, what they have and it’s just not fair for them to do all that kind of, do work and work hard for their money and then somebody just come and take it, who just, who doesn’t want to do anything. Yeah. I just think, I just like play it in my mind, if I do this, what would happen, if I don’t do this, what’s gonna happen, I guess that’s how I face things like that. Yeah. Mm-mm, that’s pretty much it.
column585: The respondent has always had a clear sense of right and wrong, believes that many people today have lost this understanding due to poor choices and lack of education, and relies on considering the consequences of actions to make decisions, while also feeling guilty about gossiping and adhering to their mother's expectations regarding behavior and discipline.
column586:
I:So overall, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:How good, could you repeat the question?
I:Oh it was just asking in general how do you decide what’s good or bad or right or wrong?
R:I guess from past experiences as far as uh, places I go, uh, I mean I go to a club that’s generally a lot of fighting or run into other people, I generally not go to that one.  Uh, I make, I guess I make pretty good decisions.  Sometimes I don’t.  It depends on what the situation is, I make it for I guess.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I mean if it’s, is it right for me not to do it, I mean if it’s wrong, I make that decision, but it’s easy for me to make a right decision if I know that it’s right.  If I, if it’s wrong, it’d probably be easier for me not to do, I mean it just depends on what it is.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Oh, yeah, now I’ve figured out what things, are right and wrong, it’s more easy for me to figure out, when I was younger, maybe 12, 13, I used, I probably made bad decisions, well not the right ones.  But now I make pretty good decisions on what I do.  What I do.
I:And why do you think it’s become easier to make the right decision?
R:Uh, probably my maturity, I’m mature, understanding stuff, the consequences, I would say.  Here’s the consequences and what could happen and what won’t happen.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um probably what happens, uh, hm, can you repeat the question?
I:Yeah, just what is it in your mind that makes some thing right or wrong?
R:It’s something, if I do something right and something good happens, okay then I must have made the right decision.  But if I did something bad and something bad happens, it must have made the wrong decision.  That’s how I look at it.
I:What kinds of consequences would make something wrong?
R:Uh, say I go somewhere I wasn’t supposed to and somebody sees me and they tell somebody like my mom and she finds out, then that’s probably bad, that’s something bad like that.  Or uh, if I study for a test and get a B or A on it, I must have done something, I must have made the right decision.
I:Are there any actions that are always right or always wrong?
R:Um, not really, well what do you mean by that?
I:Can you think of something that you know is always wrong to do.
R:Is always wrong?
I:Uh-huh
R:Probably would be drinking and driving, that’s mainly, I mean there’s nothing wrong with drinking, but driving, driving there would be something wrong with all the time.
I:And what do you think makes that wrong all the time?
R:Uh, it’s a rule I thought.  It’s a rule that you’re not supposed to drink and drive, so you’re breaking a rule.  I guess that’s wrong.  I’d say that’s wrong.
I:Okay.  And uh, where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Where?
I:Yeah, where do you get them from?  I mean uh,
R:Um, my mother, uh, like from things they always used to tell you, like don’t drink and drive and stuff like that, uh, I know DARE was one, dare not do drugs and stuff like that, so I just stay away from drugs and stuff like that.

column588: The respondent would use a hypothetical inheritance of $100,000 to pay off family bills and personal expenses, reflecting a sense of responsibility towards their mother, while their moral decision-making has improved with maturity, influenced by past experiences and parental guidance, emphasizing the importance of honesty and the consequences of actions.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Pretty much my decision-making is pretty good so I just, if it feels wrong or I know it’s wrong I pretty much try to stay away from it and don’t do it.
I:So it’s something you feel or just know?
R:Pretty much both. If I know something’s right, if I know drinking, you shouldn’t drink, that’s wrong.
I:How would you know that?  How do you know that?
R:Just my upbringing I guess, you know, always grew up someone told me you don’t need to smoke; smoking’s not good for you.  And growing up you see all the ads about smoking and what is does to your body, on top of the things that you already do.  So that would make it even worse.
I:And how hard or easy is it for you to know what’s wrong and right?
R:It’s pretty much easy.  I mean pretty much some of the things I do is repetitious so pretty much the same thing.  So anything out of the ordinary I can recognize I shouldn’t be doing this and search for another way
I:So you kind get in a good routine.
R:yeah.
I:And have your moral views changed at all in the last couple years?
R:No, I wouldn’t say that. Yeah.
I:What is it that makes them that way?
R:That depends on the person.  I may feel that something’s wrong or right that you may not feel that it’s wrong or right.  Inside a person, through the situation.
I:But if it really comes down to how people feel about it, then really there are really no rights or wrongs, it’s just people’s feelings.
R:Well…
I:Like for example.  If I was a twisted person and I enjoyed hurting other people, I would feel like it’s a good thing, I want to do it, there’s nothing wrong with it, but I really think- my real self is, No that would be wrong.  There would be something wrong with me.  And even if I felt it was okay, I would be wrong.  So what is it that makes something objectively right or wrong and not just how people feel about it?
R:I guess.  Um.  That’s tough.
I:Do you know what I’m saying?
R:I know what you’re saying.  But…I guess, um.  I guess.  I don’t know.
I:Okay, so you said you know partly from how you were raised.  When you were brought up, what was explained to you about here’s why things are right or wrong?
R:Okay.  Pretty much what boils down for me was not having sex until you’re married.  You’re not supposed to do it, in the Bible. That’s one of the things that was told to me, it was constantly told to me, so.
I:So something being from the Bible.  That would partly makes something right or wrong?
R:Yeah, for me it would.
I:Do you believe that? If it’s in the Bible that helps to define right or wrong?
R:Yeah.  And, that’s tough.
I:Like why is stealing wrong?
R:Because it’s not yours.
I:So what? I could make it mine.
R:Well, I mean that’s how I feel.  If it’s not mine I shouldn’t take it.
I:But is there anything other than your feelings about it that make it wrong.
R:I mean, similarly, if you steal something there’s going to be a consequence.  If you don’t want to face that consequence, you shouldn’t have stole it.  There’s always a cause and effect.  So if you do something it’s going to be a reaction to it.
I:What if a society decided, well stealing’s not really wrong so we should stop punishing each other for it.  Survival of the fittest.  Whoever gets away with the most, that’s what they get away with.
R:Then we might have a world of chaos.  A lot of chaos then.
I:Okay.
R:If people think it’s okay to steal.
I:Uh huh.  So partly you’re saying right or wrong is defined by the Bible, and partly it’s defined by potentially the law or consequences.
R:And just by, I guess the society as a whole.  Like what people view as, that’s not right.
I:Uh huh.  Society’s view.
R:Right. Sometimes how I look at it, some people twist it in a way that they, it may not be, they put it in their favor.
I:But sometimes society as a whole is totally wrong.  In this country with slavery, in the ‘30s with the Nazis.  I mean the Germans in the ‘30s just thought we just exterminate Jews.  Now we look back and say that was wrong.
R:Sooner or later, you know maybe fifty something is different.  Maybe it still won’t be okay here.
I:But do you think there are things no matter what people think about them, one way or the other it’s just right or wrong.  It’s just the way it is.  Like murder, stealing, adultery, whatever like that.
R:I mean, probably not.  I mean, I don’t know.  If you think about murder, some people maybe could have reason to murder somebody.  You know, there’s always a reason when you do something.

If I know something’s right, if I know drinking, you shouldn’t drink, that’s wrong. Just my upbringing I guess, you know, always grew up someone told me you don’t need to smoke; smoking’s not good for you.  And growing up you see all the ads about smoking and what is does to your body, on top of the things that you already do.  So that would make it even worse. It’s pretty much easy. Well… I guess.  Um.  That’s tough. I know what you’re saying.  But…I guess, um.  I guess.  I don’t know. Yeah, for me it would. Yeah.  And, that’s tough. Because it’s not yours. Well, I mean that’s how I feel.  If it’s not mine I shouldn’t take it. I mean, similarly, if you steal something there’s going to be a consequence.  If you don’t want to face that consequence, you shouldn’t have stole it.  There’s always a cause and effect.  So if you do something it’s going to be a reaction to it. Then we might have a world of chaos.  A lot of chaos then. If people think it’s okay to steal. And just by, I guess the society as a whole.  Like what people view as, that’s not right. Right. Sometimes how I look at it, some people twist it in a way that they, it may not be, they put it in their favor. Sooner or later, you know maybe fifty something is different.  Maybe it still won’t be okay here. I mean, probably not.  I mean, I don’t know.  If you think about murder, some people maybe could have reason to murder somebody.  You know, there’s always a reason when you do something.  Okay.  Pretty much what boils down for me was not having sex until you’re married.  You’re not supposed to do it, in the Bible. That’s one of the things that was told to me, it was constantly told to me, so. Yeah, for me it would. Yeah.  And, that’s tough.
column591: The respondent makes decisions based on a combination of intuition and upbringing, feeling a moral obligation to avoid wrongdoing influenced by their mother's guidance and biblical teachings, while also recognizing the consequences of their actions and the importance of seeking advice from respected figures.

column583:
I:Okay.  Where do your, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Probably from my parents and from church and from the community also that we lived in or I grew up in.
I:M11:So is hurting other people the definition of making something morally M11:wrong?
R:M11:No.  Making something morally wrong is something that like your M11:personal convictions, um, something that well, I wouldn’t say society has M11:said is wrong, there’s a lot of stuff society says now isn’t exactly M11:considered,
I:M11:So what if it’s not against my personal convictions to,
R:M11:Drink alcohol?
I:M11:Yeah.
R:M11:Then I guess it’s up to you,
I:M11:Then is it not morally wrong for me?
R:M11:Something that’s between you and like I don't know your conscience. M11:Um, and your background and your belief system, your ethics, that,
I:M11:So then it might not be morally wrong for me, but it would be morally M11:wrong for you?
R:M11:Yes.  It could be that way.  Because some people have different views M11:on morality and some people have different views on ethics, some people M11:are more conservative than others, but I mean I could say I wouldn’t, I M11:mean cause actually people always go to the bible and stuff, but the bible M11:doesn’t exactly say anything about not drinking alcohol, but I don't know M11:considering that it puts so, that I see more wrong things I would say more M11:bad things end up happening out of it than good things and for me that M11:would make it more of a wrong situation than a right.

column585: The respondent reflects on their moral dilemmas, particularly regarding authority and community influences, noting that their views on right and wrong are shaped by their parents, church, and the conservative nature of their upbringing, while also acknowledging the pressure from peers and the media in shaping societal norms.
column589:
I:How would you say you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I usually think exactly first what my parents would do, or ask my parents, that’s one of the first things I do.  Or if not I ask like a minister or one of my good friends that’s not… I mean, older, I don’t ever go really for peer decisions so.
I:Is it generally easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It depends on what it is.  If it’s like something for my future then, you know, yeah.  Not saying I’m gonna like go kill an old lady and save her money for my future, but you know what I mean.
I:I got you.  has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years or so?
R:I think it’s gotten easier, maybe it’s only because I’ll have my camp kids ask me stuff that I really struggled with in high school and in college, and now it’s so clearly right and wrong.  But at their age, you really can’t tell, you know?  And I think I probably still do with stuff like that, but I think it’s to some extent it’s become easier for right and wrong, you know, things I never thought I’d hear myself saying, I am, so.
I:Would you say your moral views have changed in the past two years?
R:No I’d say they probably still have stayed the same.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think, like religious… I guess religious teachings and the thought process… and of course the law, but you know, the Bible.
I:Ok.  Why would you say that?
R:Because that’s what I’ve been taught, you know, it’s kind of a circular reasoning thing but…
I:You know what… I mean I just… I mean that’s what you’ve been taught, but why not how it feels or just the consequence of it or…?
R:I think sometimes I do think about the consequences probably moreso than…
I:But that’s not your first…?
R:That’s not usually the first thing.  I think consequences are probably the second thing, if I’m really thinking it through.  at camp we used to joke, it’s better to ask for permission than forgiveness, you know, or better… it’s better to ask for forgiveness than permission.  Or it’s like easier to ask for permission than forgiveness, because if you get away with it or whatever it was, you just went ahead and did it and you never got caught, then there’s no looking back, so.  That’s not a thought process I live by, but sometimes.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views, would you say?
R:The church and my parents.
I:The church and your parents?
R:Yeah.

Or if not I ask like a minister or one of my good friends that’s not… I mean, older, I don’t ever go really for peer decisions so. It depends on what it is.  If it’s like something for my future then, you know, yeah.  Not saying I’m gonna like go kill an old lady and save her money for my future, but you know what I mean. Because that’s what I’ve been taught, you know, it’s kind of a circular reasoning thing but… I think sometimes I do think about the consequences probably moreso than… That’s not usually the first thing.  I think consequences are probably the second thing, if I’m really thinking it through.  at camp we used to joke, it’s better to ask for permission than forgiveness, you know, or better… it’s better to ask for forgiveness than permission.  Or it’s like easier to ask for permission than forgiveness, because if you get away with it or whatever it was, you just went ahead and did it and you never got caught, then there’s no looking back, so.
