column591: The respondent emphasizes the importance of religious teachings, particularly from the church, in their decision-making, stating they would tithe 10% of an inheritance to the church, prioritize saving and investing the rest, and rely on their parents and religious figures for moral guidance, while also expressing a strong belief in absolute moral truths and a sense of moral responsibility to help others, albeit with caution regarding personal safety.

column583:
I:Where does moral right and wrong come from?
R:God, God’s word is truth.  In the Bible, I believe that’s it.
I:So we would know it through the Bible, and it comes from God.  Um, okay.  So when you, so you’re, so the way you have learned what’s right and wrong would be from your religious faith or the teachings of the Bible?
R:And even if you haven’t like read the Bible for, if you go out and kill someone, I mean you would know that was wrong.
I:Even if somebody didn’t know God or?
R:Right.
I:How do they know that’s wrong?
R:Well we have a law, here, too.
I:You mean the government’s law?
R:Uh-huh, we have, we have a government’s law and I think there’s also a sense of guiltiness, too, when someone just does that even if they didn’t even know the government’s law.
I:You mean they just know, their conscience knows, what’s right and wrong?
R:Right.
I:What about people like Hitler or whoever who seem, or lots of people seem to be able to murder people and not—
R:Care about it?
I:In, in today, in today’s paper, there was an article about a guy who tried to kill his pregnant wife, because he was afraid that she would find out that he was addicted to pornography so he tried to kill her, well he repented eventually but I mean, some people will kill and laugh.  What, do they not have a conscience, or?
R:No, no they have a conscience, they just choose to ignore it.  They um, they’ve gone, they’ve done so many things that I think it’s just become hardened.
column584: God, God’s word is truth.  In the Bible, I believe that’s it. And even if you haven’t like read the Bible for, if you go out and kill someone, I mean you would know that was wrong. Right. Well we have a law, here, too. Uh-huh, we have, we have a government’s law and I think there’s also a sense of guiltiness, too, when someone just does that even if they didn’t even know the government’s law. Right. Care about it? No, no they have a conscience, they just choose to ignore it.  They um, they’ve gone, they’ve done so many things that I think it’s just become hardened.
column585: The respondent believes that moral right and wrong comes from God and the Bible, feels guilty about lying to their parents, and tries to encourage friends to make better choices, while also acknowledging the influence of their parents' consistent discipline and their own conscience in decision-making.
column586:
I:Okay.  Some questions about morality.  Um, that we ask all the teens we interview, sort of how people know right or wrong or whether they think there’s right or wrong or what, how that plays out in their life, ah, what is your general thinking about what makes things right or wrong or good or bad or wise or unwise, etcetera?
R:Um, I think there’s a standard and there’s morals, whether people want to believe it or not and there’s a definite right and wrong.  And whether they get that from the Bible or from their family or the law, there is moral, there is morals and there is right and wrongs that people know not to steal because it’s illegal, but because our country was based on biblical principles and keep going way back and back and back and we were all created in God’s image and so we all have a sense of like, duty, um, and obligation, because we were created in God’s image and so whether people get their morals from the law, it all goes back to what God said for us.
I:So, there’s a definite moral system and it comes from God is what you’re saying?
R:In the end, because ultimately, nothing else matters except for God.
I:Okay, and that can be expressed in like laws?  Like governmental laws?
R:It can be.
I:Or not?
R:I think that it is.
I:If the government makes a law, does that mean that this is God’s will?
R:No, I don’t think that, just because the government makes a law, that’s God’s will.  But there are morals for people that even if they don’t believe in God or they don’t have any sort of religious faith, that there is morals and certain things that they should go by because there is law.
I:Okay.  So you’re saying, ah, correct me if I’m wrong, people that believe in God will act morally because they believe in God, but people that don’t believe in God, it’s the government’s job to get them to act morally, even though they don’t believe in God?
R:Um, no.  That if people that don’t believe in God and they’re like, oh, I don’t have anywhere to get morals from, and they’re like, oh the government has a law.
I:Do you think, what do you think about conscience, I mean, I interview people that don’t believe in God and they just say they intuitively know right and wrong, what about that?
R:Well, they intuitively know right and wrong because whether they want to believe it or not, everyone is created in God’s image and so because of that, we all have the right and wrong, and conscience, in us and, yeah.
I:Okay.  In the last two years, have you, has sort of figuring out right and wrong been hard, easy?
R:It’s been pretty easy.
I:Okay.  Has it been, knowing what’s right and wrong, sort of doing what’s right and wrong or figuring out how you’re gonna behave, has that been easy or hard or confusing or clear, or?
R:Doing what’s right and wrong, is always clear, but the doing part is never easy.
I:Okay, it isn’t.
R:I guess sometimes.
I:Why is that?
R:Because I have this nature that wants to do bad a lot.
I:You have a nature.
R:Yes.
I:That wants to do bad, why is that?
R:Because I am sinful, I’m a sinner.
I:You are.
R:Yes.
I:Uh-huh.  So you want to do the wrong thing?
R:Yes.  But you know to do what’s right.
I:But you still know that you should do what’s right.
R:Right.
I:I interview a lot of teens that say, oh, I know what’s right and wrong, I’m just not gonna do it, I’m gonna do what I wanna do.
R:That’s stupid.
I:Why?  Would What if? But?  they say I’m having fun or I don’t care or?
R:Because I, I don’t know, hopefully one day they’ll look and be like I was being stupid and I was wasting my life and because even if you’re having fun, there’s no fulfillment in it.  Because like you’re, you can have fun in the moment, but what are your future plans and what are your goals and what are you gonna do for the rest of your life, it’s just now and me and nothing else.
I:Well some of them would say, I’m not trying to convince you that they’re right, but some of them would say, no I’m having a great time and when I get older I’ll settle down and everything will be great.
R:I don’t know how they can really believe that.  But, I—
I:Because why, why are you skeptical of that?
R:Because I think that any life without God in it isn’t really fulfilling and then there’s no, like, purpose and for me that’s kind of sad and so for them to honestly think that they’re doing fine and like later they’ll be okay and I just don’t think that it’s going to turn out that way and if they’re having a good time now it’s not gonna be a good time later and like what about eternity?
I:Well they, what they say is I’ll figure that out later.
R:When’s later?  Who knows when they’re gonna die, they don’t know when they’re gonna die.
I:Okay.  Well, actually yesterday I interviewed somebody that said, I’m a pretty good person so I’m not, I don’t think I’m gonna be, I actually live pretty decently so I’m not worried about when I die.
R:But how, how, where do you draw the line, where is good and is the next person doing good and so you can ask them well, do you know, on a scale on 1 to 10 how good you have to be to get into heaven and where are you, and what if someone’s scale is different?
I:So you think there’s a line somewhere that you have to be on the one side of or something to be okay when you die?
R:Not, not like a line, but faith in Jesus and God, not, not it was more like an example, like if there was no God or Jesus then you have a scale.
I:I’ve also interviewed kids that say oh, yeah, I believe in God, I believe in Jesus but I’m also gonna do what I wanna do.
R:I, I have a friend like that and I didn’t know until like this summer and it, it like scares me because I’m worried for her and worried about what she’s gonna do with her life because even though they’re gonna do what they’re gonna do and have fun, there’s so much more and I know that she does stuff to just find fulfillment and nothing is working.
I:So what’s happening with her, what do you mean?  She didn’t, so she didn’t fully let you know how she’s living her life, and?
R:Yeah  I don’t think a lot of people did.  Because maybe they felt like I was gonna judge them or they didn’t want to tell me and I still really love them, but a lot of stuff, like I didn’t know until after school was out and like, probably like three weeks ago, like my friends that I was close with and they want, like them to do good and I care about them, but they’re just like trashing their lives by going to partying and getting drunk and having sex and I’m like, this is a Christian school, this is not supposed to happen!
column587: Well, they intuitively know right and wrong because whether they want to believe it or not, everyone is created in God’s image and so because of that, we all have the right and wrong, and conscience, in us and, yeah. It’s been pretty easy. Doing what’s right and wrong, is always clear, but the doing part is never easy. I guess sometimes. Because I have this nature that wants to do bad a lot. Yes. Because I am sinful, I’m a sinner. Yes. Yes.  But you know to do what’s right. Right. That’s stupid. Because I, I don’t know, hopefully one day they’ll look and be like I was being stupid and I was wasting my life and because even if you’re having fun, there’s no fulfillment in it.  Because like you’re, you can have fun in the moment, but what are your future plans and what are your goals and what are you gonna do for the rest of your life, it’s just now and me and nothing else. I don’t know how they can really believe that.  But, I— Because I think that any life without God in it isn’t really fulfilling and then there’s no, like, purpose and for me that’s kind of sad and so for them to honestly think that they’re doing fine and like later they’ll be okay and I just don’t think that it’s going to turn out that way and if they’re having a good time now it’s not gonna be a good time later and like what about eternity? When’s later?  Who knows when they’re gonna die, they don’t know when they’re gonna die. But how, how, where do you draw the line, where is good and is the next person doing good and so you can ask them well, do you know, on a scale on 1 to 10 how good you have to be to get into heaven and where are you, and what if someone’s scale is different? Not, not like a line, but faith in Jesus and God, not, not it was more like an example, like if there was no God or Jesus then you have a scale. I, I have a friend like that and I didn’t know until like this summer and it, it like scares me because I’m worried for her and worried about what she’s gonna do with her life because even though they’re gonna do what they’re gonna do and have fun, there’s so much more and I know that she does stuff to just find fulfillment and nothing is working. Yeah  I don’t think a lot of people did.  Because maybe they felt like I was gonna judge them or they didn’t want to tell me and I still really love them, but a lot of stuff, like I didn’t know until after school was out and like, probably like three weeks ago, like my friends that I was close with and they want, like them to do good and I care about them, but they’re just like trashing their lives by going to partying and getting drunk and having sex and I’m like, this is a Christian school, this is not supposed to happen!  Um, I think there’s a standard and there’s morals, whether people want to believe it or not and there’s a definite right and wrong.  And whether they get that from the Bible or from their family or the law, there is moral, there is morals and there is right and wrongs that people know not to steal because it’s illegal, but because our country was based on biblical principles and keep going way back and back and back and we were all created in God’s image and so we all have a sense of like, duty, um, and obligation, because we were created in God’s image and so whether people get their morals from the law, it all goes back to what God said for us. In the end, because ultimately, nothing else matters except for God. It can be. I think that it is. No, I don’t think that, just because the government makes a law, that’s God’s will.  But there are morals for people that even if they don’t believe in God or they don’t have any sort of religious faith, that there is morals and certain things that they should go by because there is law. Um, no.  That if people that don’t believe in God and they’re like, oh, I don’t have anywhere to get morals from, and they’re like, oh the government has a law.
column588: The respondent expresses a strong belief in a moral standard derived from God, emphasizing that while everyone has an innate understanding of right and wrong due to being created in God's image, the challenge lies in acting upon that knowledge, and they also highlight the importance of helping others as a Christian duty, regardless of personal connections.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good, bad, right or wrong in life?
R:Um, through the Bible.  Each circumstance that comes can be found somewhere in there.
I:Okay and so that’s your main thing you go to?
R:Right.
I:Okay and in general, do you think it is easy or hard for you to decide what’s right or wrong?
R:It’s usually pretty easy.  And if I have trouble deciding, I know what’s right, like I just don’t want to.
I:Do you think it’s become easier or harder to know what’s right or wrong as you get older?
R:Sometimes it’s harder, a lot of times it’s easier.  I don’t know, I think there, I think it’s the same.
I:It’s always the same?
R:Mm-hmm , sometimes stuff is more confusing or people are more involved now.  And okay, it’s probably harder because before when I was in high school, my parents were always like there so they could say everything and monitor everything but now I think it’s harder because now I'm being the one being like oh my parents told me I couldn’t go, like I don’t want to go, why don’t you want to go?  Because I don’t want to go.  So it’s me instead of them, so harder.
I:Yeah, you can't even say it was my parents.
R:Like there’s no blaming anybody else.
I:Okay and what is it that you think makes something right or wrong?  What is that thing that makes it a right or wrong thing?
R:Like a standard?
I:Yeah.
R:The ultimate standard I think is God’s word, the Bible.  So I think anything held up against that.
I:And what if you’re unsure about that?  You said like if you—
R:If you’re unsure I think you should seek wise counsel and godly counsel from people in your life.
I:And you said, like for the other example you gave like you would consider your mom or people like that?
R:Mm-hmm .
column590: Um, through the Bible.  Each circumstance that comes can be found somewhere in there. Right. It’s usually pretty easy.  And if I have trouble deciding, I know what’s right, like I just don’t want to. Sometimes it’s harder, a lot of times it’s easier.  I don’t know, I think there, I think it’s the same. Mm-hmm , sometimes stuff is more confusing or people are more involved now.  And okay, it’s probably harder because before when I was in high school, my parents were always like there so they could say everything and monitor everything but now I think it’s harder because now I'm being the one being like oh my parents told me I couldn’t go, like I don’t want to go, why don’t you want to go?  Because I don’t want to go.  So it’s me instead of them, so harder. Like there’s no blaming anybody else.  Like a standard? The ultimate standard I think is God’s word, the Bible.  So I think anything held up against that. If you’re unsure I think you should seek wise counsel and godly counsel from people in your life. Mm-hmm .
column591: The respondent primarily relies on the Bible for moral guidance, believes in seeking wise counsel from family, especially their mother, and acknowledges the influence of their parents in decision-making, while also expressing a desire to help others as a Christian obligation.

column583:
I:Ah, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:From church, pretty much.
I:Ah, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:The consequences after, I think.
I:Like what do you, what do you, can you give me an example, maybe, of somebody that you think is wrong or right because--?
R:Well I think it’s wrong like to have sex before you’re married because like if you end up pregnant, like I have a friend who is pregnant right now and like something like that is wrong just because of the chances and stuff and it’s just wrong cause of the way it like, it affects you, cause she’s really different now.
I:Okay.  Um, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um, pretty much, I just know pretty much like from learning it, as I’ve grown and like my parents told me a lot of like don’t do this and that kind of stuff.
column584: From church, pretty much. The consequences after, I think. Well I think it’s wrong like to have sex before you’re married because like if you end up pregnant, like I have a friend who is pregnant right now and like something like that is wrong just because of the chances and stuff and it’s just wrong cause of the way it like, it affects you, cause she’s really different now. Um, pretty much, I just know pretty much like from learning it, as I’ve grown and like my parents told me a lot of like don’t do this and that kind of stuff.
column585: The respondent expresses uncertainty about right and wrong but acknowledges feeling guilty about listening to inappropriate music and lying to parents, attributing their moral views largely to church teachings and parental guidance, while also recognizing the influence of peers and the consequences of actions in their decision-making.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um, usually just like by how I feel about it.  Like I think I have really good like intuition and like, if I don’t feel right about something then I know its wrong.
I:Can you describe like the feeling that you’re talking about, I don’t know.
R:Just kind of like, it’s just feeling like uneasy and just kind of, I don’t know.  Well, I don’t know if it’s always like something like that I know is necessarily wrong but just like if I don’t think, like a couple weeks ago I was going to go to Vegas with some friends for the weekend but it was like really short notice and like we were getting ready to leave and like I was getting all packed and I just didn’t feel good about it so I just told them I didn’t want to go anymore.
I:Okay.
R:But so, like maybe that wasn’t necessarily wrong but that’s the kind of feeling I get, like where I just don’t feel right about it.
I:And would you describe that as like a kind of physical feeling, an emotional, a spiritual feeling?
R:Yeah, I start feeling like kind of like sick to your stomach.  That’s kind of how I feel about it.
I:Okay, um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, like, I think like the consequences, like if it results in something good like in the long run, then it’s right.
I:Okay and like how do you determine what a good consequence versus a bad consequence is.
R:I think if it’s something that makes you happier in the long run, like it will put you like in other circumstances, it will like allow you to like do other good things.
I:Okay, okay, are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Like which kind of things?
I:Like something that would just, it would always be wrong to do something.
R:Like to murder someone?
I:Well, that’s a good example actually.
R:Yeah, like, well I think to like murder someone or like do drugs, that can never, or I mean like drink, that kind of stuff, that never would result in like a long time term good thing.
I:Like the murder someone, the common rejoinder is like in cases of war, it’s okay to murder somebody because, you know, but murder, you’re talking about a different –
R:Yeah, I’m talking about like –
I:Not being self-defense.
R:Yeah, yeah.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:From my parents and from church.
column587: Um, usually just like by how I feel about it.  Like I think I have really good like intuition and like, if I don’t feel right about something then I know its wrong. Just kind of like, it’s just feeling like uneasy and just kind of, I don’t know.  Well, I don’t know if it’s always like something like that I know is necessarily wrong but just like if I don’t think, like a couple weeks ago I was going to go to Vegas with some friends for the weekend but it was like really short notice and like we were getting ready to leave and like I was getting all packed and I just didn’t feel good about it so I just told them I didn’t want to go anymore. But so, like maybe that wasn’t necessarily wrong but that’s the kind of feeling I get, like where I just don’t feel right about it. Yeah, I start feeling like kind of like sick to your stomach.  That’s kind of how I feel about it.  Um, like, I think like the consequences, like if it results in something good like in the long run, then it’s right. I think if it’s something that makes you happier in the long run, like it will put you like in other circumstances, it will like allow you to like do other good things. Like which kind of things? Like to murder someone? Yeah, like, well I think to like murder someone or like do drugs, that can never, or I mean like drink, that kind of stuff, that never would result in like a long time term good thing. Yeah, I’m talking about like – Yeah, yeah.  From my parents and from church.
column588: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on parental expectations and personal intuition, feeling uneasy about choices that don't sit right with them, while their moral views are shaped by their parents and church teachings, emphasizing the importance of helping others and maintaining consistent moral standards despite societal changes.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:I think a lot of it is just how I feel about something. I remember one time I heard when I was fairly young, someone told me that if you have to rationalize anything to yourself just so because you know it's wrong deep down inside, it's always kind of stuck with me, and I remember that, when I think I'm just gonna go “Well, it’s okay because of this and this and this and like that just means that deep down, I feel wrong about it and I have to like make excuses to myself.  Because that's always been a big determiner for me, knowing what's something that I really don’t feel right about inside.
I:Would you say it's easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Most of the time I think it’s fairly easy.  But I think there are times when it’s more difficult, if it's something I really…especially when I feel angry about something, it's harder for me to make like a choice.  Sometimes I know like I’m losing my temper or I'm doing something wrong but I just like, "I don’t care."
I:Right.  Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:I think there were times that it's gotten a lot harder.  But I feel like now, like right now, I probably don’t have much many problems but there have been times, definitely in the past couple of years when it's been really hard or…
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:It's a hard question.
I:Well, take your time.
R:I think how it affects people around you and also like how it affects yourself like if it's going to lead to something positive and it's not going to be hurting you or somebody else and that surely is a good thing, rather than it's going to be making someone else upset, making yourself upset, those kinds of things.
I:Where do you think you acquire your moral view, like where did they come from?
R:Mostly from my parents probably and then also from my religion, which I think goes along with my parents, it's taking me to church, those kinds of things.  Probably, also some from school; growing up, they teach you things in school, probably those three places, probably the most.

column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on their moral beliefs influenced by their religion and parents, emphasizing the importance of aligning actions with what they believe God wants, while also considering the consequences of their choices and the impact on others.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I would usually ask myself before doing something, I would ask myself tomorrow morning when I wake up, will I regret that?  And if the answer is yes than I won’t do it.
I:And so in general, do you think it is an easy or hard thing to do to make those decisions for you?
R:Most of the time it’s easy.
I:It’s easy?  And as you get older do you think it gets easier or harder?
R:Sometimes it’s easier, sometimes it’s harder, it just depends on the situation, but-
I:Like as compared to when you were 19, was it harder or easier now that you’re 23?
R:It’s probably easier now.
I:What do you think makes it easier as you’re older?
R:When you’re younger you have peer pressure and you’re more concerned well what is this person going to think about me if I make this decision or what is this group of people going to think and you know once you get older you’re like I don’t really care what people think, you know?
I:Okay and so what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  What makes it a wrong thing or a right thing?
R:A wrong thing would be something that could possibly hurt me in any kind of way, financially, socially, just you know physically.  Any kind of way.

Most of the time it’s easy. Sometimes it’s easier, sometimes it’s harder, it just depends on the situation, but- It’s probably easier now. When you’re younger you have peer pressure and you’re more concerned well what is this person going to think about me if I make this decision or what is this group of people going to think and you know once you get older you’re like I don’t really care what people think, you know?  A wrong thing would be something that could possibly hurt me in any kind of way, financially, socially, just you know physically.  Any kind of way.
column591: The respondent plans to invest most of an inheritance while also indulging in personal purchases, makes decisions based on future regret, finds it easier to disregard peer pressure as they age, believes in helping others despite social backlash, views morality as situational, and prefers to make decisions for themselves rather than solely relying on parental advice.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I would have to say probably I think in general you have an idea of what’s good and bad. You know what’s right and wrong inside, but I also think the way my parents raised me had a lot to do with it. I think they raised me with really strong beliefs in what’s right and wrong. Even if you want to do something, you don’t do something just because you want to do it, you do something because it’s the right thing to do. You don’t do something that’s wrong even though it’s something you want.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Well to decide if it’s right or wrong it’s not that hard, but to decide if I want to do something that’s right or wrong it’s a little different, but I guess it’s not that hard.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:I think it has gotten easier.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:In general, I believe that it has do with the commandments. I do. I think it has to do with what . I think that if you’re hurting someone is wrong.  I think a lot of it has to do with putting good out there and not being bad out there. Doing what you know are the right things, whether it’s religion or parents telling you or something you innately. It’s kind of hard to describe that.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:My parents and religion for sure.

Doing what you know are the right things, whether it’s religion or parents telling you or something you innately. It’s kind of hard to describe that.  My parents and religion for sure.
column591: The respondent plans to use an inheritance primarily to support their parents and save for future needs, believes their moral compass is shaped by their parents and religious teachings, and struggles with the rightness of their brother's drug use while asserting a moral obligation to help others, emphasizing that true moral decisions should align with religious principles rather than personal gain.

column586:
I:Okay but nothing in mind that you’d save it for at this point. How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:(sighs)  I guess, um, huh,
I:First let me ask you is it hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Um, I usually just, it’s kind of hard a little bit, yeah it’s uh, if I’m faced with uh, if a friend’s fighting with another friend but they have two good points of views, it’s kind of hard to find out who’s right and who’s wrong, that’s a big challenge.
I:Okay.  What else do you do to kind of, well do you have a moral compass?
R:Um, not really I would, I’m usually, I have my own sort of views on how to deal with it.
I:Okay tell me what some of those views are.
R:It depends on like, I don’t really know, it depends on the situations.
I:Okay what would be some of the determining factors?
R:Like if somebody was drinking of course, I have a view that drinking is bad, and I’d try to tell them not and if they were smoking I’d try to tell them smoking is bad.  Um, if they had relationship problems, I’d try to help them with that and put my point of view in there.
I:Alright.  Let me ask you a more general question, and maybe it will help you think more through this as well.  Uh, what do you think, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, huh, I’m not sure.
I:Okay some people may say it’s the consequences, some may say it’s based on what kind of consequences, maybe feelings, do you have, or is that a basis for your decision on what’s right or wrong or is it outside of those?
R:I think it’s the consequences.
I:Okay so you use consequences as a basis of what’s right or wrong, making your decisions?
R:Uh-huh.
I:Okay, can you give me an example?
R:Uh, if um, huh, I’ll go back to my drinking and stuff, you know if you smoke, I try to tell them that they’re going to get lung cancer, and emphazema, and when they drink they can like destroy your uh, liver.  I try to tell them the consequences to most of the things out there, maybe going out late, um, some people are out having sex, I try to tell them the consequences about that, and it usually doesn’t work but I still try.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Uh, basically from my mom.  And I’m kind of like her on the whole idea, cause she tries to teach me and tell me all the bad things in life.  But of course I’ve kind of chosen my ideas on what I think are right and wrong.
I:Where would you say you differ?  Can you give me any examples of that?
R:Um, huh, I don’t really have much a big difference on things, it would be political ideas, she has a lot, she’s very political and she made me become political but I have a few different views.  Um,
I:What are those differences?
R:Um, she, not, huh, what’s one?  I know I have one different view between me and her, uh, I think I’m not sure on her abortion idea, but I’m not really up for abortion, though she’s democratic, and she’s all about different civil rights.  And I have a few different views on civil rights, I cant really elaborate on the issue cause it would take time I think on that one.
I:But you are different in that respect.
R:Uh-huh.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:The bible (giggles)
I:The bible?
R:Yeah.
I:Like literally, you read the bible when you’re wondering?
R:Not literally, because…
I:Or you ask your mom?
R:Because there’s some things that are like, if you disrespect your parents you shall be stoned at the doorpost in Leviticus somewhere so that’s like, uh, no…so basically, basic laws you know.  Love your neighbor and that would be caring about them and not wanting harm for them and just you know, basics.  Don’t steal, it’s not yours.  Don’t kill, cause people deserve to live just like you deserve to live, all that stuff.
I:So how do you go about deciding what’s good or bad or what’s right or wrong?  Suppose something’s not written in the bible just in general say day to day decisions?
R:In general…just um…you know think about what’s right, I just think about it, I mean is this like really right…I mean am I like…I don’t know.  I mean just like if the basic people think it’s right and wrong…basic laws I guess.
I:So suppose you made a quick second decision, the light is flashing don’t walk, should I go or should I not go, what goes through your head?
R:Are the cars coming or are the cars not coming?  You know, just decide on that.
I:So am I going to get killed or am I not going to get killed?
R:Yeah.  Basically.  Like…yeah…your basic decisions, your brain working.
I:Well people have different, yeah there’s common sense.
R:Yeah, there’s common sense, that’s the word I was looking for.
I:But people still have different, I mean if you’re crossing the street, it’s common sense, yeah if cars are coming you’re not going to do it but you know suppose it wasn’t something that you weren’t going to die and you know just making sort of a day to day decision, should I yell at my brother…should I…
R:Think of the consequences.
I:Consequences.
R:Yeah, because, consequences, I’m not going to go to the bible for every little decision I have to make, that’s something my mother would do (laughs), so you know, think of the consequences, if I do this or if I do that, what is it going to turn out like?  If I don’t do this what could happen.  Or if I don’t do this what could I miss out on, so I weigh out the options.

Don’t kill, cause people deserve to live just like you deserve to live, all that stuff. column585: The respondent navigated a difficult decision regarding a friend's need for space versus support, ultimately relying on advice from her mother and youth group, while also expressing a belief that morality is rooted in religion and feeling guilty about her own selfishness in comparison to others' struggles.
column586:
I:How do decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:It’s based on my interpretation of the Bible, because I don’t go by, because I don’t always go by what they interpret.  So based on what I interpret in the Bible.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide what’s right and wrong?
R:In general, easy.
I:Okay.  Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past few years?
R:Harder.
I:Why is that?
R:Because I’ve been faced with more challenging situations, like, um, I’ve been more, I’ve been exposed to the world more, like, more classes, more options, more freedom, more friends, more events, more activities, more of everything.  So, since you, if you’re really like clustered in a little place, it’s really easy to be like, oh well this is wrong and this is right.  But if you have all these things to choose from, you kind of like have to take a step back and think about it, so it’s kind of hard.
I:Okay.  What do you think makes something right or wrong?
R:What makes something right or wrong.  Mm.  Whoa, that’s a hard one.  What makes it—if, okay.  If you’re hurting someone, obviously, that’s wrong.  And if you’re hurting yourself, in any way, that’s wrong.  And basically if you’re not like loving your neighbor and like taking respect in any kind of like moral law, I don’t know what I’m trying to get at.  Like you know, the basic ones, like love your neighbor as yourself and try and like you know, be good to everybody.
I:Okay.  Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves?
R:Killing.  Stealing, obvious—well, no, actually, because if you’re like stealing to save your family, I guess like, I don’t know.  I know killing is.  Um, I have no idea.  I guess, everything has like a double standard to it.  Because, like, if you’re stealing to save your family from starvation, you kind of have to.  I know my Mom would probably say that’s wrong anyway, but in my opinion, you kind of have to, if you have to like save your family or something and if you have to like lie to save somebody’s life, then I think that’s, it’s okay in that sense.  In my Mom’s case, like she’d say like, no a lie is a lie.  And you should have like faith or like whatever that you’ll be saved anyway or you should have faith in God that he’s gonna provide food for you.  In my opinion, yet, if you don’t believe in God or you don’t have that kind of faith or those kind of resources, you gotta steal, you gotta steal.
I:Okay.  Um, where have you acquired your moral views?
R:The Bible.

Stealing, obvious—well, no, actually, because if you’re like stealing to save your family, I guess like, I don’t know.  I know killing is.  Um, I have no idea.  I guess, everything has like a double standard to it.  Because, like, if you’re stealing to save your family from starvation, you kind of have to.  I know my Mom would probably say that’s wrong anyway, but in my opinion, you kind of have to, if you have to like save your family or something and if you have to like lie to save somebody’s life, then I think that’s, it’s okay in that sense.  In my Mom’s case, like she’d say like, no a lie is a lie.  And you should have like faith or like whatever that you’ll be saved anyway or you should have faith in God that he’s gonna provide food for you.  In my opinion, yet, if you don’t believe in God or you don’t have that kind of faith or those kind of resources, you gotta steal, you gotta steal.  The Bible.
column588: The respondent plans to use an inheritance to help their brother buy a house and give to the church, influenced by their mother's expectations, while their moral views are primarily shaped by their interpretation of the Bible, leading them to believe that right and wrong are absolute, despite acknowledging the complexities of certain situations like stealing to save a family member.

column583:
I:Let’s see, um, so where do you think your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:My mom and um, religion I guess, also just like things that I’ve seen cause kids I don't know parents are oblivious but then kids are so oblivious, too, like they don’t, parents know more than they’ll show, like as much as they don’t know, they, they know a lot more than you think they know and they like um, I don't know like they know sometimes like when you’re lying, like right away, they’ll know and then like mothers always like I had you in here and I know what you felt like and I know when you’re lying and it’s like no you don’t, but sometimes they really do and I swear she can read my mind and I don't know but like, like I forgot what I was getting to.

But, if there’s like a consequences that could happen, you know like if you’re afraid of getting caught, you better not do it cause like you know there’s always that chance or it’s probably bad for you.

column585: The respondent makes decisions based on a mix of personal beliefs, fear of consequences, and social influences from friends and family, particularly feeling guilty about disappointing her mother and adhering to her religious values, which discourage behaviors like drinking and smoking.
column586:
I:Okay.  How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Uh, your morals I guess, right?  Your morals, and then some of it I guess just common sense but like, that doesn’t really explain much, cause a lot of people are so non common sense.
I:Is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s usually easy, just doing is harder.  It’s like I know this is wrong, but I’m going to do it.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:It’s easier.  It’s easier because after a while you just realize it’s not even worth it.  It’s like, I don’t need to do anything that I don’t want to or have to.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  You said it’s usually easy to figure out what it is, but
R:Just if you ever have like a doubt that yeah, I should do it, or I shouldn’t, then yeah, usually it’s wrong, you know it’s just like, like if you don’t know for sure that it’s right, then most likely it’s wrong.  Cause I don’t know, it’s that whole little voice in your head thing, it’s like, would your mom be okay with it?
I:So do you think your morals have come from your mom?  Somewhat?
R:Not really from my mom, but, yeah, I guess maybe.
I:Okay.
R:It’s just like a cultural, family and yeah, since my mom’s been my cultural thing, (giggles0
I:No, that’s totally fine.  Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Always wrong, I think so, like no matter who does it?
I:Yeah, like no matter who does it.
R:Yeah, things like, murder and lying and cheating and stealing, any, any of those things, like even not like actions, but like being jealous and angry, all of those things are pretty much bad.
I:So why are those wrong in particular?
R:Just cause I don’t know, I think when you, when you have like jealousy it takes away from concentrating on good things you could have, like I don’t know, just like, all the time you take to think about how much you hate that one person and you wish they didn’t have all the things they have, just could be spent on working your way to getting those things, I don’t know, it’s just pointless, and it doesn’t do you any good.
I:So what about like killing and things like that, what is it about those that makes things wrong?
R:That’s just stupid.
I:I know it sounds like a stupid question, but when you think about it why do you think killing is wrong?
R:Why is killing wrong?  Because, because taking something, just taking the life of somebody else, or something else, it’s not yours to take away, you have no right to it. Even if it’s your life, you shouldn’t, because you, you didn’t give yourself life.  So why would you destroy something that it’s not yours to destroy.
I:Okay, so you said you’ve acquired your moral views from your mom and from your culture and that kind of thing.  So in what ways do you think?  Your religion?  Does that come in?
R:Religion, yeah, definitely.  Um, in what ways, um, I don’t know, like culturally, like I go to school with people and like maybe my best friends will like wear like, it’s not really that I think it’s wrong, it’s just that I don’t feel like comfortable doing it cause I just grew up in a family where like, yeah, I’m not going to wear like a headdress, like I’m just more comfortable wearing like pants, and like shorts, sure, but like a skirt that’s pretty, but not like my butt cheeks are going to hang out.  I just don’t feel comfortable.  Some people, are comfortable, look good in it, that’s okay, that’s you.  I just cant, I just don’t feel right.
I:So it’s kind of whatever is good for each person?
R:Yeah, just like, I mean it’s not like yes, oh please wear this, cause I like it when your butt cheeks hang out,
I:(giggles)
R:You know, but it’s just like if you want to do it, that’s fine, I’m not here to change your mind, but I wouldn’t do it,

column588: The respondent emphasizes the importance of family and self-respect, acknowledges the influence of cultural and religious values on their moral decisions, and believes that while basic moral principles like not killing or stealing should remain constant, individuals can adapt their views based on societal changes, ultimately valuing personal growth and the obligation to help others.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:You know how they say would you do that in front of your mom, or would you do this and that.  I feel like if it is bad I wouldn’t be able to tell my mom about it, if it is bad I wouldn’t be able to say it out loud or I wouldn’t be able to tell her, or your morals and just kind of are you embarrassed of it or are you not embarrassed of it.
I:So you think it is internal or is it more like telling your mom…or do you feel like your mom is a big…
R:I think it is both.  I think it is internal, like you are at ease with it.  It is ok with you, or do you kind of have an anxiety towards it.  And also how will you be perceived if you do this, so it is both.
I:And when you say perceived you don’t just necessarily mean in general by the outer world, but you mean people close to you?
R:Yeah.  I mean it is outer world as well.  It depends on the situation.  You don’t want to always give the wrong impression to a big group of people either.  Or people that don’t know you that will automatically form an opinion about you because the people who know you better won’t necessarily change their opinion about you based on one thing.  It’s just about sending the wrong message I think.  You have to kind of put it in perspective.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s easy to decide what is right and wrong.  It’s harder to decide whether you want to still do it or not.  I can know it is wrong, but I can say to myself is it something that is this much wrong but I can do it and not feel totally guilty or it won’t effect other things, or is it kind of like the one wrong where it will send everything into a wack…there are certain things, like is it a wrong that I will get away with or is it a wrong that is going to come bite me later?
I:So it is consequences versus how you feel inside?
R:Yeah.
I:They are two different things?
R:Yeah.
I:Do you think it’s gotten harder or easier as you’ve gotten older to make those decisions?
R:It gets easier I think.  Well it gets easier to a point because you are not as afraid it.  I think when you get older everything spreads out.  Your friends aren’t going to school with you all of them.  You are not always in the same classrooms and word doesn’t spread as quickly.  They are not as involved in all aspects of your life.  You have a job here and you have friends here, you go home here.  So you can kind of make the right decision and not everybody has to know you are a loser that made the wrong decision so you tend to look more inward than look outwards as you get older.
I:So you don’t have as much peer influence?
R:Yeah.  Peer pressure, that I think doesn’t exist, but it does.

Yeah. Yeah. It gets easier I think.  Well it gets easier to a point because you are not as afraid it.  I think when you get older everything spreads out.  Your friends aren’t going to school with you all of them.  You are not always in the same classrooms and word doesn’t spread as quickly.  They are not as involved in all aspects of your life. Peer pressure, that I think doesn’t exist, but it does.
column591: The respondent primarily bases their decisions on their internal moral compass and the potential consequences of their actions, influenced by their desire to avoid embarrassment in front of their mother and the need to help their family financially, while also acknowledging the importance of maintaining their own beliefs and adapting them to modern contexts.

column583:

R:Where does it come from?  Probably, probably how my parents grew me up, the society I’m in and mostly I should say it depends on me, what’s right or what’s wrong.  Like what I just told you, if doing something that’s right would not physically, emotionally, mentally harm someone, you know, but then again, there are some, some cases like I said with the guy with the medicine and his wife, but the, ultimately what I see is right and wrong is what is best for the situation.  As long as it’s not hurting no one.
I:Um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, just the, the fact that, all right, let me see, why I think, what do I see as right and wrong?

R:Oh, that makes something right or wrong?
I:Yeah.
R:Um, the fact that no one could be adversely affected by the decision you make.  That’s, that’s what ultimately decides what’s right or wrong.

column585: The respondent makes decisions based on a combination of personal judgment, parental influence, and situational outcomes, believing that what is right or wrong ultimately depends on whether it causes harm to others, while also acknowledging feelings of guilt when acting contrary to their values, particularly in relationships.
column586:
I:Okay and how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Mmm, my parents.  The Bible, what I feel is right and wrong, you know, moral standards that I have within myself.  What I think is a standard for me.
I:Is it, in general, difficult or easy for you?
R:It’s not, it’s not hard at all, you know, because certain things that just won’t find myself in.  Situations, if you know what I’m saying, I would just think, I would totally avoid having to decide, you know, what’s right or wrong, but then there is the inevitable chance that I’m gonna have to, you know, go either route.  I’m always gonna stick to the right, that you know, according to the Bible, the straight and narrow, but I think, I don’t know, I don’t think its hard at all because usually, I like, I make my decisions and I make, I’ve learned to make wise decisions.
I:Has it gotten easier or more difficult?
R:Oh, it’s easier.  It’s much easier now.  I think it’s easier because like, before I thought it would have been like, like risky, too risky for me, you know, and what would be the consequence, but that was just me, the young me thinking, but now, you know, I sit back and I look at the whole situation, weigh all the options and I’m like, well this seems to be the best option for me so I’m gonna go this route.  That’s all, that’s how I base making my decisions on.
I:Okay, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Wow, how you feel about it.  If, I, I go by my gut feeling.  It’s something within me.  It’s always different for different people, you know, but I think there’s like, a like a general standard for people because, you know, everyone thinks like killing people is wrong and stealing is wrong, you know what I’m saying, but it comes down to the individual as far as more personal things are concerned.  What do you feel is right or wrong?  How does it affect you, how does it affect people around you?
I:Where do you think the feelings come from, in your view?
R:I don’t know, I can’t, I can’t even do that.  I don’t know.  I can’t explain that, there’s just within me because I look at it based on how it’s gonna affect me in the long run, how’s it gonna affect people around me.  If it’s gonna hurt anyone, if I’m gonna short change myself, then that’s where I go on from there.
I:Okay, are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Mmm, no, it’s all dependent on the situation and what you trying to accomplish.  That’s why, that’s why it’s never always wrong.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:From my parents, from everyone around me and growing up, you know, and just from personal experiences.  I’ve made a lot of wrong decisions and I’ve learned so, I’m like, any time I get into any situation where I know it’s gonna hurt me, you know, I just go the other route.
I:Okay.
R:You need and example?  I could give you and example if you want.
I:Sure, yeah.
R:When I was in school, um, I’m gonna keep saying when I was in school because a lot of stuff happened when I was over there in that short one year of me finishing, then I think a lot, you know, has happened in my whole life because I got fired from a job, you know.  I went to another job, they tried to fire me over there so I quit, you know, I’ve learned that, alright, for example, you know, you go to your job you go to make money, you don’t go to make friends, you don’t go to make anything, you know.  There are gonna be some times when you have casual conversations and whatever but that’s it, a lot of the guys at the job I worked at, they like, talked bad about me behind my back and stuff and they tried to get me fired and a whole bunch of stuff because I worked in the office.  I worked in a shipping company and they were on the dock and it was cold and it was Chicago* and it’s windy and snowy and they pretty salty about it so, how my,  you know, a young guy just got the job, you know, sitting down behind a computer in the warm room, you know, and like I never really understood it like that.

column588: The respondent plans to use a hypothetical inheritance of $100,000 to pay off school loans, support their mother, and invest for the future, while they base their moral decisions on parental guidance, biblical principles, and personal intuition, emphasizing the importance of avoiding harm to others and the belief that everyone has a purpose in life.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, wrong or right in life?
R:I categorize it based on if, how I feel about it.  If it’s gonna hurt someone, if it’s gonna hurt me, if I would want that done to me, if I want someone to experience that, depending if it’s bad or good, that’s how I would categorize it.
I:In general, would you say it’s easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:No.  It’s really easy for me, actually.
I:Why do you feel it’s easy?
R:Because like, like I don’t know.  It’s just something in you.  Like you know what’s good or what’s bad.  Obviously if something’s gonna affect you adversely it’s bad.  If it’s gonna be for the positive, it’s good and I try to keep myself in a lot of black and white, no gray areas.  I mean, there are times when it’s gonna come to gray areas but like stuff like religion and beliefs and stuff, that’s what comes up.  Like what would I do in this situation, is this good for me as far as like morally, because how I would I feel after I do this?  Would I want someone else to do this, like would I want to do this and get away with it if no one knew, stuff like that.  A lot of times I do the right thing.
I:And has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past couple years?
R:It’s gotten easier, to some extent.  I paid for it the other day by pulling over.  It cost me four tickets, $585 bucks and I have to walk across an expressway into a service road, off the highway, after they impounded my motorcycle.  So, I did the right thing, not necessarily the best thing I guess, at that time, but it was the right thing.
I:Have your views changed in the past couple of years, like your moral views?
R:No.  If anything, it got more sound because I am getting older now, I’ve experienced more things, put myself in certain situations where deciding whether right or wrong, or morally sound is right, I would tend to like think that I’m better off doing things that I feel is morally correct, so it’s easy.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Well, a lot of the times it’s personal, it changes from person to person.  What you may think is right may not necessarily be right for me, understand?  So it’s all individual.  As far as that’s concerned, but there’s some cases where you have to, of course it’s gonna be right, it’s gonna be wrong, as far as like hurting people or getting hurt or doing something that’s gonna cause someone some negative effect.
I:So for you, what makes something right or wrong, is it like rules, laws, consequences, how it feels, I mean?
R:How it feels.  You know, I’m very logical.  I look at it logically.  Is this gonna be better for the situation or worse?  Obviously, if it’s worse, it’s gonna be wrong.  If it’s better, all go.
I:So it’s usually the consequences.
R:Yeah, the consequences, you know?  And how I feel, too.
I:And how you feel.
R:And how I feel, too.  Sometimes doing what’s right is gonna hurt me.  I mean, I don’t mean physically, I mean like sacrifice, you know but a little sacrifice is good.

column591: The respondent prioritizes paying off debts and supporting family to minimize stress, believes moral decisions are based on personal feelings and consequences, and emphasizes the importance of helping others, influenced by a sense of karma and compassion learned from their mother.

column584: I'd say, you know, like, well first of all, like what does the bible say, mostly on my religion and then you know what would my parents do?
column585: The respondent primarily bases their decisions on religious beliefs and parental guidance, acknowledges the complexity of right and wrong in contemporary society, feels guilt from thoughts contrary to their values, and has experienced difficulty standing up to friends when they perceive wrongdoing.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good or bad, right or wrong in life?
R:I’d say most of that for me is generally guided by religion.  I look at most things for a moral I should know, read the Bible, figure it out.  Everything for me is based off of love God, love other people.  If anything is in contradiction to that, then it’s bad.
I:How hard or easy is it for you to know right and wrong, good and bad?
R:The big stuff,  and that’s an issue for me that I’m trying to research and find out, but if it comes to the sense that it doesn’t necessarily state it and it doesn’t go against my love God, love your neighbor, then it’s okay.
I:Is there a specific Bible verse or passage that says women shouldn’t wear jewelry?
R:There is one that people use a lot, but it also says not to basically tattoos, but it
I:2 Timothy, or something like that?
R:Yeah, but it also says that women shouldn’t braid your hair, so obviously people still braid their hair, so there’s gotta be something bigger behind that, and why that was said, and I’m not exactly clear on that, but I
I:There’s another passage that says women shouldn’t speak in church, but ask their husbands after they get home, so does the Adventist church enforce that or teach that?
R:Not not speaking in church, but we don’t support women as pastors, so that’s something.
I:You may have already answered this, but what is it that you think makes things right or wrong, or morally good or bad?  You referred to teachings in the Bible, but what is it that makes that?
R:I think that it all goes down to my beliefs about good to be right or wrong, so for me because I believe that God created the universe, and the universe is governed by his character, and therefore, his character is good and everything outside of that is bad, so if his character is the character of love and mercy and all of that, then anything outside of that is bad.  That’s my plausible explanation, and in the Bible that has a lot more specific examples that I can look at for reference.
I:And the way that’s communicated or revealed is in the Bible?
R:In the Bible, I don’t know, in people’s experiences, in life.
I:Why do you think the Bible is written in so many different genres?  It’s quasi-historical.  It’s proverbs.  It’s theological writing.  It’s worship.  Why didn’t God just put together the boy scout and girl scout manual for life, and here it is, plain and simple?  It can be complicated in the Bible.  You have to pull out and sort through and figure out, and why is that?
R:I think to think because made human , and that’s not very interesting at all, and I think that, well, I don’t know.  Reading a story and learning a lesson from a story that’s written in the Bible, it’s a lot easier to learn from, and having someone say here it is, cuz why would I ask about why, why not?
I:But it also says, don’t do this too.
R:Well yeah, but then it has all those examples of why not do, and I think proverbs and psalms and stuff like that.  I like to think they’re there because there are different, everything’s different, and we all have different ways of, different personalities and different ways of worshipping.  For me specifically, I’m really touched by words, and I love poetry and I love writing, so me reading psalms is just wonderful.  Reading  as much, so I think that there are all sorts of different writings, genres like you said, it’s easier, you touch more people that way.
I:Okay.  What do you think about the fact that people who believe the Bible and believe it’s authority and it teaches God’s will and so on seem to interpret it so many different ways.  You can find any issue and it seems like there are three or four different readings about which people argue and fight and split and create separate denominations, and how do you?  The question essentially is, how can something be an authority that everybody reads in so many different ways?
R:Very good question.
I:I’m not trying to undercut its authority.  It’s an interesting question for me.
R:No, no, I know.  It is interesting.  Even within denominations, there’s debates and interpret it differently.  It was written people, and people aren’t perfect.  You can edit something a thousand times, and there would still be mistakes and stuff, which obviously, and there’s one story that’s told a couple different times in the Bible, and there’s little details changed, and it’s been translated however many times.
I:But even apart from details, some Episcopalians right now are in a mess about American Episcopalians want to ordain gay bishops, and then obviously other denominations are like, what in the world are you talking about?  Do you think everyone has to do their best and it’ll shake out in the end, or do you think some people are wrong, or do you think God wants a whole variety of things?
R:I think, it’s hard because 7th Day Adventists normally tend to have the attitude that we’re right and everyone else is wrong.  I don’t think that’s necessarily true because, just from history, tons of different religions of people have had that attitude, and it turns out they’ve been wrong.  They’ve done horrible things, and the problem is, I think that everybody probably has a piece of the truth, but we’re trying to make God a lot smaller than he is, and trying to dictate every aspect of everything, and either this is right or wrong, or this is right or wrong, and it’s harder than that.  You can’t say jewelry is right or wrong because it goes deeper than that.  What’s behind that?  Why would it be bad?  How could it be bad?  Because if you take it too hard, it becomes an idol, and the most important thing in you life, if you spend all your money on that, but it’s easier for them to say that it’s wrong, so I think people, I don’t know, just in an effort to make  seem more controlling and more ordinary as to religious creed, some of these boundaries that they derive from the Bible supposedly, more like a couple verses here and there.
I:Do you, so different people are raised differently, and you were raised one way, and that’s mostly what you’re going with, and do you believe that’s mostly the right way and that’s the proper interpretation of Scripture?  Do you feel like that’s what you have, what else are you going to do?  Do you not really want to think about it, or what?
R:As far as I have been on my own, most of the core beliefs that I’ve grown up with are still true as far as I stand.
I:And a lot of other denominations would agree with those.
R:A lot of other denominations have
I:Pardon me?
R:Ellen White, have you heard of her?  She’s a prophet in 1844.  Anyway, there’s this big whole thing, and so a lot of people, she wrote a lot of books.  They’re really inspiring, and maybe inspired a belief that she was spoken to by God.   a lot of people in my denomination is that people will take what she says a lot more than they would, say, read the Bible, so that’s where I split from a lot of people in my church.

column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on their religious beliefs, particularly the principle of loving God and others, while also considering the financial well-being of their parents and the moral implications of their actions, emphasizing a responsibility to help others and a belief that moral truths are grounded in God's character.

column589:
I:How would you say you normally decide what’s good and bad right and wrong?
R:I think for the most part the things that are right and wrong are clear-cut and the things that are gray; that is, where you have to use your intuition put yourself in situations and look at long term.  If you go with this decision how is it going to affect your life later on and then something really serious enters the relationship I pray on it and see what happens from there.
I:So you use a combination depending on the situation is that what you’re saying.
R:Yeah, you’re right.
I:Is it generally hard or easy for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I mean of course, there is temptation in everything.  There are things that are definitely wrong that I choose not to do.
I:I don’t mean necessarily doing right; I just meant deciding between right and wrong.
R:Things are pretty clear-cut for me.  Give me a situation, is there a specific –
I:No, I just meant in general, deciphering between right and wrong, knowing what’s right and wrong.  Do you feel it’s pretty easy or –
R:Yeah.
I:And has that gotten easier or harder the last couple of years?
R:Easier, you know, you see people have chosen certain routes and you see how they end up with certain decisions that they make and you have to keep that in your memory bank.  And then when it’s your turn to decide, you can see what other people have done and see what happens to them and then – so I think it becomes easier.  Then it also become harder too because you’re so educated and you see so many different things and then you’re questioning some of your beliefs.  I think that’s where faith comes in.
I:You mentioned education, do you think that has to do with an education?
R:Well see when you’re educated, it opens so many different doors so many different influences so many factors come in and it’s not all, “okay this is what you were taught when you were young and that’s it.”  Then again, you have to have certain beliefs that I think are your foundation that I think you can build upon.
I:Okay.  Now for you, what makes something right or wrong?
R:I am going to go into some philosophical stuff
I:I mean is it the rules, the laws, the consequences is it how it feels, the Gods will is it something else?
R:I mean God's will plays a role in it but also the rules of the laws of the land and all.  Also if you feel shaky about it there’s got to be something wrong.  When in doubt, don’t do it.
I:So you recognize some of the feelings like what kind of feelings?
R:Like guilt, guilt is the biggest one.
I:What role do you think guilt plays?
R:A big part I think, because you have to live with yourself every day.
I:Where do you think that comes from?
R:Guilt?  Your conscious, some people are more immune to it than others and more people are susceptible to it.  Other people who can’t live with a guilty conscious who would be more reluctant to do certain things than other people.  I think the conscious is also your upbringing as well.
I:Where do you think you acquired your moral views?
R:My parents and growing up in the Church.

My parents and growing up in the Church.
column591: The respondent prioritizes long-term investments and education over immediate pleasures when making financial decisions, relies on intuition and prayer to navigate moral dilemmas, and emphasizes the importance of adhering to personal morals and religious beliefs while helping others, particularly influenced by their upbringing and experiences in college.

column583:
I:Okay, um, how do you typically decide what to do then when you’re trying to decide, like make a choice?
R:I don’t really listen to anybody else.  I just do what I think I should do. It doesn’t matter like if my friends are like doing something, they’re like oh, you should do this, cause it’s really cool and if I think it’s wrong, I won’t do it.  If I think it’s cool then yeah, I’ll do it but it wouldn’t matter what my friends think.  It doesn’t matter what my parents tell me or what teachers tell me, when it comes down to it, I’ll just do what I think in my head.
I:Okay, um, where do your views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, I guess it comes from, some of it’s probably from my friends, some of it’s probably from just like society and TV and some of it’s probably from my parents and maybe some of it’s just from my own head.
I:Okay.  Um, can you think of any general ideas you have about what makes something right or wrong?
R:I guess if it hurts someone in some way then it’s wrong.  But if it’s not really doing anything to anyone else, then it’s okay, I guess, like generally.
I:Yeah, um, I know this is, these are deep things, but let me push you on this a little um,
R:
I:What do you think’s wrong about hurting other people, some people would just say well if it’s not gonna hurt you, you can do it.
R:Uh, you shouldn’t try to like, it’s not your decision about like other people, I guess, you can only make the choices for yourself, you shouldn’t try to make choices for other people, other than like if you hurt them then, maybe they don’t want to be hurt, so you shouldn’t do that, it’s like wrong, it’s mean, I don't know.

column585: The respondent believes that while they have a clear sense of major moral issues, they often make decisions based on their own judgment rather than social influences, acknowledging feelings of guilt when they hurt others or engage in wrongdoing, and they attribute their moral views to a mix of personal reflection, societal norms, and the influence of friends and parents.
column586:
I:Okay.  Uhm, how do you decide or how do you know what’s good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:I think it totally depends on the situation.  I think that those can’t really be defined.  Uhm, really hard to define. And in some cases, it’s pretty obvious, like, like, rob an old man, it’s--you know, that’s wrong.
I:Uh-hu.
R:….but, like, rob an old man because someone that you know is, like, dying and has no money and needs medicine or something, then it’s like, well, maybe it’s not so wrong.
I:Uh-hu.
R:So, just--you just have to kind of go with it….
I:Yeah.  In general, how hard or easy do you think it is to figure out what’s right or wrong?
R:I mean, in general, like in everyday situations, I think it’s really easy to figure out what’s right or wrong.  But, you know, there’s some situations that it’s, like, really tough.
I:Do you think that it’s gotten harder as you’ve gotten older in the last couple of years?
R:No, I don’t think it’s gotten harder, because I think, everybody kind of, like, knows what’s right or wrong.  I don’t know if it’s like some kind of crazy thing from, like, genetics, like, built into humans, you know, know what’s right and wrong, but I think everybody sort of can feel what’s right or wrong.  So…
I:Okay.  Uhm, so what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Well, I think a big part of it is, uhm, society, and it just depends on the time and what’s going on socially, like, in the world, in the country, like, where you are, or maybe in your group of friends, or….
I:Uh-hu.
R:…and, like, your family and stuff, like, I don’t think it--it just changes.  I think it changes a lot.
I:Uhm, what kind of things do you think are behind it, though, even if it’s changing—what’s--any given situation, what kind of things do people rely on to figure out what’s right or wrong?
R:Well, I don’t know.  Like I kind of said before, I think people just kind of feel it.  I think people just kind of know what’s right or wrong, like, kind of goes along with, like, compassion and, like, would you want to hurt some--would you be hurting somebody, and, like, or who would you be hurting more, like, you know what I mean?
I:Uh-hu.
R:Like, nobody wants to make anybody feel bad, in general.  You know, nobody wants to, like, hurt anybody or do something that could hurt somebody.  So, I think that has a lot to do with it, even if some situations with right or wrong have nothing to do with people getting hurt.  So…
I:Uh-hu.  Where do you think most feelings come from?
R:Well, I guess, society, kind of, and, like, upbringing, and, like, I mean, so many things, like TV, like media--media, and, like, family and religion are pounded into your head ever since you can think, pretty much and pretty much molds people, sort of.  So…
I:Okay.  Do you think there are any actions that are always wrong?
R:Well, I think hurting people.  I think hurting people is always wrong, or not helping someone if they’re in a hurting situation and you could help them.  I think that’s always wrong.  And, like, that can--that pretty much covers a lot of stuff, you know what I mean?  And, so…
I:Okay.  Uhm, from where have you acquired your moral views?  Where did they come from?
R:My parents, a lot from my parents, and, of course, media and my friends, and family.  Not so much my family, because I don’t really, like, I don’t really see my family much, because my family doesn’t live in Michigan*.  None of my family lives in Michigan*, so they haven’t really been a big influence on me.  But, my family because they’ve been an influence still, because, you know, my family raised my parents, you know, and they put their beliefs and morals, and stuff, and what’s right and wrong into my parents, and then they put that into me.  You know?  A little bit changed, you know.  Everybody….
I:Right.
R:…tweaks stuff a little bit, but…
column587: I think it totally depends on the situation.  I think that those can’t really be defined.  Uhm, really hard to define. And in some cases, it’s pretty obvious, like, like, rob an old man, it’s--you know, that’s wrong. ….but, like, rob an old man because someone that you know is, like, dying and has no money and needs medicine or something, then it’s like, well, maybe it’s not so wrong. So, just--you just have to kind of go with it…. I mean, in general, like in everyday situations, I think it’s really easy to figure out what’s right or wrong.  But, you know, there’s some situations that it’s, like, really tough. No, I don’t think it’s gotten harder, because I think, everybody kind of, like, knows what’s right or wrong.  I don’t know if it’s like some kind of crazy thing from, like, genetics, like, built into humans, you know, know what’s right and wrong, but I think everybody sort of can feel what’s right or wrong.  So…  Well, I think a big part of it is, uhm, society, and it just depends on the time and what’s going on socially, like, in the world, in the country, like, where you are, or maybe in your group of friends, or…. …and, like, your family and stuff, like, I don’t think it--it just changes.  I think it changes a lot. Well, I don’t know.  Like I kind of said before, I think people just kind of feel it.  I think people just kind of know what’s right or wrong, like, kind of goes along with, like, compassion and, like, would you want to hurt some--would you be hurting somebody, and, like, or who would you be hurting more, like, you know what I mean? Like, nobody wants to make anybody feel bad, in general.  You know, nobody wants to, like, hurt anybody or do something that could hurt somebody.  So, I think that has a lot to do with it, even if some situations with right or wrong have nothing to do with people getting hurt.  So… Well, I guess, society, kind of, and, like, upbringing, and, like, I mean, so many things, like TV, like media--media, and, like, family and religion are pounded into your head ever since you can think, pretty much and pretty much molds people, sort of.  So… Well, I think hurting people.  I think hurting people is always wrong, or not helping someone if they’re in a hurting situation and you could help them.  I think that’s always wrong.  And, like, that can--that pretty much covers a lot of stuff, you know what I mean?  And, so…  My parents, a lot from my parents, and, of course, media and my friends, and family.  Not so much my family, because I don’t really, like, I don’t really see my family much, because my family doesn’t live in Michigan*.  None of my family lives in Michigan*, so they haven’t really been a big influence on me.  But, my family because they’ve been an influence still, because, you know, my family raised my parents, you know, and they put their beliefs and morals, and stuff, and what’s right and wrong into my parents, and then they put that into me.  You know?  A little bit changed, you know.  Everybody…. …tweaks stuff a little bit, but…
column588: The respondent believes that moral decisions are influenced by societal norms, personal upbringing, and compassion, emphasizing the importance of helping others and the consequences of one's actions, while also reflecting on their own experiences of secrecy in relationships and the challenges of navigating right and wrong in complex situations.
column589:
