R:um, well. Do you want the person answer? Or the student answer?  Do you want the sociology student answer? Or like the personal answer?
I:The personal.
R:Um, I mean I would definitely say I just kinda figure it out, but the person is still the student, so I can’t separate that.  So I would say I don’t really figure that much out and basically a lot of stuff that influences me, whether I notice it or not.  I mean, my parents, obviously, like the way I was raised.  You know.  My friends sort of, we’re all kinda the same so. Um, stuff I learn at school definitely influences me a lot. Like my professors I would say influence me a lot definitely and of course there’s like media stuff which is like influencing me right now and I don’t even know it.
I:Are you sure that was the personal and not sociology answer?
R:I mean yeah, like I said, the person is the student, it’s hard to separate that, I mean if I like had to make a decision about something and I couldn’t make up my mind, I would probably talk to Mellie*, who’s my girlfriend, or I would talk to my roommate. Or I might run it by my parents, like the disclaimer I’m not going to do what you say just because you say it, I’m asking for your opinion, but that’s all I’m asking, I’m not asking for your permission.  So I feel like my mom, it’s always like a permission thing and I’m like I’m not asking for your permission, I don’t live with you, I have my own money for things and I have my own life, I’m just asking for your opinion.  So I would ask like friends and family.  Um, but I am definitely really influenced by a lot of the stuff I read for school and a lot of the stuff I learn in class.
I:and in general, how easy or hard is it for you to decide between right and wrong.
R:I don’t think it’s not that hard, usually it’s sometimes, you just have like a gut feeling, even if that really is being influenced by everything around you or sort of like, even if I make a decision on my own, you hear different people’s voices and I think right and wrong’s pretty simple, except when there is no right and wrong.  But that’s simple, too, because it’s just not there.
I:And do you think it’s gotten easier or harder over the last few years?
R:I think it’s been the same.
I:Yeah?
R:Mmhmm.
I:and what do you think makes something right or wrong, like you mentioned talking to your friends and family but you also said that sometimes you might be disagree with that..?
R:I mean the best way to figure out if something is right or wrong is to just sit and think about it by yourself and then whatever decision you come to, maybe it’s not, maybe someone else might come to a different decision, but that’s what you think is right for you or wrong for you.  But even when you sit alone, well what would this person say, what would that person say? I don’t know, so.
I:so when you’re trying to make a decision what kinds of things are you thinking about? Like what kind of consequences?
R:Like how will this affect me and how will this affect the people around me and maybe even if I won’t benefit, maybe a lot of people around me will benefit from it.  Like I need to make a decision and what I choose can harm people around me, then I’m probably not gonna do it.  Because I wouldn’t want to do that.

column591: The respondent plans to allocate a portion of an unexpected inheritance towards personal expenses, investments, and donations to organizations they believe in, influenced by their upbringing, social circle, and a strong sense of responsibility towards others, while also reflecting on the moral implications of their decisions and the importance of considering the impact on those around them.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:You don’t. I tend to overanalyze everything, but I usually do whatever makes the most sense, and it seems like it isn’t going to have that many drawbacks. Try not to act impulsively. If something bad comes up I deal with it then.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s usually pretty easy. I mean, not everything’s that cut and dried; even when it is, it’s pretty easy.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:Easier.
I:Why?
R:I’m just stronger now than I was then.
I:Have your views changed about what’s right and wrong in the past two years?
R:I don’t think my views have changed. I think I’m a little bit more aware of things. It makes it easier to see things clearly.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I couldn’t say.
I:Is it rules or laws?
R:Sort of man-made.
I:What about consequences?
R:Maybe sometimes. Probably insofar as rules and laws, though.
I:How it feels?
R:I almost want to say yes but not necessarily, because whether that’s true or not, it may depend on your state of mind. Because things that felt right to me a couple of years ago were bad ideas but I wasn’t in much of a state of mind to be feeling anything so it’s kind of hard to tell whether I might regret it later or not.
I:Some people say “God’s will.”
R:If that’s what they believe, it’s not my belief. People have the freedom of choice.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:I guess somewhat the family that I was close to when I was little. My aunt, a little bit of my mother, my grandfather before he died, I’m sure—everybody says we were close. I can’t remember. Other than that, just my life.
I:Where do you think morals in general come from? Like do they exist out there somewhere or… you know what I mean?
R:There’s so many different types, just so many different morals, I don’t think it’s possible that they just exist out there. People make them for themselves, or let others make it for them if they aren’t competent enough to make their own.
I:So there are multiple moralities kind of out there?
R:Yes.
I:Are you saying each person created their own morality?
R:To an extent, I guess so.
I:What’s the limit to that?
R:Actually, I have no idea.

If something bad comes up I deal with it then. It’s usually pretty easy. I mean, not everything’s that cut and dried; even when it is, it’s pretty easy. Easier. I’m just stronger now than I was then. I don’t think my views have changed. I think I’m a little bit more aware of things. It makes it easier to see things clearly.  I couldn’t say. Sort of man-made. Maybe sometimes. Probably insofar as rules and laws, though. I almost want to say yes but not necessarily, because whether that’s true or not, it may depend on your state of mind. Because things that felt right to me a couple of years ago were bad ideas but I wasn’t in much of a state of mind to be feeling anything so it’s kind of hard to tell whether I might regret it later or not. If that’s what they believe, it’s not my belief. People have the freedom of choice. There’s so many different types, just so many different morals, I don’t think it’s possible that they just exist out there. People make them for themselves, or let others make it for them if they aren’t competent enough to make their own. Yes. To an extent, I guess so. Actually, I have no idea.  I guess somewhat the family that I was close to when I was little. My aunt, a little bit of my mother, my grandfather before he died, I’m sure—everybody says we were close. I can’t remember. Other than that, just my life. There’s so many different types, just so many different morals, I don’t think it’s possible that they just exist out there. People make them for themselves, or let others make it for them if they aren’t competent enough to make their own.
column591: The respondent expresses uncertainty about how to use a hypothetical inheritance, indicating a desire to help family members, particularly their grandmother and mother, while emphasizing that their decisions are influenced by caring for those close to them and a preference for logical analysis over impulsive actions.

column586:
I:Okay, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, or what is right and wrong in life?
R:Um, I believe that everything that has their own, has a, like a set rule, you know, if you know that killing is wrong, you know that stealing is wrong, you just know that regardless of laws or religion, you know it’s wrong, I think.  You have a guilty conscience when you do wrong things and you should, and you know what’s right and wrong by the decisions you’re gonna make, by the conscience.
I:Okay, maybe I would just come back to that, actually, um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, the consequences that follow.  Are they gonna benefit you or are they gonna hurt you.

R:Well, not your, maybe you and others.  You know, if it’s gonna benefit you and other people, then it’s right.  If it’s not gonna benefit you and it’s not gonna benefit anybody else then it could be wrong _________ other people __________.

R:Um, mostly myself and my experiences, I’ve just adapted them to myself.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong in your life?
R:I just use morals. Every human being has got their pretty basic set of morals.  They have a pretty good idea what is right and wrong.
I:So how easy or hard is it for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It's not hard at all.
I:Would you say it's gotten easier or harder over the past two years or stayed the same?
R:Stayed the same.
I:Have your views at all changed over the last few years?
R:I'm sorry?
I:Have your views changed at all over the last few years?
R:For?
I:Like on issues on morality?
R:Oh, no.
I:So in general, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  To be more philosophical, what makes some things right, some things wrong?
R:Something wrong would be, if you're going to hurt yourself, is it going to hurt others? Are you breaking a moral?  That would be wrong.  Right would be, does it benefit you, does it benefit others?  It's not breaking your moral?  Yes?  So go.
I:So where do you think you got your views about right and wrong?
R:Part of it, my peers.

Right would be, does it benefit you, does it benefit others?  It's not breaking your moral?  Yes?  So go.  Part of it, my peers.
column591: The respondent believes in using personal morals and considering the consequences of actions to determine right from wrong, influenced by peers and a sense of responsibility as an example to others, while also emphasizing the importance of personal happiness in decision-making.

column588: The respondent would use an inheritance of $100,000 to buy a car for family convenience and help their parents go on vacation as a way to give back for their support, while they navigate moral decisions based on personal happiness, parental guidance, and the influence of social situations, ultimately believing that morality is relative and shaped by rules and laws.
column589:
I:Got you.  So, how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Just by families, like you’re going to look at it and see like, “Okay, if I do that there is going to be bad consequences.  If I do that there could be good consequences.”
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide?
R:If it’s like off the moment, it’s kind of hard.  But if I can like see it and then take time before I do it, that’s pretty easy.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:Easier.
I:Why do you think that?
R:Just because I’ve been through a lot, like everything lately and stuff.
I:Have any of your views about these issues changed in the past two years?
R:Not really.
I:I see.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think it’s your personal belief on what’s right or wrong.
I:Like, what do you mean by that? Can you tell me what that mean?
R:Some people might think this is not bad but then something else is bad.  To other people it’s just like...let’s just say like drinking.  To some people it’s bad and other people like, “Oh, that’s not bad, killing somebody is bad.”
I:If so, let’s say two people disagree about something.  Is it possible that one of them is like more right than the other one or is it just what’s right for one person is right for one person and what’s right for another person is right for another person?
R:What’s right for one person is right…because everybody is different.  There’s like, maybe you could find maybe some that are the same but everybody is different. Everybody will say they’re right, so just one person.
I:Where do you think you got your moral views, your views about right and wrong? Where do you think you got this from?
R:From a lot of different people, some from my parents and some from my friends.  It’s a little bit different but…
I:How do you think you sort of pick them up and get them? I mean, how do you learn them?
R:Like sometimes being put in a situation and then sometimes my parents taught me and stuff.
column590: Just by families, like you’re going to look at it and see like, “Okay, if I do that there is going to be bad consequences.  If I do that there could be good consequences.” If it’s like off the moment, it’s kind of hard.  But if I can like see it and then take time before I do it, that’s pretty easy. Easier. Just because I’ve been through a lot, like everything lately and stuff. Not really.  I think it’s your personal belief on what’s right or wrong. Some people might think this is not bad but then something else is bad.  To other people it’s just like...let’s just say like drinking.  To some people it’s bad and other people like, “Oh, that’s not bad, killing somebody is bad.” What’s right for one person is right…because everybody is different.  There’s like, maybe you could find maybe some that are the same but everybody is different. Everybody will say they’re right, so just one person.  From a lot of different people, some from my parents and some from my friends.  It’s a little bit different but… Like sometimes being put in a situation and then sometimes my parents taught me and stuff.
column591: The respondent makes decisions based on family influences and the potential consequences of their actions, finds it easier to discern right from wrong over time, and prefers to follow the advice of respected adults when unsure, while also acknowledging the relativity of moral views shaped by personal beliefs and social experiences.

R:Mm, that’s just something you don’t do.
I:Okay.  Do you think that um, if a person thought that ah, killing people was a good thing or that stealing was a good thing, if it was for a good cause, do you think they could be right about that, or no?
R:No.
I:Do you think if a person was um, oh I don’t know, stole something to ah, feed their family or something, they were really poor, do you think that would be right or wrong or what?
R:No.
I:You don’t think it would be right?
R:No.
I:Okay, um, what if ah, what if you had to steal something to save someone’s life, do you think that would be right or wrong?
R:That’d probably be right.
I:Okay what would make that right?
R:Ah, well if some, a life is more than something you stole.
I:Okay so, how, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Ah, yeah, you have a feeling ah, the right feeling is you don’t get a feeling at all when you do something right, but when you do something bad you just know, you know it’s bad.
I:Where do you think that feeling comes from?
R:Ah, just down in your soul.
I:Okay.  Do you think everyone has that feeling or only some people, or only a few people?
R:Well I think the people who have been doing it for a while, they don’t get the feeling anymore.
I:Okay, why is that?
R:Cause they’re just so used to doing bad that it doesn’t even affect them anymore.
I:What ah, why, why do you think people have that feeling, what is it, what’s the source of it?
R:Ah, I don’t know, it’s hard to explain.
column584: Um, could you say that again? Um, ah, don’t choose bad, I guess. Oh, my Mom and Dad. Um, right is something good that you do for someone else or, and bad is something like stealing and just killing people. Mm, that’s just something you don’t do. No. No. No. That’d probably be right. Ah, well if some, a life is more than something you stole. Ah, yeah, you have a feeling ah, the right feeling is you don’t get a feeling at all when you do something right, but when you do something bad you just know, you know it’s bad. Ah, just down in your soul. Well I think the people who have been doing it for a while, they don’t get the feeling anymore. Cause they’re just so used to doing bad that it doesn’t even affect them anymore. Ah, I don’t know, it’s hard to explain.
column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are clear, attributing their moral views primarily to their parents, and while they feel guilty about not attending church due to their religious beliefs, they acknowledge that they sometimes cheat in school despite knowing it is wrong.

column586:
I:I’m interested in your thinking about sort of morality, good, bad, right, wrong, etcetera, how do you go about living your life in terms of deciding what you’re gonna do and not do, what you’re gonna choose, what you’re gonna choose against, how you figure out moral issues?
R:Um.  Like if I just feel like that’s the right thing to do, then, it’s within myself.  Um.  For instance, um, underage drinking.  Ah, I do it.
I:I noticed there’s a lot of beer bottles out on the sidewalk and a bunch of booze on top of the refrigerator .
R:Ah, yeah.  Yeah.  Um.
I:But some people would say, that’s a legal issue, not a moral issue.
R:Right, well, legal, legal issues come in hand with moral issues.
I:Yeah, okay.
R:Um, moral issues, maybe more sensitive, um.  Like stealing, killing.
I:I mean, it could be anything from you know cheating, stealing, um, taking advantage of women who have drunk too much, to just being good and kind and gracious, I mean, you know, it could be a whole range of virtues and character traits, you know?
R:Um, if it’s wrong, if I feel it’s wrong, I just won’t do it, like there’s other people that you know, like, for instance, take advantage of drunk girls.  Ah, my, some people in my fraternity like, that does happen in college all the time, but I mean, if like, it’s just a gut instinct that like, no, she’s too drunk, she doesn’t, she doesn’t really want to like, I’ll just, you know I won’t go out of my way to do something wrong like that.
I:So you’re saying you have sort of like an internal conscience that you rely on?
R:Right, yeah.
I:And how, where do you think that, what’s that based on or where does that come from?
R:Just living, you know?  A lot to do with your parental influence.  You like—
I:So some of it is what your parents taught.
R:It’s, it’s, it comes from your parents, friends, you take, try to take the good out of everybody, you know.
I:But how do you know what’s good, is the question.
R:Um, that’s your own personal judgment.  Um, also like, like these guys, I talk with them a lot about that, we always have these kind of talks like, and you know like I think being honest and straightforward with like, everybody know, everybody would know what I think is right and what I think was wrong, and that’s, that’s how I like to, I like to be open about how, what I think is right and what I think is wrong.  And that way you’ll get feedback and like maybe alter a few things.
I:Do you think most people, or all people have a similar moral conscience, that’s reliable?
R:Reliable?
I:I mean, that, we know there are some psychopaths that they don’t have any conscience.
R:Right, right.
I:And we have some people whose consciences are so screwed up that they shouldn’t rely on them.  Like they need the law or police or whatever to keep them, but do you think for, the majority of people, pretty much know what’s right and wrong, and their conscience pretty much tells them or do you think, you know, some people do because they’ve had good training, they’ve had good parents, they’ve had, and other people are lost, you know, I mean, they need--?
R:Right, um, yeah, like um, it definitely has a lot to do with your parents.  As you’re growing up, and um, how much you listen to them.  Um, the environment you grow up in, like, the teachers, it’s evident, you know, like, people that grow up in those kind of neighborhoods, like, it’s very rare to see them come out on top and who’s to blame?  Um, but.
I:So what is it that makes things morally right or wrong, ultimately?
R:What makes--?  There is no, there is no definite answer for that, but I feel…there’s no definite answer.  We have the judicial system that creates guidelines, so no killing, cheating, stealing, um, then we have religious, religious um, influence, then we have the media, social influence, you know, like um, it’s very hard to not know what’s right, I feel like, these days.
I:So people should know, they should be able to know what’s right.
R:Yeah, like if you’re, if you’re like killing some—like a murder, you don’t, you got to know it’s wrong, um, unless you have some kind of a mental problem.

column588: Respondent M1 would use a sudden inheritance of $100,000 to pay off college tuition and save for future living expenses, while Respondent M2 relies on an internal moral compass influenced by parental guidance and social interactions to navigate moral dilemmas, emphasizing the importance of personal judgment and conscience in decision-making.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good or bad, right and wrong in life?
R:You just know.  I just know.  It's like – well, how I made the decisions.
I:Yeah –
R:What formula – I guess it's society, the way – what's interpreted as right or wrong within society.  You just know.  Like cheating, you know it's wrong.  Everybody does it, whether it's with your girlfriend, or a test, or your taxes, or, you know, everything.  There's so much corrupt practices going on these days, you know.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:To decide whether to act right or wrong?
I:Yeah.
R:It's harder to act right.
I:Okay, but in terms of acting and deciding, is that easy for you to do both of them, I mean, or is it hard?
R:It's hard. Yeah, it's hard because I make a lot of decisions that I know are wrong.
I:Um hm.  Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:Harder.
I:Why?
R:The severity of my decisions are more – are higher.  Could you repeat the question again?
I:Yeah.  Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:Deciding between right and wrong.  Yeah, definitely harder.  As you grow older, you feel as if you should start making decisions that are more right but, I guess, I find it harder to make the right decisions as I get older.
I:Have your views about what's right and wrong changed over the past two years?
R:No.  I'm sure a little bit – no, not really.  Not that I can –
I:Okay.  So what is it that you think makes something right or wrong?
R:What society has evolved to claim what is right and wrong.  So, like, back then, slavery was accepted; it wasn’t considered wrong.
I:But was it wrong in your eyes?
R:Well, it's easy for me to say now, but say back then, who knows what I would have thought.  In some countries, murder is – I don’t know, one of those third world countries – killing people is not considered wrong.  I feel like you have to work within your network, your – how's a person in the slave years, you know, everyone is doing it.  I mean, you look back now and you're like, wow, how dumb must they be to think that they can treat people of different color like that, but, you know, you just conform to what everybody else is thinking and what everybody else is doing.
I:So if everybody is doing it, does that make it right?
R:No.  No, no.  But – I'm trying – I don’t know the answer to that question.
I:Okay.  So I'll give you some, maybe, ideas or leads.  Do you think it's, like, just rules or laws in society?  Is it the consequences of the action –
R:Yeah, the law.  The constitution, you know –
I:Constitution.
R:The law.  The law is the basic framework for what you must follow, and then there's people's opinions and ideas.  Like, for instance, yeah – next question, let's move on.

column589:

R:I really don't know. I just do it. I don't know, I guess I think about the consequences later.

R:It's easy. I mean, I know I kinda know if I'm doing wrong most of the time.

R:I don't know, it's just like, in your head, and you're like "no, that's wrong."

R:From church. My mama.

column591: The respondent would use an inheritance to help their struggling family, particularly their grandparents and mother, and relies on their mother's guidance for moral decisions, indicating that their sense of right and wrong is influenced by consequences and their upbringing, while also acknowledging that morality can be relative.

column583:

R:My religion, my family.  Um, I think if you have either one you’re doing pretty well.

column589:
I:Okay.  So how do you normally decide or know what's good and bad, right and wrong?
R:I ask God.  If I can't – if it's not completely obvious as far as what I should do and what I shouldn’t do, I ask God.  And eventually, it'll become clear to me, you know?  I can't say I have all the answers, because I don't.  Sometimes I do try to determine what is the right and what's wrong, and if I make a mistake, then I just suffer my consequences and go and just move on.  So I if I really had – you know, some people be like, "Oh, I asked my mom," but I couldn’t do that, so I'd just pray about it.
I:So in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It's not very hard.  Depending on the circumstances, if it's a situation I have never been in, I guess like dating this guy – I've never been in a situation like that, I've never dated a guy with kids before in my life, so it was hard for me to determine what was right and wrong.  And I just had to kind of play it by ear, and if I made a mistake, apologize for it or ask for forgiveness or whatnot.  But if I had no idea, I'd just pray.
I:And has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder in the last few years?
R:It's gotten easier.  I think one thing that's kind of easy about it is not making a quick decision.  Like when I was younger, I wouldn’t think things through all the time, so I'd, you know, just react instead of, you know, think about what I'm about to do.  So I think it's gotten easier for me over a couple of years.
I:And what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I guess whatever was taught – I guess – when I have to decide on what's right or wrong, I think about the church, you know?  I think about what my pastor said or the bible or stuff like that.  That determines to me what's right and wrong, but  at the same time, because sometimes I think everything is just too strict, and they want us to just walk, you know, a certain way and it's not as easy as it sounds, so.

column591: The respondent primarily relies on prayer and scripture to determine right from wrong, acknowledges the difficulty of acting morally due to societal pressures and personal desires, and emphasizes the importance of helping those in need while recognizing the challenges of generosity in a selfish world.

column583:
I:So, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, my mom.
I:Your mom, uh-huh.
R:Yeah, cause she tells me what’s right and what’s wrong.  Sometimes I disagree with her, but then she has her reasons.
I:So do you usually talk with her, I don’t agree with that mom, does she tell you why, or what happens?
R:Um, yeah.
I:Or do you just sort of take her word for it?
R:Um, sometimes like mostly me and my mom agree about everything, the only thing I like disagree with her about is like the guys and talking to them. And like you get a bad name and I’m like okay, that’s the only thing I disagree with her.
I:But you still listen to her.
R:yeah, I still listen to her.
I:So, what do you think it is that makes something inherently right or wrong?  So, why is stealing wrong?
R:I think it’s wrong cause um, like when you steal, it’s like I don’t know, you’re stealing out of somebody’s like, you know, they’re making money and like they’re paying for the stuff and you just take it out with out paying for anything, so…
I:So you’re hurting somebody else.
R:Yeah, it’s basically you’re hurting somebody else and like you’re hurting yourself, too, because I don’t know, but like, if I steal something, I know sooner or later, I’ll feel really bad and I’ll probably like go up to the person and I’ll give them money or something or I’ll give it back to them.
I:How about something that doesn’t hurt somebody else…like I’m gonna sit here and do drugs…that doesn’t hurt you…but is that wrong?
R:No…it’s wrong cause you’re just hurting yourself with that.
I:So it’s wrong to hurt yourself and other people?
R:Um…it’s well, you’ll feel really bad and stupid on the choices that you made.  And then, like, I don’t know, but I think some people do feel bad even though they don’t admit it.  They’ll feel bad because like your parents don’t like when you do drugs and they get really disappointed and they’re really sad and I think sometimes you’ll feel really bad why you did that and but my mom says that if I do drugs, she’ll do everything to stop me but she’ll feel really sad for me.  And, she said like I’m not gonna be hurting her, but she’ll be really sad for me, but she always tells me I’ll be hurting myself and ruining my goals that I made already.
I:So you think it’s wrong to do things and hurt other people, hurt yourself, are there any other things, like um, anything else that makes something wrong?
R:Um, no.
I:So, how do you decide or know what’s good and bad, right and wrong in life?  So everyday, you have to make decisions, so…how do you what’s wrong and right, good and bad?
R:Um, usually, I think it over, like, my mom tells me what’s right for me usually a lot, and so I go from her opinions a lot like right now, I want to finish my high school here earlier.  So like next summer, my mom’s gonna be taking me to her, cause she works at a college, and I’ll be taking college classes so I can finish my classes earlier there.
I:And why do you want to do that?
R:Um, I want to be ahead of my self right now.  I want to be ahead of everything so I can graduate earlier from high school and I want to go to college and I have to go to more medical school so I think I’ll be really old by the time I finish all that stuff…
I:Yeah, you’ll be like my age…that’s pretty old.
R:So…I was like…I want to be young, still.
column584: Um, I wouldn’t think it’s right, but again, like, it’s your choice, and I’m not the one who’s gonna be in trouble for that stuff, so… I would tell you it’s not right… I would tell you it’s…wrong.  Cause that’s what my like…my friend is tempted to grab stuff all of the time but I was like okay, think of it this way you’re gonna get in so much trouble and you’re gonna lose your trust with your mom. And, she said like I’m not gonna be hurting her, but she’ll be really sad for me, but she always tells me I’ll be hurting myself and ruining my goals that I made already. Um, no. column585: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on their fear of consequences, particularly the loss of their parents' trust, and they often rely on their mother's guidance regarding right and wrong, while also acknowledging the influence of friends in situations involving temptation, such as stealing.

column583:
I:Right, right, okay.  So where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, it’s hard to say.  I'd like to think that I’ve pretty much come up with it by myself, but I’m sure there’s tons of different factors that have affected why I think as I do, yeah.
I:Uh-huh so it doesn’t sound like there’s one source that you can think of as going to,
R:No.
I:Yeah.  Is it um, something that you, you feel or you think through or you look at uh,
R:Well generally, there’s just an intuitive feeling of is this right or is this wrong, and if you’re unsure then you kind of think through it.
I:Uh-huh.  Is there anything that you can pinpoint and say this is a reason why things are right and wrong?
R:I don’t suppose you have an example of something like that?
I:Um, let’s see, let’s see, um, something that makes something right and wrong, well, let’s see, what have we, some people will talk about um, uh, well of course you have, you know people who have appeals to the bible or something, you know that could be an example or you know other people might appeal to um, importance of relationships or um, anything like that?
R:Not that I can think of.
I:So um, I think, we’ve kind of touched on this but I realize it’s a really difficult thing to figure out, for the most part, we’re living, not thinking about everything, but how do you decide or know what’s good and bad, what is right and wrong in life?
R:Um, well one big one is how it affects other people and if you’re using other people or if you’re doing something that you know has a bad affect on other people then that’s not good.
I:Uh-huh, are there any examples of where you’ve had to make these decisions about right and wrong?
R:Um, no, not really.
column584: Um, it’s hard to say.  I'd like to think that I’ve pretty much come up with it by myself, but I’m sure there’s tons of different factors that have affected why I think as I do, yeah. No. Well generally, there’s just an intuitive feeling of is this right or is this wrong, and if you’re unsure then you kind of think through it. I don’t suppose you have an example of something like that? Not that I can think of. Um, no, not really.
column585: The respondent believes that while morality can be seen as relative, they rely on an intuitive sense of right and wrong, influenced by their concern for how their actions affect others and the desire not to disappoint their parents academically, while also expressing a clear stance against drug use and cheating, although they acknowledge the complexity of lying in certain situations.
column586:
I:I see, uh-huh, yeah.  And um, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um.  I think a lot of it is just common sense.  I don’t know.  It’s certainly not based off any religious feeling or anything like that.
I:Yeah, so common sense.  And in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s generally pretty easy.
I:Has it gotten easier or harder over the last couple years?
R:Um.  Well I’m not, I don’t really find myself in a lot of situations, debating about what’s right or wrong, aside from very theoretical things, so.  It’s pretty much the same.
I:Okay, haven’t come across, okay.  Ah, let’s see.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um.  Well I think it has to do with the impact that it has on other people, in general.  I mean, if it has a negative impact, it’s probably wrong.
I:Yeah.  Any, any, how would you describe those kinds of impacts or those consequences that would make something wrong?  Any particular kinds of impacts?
R:Um, I’m not really sure what you mean by that.
I:Mm.  Um, yeah, like if you, if you ah, thought about the kinds of consequences that make something wrong, and you were saying that um, it’s wrong depending on how it affects others.
R:Ah, or yourself, too, right.
I:Or yourself, okay.
R:Both.
I:So, in terms of your kind of health and well being?  Or, mm, kind of your psychological, mental health, or?
R:Um, probably a mixture of both.
I:Okay, so kind of thinking about consequences, um, of health and well being, at all different levels.  Okay, and um, what do you think, are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Not necessarily.  I mean, I hate to be sort of you know, teenage, it’s all relative type of thing, but I can’t think of anything, any specific action that would always be wrong, I guess.  I mean, I probably could if I thought about it.
I:Nothing immediately, or things that you always have in your head as this is wrong, you know, no matter what, no matter the context or anything.
R:Um, I don’t know, it’s fine to say.
I:Uh-huh, right.  And um, where would you say you’ve acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Um, probably parents and teachers and family.
I:And they explicitly tell you things or you sort of pick them up?
R:Well I think I, um, well, I can’t specifically remember going through a list of, no, this is wrong, or this is right.

R:Um, but I think generally seeing how they conduct themselves and you learn by example.

column588: The respondent views moral decisions as largely based on common sense and the impact of actions on others, believes that moral views are shaped by parents and teachers, and emphasizes the importance of considering societal changes in moral evaluations, while rejecting the idea that it is acceptable to break moral rules for personal gain.
column589:
I:Interesting.  How do you normally decide, or know, what is good or bad, right or wrong in life?
R:I’d, I’d say I have an inner sense about it that is not really based on specific moral system or religious values, but just my general sense of how people should treat each other, and, let me think, I don’t know, I think it’s hard to pin down.
I:Do you feel like it’s hard to decide between right and wrong?
R:I feel like in a lot of situations there are a lot of factors to be considered, and that, um, that, from different perspectives right and wrong may have different meanings.
I:Do you feel like it’s gotten harder in the last two years to decide?
R:Um, in the last two years…I think, well, I think it just becomes harder  well, maybe not necessarily harder, but the more nuanced in general the more experience you have with the world and the more exposure you have to different ideas and to different ways of thinking about things.
I:Would you say your views have changed at all about right and wrong in the last 2 or 3 years?
R:Um, only, only that understanding that I just mentioned.  That, that it is fairly complex and difficult issue.
I:What do you think it is that actually makes something right or wrong?
R:I’m not sure that right or wrong is necessarily an attribute that anything has inherently.  I think it’s more your own perception of that.
I:Where would you say your views on morality come from?
R:Probably, probably my parents.  But no in the sort of directed, instructional sense of “don’t do this, this is wrong,” but rather, you know, the cues that I’ve picked up from the way they do things, and the way they think about situations.

column591: The respondent would invest an inherited $100,000 for its long-term benefits, relies on an inner sense of morality shaped by parental cues rather than explicit teachings, believes that right and wrong are complex and subjective, and prefers to seek guidance from respected individuals when uncertain about moral decisions.

column583:
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Something right would be, in a general type of case, something right would be something that is something with a favorable outcome, that benefits you or people pertaining to it.  People that could be affected by it. Something wrong would be the opposite, something that is negative to someone or a group of people or a time or anything.
I:Why is it wrong?
R:Because it, it’s, it’s, in my eyes it’s wrong because you’re taking away your life before you know what’s gonna happen.  You don’t know what’s gonna happen.  You don’t know how things are gonna clear up, you don’t know.
I:What if you’re terminally ill and you know what’s gonna happen?
R:No one knows.  No one knows.  There’s been so many different cases where people have been terminally ill and—my aunt that I lived with.  Her sister was diagnosed with Lime’s disease and told she had three months to live and that was three years ago, or four years ago.  So you never know.
column584: Something right would be, in a general type of case, something right would be something that is something with a favorable outcome, that benefits you or people pertaining to it.  People that could be affected by it. Something wrong would be the opposite, something that is negative to someone or a group of people or a time or anything. Yeah, it’s still wrong.  You know it’s still the law. I mean, the law is there for a reason.  I think that it goes the same way for rights and wrongs, you know. Yeah. Are there things that wrong…no laws against.  Um.  Well, there’s no law against ah, no law, well actually there is a law against suicide, but. Sort of.  Um, although I don’t know how they can enforce that, yeah. Um, you know suicide is wrong, yet there’s no law against it. Because it, it’s, it’s, in my eyes it’s wrong because you’re taking away your life before you know what’s gonna happen.  You don’t know what’s gonna happen.  You don’t know how things are gonna clear up, you don’t know. No one knows.  No one knows.  There’s been so many different cases where people have been terminally ill and—my aunt that I lived with.  Her sister was diagnosed with Lime’s disease and told she had three months to live and that was three years ago, or four years ago.  So you never know.
column585: The respondent often feels unsure about right and wrong, typically seeking advice from their girlfriend's parents rather than family, acknowledges that many people knowingly choose wrong actions for rebellion, and believes that right actions generally lead to favorable outcomes while wrong actions have negative consequences.
column586:
I:Ok.  Um, how do you decide or know what’s good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:Um, probably, if it wasn’t really related to church, if I couldn’t get it thru religion then, it would depend probably on my girlfriend’s parents or my parents.
I:So, you’d talk to people?
R:I’d talk with somebody.  Or, or unless it was not an extreme situation than I could probably just figure it out on my own.
I:So, you, the way you talked about that it made me, gave me the impression that you, uh, you normally wouldn’t  lean to your religion to know what is right and wrong, first?  Is that right?
R:Most of the time.
I:Um, any, well, sort of given what talked about:  so you have got your religion and you’ve got sort of family and friends and then yourself, in general do you think it’s easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?  In thinking about the way you would normally decide?
R:I would say probably pretty easy.  Um, in addition to religion, I do a lot of checks and balances.
I:What do you mean by that?
R:Weigh the costs and the prices of the situation.  And you know there’s, if I’ve got an issue, I think about what, alright, what are my choices first of all, lay those choices out.  Now try and find every possible scenario for each choice.  And once I have found all of those see which one is most favorable.
I:Ok.
R:Then do that.
I:Do you think that deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or harder in the past two years?
R:I don’t know if it’s gotten easier or hard but I know it’s more of a question that had to be asked more often.
I:What do you mean by that?
R:More, more, ah, freedom has been given to me and I don’t have someone else there to make those decisions for me.
I:Ok.
R:I just get that question a lot more than I would if I was completely sheltered some where else.
I:It’s up to you to make the decisions more often now?
R:Yeah.
I:Ok.  But, we’ll probably get back to something.  If you think of something please tell me.  Um, so, what do you think that it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Makes it right or wrong?
I:Um hum.
R:Probably the, weighing out the costs.  If it’s right the costs are going to benefit everybody.  They’re going to be a positive effect.  If it’s wrong it’s probably going to have a negative effect on, maybe not you at the time, but somebody.  A positive, ah, doing something right is pretty much going to effect everyone positively.  If it’s something that’s wrong it seems most of the time that it would definitely affect at least one person negatively in every situation.
I:So, what kind of consequences, some sort of costs, would make something wrong?
R:Ah, any type of wrongdoing, we can’t use that word, but, um, it’s pretty much the first word that comes to my head, is using the same word, wrongdoing, it’s what, um, morals have taught you over the years of what, I mean, it’s more what’s been instilled in you that would give a basis.
I:Um hum.  Well, when you say that they, sort of the costs or the consequences of something, or, or, or, are like that bad costs or consequences, what, what kinds of things are bad consequences, like, what are the consequences that make something wrong?  What would it take, what would be an example of some of the consequences that would make something wrong?
R:Ah, any type of death or injury or hurting someone in, in, you know, an emotional way.
I:Um, are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves?
R:Anything that has to do with death or injury.
I:Ok.  Um, so what, what makes that wrong, what makes it wrong killing people or hurting people?
R:For me, my religion.
I:Your religion?
R:Um hum.
I:Um, ok.  Can you tell me a little bit, a little bit more about that?  In terms of like what it is about your religion that, like would….
R:It’s, it’s, it’s, it’s taking a life from someone else.  You can’t do that.  It’s just how I have been, you know, its how I have been taught since beginning, as long as I can remember.
I:Ok. Um, so where do you think you have gotten these moral views from?
R:Probably from growing up, having my parents teach them to me and church and from different friends.  You know, seeing what friends have done and how their actions have had reactions.
I:Do you have a sense of what the sort of, most, if there is one, are these sources sort of equal, do you feel like, one, one or more of them are sort of more fundamental to having, to your, how you know what’s right and wrong, do you feel like they sort of evolve?
R:They kind of evolve.  Play them together.

column588: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on common sense and the desire for financial growth, while determining right and wrong through a combination of personal reflection, family influence, and religious teachings, emphasizing the importance of weighing consequences and the belief that helping others is a moral obligation rooted in empathy and social connection.

column583:
I:So where do you think that your own views from right and wrong come from?
R:My Mom and my sister.  Once in a while I have my own, like from out of nowhere, I would have, my Mom would think like where did you get these things, from your Dad, from your Mom, who did you get these examples from, where did you learn to be stubborn, where did you learn to be so prude , when did, where did you learn to talk back. I’m like did it all myself, but she won’t believe me, it’s just things like that, like certain things she’s wrong, like how to be stubborn, I learned from my Mom and my sister and my Dad, but my Mom ignores that as, it’s not true, it’s not true, your Dad’s the stubborn one.  And then, my Mom would say, you’re like a, you’re like a Martinez.  My Dad’s side and my Dad will be like you’re like a Gomez.  It’s kind of weird, like at my Dad’s house I act like my Mom, I fight with my Dad like, like little tiny arguments, not fight- fight but just like trying to see each other’s point of view.  Trying to like see like, it’s like almost kind of like a contest, like, like, I’m like no, it’s this and this and this thing, he’s like no that’s not, it’s true, it’s this and this and this until we actually find a way.  And he’s like and then once in a while he goes ay, you’re like a Gomez and I’m like that’s what Mom says, except Mom says I’m like a Martinez.  So.
I:So what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I really don’t know.  Right or wrong is what you learn.  Most likely, because nobody would know what right or wrong is until they learned it. When they’re little.  That you grabbed something you’re not supposed, like eat candy before dinner, they’ll be going no, bad!  No!  And that’s where you learned wrong from right.  From your parents.
I:But you said that, something like killing is always wrong.
R:Yes.
I:So what is it about killing that makes it wrong?
R:You’re taking another person’s life away.  They cannot, for all you know, for all they know, something can be important in their life, family, friends, maybe they’re gonna make something good of themselves.  But they’re taken away their life, so they really can’t have no, they have, they don’t have, how do you say, um, a chance to do what they need to do.  They don’t have a chance to go back or anything.
I:How about littering, do you think that’s wrong, like if I had a coke but I just through it out, on the grass, would that be wrong?
R:Yes.
I:Is that, or is that wrong for everyone?
R:Yes, it is, I think it is, cause I always learned that way.  Because in a way you’re actually helping supposedly the devil take over us.
I:Oh really?
R:Yeah because he is the one that tempts us to do wrong things like murder someone, throw things on the floor, calling out people, things like that, like calling people names.  Yelling, stealing, things like that.
I:So how do you decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong?  You talked about, you, you look at the pros and cons, is there anything else you do?  When you’re trying to decide what’s good and bad, right and wrong?
R:Um, I look to where I learned, my, where I learned wrongs and rights. And then if that can’t help me, most likely I just, I look at everybody else, cause they’re doing the same thing and they see, and I feel like they’re doing something wrong, then I know it’s wrong.  Like, like people say when you’re looking someone else and you see they’re doing something wrong and then you notice that you’re either doing the same thing, you know it’s wrong.  If you feel that way, the same way when they’re doing it, then you have to feel the same way when you’re doing it.
I:Can you give me an example of some time when you were trying to decide, um, you know what’s wrong or right, good and bad?
R:Um, fights.  I think because you see someone fighting they’re like, how stupid can they be?  They’re just ruining themselves.  They can’t even be, they can’t be more mature, try to help themselves they just instead they wanna hurt someone just to see them, see right to like they feel, like sometimes I feel that they feel that like oh, it’s just that I, if I fight, they’ll understand me, if I fight they, nobody will do any, nobody will try to hurt me, when it’s not true because once you start fighting, they know how you fight, they learn you, and then they start jumping on you; everybody starts to hate you, their friends will start to hate you, things like that. was talking, someone (interviewer?) was rooting around in a bag or something and rustling through things which made it hard to understand some things/was distracting]

column585: The respondent often grapples with moral dilemmas, relying on a mix of pros and cons analysis, personal experiences, and guidance from their mother and sister to navigate decisions, while also expressing concerns about social pressures from friends and a desire to avoid losing their relationships.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good or bad or right and wrong in life?
R:Usually I don’t.  I go with what, one, my religion says.  Two, what I feel is right and three, what is socially accepted in the world and the environment around me to figure out what can be considered in the wrong area and the right area because a lot of things you don’t exactly know, so you have to ask around and that, asking around, is more in the area of your environment for that to be in the third category.  If my religion doesn’t say anything about it and in my personal beliefs I do not know yet, I can ask the people around me what is socially correct to them and from there I can make a decision what I feel from that answer, what I feel is right.  So I think it comes with three things, my religion, my morals and my social interaction with others that help me figure out what I think can be wrong and what I think can be right.
I:And is that sort of formula, religion, others and culture, did that change over the last three years or is that something you just developed more recently or is that something you’ve had for a while?
R:I think I developed it gradually growing out because before I never thought about religion, I thought about myself and then growing up I thought about religion and myself and I noticed during the times where I thought about myself when I was unsure of myself, I would ask my friends so it gradually incorporated all each other in together.  So growing up I started learning to realize what I use to determine things, how I am, my personality wise and I started to realize it growing up and started utilizing it with anything that I did.
I:Tell me what you think it is that actually makes something right or wrong?  What is it in the thing itself that you think makes it right or wrong and even though you have to go through this in different steps?
R:Generally a lot of people probably think it’s right or wrong is the rules that it’s socially set up.  Like the government set up rules buy I think what also helps the government is everyone’s own beliefs and religion because every person who has a right or wrong, people who don’t believe in God or hell, their right or wrong is very general and they have trouble determining what’s right or wrong and so instead of saying it’s right or wrong they say they don’t care, they’re doing what they want because that’s what they feel is their right.  So with them I see it as they don’t see right or wrong, they just do what they want to do.  It’s do what you feel and have no regrets.  As for other people I see that they do the right or wrong; one, because they don’t want to get punished, like stealing from the store.  You will get fined or punished so that’s another thing of what’s right and then they also think of what their religion tells them or what their families taught them.  So I think that’s what the general right or wrong is.  It’s what socially tells you, like will you get punished for it?  Will you get fined?  Will you get hurt?  Will you get lectured by your parents?  And also the fact of will my parents be happy that I did this?  Will my mom who died away, would she be fine with this?  Is my religion saying this is okay?  Does my conscience say it’s okay?  Because your conscience is what your family built up for you, your conscience, like what’s right or wrong is what your family taught you what right or wrong is so that is your conscience.  So either way, it still relates to your family and what they taught you.
I:And you talked about consequences and you talked about, it sort of comes from religion or rules or whatever.  Are those sort of equal in your mind in terms of determining what’s right or wrong or is one more determinative than the other do you think?
R:I think they’re equal.  A lot of times they’re equal unless – occasionally one that’s usually more stronger than your religion would be rules because you don’t always think about your religion 24, seven.  You should as we are devoted – in my religion you should be thinking about doing the right thing and the wrong thing all the time.  It should be on your mind every minute of your life, but it usually isn’t because you have things at school, work, friends, family, emotional problems, home problems, that you don’t always think about it; and so I think what is higher than your religion would be rules, the consequences from the rules that is socially set.
column590: Usually I don’t.  I go with what, one, my religion says.  Two, what I feel is right and three, what is socially accepted in the world and the environment around me to figure out what can be considered in the wrong area and the right area because a lot of things you don’t exactly know, so you have to ask around and that, asking around, is more in the area of your environment for that to be in the third category.  If my religion doesn’t say anything about it and in my personal beliefs I do not know yet, I can ask the people around me what is socially correct to them and from there I can make a decision what I feel from that answer, what I feel is right.  So I think it comes with three things, my religion, my morals and my social interaction with others that help me figure out what I think can be wrong and what I think can be right. I think I developed it gradually growing out because before I never thought about religion, I thought about myself and then growing up I thought about religion and myself and I noticed during the times where I thought about myself when I was unsure of myself, I would ask my friends so it gradually incorporated all each other in together.  So growing up I started learning to realize what I use to determine things, how I am, my personality wise and I started to realize it growing up and started utilizing it with anything that I did.  Generally a lot of people probably think it’s right or wrong is the rules that it’s socially set up.  Like the government set up rules buy I think what also helps the government is everyone’s own beliefs and religion because every person who has a right or wrong, people who don’t believe in God or hell, their right or wrong is very general and they have trouble determining what’s right or wrong and so instead of saying it’s right or wrong they say they don’t care, they’re doing what they want because that’s what they feel is their right.  So with them I see it as they don’t see right or wrong, they just do what they want to do.  It’s do what you feel and have no regrets.  As for other people I see that they do the right or wrong; one, because they don’t want to get punished, like stealing from the store.  You will get fined or punished so that’s another thing of what’s right and then they also think of what their religion tells them or what their families taught them.  So I think that’s what the general right or wrong is.  It’s what socially tells you, like will you get punished for it?  Will you get fined?  Will you get hurt?  Will you get lectured by your parents?  And also the fact of will my parents be happy that I did this?  Will my mom who died away, would she be fine with this?  Is my religion saying this is okay?  Does my conscience say it’s okay?  Because your conscience is what your family built up for you, your conscience, like what’s right or wrong is what your family taught you what right or wrong is so that is your conscience.  So either way, it still relates to your family and what they taught you. I think they’re equal.  A lot of times they’re equal unless – occasionally one that’s usually more stronger than your religion would be rules because you don’t always think about your religion 24, seven.  You should as we are devoted – in my religion you should be thinking about doing the right thing and the wrong thing all the time.  It should be on your mind every minute of your life, but it usually isn’t because you have things at school, work, friends, family, emotional problems, home problems, that you don’t always think about it; and so I think what is higher than your religion would be rules, the consequences from the rules that is socially set.
column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on their religion, personal morals, and social influences, emphasizing the importance of not regretting their actions and the role of family in shaping their understanding of right and wrong.

column583:
I:Uh-huh.  Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, mostly the Bible and like my personal like individual views, I uh, I try to stay away from anything that like, like putting stuff into my body or whatever, drugs or alcohol, stuff like that, to make me feel better, or that numb the pain or do that, I try to avoid that.  And part of that is because of my dad and him like being an alcoholic and running from stuff.  I try like to never run from stuff.  Like even with little stuff, like I don’t even drink coffee, cause I’d rather, you know, try to, like, go through myself, you know, or, that’s another thing too, if I’m really tired sometimes then I wouldn’t need that much coffee cause I haven’t build up like that.
I:Yeah.
R:And so.  Yeah.
I:Cause your tolerance is way low for coffee.  Or caffeine I guess.
R:Yeah.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, how it affects you and how it affects the people around you.  Um, I think that, the concept of sin, or the mainstream is like the thing that God says you can’t just do.  There’s no, you know, there’s no real logic, you can’t just do it.  But the thing is sin is anything that you’re, you’re doing that is hurting yourself in the long run or hurting yourself you know, like that’s the basis for morality, in my view anyways.
I:Why do you think it’s wrong to hurt you or to hurt somebody else?
R:Because, this is a hard question.  Um,
I:I’m not trying to talk you out of anything,
R:Yeah.
I:I just want to sort of see what’s behind what you’re saying.
R:Yeah.  (pause)  That’s a good one.
I:Well I mean for example if uh, if uh, and I think we have some questions about lying and stuff like that, but if you lie or cheat on a test, that’s not really going to hurt anybody else or it’s not going to hurt you is it?  Is that okay to do or why is that not okay to do?  Would it hurt somebody else?
R:Um, (pause) I don’t know.  I guess uh, you could say it would hurt you in the long run because you’re, you’re doing something that you’re taking the easy way out and you’re not really learning the stuff you know, that’s kind of like a lame reason not to do it.  Cause if you do it you’ll get an A or an F, you know, or I could pass this class because I cheated you know.  But it’s one of those like flimsy things, I guess.  But you don’t, you don’t hurt yourself or other people because that’s not logical, you’re trying to survive, you’re trying to advance yourself, and like you know, stupid Darwinism, or like survival of the fittest, you’re still like, you’re like an animal, you’re trying to survive.  And if you’re hurting other people you’re hurting yourself and you’re hurting humanity, and you’re hurting your chance of survival I guess.
I:And when you make those decisions based on whether you are or not going to hurt somebody or yourself, how do you know the consequences are going to be bad or wrong down the road?
R:Um, well ultimately you don’t really.  Like with some stuff you won’t know.  You just like, you know, like your best guess, like is it a good idea for me to cheat, to cheat on the test?  Well, it probably won’t hurt me but it could, and you, you just say, well, you just kind of go from there I guess.  I don’t know if that answers your question.
I:Well do you have any specific examples of an instance where you had to make a decision recently?
R:Um,
I:Relatively recently, it doesn’t have to be in the last few days or weeks or anything?
R:(pause) I don’t know.  Well stuff has been pretty much black and white. I don’t really run across that very much so.
I:So give me a black and white one.
R:Like,
I:Like when you said this is wrong and this is right, why did you say that was wrong, or why did you know that was wrong?  Whatever it was?  Tell me that situation?
R:Um, (pause), I’m trying to think of a situation like, actually the truck one might be a good idea.  Cause um, I wanted to go back and get the license plate cause then I would look like I didn’t trust him, and I felt,
I:Tell me because this will be somebody that will be hearing this and they don’t know the back story, so just a little bit.
R:Oh, um,
I:That you got, somebody hit you?
R:Yeah, a guy hit my truck and I was like lame and I went over and got his phone number and it only like ended up like breaking my, um, like breaking my brake lamp, so I was like all right, it’s only like 60 bucks, no big deal, I’ll just get his phone number, and I’ll call him.  And then I was thinking well, should I get his license plate number?  Like, like you should, thinking with your brain you know, you should like back yourself up.  And then I started thinking about it and I was like well I’ll have to walk all the way over there and he’ll know that like, I obviously don’t trust him cause like the, the, I don’t know, I didn’t trust that he gave me the right phone number. So I was like, well I guess I won’t.  Yeah, and then I ended up being screwed over.  End of the story.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um,  I think that’s a funny question, uh, the easy, well that’s not an easy answer, I think in general I identify with Christianity and especially like with Jesus and his story and I think a lot of like what he does is like motivated by loving people and loving God and like in a way where like you’re not just like letting people do whatever you want, you know, you want what’s best for them and so that’s generally I guess, trying to figure it out.
I:So in a sense looking out for other people and wanting what’s best for other people?
R:Yeah.
I:So that’s how you know what’s good or bad or right or wrong?
R:Yeah, like—
I:Sort of like that’s the measure?
R:That’s what I try to do and like that’s very, you know in one way where that’s really I guess like evident but the  some of my friends is like for me like, well my dad was like an alcoholic and died when I was pretty young so like alcohol is pretty significant for me so like generally like I’d be like pretty standoffish with it even though like a lot of my friends aren’t and it’s not, and so like you know like and I think like in terms of like biblically, like I think it’s completely fine to drink.  I don’t think that there’s any problem with that, it’s just that like my individual experience is also like defining what that looks like.
I:So you have, but you do have this kind of, you said biblically it’s okay, so you, there’s an external—that you would look to, but since you think it’s okay there, it’s more of a I don’t want to have anything to do with it because of what my personal experience has been and stuff like that?
R:Yeah, yeah, and I think in general like yeah there’s trying to like love people, love myself, love God, is like the more external guiding thing.
I:Would you say that in general it’s very easy or very hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Um, I think generally it’s pretty easy.  Yeah, in general.
I:Would you say that that’s gotten easier in the last few years or it’s about the same, or?
R:Uh, I think it’s, it’s about the same.  I think one of our, kind of my first few years of college I was more, things were more black and white, you know, and like as time has gone on it doesn’t feel quite as black and white, um, but—
I:So does that make it harder to figure out what’s—
R:Harder.
I:The right or wrong thing to do in any given situation?
R:I think so.
I:What is it that you think makes something right or wrong?  What is it that is either, makes it—yeah.
R:Um, I think , Yeah, so I’d like to say that like loving yourself, loving people, loving God position, but then it’s like well if there’s a decision where you think that you’re loving someone and you’re not, is that still the right decision anyways, you know?  I don’t really know, so I guess I’d say like yeah, trying to do things out of love but with a, like the little asterisk saying that might be more complicated than I realize.  You know what I mean?
I:Do you think that that notion, your idea of doing things out of love is related to consequences or is it related to some sort of, you know something, I'm not sure I want to say it this way, but I will, it’s like a rule or a law about love or something like that or is it something else sort of transcends or goes away from any of that sort of stuff?
R:So I think in general I'm not very concerned with like right and wrong, like that’s not really the paradigm that I tend to think about and um, and so like that idea of doing things like out of love I think more has to do with so my  is like that’s how we were like created to be, you know?  and so yeah, it’s not, it’s not the like you’re doing things because you don’t want to like go to hell or you don’t want to like you know give back some way or have karma like do something.  It’s just that like living as we were created to.  Like being a full human being, having a full human experience, like being able to identify with humanity and to like see people as people.  You know what I mean?  Because when you don’t, when you can't see people as people like they suffer because you know you do asshole things but like you suffer because you like aren’t recognizing that, you know what I mean?  So.
I:So and then back to what you were saying before about with the asterisk and that difficulty is to how to figure out what actually demonstrates actual love toward the person in the sort of decision?
R:Yeah, and most of the time I think we have no clue like what that is, like especially in terms of something cross-cultural or coming into a new situation or especially like as Christians, walking in and saying well we’re going to do this or we’re going to do that and a lot of times that’s totally messed up and you’ll find doing something that’s really offensive or totally obscures like who Jesus is, you know that, if you do what you do.
I:Where do you think your moral views come from?
R:Uh, I would think that they come from the Bible.  You know?  I hope.  I may not, but I think so.
I:And trying to put that into practice in some way?
R:Yeah, I think just, yes, thinking I would figure it out and then going back and being like wait but this part doesn’t make sense and then, you know, so it’s like, just continue like changing things, so I'm sure like if we ever meet again I’ll think something different, you know, but.
I:Yeah, but that’s, so that’s more of—
R:Just a process—
I:Yeah, like essentially a process throughout your life.
R:Yeah.

column591: The respondent primarily relies on their Christian faith and the teachings of Jesus to determine right and wrong, influenced by personal experiences with alcohol in their family, while also acknowledging the complexity of moral decisions and the importance of love in guiding their actions.

column583:
I:Okay, so um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, I don't know how it like impacts you or something or your family, what your parents would think of it.
I:Okay, so how it would impact you or your family.
R:Yeah.
I:Are those the only people you have to consider when you think about what’s right and wrong?
R:Well and your friends and yeah, pretty much.
I:Okay, so how do you know what’s good or bad, right or wrong?
R:I just know cause my parents taught me it.
I:So you think it comes mostly from your parents?
R:Yeah.
I:Anywhere else?  I mean anything else that influences your decisions?
R:I guess those things in school that like health class.
I:Okay, are there um, have, let's see, so, if, if something, if somebody um thinks something’s okay and it’s not gonna hurt them or their friends or family, does that mean it’s okay?
R:For that person,
I:Uh-huh.
R:I guess.
I:So they decide that they wanted to go steal from a local store but no one they know would be hurt by that, is that okay?
R:Well, I don’t think it’s okay, but if that kid thinks it’s okay, then I guess, I don't know.
I:So if they think it’s okay.  Okay.  Is it always just up to the individual person then?
R:Yeah, it’s his decision.
column584: Um, I don't know how it like impacts you or something or your family, what your parents would think of it. Yeah. Well and your friends and yeah, pretty much. I just know cause my parents taught me it. Yeah. I guess those things in school that like health class. For that person, I guess. Well, I don’t think it’s okay, but if that kid thinks it’s okay, then I guess, I don't know. Yeah, it’s his decision.
column585: The respondent primarily relies on personal feelings and parental teachings to make decisions about right and wrong, acknowledges the influence of friends, feels guilty about actions that contradict parental expectations, and recognizes the legal implications of behaviors like drinking, while also admitting to occasional involvement in risky activities for fun.

column589:
I:So how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:It’s a really hard question to answer.
I:So, in general, when you think about making moral decisions like that, do you think it’s easy or hard to decide?
R:It’s hard to decide.
I:And do you think that deciding has gotten easier or harder over the last couple years?
R:Easier.
I:How so?
R:Now that I’m a mom, it’s a lot different.
I:And what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Mmm.
I:When you are making a decision, do you think about the consequences, or do you get a feeling of what’s right or wrong, or do you base it on laws?
R:I get a feeling.
I:What’s the feeling like?
R:It’s like a stomach feeling.  I just get a gut feeling, and just.
I:You just know?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.  So, from where have you acquired your moral views?
R:
I:Do you feel like that’s something you were taught, or something you thought of on your own?
R:Something I thought of on my own.
column590: It’s a really hard question to answer. It’s hard to decide. Easier. Now that I’m a mom, it’s a lot different.  Mmm. I get a feeling. It’s like a stomach feeling.  I just get a gut feeling, and just. Yeah.   Something I thought of on my own.
column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on what is best for her daughter, often relying on her gut feelings about right and wrong, and she believes that moral guidance comes from her own reflections rather than external influences, although she expresses a preference for following religious principles when unsure.
