column586:
I:Okay, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I guess I always do what my, I just follow what my parents told me you know, what was good and bad when I was younger, I still do that today.
I:You follow what they tell you.
R:What they told me.
I:They told you.
R:You know like, don’t drink, don’t do drugs, stay in school you know, stuff like that.  I still listen to them.  Plus alcohol is really gross tasting to me.
I:How hard or easy is it for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Easy.
I:Why is that?
R:Um, I don’t know.  Its’ just always –
I:Do you have a fierce sense of what’s right and wrong?
R:Yeah.  I just, whenever something even slightly wrong happens, I get in a whole and I just start feeling really awkward and weird and I want to stop it.
I:Slightly wrong happens, meaning you do something wrong or some body else does something wrong.
R:Uh, like uh if I’m going, if I’m driving down the road and the speed limit is like forty and I see I’m going like forty-four, its like, I like hit my brakes you know, stuff like that.  I mean, I know it isn’t like really something wrong but --
I:Interesting.
R:You know, I’m really, I play by the rules,
I:Let me make an observation.
R:Okay.
I:Two years ago you struck me as a little bit less like that and a little bit more sarcastic and does that, would that be accurate or not?
R:I’m still like that, I’m just, I don’t know, it’s kind of, I’m not sure why I’m not like, always like that.  I’m just not like that right now I guess, I don’t know why.
I:It’s alright, that’s fine.  I think I uh, well I’ll leave it at that.
R:But yeah, I mean, I’m still the same person, it’s just uh, I guess I don’ know, my mom was out there before, I guess it made me feel more comfortable and uh, I don’t know.  Don’t mean that as any offense or anything, it’s just kind of weird I guess a little bit.
I:Um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:(long pause)
I:Is it rules, is it laws? Is it the consequences of something?
R:That’s a tough question.
I:Is it how it feels?  Is it what God says?  Is it something else?
R:All of the above.  Uh, jees I don’t know.
I:Well, I’m gonna hazard a guess then, rules aren’t necessarily what makes something right and wrong.
R:That is correct because there can be –
I:You do break the rules it sounds like as long as somebody tells you it’s okay.
R:Yeah.
I:So what makes something right or wrong?
R:Uh, (long pause), if something, if you do something and I don’t know, like if you do something and it doesn’t like hurt anyone, then I guess it’s okay, gol that’s a really stupid thing.
I:Now uh, you break the speed limit and it might not hurt anyone, you go more than five miles over and you stop and get slower but it doesn’t hurt anyone to go ten miles and hour over.
R:Then I guess that’s one of the rule ones then, uh, oh jees.
I:Take your time.
R:Um, I guess you have to give me an example and I’d tell you why it’s wrong or right or something.
I:Okay, so is drinking alcohol wrong because it tastes bad, wrong because it’s against the rules, wrong because it can cause harm to somebody else.  What if you’re just popping a beer at home, you’re not gonna get drunk, nobody will know, you’re not gonna drive.
R:I think that’s perfectly fine.
I:It’s perfectly fine.
R:Yeah.
I:Okay, you just don’t.
R:I just don’t because it tastes like crap except for saki.
I:So obviously the rules, that it’s against the law to do that drinking, --
R:Which I think is also really stupid because you know, you can go and get killed but you can’t have a beer.  But that’s a completely different story.
I:So, it’s not the rules or laws necessarily, maybe sometimes it might be.
R:I guess it’s moral judgment too.
I:Moral judgment, what do you mean by that?
R:I knew that was coming.  Uh, I don’t know, like if you think about something and you think it’s okay then, oh that’s really bad because some people think really bad stuff is okay but uh, like average joe, what he thinks is right and wrong, I think you know, would probably be okay.
I:So generally speaking, you can trust the moral judgment of the people around us.
R:I think so for the most part.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Well, obviously like extreme stuff, like rape, I think that should have the death penalty but uh.
I:Why?
R:It’s just, oh it’s just, I think its worse than murder.
I:Why?
R:I just think it’s just horrible, I don’t know.  It’s just –
I:Where’d you come up with that?
R:Ever since I found out what that meant, you know, like along time ago, I just thought it was like the worst thing ever.
I:Why?
R:It’s just, I don’t know why, it’s just wrong.  I –
I:Some people would say, well it didn’t kill the person, is what they would say to that.
R:Oh, well like, but for the most part, it like ruins it, like if they’re dead, obviously it like ruins your life, you don’t have to live with it but if you’re raped you have to live with the indignity you know, the rest of your life and the memory, it just haunts you.
I:What if you never told anybody?
R:It’d still effect you.
I:True.  Besides rape and murder, any actions that are always wrong in themselves?
R:Not stealing because sometimes you have to steal like, well not now a days, but like, I’m not talking about myself but, like uh, like starving family you know, there’s a loaf of bread, go steal a loaf of bread to feed their little kids.
I:These people in New Orleans, they’re looting, but there is no law, no order, nobody stopping them.
R:Are they actually looting there?
I:Is that wrong?
R:Well, that’s a tough one because uh, for the most part it is but, I don’t know, like the stuff, where the stuff is just gonna get ruined, well, yeah, I think it’s wrong, but if the stuff is gonna get ruined, I can see why they do it though, but that’s probably not what they’re thinking.  So, yeah, I think it’s wrong.
I:Why is it wrong?
R:Because it’s not theirs.  They didn’t pay for it where they could if the really wanted, they could have gotten it.
I:But you just told me that if you’re really hungry, it sounds like stealing food was okay.
R:Yeah, but, that’s like in, that’s a need, not a want.  Like, you might want a T.V. you don’t need a T.V.  You need food.
I:Okay.
R:Because I assume you’re talking about like looting like electronics and stuff like that, you’re not talking about like stealing like –
I:Some guy stole a bunch of shirts, why would you do that?
R:Oh, my gosh, a bunch of shirts?
I:Where to do you, where have you acquired how you think about morality?
R:I guess my parents mainly.

column588: The respondent plans to use an inheritance of $100,000 primarily to buy a car and pay for education, influenced by the necessity of transportation and the importance of a degree for job prospects, while also expressing a desire for parental support and a fear of the unknown in college life, alongside a strong moral compass shaped by their parents' teachings against drinking and drugs.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t know. I just know if it is good or not.  I have always been taught that stealing is wrong and stuff like that. I just know I guess.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Easy.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Pretty much the same.
I:Why?
R:It has really changed. Right or wrong has really changed in 3 years. I guess I’ve matured more, but I still know what is right and wrong.
I:Have your moral views changed in the past 2 years?
R:What do you mean by moral views?
I:Like how view what is morally right or wrong?
R:That is pretty much the same.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Something that doesn’t hurt anyone and good things come if it is the right thing to do.  If you hurt someone or something bad happens because it is wrong to do.
I:What kinds of consequences would make something wrong?
R:If it negatively affects someone I mean it is a bad thing.  I can’t really think of something to describe that.
I:So if it doesn’t negatively affect someone to you it is not wrong?
R:I don’t know I need an example.  There are some things that don’t negatively affect people, but are still wrong so I don’t know.  It’s kind of a difficult question.
I:So if someone steals something, but it doesn’t really affect the company because they have insurance and maybe it didn’t hurt anyone-no one was there and no one saw it and they really needed it for their family, then what?
R:Well then, if they really needed it for their family and it doesn’t hurt anyone.  It is wrong, but I mean -what are they stealing? In your example what are they stealing?
I:Well, do you see different things as different?
R:Yeah, it is obviously wrong stealing is wrong, but it isn’t affecting them.
I:So what if they were stealing medical supplies?
R:Yeah, that is OK.
I:What if they are stealing money?
R:For what?
I:Just to provide for their family.  Their family is poor and they don’t have any money.
R:That’s a tough one. It is wrong.  I don’t know. That’s a tough question.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:I don’t know.  Maybe my parents a little bit, but honestly I don’t know.

It has really changed. Right or wrong has really changed in 3 years. I guess I’ve matured more, but I still know what is right and wrong. What do you mean by moral views? That is pretty much the same.  Something that doesn’t hurt anyone and good things come if it is the right thing to do.  If you hurt someone or something bad happens because it is wrong to do. If it negatively affects someone I mean it is a bad thing.  I can’t really think of something to describe that. I don’t know I need an example.  There are some things that don’t negatively affect people, but are still wrong so I don’t know.  It’s kind of a difficult question. Well then, if they really needed it for their family and it doesn’t hurt anyone.  It is wrong, but I mean -what are they stealing? In your example what are they stealing? Yeah, it is obviously wrong stealing is wrong, but it isn’t affecting them. Yeah, that is OK. For what? That’s a tough one. It is wrong.  I don’t know. That’s a tough question.  I don’t know.  Maybe my parents a little bit, but honestly I don’t know.
column591: The respondent prefers to invest a hypothetical inheritance rather than spend it impulsively, believes in a clear understanding of right and wrong based on upbringing, acknowledges the complexity of moral dilemmas, and ultimately values personal happiness and doing what they believe is right over religious or social influences.

column589:
I:And how do you normally decide or know what is good or bad or right or wrong in life?
R:I go with my gut feeling, I go with my heart.  Like my heart tells me a lot of things.  Like, I can tell if something is wrong, because my heart will start pounding real fast and I can tell that something’s not right.  And then if I know it’s good, I would be very calm, like okay, totally different person, but if I know something is wrong, I’m very iffy about it and my, I start really thinking different, so that’s how I make decisions.
I:So it’s like an internal thing that you have.  Okay.  And where do you think that came from for you?  Like where do you think the ability to know those things?
R:I have no clue.  I think the only person that would know that is God himself.
I:Do you remember always being that way?  Being able to tell like that, what was right or wrong?
R:Yeah.  Younger, when I was younger, I used to feel that way.  When I know I did something wrong.  I would just be thinking like, oh, I know I was wrong, I know I’m getting a butt whipping and sure enough I’d get a butt whipping, so.  I would know it just from that   inner instinct.
I:So, for you then, do you think it gets easier or harder to make those decisions about right and wrong as you get older?
R:I think it pretty much gets a little bit harder just because it’s not about just me anymore, I have someone younger than me, so it gets harder because not only do I have to think for myself, I have to think for my family and I have to think for my daughter.  So, it’s kinda, it gets difficult.
I:And what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  Like what is it that actually makes something a right or a wrong thing.
R:I’m not too sure.
I:Like do you think it’s more external things like the consequences, how the person feels about it?
R:I think it’s consequences.
I:Okay, like what will happen if you do it?
R:Yeah, if you do this, you will get a butt whooping.  That’s how I look at it with my daughter.  I set her down and I say if you touch Mommy’s, if you touch Mommy’s computer, you will see this belt hit your booty, so she thinks about it and she try to do something else, so I think it’s consequences that really makes it.
I:Makes it right or wrong.
R:Yep.

I set her down and I say if you touch Mommy’s, if you touch Mommy’s computer, you will see this belt hit your booty, so she thinks about it and she try to do something else, so I think it’s consequences that really makes it. Yep.  I have no clue.  I think the only person that would know that is God himself.
column591: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on gut feelings and intuition, influenced by a belief in God and the consequences of actions, while also considering the needs of her daughter and the importance of moral guidance from scripture.

column583:
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:What do you mean what makes something right or wrong?
I:Why is doing one thing right verses doing another thing wrong?
R:I mean it depends on what kind of situation you’re in.  It really does. Like, like, the situation is like, say my friends is going out to go partying and do drugs or whatever, um, it would be up to me to tag along.  But in reality I know in the back of my head, I know what is right.  To let them go and stop hanging out with that crowd.
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:From my upbringing.
I:From the way your mom raised you?
R:Yeah, the way she raised me.  So it depends on how you were raised, if you were raised, I mean you ain’t got to live in no suburban area to know what’s right or wrong to know what to do in life.  To be successful in life or whatever.  If you were raised right, then you were just raised right.  I mean there’s rich people that’s got problems.  Everybody’s got problems.  There’s kids at school killing up their classmates and teachers, I mean it depends on what your upbringing was.
I:And maybe you could just tell me a little bit what you mean by raised right?  I mean I think I know what you mean, I just want you to explain it a little bit more.
R:Uh, basically, um, like my mom, get home from school, get off your school clothes, get that books out, get ready for dinner, I mean, that type of stuff, don’t let them hang out, run the streets, do what they want to do, that type of stuff.  I mean you have to have like um, rules and regulations. Every parent should have their rules and regulations, and if you don’t buy, you don’t live by those rules and regulations, it will just lead you to the wrong way.
I:Do you think that everybody should have the same sorts of rules and regulations?  Like your mom should have the same as somebody else?
R:I don’t  think that cause everybody has different beliefs, and they’re all, like I said, everybody has different beliefs, some parents don’t believe in what my mom believes in.  Like the hanging out and that’s one of my mom’s main beliefs, get home, get out your school clothes, get ready to do your chores, do your homework, get ready for dinner, watch some TV, ready to start the day all over.  Everybody’s parent’s don’t do that.  Some people’s parents would rather just, I mean there’s two of hard working parents out there and they don’t have time to do that stuff, but somewhere in your life you have to find that time to be able to do that, if not, your child will end up like the trench coat mafia kid, or a rapist or a killer or in prison, and I mean it’s all about you upbringing, if you’re raised right then.  And I’m not going to say everybody goes down that road, cause I would be sitting here lying if I said, cause there’s people that were raised better than me, and still just messed up in the head, I mean why, I don’t know, but, you know, it’s just the way people are I guess.
I:Okay you mentioned several things there, the first one you said was something mafia kid?
R:Yeah.
I:Is that a local gang or?
R:No, remember in Colorado, they called themselves the trench coat mafia?
I:Oh the trench coat, yeah, yeah, yeah.  I forgot.
R:You know where they killed the teacher and the kid.
I:Yeah, I gotcha.
R:I mean so some of the kids. I  Yeah, so some of them formed their own little, Yeah.  I mean parents don’t look into that kind of stuff.  My mom does, about all, she, I don’t know, you have to work, and hard, and whatever, no matter what it is, know that you have children and the reality, your world revolves around them, your world revolves around them, no matter what because by the time you die, or my mom dies or whatever, or I die before her, she’s always going to remember, she’s going to have scholarships on the wall and she raised me right.  And after she raised me it’s up to me to choose the road I took.  But as long as she knows in the back of her head what she did for me was right and, I go that wrong road, that was my choice.  But like I mean, like the kids shooting up the schools, somewhere in there they don’t have no family dinners or something.  I mean there was something wrong, those kids were messed up in their heads, they shouldn’t go kill innocent people or, it’s just wrong.  They don’t take time with their kids.
I:In any given situation, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong?  Is it just based on what you’re saying how you’re raised up and stuff?
R:Basically I’ll sit down and think what would my mom tell me.  Sit down and think what she would say if I do this.  How would she feel about it.
I:Do you have any examples maybe, recently in your life?
R:No.  I mean I don’t do wrong, I live by my mom’s rules and regulations, I mean that’s the only way you’re going to live longer.  That’s what I said, some kids out there that really don’t, that have what I don’t’ have and still don’t’ care like I said, and still go mess up, and turned out to be transients and all kind of wild stuff.
I:Do you think in those cases those kids, because they’re, let’s say their parents let them do whatever and they, do you think those kids don’t know right from wrong?  Or do they know anyway?
R:They still know right from wrong but you know, um, oh hell my parents don’t care if I actually die.
I:Yeah.
R:That’s how I feel about it.

column585: The respondent makes decisions based on their upbringing and the consequences they observe in others, particularly their family, emphasizing the importance of parental guidance and personal choice in distinguishing right from wrong, while also acknowledging that individuals ultimately know their own moral path.

column583:
I:Okay.  Um, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Ah, my values, my religion.  Yeah, um, I really think, I just really believe what, I mean, what the, my religion believes.  In morals and I see why, I don’t know, some people they, they don’t see why and but I just really think I, I see why.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:What do I think it is that makes something right or wrong.  I think, I think in your heart if you feel that this might hurt someone or might not do something good for you or if, if it isn’t, if it isn’t a good thing—I don’t know, I just think that you can, if you’re not too damaged by the world around you I think people can lose a sense of what’s right and wrong from they, are too like, when they just, like people who listen to screaming music, I think that it ruins their, their nerves and just their, any sense of, of like, I think if a person, like for example, if a person  there’s a, a girl a student with my, my teacher, and she listens to this I don’t know what they’re called but they, what they do is they scream you know and she’s, she’s a classical musician and after listening to so much screaming, she really has no sense of how to be musical, like she doesn’t, she doesn’t realize the importance of softs  and the beauty of silence and I don’t know.
I:Okay.  Um, how do you decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:What’s in my heart, what I feel is true and what I’ve learned through my religion is, is right and what I think will benefit me for the best.  You know or give me a challenge, you know, I don’t, I don’t know, that’s I think, how.
column584: Ah, my values, my religion.  Yeah, um, I really think, I just really believe what, I mean, what the, my religion believes.  In morals and I see why, I don’t know, some people they, they don’t see why and but I just really think I, I see why. What do I think it is that makes something right or wrong.  I think, I think in your heart if you feel that this might hurt someone or might not do something good for you or if, if it isn’t, if it isn’t a good thing—I don’t know, I just think that you can, if you’re not too damaged by the world around you I think people can lose a sense of what’s right and wrong from they, are too like, when they just, like people who listen to screaming music, I think that it ruins their, their nerves and just their, any sense of, of like, I think if a person, like for example, if a person  there’s a, a girl a student with my, my teacher, and she listens to this I don’t know what they’re called but they, what they do is they scream you know and she’s, she’s a classical musician and after listening to so much screaming, she really has no sense of how to be musical, like she doesn’t, she doesn’t realize the importance of softs  and the beauty of silence and I don’t know. What’s in my heart, what I feel is true and what I’ve learned through my religion is, is right and what I think will benefit me for the best.  You know or give me a challenge, you know, I don’t, I don’t know, that’s I think, how.
column585: The respondent reflects on a past experience where they felt conflicted about their values regarding a friend's sexuality, ultimately deciding to remain silent out of respect for their friend's identity, while also expressing a belief that morality is rooted in their religious values and a sense of right and wrong that they feel is diminishing in society today.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um, by what I have been taught in my childhood.  By my parents, by my church, my our scriptures and the Book of Mormon and also by the spirit.  What I feel is right or wrong.  Sometimes it’s obvious.
I:Could you describe what you mean by what you feel is right or wrong?  Could you describe what you mean to me?
R:Well uh,
I:Which uh, some people would say if it feels good to me I’m going to do something, is that what you mean?
R:Yeah, uh,
I:Do you mean feel good in what way though?
R:Like I feel at peace.
I:Oh, okay.
R:Sometimes I have to pray to get that feeling, if it’s a really tough decision, tough question, I maybe fast, I pray, just so I could be humble enough and prayerful enough so that I could hear, I could tell what he would like me to do.  Sometimes I just have to go with it you know.
I:Okay.  Okay.
R:But yeah, it’s usually a peaceful feeling in my heart.
I:Okay.
R:Or I receive an answer through someone else, that yeah, that would be a right thing to do.  And a lot of time I’m assured by my decision in what happened after I decided to do that.  I’m like oh yes, I’m happy that I did that.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?  Or maybe stayed the same?
R:I think it’s maybe, I think it’s kind of the same.  The yes, the things that I’ve decided are a little more life changing, who I’m going to marry and things like that, so I think maybe it’s harder the more substantial choices, they might hurt you, but I think it’s kind of, since I’ve been following and keeping and doing the things that I think are right, I think it’s been easy for me to make those choices.  So.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Well what your opinion is on what is right and wrong, which can of course vary.  But then also I think the laws that are set in our nation and in our church, that helps me decide what’s right or wrong, if it’s hurting someone, I can know if it’s right or wrong, um, so yeah.
I:Okay.  So this feeling that you were talking about, does that help you in convince you in thinking that something is right or wrong, cause you said for you that varies from one person to the next.  Other people might not have that feeling I guess that you’re talking about, spiritual feelings.
R:Yeah.  I think so.  I think sometimes the Spirit is felt in many different ways.  But then I also feel that um, everyone can get, and receive guidance from the spirit.  I once heard someone give a talk from our church that said when he met the girl of his dreams, he wasn’t waiting for a yes, no.  He felt right to him, and said okay I’m going with this heavenly father, unless you stop me and think it’s not the right thing, so please do this.  So yeah, sometimes you don’t feel exactly if it’s right or it’s wrong.
I:Okay.
R:I think people can tend, everyone can feel it, just in their own way.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?  And if so, can you give me some examples.
R:I think having an affair, I think that’s always wrong.
I:What makes that wrong?
R:Because um, you are deceiving your family, you are switching your love to not your wife who you are married to and you’ve made covenants in the temple to be only with them, and not you’re breaking those covenants, it’s not being honest with your wife, it’s just very wrong to me.  It’s hurtful, it hurts others around you.  It’s not following the commandments, and the, I don’t see how that could ever be seen as a good thing or the best choice or the right thing to do that will help people.
I:Have you seen circumstances where that’s been difficult for families to deal with?
R:Yes.  My mom’s best friend, her husband cheated on her, and they divorced and he lived just with this girl that he had this affair with and now she had to go full time to work and couldn’t spend the time with her children.  Her son had a really hard time with it, and um, he questioned the church and he questioned many things because of the actions I believe because of the actions, although he has decided to be righteous in the end, it was a very tough decision for him.
I:So this man was a Latter Day Saint also?
R:Yes, he was a Latter Day Saint, they were married in the temple as well, although he was ex-communicated
I:Because of the affair or?
R:Because of the affair, yes.
I:Okay.  Can I ask you, if you don’t mind, if this isn’t too personal, when you see a situation like that does that challenge your faith or call into question the power of the temple or the covenants that you’ve talked about?
R:No, cause it’s not to do with the covenants, it’s to do with the people who are keeping covenants.  They weren’t keeping covenants, although she was, he wasn’t, it just makes me actually stronger in my faith, just to know that I need to be righteous cause I know this could happen to anyone.  They were good people they just strayed, he did.  Um, and so, it didn’t call into question my faith, it just made me want to follow even more.
I:You may have answered this, but I’ll ask this anyway, from where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Uh, well I was born into the church, and um, I went to church every Sunday, I went to Sunday school, my parents they taught me, it was my decision when I was 8 whether to be baptized in the church which I decided yes I would, but yes.

column588: The respondent would use an inheritance to help their parents with debt, donate to their church as part of their religious obligations, and secure their children's education, while their moral decision-making is influenced by teachings from their parents, church, and personal spiritual feelings, emphasizing the importance of maintaining consistent moral principles despite societal changes.
column589:
I:That’s too bad. How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:How I feel? I can usually get a sense for if it might not be the best thing, also going by what I've learned because I have a testimony in my church so I think they have great advices  my church says all those things and also praying and discussing with my husband.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It's pretty easy I think. I actually haven’t really had a hard time with that.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past couple of years?
R:I’d say it's just the same.
I:Really?
R:Yeah. I never had a hard time like or was never in an environment that was like, “Oh, you should have a drink of this,” or anything like that but…
I:And why not?
R:Because of I guess who I hung out with. I guess being in Utah, I don’t have to worry about it as much, although.
I:Although yeah. I've been in Utah for a week, there are a lot of people here.
R:Actually my middle school that they’re at, that I went to in my first year, it had the worst drug problem. Yeah, my middle school. I guess, I wasn’t attracted to people that might cause harm or were doing bad stuff and they weren’t attracted to me so it just didn’t happen.
I:So you’d say it's always been relatively easy for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Yeah. Well what I think is right and wrong.
I:Have your views of what was right and wrong changed at all over the past few years?
R:No. I say they become more defined, but like focused.
I:Yeah. What do you mean?
R:Like for instance, my church has always said, marry someone like a return missionary and someone who has your values. Which I always just thought that, “Yeah, return missionary, someone who’s a member of the church”, so that was the fuzzy focus, right? And when I met my husband before he was my husband, I realized how much more like he really did have the values that I had. There can be many people in the church that don’t have your same like values or what how they, what they want to do with their family and how they see, what their political views are. I was just amazed at how we’re really we're so much alike, and so that was more of a focused. So I think I'm more like more picky.
I:More picky?
R:Picky.
I:All right. That makes sense. What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:What is it that makes something right or wrong? The belief that there is a God I think has a lot to do with that. Because if there was no God and in order to believe there is something right and wrong, you’ll have to believe it's right or wrong per se because it just helps things go better or doesn’t help things go better like a society. You know if you said that murder was okay, well your society might be running without….like there being a God. If you believe there is a God, you believe that means you have to be doing well and he has set commandments for us for what is right and what is not right. Did that answer it?
I:So where do you think you got your moral views from? Where do they come from?
R:Well, my parents taught me. Is that…?
I:Yeah.
R:Joseph* who started it, do that’s where…

column591: The respondent plans to pay off debt and tithing, buy a car, and save, while making decisions about right and wrong based on feelings, church teachings, and discussions with her husband, emphasizing the importance of divine commandments and the influence of her upbringing.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good or bad, right or wrong in life?
R:I read the Baha’i writings.  Yeah.  That’s totally how I know.  Sometimes I ask people like the Baha’i faith says that you should consult.  So sometimes I consult.  But I usually find that most people that you consult with don’t really know much about anything.  I don’t know.  I’ve found that.  Like, I’ll go ask people, should I give my dad $12,000?  And they’ll say “Yeah, because he raised you.”  And I’ll think that’s retarded because: he brought me into the world, of course he has to raise me.  So sometimes I don’t do that much, but I’ll just read the writings, see what they say.  That’s how I decide.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:In general, it’s easy.  Whether you want to, sometimes, is harder.  For example, even here.  Here certain people come in, you know they’re not going to tip you.  And so sometimes you just aren’t very excited.  But you have to remember, you have to be nice to everybody.  That sort of thing.  It’s not always easy. But I know.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:I think it’s gotten easier.  Because I think knowing most of my life, has kept me from making bad decisions that would make it harder now.  So probably if I dug myself a hole it might be kind of hard.  But I haven’t done that.
I:Hm. Have your views changed at all in the past couple of years?
R:I don’t know, I mean maybe just views of what life is like because I’ve moved out.  Now I have to make money.  It’s different to know what it’s like to earn money rather than having everything provided.  But, not so much.  I don’t know.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um.  I would say it’s the teaching of Baha’i.  I would say that all right comes from God and all wrong comes from yourself.  So sometimes I’ll think, well what would I do?  And what would maybe God tell me to do?  Sometimes that’s how I decide.  But that’s where I think it all comes from.
I:Okay.  Um.  What about consequences or feelings?  Some people say that you figure out what’s right based on whether the consequences are good for you…or whether you feel right about it.
R:Um.  I think consequence doesn’t matter.  Yeah.  There are things that may…if you’re dying of hunger, don’t steal.  The consequences .
I:So it’s really God’s will of some sort, but you would say God sort of…
R:Well his will being maybe what he tells you to do maybe during that day and age.  If he says don’t get politically involved, that creates disunity.  Maybe it would be really gratifying to go out there and campaign or something and prove people wrong but that only satisfies the desire in this world.  In reality, I’m spirit.  This world doesn’t matter.  So I don’t, I don’t do that.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  In terms of your faith.  Like what..we’re going to talk about religion more specifically later but…in terms of your conviction that it is sort of this source of teaching that is the basis for morality.  How did you learn that?
R:I would say through the writings.  Like, the Baha’i laws we believe in, and then there’s this guy who kind of expounds upon things more.  So it’s more like his explanation that makes things more clear.
I:Okay.  And is this something your dad taught you while growing up or did you?
R:Well, they always try to teach you that, in the Baha’i faith you don’t become it because your parents did.  So I did read all the books, I read the history, I decided: that’s the right thing.

column591: The respondent primarily relies on the teachings of the Baha'i faith and personal reflection to determine right from wrong, emphasizing that moral guidance comes from God rather than social influences or personal feelings, while also expressing a belief in the importance of consulting scripture and the idea that true happiness aligns with following divine guidance.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Well, um, either experience or I don’t know, gut feeling or if you don’t know, trying to base it on some biblical principle.
I:So it’s like an internal feeling usually?
R:Mostly.
I:And in general, that that’s an easy or a hard thing for you to do?
R:I would say in general it’s easy, I mean I encounter situations every now and then where I feel like you get uneasy like what am I walking into and then it’s not really until you get into the middle that you’re like well I didn’t see that coming kind of thing, but.
I:So what about as you get older, do you feel like it’s easier or harder as you get older to make?
R:Easier.
I:Easier?  Okay and any reasons you think it’s easier?
R:I think just like what I was saying with, I'm like quicker to just shut certain things down when I get an uneasy feeling about it and just not even allow the opportunity to present itself.
I:So you just trust it more?
R:Yeah.
I:Yeah, okay. What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  What is it that makes it a right or wrong thing?
R:These are just not things you think about!
I:I know, that’s why we ask them?
R:What makes it right or wrong?  I don’t know.  I base everything on the Bible anymore so if it doesn’t line up with the word of God, it’s wrong.
I:Okay so you, where do you think that your moral views have come from, again?  You’ve kind of hit on it, but so where do you think you acquired your morality and your moral views?
R:Some from my upbringing and then a lot of my moral values if I thought I had them, I would may break them before I got in church, I believe in that, oops, kind of thing.  But I think a lot of them I’ve learned more just in reading the Bible and reestablishing my view points and my values.
column590: Well, um, either experience or I don’t know, gut feeling or if you don’t know, trying to base it on some biblical principle. Mostly. I would say in general it’s easy, I mean I encounter situations every now and then where I feel like you get uneasy like what am I walking into and then it’s not really until you get into the middle that you’re like well I didn’t see that coming kind of thing, but. Easier. I think just like what I was saying with, I'm like quicker to just shut certain things down when I get an uneasy feeling about it and just not even allow the opportunity to present itself. Yeah.  These are just not things you think about! What makes it right or wrong?  I don’t know.  I base everything on the Bible anymore so if it doesn’t line up with the word of God, it’s wrong.  Some from my upbringing and then a lot of my moral values if I thought I had them, I would may break them before I got in church, I believe in that, oops, kind of thing.  But I think a lot of them I’ve learned more just in reading the Bible and reestablishing my view points and my values.
column591: The respondent looks up to their pastor's wife for her passion and ability to inspire hope, bases their moral decisions primarily on biblical principles, believes that societal issues stem from a lack of God-focused lifestyles, and prefers to make decisions according to scripture rather than personal gain or happiness.

column583:
I:Right.  Um, where do your views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, I think to some extent they come from my parents.  But at least within the past few years they’ve come more from me.  Because I’ve, I’ve gotten almost where I can analyze in situations, like how would I feel if that was me?  Like you know what, like, I’m, I’m mature enough to think of the other side of things.  You know like is it the best choice or you know if I do this how is it gonna make so and so feel?  And would I want that to be me?
I:So what is it you think makes something right or makes something wrong?
R:Um,  I think, I think, it has to do with people getting hurt.  And I don’t mean necessarily physically hurt.  An example with robbery, like you know, in kindergarten when somebody steals your favorite pencil, it’s just a pencil, you’re not hurt, it’s not the end of the world.  But to you it is, you know that was very important to you, you feel violated, you feel like that was not theirs, why did they touch it and you feel like nothing else is safe. You know like you lose your sense of security, I mean, not necessarily over a pencil, but you know, otherwise speaking, um, things like that, like if someone’s getting hurt in a situation, most of the time it’s wrong.
I:Okay.
R:You know, so.
I:So it sound like your standard of right and wrong now would be like the golden rule.  Do unto others as you want them to do unto you.
R:Yeah, yeah.  Like how would I feel?
I:So how would I feel, if I would feel crummy then I’m not gonna do it—
R:Yeah.
I:And it’d be wrong to do it to somebody else.
R:Uh-huh, basically.
column584: Um, I think to some extent they come from my parents.  But at least within the past few years they’ve come more from me.  Because I’ve, I’ve gotten almost where I can analyze in situations, like how would I feel if that was me?  Like you know what, like, I’m, I’m mature enough to think of the other side of things.  You know like is it the best choice or you know if I do this how is it gonna make so and so feel?  And would I want that to be me? Um,  I think, I think, it has to do with people getting hurt.  And I don’t mean necessarily physically hurt.  An example with robbery, like you know, in kindergarten when somebody steals your favorite pencil, it’s just a pencil, you’re not hurt, it’s not the end of the world.  But to you it is, you know that was very important to you, you feel violated, you feel like that was not theirs, why did they touch it and you feel like nothing else is safe. You know like you lose your sense of security, I mean, not necessarily over a pencil, but you know, otherwise speaking, um, things like that, like if someone’s getting hurt in a situation, most of the time it’s wrong. You know, so. Yeah, yeah.  Like how would I feel? Yeah. Uh-huh, basically.
column585: The respondent reflects on their decision to spend the night at their boyfriend's house despite parental disapproval, emphasizing their trust in themselves and the belief that it was more beneficial for a grieving friend, while also acknowledging that their views on right and wrong have evolved from parental influence to personal analysis and empathy for others.
column586:
I:Um, okay, lets see, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I go a lot on my instinct, if I feel guilty about it it’s probably wrong.
I:Okay.
R:Um, I go on what my parents have taught me, um what other you know, like other people have gone through and they’ve told me about it and I think, oh well maybe I shouldn’t do that.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to make like those decisions about what is wrong and right?
R:Pretty easy.
I:Pretty easy, okay. Has it gotten easier or harder over the last couple of years?
R:I think easier.
I:Really?
R:Yeah, because I just feel more comfortable with myself and my you know, I make more decisions in my life so I’m not as like, my god what is this gonna mean, it’s gonna change my life so I.
I:With more practice almost huh?
R:Yeah yeah, exactly, so.
I:Okay, well if you think of anything we’ll come back to it. What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, I think it’s wrong if, it’s like wrong in varying degrees as to how it hurts other people and how it hurts yourself, like um, if you do something and it benefits you  either short term or long term, but it hurts other people at all, it’s usually wrong.
I:Okay.
R:But it also depends on how it hurts them you know, like stealing is wrong because you know, it benefits you, hey I got this for free but, you know, it messes up the person who owns the store, maybe the cashier who’s working is gonna get fired because something was taken you know, on their watch, or whatever, um so I guess that’s mostly, or sometimes things are wrong just for your own self, like wrong because you know better or like wrong because you know it’s gonna turn out badly later on, even if you just feel like doing it right now.
I:So it has a lot to do with like consequences and what’s going on there?
R:Yeah, yeah.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Hmm, probably not, I’m one of those people that like sees it both ways, like murder is wrong but you know, but f it’s self defense it’s not wrong and stuff like that.
I:Yeah, okay.
R:Umm so, I don’t know if there’s anything that is like always always wrong.
I:So it depends on the situation and that kind of stuff.
R:Yeah.
I:Okay, where do you think your acquired your moral views from?  You were talking some about your parents.
R:Um, probably my parents a lot, parents, friends, um I guess mostly just parents.
I:And did, is it stuff you talked about at home or how did they teach you about morality?
R:God, I don’t even remember  just been ingrained.
I:For a long period of time.
R:Yeah  it’s just been ingrained in my head where, talking about it, don’t steal because and then they would tell me why, I don’t know I think they just taught me how to feel guilty from and early age so.
I:Was there anything that they taught you that you disagree with or you don’t do now?
R:Um, nothing I can think of.

Um, nothing I can think of.
column588: The respondent primarily relies on their intuition and the moral teachings from their parents to determine right and wrong, emphasizing the importance of considering the consequences of actions on others, while also expressing a desire for societal values to shift towards greater empathy and community support.
column589:
I:So, one second, um, —so how would you say you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um, I’ve gone back and forth throughout my life.  When I was younger it was what would my parents say?  Now that I'm older I base it sort of more on how does it make me sort of consider both choices, how do I think I would react to the one, how would I react to the other?  Generally if it makes me really nervous or if I'm really unsure about it or it makes me feel kind of guilty or bad it’s probably a wrong choice.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Pretty easy.
I:Do you think deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the last couple of years?
R:I’d say probably harder, just sort of going to college, meeting so many different people and hearing so many different perspectives, it’s opened my eyes to other ideas that I hadn’t thought of before.  I took an ethics class, medical ethics, which was ridiculous.  You know we had some topics where I was like I have absolutely no idea either way, um, so it’s gotten harder yet I feel more confident in the choices I make but I spend more time considering.
I:Okay, so just because you have more information or something else?
R:Um, I think because I’ve had more information, I’ve had more life experiences, um, I can draw on past choices that I’ve made that may have been wrong, so.
I:Would you say your views about right and wrong have changed at all the last couple years?
R:I don’t think so, no not big right and wrongs, maybe little tiny ones but nothing major.
I:So what would you say you think makes something right or wrong?
R:Um,  I guess it, I mean it varies from situation to situation, it’s sort of things that are wrong unnecessarily hurting other people or yourself, um, and things that are right don’t necessarily not hurt anyone, but usually it’s not, something can be right and someone gets hurt unintentionally, that sort of thing.
I:Okay, um, so um, so do you think that something could be, could help someone and still be wrong?
R:Yeah—
I:And so, but you think also that something could be right and still hurt someone—
R:And still hurt someone, yeah.  It’s a hard line to draw.  It is definitely not black and white.
I:Okay, so if it’s not about hurting someone or helping someone per se, can you think of a situation, like if there’s something that would be say um, right but would hurt someone, what makes it right?  Like can you think of an example of a situation where that would be the case?
R:I guess I sort of believe sometimes in the  community versus the good of the, you know, so if it helps 8,000 people and one person dies in it or one person is injured, I would think that it’s right.
I:And then what about wrong?  Can you think of an example where someone can do something wrong but it still helps somebody or might helps people?
R:I’d say a lot of situations dealing with money where um, a lot of people are helped but sort of the whole idea behind it isn’t right and it certainly wouldn’t, wouldn’t be okay in other situations.  Sort of like it worked this time but kind of only by chance.
I:Like something someone got away with it, is what you mean?
R:Yeah.
I:Like a bank robbery or something.
R:Yeah, it doesn’t really hurt anybody but it’s wrong, it’s not your money and—
I:What would make a bank robbery wrong?
R:Is, I mean it’s not your money, I mean you have absolutely no right to it, I believe in working for your money.  Um, and it does indirectly hurt people, it’s not like people see it come out of their bank accounts or anything but that money has to come from somewhere so somebody’s going to adjust or somebody might lose their job over some mistake that allowed you to, I don’t know how it works but something like that.
I:Where would you say your ideas about morality or what’s right and wrong came from?  Like what influenced you, or?
R:A lot of it’s my parents.  It’s never really been; I guess they never like sat us down and said this is this and that is that.  It’s just sort of lead by example and when we were younger, discussing current events, things like that that we gained their opinion and definitely influenced me.

Now that I'm older I base it sort of more on how does it make me sort of consider both choices, how do I think I would react to the one, how would I react to the other?  Generally if it makes me really nervous or if I'm really unsure about it or it makes me feel kind of guilty or bad it’s probably a wrong choice. Pretty easy. Yeah— And still hurt someone, yeah.  It’s a hard line to draw.  It is definitely not black and white. I guess I sort of believe sometimes in the  community versus the good of the, you know, so if it helps 8,000 people and one person dies in it or one person is injured, I would think that it’s right. I’d say a lot of situations dealing with money where um, a lot of people are helped but sort of the whole idea behind it isn’t right and it certainly wouldn’t, wouldn’t be okay in other situations.  Sort of like it worked this time but kind of only by chance. Yeah. Yeah, it doesn’t really hurt anybody but it’s wrong, it’s not your money and— Is, I mean it’s not your money, I mean you have absolutely no right to it, I believe in working for your money.  Um, and it does indirectly hurt people, it’s not like people see it come out of their bank accounts or anything but that money has to come from somewhere so somebody’s going to adjust or somebody might lose their job over some mistake that allowed you to, I don’t know how it works but something like that.  A lot of it’s my parents.  It’s never really been; I guess they never like sat us down and said this is this and that is that.  It’s just sort of lead by example and when we were younger, discussing current events, things like that that we gained their opinion and definitely influenced me.
column591: The respondent would use an inheritance of $100,000 primarily to pay off debts and possibly create a bonding experience with family, while their moral decision-making has evolved from parental influence to personal reflection on choices, with a strong emphasis on the importance of not causing unnecessary harm to others and a belief in the relativity of morality shaped by cultural perspectives.

column583:
I:Okay.  Do, uh…where do these views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, family.  Family life maybe.  School. Stuff like that.
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, my parents.
I:Um…what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um…probably the person who chooses to do it or don’t do it.
I:So if a person just decides that it’s right, then it’s right?
R:Um…no, not really, not like that.  Um, if it’s right, then maybe someone, if you think it’s right and then someone else, maybe not, maybe if they’re like good or bad, depending on what their background is, but if they believe it’s right too and you believe it’s right then maybe it’s okay.
I:So you think that if enough people believe that something’s right then it’s right, is that what you’re saying or no?
R:I think so.
I:Okay, let me ask you, I don’t know, so if the majority of people in the United States say…agreed that, um, you know, people who are on welfare should, I don’t know, be not allowed to have children or something like that, do you think that would be right?
R:No.
I:And what would make it wrong if…
R:Cause uh…
I:If the majority of the people wanted to do it, why?
R:Because a program like that was built to help people who really need the help.  For people who can’t support themselves and if they go against that that would be a little unethical.
I:So what if people in the society just wanted to change their mind and decided they wanted to do something different?
R:Then that would probably be wrong and a lot of people would be angry with that.
I:What do you think would make it wrong, like what makes it wrong, if the majority of the people wanted to do it, what makes it wrong?
R:Uh the fact that they just want to get up and do this without having any justifiable cause to do it.  You can’t just, you can’t really always go on the majority.
I:What, why, how do you know, if the majority is wrong, how do you know?
R:You don’t unless you get different views and opinions from other people.
I:And how can you judge between those opinions?
R:I don’t know, it’s up to the people really I guess.
I:So one person could decide that it’s right and another person could decide it’s wrong and, would they both be right?
R:In some ways they could be and in some ways they could be wrong, both of them.
column584: Um, family.  Family life maybe.  School. Stuff like that. Um, my parents. Um…probably the person who chooses to do it or don’t do it. Um…no, not really, not like that.  Um, if it’s right, then maybe someone, if you think it’s right and then someone else, maybe not, maybe if they’re like good or bad, depending on what their background is, but if they believe it’s right too and you believe it’s right then maybe it’s okay. I think so. No. Cause uh… Because a program like that was built to help people who really need the help.  For people who can’t support themselves and if they go against that that would be a little unethical. Then that would probably be wrong and a lot of people would be angry with that. Uh the fact that they just want to get up and do this without having any justifiable cause to do it.  You can’t just, you can’t really always go on the majority. You don’t unless you get different views and opinions from other people. I don’t know, it’s up to the people really I guess. In some ways they could be and in some ways they could be wrong, both of them.
column585: The respondent makes decisions based on personal choice and peer pressure, reflecting on past actions like smoking weed and stealing beer for social acceptance, while acknowledging that their views on right and wrong are influenced by their parents and the belief that morality is subjective and varies among individuals.

column584: Um, I think that ah, the reason why, I think that my right and wrong is determined by the way I’ve been brought up.  I’ve been brought up to know, I’ve been brought up in a way where it’s been drilled into my head that this is right and that is wrong and there is no in between kind of thing you know. Yeah.  And by my family as well, like outside of my parents. Yeah.  And um, so ah, in, in some ways I know some people that would say that they um, agree with that but in my situation, I think that no, but I know that— I, I don’t think that it’s like you know, it’s all relative kind of thing, I, I disagree, I think, I know what’s right and what’s wrong. It’s been drilled into my head, you know kind of thing, I’ve been brought up to be able to determine one from the other, however, there are some teenagers in today’s society that I know of that would disagree with me.  I think it’s all, it all depends on who you’re hanging out with at the time.  And um, how you were brought up.
column585: The respondent reflects on a past experience where they chose to go along with friends instead of following their conscience, leading to feelings of guilt and regret, and emphasizes that their sense of right and wrong has been shaped by their upbringing and social influences, particularly from family, while acknowledging the pressure from peers to engage in risky behaviors like drug use and underage drinking.
column586:
I:Oh, okay, alright.  Um, tell me this how do you decide or know what’s good or bad?  In life.
R:I think that um, I was raised, thankfully in a house with incredibly good morals.  I think that my parents have raised me to be a very morally and emotionally sound person.  Strong and sound, and um, because I am a God-fearing person, because I have such a close knit family, um, because, um, for whatever reason I always know that my dad know exactly what I’m doing, which is just terrifying to me, um, I have a very strong conscience, and I, I know, what would make my parents proud and what wouldn’t. And I know what would make me proud of myself, even more importantly, and what wouldn’t. I know what, I think, and even, I think what’s most important is, if I were looking, I were, when I look back on this situation, will I be proud of what I’ve done.  And I have, I have done things I’m not proud of, you know what I mean, but on the same token, um, I have learned that regret is not something that is healthy to live with, even if I do something wrong, do do something wrong, um, it’s something that will help me grow,  I will learn from the experience.  And I will move on, not forget, necessarily, but learn from it and move on from and become a stronger person because of it.  Become a little smarter next time.
I:Uh-hmm. Can you give an example of something that you would feel comfortable sharing that you’ve regretted?
R:Hmmm.  (long pause)
I:Trying to pick between the ones.
R:Okay, uh-hmm. Um, I was in a relationship, um, last summer. It was last summer, and uh, I was very much into, um, the guy who I was in the relationship with and uh, he, I, for whatever reasons I couldn’t see through the games that he was playing, and he ended up not only cheating on me but as soon as we um, had sex, I never heard from him again, pretty much.  And uh, I mean I did, but like, it wasn’t, it was never the same.  And, uh, it really, really hurt me, like, I, I’ve never, I, I don’t like putting myself in positions where I can get hurt like that and I’ve never felt so ashamed and so embarrassed and so heart-broken.  I was genuinely, genuinely heart-broken.  And I don’t think I’ve ever cried that hard in my life.  And um, um, like I genuinely had such strong feelings for him and I was so, I don’t think that necessarily I was, looking back on my relationships, I don’t know whether or not it was love, but I’ve never felt so strongly as I did for this guy. And I, I still, he’s still messing with my head.  Like, we don’t, we’re friends again, but it still hurts to have a conversation.
I:Yeah.
R:Like, it, it hurts my heart, um. I don’t, well, I don’t like to say I regret because I really, really try not to regret things.  I don’t necessarily regret it, I just wish it had happened differently.
I:Okay, so what would wished happened differently?
R:Um (pause).  I wish, I wish I hadn’t have put myself in the position, um, of, being used the way that I was.  I wish that um, he had at the time, had more respect for me than to treat me the way that he did.
I:Um, what do you think makes something right or wrong?
R:Hmm, I think that’s every one person’s interpretation of it, I don’t think there, I mean, I don’t think there is one right or wrong to anything.  I think that it’s what one person’s conscience takes from an experience, what one person feels, um, has been, not necessarily, uh, there’s so many different ideas out there and there’s so many different thoughts and beliefs that, I, hmmm, (pause) I really do think that it’s each individual person’s choice to decide for themselves, for the most part, what is right or what is wrong.  I think that, um, yeah, because, um, one person can feel that something, like for instance, I, I feel comfortable talking to you about this, but like, for instance, the um, KKK, they feel that what they’re doing is completely right and who are we to tell them that it’s wrong.  You know what I mean?  But they’ve been taught for so long that that’s what’s right, and nowadays, if someone’s, for instance a gay person, um, the general consensus is what they are doing is wrong.  Who are we to say what’s right or what’s wrong, that’s what they feel that they feel comfortable with almost.  You know, like, I don’t know, I, I think that it, it’s every person, I mean, I know there is a generally accepted right or wrong for everything. There is what society has us to believe what is right and what is wrong and for the most part, I will stick by that, but there are some things that really I don’t see where believe have the nerve or the right, um, to say that is completely wrong, do you know what I mean?
I:Yeah, uh-hmm.
R:So I think that, I think that people need to um, really think twice sometimes before they say what they feel is right or wrong as well.  Especially nowadays.

column588: The respondent emphasizes the importance of family and moral upbringing in decision-making, reflecting on their strong conscience shaped by their parents and religious beliefs, while also acknowledging the impact of personal experiences and regrets, particularly from a past relationship, on their understanding of right and wrong.
column589:
I:So how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I think my parents raised me pretty well to know what’s right and wrong—
I:So when you say know, are these like general rules that you could like express in like sentences or is it a feeling or intuition, like tell me what it is to know?
R:It’s a pretty good intuition.  I feel like I have a really good intuition on what’s right and wrong and granted I, I through experience have realized that there is always a gray area for every right and wrong answer.  Um, but I feel like I'm a big believer on the golden rule of do unto others so I think it’s, I feel as though it’s pretty self-explanatory what is, if somebody could get hurt in any way, if somebody, if it’s going to be harmful in any way, shape, or form to anything or anyone, don’t mess.
I:Do you think that something could be the right thing to do but have negative affects on people and vice versa?
R:Yes.  I think that for example, being honest about certain things, um, if they could affect someone in a negative way but at the same time, it’s again the gray area concept. Like there’s always a gray area for every right and wrong answer, it’s just weighing out which one in the end because I know that like for a lot of situations what’s going to happen right now may not be right but in the long run, what’s better for the greater good?
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?  Would you say it’s—
R:I'm pretty good at deciding what’s right and wrong.
I:Do you think it’s gotten any easier or harder over the last couple years, stayed the same?
R:I think as I’ve gotten older it’s gotten better because I’ve been able to look beyond what’s going on Friday night and I’ve been able to look beyond what just affects me and I’d be able to look at there is a bigger picture because I'm more mature.
I:So that happened gradually?
R:Mm-hmm .  More experience.
I:So have any of your views about what’s right and wrong changed in the last couple years would you say or not really?  Any particular views?
R:Not really.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:That’s in the eye of the beholder.  That’s a very gray area question.  Makes something right or wrong?   Um, if the great, if the effect of whatever it is that is right or wrong in the greater picture is going to be more harmful than beneficial than there’s really no point in doing it.
I:When you say more harmful than beneficial, do you mean, do you think there is a difference in who it harms?  Like are there certain groups of people where if you harm them more it matters more?
R:Hmm, I mean people are people, um, it depends on the situation.  I think it really depends on the situation.
I:So where would you say your ideas about right and wrong come from?
R:Come from how I was brought up.  Comes from personal experience.  I feel like a lot, my favorite and most important lessons I’ve ever learned I learned the hard way so it’s really what I’ve gone through up until now have really shaped the way I look at things and the way I look at the world and the way I look at right and wrong.
column590: I think my parents raised me pretty well to know what’s right and wrong— It’s a pretty good intuition.  I feel like I have a really good intuition on what’s right and wrong and granted I, I through experience have realized that there is always a gray area for every right and wrong answer.  Um, but I feel like I'm a big believer on the golden rule of do unto others so I think it’s, I feel as though it’s pretty self-explanatory what is, if somebody could get hurt in any way, if somebody, if it’s going to be harmful in any way, shape, or form to anything or anyone, don’t mess. Yes.  I think that for example, being honest about certain things, um, if they could affect someone in a negative way but at the same time, it’s again the gray area concept. Like there’s always a gray area for every right and wrong answer, it’s just weighing out which one in the end because I know that like for a lot of situations what’s going to happen right now may not be right but in the long run, what’s better for the greater good? I'm pretty good at deciding what’s right and wrong. I think as I’ve gotten older it’s gotten better because I’ve been able to look beyond what’s going on Friday night and I’ve been able to look beyond what just affects me and I’d be able to look at there is a bigger picture because I'm more mature. Mm-hmm .  More experience. Not really.  That’s in the eye of the beholder.  That’s a very gray area question.  Makes something right or wrong?   Um, if the great, if the effect of whatever it is that is right or wrong in the greater picture is going to be more harmful than beneficial than there’s really no point in doing it. Hmm, I mean people are people, um, it depends on the situation.  I think it really depends on the situation.  Come from how I was brought up.  Comes from personal experience.  I feel like a lot, my favorite and most important lessons I’ve ever learned I learned the hard way so it’s really what I’ve gone through up until now have really shaped the way I look at things and the way I look at the world and the way I look at right and wrong.
column591: The respondent emphasizes the importance of intuition and the moral teachings from their parents in making decisions about right and wrong, while also considering the consequences of their actions on others, particularly in relation to their sister's choices and their own experiences.

column583:
I:Mm-mm.  And, and where would you say your views of right and wrong come from?
R:A strong, um, strongly from my parents, um,  geez, um, yeah like, like I said, like it, you know, if you were to quote something from the Bible I’m not very well versed in the scriptures you know, so that, I wouldn’t say had a, you know, probably like what indirectly like for example my Mom was raised Catholic as I said, so you know the way she interpreted values and passed them on to me, I’m sure you know would have affected my ability to make you know decisions with my conscience and that sort of thing.  But I, I wouldn’t say you know concretely one individual and you know, these events you know, shape the way I make my, no it’s, um, I definitely think that, a-huh  a healthy, a healthy sense of fear, um, you know, like in high school you know, I, it was kind of split between I didn’t really wanna you know, dabble in like alcohol and drugs and that kind of thing, but on the other hand I knew that I could probably get in trouble and like a cost-benefit, like that’s a really dorky way to look at it, but yeah, I just kind of um, looking at it that way and realizing that it’s probably not a good choice, you know, either for my, my ah, you know, for example, like my ability to go on to college or to get a job or you know and also hazardous to my health, you know, little things like that, no, but yeah, I, I wouldn’t say there’s one like entity that guides me, yeah.
I:And so if you try and, tried to tell someone you know, what makes something wrong, I mean you mentioned health issues are one, anything else you’d add to that, like how it is that someone can know what is wrong?
R:Um, what is wrong  I ah, I definitely think that opinions are free to be like held and voiced you know, you know sometimes you know, someone might, like I might not agree with them and I might get a little annoyed by how they’re trying to like convert me or whatever, not just in a religious sense of the word but um, I definitely think that any you know, opinion that leads to destruction or you know like undermining established like, political institutions or you know,  I’m talking really ambiguously, I guess, but yeah, I, I think opinions are fine and um, you know, political views are fine but they’re, they won’t really be tested until you know, for example, like um, in this constitutional law class like some people you know were like oh yeah, you know, I don’t think capital punishment should exist at all and then some, and you know, I tend to lean to the conservative side of you know, not so much an eye for an eye but you know that’s, I, something that I don’t think should be completely ruled out, again, situational, but um, you know it’s, it’s things like that where I don’t think people’s sense of real values like come into play unless something directly affects them.  Like 9/11, I think really was a wake up call for, and I don’t mean to be, bring up 9/11 as like a cliché cause I know it’s been,--
I:Interesting.
R:--but ah, you know um, like that’s an example of people forcing their opinions and like feeling so strongly that they have to do something violent you know and that, that’s just, yeah, that’s abysmal, that’s, that’s unforgivable.  Um, you know and, and things like that.  You know, where, you know in, in a kind of democratic sense of the word, like any way that an opinion can be harmful I guess.  Like in a, like a psychological or physical or, I, I don’t even, I don’t know.  Any, any way that it can be really, really irreversibly damaging I think is yeah, not, not good.

column585: The respondent reflects on their decision-making process, emphasizing the influence of their parents' values and a personal code of ethics, which guided them to act with integrity even in minor situations, while acknowledging that they sometimes resorted to small lies to avoid conflict, and they believe that moral decisions can be situational rather than absolute.

column583:
I:Okay and where do your own views of right and wrong come from do you think?
R:My own views of it?  Where do they come from?  Just like how I was brought up and then however you’re brought up that would be how you view things and what your parents teach you.
I:Okay and what do you think it is that like makes something right or wrong do you think?
R:How the outcome would be, if the outcome of each situation would, if it comes out being better than how it was before, if it comes out being worse that would be right or wrong.
I:Okay like what kind of stuff would be like better or worse do you think, like how would you know what was gonna be right or wrong?
R:Well I guess you would look at other people who had been in that situation and see what they choose.
I:Okay.
R:And then look how they turned out or what happened to them.
I:Okay um and can you give me like any examples of like times when you’ve had to decide like what was right or wrong in a situation?
R:Well, not really big…
I:It doesn’t have to be a big thing, just anything.
R:No, not really, not just big things just basically, like where you decide to go, you know if you want to like go to this one place or another place, like something like that.
I:Okay and how would you decide what to do?
R:Well I looked at like what types of people would be at each place and then what could happen, stuff like that.
I:What types of people do you tend to like not want to hang out with as much, or?
R:More people who are more likely to get in trouble.  Or, yeah.  Who are more wild.

How the outcome would be, if the outcome of each situation would, if it comes out being better than how it was before, if it comes out being worse that would be right or wrong. Well I guess you would look at other people who had been in that situation and see what they choose. And then look how they turned out or what happened to them. Well I looked at like what types of people would be at each place and then what could happen, stuff like that. More people who are more likely to get in trouble.  Or, yeah.  Who are more wild.
column585: The respondent makes decisions primarily by consulting friends, parents, and siblings, believes that right and wrong are generally clear, and attributes their moral views to their upbringing, while feeling guilty about lying to parents and recognizing the potential consequences of their actions.
column586:
I:Okay.  Um, how do you decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:I kind of, I don’t really have a problem with you know, debating whether, whether I should do something and if it’s right or wrong.  I kind of, I’ve never really put myself in that position to have to decide something like that.
I:Okay.  So, do you just kind of do whatever you want and not worry about if it’s right or wrong?  Or do you just feel like it’s pretty clear and you make your decisions, and.
R:Yeah, well, yeah, I just know that I wouldn’t do something that was really wrong, and so.
I:So, it’s been easy for you, you think?  Deciding what’s right or wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:Has it gotten any easier or more difficult over the past couple of years?
R:Um, well I think just getting into high school and you know with lots of stuff that people, kids do like drinking and drugs and whatnot, I think that’s made it, I guess that would make it a little harder.
I:How do you typically decide what to do, then, if you’re kind of questioning what is the right approach?
R:Ask your friends.  Yeah.  I talk to my, I probably talk to my friends, my really close friends, and see what they’d do.
I:Do you usually take their advice?
R:Um.  Well, I don’t really, I don’t really talk to them about really serious stuff.  Well, maybe the advice I take would be kind of stupid, but.  Um.  I do take their advice, unless I feel that what I think is better, but, usually we all have the same kind of opinion.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Mm, well.  I think everyone already has a sense of what is right and wrong.  What makes something right and wrong?  Well, I think it’s right if it’s not hurting yourself or other people to do it.
I:Okay.  Um, you said you have a sense of right and wrong?  Where do you think that comes from?
R:Well, I think it comes from society.  I mean most, usually what people do, is what society says is good, you know, or this is bad.  And a lot of people follow like the 10 commandments and everything and I’m not religious but those are good things to follow.  It’s not like you have to be a Catholic to think they’re good rules for life.
I:Why should we even care that people don’t hurt each other, hurt themselves?
R:Because then everything will go into chaos and everyone would die.
I:Okay.  Do you feel like there are any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Are there any what?
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong, or not.
R:Well, well obviously hurting someone, or you know, really physically harming anyone.  Even emotionally, if they, I think it’s always wrong to treat people, well, I think you should treat people how you would want to be treated.  Then, you know, anything, oh, capital punishment, we kill our people and I don’t really know what to say about that.  But, what was the question again?  Terrible memory.
I:That’s fine.  Talking about actions that could be always wrong.
R:Oh, actions always wrong.
I:And you were saying, anything where anyone were hurting someone else.  Then you brought up capital punishment.
R:Yeah.
I:So do you think capital punishment is wrong, or not?
R:No, I don’t think it’s wrong, but that’s not, that’s why I kind of put myself in a weird situation there.
I:Okay.  Where have you acquired your moral views, do you think?
R:Um.  From my, I think from my family, my parents.

I kind of, I’ve never really put myself in that position to have to decide something like that. Yeah, well, yeah, I just know that I wouldn’t do something that was really wrong, and so. Yeah.
