And a lot of people follow like the 10 commandments and everything and I’m not religious but those are good things to follow.  It’s not like you have to be a Catholic to think they’re good rules for life. Because then everything will go into chaos and everyone would die. Are there any what? Well, well obviously hurting someone, or you know, really physically harming anyone.  Even emotionally, if they, I think it’s always wrong to treat people, well, I think you should treat people how you would want to be treated.  Then, you know, anything, oh, capital punishment, we kill our people and I don’t really know what to say about that.  But, what was the question again?  Terrible memory. Oh, actions always wrong. Yeah. No, I don’t think it’s wrong, but that’s not, that’s why I kind of put myself in a weird situation there.  Um.  From my, I think from my family, my parents.
column588: The respondent makes decisions based on a sense of right and wrong influenced by societal norms and parental guidance, often consulting friends for advice, while believing that actions should not harm others and that helping others is a moral obligation, despite acknowledging the challenges of peer pressure in high school.
column589:
I:In general, how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t really have trouble with deciding whats good or bad, right and wrong I went to a Catholic school for twelve years and all that and I had some sort of moral class or ethics class and moral code taught to me for all those years.  I know what's right and wrong.  I don't have any internal debate about anything.
I:But you said that you disagreed with a lot of the teachings in your school?
R:I disagree with the religious teachings.  But morals and those sort of values I think are pretty standard no matter what religion.  They all sort of basically say the same thing.
I:So in general, would you say it's pretty easy for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Yes.
I:And has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder in the last couple of years?
R:I don’t know about that, its been sort of maybe a little more difficult, meeting different people who do different things and deal with people from different cultures and what not.  For than dealing with any particular sort of conflict or anything like that.
I:So you said that you basically have kind of a feeling about what is right or wrong, right?  So what do you think that the feeling is, or you know like how you know.
R:My conscience, I guess.  Just how I've been raised my values throughout the beginning of my life.  Whatever I, how I feel is gonna be the right decision, what would make me I guess maybe happiest or better off, and what will please others in the situation too.
I:Is the primary, when you're thinking about a tough decision, what's the main thing that, is it about like the outcome for the other person, or how it makes you feel, or, like what was the?
R:I'd say put all of it together.  I think its maybe something like the situation like that, but there are other kinds of situations, like maybe going to class or not.  Pretty basic choice, but I mean like a lot of kids don't go to class, and they don't have a problem with it.  I have a problem with not going to class.  I missed class once and that was because I had to go back home for a funeral.  It was a big deal and I still was upset about missing class.  But that's still my conscience.  I can't not go to class.  I mean I know my parents are paying for it.  I try, I don't know how much each class is worth, but I would feel terrible not going.
I:Okay.  From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Probably from my parents and from school.  It was religious schooling, so I was able to absorb it from a non-religious way.

But morals and those sort of values I think are pretty standard no matter what religion.  They all sort of basically say the same thing. Yes. I don’t know about that, its been sort of maybe a little more difficult, meeting different people who do different things and deal with people from different cultures and what not.  For than dealing with any particular sort of conflict or anything like that.  My conscience, I guess.  Just how I've been raised my values throughout the beginning of my life.  Whatever I, how I feel is gonna be the right decision, what would make me I guess maybe happiest or better off, and what will please others in the situation too. Knowing that she was gonna be okay.  I think she kind of does stuff like that a lot I guess.  And then, I helped  And went to her room, she didn't really help out at all but.  So I let her stay with me, helped her out, she slept in my bed. Yeah. Mm hm.  I didn’t leave her on her own. I'd say put all of it together.  I think its maybe something like the situation like that, but there are other kinds of situations, like maybe going to class or not.  Pretty basic choice, but I mean like a lot of kids don't go to class, and they don't have a problem with it.  I have a problem with not going to class.  I missed class once and that was because I had to go back home for a funeral.  It was a big deal and I still was upset about missing class.  But that's still my conscience.  I can't not go to class.  I mean I know my parents are paying for it.  I try, I don't know how much each class is worth, but I would feel terrible not going.  Probably from my parents and from school.  It was religious schooling, so I was able to absorb it from a non-religious way.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on their upbringing and moral teachings from Catholic school to determine right and wrong, while also considering the potential consequences of their actions on others, as demonstrated in a recent situation involving a friend's well-being where they ultimately chose to wait rather than call for help, reflecting their conscience and social influences.

column589:
I:How would you say you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:How do I decide?  If I'm gonna get locked up or not.  If I know that it's gonna be, it's possible for the police to be involved, I'll take that down somewhere else.  I done,  I've had, I've had a few experiences with stuff like that.  I don't, I don't do violence and I don't deal with none of that stuff no more.

R:Easy.
I:It's pretty easy.
R:Yeah.

R:Yeah.  'Cause I don't--it's gotten easier, 'cause I don't really care what people think.  If they say, "Oh you ain't doin' this."  I don't care.  I, I shouldn't say it in the language I would tell them, but, you know, that's, that's my outlook on bein' wrong.  You know, still it's easier.

R:I don't know, that could be an opinion, you know.  Right and wrong can be an opinion with somebody.  Depends on what you, what you're talkin' about, but...I don't know.  I kinda forgot your question.  I'm kinda ADD, my mind went blank.

R:I don't wanna talk about somethin' that ain't on the subject, so...
I:Where do you think you've gotten your moral views from?
R:I used to--well--My parents, probably.  The majority of it.  I've got some I kinda figured out by myself, I believe.  Just, in my free time...I think a little bit different than my parents, but mostly the same.  You know what I mean?  Just...

column591: The respondent plans to use a hypothetical inheritance of $100,000 to buy a house and a vehicle, emphasizing a cautious approach to money management influenced by personal experiences and a desire to avoid trouble, while acknowledging that their moral views are primarily shaped by their parents, with a belief that right and wrong can vary based on individual perspectives and circumstances.

column583:
I:Where, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Where who?
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Mine?
I:Yeah.
R:Basically I just think about it really.  If I think it’s wrong then I ain’t gonna do it but if it’s right then I’ll do it, but.
I:And what kind of criteria do you usually use to decide? Like or standards or really…
R:Well most things that make me think about it is my niece though.
I:Yeah.
R:And my girlfriend, so it makes me decide if I want to be put away if I can’t, if I can’t see them for awhile or if I want to do it and not stay with them so.
I:Right, right.
R:Really those are the two things that hit me whenever something comes up, so.
I:Okay…that’s not bad, so then yeah, almost a month after, but uh…and…where would you say like, say if you’re looking at what somebody else does and you had to judge what like whether like what they’re doing is right or wrong, where did you sort of learn, where do you think you picked up the standards by which you judge if they’re right or wrong?
R:Well, where I picked it up was that I used to do it all the time and then I just started realizing what was worth doing and what wasn’t worth doing and so, basically I just did it long enough for it to just hit me and say well this ain’t right, don’t do it no more.
I:Right.  What, what kind of stuff were you in on or?
R:Going around breaking windows,
I:Uh-huh
R:Slitting tires.
I:Right.
R:Kicking mailboxes off their stands, things like that.
I:Right.
R:Stealing bikes.
I:Were you in it like with your friends or…okay…
R:I stopped hanging around them.
I:Okay, you got different friends or you kept some…
R:Yeah, I got friends that basically like to sit and talk and just play a game or something, watch TV or something, not go out and cause trouble.
I:Yeah, I gotcha.  And this was all when you lived in Lexington?   Have you ever…oh go ahead sorry.
R:Well basically if I was to come along another person like that I’d basically ask them not to come around any more.  So I wouldn’t pick back up on doing those same things again.
column584: Where who? Mine? Basically I just think about it really.  If I think it’s wrong then I ain’t gonna do it but if it’s right then I’ll do it, but. Well most things that make me think about it is my niece though. And my girlfriend, so it makes me decide if I want to be put away if I can’t, if I can’t see them for awhile or if I want to do it and not stay with them so. Really those are the two things that hit me whenever something comes up, so. Well, where I picked it up was that I used to do it all the time and then I just started realizing what was worth doing and what wasn’t worth doing and so, basically I just did it long enough for it to just hit me and say well this ain’t right, don’t do it no more. Going around breaking windows, Slitting tires. Kicking mailboxes off their stands, things like that. Stealing bikes. I stopped hanging around them. Yeah, I got friends that basically like to sit and talk and just play a game or something, watch TV or something, not go out and cause trouble. Well basically if I was to come along another person like that I’d basically ask them not to come around any more.  So I wouldn’t pick back up on doing those same things again.
column585: The respondent makes decisions based on a personal assessment of potential trouble, considers the influence of family, particularly their niece and girlfriend, and reflects on past experiences to determine right from wrong, while acknowledging that moral standards can vary among individuals.
column589:
I:How would you say that you normally decide or know what is good or bad or right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t know really.
I:So if you had to make a decision between something that maybe was a difficult decision, what would go through your mind as you weighed your options?
R:If I had to go through a difficult decision?
I:Yeah, yeah. Like a moral dilemma.
R:If it were only me, I’d just deal with my problems by getting it out of my way and not worry about it.
I:Do you feel like in the last couple of years it’s gotten easier or harder to decide between right and wrong?
R:No.
I:What would you say it is that actually makes something right or wrong?
R:Just the person’s decisions, I guess.
I:So that person that has to make the decision?
R:Yeah.
I:So is it more about like the consequences that would come about choosing one thing over the other?
R:Uh-hmm. If I was in a situation where someone was trying to get me to do something that I know that would get me jail time, I’m going to look at him and tell them they’re fools. They can do it themselves.
I:So the consequences are sure there. What about like feelings? Are there any kind of feelings that would make something right or wrong?
R:No.
I:What about like rules or laws? Like if something was against the law, does that always make you wrong?
R:Yeah, really, I don’t know. It’s kind of a tricky question.
I:Do you have a feeling for like where you got your moral views, where they come from?
R:No.
column590: I don’t know really. If I had to go through a difficult decision? If it were only me, I’d just deal with my problems by getting it out of my way and not worry about it. No.  Just the person’s decisions, I guess. Yeah. Uh-hmm. If I was in a situation where someone was trying to get me to do something that I know that would get me jail time, I’m going to look at him and tell them they’re fools. They can do it themselves. No. Yeah, really, I don’t know. It’s kind of a tricky question.  No.
column591: The respondent would donate a significant portion of an inherited $100,000 to charity because it feels like the right thing to do, would buy a house for stability due to job loss issues, and would help their grandmother, while they generally rely on their own judgment to determine right from wrong without strong influences from others or a clear moral framework.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:From mom.
I:How do you decide or know what’s good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Okay, like, okay, when I smoked the weed, I knew I was wrong, but it’s not something I’m gonna die about it or some bad thing is gonna happen to me about it, you know what I mean?
I:But what good do you get out of smoking weed?
R:I don’t know, you just, I don’t know, you just, when, when you do that, it’s like, like, like the world around you and everybody’s comment, everybody’s problem, all your problems they just go away for a moment. But even if they go away for that moment, they still went away.  You know?  And um like, my views of right or wrong come from my mother.
I:So did your mom ever specifically tell you that weed was bad?
R:Yeah.
column584: From mom. Okay, like, okay, when I smoked the weed, I knew I was wrong, but it’s not something I’m gonna die about it or some bad thing is gonna happen to me about it, you know what I mean? I don’t know, you just, I don’t know, you just, when, when you do that, it’s like, like, like the world around you and everybody’s comment, everybody’s problem, all your problems they just go away for a moment. But even if they go away for that moment, they still went away.  You know?  And um like, my views of right or wrong come from my mother. Yeah.
column585: The respondent often relies on their mother's views of right and wrong, feels guilty about their actions such as smoking weed despite knowing it's wrong, and is primarily concerned about the consequences of getting caught by their mother rather than legal repercussions.

column583:
I:So, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:(pause)  Where do my view come from?
I:Yeah.
R:Um…
I:How did you come to believe what’s right and wrong?
R:Um…(long pause)…the way that I was brought up and I kind of found out what my parents did when they were my age.  And I found out the things they did when I wasn’t around, and I kind of live by that.
I:So you kind of live by what your parents have done, or what your parents have told you is wrong?
R:I….ah…kind of a little of both.
I:Okay, are there any other factors that influence what you think is right and wrong?
R:Uh, the law.
I:How many, what do you mean by that?
R:I don’t want to break it.
I:Okay, so you think breaking the law is wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay, why is that wrong?
R:You’re breaking the law.
I:Okay.
R:I don’t know.
I:Okay.  Um, so, what if, what if you don’t agree with the law.  What if you think well the law says I shouldn’t steal but I think stealing is okay, can you do that?
R:Well, you can do it but it’s not right, you know right from wrong?
I:Uh-huh
R:Well maybe if you brought up that way you might think it’s right because like maybe your parents stole or like would steal around you, you know, say your like kind of poor-ish and they just go in to take some things that they needed not things that they wanted.
I:Uh-huh
R:That would be kind of right-ish.
I:Uh-huh
R:I don’t know.  Just say you’re going to die and you can’t go to the doctor’s office because they can’t pay for it…
I:Okay.
R:I don’t know, go and take some medicine, that’s not very, that’s bad but not very bad, I don’t know.
I:Okay.  Okay.  And do you think there’s any, I mean do you know of anything that makes something right or wrong?  Is that, what’s it based on?
R:I don’t know.
I:Okay, they’re hard questions, so.
R:Yeah.

That would be kind of right-ish. I don’t know.  Just say you’re going to die and you can’t go to the doctor’s office because they can’t pay for it… I don’t know, go and take some medicine, that’s not very, that’s bad but not very bad, I don’t know. I don’t know. Yeah.
column585: The respondent makes decisions by weighing the consequences of their actions, acknowledges that their moral views are influenced by their upbringing and parents' actions, and believes that while some actions like murder are universally wrong, many moral judgments are subjective and based on individual perspectives.

column583:
I:Okay um, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Probably, I, I have a little system where I’ll do something, whatever the consequences, like having a baby, I think that I was, I wasn’t married yet, I probably, if I could go back I probably wouldn’t, I probably would have waited ‘til we got married and then waited a few years afterwards cause right now the consequences are we’re really stressed out about money and all that, you know, cause now it’s not just me and him, it’s me, him and the baby, so, that was probably the wrong decision [small laugh, sort of laughing at herself] so I think my right and wrong decision making probably comes from a lot of experiences from other people telling me and my parents, how they raised me and their morals and stuff.
I:Okay.  Ah, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Probably the way it makes somebody feel.
I:Okay.  Like ah, what kind of feeling, what, what kind of feelings would be, make something good?
R:Like, if something made somebody feel bad, it was probably, probably wrong.  But then you can’t really say that, cause some things offend people that don’t offend other people, but I think mostly __________ like, say if we didn’t have the police, people would just go around shooting and killing people and then we wouldn’t have a world like we do today, so. It’s probably right to have police and rules and stuff.
I:Why is it wrong for people to kill each other?
R:Because it’s wrong!  Cause ah, um, it hurts other people and if we just went around killing people, pretty soon we would just kill off the world and then what would we have?
I:Um, how do you decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t really know  I think I just go along with, I kind of just go along with what people have told me, but mostly what I said with the feelings, like if I feel like something is bad, then I probably wouldn’t do it.

column585: The respondent reflects on their regret about having sex before marriage, attributing their decision-making to prayer and discussions with close individuals, while also acknowledging the significant stress and struggles in their marriage, influenced by insecurities stemming from both partners' past experiences and their upbringing.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:Usually just instinct and things I’ve learned from my parents.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy.
I:Do you think it’s gotten easier or harder over the past couple of years?
R:Easier.
I:How so?
R:I think I’ve just grown up and matured a lot and learned from choosing the wrong things rather than the right things.
I:Have your views about what’s right and wrong changed at all over the past two years?
R:Yes.
I:Tell me about it.
R:I guess the best example would be like clothing.  My sister doesn’t really put any restrictions on her daughters and that bugged me because her one-year-old daughter, well she just dresses kind of hoochie and I don’t really…I have her most of the week.
I:You do?
R:I’ve been trying to turn her around because I don’t want to be like I’m going to have during the school year and I don’t want to send her to school on something I want to send my own kid in.
I:How old is she?
R:She’s six, seven …six, yeah.
I:And so you watch her during the week?
R:Yup.
I:Do you ever talk to her about that?
R:No.
I:You don’t?
R:No, I haven’t.  I haven’t yet.
I:You can eat if you want, I’ll let you chew.  I don’t want you to wait until the end because you’ll never get the chance.
R:I guess, I don’t know.  I really go off a lot of what like my mom has taught me and my sisters and brothers have passed on and other people.  I guess that has a lot to do with just what…I don’t know, what would hurt somebody maybe like not physically but even emotionally you know.  I think that has a lot to do with it.
I:Where do you think you got your views about right and wrong from?
R:I think a lot from my mom and like I said just my brothers and sisters, teachers…

R:Yeah.  Just a little bit.

column583:
I:Yeah, okay, okay.  Um, tell me about where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, ah, I just think that everybody should know right from wrong, if your parents, she’ll tell you, sit down and tell you right from wrong.
I:Okay, okay.
R:And everybody do drinking and smoking, that’s wrong things.
I:Yeah, yeah.  Mm-mm.
R:And talking back,  that’s very disrespectful and wrong. Everybody should know right from wrong.
I:Yeah, yeah.  Do you, and so you, what do you feel like you came to understand what’s right and wrong in life?
R:Um, I think—
I:Who, who or what was, had the most influence on you, your knowing what’s right and wrong?
R:My twin sister.
I:Oh yeah?
R:Cause like every, I do every, I’m not saying I’m perfect, but I do some things bad, but my twin sister, she does everything bad and she gets in trouble for it.
I:From your parents, yeah.
R:Well, my grandmother.
I:Oh, your grandmother, okay, okay.  Is that your Mom’s Mom, by the way, that she stays with?
R:Yes, ma’am.
column584: Um, ah, I just think that everybody should know right from wrong, if your parents, she’ll tell you, sit down and tell you right from wrong. And everybody do drinking and smoking, that’s wrong things. And talking back,  that’s very disrespectful and wrong. Everybody should know right from wrong. Um, I think— My twin sister. Cause like every, I do every, I’m not saying I’m perfect, but I do some things bad, but my twin sister, she does everything bad and she gets in trouble for it. Well, my grandmother. Yes, ma’am.
column585: The respondent reflects on their decision to get a tattoo, which they felt conflicted about due to the anticipated disapproval from their parents, ultimately leading to punishment, while also emphasizing the influence of their twin sister and the importance of knowing right from wrong as taught by their parents and grandmother.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what’s good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:The majority of the time it’s just things that I learned in my childhood.  I was actually a really bad kid.
I:Oh yeah?
R:I stole from my pre-school, like Legos and stuff.  And I beat up kids.  I would even, on the school bus, because on first grade everyone is really short, I would crawl under the seat and people’s legs would be dangling, and I would yank them from underneath the seat.  So I guess after enough of figuring out that those weren’t the right things to do I developed a sense of honesty about doing on others as you’d want them to do on you.
I:What changed from school bully to?
R:I don’t know.  My dad says that I used to get spanked occasionally, so there was one time, like the last time he ever had to spank me, that it seemed like something clicked and I just began to understand that maybe this wasn’t the thing to do.
I:In general is it easy or hard for you, nowadays, to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy.  Just treating people right, I guess.  Treating people with respect.
I:Has this gotten easier or harder over the last few years?
R:I think it’s gotten easier.  I have a better understanding of how to determine in a situation what is right or wrong.  I’ve had more time to cultivate my beliefs.
I:And have your views changed about that in the last two years?
R:Not really.
I:You’re just more clear on the things that you think?
R:Right.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think it’s all relative based on society.
I:Like in your own, when you think about it is it mainly, like, what other people believe, or is it consequences of actions, or is it
R:I think it’s a whole combination.  I think, like, parenting plays a huge role, but I also think all the people’s reactions in society might even play a larger role.
I:What about rules or moral rules or principles, things that are just always wrong?
R:No, I don’t believe in anything that’s definite.
I:Where have you acquired your moral views from?
R:I guess mainly, probably, from my parents and from my friends as well.
I:Have your parents talked to you about this specifically or do you just pick them up from?
R:It’s just picked up mainly, you know, like, “Don’t do this, don’t do that.”
column590: The majority of the time it’s just things that I learned in my childhood.  I was actually a really bad kid. I stole from my pre-school, like Legos and stuff.  And I beat up kids.  I would even, on the school bus, because on first grade everyone is really short, I would crawl under the seat and people’s legs would be dangling, and I would yank them from underneath the seat.  So I guess after enough of figuring out that those weren’t the right things to do I developed a sense of honesty about doing on others as you’d want them to do on you. I don’t know.  My dad says that I used to get spanked occasionally, so there was one time, like the last time he ever had to spank me, that it seemed like something clicked and I just began to understand that maybe this wasn’t the thing to do. It’s pretty easy.  Just treating people right, I guess.  Treating people with respect. I think it’s gotten easier.  I have a better understanding of how to determine in a situation what is right or wrong.  I’ve had more time to cultivate my beliefs. Not really. Right.  I think it’s all relative based on society. I think it’s a whole combination.  I think, like, parenting plays a huge role, but I also think all the people’s reactions in society might even play a larger role. No, I don’t believe in anything that’s definite.  I guess mainly, probably, from my parents and from my friends as well. It’s just picked up mainly, you know, like, “Don’t do this, don’t do that.”
column591: The respondent primarily bases their understanding of right and wrong on childhood lessons and parental influences, emphasizing the importance of treating others with respect, while acknowledging that their moral views are shaped by societal norms and personal experiences, including a struggle with selfishness in relationships and a belief in a lifelong obligation to help others.

column583:
I:Okay, um, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, my religion, I pray about it.
I:Okay, what, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, I don’t know.  When, well for me it’s, if I’m doing something, it’s whatever brings me closer to my heavenly father.
column584: Um, my religion, I pray about it. Um, I don’t know.  When, well for me it’s, if I’m doing something, it’s whatever brings me closer to my heavenly father.
column585: The respondent primarily relies on prayer and guidance from their heavenly father to determine right from wrong, believes that societal norms have eroded moral clarity, and feels guilty about minor wrongdoings, which they address through a process of repentance in their religious practice.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Some problems it’s pretty obvious, if it’s going to hurt someone it’s bad.  I just do whatever hurts other people the least usually.  This is where I’m kind of weird and unique.  Like I don’t really have emotions but I do, but just not very strong at all.  I see I have a large control over my mind and the way I think.  So, I also don’t have like...I don’t really feel pain or like it doesn’t bother me, and so, kind of weird in that regard.  Because I don’t really have strong emotions then it’s a kind of limited thing that I have.  It’s more of a precious commodity the kind of way I look at it.  And so, hurting other people’s feelings for me is like this big deal since I don’t really have feelings to hurt.  I feel really bad especially because I can understand what they’re going through.  I do a lot of my kind of good and bad choices just kind of based on that.  I mean, I don’t want to hurt other people’s feelings.  In many times, I’m willing to go out of my way to avoid hurting someone’s feelings because I don’t mind going out of my way, and it means a lot to them usually.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s usually pretty easy and not that difficult for me to realize when I’m hurting someone’s feelings or when I’m doing something that would be bad.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past few years?
R:I might say easier, I guess.  I understand people more and it’s easier to tell what’s going to hurt them and what’s not.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:From the religious thing, I mean, since we do believe that we can become a God, I’m trying to be more like Christ, for example, as much as possible.  The way God is He made the earth and He made the universe like the galaxy and He made everything there for us so we could have happy lives and that we could progress and learn, because all my right and wrong choices are kind of based on the same idea.  I mean, if I’m helping people to become better and it’s obviously the right choice comparing to someone’s obvious wrong choice.  I guess I could probably go out and find more ways to help people if I really wanted to.  I don’t do that so that’s kind of debatable whether it’s good or bad or not.  It’s kind of neutral, I could be doing better.  But it’s kind of what it is.  It’s about making or having everyone have a happy life and be prepared for the next life.
I:Where do you think your moral views have come from?  Like your views about right and wrong.
R:I kind of said how my helping other people and stuff, my emotions, kind of ideology comes from.  It’s kind of my religion and kind of my own ideas as well.  I mean, I’m with my religion because I have had evidence that proves it to me, the kind of spiritual experiences that has proven it to me and it also the most logical church out there being very logically minded. With the things that I’ve learned from the church and from my experiences, for a lot of people their right or wrong comes from religion.  As long as they’re not hurting someone else, I don’t really see it as wrong but I don’t see it as living a happy live either.  Everything God does so we could have a happy life and prepare for the next life.  Those are two things.  So anything wrong would be preventing those two things, a happy life and preparing for the next life.  Anything good would be helping people to have those two things, and anything else that’s not really either or.  The reason why God mentions it is because He wants us to have a happy life.  Not drinking alcohol will lead to a happier life.  I also like learning from other people and so the people I’ve seen that have had that kind of problem and then drinking alcohol and stuff, it’s always seems to leave them to unhappy life, people I’ve seen.  Right and wrong is kind of different for me than most people, I guess.

I mean, if I’m helping people to become better and it’s obviously the right choice comparing to someone’s obvious wrong choice.  I guess I could probably go out and find more ways to help people if I really wanted to.  I don’t do that so that’s kind of debatable whether it’s good or bad or not.  It’s kind of neutral, I could be doing better.  But it’s kind of what it is.  It’s about making or having everyone have a happy life and be prepared for the next life.  I kind of said how my helping other people and stuff, my emotions, kind of ideology comes from.  It’s kind of my religion and kind of my own ideas as well.  I mean, I’m with my religion because I have had evidence that proves it to me, the kind of spiritual experiences that has proven it to me and it also the most logical church out there being very logically minded. With the things that I’ve learned from the church and from my experiences, for a lot of people their right or wrong comes from religion.  As long as they’re not hurting someone else, I don’t really see it as wrong but I don’t see it as living a happy live either.  Everything God does so we could have a happy life and prepare for the next life.  Those are two things.  So anything wrong would be preventing those two things, a happy life and preparing for the next life.  Anything good would be helping people to have those two things, and anything else that’s not really either or.  The reason why God mentions it is because He wants us to have a happy life.  Not drinking alcohol will lead to a happier life.  I also like learning from other people and so the people I’ve seen that have had that kind of problem and then drinking alcohol and stuff, it’s always seems to leave them to unhappy life, people I’ve seen.  Right and wrong is kind of different for me than most people, I guess.
column591: The respondent emphasizes the importance of religious beliefs in guiding their moral decisions, prioritizing helping others and minimizing harm, while also acknowledging the influence of personal experiences and logical reasoning in determining right from wrong.

column583:

column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are clear, influenced primarily by their parents and adults, and acknowledges that actions like smoking and cheating are wrong due to their harmful consequences, while also expressing that personal choices should be respected, even if they involve risky behaviors like drinking or smoking.

column583:

column584: The bible and the laws.  What the bible says and what the laws is what decides things. She would think about whether her parents would think if it was bad for her to do and what the bible says for her to do.
column585: The respondent believes that moral guidance comes primarily from the Bible and laws, feels guilty about actions like drinking and lying due to her conscience and religious teachings, and considers her parents' opinions when making decisions, although she sometimes engages in behaviors she knows are wrong.

column586:
I:Well, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Good and bad and right and wrong.  Um, I, you know I’ve grown up with Christian beliefs and reading the Bible and so that’s pretty much the biggest um standard that I you know, that I strive towards, so, yeah that’s probably the biggest one.  And obviously you know the teaching, like what my, what my parents taught me and stuff.
I:Do you struggle much with deciding between right and wrong or do you think it’s pretty tough in life or pretty easy, or how would you?
R:I think, I think it’s pretty easy, like I think everyone, everyone knows what’s right and wrong and even if they’re like, oh, I’m so lost, like really, I think everybody knows and if you, I don’t know, if you choose to not be realistic and not to see what, what you’re doing is wrong then you know that’s your decision.  I think everybody knows what’s right and wrong.
I:Okay.  How do you think people know?  Where does it come from?
R:I just think it comes from inside you, I think just everybody is born with, with a knowing of just what, what’s right and what’s wrong and like, like um, you know you don’t, like if, just like you know, human nature like if um, you know, you, if you grow up, like okay if a bunch of people are on a stranded island and, as babies, and they grow up together, like they’re not gonna kill each other, you know because that’s human nature not to kill each other, you know it’s just stuff like that.
I:Okay, has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past couple years?
R:Um, it’s, it’s pretty much the same.  Like the temptations are probably stronger, just because you know I’m getting older and there’s more temptations to choose from  but it hasn’t really gotten—probably a little bit harder, but you know.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Oh, gosh.  I like these questions.    I just have to think about it.
I:Okay.
R:Um, I think that um, like, um, what makes something right and wrong.  Wow, that’s like one of those questions like it’s, like everybody knows, it’s so easy but then when you try to explain it.  Um.  I think what makes something right and wrong is when, like rules are made to protect you and like you know, like, I know, I know a lot of people are like oh blah, you know, like the Bible is a bunch of bull and it makes your life boring and stuff and like, I, I’m not gonna be closed-minded and pretend I don’t understand where they’re coming from, like, but like, I don’t know, when you, when you like abide by laws, life is, life is so much easier and they protect you, like God’s not like, oh, you know, I’m gonna play with you and make rules because I’m angry you know, like people stop at rules until they’re in deep trouble and they’re like wow, I really wish that I hadn’t done that, I really regret that, so, um.
I:Okay.
R:Did I, did I sort of avoid the question?
I:No, I think you answered it.
R:Okay.
I:I mean it was about what makes something right or wrong, so I think you’re kind of saying right are things that are, that protect you.  Wrong ________________ .
R:Yeah.
I:Um, do you think there are actions out there that are always wrong, in themselves?
R:Yes.  Like—
I:Can you think of examples?
R:Yeah, like murder is always, well, yeah.  Like murder is always gonna be wrong, I mean, not, not self defense, but you know, hate like, hate crimes are always gonna be wrong, any kind of hate crime.
I:So, can you think for a second what’s behind those things that you think makes them ultimately wrong?
R:Things that are, I don’t know, like what makes doing something wrong?
I:Yeah, or why, what is them that makes them always wrong, so like murder, hate crimes, what is it about those things that are just wrong?
R:Something that hurts other people, um, something that is, is destructive, that is selfish, that is um, harmful.
I:Are there some things out there, just to be really difficult, just to get you think a little more--?
R:Oh yeah.
I:--that are complicated and that people do get hurt but at the same time, some people benefit, like I’m thinking of war or something like that, how do you think about those things?
R:About war?
I:Yeah, or we could use war for an example if you want, or anything you can think of where people are getting hurt and those things that you said that define something wrong, but on the other hand, some people would say there’s benefits from it, so.
R:Yeah, I think um, I mean, I think good can come out of every bad thing, you know?  And so, you know I mean, every, everybody’s heard it but it’s true, like you know without, without um, without bad things happening we could never know what good things are, without dark we wouldn’t appreciate light you know, so I think you know there’s a definitely a validness  in that.  Um.

column588: The respondent plans to save the $100,000 inheritance primarily for buying a house and helping their mother with debt, while their moral decision-making is heavily influenced by Christian beliefs and teachings from their parents, leading them to believe that right and wrong are inherent and not relative, although they have become more accepting of differing views over time.

column583:
I:Do you think that, you, then you were talking about your parents, if your parents give you, what about, do you have any rules of what’s right and wrong for you?
R:I, I pretty much don’t really have too much stuff like that, but if, like kind of drugs, right, if, if my parents would say, don’t use drugs, they’re bad for you and I have this list of morals, but it’s like, I do, I do drugs anyway, it’s no reason to have them, cause, they serve no purpose.  So.  It’s just pointless, pretty much, the way I see it 00:29:18.
I:Do you, do you have a set of your own rules that you follow?
R:Not, not really.
I:Is there anything you do that would be different than what your parents would have you do?
R:Pretty much like the clothes I wear, the music I listen to, people I hang out with, like most of the time, my parents they know all my friends but they don’t really approve of all of them.
I:Even the people that are on the basketball team?
R:Yeah.  Cause like, not all, my parents they come from like, pretty much like a structured environment so, and not too many of these kids come from that, most of these kids come from like the projects or like, like single families where, like right when they’re born, the father left and my parents they’re not really like too fond of that.
I:Where do your views of right and wrong come from?
R:Pretty much my parents.  And what the, what society is, like me, to be right and wrong.
I:Can you give, give me an example.
R:Like, if, like I know that myself that it’s wrong to run a red light, but may do it once in a while because you’re in a rush, but I’m saying like society because if you see a police man, like couple, if you saw a police man behind you or like a couple blocks up 00:30:39, you know it would be like, hey, he’s up there, I’m in a rush, but hey, let me just stay here so that I don’t get that ticket.  And, that’s basically just, just society.
I:Society.  How do you decide or know what is good or bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t really decide, it’s just like, it’s just been like, instilled in my brain, so, I know.  It’s like, it’s not, I don’t really think about it too much, but it’s just like, it’s a, it’s a instinct that you have, or just like all right, let me just chill out cause this is, it’s gonna get me in trouble, and.
I:You said instilled in your brain, did, by whom, by what?
R:By my parents just reiterating it to me like, don’t do this because it’ll lead you on the wrong road, don’t smoke because it will just end up like taking, like years off your life and just make you spend more money and stuff like that, so.  That’s basically just what I learned, like, been stuck in my brain.

column585: The respondent attributes their understanding of right and wrong primarily to their parents' teachings, believes that morality is clear but acknowledges that people often choose not to follow it, and expresses feelings of guilt related to their parents' divorce and the impact of their actions on friends, while also indicating that they sometimes lie to their parents to avoid conflict.

column583:
I:And where do you think your own views of right and wrong come from, do you think?
R:(pause) My parents.  Yeah, I’d definitely say my parents, they taught me pretty good, I guess. They taught me how to differentiate, I’ll give you that much, but not necessarily uh…I mean they tried, but…
I:And when issues or right and wrong come up, how do you usually decide what to do?
R:(pause) I think about the consequences, usually, um…it depends on the situation, um, if I was to be at a function and there were people drinking and somebody asked me for a drink, if I wanted a drink, then I would think about where I was, how many people were there, you know what I mean, if I was driving home, whatnot, I mean, there’s tons of things that I think about before I do things, um…to help me decide, and in some cases no and in some cases yes, I mean it may not be right but, it’s the choice I make, you know.
I:Okay, and where do your own, we talked about this a little bit, but where do your own views of right and wrong come from? Is there anything else, you talked a little bit about that, but just if there is…
R:Um, where do I get my standards from?
I:Uh-huh
R:From my parents.
I:Okay.
R:From them, I mean roughly.  Different people’s parents, different, different things, I think I kind of, I’ve learned things too along the way, I mean I’ve set my own, just by different, watching other people and how they act with different situations.
I:And what do you think it is that makes something good or bad, or right or wrong?
R:The outcome.  The outcome, definitely.  Um, if it was a horrible outcome, it probably wasn’t something they should have been doing, you know, it probably wasn’t something that they should have ever put themselves in the place to do, but if it was something that came out you know, nicely, something that benefited them, then I think it was the right thing to do.  It’s just the outcome I think that differentiates between right and wrong.
I:Okay, and how do you know what the outcome is going to be?
R:Um…I don’t think you really do, I don’t think anyone can really tell what the outcome is going to be, but um…but…I mean they can sit there and weigh out the pros and cons before they do something, I’m sure.  I don’t think anyone really knows.
I:How do you usually figure it out, like what you’re going to do?
R:I just sit there and figure out what the outcome is going to be, and then just decide.
I:Okay, and do you have any examples of a time that you did that?
R:(no verbal response)

column585: The respondent attributes their understanding of right and wrong primarily to their parents, considers the consequences of their actions when making decisions, and expresses guilt over past mistakes such as drinking and driving, while also acknowledging the influence of social situations and peer pressure.
column589:
I:No, thank you. How would you say you normally decide or know what is good or bad, right and wrong in life?
R:How do I know?
I:Decide or know.
R:I guess I just know. Decision-wise what’s a good or bad decision, is that what you mean?
I:I mean how do you normally decide between right and wrong?
R:Like do I take this candy bar or don’t I?
I:sure
R:I guess I just know. I mean I guess I was just taught that in life by my parents. I guess they taught me that from the beginning.
I:Generally would you say it’s easy for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Yes, I don’t really have to think about it now.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past couple of years?
R:I would say that it always gets easier.
I:Why?
R:I would just say the more experiences that I have the easier it becomes to find out what effects a certain something I do can have on someone else.
I:I don’t want to stop you, I just don’t know how well the recorder can pick up what you’re saying from over there.
R:No problem  I was just saying that sometimes right and wrong isn’t as clear cut as you grow older, it’s kind of more of what kind of impact will this have on somebody else. That’s how I feel about it. So it gets easier with experiences to make those decisions.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t know, I really don’t. I guess it’s just the effect that it’s going to have on someone else.
I:The consequences of it?
R:Yes
I:And what kind of consequences for you would make something wrong?
R:If it was going to hurt somebody else or hurt me or ruin somebody’s life you know, those kinds of things would make something wrong.
I:From where do you think you got your moral views?
R:Probably from my parents. I would say that I think it is a mixture. My dad’s not really the forgiving kind, he’s not really the kind of person that can see the other side. He’s kind of more of a cut and dry, right and wrong type person. My mom is the opposite. She’s forgiving, she can see where maybe you would have made that decision and why and it might have been right for you, where with my dad if it’s not what  he would have done, it’s not right. It’s kind of different.

column591: The respondent would primarily save the money for their child's future, influenced by a strong sense of responsibility and care for their well-being, while also acknowledging the moral teachings from their parents that guide their understanding of right and wrong, emphasizing the importance of considering the consequences of their actions on others and their reliance on both divine guidance and trusted advice in decision-making.

R:We all get along well.
I:Can you tell me—yeah—
R:We all get along well.  The kids are rambunctious but kids are kids, but you know, otherwise—everybody has their own space, it works out well.  I'm married.
I:So where do you think your common sense comes from?  What is that?
R:Experiences.
I:And so it’s basically based on consequences?
R:Off of experiences!
I:But the part that the experiences have taught you is—
R:What not to do.
I:Because if you make a wrong decision than you’ll get a negative consequence or something?
R:Yeah.
I:So what is a negative, like can you give me an example of—
R:Jail.
I:You’ve ever been in trouble with the law?
R:Yeah, jail, fines, what comes along with getting in trouble, scolded, yelled , everything in-between, just negative results.
I:And where do you think you acquired your moral views?
R:Um,
column590: Experiences that I’ve gone through. How have those taught me right or wrong? You learn from getting consequences.  If you obviously do something wrong, you get a consequence and you get in trouble and then if you do something right than you know it goes well, so experiences. It’s usually easy. It’s gotten easier. Just you know less, less predicaments.  You know, I'm with the family. We all get along well. We all get along well.  The kids are rambunctious but kids are kids, but you know, otherwise—everybody has their own space, it works out well.  I'm married.  Experiences. Off of experiences! What not to do. Yeah. Jail. Yeah, jail, fines, what comes along with getting in trouble, scolded, yelled , everything in-between, just negative results.  Um,
column591: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on personal experiences and the consequences of their actions, finds it easy to distinguish right from wrong due to a supportive family environment, and believes in adapting moral views while prioritizing self-care over helping others.

column588: The respondent plans to use an inheritance primarily for personal enjoyment, influenced by a belief that the money is theirs to keep, while their moral decision-making is heavily guided by lessons from their parents and a consideration of God's perspective, ultimately viewing life as a test of worthiness for heaven and emphasizing the importance of respect for others.

column583:
I:How do you see right and wrong?  How do you know it?
R:From what God says.
I:Yeah.  Uh, (pause), so, okay.  Thinking more than about what exactly makes something right and wrong.  You mentioned that it comes from what God says, do you mean that God speaks to you in the situation or that God speaks to you,
R:I believe the Bible.
I:Okay.
R:That’s how I believe God speaks to you through that.
I:Okay. So the Bible talks to you about what’s right and wrong and that’s how you get, get your source of right and wrong?
R:Uh-huh.
I:Um, okay.  Okay.  Is there anything, yeah I guess you’ve kind of answered this but is there anything that you could say that makes something right or wrong then?  I mean what is the essential, what does it mean that something is right or something is wrong?
R:What the Bible says I guess.
I:Okay.  Yeah, I just wanted to make sure that was what you were saying, I just wanted to confirm it.  And um, so if you were going to decide what’s good or bad or what’s right or wrong in life, um, what would you do?
R:I would read the Bible and pray.  Probably the most.
I:Okay.  Do you have any examples of a situation like that where you have to decide?
R:Not really, it’s all pretty clear right now.
column584: From what God says. I believe the Bible. That’s how I believe God speaks to you through that. Uh-huh. What the Bible says I guess. I would read the Bible and pray.  Probably the most. Not really, it’s all pretty clear right now.
column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are defined by the Bible and God's teachings, relies on trusted adults for guidance in uncertain situations, and perceives cultural peer pressure as a factor in moral confusion among peers, while feeling supported by their parents' consistent discipline and monitoring.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide, or even know, what is good or bad, right and wrong?
R:From scripture.
I:Would you say, in general, that it’s easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I think probably both.  I mean it’s, a lot of things are pretty clear between right and wrong, it doesn’t take much thinking, but  lot of everyday little situations its hard to apply that.
I:Okay, because things aren’t explicit in scripture?
R:Yeah, yeah.
I:Would you say in, like, the last 2 to 3 years or so would you say it’s gotten easier or harder for you to decide?
R:Easier.
I:Why is that?
R:I think just because I’ve gotten to know the scriptures better, and know myself better.
I:Have your views about right and wrong, have they changed at all in the last 2 or 3 years?
R:No.
I:What would you say it is that actually makes something right or wrong?
R:God does.  He decides what’s right and wrong; that’s revealed in scripture.
column590: From scripture. I think probably both.  I mean it’s, a lot of things are pretty clear between right and wrong, it doesn’t take much thinking, but  lot of everyday little situations its hard to apply that. Yeah, yeah. Easier. I think just because I’ve gotten to know the scriptures better, and know myself better. No.  God does.  He decides what’s right and wrong; that’s revealed in scripture.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on scripture to determine right and wrong, believes that moral truths are absolute as revealed by God, and feels a natural obligation to help others, viewing this duty as inherent in people’s hearts.

column585: The respondent acknowledges knowing right from wrong but often chooses to act on personal desires while ensuring not to harm others, cites social influences from friends and family regarding moral views, and expresses a belief that morality is relative, shaped by personal experiences and the desire for social acceptance, particularly in the context of drinking and drug use.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong?
R:I kind of look at in the long run, like in the whole scheme of things, like you know, I just kind of like, I’m a pretty peaceful person.  I’m really easy to get along with, like, I don’t want him to see me.  I’m pretty easy going.  I work at a restaurant, and oh the drama there, I swear to God.  But I try to stay neutral with everybody, but they come and bitch to me and I don’t like turn around and say oh but she said and that said, and she said this.  I’m just like, oh that sucks.  And I don’t want to just start anything.  And no one ever talks about me.  So I’m a pretty peaceful person.  I have good karma.   I like to think I have good karma, except me and my friends went out and egged cars.
I:And what?
R:We egged cars, that was the first time I ever did that in my life, so, so.  And then last night we stayed up until 8 o’clock in the morning cleaning my boyfriend’s room, so maybe that evened it out.
I:So when you egged cars, did you say to yourself this is wrong, I shouldn’t be doing this or not?
R:No, because I mean that’s not too harmful, it’s not like we were throwing bricks in peoples windows or you know, we dragged a couple trash cans a couple of feet, you know, but it was just mischief.  You know, my car’s gotten egged before, my house has gotten egged.  But we kind of did, it was someone in a convertible.  It was asking for it.  It was on the side of the road in the middle of the night with the top down.  I mean who does that?  Who does that?  But I mean that’s the worst thing I’ve ever done.  I mean I’ve never hurt anybody or like, did anything bad like that.  I mean I’m 18 years old and that was the first time I ever egged anybody.  But it was fun.  It was fun.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy, I kind of just, go with the flow of things, and whatever comes up I’ll figure it out.  And I’m a firm believer that you know what, it doesn’t matter what happens now, in the end things will work out.  Things can only get so bad and then they’ll turn around and get better for you.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Probably easier because I’ve gotten like a bigger perspective on the world.  After I graduated and went to college, I like totally like my mind just like shifted gears, the wheels were turning and like that.  So just a lot different, and they gave me a lot more experience and stuff like that, to be able to make decisions now.  So it’s gotten a lot easier.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, it’s all somebody’s perspective you know?  Like you might think it’s right for somebody to have an abortion, and I might not.  You know, it’s just who, what you believe is right and what you think in your head is right or wrong.  I mean there’s like things that obvious, like killing is wrong.  But like, not always.  It just depends on like the situation and your perspective, like the whole, what, what’s going on.  You know, you wouldn’t just go up and randomly kill somebody.  But if someone murdered your family then you’d you know, you’d want them dead, because they brought that on other people too.  So it just depends on your perspective of things, and how the situations and stuff.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves?
R:Um, I don’t know.  Taking over someone’s free will.  Everybody should have the will to do what they want.  I mean as long as it’s not affecting everyone else free will should be happy.  And everyone else should be happy.  That’s one thing I believe in is free will and stuff.
I:So what if someone is hurting other people, do you think
R:What?
I:If someone’s hurting other people should their free will be taken away?
R:Like physically hurting someone?
I:Or, emotionally or should they be made to stop if they’re hurting other people?
R:Well we might not necessarily take their free will away.  But like do something about it if they’re hurting someone then figure out, you know, why, or like, you know, put them in jail, where there’s like totally no free will.  We don’t have to control their lives as long as they’re like in a safe environment where they cant hurt anybody and you know, but if people, it depends on how extreme the case, you know.  If someone’s just beaten someone else up, then it’s different if someone murdered the town of Chicago, you know.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Um, all my experiences in life, I would imagine, like my family and my friends a lot.  I mean TV, I mean just like seeing things that happen on TV.  And books, you know, I mean just like everything, every minute of your life you learn something different.

column589:

R:I try to think about how it’s gonna affect me in the future and you know from somebody else’s perspective what would they what would be an objective point of view of this thing, and you know what my parents would think about it and what I think about it and if I want to do it or not, so. If it’s going to be something big, I like to make it a well thought out decision.

R:it’s pretty easy, I mean you should know what’s right and what’s wrong, but a lot of people don’t or don’t care.

I:like what?
R:M3:I dunno. R:like is it going to affect other people, is it going to put someone at danger or is it gonna you know put something at risk or is it illegal.

column583:
I:Where does he get his ideas about that, do you think?
R:Like abortion?
I:Like, about yeah, where, I mean, where did his idea of right and wrong come from?
R:Well like, I guess from the Bible I mean, it’s, it’s, blasphemous to have an abortion, like it’s against the Bible.  I don’t know and I guess since he’s finished school and you know whatever you’re doing to aim yourself to finish school then that sounds like the right thing to do.
I:Your Dad went all the way through college.
R:Mm-mm.
I:Okay.  And he gets his ideas of right and wrong largely from the Bible?
R:Yeah, from experience.
I:Um, so where do you think your views of right and wrong come from?
R:Probably from, some of them had to come from my Dad but other things just come from like what I’m feeling at the moment, like, like that’s how I feel and that’s what I’m gonna do, like if I used to cut class, if I don’t feel like going I just wouldn’t go, that’s wrong, it’s not right, but it’s the easiest thing to do so I did it.
I:Okay so convenience is one, or convenience or whatever’s easiest is one um, reason you make decisions and what you’re Dad thinks is another reason you make decisions and what makes you feel good.
R:Yeah.
I:Those are the things I think you’ve mentioned so far.
R:Yeah.
I:Where do those come from do you think, where do you, where did you get those ideas?  Well, for example, where does the idea that it’s easy and therefore that’s the, that makes it okay?
R:Well I don’t know, probably just being lazy.  Cause I mean, I think everyone wants to be lazy but you can’t afford to be lazy, and since I could always afford to be lazy then like I’ve always done it.  So like I don’t know, I do a lot of lazy things, like if I just don’t wanna get up, I just won’t, I mean if I have to get up to go to work, I would get up.
I:Mm-mm.
R:And it’s just, just things like that.
I:Okay, um, can you give me an example of ah, how you would, through a decision making process, so in others words, tell me about when you were trying to make a decision, how you went, step A, step B, step C, get to the, what you thought was right or wrong?  It can be little like when you’re deciding to go to class, okay, you have a class, and you don’t know whether to go or not.  All right, so now, tell me what happens.
R:Well, I think of, if I have something more better, that I feel better about, think of something better to do, if I had anything better to do.  And then I would think about, I mean, I would hardly ever think about getting caught, cause I would just stroll out of the building and like nobody would think anything, but if I was like dodging cars and like looking all around, they probably would be like oh she’s probably skipping and they’d run after me.  But I would always just stroll out like I was supposed to be leaving, I’m like, I’d probably think of how many days I skipped, so maybe I wouldn’t lose credit.  Then I could just forge like a class and then they’d probably give me the day off, I would think about all of that, and I usually ended up leaving, cause I could forge the teacher’s signature and then have like an excused absence.
column584: Well, I always ask my Dad, like with school I was like will this be right or will this be wrong and he was like— Yeah.  And he was like it seems like the right thing to do, you’re having such a hard time in school, not because you can’t do it but just because you don’t want to do it because they’re so boring and like I don’t know, Tita got pregnant like, even that I was like, Tita’s pregnant and he was like oh, that’s, that’s exciting, cause you know like, I guess like an older generation, when somebody got pregnant like they’re bringing a new life into the world, they should be happy, it’s like a joyous moment, I guess when a teenager gets pregnant it’s kind of like abortion or get yelled at like, and he was like oh that’s exciting and I was like oh, okay, I guess so.  So like she didn’t want to have an abortion cause she already, she had already had one so I was like okay I guess you’re gonna have a baby, like I didn’t know what, I mean, of course I’m gonna support whatever she wants to do, but I didn’t know if I was supporting the right thing, and my father was like you know, you can support her, that’s good. Like abortion? Well like, I guess from the Bible I mean, it’s, it’s, blasphemous to have an abortion, like it’s against the Bible.  I don’t know and I guess since he’s finished school and you know whatever you’re doing to aim yourself to finish school then that sounds like the right thing to do. Mm-mm. Mm-mm (yes). Yeah, from experience. Probably from, some of them had to come from my Dad but other things just come from like what I’m feeling at the moment, like, like that’s how I feel and that’s what I’m gonna do, like if I used to cut class, if I don’t feel like going I just wouldn’t go, that’s wrong, it’s not right, but it’s the easiest thing to do so I did it. Yeah. Yeah. Well I don’t know, probably just being lazy.  Cause I mean, I think everyone wants to be lazy but you can’t afford to be lazy, and since I could always afford to be lazy then like I’ve always done it.  So like I don’t know, I do a lot of lazy things, like if I just don’t wanna get up, I just won’t, I mean if I have to get up to go to work, I would get up. And it’s just, just things like that. Well, I think of, if I have something more better, that I feel better about, think of something better to do, if I had anything better to do.  And then I would think about, I mean, I would hardly ever think about getting caught, cause I would just stroll out of the building and like nobody would think anything, but if I was like dodging cars and like looking all around, they probably would be like oh she’s probably skipping and they’d run after me.  But I would always just stroll out like I was supposed to be leaving, I’m like, I’d probably think of how many days I skipped, so maybe I wouldn’t lose credit.  Then I could just forge like a class and then they’d probably give me the day off, I would think about all of that, and I usually ended up leaving, cause I could forge the teacher’s signature and then have like an excused absence.
column585: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on advice from their father, who influences their views on right and wrong through his experiences and biblical teachings, while also acknowledging the convenience of choices and their own feelings at the moment, leading to a mix of moral considerations and social influences from friends and family.

column583:
I:Okay, all right, that’s fine.  Tell me, where do you um, where do your own, what is your understanding of what’s right and wrong come from?
R:My understanding?
I:Yeah how do you, I mean, who, yeah where do you, how do you know what’s right and wrong?
R:How do I know?
I:Mm-mm.  Or how did you come to know what’s right and wrong?
R:Like how do I know, like okay, when I was younger, my Mom was, like when I used to do things wrong, Mom used to tell me, that’s not right and if I used to do that, something right, my Mom said that’s something that’s right.
I:Okay, your Mom?
R:Yeah.
I:Your Mom would tell you, okay.  And um, have, do you feel like you’ve been involved um, in anything that you think is wrong?  Have you ever been in, have you been done, have you done things or are doing things that are wrong?  Or you think is wrong?
column584: My understanding? How do I know? Like how do I know, like okay, when I was younger, my Mom was, like when I used to do things wrong, Mom used to tell me, that’s not right and if I used to do that, something right, my Mom said that’s something that’s right. Yeah.
column585: The respondent believes that people generally know what is right and wrong, attributes their understanding of morality to their mother's guidance, and emphasizes the importance of personal responsibility and consequences, particularly in relation to cheating and substance use, while also noting that they have not yet engaged in wrongdoing themselves.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Based on what my dad’s taught me and, based on what I’ve learned in school about, you know just general things and about the Bible and God. So pretty much that kind of stuff, and based on how to affect other people and myself.  You know, cause if it’s going to kill someone I’m not going to do it.  You know, that’s horrible.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think it depends on how the person is, um, deciding.  It depends on the heart of the matter and other things.
I:What do you mean?
R:Like if they’re um, if they’re doing it for the benefit for only themselves then it could only be a little bit wrong.  But if they’re doing it for the benefit for themselves and others, you know, like if it could affect others then I think it could be, you know, it just depends on how the person thinks of it. Like I don’t think God looks at the decisions you make, he looks at the heart and that’s what I think bases,
I:You said you wouldn’t, uh, you said you wouldn’t do something if it was going to kill somebody, um, why, why would that be something wrong to do?
R:Because I believe everyone has a chance to live.  Everyone should have a chance to live, even if they’ve killed someone else.  Like not really, like they shouldn’t live to kill someone else I mean like I think they should be able to have a second chance.  God gives second chances you know?  He gives like 5,000 chances, so.  You know and, so I think that everyone has a reason to be made on the earth to.  And once they fulfill that that’s when they should be able to die.  I’m not going to try and help them to not die, or to die or something, if they um, like you know if it’s not their time to die, they’re not going to die, basically how I see it.
I:Would you extend that to say that you wouldn’t do something to hurt somebody? I mean would it be whether it’s emotionally or physically?
R:If someone’s going to get hurt anyway.  Like I would try and make it so they weren’t hurt as bad.  Like based on the decision, but if it’s where either I get hurt or someone else get hurt, I’d rather I get hurt cause I know how I’m going to react to it, but I don’t know how they’ll react to it. So I’m kind of like,
I:Why is it important to try to keep people from being hurt?  I mean why does that matter?
R:Well, cause I know how it feels to be hurt.  It’s horrible and so, you know, I don’t want them to have to go through that, you know, so, I’m kind of like, like with my best friend and stuff, she’s the same way I am.  She would rather have herself get hurt than someone else.  So a lot of times we’re trying not to get each other hurt, so, it’s really kind of funny, but yeah.  I don’t know, I don’t like, I don’t like seeing people hurt either.
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?  How do you specifically make that choice, those decisions?
R:I ask other people a lot of times.  And then I kind of go with what I think.
I:Based on what they say?  What other people?  Your friends, your dad? Other people?
R:My friends, my dad.  Sometimes I pray but not as much as I should.
I:So when they give you their input, their advice or what they would do, what do you, how do you go about weighing that out?
R:Um, I kind of think,
I:And it might help if you have an example, I mean that might just tell me how you would decide one or another situation.  But if you don’t that’s okay too.
R:Well, I was going out with this one person one time and he was very like sexual and I was kind of like, you know, um, my dad doesn’t want me into that cause he wants to protect me from ruining my life or something. So he was kind of like, he was kind of like into you know all that kind of stuff, and he was trying like to get me to do things with him and I’d be like no.  You know, I don’t want to.  You know I don’t feel like I should until I’m married even.  You know so it’s kind of like that.  And um, so basically I kind of thought what should I do?  And I would ask my dad what would happen if I did this or I told you this and what would you say if I was pregnant or something.
I:Freaking him out probably.
R:Yeah.  He thought I was pregnant for awhile cause I asked him that (giggling).  I was like no dad I’m not pregnant.  And he’s like are you sure about that, you’re not screwing around or anything like that and I’m like NO!  So it was like, it was really funny though he doesn’t believe that right now.  He trusts me.  And um, but I basically would ask him what, if you were in that situation, what would you do and that kind of think and stuff like that.  And I told my friend Larissa and Ana E.  Those are like the only two people that I even told.  Cause Vanessa, she’s kind of like you know, she would be like, you know, I can’t believe that happened or something, or I can’t believe you know.  Like, he was asking you that kind of stuff, you know and then she might go and tell someone else or, and like I trust her but not fully completely kind of thing.  Cause she um, yeah, so.  I’d ask them and anyway it would be like, they would be like, well you shouldn’t you know, what would God do?  You know and they ask what would God do? And I would say he wouldn’t be doing any of that kind of stuff you know? At least until he was married and that kind of helps me also, you know I kind of knew already that I would tell him no and stuff.
I:So you think in some ways that you kind of knew what your friends would say and you knew you wanted to do, and in a way it was a way to help you make the decision you already knew you wanted to make?
R:Yeah.

column585: The respondent often relies on their intuition and gut feelings when making decisions, acknowledges the importance of prayer and guidance from their father, and feels guilty about past actions that conflicted with their moral upbringing, particularly regarding social influences and the desire to avoid hurting others.

column585: The respondent believes that most people know right from wrong, attributes their own understanding of morality to their mother's teachings, and feels that cheating and substance use are wrong, but does not express guilt over their own minor infractions.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, and right and wrong in life?
R:I get a feeling, something, you get a feeling like something’s gonna go bad or something. I just get a feeling.
I:So it’s like an internal? Just a feeling?
R:Yes.
I:And in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s easy.
I:It’s easy? Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easer or harder over the past 2 years?
R:It’s gotten easier.
I:Why do you think that is?
R:We learn from experiences. So we know what to do and what not to do from you past mistakes.
I:So your experiences help you to like see how situations turned out?
R:Yeah.
I:Have your views about what’s right and wrong changed at all in the past two years?
R:Have my views? No.
I:So you’ve held pretty constant?
R:Yes.
I:What do you think it is that makes something wrong or right?
R:I don’t know.
I:Do you think it’s maybe the consequences or something?
R:Yeah. That’s a big factor.
I:So like, if it harms other people, maybe?
R:Yes.
I:Yeah that?
R:Mhm.
I:What about how it makes you feel? Or you  feel?
R:Yeah, I wouldn’t do it if then I, if I felt bad.
I:So it’s your conscience?
R:Yeah.
I:But it’s also like consequences? So like are laws or rules, like, do you always have to follow the law? Or are there times when you can break it?
R:No. Keep the rules.
I:You should always follow the law?
R:You should.
I:Where have you acquired your moral views and beliefs?
R:My mom.

Yeah. No. Keep the rules. You should.  My mom.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on intuition and feelings to determine right from wrong, influenced by their mother's guidance, while acknowledging that consequences play a significant role in their moral decisions, and they believe that moral views can be relative depending on circumstances.

column583:

column584: Right and wrong.  Okay.  Well right is respect, right is to help others, benefit them, get people on their feet that maybe are down in the slump, a wrong thing is to solve your problems by taking out others, ah, stuff like that.
