column585: The respondent makes decisions based on what would cause the least problems for others, emphasizes the importance of respect and helping others as key moral values, and acknowledges social influences from peers and parents regarding behaviors like drinking and marijuana use, while also reflecting on personal growth and changing perspectives on these issues over time.
column586:
I:Okay.  Um, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:How do I decide?  Um, I guess by opinion.
I:Okay.  What do you usually base your opinion on?
R:Ah, well, it really depends what it is, but um, generally just how I feel towards it and if I want to do it or not.
I:Okay, um, do, are there any situations, or has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the last couple years?
R:I have to say it’s kind of just been the same in my life.
I:Okay, things aren’t getting more complicated or more clear in terms of that, your decision?
R:Yeah, a decision is kind of more of a simple thing for me to think of.  The only way it would be considered a harder, is just when we and my Mom don’t agree with something together and then that’ll take a little while to configure out.
I:So if you, say you and your Mom don’t agree about some, some course of action or whatever, how would you, what would you base it on, for you to figure out whether you think it’s right or wrong?  Would you go with what she thinks or are there other criteria you might use?
R:Um, mainly we’re gonna argue for a while on it.  And then eventually, she’s just gonna continue on until she wins.  That’s just kind of how she is, because the only reason I say continue on until she wins is because I’m just through with it.
I:Right, you don’t persist?
R:I don’t care to argue, I don’t enjoy it, so eventually I’ll just try to leave.
I:Okay.  So what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  What’s the basis on which you decide, that’s right, that’s wrong?
R:Um.  Ah.  Again, that’s mainly opinion, um.
I:Okay, so what, what kind of, you said, how you feel about it, what kinds of feelings would tip you off that, if I feel this way, that’s probably a wrong thing to do?
R:Ah, if I feel it’s wrong, it’s mainly based of .
I:This is a tough section of questions.
R:I would have to say I guess if it’s something I dislike, ah, hate, don’t enjoy, um, wish for a different source of—
I:Do you have any idea where your, where your feelings come from, like, you know, for instance, you, someone offers you coke and you look at that and say, no, that’s, that would be wrong for me to take coke, but somebody else can look at it and say that would be okay, what, why would you see that differently?  Where do your views on that come from?
R:Um, I’ve never had coke, so I can’t tell you exactly what it’s like, but just from what I’ve understood of what it is, it doesn’t seem to be something I would enjoy to do, based of what it can do to me in the long run.
I:Okay, so, maybe part of it might be the consequences of that?  Would that figure into your decision?  Like, what you think would be the outcome of taking that course of action?
R:Um, it could be there.  And also, just the idea of what I experience from it.
I:Okay, so you might base it on whether you think you would enjoy the experience or not?  Or you’d have a positive or negative—
R:Or, if I have done it and then eventually decide that I, that it really isn’t something I want to do.  For an example, have, did I ever tell you about cigarettes?
I:You probably did, but you can tell me again, because I’m not remembering exactly.
R:Ah, a while ago, I did think cigarettes were awesome and went through starting for about four months I would have three a day and then I converted to five a day for the next month and then eventually six a day and then that told me, hey, um, obviously it’s gonna continue to grow up or grow on or whatever  and um, and it does taste horrible and so I don’t really know why I’m doing it.  I did, for a while, would take nicotine and, as in rolling tobacco, and put it into a bong that’s like so big, fill that thing up and then take it all down and hold it in, making it fall over, like I would lose ability of what’s going on in my body and I found that somewhat entertaining for a little while but obviously it’s not gonna be good for my brain and after six months I decided to really get off nicotine, which was, I’m assuming a lot easier for me than anyone else that’s continued on it for a while.
I:Because you had just been smoking for about six months, you said?
R:Yes.
I:So, what, what it was, what was it, the key that made you decide you wanted to stop, what were the factors?
R:That it was advancing, with more.
I:Okay, so that, and you were thinking about what it would do to your body, eventually, was that part of it?
R:Um, well, I kind of knew throughout the time that obviously it does stuff to people because obviously have done, or gotten things, cancer is a good example, and ah, that, yeah it’s just mainly the reasons that it, well, tastes bad, it’s gonna do something to me, and it advanced.

column589:
I:Okay.  And how do you normally decide or know what is right or wrong, good or bad to - in life?
R:Right or wrong and what good and - okay.
I:So, yeah.  What’s right?  Or how do you know what’s right or wrong?
R:Well, that’s all based of opinion.  I guess that’s what you’re asking for is my opinion.  I always kinda feel the right - for right things - and of course, it always depends what the situation is - is if you’re not being negative.  But of course, that depends if it revolves around people or not because if you’re on your own doing something, then that’s not gonna be a person with you.
I:Yeah.  So how do you determine what being negative is?  Like, what makes something negative?
R:Making somebody feel sad.
I:Okay.  So it’s how you make people feel or -
R:Hurting somebody physically, holding a gun to their head.
I:Yeah.  Yeah.  Okay.  And in general, do you feel like it’s easier - or easy or hard for you to decide what’s right or wrong?
R:Most cases, I feel it’s easy because I think that’s in general, for everybody - that is because everybody has their own belief.  But there are some cases that I feel it’s really hard and ask my mom for help or my brother, depending on the situation, which is my dad.

But of course, that depends if it revolves around people or not because if you’re on your own doing something, then that’s not gonna be a person with you. Making somebody feel sad. Hurting somebody physically, holding a gun to their head. Most cases, I feel it’s easy because I think that’s in general, for everybody - that is because everybody has their own belief.  But there are some cases that I feel it’s really hard and ask my mom for help or my brother, depending on the situation, which is my dad.
column591: The respondent would use a $100,000 inheritance primarily to support education in performance arts, believes that determining right from wrong is based on personal opinion and social influences from family, and prefers to seek advice from parents when unsure about decisions, while also expressing a desire for a more cooperative world where people help each other.

I:
R:I don’t think war is right, cause they, you really don’t get anything from war except everybody dying for a piece of land that’s probably gonna get taken back anyway later on and, in a couple hundred years, but, so, depending how it’s right or wrong, I guess it’s what you feel is right, I don’t really, can’t, I can’t really explain it.
I:So it’s, so the, even the, to the extent of on the one hand you don’t want to hurt, you want, you want to draw the line at um, it’s not okay to hurt somebody, but how do you, why is that, let me, I just want to ask you one more time, why is hurting somebody, do you think that’s wrong if it’s dependent on whoever, whatever we all, individually think?  If you want to get something from me, for example, and you could take me down in one of your wrestling holds, assuming your shoulder wasn’t screwed up, why would you not do that, why would it be wrong to hurt me to take whatever I have?
R:Cause I don’t have a right to, cause everybody has their own right to their, for their, for themselves, they have the right to live or the right to be themselves, so you can’t force to take away their right from them, so.
I:M8:Okay, um,  can you give me, maybe one or two examples of, of M8:how, of, of deciding, of a dec—how you make a decision about, I don’t M8:know, something in our life that, whether it would be a right or wrong, do M8:you have any examples you could think of?  Like I mean, ah, I can throw M8:some ideas out but ah, I’d rather you, you know.
R:Like a scenario of right and wrong?
I:Yeah I mean something’s that actually happened, maybe happened in your life, you know whether it’s about schoolwork or whether it’s about you know, snagging something from the store, whether it’s about whatever.
R:M8:Like cheating on a test?
I:M8:You just took a big test today, so.
R:M8:I can’t cheat on it.
I:M8:You can’t cheat on that one, really, huh.  Yeah, I mean, what, what, ah, M8:how would you decide about that?
R:M8:If I would cheat on a test or not?  I would say I would cheat on a test for M8:the grade, but then it’s wrong because you’re not doing what’s right because M8:it’s not right to cheat because you have to do it by yourself without help, so M8:but then you get the grade, though.
I:M8:So the, so back to your sort of payoff.
R:M8:The payoff—
I:M8:Of cost and benefits, so that if you didn’t get caught, the, the benefit M8:would be a better grade, assuming you cheated off the right person.
R:M8:Right.

column585: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on weighing the pros and cons, acknowledges that moral standards are often subjective and influenced by personal upbringing, particularly their parents' teachings, and believes that while hurting others is generally wrong, individuals often justify their actions based on personal beliefs and circumstances.
column586:
I:That’s a lot of clothes.... Uh, how do you decide or know what’s good or bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Uhm, I guess the whole basic good and evil kind of thing. Maybe, the way I see it—how I see if it’s good or bad, I judge it that way.
I:How do you see that? How do you…is it easy for you to decide right and wrong?
R:Most of the times, I think, it’s pretty easy to see. But then I always kind of, like, as I, like, want my parents to be more open, I try to be more open. So I don’t really accuse anyone until I know why they’re so upset. So I really don’t get on anyone unless I know what’s going on. And if not, I kind of just let it go about itself.
I:Uh-huh. Do you think making those decisions about right and wrong have gotten easier or harder over the last couple years?
R:I think it’s gotten easier, because, back, I think, I was more accusing. I’d, I viewed whatever I thought was right, and you’re wrong. But now, I’m kind of a little more open to what everyone has to say. I don’t really blame anyone.
I:Let’s go back to how you said, that whole good and evil thing and that kind of stuff. What is it that you think that makes something right or wrong?
R:I guess, it’s been based on, like, my morals, I guess. How I think things are good or bad. Uhm, I guess I get it whether it hurts people or not? Or how much it affects someone, I guess.
I:So, something would be wrong would be hurting, like, other people? Hurting yourself? And hurting in what ways?
R:I guess, in more ways than one. Just general if it causes any disturbance, then, it could be. And then, depending on what causes it, would make it bad or good, I guess.
I:Uhm, so that would be sort of your dividing line between something that’s right or wrong is whether or not you’re going to have a disturbance or hurt somebody else or...?
R:I guess, how bad it affects other people.
I:OK. Uh, are there any actions you think that are in themselves right or wrong? Like, regardless of whether it hurts or not other people? Like something could be wrong in itself?
R:Uhm. I don’t know. Like, what would, what do you mean by that?
I:Well, I don’t know. Let’s use your example of your friend you got mad at for cheating at cards.
R:Uh-huh.
I:Was cheating wrong? Or was it...? What was it...?
R:I don’t....
I:Did you think that that was wrong?
R:I thought that was wrong, not because.... It wasn’t the cheating that really got to me, it’s just that he would break that trust between us. Because we trust him that this was just a fair game among each other. And then, he broke it, and, like, he stole. It’s that, he didn’t cheat. He, like, stole from us.
I:So the issue is more.... Let me ask it, not say it. Is the issue more trust or is the issue more stealing?
R:I would say it’s more on trust. Because we trust him not to steal. So. If he stole, like, I guess that would be the same way. But then, this is another, this is kind of more on the trust factor, because we’re all going in thinking that this is just between friends, but....
I:Would that be the same, say, you’re at Long Beach*, and you’re at your dorm. And you know these people, and you don’t really care about them. And you have a poker game, or whatever, and somebody cheated there. Would you get as upset as you did with your friend?
R:I wouldn’t, because I wouldn’t know him, so. I’d get mad, but I wouldn’t get as mad.
I:So would that be, so you wouldn’t judge that action in the same sort of moral sense as you did with your friend?
R:No.
I:And that’s because of the relationship and the trust?
R:Yeah.
I:And where do you think you’ve acquired your moral views? Where do your moral views come from?
R:I think it’s come from my parents. And then some from, I guess, my religious background. Not a lot of it. I’d say most is from how my parents raised me.

But then I always kind of, like, as I, like, want my parents to be more open, I try to be more open. So I don’t really accuse anyone until I know why they’re so upset. So I really don’t get on anyone unless I know what’s going on. And if not, I kind of just let it go about itself. I think it’s gotten easier, because, back, I think, I was more accusing. I’d, I viewed whatever I thought was right, and you’re wrong. But now, I’m kind of a little more open to what everyone has to say. I don’t really blame anyone.  I guess, it’s been based on, like, my morals, I guess. How I think things are good or bad. Uhm, I guess I get it whether it hurts people or not? Or how much it affects someone, I guess. I guess, in more ways than one. Just general if it causes any disturbance, then, it could be. And then, depending on what causes it, would make it bad or good, I guess. I guess, how bad it affects other people. Uhm. I don’t know. Like, what would, what do you mean by that? Uh-huh. I don’t.... I thought that was wrong, not because.... It wasn’t the cheating that really got to me, it’s just that he would break that trust between us. Because we trust him that this was just a fair game among each other. And then, he broke it, and, like, he stole. It’s that, he didn’t cheat. He, like, stole from us. I would say it’s more on trust. Because we trust him not to steal. So. If he stole, like, I guess that would be the same way. But then, this is another, this is kind of more on the trust factor, because we’re all going in thinking that this is just between friends, but.... I wouldn’t, because I wouldn’t know him, so. I’d get mad, but I wouldn’t get as mad. No. Yeah.  I think it’s come from my parents. And then some from, I guess, my religious background. Not a lot of it. I’d say most is from how my parents raised me.
column588: The respondent makes decisions by prioritizing savings and moderate spending, influenced by their understanding of good and evil based on personal morals and the impact on others, while acknowledging that their views on morality have evolved to be more open-minded, shaped primarily by their parents and a bit by their religious background.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I guess from what you’re told and also how I’ve been raised.  So certain issues I guess it’s just on what I believe and I, when I think about it, I don’t know where I got the assumption on whether that would be right or wrong but I kind of, I guess I just go with whatever I feel at the time.  I just answer with whatever I, what’s ever in my gut, I guess—
I:Like a gut feeling—and in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I guess if my gut feeling isn’t good enough, then I just kind of weigh out the options on which one is, which one I guess would make sense logically, I guess, if like, if I was choosing between right or wrong, which one seems more wrong and like kind of just based on the facts on which one does not work in my eyes, I guess that’s how I would choose.
I:So, let’s just, I want to understand how you’re thinking about this, so you would whatever the issues is, how do you judge logically in your mind as you’re working through this, what’s more right, is it because of consequences or because of some external principles that you believe in or other things?
R:I would guess how, um, depending on whether it’s good or bad I guess that would come down to whether that person is doing wrong to others or doing wrong to himself, whether that’s being based on if it’s good or bad or not and then if he, if I, if they’re doing harm to themselves or others than I already regard that as bad.  But then if there was an issue of whether they were doing harm, but then there’s other factors involved than, harder to decide whether he’s doing, what he’s doing is wrong or not, then kind of, I’d have to, if that ever happened I would just weigh out why his reasons for it and then his, and then what he’s actually doing.  So I guess, so that’s how I would.
I:So in general, whether there’s harm involved to other people, would about to the person?—Yeah.
R:That himself, then if it’s harm to others then I'm more inclined to call it bad because if you’re hurting others than it’s not, like you shouldn’t be doing that anyways and if anything, like I would regard hurting others before hurting yourself as worse off, I would guess, and then if you’re hurting yourself, that’s depended on why you are, which are mostly never good so it’s always, always kind of a dilemma when people are doing that kind of thing.
I:Would you say that in the last few years deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder?  Since the last time we talked?
R:I would say it’s harder now, just getting older you run into different situations and more circumstances—
I:There’s more complex situations you have to think about?
R:Yeah, I would say, just thinking whether it is a good thing or not, to do, or—
I:Where would you say your moral view come from?
R:I guess from all around, mostly from my parents and what they’ve taught me and then just from what you learn in society-wise, they tell you never to do that or to get in trouble by the law and certain things like that so I would say it’s just all kind of from everywhere I go really and then people that I meet and things change and your ideas change on whether you think it should or it shouldn’t be.  So it’s just kind of everything I guess, but then majority, my parents.
column590: I guess from what you’re told and also how I’ve been raised.  So certain issues I guess it’s just on what I believe and I, when I think about it, I don’t know where I got the assumption on whether that would be right or wrong but I kind of, I guess I just go with whatever I feel at the time.  I just answer with whatever I, what’s ever in my gut, I guess— I guess if my gut feeling isn’t good enough, then I just kind of weigh out the options on which one is, which one I guess would make sense logically, I guess, if like, if I was choosing between right or wrong, which one seems more wrong and like kind of just based on the facts on which one does not work in my eyes, I guess that’s how I would choose. I would guess how, um, depending on whether it’s good or bad I guess that would come down to whether that person is doing wrong to others or doing wrong to himself, whether that’s being based on if it’s good or bad or not and then if he, if I, if they’re doing harm to themselves or others than I already regard that as bad.  But then if there was an issue of whether they were doing harm, but then there’s other factors involved than, harder to decide whether he’s doing, what he’s doing is wrong or not, then kind of, I’d have to, if that ever happened I would just weigh out why his reasons for it and then his, and then what he’s actually doing.  So I guess, so that’s how I would. That himself, then if it’s harm to others then I'm more inclined to call it bad because if you’re hurting others than it’s not, like you shouldn’t be doing that anyways and if anything, like I would regard hurting others before hurting yourself as worse off, I would guess, and then if you’re hurting yourself, that’s depended on why you are, which are mostly never good so it’s always, always kind of a dilemma when people are doing that kind of thing. I would say it’s harder now, just getting older you run into different situations and more circumstances— Yeah, I would say, just thinking whether it is a good thing or not, to do, or—  I guess from all around, mostly from my parents and what they’ve taught me and then just from what you learn in society-wise, they tell you never to do that or to get in trouble by the law and certain things like that so I would say it’s just all kind of from everywhere I go really and then people that I meet and things change and your ideas change on whether you think it should or it shouldn’t be.  So it’s just kind of everything I guess, but then majority, my parents.
column591: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on gut feelings influenced by their upbringing and societal norms, weighing the consequences of actions on others, and ultimately prioritizes personal happiness in decision-making, while also acknowledging the complexity of moral dilemmas and the influence of friends and parents on their views.

column583:
I:Um, where would you say your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:My parents.
I:Okay.
R:religion too .
I:Okay.  Um, let’s see.  How do your parents, how would you say your parents teach you what’s right and wrong, like how have they?
R:What do you mean?
I:Like um, do they usually just kind of tell you, or do they use like the Bible, or something like that?
R:Oh, they tell you.
I:Mm-mm.
R:They discipline, too, so.  They teach you.
I:Oh, okay.  Um, let’s see.  When given a tough situation, how do you know what’s good or bad or right and wrong?  Do you, like what’s, how do you make that decision?
R:Talk to people.
I:Mm-mm.  Who do you usually talk to?
R:Um, my Mom, my sister.
I:Okay.  Um, do you trust their advice pretty well?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.  Um, let’s see.  Can you give me an example of a time when you went to your mother or your sister for advice, like what that was like, or?
R:I can’t think of any.
column584: My parents. religion too . What do you mean? Oh, they tell you. They discipline, too, so.  They teach you. Talk to people. Um, my Mom, my sister. Yeah. I can’t think of any.
column585: The respondent believes that a clear sense of right and wrong is instilled by their parents and religion, and they make decisions by consulting their mother and sister, while feeling guilty about lying and considering actions like cheating and substance use as morally wrong due to their consequences.
column589:
I:Ok.  How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:From my parents.
I:From your parents?
R:My upbringing.
I:And in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Easy.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:Easier.
I:Why?
R:Just being older and more experiences and knowing how to deal with people and situations.
I:Ok.  Have your views about what is right and wrong changed in the past two years?
R:I’d say a little bit.
I:How so?
R:New things – drinking and all that.
I:Ok.  So you – so what do you mean by that, though?  The drinking is now something acceptable to you?
R:Yeah.
I:And it previously wasn’t?
R:Yeah.
I:And what affected that change, do you think?
R:Just the college life.
I:Um hm.  Ok.  And what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Deciding.
I:What do you mean?
R:Say, just from the standards, laws and – don’t speed, even though you think you’re going safe.
I:Um hm.  Is that the only thing?  That – so when you personally think about what’s right and wrong, do you go by society’s standards?
R:No.  It’s also your experiences and yourself.
I:So how do you – how do you know what’s right and wrong?
R:A combination of your upbringing, what society tells you and your experiences and –
I:So do you think that people have different standards of what’s right and wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:And how does that work?
R:That’s how they are and what they believe to be right.
I:Do you think that there are moral absolutes?  That there are some things that are just wrong and that, like, should be wrong for everyone?  Or is everything sort of relative?
R:Relative.
I:You think so?  And so, like, is there anything that is always wrong?
R:I think murder would always be wrong.
I:And what makes it wrong?
R:Just to take someone else’s life, not your own – it’s not what you should do.
I:Ok.  So is stealing always wrong?
R:It depends if – like, if you’re actually starving, and you wanna steal some food, I’d say go for it.
I:Ok.  So do you think that there are kind of consequences that make things wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:Like, what sorts of things?
R:Consequences will make you think about what you’re going to do.  So if there’s no consequence, why not do it?
I:What about the idea of guilt?
R:Guilt .
I:And so where does guilt come from, do you think?
R:I have no idea.  Our conscience?
I:Ok.  I could have asked this already – so what do you mean a conscience?  Does everybody have a conscience?
R:Yeah.
I:Where does it come from?
R:I guess your upbringing.
I:Um hm.  So you still think it’s sort of, like, rooted in society?
R:Um hm.
I:Ok.  And where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Parents.
column590: From my parents. My upbringing. Easy. Easier. Just being older and more experiences and knowing how to deal with people and situations. I’d say a little bit. New things – drinking and all that. Yeah. Yeah. Just the college life.  Deciding. Say, just from the standards, laws and – don’t speed, even though you think you’re going safe. No.  It’s also your experiences and yourself. A combination of your upbringing, what society tells you and your experiences and – Yeah. That’s how they are and what they believe to be right. Relative. I think murder would always be wrong. Just to take someone else’s life, not your own – it’s not what you should do. It depends if – like, if you’re actually starving, and you wanna steal some food, I’d say go for it. Yeah. Consequences will make you think about what you’re going to do.  So if there’s no consequence, why not do it? Guilt . I have no idea.  Our conscience? Yeah. I guess your upbringing. Um hm.  Parents.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on their parents' teachings to discern right from wrong, finds it easier to make moral decisions as they gain more life experience, and believes that moral standards are relative, although they acknowledge a moral obligation to help others, particularly war veterans.

column583:
I:Okay. Where, where do you think your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:I’d say mostly from my parents.  And uh, just from people that I’ve been around my whole life.
I:Okay.  How, how do you decide if you’re in a certain situation, how do you decide if something’s good or bad or right or wrong?
R:(Sighs) It’s kind of funny.  Um, most of the time I pretty much base it on, you know, am I going to get in a whole lot of trouble for this? (Giggles) And then, it, it, kind of doesn’t sound right but I do, I base it on how much trouble I think I’m going to be in or how bad like my parents will view it as or police or you know, something like that.
I:So the consequences of it.
R:Yeah.
I:So if you, if there was something presented to you and you knew that you wouldn’t get in trouble for it, then you would think that would be, that that would be right, or that would be okay?
R:Well, no, it’s not so much if I just knew that I could get away with it, but like at my new, not, if I knew that I was going to get away with it anyways no matter what happened, but if I did get caught, it would be a trouble, you know, then it would still.  Like if I couldn’t get caught, but if I did.
I:Then if there would be consequences if you were to get caught, even if there was no way you would get caught.
R:Yeah.
I:Then you think that would be wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:Why?
R:Just cause, well if you’re gonna, usually you’re gonna get in trouble for doing something wrong so, if there’s something you’re gonna get in trouble for it’s usually pretty wrong, so.
I:So the fact that you would get in trouble for it is what tells you that this is wrong to do.
R:Yeah.
I:It, so if there was something that you didn’t think you would get in trouble for then that would mean to you that it wasn’t wrong…is that right?
R:Pretty much.
I:So, can you give me any specific examples of how you recently had to decide you know, how right or wrong something is?
R:Um, I’d, I can’t think of any recent examples, you know.
I:Okay.
R:It’s kind of, it’s hard to.
column584: I really couldn’t think of something, you know, unless you were in a dire situation or something you know. Yeah. I’d say mostly from my parents.  And uh, just from people that I’ve been around my whole life. (Sighs) It’s kind of funny.  Um, most of the time I pretty much base it on, you know, am I going to get in a whole lot of trouble for this? (Giggles) And then, it, it, kind of doesn’t sound right but I do, I base it on how much trouble I think I’m going to be in or how bad like my parents will view it as or police or you know, something like that. Yeah. Well, no, it’s not so much if I just knew that I could get away with it, but like at my new, not, if I knew that I was going to get away with it anyways no matter what happened, but if I did get caught, it would be a trouble, you know, then it would still.  Like if I couldn’t get caught, but if I did. Yeah. Yeah. Just cause, well if you’re gonna, usually you’re gonna get in trouble for doing something wrong so, if there’s something you’re gonna get in trouble for it’s usually pretty wrong, so. Yeah. Pretty much. Um, I’d, I can’t think of any recent examples, you know. It’s kind of, it’s hard to.
column585: The respondent believes that while people generally know right from wrong, their decisions often depend on the potential consequences and the influence of their parents, admitting to making choices based on whether they would get in trouble, and acknowledging that some actions, like smoking marijuana, are viewed as wrong by society but not necessarily by themselves.

column583:
I:Okay.  Okay.  Let’s see, when you think of where your views of right and wrong come from, where would you say the most important source of your view of right and wrong?
R:Hm, I would probably say from the morals of my karate, probably.
I:Uh-huh.  What, what are some of those morals?  Are they things that come from karate itself or is your teacher a very moral person?
R:Well, sort of a little bit from both.
I:Is there something about karate that creates morals in a way?  Does it give you a sense, what are some of the most important things about karate that um, that you look at and you like it, that it’s right, because it teaches,
R:Well for one thing, karate isn’t just about, I mean this form isn’t about learning how to fight, it’s about learning how to stay out of a fight, you know?  And, hm, you know, if, I don’t know, there’s a bunch of different moral code and stuff like that in it.
I:And you try to follow those?
column584: Hm, I would probably say from the morals of my karate, probably. Well, sort of a little bit from both. Well for one thing, karate isn’t just about, I mean this form isn’t about learning how to fight, it’s about learning how to stay out of a fight, you know?  And, hm, you know, if, I don’t know, there’s a bunch of different moral code and stuff like that in it.
column585: The respondent believes that their sense of right and wrong is primarily derived from the moral teachings of karate, feels no guilt about their actions, and acknowledges their parents' consistent discipline and supervision, which they view positively in the context of their home-schooled upbringing.

column583:
I:Where did you learn, or where did you get your pretty solid sense of what’s right and wrong, where did your views from, you think?
R:The ten commandments, like basic, it’s like just, I’m, I’ve broken like one of those.
I:Okay.  In your life, or recently?
R:Uh, both.
I:Okay.
R:Cause I don’t, I’ve never stolen anything, I’ve obviously never killed anybody, I mean, I haven’t broken any of those except one.
I:Um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Just um, I don't know, just, you’ll know, like if you have a choice between this or that and this has like risks, where you might get in trouble, or something, like something bad might happen and this way’s just like a safe way, obviously that’s the right way.
column584: The ten commandments, like basic, it’s like just, I’m, I’ve broken like one of those. Uh, both. Cause I don’t, I’ve never stolen anything, I’ve obviously never killed anybody, I mean, I haven’t broken any of those except one. Just um, I don't know, just, you’ll know, like if you have a choice between this or that and this has like risks, where you might get in trouble, or something, like something bad might happen and this way’s just like a safe way, obviously that’s the right way.
column585: The respondent believes they have a clear understanding of right and wrong, which is influenced by their religious upbringing and the Ten Commandments, and they feel guilty about actions like lying to their parents and having sex, while also opposing friends involved in gangs and drugs, emphasizing that they do not feel pressured by peers to engage in drinking or drug use.
column586:
I:how do you know or decide what’s good or bad, how do you differentiate, what’s good or bad, what’s right or wrong?
R:like how do I figure out what’s good or bad or right or wrong?
I:yeah, like with situations you come into contact with during the day, how do you determine?
R:well, people say you can rationalize it, in my life there’s no rationalizing, you’re gonna do bad or you’re gonna do good, for some reason you just know. Like you, there’s really no…well I guess maybe it’s society, like growing up as a little kid, learning things, but people rationalize too much and they’re like oh, if I just do a little bit of this it’s not as bad. I mean I do bad things, don’t get me wrong, but I know they’re bad when I’m doing it, I don’t say like oh that’s good and lie to myself.
I:I see. Has it been harder to decide between what’s right and wrong?
R:I mean I know, that’s the thing, I know what’s right and wrong. I know, like what’s good and bad, it’s just deciding whether I’m going to do it or not.
I:so it hasn’t gotten any harder over the last few years?
R:no.
I:well what do you think makes something right or wrong?
R:what makes something right or wrong?
I:umhum.
R:well morally I guess you could say, if it goes against what my beliefs are religious-wise it’s wrong, or certain things like that. And I guess you just learn it growing up. I mean, I can’t explain how I learned right and wrong, you just know I guess.
I:so you, what you’re saying you were taught that way?
R:yeah.
I:and pretty much from what you’re saying as well, you’re taught in a way that’s pretty clear, pretty easy for you to decide now what falls in whichever category, and you haven’t been stuck anytime recently?
R:uhuh. I mean it’s not about being stuck, it’s like this is wrong. Like, listening to the music I listen to, it’s kind of wrong you know what I mean, the things that they talk about, but I don’t care ‘cause that’s what I like to listen to. it’s not about oh is it right or is it wrong, it’s just right or wrong.
I:okay, so where did you get your moral views from?
R:my parents probably.
I:and how did they communicate that to you? Can you think of ways that they did that?
R:I don’t know ‘cause I never, when I was a kid I didn’t get into any trouble at all, like at all. So I was kind of seeing that other, observing of kids getting into trouble.
I:any other avenues by which you received the understanding of what’s right and wrong?
R:not that I can think of.

column588: The respondent would use an inheritance of $100,000 primarily for school and to help family members in need, emphasizing the importance of family support and the joy of giving, while also expressing a clear understanding of right and wrong based on personal beliefs and societal influences, particularly from their parents and religious upbringing.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what's good or bad or right and wrong in life?
R:I think everybody knows what's right and wrong.  It's--you--everybody's--I think everybody's smart enough to know right and wrong.  That's like, basic knowledge, right and wrong.  You decide to follow it, to do it or break the rules.
I:And is that easy or hard for you to decide, to see what's right?
R:I mean, depends on how, what kind of situation you're in.  Like certain situations, it's easy.  It's real easy.  Like, I'm not gonna go kill somebody, because, that would ruin, like, you know what I mean?  Like there's no point.
I:Yeah.  What about other--what would be ones that are less obvious.
R:Less obvious is like--
I:Killing somebody--
R:'Cause everything
I:But I mean in everyday life--
R:'Cause to me, to me everything seems obvious.  I, I really just choose to break the rules or to do it, you know?  Like--
I:So you know when you're doing something wrong?
R:Almost every time.
I:And has that--has making that decision become, gotten easier or harder for you over the last three years?  To do the right thing or to break the rules.
R:Easier.
I:Easier?
R:As you get older it's always easier, just--you know, I don't need.  There's a lot of things you avoid.
I:So, ok, I just, so why has it gotten easier for you?
R:There's no, there's no pressure to do any of it.  Like, there's never pressure.  It's just--it--you are who you are.  And you just decide.  I mean, if I wanna do--if there's something I do wrong all the time, I just do it wrong all the time.    But, if not, you just don't.
I:What is it you think that makes something right or wrong?  You say that everybody that, that most everybody knows what's right or wrong.  But what is it that actually makes something right or wrong?
R:I think there's like a--There's universal right and wrongs, but then there's certain things that--Whatever culture believes is right and wrong, 'cause certain people, they've never heard the things that I've heard, so they, they would--they don't have the same judgment I have, because they've grown up different.
I:What would be the universal right and wrongs, do you think?  And what would make them universal, I guess?
R:Like the commandments are basically--I, I would THINK they're universal.  Even though, I guess, I-- I kinda think like, since you're born, like, you don't wanna grow up and kill people, or you don't wanna grow up and hurt other people.  Like, having a good relationship with people around you.
I:So you think the Ten Commandments, unless you , those are your example, are sort of a universal right and wrong stamp.
R:Well, not all the commandments, and some of them are do in that religion, like--So some about what God and them--
I:So what is it about those that makes them universal?  Is it because they will happen if you break them, or because God gave them to us, or because they're in the Bible, or because--just because?
R:Well that, well--I guess I'd say that came to my head because that's what I know.  But if you're in another religion, I'm sure they have their own thing, like they would refer to.  But I kinda think that certain things, that, they'll blend together.  Like, I don't see, I don't really think that there's a lotta religions that agree with murder or agree with stealing or stuff like that.
I:So, blend together, you mean like, they'll blend together what's going on in the culture?
R:Like, 'cause the Ten Commandments, they have things like, like:  Keep only the Sabbath, or like, false gods and stuff, where that's gonna be, that's gonna be completely out of a different religion, but I'm sure in that religion, they don't agree with killing people. So, like, certian things will blend in.
I:And your moral views, where have you gotten your moral views from?
R:From my parents a lot, and then, just certain stuff I decide to do.  Like, I, I can agree or disagree, like.  But mostly just from my parents.  I see them and I take what I want and leave out what I don't.

column591: The respondent primarily relies on personal intuition and the desire to support their son when making decisions, while also acknowledging the influence of their parents on their moral views and recognizing the challenges of adhering to societal expectations, such as attending church, despite understanding the universal nature of certain moral principles.

You know just, just cause, you know.

column585: The respondent makes decisions based on a desire for consistency with their beliefs to avoid being two-faced, influenced by their family's teachings and their own common sense, while also feeling a sense of guilt for potentially leading others astray and maintaining a strong stance against underage drinking and drug use, which they attribute to their faith and the expectations set by their parents and peers.
column589:
I:Ok.  And how do you normally decide what is good or bad, right or wrong in life?
R:First of all, how is it going to affect others?  The people around you like even if you don’t know them from like your right arm or your left, they are still people and I always wonder how it will effect them, and will it effect me in the long run.  Also, like my faith.  I think people know why they believe in…even if you believe in nothing you believe in something because you are choosing.  Everyone has a level of morals and I would go by that.
I:And how easy or difficult is it for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Pretty easy.  I always get little stomach feelings.  I go a lot by those.  Like oh that didn’t feel good, so I don’t think its right.
I:So it is like an internal thing.
R:Yeah.
I:Do you think that deciding between what is right or wrong to do has gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:I mean just because I know the right thing to do, doesn’t mean I do it and so I think it is always harder because you want to please everyone, you really do.  And you want to make sure you are doing the right thing, but sometimes I might choose things to please others that might not be the right thing.  So it can get harder, because then you can be unhappy.  But then why do you choose the right thing?  It is like you know; you have a peace about it and you can go on.  So it is circumstantial.
I:What is it that you think makes something a right or wrong thing?  How do you know what makes it right or wrong.
R:How it affects others, and how it affects you.  If it is just morally wrong, I know everyone has different morals but at the same time someone may have offended you and they are coming at you, but hitting them still isn’t right.
I:So is it more of a feelings things or a consequences thing?
R:I think it is a feelings thing.
I:So where do you think that you acquire your personal moral views about things?
R:By my faith.
I:And have your views about right and wrong changed over the past three years, or not?
R:Yeah I think they have been changing my whole life as I learn.

column591: The respondent would use the hypothetical $100,000 inheritance to travel and provide aid to children in need, making decisions based on the impact on others, their faith, and personal intuition, while reflecting on the importance of moral obligations to help others and the influence of their grandmother as a role model.

column589:
I:Okay.  And how do you normally decide or know what’s good or bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Generally, I just go with my gut instincts, really.  If something doesn’t seem right, I don’t do it.  And aside from that, I always have to look at what’s best for my daughter.  And if it’s something that’s going to hurt her, I don’t do it.
I:Okay.  And in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s usually pretty easy.  I mean, you know, if something strikes me as wrong, I just – you know, I don’t push it.  I just don’t do it.
I:And has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the last few years?
R:Well, since I had my daughter, it’s gotten a lot easier, you know.  It’s not, well, maybe this will turn out bad; it’s, you know, it’s probably gonna turn out bad.
I:Okay.  And what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Well, the law, first of all, you know, not doing stuff that’s illegal is usually a good priority.  And then also there is, you know, just making sure that, you know, whatever it is that I’m doing isn’t harmful to myself or my daughter or other people.
I:And what kinds of, what kinds of consequences would be harmful?  Like physical harm or –
R:Physical harm or even, really, emotional harm I would say, just because I’m the kind of person I don’t like people to have hurt feelings.
I:And, and so how do you know if, if something’s going to be hurtful to someone?
R:I just try and think about if I were in their place, you know, what – how would I feel.  And if it would hurt me, then I try not to do it to them because, you know, I don’t know necessarily if it would hurt them if it – you know, as the same it would hurt me.  But, you know, if I think it would hurt me, then I’m just going to assume it would hurt them.

And if it’s something that’s going to hurt her, I don’t do it. It’s usually pretty easy.  I mean, you know, if something strikes me as wrong, I just – you know, I don’t push it.  I just don’t do it. Well, since I had my daughter, it’s gotten a lot easier, you know.  It’s not, well, maybe this will turn out bad; it’s, you know, it’s probably gonna turn out bad.  Well, the law, first of all, you know, not doing stuff that’s illegal is usually a good priority.  And then also there is, you know, just making sure that, you know, whatever it is that I’m doing isn’t harmful to myself or my daughter or other people. Physical harm or even, really, emotional harm I would say, just because I’m the kind of person I don’t like people to have hurt feelings. I just try and think about if I were in their place, you know, what – how would I feel.  And if it would hurt me, then I try not to do it to them because, you know, I don’t know necessarily if it would hurt them if it – you know, as the same it would hurt me.  But, you know, if I think it would hurt me, then I’m just going to assume it would hurt them.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on gut instincts and prioritizes decisions that benefit her daughter, finding it easier to discern right from wrong since becoming a parent, while also emphasizing the importance of not causing harm to others and rejecting the idea of breaking moral rules for personal gain, despite acknowledging the influence of her mother's values on her choices.

column583:
I:Where do you think rights and wrongs come from?
R:I don’t know, like it’s like, the law, like if you go against the law it’s wrong.
I:How, how do we know what to make into a law, is there something beyond the law that makes things right or wrong?
R:God.
I:God does?
R:Yeah what he wants you to do.
I:Okay.  So how would you know what God wants you to do?
R:Pray.  Ask him what’s right or wrong.
I:Do you, okay um, where do your own views about what you think is right and wrong come from?
R:Mm, my parents, what they taught me, God, the law.
I:Mm-mm, okay.
R:What my friends do.
I:What your friends do, helps you to know right and wrong?
R:No, but it helps me choose from right and wrong.
I:You like, so you mean you view, you look at what they’re doing and then you think about what you want to do?  Mm-mm.
R:Yeah like if my friend Brandy, she’s normally really, really bratty, most of the time and so I look at her and then I go I don’t want to act like that and so.
column584: I don’t know, like it’s like, the law, like if you go against the law it’s wrong. God. Yeah what he wants you to do. Pray.  Ask him what’s right or wrong. Mm, my parents, what they taught me, God, the law. What my friends do. No, but it helps me choose from right and wrong. Yeah like if my friend Brandy, she’s normally really, really bratty, most of the time and so I look at her and then I go I don’t want to act like that and so.
column585: The respondent believes that people generally know right from wrong but often choose to do wrong for fun, citing influences from God, their parents, and friends in shaping their moral views, while also admitting to engaging in vandalism for the thrill of it, which they rationalize as not being significantly harmful.
column586:
I:Okay.  Um, I have some questions about morality.  Thinking about good and bad, right and wrong, wise and unwise, just and unjust and how, how do you ah, how do you know what’s good and bad in life, right and wrong?  Or do, first of all, do you?
R:I know.  Yeah, I know.
I:Yeah.  How do you know that?
R:Just by um, like Christian beliefs and laws and just—
I:Like governmental laws.
R:--you know, you can, you can just feel what’s right and wrong, you know, well, stealing this is wrong.
I:So you mean like, a conscience?  Or?
R:Yeah.
I:Yeah, okay.
R:Do I always listen to it?  No.
I:Okay, but you know it’s there.
R:Like, yeah, like I know drinking is wrong.  I should probably not hang out with some of the people I hang out with, it’s wrong.  But, I do it anyways because it’s fun.
I:Why is it wrong to hang out with people?
R:Well, no, just like some of the people are not very good influences, and they do pretty bad stuff, but they’re my friends and so.
I:What is the bad stuff they do?
R:Drugs.  Drinking.  Stuff like that.
I:Drugs, like pot or hard drugs or what?
R:Well a couple people, mm, mostly pot.  But some of my friends do harder drugs, like crack and stuff.  Which I would never do.  I do pot.  But I don’t—
I:But you hang with them.
R:Yeah.  They’re my friends, you know, it’s their life, they can do what they want, as long as they, you know, it doesn’t—
I:All right.  Um, so you’re saying, you pretty much always know what’s right or wrong and it’s a separate matter whether you do that.
R:Mm-mm (yes).
I:Do you mostly do what you think is right, or, and just occasionally do, or do you, are you--?
R:It’s, I don’t know.  It depends on the day.
I:Yeah, okay.  Um, has, has dealing with moral issues, right or wrong, good or bad, gotten harder or easier in the last two years, since we last talked?
R:Um, knowing that it’s right or wrong, just as easy, you know.  I, it’s easy to know what’s right or wrong.  Choosing what’s right or wrong is easy, too, it’s just the fact that I normally choose wrong more than right.
I:Okay.  So it’s not gotten easier or harder, it’s just that you’re choosing somewhat differently.
R:Yes.
I:And why do you think that’s changed in the last two years?
R:Because doing what’s wrong is more fun than doing what’s right.
I:Okay.  Do you think there are any costs to doing what’s wrong?
R:Probably.  There’s just none yet.
I:Okay, so you’re just enjoying, you’re having fun, doing the wrong.
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.
R:It’s probably gonna catch up with me one of these days and I guess I’ll deal with it, then.
I:Do you have any idea what the catching up will look like?
R:Getting caught drinking, going to jail, I don’t know.  Getting fined. I, I’m more of the influencer, I’m more of a leader than a follower.  I don’t really, like if someone will tell me something, what to do, I won’t listen to them, I’ll do whatever I want, pretty much.
I:Okay.  All right.  Um.  Now, so, you think certain things are right, and certain things are wrong.  What is it that makes things right or wrong?
R:Your beliefs.
I:Like, what?
R:Laws.  Like—
I:So if the government says, this is against the law, that makes it wrong.
R:Well, technically, yes.  It is.
I:Does it make it illegal or does it make it morally wrong.
R:Oh, illegal.
I:What is it that makes things morally wrong?
R:Your beliefs, your morals, your religion, your parents, stuff like that.
I:So, what are, um, okay.  But, if your parents, let’s suppose your parents were weird and they said, it’s wrong to drive a green car.  You would say, it’s not wrong—
R:Are you crazy?
I:I mean, you may not like that, but it’s not wrong.  So, how is it that parents saying something makes it wrong?
R:I don’t know.  It’s just the way things are.
I:So what, so what makes something wrong, just because it hurts somebody?
R:Because it’s wrong, because it hurts them?   I don’t know.
I:So, anything that hurts somebody is wrong?
R:Yes!  That’s what I believe.  Yes.
I:Okay.  What’s wrong with hurting somebody?
R:Because it hurts them.  I don’t know!
I:Well, I’m not trying to terrorize you, here, I’m just curious how you think about it.
R:It just, it just is.
I:So you’re saying—
R:There’s just some things, it’s just the way things are.
I:Okay.  So it’s a general, moral rule, that people should—morally, should not hurt each other?
R:Yes.
I:Okay.  And you think that’s just the way things are?
R:Yes.
I:In the universe, it’s just the fabric of reality?
R:Yes.
I:Okay.  Earlier you said you thought morality might have something to do with religion?
R:Yeah, kind of.
I:How might it?
R:Well—
I:Or, in what ways?
R:Some people, like Christians, believe in some things and Mormons believe in some things and Jews believe in some things and it’s each to their own.
I:Uh-huh.  So when you say that you’re a Christian, do you think that Christian faith influences how you think about moral right and wrong?
R:It used to.
I:It used to.  Meaning, it doesn’t anymore?
R:Not really. Well, the people who believe in them, they think it applies to everybody, it should apply to everybody.  But, it doesn’t.  It just depends on if you believe in them or not.
I:So you’re saying, you don’t think the 10 commandments applies to everybody, it’s just if you believe in those?
R:Well, I think they sh—um, I’m confused.  I don’t know.
I:Okay.
R:Like, they, to some people it doesn’t apply to them because they don’t believe in it, but other people believe that they should apply to them, other people like, it does, like Christians, the 10 commandments, think they apply to everybody, just people choose not to do them.  And then, but the people who don’t believe in the 10 commandments think that they don’t apply, that it’s not there.
I:Okay.  Um, what about, you know, in the old days, the Romans used to feed people to lions for entertainment.  Now that’s clearly hurting somebody.  Do you think they were wrong, morally?
R:I just think they’re messed up .  I guess, I don’t know, that was their time, their day and age.  So.
I:So you find it hard to judge that?
R:I don’t like judging other people.

Do I always listen to it?  No. Like, yeah, like I know drinking is wrong.  I should probably not hang out with some of the people I hang out with, it’s wrong.  But, I do it anyways because it’s fun. column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:Conscious I guess.  From what my mom taught me.
I:So your mom taught you stuff and that’s stuck with you and now when you sort of go about living that’s what you rely on?
R:Yeah.
I:And in general is it easy or hard for you to know what’s right or wrong?
R:It’s easy, it’s just making the choice of doing it.
I:What you think is right or wrong?
R:What I think.  It’s pretty easy because like I said I’m really open to things and so it doesn’t really, and I don’t have any regrets just because at that point and time it’s exactly what you wanted to do so why regret when you can’t change anything, you know?
I:Have your views on what’s right or wrong changed at all in the last three years?
R:Yeah.
I:In what way?
R:Well I guess not in the last three years, but from like the time I was younger until the time I moved out.
I:How did anything change?
R:I realized that some of the things your parents say not to do is more so because they are really concerned and worried about you rather than it being wrong to do.
I:So it’s okay, but it’s just…  But are they right that it’s risky?
R:Yes, they are right that it’s risky.  You just gotta be safe in what you’re doing.
I:So you used to think they were morally wrong and now you just think they are cautions?
R:Umhmm.
I:Like what would be examples of that?
R:Like drinking or going bungee jumping or skydiving, stuff like that.
I:Have you done bungee jumping or skydiving?
R:No, I want to.
I:Okay.
R:I want to really bad.
I:So be careful about it.
R:Yes.  Like my mom always scared me out of doing stuff like that.
I:So do you have kind of a risk attracted personality?  Do you like living on the edge?
R:I do.  I do a lot.
I:And that’s part of your sort of rebellious whatever?
R:I guess.  I don’t know.  I’ve just always, I guess you could say adrenaline junkie.  I like the adrenaline.  I like doing scary things.  It’s fun.
I:What’s the scariest thing you’ve ever done?
R:Oh man, white water rafting probably.  I haven’t had a lot of money to do the things that I want to do.
I:What is it that you think makes something right or wrong?  Now not the cautionary things, but like morally right or wrong things.  What is it that makes morality what it is?
R:I couldn’t tell ya.  I guess it’s just personal beliefs, religion, parents…

column591: The respondent primarily relies on their mother's teachings to discern right from wrong, acknowledges the importance of personal beliefs and religion in shaping morality, and expresses a desire to live life to the fullest while also recognizing the risks associated with certain actions, such as bungee jumping or skydiving.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:You just know.  I mean you’ve just been taught.  You know what’s right and you know what’s wrong, but you have a feeling, you’re conscious will squeeze you in the pit of your stomach if you know it’s wrong and you’re doing it anyway.  So it’s just something you’ve been taught, it’s something you’ve grown up.  You’d either instill it in yourself if you didn’t really have good parents, or you had good parents who instilled it in you, and you see it from example.
I:Do you think right and wrong is the same for everyone then?  Are there like moral absolutes?
R:Unfortunately a lot of people have probably been taught wrong.  But I think right and wrong, it’s very distinct.  I think people probably know it or feel it, but do the opposite anyway, but right - right - you know you shouldn’t kill somebody, and people do.  So I mean right and wrong I think is very distinct.
I:So do you think that when people do things that are wrong, like they know it, like they’re - they’re just ignoring that feeling?
R:Unless they have a neurological disease, yes.
I:And in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s very easy.
I:And has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:Easier.
I:Why is that?
R:Probably just because I - I keep myself - my schedule is so - it’s so involved that I don’t really stray, I don’t stray to parties or anything like that, so I’m never really presented with choices other than what I’m used to.
I:Gotcha.  And have your views about what is right and what is wrong changed in the past two years?
R:Not really.  I still - I try t accept other people’s rights and wrongs as what they choose to do, but for me, my rights and wrongs are always gonna be the same.
I:What do you think it is that make something right or wrong?
R:The consequences.  Knowing - What was the question?  I’m sorry.
I:I’m sorry.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Oh, the consequences.
I:The consequences.
R:Knowing what the outcome is gonna be, if it’s gonna affect anybody in a negative way.  Sometimes right and wrong, it’s - it’s - there still might be negative consequences, like maybe if somebody’s lying to their parents and you’re not gonna lie for them kinda thing, there might be negative consequences where somebody might not be your friend, or might look at you badly, or not as a friend, but you - you just know.  Even if there are negative consequences, there’s right and wrong.

Even if there are negative consequences, there’s right and wrong.
column591: The respondent would use an inheritance of $100,000 to pay off bills and potentially buy a house, attributing their understanding of right and wrong to lessons learned from their upbringing and a strong sense of intuition, while also acknowledging the influence of their parents in shaping their moral compass.

column583:
I:Okay.  Um, so where do you think, I mean in these situations where you can think yeah, there’s definitely a right and wrong, where do you think your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:My grandmother.  Definitely my grandmother cause you know she’ll always talk about you know drugs and drinking again, you know she’ll always talk about that you know different situations she was in you know, it’s really helpful when she puts her opinions and situations she’s been in, it really helps out a lot.
I:Okay, um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong? Are there guidelines you follow?
R:I really don’t think there is a guideline to where you can follow yes or no, it’s just basically gut instinct, if you’re that kind of person you do this thing, if you’re not, you know you don’t.  I really, it’s all about gut instinct for me, I really don’t follow any guidelines.
I:Do you think there’s um, even though it sort of feels like the gut somehow, do you think, where does that gut get developed or those ideas?
R:Friends and grandparents.  Definitely them, cause you know like I said I’ll put myself in my friends situation and I’ll get stuff from my grandmother and it just, that’s where it comes from.
I:Okay, um, so can you give me some specific examples maybe?  Things you were thinking about when we started out and were saying sometimes it’s tough to decide what’s right and wrong and you kind of have to choose, whether it’s go by your gut or what your friend would do?
R:There’s been one time really recently, like maybe a week ago that I went out with my friends you know and then they left, their parents picked them up and I thought my mom was supposed to be picking all of us up so I was left with one guy and so you know I called my mom and I didn’t want to tell her that a guy was dropping me off so I just said that some of my like my mom’s, my friends parent was gonna pick me up and then you know he drives and he brung out um a little marijuana joint, you know I’m just like no, you know I’m just gonna call my mom and everything so you know I got out of the car, I really, I was not thinking at all, I just got out, I just saw it and I was just like no that’s okay cause I know if I did, I'd get killed.  My mom would smell it right away and she’d lock me in my room so basically,
I:So that instant when you saw it and decided to get out of the car, you made a decision of what was
R:Yeah, I didn’t, there was no gut instinct on that one, there was just get out of the car now just,
I:And you said you thought of what your mom would say so she’s made it pretty clear to you that that is wrong,
R:Yeah.
I:So in that situation you sort of went on what your parents, what your mom,
R:Yeah, but like my mom really hasn’t talked about it much, she doesn’t, well she pretty much hasn’t talked about it at all you know I’ve been through some stuff that she’s, she’s really grounded me for a while, you know so I just did not want to do that again, that was not fun, so I was just like,
I:Was it all for reasons about your mom or was there anything that sort of you’ve decided in your head that you’re not gonna smoke marijuana and there’s reasons why or is it just really don’t want to get in trouble with your mom?
R:I really think it’s just you know my actions will probably cause a reaction to her hand to my face.  So yeah, it’s pretty much what my mom’s gonna do, you know my actions, what she’s gonna do.

Definitely my grandmother cause you know she’ll always talk about you know drugs and drinking again, you know she’ll always talk about that you know different situations she was in you know, it’s really helpful when she puts her opinions and situations she’s been in, it really helps out a lot. I really don’t think there is a guideline to where you can follow yes or no, it’s just basically gut instinct, if you’re that kind of person you do this thing, if you’re not, you know you don’t. My mom would smell it right away and she’d lock me in my room so basically, Yeah, I didn’t, there was no gut instinct on that one, there was just get out of the car now just, Yeah. Yeah, but like my mom really hasn’t talked about it much, she doesn’t, well she pretty much hasn’t talked about it at all you know I’ve been through some stuff that she’s, she’s really grounded me for a while, you know so I just did not want to do that again, that was not fun, so I was just like, I really think it’s just you know my actions will probably cause a reaction to her hand to my face.  So yeah, it’s pretty much what my mom’s gonna do, you know my actions, what she’s gonna do.
column585: The respondent often relies on gut instinct and the influence of friends and her grandmother when making decisions about right and wrong, while also feeling pressured by her mother's strict expectations and the potential consequences of her actions, particularly regarding substance use and peer pressure.
column586:
I:How do you typically decide what’s good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:How do I decide?  Ah, if I feel, if I feel like something is wrong, I’ll either tell someone or I’ll either ask someone what’s going on or if I, if nothing, if they don’t say that nothing is going on, you know, I usually just kind of stay with them, keep quiet and see what’s, see what’s really going on.
I:Yeah, you said sometimes you feel if it’s right or wrong, where do you think those feelings come from?
R:Instinct.  Like if, um, if everyone is quiet, like cause like now I know like how everyone reacts if something really bad is going on, like my Aunt’s wedding and everything.  Because there’s a whole lot of different reactions and you know, if we asked what was going on, they’ll usually give the default answer, nothing, you know.  Like everything’s fine, they’re just PMSing or something like that, they’ll be like go ahead and go off somewhere and so if I get that kind of response or something, I’m gonna know something is up and I’m gonna wanna learn
I:Okay, in general, how easy or hard is it for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy, because I mean, I’ve been, I’ve grown up with a nice family and everything and they’ve taught me a whole lot of difference between right and wrong, and a whole lot of that comes from them.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:How you feel about it.  Like, my boyfriend, he’ll, like with the whole car thing, he’ll go racing or something like that and he thinks it’s perfectly okay but I’m, you know, he’s not gonna think it’s perfectly okay when he gets into a car accident or something, but I, I’d automatically think it’s wrong.  Um, I don’t know, I think my gut tells me.  There’s a whole lot of things we argue about, what’s right and wrong, but we all agree with it, one way or _______________  .
I:So what would you say makes racing wrong?
R:Like just because if there’s a potential accident gonna happen and he’s gonna, I mean, what am I gonna do if he dies in a car accident, so.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I just trust my gut.  I think I have been raised to where my instincts tell me whether I am right or wrong.
I:Ok, so it is like an internal thing.
R:Yeah.
I:And in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I think it is fairly easy, and some of my friends go behind my back and say it’s fine, or don’t do that.
I:So they muddle that for you, but it has never really affected my decision.
R:It’s muddled, but in the end it has never really effected my decision.
I:So you feel like in the end you still make whatever you were going to.
R:Yes.
I:And do you feel like over the last two years as you get older that deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder?
R:I think it has been a whole lot easier because I have been able to look back at some of the decisions I have made and say wow that is pretty stupid.
I:Just from being older
R:Yeah, and from seeing my friend’s mistakes and all that.
I:And what do you think it is that makes something a right or wrong thing to do?
R:How it affects others I would assume, or how you feel after you have done it.  If it is the right thing you should feel better after you do it, I guess.
I:Ok, so it is like consequences and feelings.
R:Yes.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:My mom.
I:Have your views about right and wrong changed over the past three years or stayed the same?
R:Well, with maturing you can’t really go off with the boy that you fell in love with at the concert, stuff like that. I used to think about that all the time, but stuff like that, like your outlook on different situations change.
I:So it has changed you feel like?
R:Yeah.

I used to think about that all the time, but stuff like that, like your outlook on different situations change. Yeah.  How it affects others I would assume, or how you feel after you have done it.  If it is the right thing you should feel better after you do it, I guess. Yes.  My mom.

column589:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:How do I decide what is good or bad?
I:How do you know how to live, what’s right, wrong, good, bad?
R:I think that’s all just kind of, first of all, the way I was raised.  I know what’s good, bad, right or wrong and that’s what I grew up with.
I:Is it easy or hard for you to know?
R:I wouldn’t say it’s easy or hard because I make up my own mind and I think that’s all you can opinion, someone’s opinion what’s good, bad, right or wrong.   Like underage drinking: I don’t think that’s bad in my situation, but I was always responsible about it.  I never got over the limit.  I didn’t go anywhere; I didn’t put myself in a bad position.  So I don’t necessarily think that’s bad, the way I handled it.  But at some point I was fine, so I think it’s all relative to what opinions are.
I:So what is it, you say that a lot of it gets down to people’s opinion, what is it that you think ultimately makes things right or wrong anyway?  I mean if somebody makes a moral claim: it’s wrong to do something or it’s a good to do something.  Why, where does that come from?
R:Hmm, Gosh I don’t know.  That’s going to make my brain  happens.
I:Are there any perceptions that people have that are wrong?  Or if they have that perception is it right for them?
R:Yeah, I think a lot of people’s perceptions or their own opinions that can be wrong, it’s just like a racism claim or something like that and they may think that’s a quick way, not necessarily means it is, but-
I:So what’s the standard independent of their perception that makes their perception wrong?  I mean how would we know that racism or slavery or whatever is wrong?
R:I don’t think we really would other than that group consensus or idea - but it’s kind of just a majority-.
I:So it’s relative to sort of the majority view?
R:Yeah, possibly.
I:So, sort of a hypothetical, but so in the 1930s in Germany there was a lot of anti-Semitism, I mean it was fine to round Jews up and ultimately exterminate them-
R:Right.
I:And if that was the majority view would that in that context, in that time and place, would that be morally okay because most people thought it-
R:No…
I:Or would you say-no that’s actually wrong-
R:Yeah, see that’s a good one because I would say absolutely that’s wrong, that’s absolutely wrong.  But if you look at it from the perception of if I was in that time, just like everyone else, it might have affected my opinions even then if I’m going with the group consensus.  It might have seemed more appealing or more like the right thing to do, even though right now that’s of course, that’s wrong, that’s the wrong thing to do.  So I don’t know, I would say
I:So in parts of the Roman Empire there were if a baby was born to a family the father had like a week to decide if he wanted to keep it and if it would be part of the family and if he decided against it, he could just leave it outside in the mountains to die.  We’ve since decided that’s not the right thing to do, but if um, by the time you have grandchildren, things had evolved so that people think that again, it would be widespread, would that be okay?
R:I don’t think that would be okay.
I:Is there a reason or would it just be that’s how you were raised?  I mean is it something other than just your upbringing?
R:I think it’s something other, it’s got to be, I think that’s moral issue  I mean that’s a moral issue that I just don’t agree with.
I:So what makes it a moral issue?
R:Well, I don’t know, I'm trying to think of the right way to describe it, I just don’t agree with that thought of mind.  Yeah, I don’t know.
I:Some people we talk to say well there’s kind of a natural law in reality that there’s just certain things that are given that are just right and wrong and then some people would say God had commanded certain things and they’re right and wrong for everyone even if whether or not you even believe it and other people would say something like Utilitarian like maximizing pleasure, minimizing pain as sort of like a constant rule, or is there anything outside of just people’s views that make things right or wrong or make, judge people’s view?
R:Yeah, I don’t know maybe the natural approach; you just know what’s right and wrong.  I don’t know if I could go so far as to say it’s a God thing and I wouldn’t do the, you know, imminent pleasure thing, I don’t know, I'm not sure what really decides that.
I:Do you think all normal people have sort of a moral intuition where they just know it’s wrong and that’s as far as you can explain it?
R:Yeah.  I guess that’s how I’d put it.  I think that everyone, for the most part, knows, has a sense of right and wrong and that’s just part of who you are -feeling something is wrong-
I:Okay so if it comes out in the news that somebody has been apprehended for molesting children or whatever like that, then we would say there’s something objectively wrong with them.  If they don’t have a moral conscious themselves that tells them that’s wrong then they are not normal, you would make that kind of judgment?
R:Yes.
I:We wouldn’t just say well that’s their opinion?
R:No .

column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on personal benefit and intuition, influenced by their upbringing, while also acknowledging the importance of moral standards and societal consensus, although they do not strictly adhere to religious guidelines.

column583: R:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from? She said mostly her ideas of right and wrong come from her friends. How do you decide or know what’s good or bad or right and wrong? She said she would think about what it would do to others, that’s how she would make her decision about what’s right and wrong; the consequences it would have for other people and whether it would harm either yourself or other people.

column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are generally clear, derives her moral views primarily from her friends, considers the consequences of her actions on others when making decisions, and has opposed her friends' wrongdoings, such as skipping class, while feeling no pressure to engage in drugs or alcohol.

column583:
I:And what makes them wrong?
R:Ah, just cause they’re illegal to do.
I:So that it’s against, breaks the law.
R:Yeah.
I:And you said treating people a certain way, what’s, what’s a right way to treat people or a wrong way to treat people?
R:Well like abusing people, or abusing kids or stuff like that.
I:And what is it that makes that wrong?
R:Ah, you’re, you’re just, you’re hurting someone.
I:Okay um, I’ve talked to some people that would, don’t really care about hurting people I mean, they’re just, who cares, that’s their problem, it’s not, as long as I take care of myself, what do I care about other people.  Why are they wrong?
R:Um, it doesn’t necessarily make them wrong, maybe something’s happened in their life that’s just made them think that way.
I:Mm-mm, so maybe they could be right in thinking that?
R:Um, not necessarily right, they just—
I:So we could explain, okay, well they were abused or they were in—but let’s, but even so, um, you might say well I understand why they think that, but they’re wrong, right?
R:I think they’re wrong.
I:So and what is it that makes them wrong, I mean, why is it that we should not hurt other people?
R:Mm, just common sense.
I:It’s just obvious.
R:Mm-mm (yes).

R:Oh, that’s fine!
I:But I’m just trying to think things through, um, there are a fair number of people for whom that isn’t common sense, you know, they enjoy shooting you know, helpless, and they enjoy torturing animals, they enjoy, I mean, even not, even monster people I mean even, even I hear stories about kids in high school or whatever you know that harass girls and are mean, pick on helpless people and so do they really know that that’s wrong and they’re just ignoring it or?
R:Yeah.  Most, I mean, you gotta think, you look at the person, they’re mostly either doing it for attention or they, they just don’t care, they’re angry at something.
I:Mm-mm.  Now, I know this is sort of philosophical, but where does that right or wrongness come from?  Finally?  I mean, what, why is it wrong?

R:It just comes, I don’t really think about it, it’s just what I think.

R:Mm-mm (yes).
