column585: The respondent believes that people generally know right from wrong but often disregard it, citing common sense and parental teachings as influences on their moral decisions, while acknowledging that they have experimented with drugs despite knowing it was wrong due to social pressures and personal urges.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Go with my gut feeling.  I don’t know, if I do something wrong I kind of get this feeling I should not have done that.  I just kind of go with it.
I:Where do you think that feeling comes from?
R:I have no clue.  Pretty much what you have learned and what your parents have put into you about what is right and wrong.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Easy.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Easier.
I:Why?
R:I think I am a Mom now and I need to be more responsible.  Just can’t go out and party on Friday nights and stuff like that.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  What kind of feelings makes it right or wrong?
R:I don’t know.  I am not very good at these types of questions.
I:What kinds of consequences or rules how do you decide?
R:I would say what would my family think.  What would they think if I did this or what would my friends think if I did this.  That is pretty much where I get it.
column590: Go with my gut feeling.  I don’t know, if I do something wrong I kind of get this feeling I should not have done that.  I just kind of go with it. I have no clue.  Pretty much what you have learned and what your parents have put into you about what is right and wrong. Easy. Easier. I think I am a Mom now and I need to be more responsible.  Just can’t go out and party on Friday nights and stuff like that.  I don’t know.  I am not very good at these types of questions. I would say what would my family think.  What would they think if I did this or what would my friends think if I did this.  That is pretty much where I get it.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on their intuition and gut feelings, shaped by their upbringing and parental influence, to make decisions about right and wrong, while also considering the consequences of their actions on their family and friends, and expressing a belief in moral responsibility to help others, particularly those close to them.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Based on I guess experience and what I learned you know in school, you know, my own instinct, or not necessarily instincts but just
I:Is it mostly easy or hard for you to decide right and wrong?
R:I don’t think it’s hard to decide between right and wrong.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:It’s gotten easier.  I just feel like I’m more focused.  I know what my goals are, what I have to do to get there, there’s less trial and error, you know, but then there’s new situations that I’m coming across, you know, that comes with different areas of life.  So, I don’t think I’m backtracking, so that’s a good thing.
I:Have your views about what is right and wrong changed in the past 2 years?
R:Not necessarily.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t think it’s one specific factor, I mean, I think there’s religion that comes into play and government and the environment, can’t really pinpoint necessarily.  It just depends, like if it’s something very simple versus something where it like affects society as a whole, I don’t know, you can’t really.  Can you give me an example, like?
I:
R:I know it’s hard to think of, or, I mean it’s right and wrong, like, right and wrong versus like ‘should I give that person on the street a dollar when they ask for you know change?’ I can’t tell you what’s the right decision.  In my gut I feel bad when I don’t give the change, so, most of the time I’m going to give that person something.  But then there are times when I’ve had a bad day and I’m like I just failed my test that I studied for you’re not getting my change because I could be right where you are, you know what I mean, so it just depends.
I:
R:What makes an action right and wrong?  Well, a lot of times it’s the law, you know, what the rules are.
I:Do you think that they
R:No, because there have been cases where the law was found unconstitutional.  But I would say this far into our history of our country I think we’ve learned a lot from where we’ve from but as of now I would say there’s, I mean, it’s never a foolproof system.
I:Laws can vary from state to state, so how do feel about that?  Is one wrong is one right?
R:No, but in the eyes of that law or that city or whatever, you wouldn’t be wrong.  I mean, if you don’t follow it, an ignorance of law isn’t an excuse most, see this is very like theoretical stuff, I don’t know, we can’t go on, who knows what the answer is.
I:What do you think the answer is?
R:I think the answer is, well, you can’t really answer the question because I need, I’m more of a person of examples, give me an example, you know.
I:
R:Let’s say, okay, in Georgia* there are some laws that on the books that are against the law but people practice them.  Like sodomy, like you know, fellacio or whatever.  And that’s just when
I:Because that’s on the books that that’s wrong in Georgia* is it wrong?
R:I think it’s something that you can’t even call out, like, you, I think it’s an individual choice because like I was saying, when there are rules put into place, more than one factor can be in play.  I think when that rule was made, it was more of a religious factor, when nowadays, it’s not just, society influences it also, so kind of, the masses kind of outweigh just the individual law.
I:you actually like, I don’t know, what do you go to?  What is your like one
R:What is my first thought process and my second?  My first thought process is, I want to honestly say I do take account of the law, you know.  And then, when I want to say what defines my decision most is what’s going to be safe for my daughter which in turn what’s going to safe for me because I have take care of my daughter, you know.  Let’s say the law is ‘you can’t use your water because of the drought*’, but I had to use it for something that was needed for my daughter, then I would probably break that law and use water, you know what I’m saying, so in that case my daughter’s safety outrules, or in my opinion, overrules the legislation.
I:Do you think is has to do with like the types of consequences
R:Well, I think it’s in human nature is, if you’re not going to have a consequence involved with something negative that you’re going to do and there’s no negative consequence even if you do the action, then you’re more likely to do it.  I think we’re creatures of habit and there have to be laws and consequences put in place or you know society wouldn’t be able to run.
I:Where do you think you acquired your moral views from?
R:I want to say more than one faction.  Parents, friends, school, a lot of teachers.  Teachers, I want to say, are probably the most influential outside of your initial parenting, you know.

column591: The respondent would invest a portion of an inheritance in education and support family, guided by a sense of responsibility towards loved ones, while their moral decisions are influenced by experiences, education, and a belief in a higher power over human authority.

column589:
I:I have some questions about morality.  How do you normally decide or know what is good or bad or right or wrong in life?
R:I dunno-just kind of instinct and by what you think as a person it’s right to do or not.  I can’t talk for other people, you know?
I:You kind of have an instinct or intuition? Is it easy or hard to know right or wrong for you?
R:No.
I:It’s not?
R:It’s hard when you know it’s wrong and you’re deciding whether or not to do it and you already know that it’s wrong.
I:So it’s not hard to know, it’s hard to decide the right thing.
R:Yeah.
I:Ok, and is it still that compared to when you were say 16.
R:No, it’s a lot easier now.
I:what is it that you think makes things right or wrong?  First of all, do you believe there are certain things that are objectively right or wrong?
R:I think a lot of it’s probably from when you're little, what society and your parents and friends and family growing up.
I:so that’s how people come to know that they think is right or wrong, is there anything objectively right or wrong, could somebody believe something is right or wrong and they’re wrong about that?
R:well, other than myself, obviously laws. I think anything else is just your own opinion.
I:could anybody’s opinion be wrong?
R:yeah, but that’s still their own choice and what they think is right and that may be right, depending on the circumstances that they live in.
I:Ok, so is morality ultimately what society agrees on and what people believe, or is it anything beyond-does it have any source or root beyond that?  Like natural law?
R:I dunno, I just sort of locate it in religion, so I think some of that definitely comes whatever higher power people believe in.
I:Do you think some morals come from the higher power?
R:I think so.
I:and that would make it not just people’s opinions.
R:yeah.
I:do you have any ideas which examples of what would come from that?
R:yeah, well I think maybe how to treat people and how respect and stuff like that just comes, I think that’s already in there.
column590: I dunno-just kind of instinct and by what you think as a person it’s right to do or not.  I can’t talk for other people, you know? No. It’s hard when you know it’s wrong and you’re deciding whether or not to do it and you already know that it’s wrong. Yeah. No, it’s a lot easier now.  I think a lot of it’s probably from when you're little, what society and your parents and friends and family growing up. well, other than myself, obviously laws. I think anything else is just your own opinion. yeah, but that’s still their own choice and what they think is right and that may be right, depending on the circumstances that they live in. I dunno, I just sort of locate it in religion, so I think some of that definitely comes whatever higher power people believe in. I think so. yeah. yeah, well I think maybe how to treat people and how respect and stuff like that just comes, I think that’s already in there.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on intuition and personal beliefs shaped by societal and familial influences to determine right from wrong, while also acknowledging the role of a higher power in moral guidance, and expresses a preference for seeking advice from their father when uncertain about decisions.

column583:
I:Mm-mm, and what is it that you make, that makes something, you think, right or wrong.  Is there any like standard by which you judge?
R:Um.
I:Curious about where you own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Well probably I guess from you know, what I’ve been taught through like the church or whatever, you know, like the ten commandments and stealing and some like that, that plays a lot into it and just I don’t know, I’ve been always taught to treat people with respect you know, kindness and compassion and obviously if you’re just being a, you know, if you’re not doing that, I guess, that would be wrong, or if you take other things from people, stealing I, I really have a problem with stealing, I guess that’s, that’s definitely wrong.  And I don’t know, I guess that mostly that’s where it comes from, but.
column584: Um. Well probably I guess from you know, what I’ve been taught through like the church or whatever, you know, like the ten commandments and stealing and some like that, that plays a lot into it and just I don’t know, I’ve been always taught to treat people with respect you know, kindness and compassion and obviously if you’re just being a, you know, if you’re not doing that, I guess, that would be wrong, or if you take other things from people, stealing I, I really have a problem with stealing, I guess that’s, that’s definitely wrong.  And I don’t know, I guess that mostly that’s where it comes from, but.
column585: The respondent relies on their parents' guidance and teachings from the church to shape their moral compass, acknowledges the existence of definite rights and wrongs, feels guilty about minor infractions like speeding, and believes that while drinking can be fun, it should be done responsibly without succumbing to peer pressure.
column586:
I:All over the place.  Okay, okay.  All right.  Ah, so um, switching topics a bit from that, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Good and bad, right and wrong.  A lot of it’s instinctual, I guess you know you should just, it seems pretty straightforward with what’s decent, I guess, religion plays a big part of it, you know.  Granted, I don’t know, like a Roman Catholic would do, I believe everything that’s taught as a, you know, like on abortion, I don’t know, I mean, I’m not sure what I think about that, I’m not sure what I think about the death penalty, you know and obviously there’s really strict things, I mean, obviously on simple every day matters, you know, don’t lie, cheat and steal, you know, just accepted in societal morals, you know, that I’ve been instilled through my parents, I think they did a pretty good job, you know, teaching me but then also living out you know, practicing what they preach and showing me the right way of being a decent, moral person.  I guess that’s just engrained, you know, then it’s been reinforced over so long that you’d feel bad if you would be to break, you know, something like that, so.
I:Okay.  Is it, ah, well, is it generally easy or hard for you to decide what’s right or wrong?
R:Pretty easy.
I:Pretty easy.
R:I mean, yeah, pretty easy.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:What it is that makes something right and wrong?  Judge, I mean, against like the moral code, I mean, yeah, I don’t know, if the, probably then you can get into it philosophically you know, is it divine dictation, I accept religion and know all that and yeah it is, um, so I don’t know.
I:Well what do you think?
R:I don’t know, divine dictation, it just seems like common sense, decent stuff, respecting somebody else as a person and showing them courtesy that you would expect to get and receive and whatever, you know, it helps to foster you know, respect and just well being amongst people would be, it seems like you know, granted, I don’t know if that’s a societal, and they decided to make it up through the course of whatever time or whatever or if it’s a divine commandment, I’m not sure, but something that respects people as an individual and tries to not harm them, if possible, but.
I:Okay.  Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves?
R:Always wrong in themselves.  Like murder or something like that, I don’t know.  Probably not, I mean, I, I think it’s really hard to say, there’s never, you know, to use such a definitive term as always and never, I mean, even murder if it’s in self defense or what if you’re saving 100 people, you know, like no I don’t think so.  To say always is really a pointed statement and I can’t agree with that.
I:How about rape, is that?
R:Rape?  Ooh, that would probably be one that would qualify, um, unless there’d be some really odd extenuating circumstances, um, but I, I don’t know.  That would, then it would be one, it’d probably be close to that, but, yeah, I guess.  But again, I mean, I’d want to take a look at the situation, you know, if it’s gonna save a million people, well, I don’t know, you know, that’s a moral quandary, but yeah.
I:And where would you say that your views come from?
R:Parents and church and combination.
column587: Good and bad, right and wrong.  A lot of it’s instinctual, I guess you know you should just, it seems pretty straightforward with what’s decent, I guess, religion plays a big part of it, you know.  Granted, I don’t know, like a Roman Catholic would do, I believe everything that’s taught as a, you know, like on abortion, I don’t know, I mean, I’m not sure what I think about that, I’m not sure what I think about the death penalty, you know and obviously there’s really strict things, I mean, obviously on simple every day matters, you know, don’t lie, cheat and steal, you know, just accepted in societal morals, you know, that I’ve been instilled through my parents, I think they did a pretty good job, you know, teaching me but then also living out you know, practicing what they preach and showing me the right way of being a decent, moral person.  I guess that’s just engrained, you know, then it’s been reinforced over so long that you’d feel bad if you would be to break, you know, something like that, so. Pretty easy. I mean, yeah, pretty easy.  What it is that makes something right and wrong?  Judge, I mean, against like the moral code, I mean, yeah, I don’t know, if the, probably then you can get into it philosophically you know, is it divine dictation, I accept religion and know all that and yeah it is, um, so I don’t know. I don’t know, divine dictation, it just seems like common sense, decent stuff, respecting somebody else as a person and showing them courtesy that you would expect to get and receive and whatever, you know, it helps to foster you know, respect and just well being amongst people would be, it seems like you know, granted, I don’t know if that’s a societal, and they decided to make it up through the course of whatever time or whatever or if it’s a divine commandment, I’m not sure, but something that respects people as an individual and tries to not harm them, if possible, but. Always wrong in themselves.  Like murder or something like that, I don’t know.  Probably not, I mean, I, I think it’s really hard to say, there’s never, you know, to use such a definitive term as always and never, I mean, even murder if it’s in self defense or what if you’re saving 100 people, you know, like no I don’t think so.  To say always is really a pointed statement and I can’t agree with that. Rape?  Ooh, that would probably be one that would qualify, um, unless there’d be some really odd extenuating circumstances, um, but I, I don’t know.  That would, then it would be one, it’d probably be close to that, but, yeah, I guess.  But again, I mean, I’d want to take a look at the situation, you know, if it’s gonna save a million people, well, I don’t know, you know, that’s a moral quandary, but yeah.  Parents and church and combination.
column588: The respondent plans to use a hypothetical inheritance of $100,000 primarily for investing in land and saving, influenced by a desire for financial security and a sense of responsibility instilled by their parents, while their moral compass is guided by instinct and religious teachings, leading them to believe in the importance of helping others but also recognizing personal accountability in moral obligations.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Uh, I mean, just kind of values that have been reinforced, growing up.  From my parents, from church.  And then also, again, with Marines, but the standards that they hold you to, it kind of helps in making those decisions.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Um, pretty easy for the most part.  I mean, it’s kind of a gut feeling, that’s like, well, it’s kinda, you shouldn’t be doing that.  Um, I mean, I haven’t faced any huge moral, ethical quandaries, so…
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the last couple of years?
R:I’d say maybe a little bit easier.  Just as you see more people, like, kind of, a negative reinforcement.  I mean and also a positive reinforcement.  I mean, as you gain more experience, you meet more people, you see how more people act, and realize, “Wow, that’s pretty, like, heinous”, or, hey, on the converse, “Hey, that was a good thing to do and that’s a quality individual”, and those traits kind of distinguish that person.  I think that’s kind of helped to clarify between the two.
I:Have your views about right and wrong in any way changed in the last few years?
R:Not terribly.  I mean, pretty, yeah, I haven’t had any wild, crazy changes in college, so for the most part, they’ve stayed pretty constant.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  Why is something wrong?
R:Why is something wrong.  Well, I think it could be wrong for any number of reasons, depending on what the situation is.  If it’s just dealing with another person, on how you treat them.  I mean, kinda use, like, a camp song, where you want to make someone better than you found ‘em.  And if you’re doing something that’s causing them pain and consternation, er, you know, being unfair to them, I guess that would qualify as being wrong, um.
I:Why?  Why would those things qualify as being wrong?
R:Well, I don’t know.  Treat others as you want to be treated, I guess.  And if you’re doing something that you wouldn’t want someone reciprocating to you, and then, that’s just kind of reinforced through growing up.  But, like, you know, do unto others as others do unto you, so, you’d hope that it kinda comes through there.
I:Some people say that if it feels right, that it’s OK.
R:Well, I mean, then that’s kind of arbitrary, and whatever.   I  .  I mean, I think there are kinda some absolutes, like, hey, but, I mean, I don’t know.
I:What would be a ?  Laws or principles, or …
R:Good question.  Um, you know, I don’t know.  I think it ties in, I don’t know, with religion, just kind of a generally… I don’t know.
I:Where have you acquired your moral views from?
R:Well, just reinforcing, growing up from going to church and going talking with my parents.  And then again, just from observing other people and just thinking, “Wow, that was really heinous”, and I don’t, you know, I don’t want to…  If someone would be looking at me doing that same thing, I’d hope they’d be kinda disgusted by it.  And if I’m disgusted, then, hey, that’s probably something I should take from it and not try to repeat, but…

column591: The respondent emphasizes the importance of values instilled by parents and church in guiding their moral decisions, believes in helping others to the best of their ability, and prefers to seek advice from respected figures when uncertain about right and wrong, while also acknowledging that personal happiness should not be the primary motivator for decisions.

column583:
I:Okay.  Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?  From, what we were just saying?  From your Mom and Dad, or?
R:I’d, I’d say probably yeah, probably them.
I:Any other places?
R:No.  I don’t go to a church or anything like that, so, no.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  Is it again what we were saying earlier, the consequences or is it, something in the act or whatever, itself?
R:I’d say the consequences.
I:Can you give me any examples of any um, recent things when you’ve kind of had to think about that?
R:Mm—
I:I don’t know, it could be anything, like thinking about cheating, thinking about ditching school?
R:No, probably I don’t think.
I:Not that I’m suggesting you ditch school or cheating for that matter!
R:Yeah, um, ah, I don’t know.
column584: I’d, I’d say probably yeah, probably them. No.  I don’t go to a church or anything like that, so, no. I’d say the consequences. Mm— No, probably I don’t think. Yeah, um, ah, I don’t know.
column585: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on weighing the long-term consequences of their actions rather than strict notions of right and wrong, acknowledges that their views on morality are influenced by their parents, and believes that societal perceptions of right and wrong can vary significantly based on individual upbringing and cultural context.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good or bad or right or wrong in life?
R:I try to imagine all the effects it would have on me and other people involved.
I:How easy in general would you find…how easy or hard that is in general, do you find it is to decide between right and wrong?
R:Well, harder if you put those labels on them but I mean, I try to think of about useful and not useful but I guess it sounds kind of Machiavellian, but rather, the effects of it.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder for you in the last two years?
R:It is about the same because I have the same thought process.
I:You feel like your views on anything like changed in the last two years?
R:I would not say my views have, I would say my experiences have because I have the same thought process but now I have more information to go and make important decisions.
I:Do you feel like you make better decisions now than you did before?
R:More informed decisions.
I:You have mentioned you know looking in terms of views rather than right and wrong.  So what do you think it is that makes something you know right and wrong then?
R:Sorry?
I:What do you think makes something right and wrong then?  You have mentioned views.
R:Whether it…how it balances out I guess whether how it would hurt people involved or how it would in their view hurt them or make them happy.
I:What kinds of consequences of a decision that make something wrong?  Can you think of anything?
R:If it hurt somebody physically or hurt their opportunities whatever in life, I would unless there was extenuating circumstances I would not want to do that.
I:Let’s see.  So you talked about if it would like affect their chances later in life, what kinds of things do you think are kind of valuable things that people should get chances with?
R:People’s abilities whether their talents was there and aware of them or not, like if there is somebody where you know that they are only good at doing a certain thing but it would help you a little bit to get in their way of doing…I have to think carefully about those.
I:Where would you say you acquired your views or morality from, if anywhere?
R:My observations about history I guess and personal interaction and what I have observed about society and other societies, and I mean, my views are very similar to my mom but I don’t know if I would say they are because of my mom but I might you know who’s to say, it may be subconsciously or whatever.

column591: The respondent plans to use an inheritance of $100,000 primarily for travel and music equipment, believing that these experiences are valuable and fulfilling, while making decisions about right and wrong by considering the effects on themselves and others, influenced by their observations of history and their mother's views, and ultimately prioritizing personal advancement and happiness over religious or parental guidance.

column583:
I:And, um, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, my faith I think.  Like I’ve gone to Catholic school since I was like in 3rd grade.  And it’s not like it’s been put upon me or anything, but, um, we, I’ve always had religion class and we talk about things like faith and like issues and current events and so I just think about, it’s given me time everyday to think about things like that in school.  And, I think, it helps me form my views on what’s right and wrong.
I:And what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, I guess the bottom line is if it hurts somebody.  And if it hurts somebody then it’s wrong.  Then it’s kind of like generalization of that.

column585: The respondent often struggles with decision-making, relying on the advice of family, particularly her sister and mother, while feeling guilty about potentially hurting others; she attributes her sense of right and wrong to her Catholic faith and believes that actions are wrong if they hurt someone, although she acknowledges the blurred lines of morality in society today.
column586:
I:well, it’ll get you somewhere at least.  How do you decide and know what has been bad and right and wrong?
R:I guess a lot of it’s like just like your gut reaction to like what you do, feeling like inside, sometimes I think I feel guilty for no reason, like when I apologize to my mom for telling her how I felt about that fight, I don’t know.  It’s just this gut reaction, probably based on moral things over time.
I:is it usually easy or hard for you to decide what’s right or wrong?
R:um, it’s, I think it’s easy to know what’s right and wrong, most of the time, but when it comes to like specifics, like certain things are hard.
I:so what kinds of things are harder?
R:like things like, I’ve kind of like resolved this one for myself about like sex, that I would rather wait.  But, sometimes it’s hard to know, is it because it’s morally wrong, cause like, would god want us to wait?  Or would god want us to do what feels natural, I don’t’ know, stuff like that, where you’re like, you could work it out either way, you could reason both sides and it’s hard to tell sometimes.
I:do you think deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or harder over the past couple of years?
R:probably easier, just like getting in touch with what I want and hoping that I’m doing the right thing, that what feels like it’s right is right, just like practicing it more…
I:oh like having more experience?
R:yeah.
I:okay, that’s fine.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:um, I guess first like there’s a couple of things.  What’s right for you in a situation, like what you need in your life I guess and then you can think about how you’re gonna affect other people.  And this is severely complicated I guess.
I:yeah it is really .
R:like what would, like what would Jesus do you could think of it that way too, what’s the right thing to do morally.  They all factor in I guess.
I:where do you think you’ve acquired your moral views? Like where do they come from?
R:I think a lot happened actually in high school like developing my views because of religion classes actually, just talking about stuff actually.  Especially this one class sophomore year with Mr. Santos* I remember, he was like a deacon candidate or something…
I:you went to a catholic high school?
R:yeah.  And we talk about moral things like, and people debate because everyone has their own opinion and he really opened up the space and that helped a lot I think.

column588: The respondent expresses a desire to invest a hypothetical inheritance in education to avoid loans, relies on gut feelings and moral teachings from religion to navigate right and wrong, acknowledges the complexity of moral decisions influenced by social contexts and personal experiences, and believes in the importance of helping others while reflecting on the potential for goodness in everyone, ultimately valuing family, spirituality, and meaningful connections in life.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what’s good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Common sense.  I am how my mommy raised me basically.  You could say her common sense.
I:So is it generally easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Depends on the situation.
I:What do you mean by that?
R:Whether to drink or not really depends on where I’m at, who I’m with, what time I have to be up in the mornin’.  Stuff like that.
I:So it depends on a lot of things?
R:Yeah.  If I gotta be up at work at four in the mornin’ I’m not gonna stay up ‘til two drinkin’.  Goin’ into work with a hangover is not fun.
I:That’s not a good thing?
R:Naw, we’ve all done that before.
I:Now has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder in the last couple of years?
R:It’s about the same ‘cause when I was in school, it was whether to cut out from class and stuff like that, well now, it’s whether to speed, slow down, obey the traffic laws, and I don’t know why I started talkin’ about that, ‘cause there’s a cop out there, that could be it.  Whether to do drugs has stayed the same in school from now.  And I have more responsibilities now ‘cause I have to have a car payment comin’ in, insurance, pay my cell phone bill, stuff like that.  And I was payin’ all that when I was in school, but it got a whole lot higher when I got out.  ‘Cause in school I was drivin’ an ’86 Caprice.  Forty miles a gallon.  Not fun.
I:Would you say your moral views have changed in the past couple of years?
R:Not really.
I:About the same?
R:About the same.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Your own personal view on it.  Along with the society that you live in’s view on it.  The majority of people that do drugs, they don’t think it’s wrong, and then they think the same thing with alcohol.  It alters your state of mind and how you feel.  If it was up to everybody else, all these drug-dealers and stuff, they would have it legal because they think that the only reason it’s not legal is ‘cause the government can’t tax it.  Same thing with moonshine, but it is legal to create moonshine, you can do that.  Just no more than a gallon a week.  Not that I would know that.
I:Where do you think you’ve acquired your moral views from?
R:My mom.  She’s, I hate to say it, people say if I had longer hair and was just a little bit shorter I would be my mom.  That’s sad.  Not just because we look alike but the way we act.  Yes, I’m a little louder than she is, and way more aggressive than she is, but we’re just about the same person, it’s sad to say.

column591: The respondent plans to use an inheritance primarily to pay taxes, tithe, pay off debts, and make a down payment on a house, emphasizing the importance of financial responsibility and the influence of their mother's teachings on their moral decision-making, while also expressing a clear stance against engaging in morally questionable activities.

column583:
I:What makes that wrong?
R:It’s just, I mean, why would you want to, why would you hit somebody? Just cause they make you mad?
I:What if you were mean?
R:If I was mean?  Well then I’d probably hit somebody but.
I:I mean, would you be doing something wrong?
R:If I was mean?  Ah, I don’t know.
I:Like, like, what if, if you stole, if you found somebody’s wallet in here, had $1,000 in it.
R:Oh well then I’d take it to the front desk .
I:Why not keep it?
R:Well because I wouldn’t want somebody taking my money you know if I lost a thousand dollars I’d want somebody to do the same thing, I would want somebody to take it and return it you know?  I’m just—
I:What if somebody said, I’m not advocating this, but what if somebody said, well you don’t lost your wallet, but if they lost their wallet it’s too bad.
R:Well then I’d say well that’s your choice, I wouldn’t, I wouldn’t talk to them, I wouldn’t hang out with them you know, that’s messed up I’d tell them like if you didn’t return it or see you later, find some new friends you know cause that’s messed up.
I:So are you saying that that’s, like morally right and wrong, or is that just society works better when people behave like that?
R:Behave like taking stuff from other people or?
I:No when people sort of treat each other properly.
R:Yeah, if it was, if everybody was like that then yeah, the world would be a better place  but you know it’s never gonna be like that, so.

Well because I wouldn’t want somebody taking my money you know if I lost a thousand dollars I’d want somebody to do the same thing, I would want somebody to take it and return it you know? Behave like taking stuff from other people or? Yeah, if it was, if everybody was like that then yeah, the world would be a better place  but you know it’s never gonna be like that, so.
column585: The respondent feels a clear distinction between right and wrong, influenced by personal experiences and social interactions, acknowledges the appeal of using drugs as a means to cope with daily problems, and expresses a desire to eventually quit smoking weed and pursue a better future, despite recognizing the risks and consequences associated with their choices.
column586:
I:What do you, um, what do you think about morality these days.  What makes things right and wrong, good and bad, I mean, are there moral truths that people should live up to, is it all relative, or what? What makes it wrong?  Why is that wrong?
R:You know it depends on who you’re, I mean, it doesn’t really depend on who you steal from, but I mean, if you steal from the store, you know you steal from a store, you know, you’re, you know you’re causing them to lose money.
I:So what?
R:You know?  So.
I:I’m not saying it’s not wrong, I’m just asking, so why should you care about them losing money?
R:Well because if I owned a store, I wouldn’t want somebody coming in you know, kind of like you know, doing to others as you’d have them do unto you, you know?  That’s what I go by, you know, I wouldn’t want to, I wouldn’t want to have a store, and somebody walk in and start jacking shit off the shelves and jamming out you know because then that’s costing me money, you know that’s money that somebody could come in and buy this you know?  Say somebody comes in and jacks like, you know like a model care worth like 50 bucks or something and just jamming out with it, you know, somebody comes in later and wants to buy it, it ain’t there, you know?  That just lost me money, you know?  I don’t know.
I:Okay.  All right.  So do unto others, that’s sort of a religious, I mean, that’s from the Bible, Jesus said that and so would you say that your view, that your view of right and wrong or morality comes from God or what?
R:Because I was always raised like that, my Mom was always, my Mom always took us to church, you know, even when we lived in Illinois, we went to church, we went to churches as soon as we first moved here, we, well, until we were seven years old and then we moved out here, to Illinois, or to Idaho, out here, and started going to church in Meridian, or actually in Boise, because we lived with my grandma when we first moved here and then we lived in this apartment complex and we went to the same church in Boise for like two years and then we moved here, to Nampa*, and then we started going to this little church, it’s out in, I can’t even think of what road it’s off of, it’s in town though, but we went there for like you know, like eight, like seven years maybe, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, twelve, yeah.  And then for like the last three years we haven’t even been going to church.  We like started going to church and then you know, all of us kids started doing stupid shit and falling apart and just fucking up and you know, and my Mom hasn’t really had the energy to chase my brothers, or my brother and my sister around at night you know, doesn’t have the energy to go to church, you know, she’ll either sleep all day on Sunday or you know clean the house as much as she can.

column583:

R:I guess it just depends on how you were raised, like I was raised where swearing is bad or watching R rated movies is bad or having premarital sex is bad and people just haven’t been raised like that, so, to them it’s, it’s okay to swear, it’s okay to do that stuff, but to me it’s not.

R:Well no it, I don’t know how to explain it, it’s just  um, that’s a hard question.  It’s…

R:It’s basically what the outcome of the action is.  If, if it’s gonna harm someone or if it’s um, you can just tell if it’s right or wrong, I don’t know how to explain it, but a lot of times you just can.

I:No, your—
R:Um, cause I believe that you should wait ‘til you, um, wait ‘til you’re married and when just ‘til that, with that person.

R:Um,  you could end up having problems like if you get pregnant or um, it just causes more tension between the people and it just, you know it’s.
I:Okay.  So what if um, what if two people let’s say were, like there was no danger of them getting pregnant, well if the girl getting pregnant and, and they thought that they could handle it and everything, would that still be okay?
R:Um, I, I think it still just causes tension between the two people.
I:What is it that causes the tension, do you think?
R:Um, I don’t know.
I:Okay.  Um, how do you know what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:Um, I guess it’s, measuring out the consequences and um, just gut instinct, basically, most of the time.
I:Okay.  Um, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Mostly experience.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Try to think if my mom and my grandfather would approve of it. Just legality as a law.
I:So if it’s against the law, then…
R:Yeah. And I have a really big guilty conscience, so if it’s going to cause me grief like a couple of years’ time… keep on thinking about them not to pursue anything like that.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Not really. It’s pretty clear to me.
I:Pretty clear?
R:Yeah.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:Easier I think.
I:Why?
R:I spend like less time with my friends and less time with other people and focus on me and attending school so it’s like less peer pressure to do between right and wrong so it’s just do what I feel is right and wrong so it’s pretty precise so it’s become easier.
I:And have your views about what’s right and wrong changed over the past two years?
R:Yeah, I think so.
I:How?
R:Like I can see other people’s point of views better, so if I think something’s right or wrong, and they explain to me why they think it’s—if I say something’s right and when they say it’s wrong, they explain to me what they think, then I might be able to change my mind, stuff like that.
I:Are there any particular issues or ways in which you kind of changed your view between right and wrong?
R:Not really. But I’ve changed my view on religion a lot in the past year or so because other people was influenced and stuff like that. I’m a history major so, and a science major, so like you get to see religion from way back so you can see some differences in your mind so…
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I guess that’s more a personal opinion.
I:Personal opinion.
R:Yeah. I would say,  guilt, I don’t know.
I:So if it feels guilty…
R:If it feels guilty or… yeah.
I:Anything else you think that might make something right or wrong?
R:If it’s hurting another person. I think it’s wrong.
I:From where do you think you acquired your moral views?
R:Probably from my grandfather.
I:Grandfather?
R:Yeah.
I:Any other places they come from?
R:My friends, from my friend’s families.

column591: The respondent plans to use an inheritance of $100,000 primarily to pay for school and buy a new car due to financial concerns and the burden of a faulty vehicle, while their moral decision-making is influenced by the approval of their mother and grandfather, a strong guilty conscience, and a clearer understanding of right and wrong developed through reduced peer pressure and increased focus on personal values.

column586:
I:Okay um, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I go with my heart on that.
I:Okay, in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:At the time or later on?
I:At the time.
R:At the time of the decision it seems pretty easy, I just make my decision and I go with it.  Do I regret things I do sometimes?  Of course, but there’s no time to hesitate sometimes, you just have to do things.
I:Now when you say you go with your heart, what do you mean by that exactly?
R:I go with what I feel is necessary at the time.
I:Okay, does it, what does that feel, is there a particular feeling that’s associated with that?
R:I don’t know, it’s just uh, a feeling of that’s what needs to be done, that’s what’s right, that’s what you gotta do about it.
I:Okay um, has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:At, on the spur of the moment, easier.
I:Okay um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:That’s hard to say.  A lot of things man.  How it benefits you, it’s how it hurts other people, it’s every thing that happens because of what you do.  All the little side affects, how they all add up in the end.
I:Okay um, do you think that there are, so you’d say mainly it’s consequences then?
R:I wouldn’t call it consequences because I mean, when you say consequences people think like jail time or like laws but it’s like how it affects everything.
I:Okay what kinds of affects would make something wrong?
R:The sort of affects that like harm innocent people.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:I don’t believe in that.
I:Okay where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Aside from my parents, like my, definitely mostly my parents.  Mostly my parents but a lot of what I see day to day in the street and everything else affects it.

I don’t know, it’s just uh, a feeling of that’s what needs to be done, that’s what’s right, that’s what you gotta do about it. At, on the spur of the moment, easier.  That’s hard to say.  A lot of things man.  How it benefits you, it’s how it hurts other people, it’s every thing that happens because of what you do.  All the little side affects, how they all add up in the end. The sort of affects that like harm innocent people. I don’t believe in that.  Aside from my parents, like my, definitely mostly my parents.  Mostly my parents but a lot of what I see day to day in the street and everything else affects it.
column588: The respondent plans to bank an inheritance to invest in real estate for financial security, makes decisions based on intuition and immediate feelings about right and wrong, acknowledges the influence of their parents on their moral views, and believes that while morality can be subjective, there are actions that are inherently wrong, particularly those that harm innocent people.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Well, if it’s a personal, private decision, I go by what I feel.  If it’s something that, like a workplace decision, I normally go by what I think my higher ups morals and values are.
I:Can you give me an example?
R:Hmm.  Well, yeah.  Let’s say like at my most recent job, let’s say I’m out and about doing my sales thing, like running inquiries and people who I’ve given them estimates and I come to a house that asks for me to come up with an estimate and they already have an estimate on their door from another company doing the same thing.  Now, normally, honestly, I would, even though I have loose morals, I would never just leave that there, because they’re gonna get the quote either way, but I know my boss is all about taking those things, he likes to look at them, he likes to see, because like, he’ll have a yellow copy of my estimate, he likes to compare our estimates to theirs, see how they stack up and he’d rather the potential customer never even saw the other person’s estimate.  So in that situation, I’ll just grab it because I know he’s gonna be like oh, good job, when I give it to him, and it’s gonna get me ahead a little bit, so.
I:Gotcha, okay.  And so that’s a routine practice for you?
R:Well I mean, if he discouraged it, I wouldn’t do it.  But because he encourages it, I do it.
I:Okay, because you think it’ll help you in the company, right?  Okay.  In general, how easy or hard would you say it is for you to decide what’s right and wrong?
R:Pretty easy.
I:Has it gotten, do you think it’s, since the last time we talked to you, do you think it’s gotten easier or harder, stayed about the same?
R:Always harder.
I:Really?
R:Always harder.
I:How so?
R:The older you get, the more your decisions affect other people.  I mean, when I was young and single, it was just me.  And now I got to worry about my girlfriend.
I:But generally would you say it’s pretty easy or harder to choose what you know is right.
R:It’s fairly easy.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think that’s all about how you were raised.  I mean, morals are, they’re so, I mean people tell you they’re not subjective but they are.  Someone who is raised in institutions their whole life has a whole different set of morality than someone who was raised in like a Mormon or one of the very religious backgrounds.  Yeah, totally different morals.  Now that’s because the guy was raised in institutions his whole life is even worse,  but it’s just what he was taught when he was young.
I:And what do you think, do you think there’s like, but do you think like, let’s say these two people they disagree about what’s right and wrong.  Is one of them closer to right than the other one?  And, if so, how?  Why?
R:Well, generally, you have to go by the group consensus, so sure one of them’s got to be closer to right because when we, what the general population views is right is sort of the general consensus.  I mean, there was once a time when people thought it was right to throw two people in the arena and ____________  to death.  That was seemed generally okay.  That’s not anymore.  You’d never get away with that now.
I:Do you think it was right then, though?  Like do you think it was right or wrong?
R:For me from now, no?  If me grew up back then, I’d think it was fine.
I:But who would have been right?
R:I don’t know, is anybody even right?  I mean, that’s the real question, I’d probably be right.  Is it a sin if nobody believes it’s a sin?
I:And what about, where do you think your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:My own views of right and wrong I think come from a combination of how I was raised and what I see when I was growing up, things that experienced.
I:Like anything stick out in particular?
R:Well, you know, met quite a few people with a lot of money who really don’t have any morals at all.  I think that sort of affects me a little bit.
I:Really?  How’s that?
R:Because if you look around the real genuinely, genuinely nice, great people--not doing that good.
I:Okay.
R:I mean, know what a Vice Presidents of major corporations run by someone without skeletons in their closet.  So, there’s something to be said about that.
column590: Well, if it’s a personal, private decision, I go by what I feel.  If it’s something that, like a workplace decision, I normally go by what I think my higher ups morals and values are. Hmm.  Well, yeah.  Let’s say like at my most recent job, let’s say I’m out and about doing my sales thing, like running inquiries and people who I’ve given them estimates and I come to a house that asks for me to come up with an estimate and they already have an estimate on their door from another company doing the same thing.  Now, normally, honestly, I would, even though I have loose morals, I would never just leave that there, because they’re gonna get the quote either way, but I know my boss is all about taking those things, he likes to look at them, he likes to see, because like, he’ll have a yellow copy of my estimate, he likes to compare our estimates to theirs, see how they stack up and he’d rather the potential customer never even saw the other person’s estimate.  So in that situation, I’ll just grab it because I know he’s gonna be like oh, good job, when I give it to him, and it’s gonna get me ahead a little bit, so. Well I mean, if he discouraged it, I wouldn’t do it.  But because he encourages it, I do it. Pretty easy. Always harder. Always harder. The older you get, the more your decisions affect other people.  I mean, when I was young and single, it was just me.  And now I got to worry about my girlfriend. It’s fairly easy.  I think that’s all about how you were raised.  I mean, morals are, they’re so, I mean people tell you they’re not subjective but they are.  Someone who is raised in institutions their whole life has a whole different set of morality than someone who was raised in like a Mormon or one of the very religious backgrounds.  Yeah, totally different morals.  Now that’s because the guy was raised in institutions his whole life is even worse,  but it’s just what he was taught when he was young. I mean, that’s the real question, I’d probably be right.  Is it a sin if nobody believes it’s a sin?  My own views of right and wrong I think come from a combination of how I was raised and what I see when I was growing up, things that experienced. Well, you know, met quite a few people with a lot of money who really don’t have any morals at all.  I think that sort of affects me a little bit. Because if you look around the real genuinely, genuinely nice, great people--not doing that good. I mean, know what a Vice Presidents of major corporations run by someone without skeletons in their closet.  So, there’s something to be said about that.
column591: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on personal feelings and the influence of their boss's morals at work, acknowledges the increasing complexity of decisions as they affect others, and believes that moral views are shaped by upbringing and personal experiences, while also expressing a desire to help others but recognizing the subjectivity of moral obligations.

column584: Well I just think about how I was brought up, would that, would that be okay in the eyes of my parents, would, do I think that’s okay.  Ah, is it okay legally, is it okay in general, and ah, I just go by that. Well just the type of activity that it is, I mean, if we’re just going somewhere, like to play a game, or just to go hang out, but if we’re going somewhere to go hang out and drink or something, that would not be okay. Like that. Well, like behavioral type things, I mean, talk to your parents with respect, I mean, talk to other adults with respect, and then wrong things like trying, like don’t break the law.  Like just common sense mainly.
column585: The respondent primarily bases their decisions on their upbringing and parental approval, acknowledges the clarity of right and wrong but believes people have stopped caring, admits to engaging in drug and alcohol use out of curiosity rather than peer pressure, and feels that while they don't consider lying to parents as wrong, they recognize the importance of honesty in significant matters.

column588: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on the consequences for themselves and others, influenced by their parents and peers, while acknowledging that their moral views are shaped by these social influences and that they sometimes engage in behavior they know is wrong, such as skipping school, despite understanding the consequences.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide what is good or bad, right or wrong?
R:I guess the way it would affect other people.
I:Like consequences?
R:Yeah. Pretty much, yeah.
I:Now in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Pretty easy.
I:Pretty easy? Why do you say that?
R:I mean, it could either have positive results or negative results, and I’d try not to get negative results, I guess you could say.
I:What if it’s a situation you never had an experience with and you’re unsure?
R:I don’t know, I guess I’d get advice or something.

R:I don’t generally find myself in those kind of positions where I have to decide between right and wrong that often.

R:Not really, no.

R:Somebody going without something, I’m not too sure.

column591: The respondent would use a $100,000 inheritance to support family, buy a car and a house, and potentially save or donate, emphasizing the importance of family and the consequences of actions in determining right from wrong, while also acknowledging the influence of parents and society on their moral views.

column583:
I:Okay, um, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, my religion, mostly.
I:Okay, um what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong? Okay, um, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Um, I mostly, I almost always fall back on my religion.  It’s like there’s values for everything and structure and just things to fall back on, it’s just, it’s, it’s a good thing.
I:Okay, could you give me some specific examples of things?
R:Um, I guess like the word of wisdom, for example, where you can’t have alcohol and you can’t have hot drinks like tea or coffee or whatever and, and, just drugs in general and things like that, and even just, even overdosing on a, on a over the counter prescription drug.  Just things like that, I was on a, actually I went on a, I went on a cruise to the Caribbean for Spring Break and there was a, I sort of had a weird feeling, like I was down there, I should have known, but um, I was down in a, it was a club for 18 and older from, it was from like 10:30 ‘til like 4 in the morning or something or, whenever it fizzled out, but I was down there and it was like, I think it was like midnight or something but they were passing out jell-o and everyone was like oh jell-o shooters and I was like oh, jell-o okay, but I like, I didn’t know it was alcoholic but I had a friend that she was eating them and everything but I was actually, um, was talking to her about my religion and I actually gave her a book of Mormon, but I put the straw to my mouth and I started sucking, she’s like there’s alcohol in that, and I was like oh, so I was like this close to having alcohol, but, so I was cutting it close and I’ll need to watch out for that, but that’s, I think that’s probably the closest that I’ve ever come to having, to having anything that goes against my standards.

column585: The respondent reflects on a time of uncertainty regarding moving to Virginia, influenced by their father's desire for family closeness and the challenges of adapting to a different religious environment, ultimately deciding to stay due to a strong attachment to their current community and the potential negative impact on their faith.
column589:
I:Well how do you normally decide what is right or wrong in life?
R:It depends on the majority of the time I just go by what I have been taught and how I have been raised and there are a lot of decisions I just decided a long time ago and they haven’t been a problem, like smoking and drinking.  I never even think about it.  I just like no, I just don’t do it.
I:Do you feel like it is easy or hard for you to decide what’s right or wrong?
R:With reference to?
I:Just in general.  Do you have a hard time knowing what is right or wrong?
R:I think that all depends on the situation at least in my case.
I:Like what we are trying to get at I guess is what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  What is the criteria there?  Like do you think it is rules or laws, consequences, how it feels?
R:I think how it feels.
I:Ok, so it is more internal.
R:Yes, I mean I think somebody should make decisions that are correct based on intrinsic factors rather than external.  The inside rather than being influenced by outside sources to do something right.
I:Well that sort of falls in line with this, but…
R:Like one quote that I heard is integrity is making the right decision when nobody else is watching.
column590: It depends on the majority of the time I just go by what I have been taught and how I have been raised and there are a lot of decisions I just decided a long time ago and they haven’t been a problem, like smoking and drinking.  I never even think about it.  I just like no, I just don’t do it. With reference to? I think that all depends on the situation at least in my case.  I think how it feels. Yes, I mean I think somebody should make decisions that are correct based on intrinsic factors rather than external.  The inside rather than being influenced by outside sources to do something right. Like one quote that I heard is integrity is making the right decision when nobody else is watching.
column591: The respondent primarily bases their decisions on their upbringing and personal integrity, emphasizing the importance of intrinsic factors over external influences, while also acknowledging the detrimental effects of actions that conflict with their moral beliefs, and expressing a preference for following guidance from respected figures and spiritual teachings over competitive motivations.

column583:
I:Okay. So where do you think your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, some come from influence from my friends and family.  Other just seem to like, come out of the sky
I:Okay.  What do you think it takes to make something right or wrong? Like what do you think makes something right or wrong?
R:I really wouldn’t know.
I:Okay, let’s see.  We kind of covered this some, but how do you decide or know what’s good or bad or right or wrong in life in general?
R:Um, well like I said before, well with like the conscience and all, um if something just feels like it’s really out of place and sometimes I’d consider it wrong.
I:Is that emotionally out of place, or
R:It could be emotionally out of place, or also, if something just seems weird to me, it’s not like, regular, then.
I:Okay.  Let’s see, so would you say that you strive to keep a level of normality in your life when it comes to making decisions about what’s right and wrong?
R:At times, yes I will.  Um, sometimes I’ll feel like really conscience about myself thinking, people are going to think I’m really weird, so I try to act, it’s like, what I consider to be normal.
I:Okay.  Do you know what might influence that?
R:I don’t know, maybe, I just think I’m afraid people are going to think that I’m crazy or something.
I:Okay.  Let’s see, can you tell me why you think that would be bad?
R:Um, well, some, I just don’t like the feeling that people are going to be looking at me and saying “oh look at that girl, she’s…crazy.” (Giggles)
I:So do you think that what most people think is normal is, could be considered right, and what people would consider really abnormal would be something you’d considered wrong?
R:Sometimes, um, what some people consider abnormal, I could use an example of a boy from my school.  Um, I’m, I’m not sure if I’d consider him wrong, but he’s…scary.  And a lot of people consider him abnormal. But some of the things that he does are not, right.
I:Okay.  Can you think of things in a situation, say if something were abnormal, can you think of something that might be abnormally, abnormal socially, but still right, morally right?
R:Um, (pause), I don’t know, I’m thinking of like, examples.
I:Take your time.
R:It could be, um, abnormal socially, but it could be pretty much right. Um, maybe, I’m not sure if this would be a good example, but like, um, going and helping people that are like sick and have like, um, really bad diseases, a lot of people think that that’s just like disgusting, you don’t want to go near people that are all like, dirty and diseased, but then it’s morally right, because it’s nice to help somebody.
I:What about being religious, do you think that being religious is viewed as kind of right or wrong, or socially normal or abnormal?
R:No. I think that people can be whatever religion that they want, cause it really doesn’t matter.
I:Okay, so that doesn’t fall into the kind of right and wrong?
R:No.

column585: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on their conscience and instinct, often seeking advice from friends and parents, while feeling guilt over actions like skipping class due to a strong sense of right and wrong influenced by societal norms and personal beliefs.
column586:
I:Okay.  Alright.  So, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Oh, well there’s always that inner voice that tells me if something’s wrong or right.
I:Where do you think that inner voice comes from?  Can you kind of describe?
R:Uh, I’m not really sure.
I:What it is or you’re not sure?
R:Uh, probably just from things I’ve learned just through life.  From parents, from friends and teachers and all that.  All those things combined together, telling me what’s right and what’s wrong.  Like for example, I don’t need an inner voice to tell me about things like drugs and alcohol, because I just know about my life, that’s bad.  Um, and then other things, like cheating or stealing, I think that’s pretty much the same thing, where all throughout my life I’ve been told and so I just remember that.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Usually it’s pretty easy.
I:Has it gotten more difficult over the past 2 years?
R:Not really.  But, yeah, I don’t think so.  If anything it might have actually been a little bit easier.  Because before I would have had some trouble in those decisions, and then I’m not sure what changed, but things started becoming so much more obvious to me.  Like before I was you know, I remember friends telling me, well everyone drinks in college, so I was like oh, well maybe I will drink a little bit before 21, and then I was like no way, I’m not going to do that.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Uh, I’m not really sure.  How much it hurts others, in accordance to how much it helps you.  Not in accordance, I don’t know where that word came from, um, just you know, if it hurts somebody a lot, and if it helps you quite a bit, then it’s probably not the best to do.  I try my best to do something that wont hurt someone else, like drastically, I mean, I’m trying to think, winning a game or something like that, it’s not that I’m going to go easy on someone playing some sort of sport just so that um, I can help them feel better, cause once again I have that competitive streak.
I:Do you have a sense where you draw a line?
R:Yeah, I mean, if I’m playing against a beginner, I don’t play it anymore, but when I used to play tennis against a beginner and I could see them feeling completely miserable every time they missed a shot, then I would go a little more easy on them.  But I’m not nice enough to completely sacrifice my game to let them win.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Um, well in my opinion, doing drugs, stealing and killing people.
I:What do you think these things have in common that makes them wrong?
R:I’m not sure, um, probably, well killing people you know, I just find that really bad, unless it’s something in self defense, I understand that, but if you just go to someone and you dislike them and kill them or hurt them really badly, that’s just wrong, cause it’s like, I don’t know, I just don’t think that it’s right.  Um, I’ve never been asked actually what makes that wrong.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:A lot of it probably comes from you know, school and always being told, alcohol’s bad, and hey there’s Ryan* um, and certain things like that.  Yeah.
column587: Oh, well there’s always that inner voice that tells me if something’s wrong or right. Uh, I’m not really sure. Uh, probably just from things I’ve learned just through life.  From parents, from friends and teachers and all that.  All those things combined together, telling me what’s right and what’s wrong.  Like for example, I don’t need an inner voice to tell me about things like drugs and alcohol, because I just know about my life, that’s bad.  Um, and then other things, like cheating or stealing, I think that’s pretty much the same thing, where all throughout my life I’ve been told and so I just remember that. Usually it’s pretty easy. Not really.  But, yeah, I don’t think so.  If anything it might have actually been a little bit easier.  Because before I would have had some trouble in those decisions, and then I’m not sure what changed, but things started becoming so much more obvious to me.  Like before I was you know, I remember friends telling me, well everyone drinks in college, so I was like oh, well maybe I will drink a little bit before 21, and then I was like no way, I’m not going to do that.  Uh, I’m not really sure.  How much it hurts others, in accordance to how much it helps you.  Not in accordance, I don’t know where that word came from, um, just you know, if it hurts somebody a lot, and if it helps you quite a bit, then it’s probably not the best to do.  I try my best to do something that wont hurt someone else, like drastically, I mean, I’m trying to think, winning a game or something like that, it’s not that I’m going to go easy on someone playing some sort of sport just so that um, I can help them feel better, cause once again I have that competitive streak. Yeah, I mean, if I’m playing against a beginner, I don’t play it anymore, but when I used to play tennis against a beginner and I could see them feeling completely miserable every time they missed a shot, then I would go a little more easy on them.  But I’m not nice enough to completely sacrifice my game to let them win. Um, well in my opinion, doing drugs, stealing and killing people. I’m not sure, um, probably, well killing people you know, I just find that really bad, unless it’s something in self defense, I understand that, but if you just go to someone and you dislike them and kill them or hurt them really badly, that’s just wrong, cause it’s like, I don’t know, I just don’t think that it’s right.  Um, I’ve never been asked actually what makes that wrong.  A lot of it probably comes from you know, school and always being told, alcohol’s bad, and hey there’s Ryan* um, and certain things like that.  Yeah.
column588: The respondent makes decisions based on an inner voice shaped by life experiences and influences from parents, friends, and teachers, emphasizing the importance of not hurting others and feeling a moral obligation to help those in need, while also reflecting on personal struggles with competitive situations and the desire for success.
column589:
I:So how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t know, intuition sort of.  I mean I use judgment with everything like – I don’t know, it just kinda comes naturally.  Like I can’t think of anything that really like actively influences me to decide what’s right or wrong, or good or bad.  Maybe it’s just sort of how I’ve developed as a person that kinda helps things like that along.
I:And in general is it easier or harder for you do decide between right and wrong?
R:Usually not, usually the wrong choice kinda glares at me like, “No!  Wrong!”  Although like relationship wise I have a really bad time deciding like what’s right and wrong in that case.  I’m – because I’m just terrible at it.  But other than that usually like if I’m in a situation where I feel like it’s – I’m doing something wrong, then usually I get really uncomfortable with it and I just back out.
I:So do you think that deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or harder over the last couple years?
R:I don’t think there’s really been much of a change.  My definitions of right and wrong have changed, but with the ease of deciding between them, I don’t really think there’s much of a difference.
I:And you said that your views have changed?
R:Yeah.  Like I used to be total straightedge and I felt like pretty much everything was bad.  Like – I don’t know – everything that like any normal college kid does is like, “Well, that’s bad!  You shouldn’t do that.”  And now I just don’t care and like your entitled to do what you want just try and at least take care of yourself, and just try and like make good decisions for yourself and for the people around you.  Don’t get yourself into kind of a pit where you either you don’t – cant’ get out yourself, you drag other people in, that sorta thing.  That’s pretty much it.
I:So what do you think makes something right or wrong?  Is it like a consequence, or a feeling, or –
R:I don’t know.
I:How do you decide?
R:It’s usually just kind of a gut feeling sort of like based on morals and all that sorta thing.  It’s like – I don’t know – it’s like ethics, sort of.  Like for example, like he would consider – well, I can’t even think a good example. I was gonna go down the path of like science or something like that, but I don’t remember what I was gonna say.  But in any case, it is just sort of like a gut feeling sort of dealing with like – just sort of like principal ethics of society like – I mean you can’t like say killing people is right.  Well, I mean like just in cold blood, killing someone, you can’t like – there are pretty much no ethics anywhere that say that’s the right thing to do, just shooting someone for the fun of it, but yeah.  I don’t know – like there are certain things that are like right or wrong based on the individual.  Sort of – so sort of like how your life was shaped, like what you grew up in, and just sorta your view of society as a whole, your whole like morals and set of ethics and standards and everything like that.  But there are certain things that are just right and wrong like based on society that’s sort of – I don’t really know how to explain where it comes from, it’s just sort of innate, you know?  Like for example, killing someone in cold blood, that’s just wrong.  And I don’t really know where that comes from, like who was the original person to say that, it’s just something that’s always been there.  Do you know what I mean?
I:Yeah.  But so if it’s kind of an innate gut feeling, what happens if people’s feeling tells them something different?
R:I don’t know, honestly I don’t.  Like is it something that’s just – it’s hard to understand. Like I’ve never really completely the concept of like right and wrong and where it comes from.  I just know that like there are certain sets that everyone – most everyone – seems to follow.  And it’s a really hard thing to decide sort of as a general society like sort thing.  Like I honestly don’t know like where it came from, how it started, and what it really is – right and wrong.  I don’t know.  It’s weird.
I:So where do you think you’ve acquired your moral views from?
R:I don’t know.  That’s something I’ve asked myself a lot. I have no idea where I ever came up with the idea of like atheism, or where I came up with like just a lot of my like views of right and wrong.  I – because a lot of like views that I have now they like right and wrong switches views entirely. I have never heard anybody else that has anything like it, and I just – I don’t know where it came from.  Like just kinda things that I thought up that I decided was right for me.  So I don’t know.  I honestly don’t.  It just kinda came outa thin air.
column590: I don’t know, intuition sort of.  I mean I use judgment with everything like – I don’t know, it just kinda comes naturally.  Like I can’t think of anything that really like actively influences me to decide what’s right or wrong, or good or bad.  Maybe it’s just sort of how I’ve developed as a person that kinda helps things like that along. Usually not, usually the wrong choice kinda glares at me like, “No!  Wrong!”  Although like relationship wise I have a really bad time deciding like what’s right and wrong in that case.  I’m – because I’m just terrible at it.  But other than that usually like if I’m in a situation where I feel like it’s – I’m doing something wrong, then usually I get really uncomfortable with it and I just back out. I don’t think there’s really been much of a change.  My definitions of right and wrong have changed, but with the ease of deciding between them, I don’t really think there’s much of a difference. column591: The respondent primarily relies on intuition and personal judgment to determine right from wrong, acknowledges the difficulty of making decisions that prioritize their own happiness over others' feelings, and expresses a desire for greater compassion and understanding in the world, while also admitting to feeling superior to those they perceive as less intelligent.

column583:
