column585: The respondent reflects on their decision-making process, indicating that they often rely on the consequences of their actions, such as punishment from parents, and acknowledges the influence of their mother's teachings on right and wrong, while also admitting to making choices that they know are wrong, like engaging in risky behaviors with friends despite feeling guilty afterward.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Well you know, just sometimes you don’t think something is wrong until you face it.  And then when you face it, then you say, oh shoot it’s wrong, you know, I shouldn’t be doing this.  And sometimes you know when it’s wrong but you still go and do it.  Yeah, so.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Well, uh, it’s like, say example, you supposed to be going to school and you say I’m going to be going with my boyfriend.  And I’d say that’s wrong, and you know, it depends on you if you want to do the wrong or if you want to do the right, you know.
I:Do you think that’s easy or hard for you?
R:It’s real easy for me.  If it was in New York*, that’s so easy for me.  But Georgia* it’s hard, you know, you got to drive everywhere.
I:So how easy or hard is it for you to decide between what’s right and wrong?
R:Like, I had to uh, example, example, is and like, um, uh, for like an example, like, like last week I was supposed to be going out and I had some other, I had to tell my mother I was going out with some friends, but I was really going out, and you know, it was wrong you know, but I wanted to get out of the house, but you know, afterwards when I sit down and think about it, I said that’s the wrong thing to do, you know, you’re lying, and so.
I:So, has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Easier.
I:Easier?  In what way?
R:Always tell the truth.  Always tell the truth.
I:Does doing the right thing come naturally or is it hard?
R:Come naturally.  Naturally.
I:So has that changed at all over the last couple of years?
R:Yeah.
I:Why do you think that is?
R:Cause it’s not worth it.  You know, telling the truth is the right thing you know?  Cause if you lie long enough your parents are going to know, so.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:What it is?
I:Yeah, what makes something right or wrong?
R:You just, like if you know that it’s not a good, if you know that it’s not a good um, a good thing to do, it don’t make no sense to you, you know, if you know it’s good then you know you made the right choice. Like for me an example, the boyfriend, I don’t think I’m making a right choice because I, you know, I was making the right choice, but you know, it’s a hard thing.
I:So what about a situation, or what about meeting a boy or something like that, makes you know whether it’s right or wrong?
R:Well you know, first time, first time you can’t say something, um, you meet the guy and you think he’s the right one. And then you start going out and he’s being nice and everything, and you say “oh mom, look at this guy.”  But my mom knows if a person’s right for me or not.
I:What about things that are right and wrong to do?
R:What?
I:What about things that are right and wrong to do?  Like what makes something that you do, good or bad, or right or wrong.
R:Um, I’d just say, you know, you know if I do a good thing, you know I be so proud of myself.  But when you do a bad thing, you feel, you feel good, but then afterward, later on, you feel so guilty.  So you just got to make the right choice.
I:So what kind of feelings do you think indicate what’s right and wrong?
R:You’ll know my feelings, cause I’ll start crying.  There’s that, and you’ll just see a big smile on my face if I’ve done something good.
I:Okay.  And where do you think those feelings come from?
R:If it good?
I:Uh-huh.
R:If someone does something real bad to me, or if I do something real bad, yeah I think that’s where I get that bad feeling.  But if I’ve been doing good, been volunteering what I’m supposed to be doing, that’s a good thing.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong?
R:No.
I:No?  Why do you think that?
R:Because, I’m never wrong.  I mean these few years I’ve never done nothing wrong that I’m not supposed to be doing, so I think it’s nothing you know.
I:What about things in general that people do?  Are there any things that people do that are just wrong always?
R:Yeah, having kids.  That’s wrong.  That’s right but that’s wrong.  If you’re not married, that’s wrong.
I:Can you think of any other examples?
R:Pregnant.  You got to get married to get pregnant.  Doing drugs.
I:Can you think of any things that people do that are always right?
R:Go to school.  Just try to get an education.  Wait until you’re married to have some kids.  Um, that’s the best choice, you know.  Um, um, yeah, just trying to find the right person.
I:Why do you think those things are right?
R:(no answer, spoke to child)
I:Where do you think your views of right and wrong come from?
R:My mom tells me if it’s wrong.

column588: The respondent reflects on their decision-making process regarding right and wrong, emphasizing the importance of honesty influenced by their mother's guidance, while expressing uncertainty about a relationship and acknowledging feelings of guilt associated with past actions, ultimately believing that being a good person involves education, faith in God, and helping others.

column583:
I:Where did those come from?
R:What do you mean?
I:Like where do your views of what’s right and wrong come from? What helps you know what’s right and wrong?
R:Um…I don’t know.
I:Do you think that, is it your parents, is it your church, is it other, teachers, or where did, how did you dec-, you know come to figure out that drugs are right or wrong and this is right and that’s wrong.  Where do you think that those ideas came from?
R:Uh, parents, teachers.
I:What do you think has been the biggest influence for you personally, in figuring out what’s right and wrong?
R:Like drugs?  The commercials, they’re really disgusting.
I:Okay.  What about other things?
R:Um, knowing that my parents did it, and when they did it, it was wrong.
I:Okay, and did they tell you it was wrong?   They did?  Okay.   So, do you think your parents have been the biggest influence on what is right and wrong?
R:My parents what?

R:Yeah (yes)
I:Okay, are there any other factors?
R:Nope.
I:Okay.  What do you think makes something right or wrong?
R:What do I think makes something right or wrong?
I:Uh-huh (yes)
R:(pause)
I:Like, you know, why are drugs wrong, or why something else be wrong?
R:Because, it’s a matter of getting caught and getting in trouble.  Like drugs you get in trouble with the law, other things you could like, stealing you get in trouble with the law, stuff that you do at home you get in trouble with your parents.

R:No.
I:Why not?
R:Because you can still die from it.
I:Okay, then it’s wrong because it can hurt you?
R:Yep.
I:What if it didn’t hurt you, then would it be wrong?
R:It would still be wrong.
I:Okay.  So what are some other things you think maybe are wrong?
R:Uh, I’m not sure.

column585: The respondent believes that they have a clear understanding of right and wrong, attributing their moral compass primarily to their parents and teachers, while expressing concern that many teenagers know the difference but choose to ignore it, particularly regarding drugs and alcohol, which they view as harmful regardless of legality.

column585: The respondent believes that their sense of right and wrong, instilled by their mother and grandmother, is clear and unwavering, and they oppose cheating and lying, feeling guilty when they act against their upbringing, while also emphasizing the importance of the consequences of actions on others.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what’s good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Well, I think about what, it’s like if, if I were doing something, when anything that I think of is, well, it’s like when my grandmother or my mother, would they be happy? If someone were to hear, oh, would say, “oh I heard Matthew* did this”, would they be happy if they heard that? Or would they be, would they be disappointed? And pretty much just the morals, and what my mother taught me from childhood till now. And then just a little, and then what, from my own experience, from the situation. Well, that’s what I do.
I:In general, would you say it’s easy or hard to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s easy to decide.
I:Has deciding between wrong, right and wrong gotten harder or easier over the past two years?
R:It’s gotten, it’s gotten easier since, over time. Because now I just, I, don’t know. Some people look at it, well when you’re younger, you can maybe get away with it, I wanna say. Not exactly get away with it, but maybe the punishment might not be as severe because of your age. But now that I’m older, it’s, it’s just hit or miss. If you do something, it’s like, I don’t know what there may be, but if it’s wrong, that could end your life right there, or your goals, or what you’re pursuing for. So, it’s gotten a lot easier to know what’s right and wrong because, this is right, this is wrong, look at all the consequences. If I do this, if I do that, I could, all of this could happen and everything I worked up to to this point will be gone. So, it’s gotten easier to decide, to distinguish between the two.
I:Have your views changed in the past couple of years?
R:No, they’ve pretty much stayed, remained the same.
I:Why would you, how would you say it remained the same? Or why have they remained the same?
R:Well, it depends on what it is. I don’t know.
I:Are you thinking of like a specific?
R:Like, I don’t know. Like you said have your views over
I:Yeah, like, like moral views.
R:Oh, moral. Yeah, they’ve stayed the same. I don’t know, they haven’t changed, because I’m not really sure why.
I:So, for you, it’s gotten, is it, has it gotten easier? I mean, is it pretty easy for you to choose right or wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:The, the action, like the cause and effect. So, I guess, whatever the affect is of what your actions, or what happens, or what you’ve done. I think that determines what’s right and wrong.
I:So what kind of effects would make something wrong?
R:Well, a main one which happened a lot on camp, well not happened a lot but it was often heard of, people drinking and driving. People, in the dorms, not as much as the one that I stayed in, but other ones, people getting caught drinking under the age. And then they have it where, if you do it like, I think it’s three strikes or something, and you’ll be kicked out of your residential hall, your dorm room. And so, obviously that was wrong, because then you won’t have anywhere to live, and it’s on your record and stuff, so.
I:So the consequences? Getting kicked out?
R:Yeah, the consequences.
I:From where, from where have you acquired your moral views?
R:From my grandmother and my, my mother.
I:I mean, how so? I mean, how did they, how do you think they were sort of influence?
R:Through, oh, through experience. Just while, while growing up. Like, just, strong, also when I lied. Like, if I lied when I was growing up, even if it was a small one, they always got on me. Like, they were really strict about that, because they said that lying, like lying, you just shouldn’t do it in general. And because lying leads into other things, and then the more you lie, the more you have to, you know, fix yourself, tell another lie. And then, in one sense, if you’re lying, depending on the situation, you could get in more trouble. It could lead into stealing, killing, et cetera. So, you’re kinda off to a wrong, like headed towards a wrong path of life, by constantly lying. So, so I guess that’s one of the main ones , was to always be honest.

So, I guess, whatever the affect is of what your actions, or what happens, or what you’ve done. I think that determines what’s right and wrong. Well, a main one which happened a lot on camp, well not happened a lot but it was often heard of, people drinking and driving. People, in the dorms, not as much as the one that I stayed in, but other ones, people getting caught drinking under the age. And then they have it where, if you do it like, I think it’s three strikes or something, and you’ll be kicked out of your residential hall, your dorm room. And so, obviously that was wrong, because then you won’t have anywhere to live, and it’s on your record and stuff, so. Yeah, the consequences.  From my grandmother and my, my mother. Through, oh, through experience. Just while, while growing up. Like, just, strong, also when I lied. Like, if I lied when I was growing up, even if it was a small one, they always got on me. Like, they were really strict about that, because they said that lying, like lying, you just shouldn’t do it in general. And because lying leads into other things, and then the more you lie, the more you have to, you know, fix yourself, tell another lie. And then, in one sense, if you’re lying, depending on the situation, you could get in more trouble. It could lead into stealing, killing, et cetera. So, you’re kinda off to a wrong, like headed towards a wrong path of life, by constantly lying. So, so I guess that’s one of the main ones , was to always be honest.
column591: The respondent prioritizes using a potential inheritance for education and family experiences, bases their moral decisions on the approval of their mother and grandmother, and believes that right and wrong are determined by the consequences of actions, emphasizing the importance of honesty and personal responsibility while also expressing a desire to change societal issues like racism.

column583:
I:So where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Probably from the Bible actually, like what Jesus did.  I mean how can you argue with God?  There’s no arguing right there, so.
I:Okay.  And I know it’s hard to pinpoint it but what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  Like what inherently about it?
R:Um pretty much your morals, uh whatever you believe in.  Like you can’t say like, maybe I’ll think this is right and the guy next to me, well he thinks it’s totally wrong, I mean it’s your own beliefs and your own opinions.
I:How do you decide or know, I mean you mentioned the Bible, is that they way you know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Uh, yeah, and what your parents influence you on.  I mean you know it’s not all right to call people names and pick on them and that.  And the Bible, I’m not going to argue with that, so.

Like you can’t say like, maybe I’ll think this is right and the guy next to me, well he thinks it’s totally wrong, I mean it’s your own beliefs and your own opinions. Uh, yeah, and what your parents influence you on.  I mean you know it’s not all right to call people names and pick on them and that.  And the Bible, I’m not going to argue with that, so.
column585: The respondent generally feels confident in distinguishing right from wrong, often influenced by their religious beliefs and parental guidance, but acknowledges the impact of peer pressure on their decisions, leading to feelings of guilt when they act against their morals.
column589:
I:Right. Um, how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um, I think the old golden rule applies. Whether or not ah like would you want that done to you. Like  is that a good decision. You always think you know, you had that conscience and you’re like man should I be doing this? Is that a good thing or a bad thing? So.
I:Ok. In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong in life?
R:Depends. It’s situational. I mean usually it’s just like yea it’s stupid, don’t do it, you know. Sometimes there’s some things you’re like man should I do this right now and you’re just like ah screw it, whatever, I don’t care, I’ll do it. It’s pretty, it’s pretty cut and dry.
I:Right. Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:I think easier. I mean you become more focused, especially you know this close to graduation. You know I only got one year down at Juniata*, I’m applying to medical school so it’s like if you’re committed, you know, you can’t be doing things, so the line between right and wrong, you know, is pretty, pretty clear cut.
I:Um. Have your views changed about what’s right and wrong in the past 2 years?
R:I don’t think. Nothing, nothing major.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think your beliefs. I mean what you feel. It’s a gut instinct, you know, um. What might be right for me might be completely wrong for the guy next door to me, so.
I:So where do those instincts come from?
R:I don’t know if you want me to say it’s like biologically ingrained in you or you know it’s part of your environment, but I think it’s both. Um, I mean that natural instinct that comes what people say like man you know that’s wrong, don’t do it, you maybe it’s socialistic your environment. Hey everyone’s like man that’s how you were raised ah, but there might be something internally in you that says you know what that’s just not the right thing to do, don’t do it.
I:Are those instincts common to all people?
R:I’d like to think so, but that’s definitely not, not true. I mean, everyone’s different, so.
I:Right. So what, where does this come from? Why do you believe so strongly about this?
R:.
I:So is it kind of your experiences that have taught you this?
R:I guess, I mean it would shape my mind and shape my my thoughts and beliefs on it I guess, yea some of, some of the speakers and stuff like that, some of the experiences I’ve had.

column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on a gut instinct to pay off debt, influenced by the pressure of school and future obligations, while also adhering to the golden rule for moral guidance, though they acknowledge that moral judgments can be situational and shaped by personal beliefs and societal changes.

column583:
I:And that, you said you, you kind of have a sense of right or wrong, um, and you go with your head and your instinct, um, where does that come from?
R:Um, I’m sure that came from my, my parents letting me find stuff out on my own, um, I think both of them feel like a good way for me or for any other young person to learn something is through experience, so I mean, they’ve never really, I’ve never really had a set of rules, right along—right or wrong, like laid in front of me by either one of my parents, it’s always just been kind of, they’ve encouraged me to build up my own sense of what’s right and what’s wrong you know in hopes that it’s, that I turn out okay I guess, so.
I:And um, if you had to decide ah, what is good or bad, right and wrong, in life, um, how do you decide that?  I mean how do you know what makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, one of the things I would think about is how other people would feel what’s right and what’s wrong, also um, I guess from my own experience I’d, I’d probably think about my parents, I’d think about experiences like if I wasn’t experienced I’d think about similar ones I’ve had, I just, I’d just probably just relate it back to something that I already had been before, so, um, pretty much just experience, I think.
I:Mm-mm.  Do you have any examples of that?
R:Oh,  I haven’t really done anything where I had to think about what’s right and what’s wrong recently, so.
I:Yeah, yeah no that’s fine.
R:No, I don’t think so.
column584: Um, I’m sure that came from my, my parents letting me find stuff out on my own, um, I think both of them feel like a good way for me or for any other young person to learn something is through experience, so I mean, they’ve never really, I’ve never really had a set of rules, right along—right or wrong, like laid in front of me by either one of my parents, it’s always just been kind of, they’ve encouraged me to build up my own sense of what’s right and what’s wrong you know in hopes that it’s, that I turn out okay I guess, so. Oh,  I haven’t really done anything where I had to think about what’s right and what’s wrong recently, so. No, I don’t think so.
column585: The respondent relies on their intuition and personal experiences, shaped by their parents' encouragement to learn through experience, to navigate moral dilemmas, while acknowledging the influence of social issues and the importance of maintaining positive relationships to avoid guilt.
column586:
I:and then if you generalize from that, how do you decide or know what’s right or wrong in life, what’s good or bad, is there any general principles that you could give someone of what’s right and wrong?
R:well what I could give them is I guess my own principles which I go on, which are sometimes unclear even to me at times, but usually right and wrong I decide by harming others, giving I guess, benefiting where benefit needs to be given like in this case my mom could really use the money towards her medical bills a lot more than I could use a new car. I have a car, it’s fine. So I guess, I don’t know sometimes I wonder about my own moral conscience at times but, just what seems right to me is…there’s always usually something that’s like that just seems like the right thing to do, it’s hard for me to explain, I think it’s just a general fundamental situation that you know, if you do this and there’s harm to be done here then you just have to weigh it out and I guess just weight out the harm and the benefit and I, I just think not hurting other people unnecessarily is one of the main factors that…
I:has deciding on right or wrong, has it become harder or easier over the last couple of years?
R:um, hmmm. I think it might have become harder, I think it’s become harder because there’s so many decisions that I make that I don’t stop and think you know is this right or wrong. But then again, there’s a lot, I mean that might be because I’m doing a lot, I’m doing fewer things, I’m more busy with school, I’m doing fewer things that that decision needs to be made with. But I think that living on my own stuff, things just come, I just do things based on instinct and what I, I just…this feels like the right thing to do, I just make the decision. So I don’t know if it’s become more difficult, but I find myself stopping to consider it a lot less than I did. I trust my judgment a lot more.
I:wow, alright. Is there anything you would say makes things right or wrong, that you would point to and say, this makes it right or wrong?
R:I think the overall situation, like I said before, if something creates more harm in one area, to create a little bit of benefit in another area, I think you have to consider the whole benefit, so I think just the balance, if something creates more of a negative balance whatever that may be, then I think that would be more likely to be wrong than right and vice versa. So I think the consequences of an action, all told, are what would most make the decision of if it’s right or wrong.
I:and is there any way of talking about the relative importance of different kinds of consequences?
R:oh yeah, certainly. I think if family is involved versus, I mean if it would’ve been*Indian*or a family member, obviously the focus would have been more on my family. Family or I guess grander things that affect many more people, obviously, are relatively more important when considering the overall consequences of an action. So yeah, I think you have to consider the relative importance of everything.
I:any actions that you would say are wrong in themselves?
R:um…hmmm. I think any action that is just fundamentally wrong, regardless of the circumstance, I think physically hurting women, that pops into my brain first as like, the situation would have to be a pretty unique situation for me to see that as being an acceptable thing to do, like physically hurting women and children.
I:and that in particular is because of the power dynamics there?
R:um, maybe, maybe just because society says that you know, you’re not supposed to hit women and children, but yeah, I just think basically because they’re usually viewed as being more defenseless. I mean I don’t, I mean if you have, I think the reasons for hitting another man can be, you can have a lot less reasons to do that than to hit a woman or a child. Hurting family members, you know physically or not, I think is hard to justify in my mind. Being malicious about things that you have no reason to be malicious about you know, just for the fact of being violent or rude, I think you know, basically things that have no reason, no motivation behind violence or evilness I guess, those sort of things I see as…
I:and then if, okay so, that’s interesting how you put it about having an outside structure that tells you right and wrong and so, where would you say that your understandings of right and wrong come from?
R:because I don’t have an outside structure, I’d say they come from observations, experience, past experience, so I guess when I’m making decisions of right or wrong, instead of looking to a religious framework or some other framework set up outside, I look to my own past experience, my own decisions I’ve made before, what was my mindset when I made that decision, do I trust my own instinct in that case to apply it here again. So just sort of reflection on my own past decisions, observations on what my parents have done, what other people have done, observing those consequences.

I have a car, it’s fine. Being malicious about things that you have no reason to be malicious about you know, just for the fact of being violent or rude, I think you know, basically things that have no reason, no motivation behind violence or evilness I guess, those sort of things I see as…  because I don’t have an outside structure, I’d say they come from observations, experience, past experience, so I guess when I’m making decisions of right or wrong, instead of looking to a religious framework or some other framework set up outside, I look to my own past experience, my own decisions I’ve made before, what was my mindset when I made that decision, do I trust my own instinct in that case to apply it here again. So just sort of reflection on my own past decisions, observations on what my parents have done, what other people have done, observing those consequences.
column588: The respondent would use the $100,000 to pay for their education and their mother's medical expenses, motivated by a desire to alleviate their mother's financial struggles, and they believe that right and wrong are determined by the potential harm to others, reflecting on their own experiences and the influence of their parents, while also expressing a struggle with moral decisions in complex situations, such as caring for a friend's well-being versus the potential consequences of seeking medical help.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong?
R:Normally, that’s hard to say.  I think usually I go by past experience.  My own past experience and just think, have I been in this situation before, what was it like, could I do it different this time or not?  If it’s something sort of amoral I’ll think about whatever my Dad would do probably.  Something sort of practical.  Something moral, I would still probably first think about, not necessarily what would my Dad do but what would my Dad think about what I did.  And disappointing my Mom is another thing that I’m always trying to avoid doing.  So if I’m faced with a decision, I think well if I make this choice, would I want my Mom to find out about it or not and a lot of times that’s like the low water mark for like depraved action, you know what I mean?  It’s like, if I would never want my Mom to find out about this, then I’ll probably rethink doing it.
I:Would you say it’s easy or hard for you to decide?
R:It’s usually easy because the decision itself, like isn’t always, I’m never really cognizant of the decision, you know what I mean?  I sort of tend to just live and react and sort of trust that I know what I’m doing, even though I really don’t think I do, I guess.  But I’m gonna say it’s easy just because I never like stop and think about that kind of decision very often.
I:Has that gotten, has that changed at all in the last 2 years?  Has it gotten easier or harder?
R:No, I don’t think, I don’t think that’s changed at all, I think.
I:And your standards of right and wrong, would you say that’s changed in the last couple years?
R:Yeah, if it has changed, my, it’s become a little, what’s right and what’s wrong has become a little bit more rigorous I think from just maturing through college and taking classes like when I have to think about children and things like that and every time I encounter people I’m always sort of, the past experience and things I talked about was always sort of revised, so I think it’s just, it becomes more honed as I get older.  I’m finding that to be the case.  Where like, before I would be like well I’m not really sure what I think about this, I kind of think this way now, now I’m more able I think so think about the reasons why I think something and stand behind it, I’m a little less wishy-washy.
I:Okay.  What do you think makes something right or wrong?
R:Hmm.  .  I don’t know.  I don’t agree with, I don’t think I agree with Hagle or Kant how to determine whether something is right or wrong, but I don’t—oh.  That’s such a difficult question.  I don’t know if there is any way to determine if something is right or wrong, I guess.  I mean, I think that’s the way I feel about it.
I:Where would you say you’ve acquired your moral views?
R:Oh, anywhere and everywhere, I guess.  My parents didn’t try to like present and drive home a set set of morals or values to me.  They’ve sort of demonstrated them to me and let me pick them up as I go and a lot of it has come from outside the family, just experience, things I’ve read, things I’ve listened to, things I’ve watched, causes I’ve taken.  It’s hard to put your finger on the part of that that was with you from the beginning, I think but you’ve always had, because it’s always changing and it’s hard to point to the things that have changed but I think that for me that’s something that’s always sort of being added to and evolving just as I live my life, I guess.

I’m finding that to be the case.  Where like, before I would be like well I’m not really sure what I think about this, I kind of think this way now, now I’m more able I think so think about the reasons why I think something and stand behind it, I’m a little less wishy-washy.  Hmm.  .  I don’t know.  I don’t agree with, I don’t think I agree with Hagle or Kant how to determine whether something is right or wrong, but I don’t—oh.  That’s such a difficult question.  I don’t know if there is any way to determine if something is right or wrong, I guess.  I mean, I think that’s the way I feel about it.  Oh, anywhere and everywhere, I guess.  My parents didn’t try to like present and drive home a set set of morals or values to me.  They’ve sort of demonstrated them to me and let me pick them up as I go and a lot of it has come from outside the family, just experience, things I’ve read, things I’ve listened to, things I’ve watched, causes I’ve taken.  It’s hard to put your finger on the part of that that was with you from the beginning, I think but you’ve always had, because it’s always changing and it’s hard to point to the things that have changed but I think that for me that’s something that’s always sort of being added to and evolving just as I live my life, I guess.
column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on past experiences and the desire to avoid disappointing their parents, particularly their mother, while also acknowledging that their moral standards have become more rigorous over time, although they find it challenging to translate their thoughts on right and wrong into actions.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:What’s that?
I:Where do you think, where would you say your views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, definitely my parents.
I:Okay.
R:Definitely my dad.
I:Uh-huh.
R:Um,  um, I don’t know, I was a kid that you know 6th and 7th and 8th grade they, they held onto me so close and I was just like, I’m an only child,
I:Right, right, right, right.
R:So that plays a big part in it and I wanted freedom and they wouldn’t give it to me and um, I guess I kind of learned from myself what’s right and what’s wrong these days, but if, I don’t know, if, if you look back, I know my mom and dad kind of adopted that for me.  So.
I:Right.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  Or what’s the criteria that you would say something is right or wrong?
R:Um, well, uh, well, definitely when it comes to the law you know right is right and wrong is wrong.
I:Okay.
R:But I think from a teenager’s point of view, I think the parents play a huge role in that.
I:Right.
R:And that’s where you get it, that’s definitely where you view it from. And if you don’t have parents then everything is just what you want to do.
I:Right.  Cause one of the things you mentioned is making fun of people.
R:Yeah.
I:And as far as I know there’s not a law against that, so what would make that wrong I guess?
R:Um, I think religiously it’s not a very nice thing to do and um, I don’t know, like it’s never, it’s not in the Bible or anything, but it just comes down to respect, and respecting people, definitely, just, I don’t know you don’t need to do that and it’s just bad for you, you know?  It will come back to you in the long run.  So I think it’s just, it’s just not nice you know?
I:So is it more wrong because of the consequences then because it will come back around to you or is it just intrinsically wrong itself or?
R:I think, well, I don’t know, like, I think, I think both of those are definitely right.  Cause I think, um, doors open for reasons and uh, definitely, if you do something, something is going to happen to you.  I believe in that.  And also I think, um, being wrong, or doing something wrong is definitely, is definitely, yeah, it will come back to you.  So yeah, both of those I agree with.

It will come back to you in the long run.  So I think it’s just, it’s just not nice you know? I think, well, I don’t know, like, I think, I think both of those are definitely right.  Cause I think, um, doors open for reasons and uh, definitely, if you do something, something is going to happen to you.  I believe in that.  And also I think, um, being wrong, or doing something wrong is definitely, is definitely, yeah, it will come back to you.  So yeah, both of those I agree with.
column585: The respondent attributes their understanding of right and wrong primarily to their parents, particularly their father, and acknowledges feeling guilty for actions that conflicted with their upbringing, while also expressing concern about the decline of moral clarity among peers, especially regarding issues like substance use and disrespect, which they believe stems from a lack of values instilled by parents and societal influences.

column585: The respondent generally feels confident in distinguishing right from wrong, often relying on their parents' and religious teachings for guidance, while making decisions based on the potential consequences of their actions and occasionally choosing to take risks for fun, but they do not feel pressured by friends to engage in risky behaviors like drinking or drugs.

column585: The respondent's decision-making is influenced by their upbringing and morals instilled by their parents, particularly referencing biblical teachings against stealing, while they also acknowledge the thrill of engaging in risky behaviors like stealing and getting high, often succumbing to peer pressure but feeling no guilt about their actions.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what's good or bad, or right or wrong in life?
R:My judgment.  I have to go off my own instincts to know if it's right or wrong, you know.  Yeah, just go off my own instincts.
I:Is that generally easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It's generally easy because I'm going with what I feel.  If I don’t feel like its right, I won't do it.
I:Would you say that deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or harder over the last couple of years?
R:I'd say it's gotten a little harder now that I'm getting a little older.  I have to watch all the mistakes I make because I have a baby now.  She's almost gonna be two, so I have to watch everything I do, because she watches me.
I:You're like an example to her whether you want to be or not.
R:Yeah, everything I do.  If I'm snapping my fingers and telling her no, she's trying to snap her fingers and telling me no.
I:Have your views changed more right and wrong things in the last couple of years?
R:Yeah, because about three years ago, I was 18 or 19.  I was just out of high school, you know, had my parents’ car that I was able to use so I was running around doing anything and everything that I could do at that time.  Now, I pretty much just go to school, come home, stay with my little girl all day and things like that.  So yeah, my views have changed a lot.  Now I know I have to look at things in the bigger picture.  I have to consider getting my own house, getting my car and my truck and things like that.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Your morals.
I:So what about the, so
R:The way you were brought up, how you were taught as a kid, your lifestyle.
I:Okay, so when you said you decide that you know right and wrong based on your gut, that's based on what you've been taught throughout your life.  Is that related to anything else like rules, laws, consequences, or how something feels, or –
R:The law is a big thing, because you never want to get in trouble with the law, you know what I mean?  So that’s a big thing.  Right or wrong is basically, yeah –
I:Where would you say that your own moral views come from?  Where did you get what you think is right and wrong?
R:Basically, the way I was brought up, the way I was taught.
I:From your mom and dad?
R:Yeah.
I:Any other places?
R:Just who they had me grow up around, like their friends, my aunts, my uncles, my cousins, you know, better influences and stuff like that.

column591: The respondent expresses a desire to invest a hypothetical inheritance into building apartments for financial security, relying on their instincts to determine right from wrong, while acknowledging that their moral views have evolved with the responsibilities of parenthood and the influence of their upbringing, emphasizing the importance of personal happiness and moral integrity in decision-making.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what’s good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Most of it’s a gut feeling, and then, just in the way I’ve been brought up, and it all makes sense to me. I think about it and it makes sense. I think when you’re younger it’s  you’re influenced by your parents. And then when you get older you can kinda think about it in your own head, make sense of it. And I’ve thought about it, and a lot of it makes sense to me.
I:Is this or hard for you in general to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy.
I:And has this gotten easier or harder, you’d say, in the last couple years?
R:Easier.
I:Any reason why?
R:I think just because I’ve grown up and I can understand things a lot better than when I was younger.
I:Have your views changed in any way in the last couple years?
R:Not really, no.
I:You’d just things are a lot clearer, but they’re not different?
R:Right, yeah.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think it’s all the way I believe it and the way that the society looks at it, too.
I:Like some things are right or wrong depending on whether your society says it’s right or wrong?
R:Kinda like the peer pressure thing.
I:I mean, is it wrong because your, I don’t know, your friends say it’s wrong, or because…
R:And the things I believe in. That, too.
I:Why do you believe those things?
R:I think it’s kind of just a sense of hope and things like that. Like my religion, I believe in what I believe in because I know I’m saved when I die.
I:Some people say it’s consequences of your actions that make something like wrong as opposed to being good for a lot of people. Or people say, no it’s what you feel, if you feel it’s right, then it’s right, regardless of what people tell you. So what do you think about those kinds of things?
R:Well to me with my religion it’s kind of all right in the Bible. It says you should do this, you shouldn’t do this, you should do this, you shouldn’t do this, and that’s the way I look at things. And it’s not to benefit me. I do it because God said so.
I:Is there a difference between what your friends say is right and what society says is right versus what the Bible says is right?
R:Not really, because  kinda believe in the same things.
I:I mean your friends and you.
R:Yep.
I:In terms of societal things, like I mean, something like, I don’t know, living with your partner before getting married; I mean, a lot of people say that’s the right to do, but you wouldn’t agree, right?
R:Right.
I:So why? Like, what is it about, what makes that right what makes it wrong?
R:Well, you know, I also believe that I shouldn’t be sleeping with my partner until I get married. And I think if we were under the same roof it would be a little harder to not do that. And it’s just, we’re supposed to wait to live together before we get married. I know a lot of people do it, and I don’t believe, they probably don’t have the same religion as me.
I:Would you think it’s wrong for somebody to do that, or is it right for somebody to do that?
R:If they’re living together and they’re not sleeping together, then it would be fine, according to me.
I:What if they are sleeping together?
R:Then, according to my religion, it would be wrong.
I:So even if society says it’s right, you’d say your religion has to be the main determining…
R:In my life, yeah.
I:But  you would apply that to other people? Would you say other people shouldn’t be doing it?
R:I wouldn’t go up to them and say so. But the way I look at it, yeah.
I:And where do you think you’ve acquired these moral views from?
R:Well, my parents started it and I kinda just followed with it once I grew up.
I:Was that ever a struggle? Did you have to, did you ever disagree with them about these things? Did you always agree what they were
R:Yeah, for the most part. That’s the way I was brought up. I’ve always gone to a private school, and I’ve always taken religion classes in high school, and go to church, it’s, I’ve always agreed with it. It always makes sense. I did, wouldn’t say I questioned it, but I did start turning it my head a little bit, just trying to figure it out a little more when I grew up, and it still all makes sense.

column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on a combination of religious beliefs and parental influence, stating that they would donate to their church and prioritize their wedding, while also emphasizing that their understanding of right and wrong has evolved through personal reflection and upbringing, with a strong belief in adhering to biblical principles over societal norms.

column583:

column585: The respondent believes that their sense of right and wrong is shaped by their parents and church, contrasting with peers who lack moral clarity, and they feel uncomfortable in situations where friends engage in questionable behavior, yet they do not confront them, attributing their moral compass to personal beliefs and societal laws.
column589:

R:Um, I guess just my own judgment and then if I'm not sure of a decision, like what would become of it, probably ask people, analyze it a little bit.

R:Friends.

R:It’s probably pretty easy but sometimes you just make the wrong choice anyway.

R:Yeah.  I guess rules, regulations, laws, um-

R:Then how would people know?  Um, I guess just if whatever you’re going to do is going to be hurting someone else, not the right thing to do.

R:Um, probably from my parents and um, how I was brought up.

column591: The respondent primarily relies on their own judgment and the influence of friends when determining right from wrong, acknowledges the ease of making wrong choices despite knowing better, and attributes their moral views largely to their upbringing by their parents.

column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are clear, often relying on biblical morality, but admits to being tempted by bad decisions for money, while also feeling guilty about the potential harm they could cause others and justifying their actions through societal expectations and personal experiences.

column583:
I:Okay.  Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Well, they reflect from like my parents and from church and from my friends and from my own views, really.  I mean, I really, I think I get a lot of my, I don’t really agree with one person and not the other person, like I’ll agree with some things you say and some things another person say, like.  I mostly think some things are right by the situation or not, or wrong by the situation or not, it just all depends.
I:And what do you think it is that makes something, like, right or wrong, like what does it depend on?
R:Like, if, if you’re gonna, if it’s gonna hurt you or if it’s, if there’s gonna be some bad consequence in the end, then you probably shouldn’t do it, it would only be common sense, but.  A lot of people don’t have that, so.  But.
I:Okay.  And how do you decide what’s like good and bad or right and wrong, and like?
R:I just kinda live from day to day, like I, I, before I make a decision, I think okay, am I gonna get caught, am I gonna get in trouble, am I gonna get hurt, like am I gonna be able to get home safely and are bad things gonna happen around me that I don’t want to, I try not to put myself in situations where I know it’s gonna be trouble or where I’m gonna get hurt or something, I don’t put myself in situations like that.
column584: Well, they reflect from like my parents and from church and from my friends and from my own views, really.  I mean, I really, I think I get a lot of my, I don’t really agree with one person and not the other person, like I’ll agree with some things you say and some things another person say, like.  I mostly think some things are right by the situation or not, or wrong by the situation or not, it just all depends. Like, if, if you’re gonna, if it’s gonna hurt you or if it’s, if there’s gonna be some bad consequence in the end, then you probably shouldn’t do it, it would only be common sense, but.  A lot of people don’t have that, so.  But. I just kinda live from day to day, like I, I, before I make a decision, I think okay, am I gonna get caught, am I gonna get in trouble, am I gonna get hurt, like am I gonna be able to get home safely and are bad things gonna happen around me that I don’t want to, I try not to put myself in situations where I know it’s gonna be trouble or where I’m gonna get hurt or something, I don’t put myself in situations like that.
column585: The respondent acknowledges knowing when they are doing something wrong but often succumbs to peer pressure, feels guilty about their actions especially in relation to their church teachings, and believes their moral views are influenced by their parents, friends, and situational consequences rather than strict absolutes.
column589:
I:how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad and right and wrong in life?
R:How do I know?  I mean it’s really half is my religious background and the other half is more common sense… I know, I think about negative consequences before I do things.
I:That’s the common sense part?
R:Yeah.
I:And then what’s the religious background part?  What do you mean by that?
R:like, like relationship-wise, like I wouldn’t… religion would come into play with, you know, I would need a certain amount of time before I become intimate with anyone, that’s my religion.  Common sense reminds me that drinking and driving is… the fact that I have a lot of friends with DUIs and I can’t afford for my insurance to go up, so that’s my common sense.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide or know what’s right and wrong?
R:It’s easy.
I:Ok.  Has it gotten easier or harder in the last three years?
R:Easier.
I:Why do you think so?
R:because before I was more willing to do, you know, schemeful or do things that other people were doing, and now, it’s just focused on me and what I wanna do.
I:Mmhmm.  Ok.  Have any of your moral views or ethical views changed actually in the last two or three years?  Like you used to think something was right or wrong and now you don’t or…?
R:Yeah.
I:What?
R:sometimes when I was younger I would  and eventually I’d like to marry and that kind of stuff doesn’t really fly when you get older.
I:Mmhmm.  So how would you describe the moral change in that?  Looking back you realize now that it’s wrong to use alcohol, how would you describe that?
R:I would just say that I have… before all I thought about was the present and what would happen to me right then and how I felt right then, and now I think about how it’s gonna affect me in a year or two or who I might meet because of what I’m doing.
I:So is the change because you’re just at a different place and you realize things differently or were there actually sort of like hard knocks that woke you up to, oh my gosh, I can’t do that.
R:No, no hard knocks or whatever.
I:Ok.  What do you think it is, is it that makes something right or wrong?  I mean we’re talking about morality, good, bad, right or wrong.  What is it that makes anything right or wrong in the first place?
R:The consequences that come after it is completely what controls why I do the things I do.
I:What about the consequences?
R:if it’s gonna negatively effect my future, then I don’t, I consider that a negative consequence and I’ll  the frequency of doing anything that will negatively affect me.
I:Ok.  How does that… so that seems to fit with the common sense half that you talked about?  How about the consequence on how it will affect your future?  How does that fit in or not with the sort of the religious upbringing half?
R:I’m working on it.  As long as it’s not, you know, unfortunately it’s not one of my top priorities.
I:I’m not saying you should or anything, I’m just interested in sort of how you think about these things.
R:Oh I know.  you know to be completely honest, I always figure that one day, like, when I get married and I have kids and I’m going to decide to go back and…
I:To church or faith or something like that?
R:Church and faith on a regular basis.  which, it’ll be easier because I’ll have the motivation.
I:What would be the motivation then that you don’t have now?
R:because I want to raise my kids in a church, and they have those good morals that I had that you can’t, you know if your parents are teaching you, you know, some people do the exact opposite of what their parents say, so I’d rather get the whole, I say it, they say it, we say it, sort of thing and then just rely on them going with what I say.
I:so the getting married and having kids part would sort of kick that into gear?
R:Yeah.
I:And then do you think that it would be good for you?  I mean I hear what you’re saying about you’re not a morning person, your lifestyle, whatever.  Do you think at your age religion would be even relevant or has anyone to teach you?  I mean part of what I hear you saying is, you know, sorta like you need the Sunday school training and you need the basic morals laid down.  What about for someone who’s twenty or twenty-five?  Does religion have anything that’s worthwhile or is it just like, that’s not relevant?
R:It should, I mean if you’re having problems yourself with making the right decisions, I think that you need, which a lot of people do, you need that moral support or you know, you need to keep doing what’s right and wrong to go with God and then do what’s right, and then I say 100% you should go every Sunday, you should go every day if that’s what you need to do.  But if I have it gutted in me, and I feel like I make pretty good decisions without going every Sunday, then you know, it just doesn’t seem like a priority to me to go every Sunday.
I:Ok.  so back to the what makes something right or wrong?  So it’s mostly the consequences it will have for your future?
R:Yeah.
I:So might there be things that are right to do morally that don’t help your future or that hurt your future?  Or might there be things that are wrong to do that would help your future?
R:well I hope that I have a big conscience.  I can’t, I can’t, I feel like even if it’s not just directly about me, I feel like I care a lot about others and if it’s gonna hurt someone else in some other way, I don’t want any part of it.  I don’t want to be held responsible for anything that would happen to anybody else.  I feel like everyone has enough to themselves, they do not need someone else to bring them around.
I:So the consequences are for you and for everyone who you might influence?
R:Mmhmm.
I:Ok.  Are there any things that are just pure right or wrong, regardless of what their consequences are, it doesn’t matter, it’s just the act, you just do it or you don’t do it?  It has nothing to do with consequences.
R:No.  I don’t think that applies .
column590: How do I know?  I mean it’s really half is my religious background and the other half is more common sense… I know, I think about negative consequences before I do things. Yeah. like, like relationship-wise, like I wouldn’t… religion would come into play with, you know, I would need a certain amount of time before I become intimate with anyone, that’s my religion.  Common sense reminds me that drinking and driving is… the fact that I have a lot of friends with DUIs and I can’t afford for my insurance to go up, so that’s my common sense. It’s easy. Easier. because before I was more willing to do, you know, schemeful or do things that other people were doing, and now, it’s just focused on me and what I wanna do. Yeah. sometimes when I was younger I would  and eventually I’d like to marry and that kind of stuff doesn’t really fly when you get older. No, no hard knocks or whatever.  The consequences that come after it is completely what controls why I do the things I do. if it’s gonna negatively effect my future, then I don’t, I consider that a negative consequence and I’ll  the frequency of doing anything that will negatively affect me. I’m working on it.  As long as it’s not, you know, unfortunately it’s not one of my top priorities. Oh I know.  you know to be completely honest, I always figure that one day, like, when I get married and I have kids and I’m going to decide to go back and… Church and faith on a regular basis.  which, it’ll be easier because I’ll have the motivation. because I want to raise my kids in a church, and they have those good morals that I had that you can’t, you know if your parents are teaching you, you know, some people do the exact opposite of what their parents say, so I’d rather get the whole, I say it, they say it, we say it, sort of thing and then just rely on them going with what I say. Yeah. It should, I mean if you’re having problems yourself with making the right decisions, I think that you need, which a lot of people do, you need that moral support or you know, you need to keep doing what’s right and wrong to go with God and then do what’s right, and then I say 100% you should go every Sunday, you should go every day if that’s what you need to do.  But if I have it gutted in me, and I feel like I make pretty good decisions without going every Sunday, then you know, it just doesn’t seem like a priority to me to go every Sunday. Yeah. well I hope that I have a big conscience.  I can’t, I can’t, I feel like even if it’s not just directly about me, I feel like I care a lot about others and if it’s gonna hurt someone else in some other way, I don’t want any part of it.  I don’t want to be held responsible for anything that would happen to anybody else.  I feel like everyone has enough to themselves, they do not need someone else to bring them around. Mmhmm. No.  I don’t think that applies .
column591: Respondent M1 prioritizes paying off debt and investing for future growth, while Respondent M2 bases decisions on a mix of religious beliefs and common sense, considering negative consequences; Respondent M3 faced a moral dilemma in a breakup, ultimately choosing to prioritize self-respect, and Respondent M4 struggles with acting on known morals, often justifying risky behavior; Respondent M5 emphasizes the importance of consequences for both self and others in decision-making, while Respondent M6 believes moral views are shaped by upbringing and culture, rejecting absolute right or wrong; Respondent M8 acknowledges the inevitability of moral failures but believes in divine accountability, and Respondent M9 feels a moral obligation to help others, linking it to karma; Respondent M12 desires equal opportunities for all to eliminate excuses for failure, and Respondent MX grapples with the tension between inherited beliefs and personal questioning, aiming to guide future generations while allowing them to form their own beliefs.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um…well wait a minute, I also, still also to backtrack to the other question, I also think there are a few situations and circumstances that…the judgment of right or wrong is…kind of…um…shall we say vague shall we say.  Uh…let’s say I took a gun and I pointed at you and I said…uh…let’s say you somehow had some kind of experience in bomb making…just out of the blue situation, let’s say, or you are part of a bomb squad, here’s that’s better, if you are part of a bomb squad and I came up and pointed a gun at you or pointed an automatic weapon and said make me a bomb right now…then, I would think because of the circumstance, since you were that bomb squad if he forced you to make that bomb and he used it to blow something up, I think that we should have a little…uh…either have a little bit, a small bit of punishment for you but…you were forced with an automatic weapon pointed at gun, to force to make this bomb that I used to blow something up, I think that you should have a little ease on that one.
I:Okay, um,
R:I think that because of the circumstance you aren’t doing the wrong, you are forced to do it cause I had a gun stuck to your head.

column585: The respondent believes they have a clear understanding of right and wrong, influenced by their upbringing, and they express concern about societal norms and the consequences of actions, particularly regarding the importance of personal responsibility and the potential misuse of circumstances as excuses for behavior.

column583:
I:Okay.  Where do you get your views of what’s right and wrong.  Where did that, where does that come from?
R:Um, my training from my grandparents.
I:Um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, what do I think it is?
I:Yeah, yeah, what, what makes something right or wrong in your eyes?
R:Like—
I:You know is there, is there some, is there some, I don’t want to give it away or you know kind of pinch your thinking, but is there some standard for what’s right and wrong in your eyes, is there something that gives it the tag of right and wrong, this is right, this is wrong.
R:Not really.
I:Nothing?  Okay.  How, how do you decide or know what’s good and bad, right and wrong in your life?
R:What is good and bad in my life?  Like what does it mean to me?
I:Yeah, how do you come up with, with the thought that this is good, that’s bad, this is right, that’s wrong.  In your own life.
R:It depends on the situations, it depends on the situations, like if someone’s carrying a gun and they want me to carry one, I know that was bad for a fact, cause you can get in trouble and yeah, like.
I:So nothing helps you define what’s right and wrong in your own life?
R:Nothing but my training.
column584: Um, my training from my grandparents. Um, what do I think it is? Like— Not really. What is good and bad in my life?  Like what does it mean to me? It depends on the situations, it depends on the situations, like if someone’s carrying a gun and they want me to carry one, I know that was bad for a fact, cause you can get in trouble and yeah, like. Nothing but my training.
column585: The respondent often relies on the moral training from their grandparents to navigate decisions of right and wrong, experiences guilt from peer pressure situations, and believes that while there is societal pressure to engage in risky behaviors like drinking and smoking, they choose to avoid such influences.

column583:

R:Yeah.

R:It’s not right to kill people.   Commit adultery or stuff like that. Just all the basic stuff, in the 10 commandments.

R:Well I don’t, I’m not sure which, you just, um, it’s um, some sort of concept that we’ve always had and I never have really known, um, where it came from like um, why is this wrong, why is this right.  And I, I’m not really sure, I don’t know.

R:Well my church um, that helps me to decide what they say is right and wrong, I just say, okay.  Because I think it’s right and wrong if they say it’s right and wrong.
column584: Ah, well my church. Yeah. It’s not right to kill people.   Commit adultery or stuff like that. Just all the basic stuff, in the 10 commandments. Well I don’t, I’m not sure which, you just, um, it’s um, some sort of concept that we’ve always had and I never have really known, um, where it came from like um, why is this wrong, why is this right.  And I, I’m not really sure, I don’t know. Well my church um, that helps me to decide what they say is right and wrong, I just say, okay.  Because I think it’s right and wrong if they say it’s right and wrong.
column585: The respondent often relies on their church for guidance on right and wrong, feels guilty when they don't act according to their conscience, and believes that while there are clear moral standards, individual perceptions of right and wrong can vary based on the situation.

column583:
I:Yeah.  Um, now you said that your, your views of, tell me if I’m saying this back to you correctly, ah, your views of right or wrong come from your personal experience, from where else?
R:My family.
I:Your family.
R:How I’ve been raised, school.
I:Okay and you also said common sense, maybe, stuff like that?
R:Yeah common sense.
I:Okay um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, basically I know it’s right or wrong just, probably from the outcome, like what you’re gonna get from it, the consequences that will follow whether it hurts other people, their self.
I:Why, why is it wrong to hurt other people, do you think?
R:Cause it doesn’t really do any good for anyone, it hurts them, you, and I know that’s wrong, that’s what I’ve been taught.
I:Does it, in the end run, I mean, if, if we can sort of make those decisions individually and I’m not trying to put you on the spot, I just want to get at what you, what you have in mind, um, does it really matter whether we hurt each other or even hurt ourselves in those situations as long as we get what we want?
R:Yeah it does cause, like you want it, you have to be able to achieve it in a peaceful, nice way, I mean, um, probably what you want, if you achieve it in like the wrong way by hurting someone, it’s probably not gonna be the same in the end.

R:Um, just—
I:Cause you might get in trouble if you don’t tell them everything, or?
R:Um, I’m not gonna get in trouble maybe just that they don’t, um, mm. They probably might not see it the same way I do or something, maybe?

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um, I guess I just know there are certain consequences or contexts that I don’t like, so I just stay away from them.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy. I just stay away from certain situations.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:It hasn’t really changed.
I:It’s always been pretty easy?
R:Yes, it’s just easy for me.
I:Ok, that’s fine. Some of these questions are pretty philosophical. So you mentioned early that it has something to do with consequences. What kinds of consequences would make something wrong?
R:I guess if it hurts someone else. I think you just have to decide if it’s going to cause harm to someone else. Like I guess another example would be if someone really wants to go out with a group of my friends, and other people specifically don’t invite them even though they know they want to go. I guess if they found out about that it would be hurtful, so I don’t think people should do that.
I:So would that still be wrong if the person didn’t find out?
R:Well yeah, I think it would. I would feel guilty about that. I guess it’s just not a good idea to do something harmful to someone, even if they don’t find out about it.
I:Ok, so you said you would feel guilty about that, where do you think that feeling of guilt comes from?
R:What do you mean?
I:Well, is there a reason why you would feel guilt? Or is there a specific way you figure out what would make you feel guilty or not? Are there rules or laws?  Or is it mostly about consequences in relationships? Or?
R:It’s just never ok to do something that would cause harm to someone else.
I:So from where do you think you acquired your view on what is right or wrong?
R:My family, and also my classes here at school.
I:Have your views about right and wrong changed over the past three years, or not? Why? In what ways?
R:No, I don’t think so.
I:You said that they’ve been influenced by your classes at school here, so have they changed at all as a result of your classes?
R:No, my classes have just strengthened what my parents already taught me.
column590: Um, I guess I just know there are certain consequences or contexts that I don’t like, so I just stay away from them. It’s pretty easy. I just stay away from certain situations. It hasn’t really changed. Yes, it’s just easy for me. No, I don’t think so. No, my classes have just strengthened what my parents already taught me.  I guess if it hurts someone else. I think you just have to decide if it’s going to cause harm to someone else. Like I guess another example would be if someone really wants to go out with a group of my friends, and other people specifically don’t invite them even though they know they want to go. I guess if they found out about that it would be hurtful, so I don’t think people should do that. Well yeah, I think it would. I would feel guilty about that. I guess it’s just not a good idea to do something harmful to someone, even if they don’t find out about it. What do you mean? It’s just never ok to do something that would cause harm to someone else.  My family, and also my classes here at school.
column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on the consequences of their actions, influenced by their parents' teachings and a sense of moral obligation to avoid causing harm to others, while also expressing a belief in the importance of tolerance and the need to help those in need.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of what’s right and wrong come from?
R:Probably experience.
I:Like, what’s an example of that?  What’s something you think is wrong?
R:Well, I know me doing drugs and drinking’s wrong cause it’s, you’ve already met my step-dad, and I know he knows it’s wrong.
I:So, you’re saying you know it’s wrong, because he tells you it’s wrong.
R:Yeah, cause I get in trouble for it.
I:But people can get in trouble for things that aren’t wrong.
R:Well, yeah.
I:Is it wrong to kill somebody?
R:Yeah.
I:Why?
R:Well, actually, it depends on what the circumstances are, if it was out of self-defense or something then it’d be all right, but not if you hate somebody and you just wanna kill them.
I:Is it wrong to steal stuff?
R:Yeah, cause that stuff’s not yours, not unless you’re really broke and you really need something.
I:Okay.  But, so what if it’s not, someone might say, who cares if it’s not yours, take it.
R:I don’t think that’s right.
I:Why?
R:Well, I mean, I wouldn’t like it if somebody stole something that was mine, that I worked hard for.
I:So, people should do what they want done to them?  What if somebody said, well they’re not gonna get mine, but I’ll take theirs!
R:No, I don’t think that’s right.
column584: Probably experience. Well, I know me doing drugs and drinking’s wrong cause it’s, you’ve already met my step-dad, and I know he knows it’s wrong. Yeah, cause I get in trouble for it. Well, yeah. Yeah. Well, actually, it depends on what the circumstances are, if it was out of self-defense or something then it’d be all right, but not if you hate somebody and you just wanna kill them. Yeah, cause that stuff’s not yours, not unless you’re really broke and you really need something. I don’t think that’s right. Well, I mean, I wouldn’t like it if somebody stole something that was mine, that I worked hard for. No, I don’t think that’s right.
column585: The respondent acknowledges knowing the difference between right and wrong but often chooses to act against it based on personal desire, feels guilty about certain actions influenced by social relationships, and believes that morality is clear despite societal pressures, while also admitting to engaging in behaviors like drinking and smoking despite recognizing their potential wrongness.
column586:
I:tell me, last time we talked and one thing we’re interested in understanding is how people understand right and wrong, good and bad, what’s moral, what’s not moral, just how people think about that. So do you think things are good and bad, right or wrong, or is it just whatever it is, is. Do you believe there’s sort of a moral reality that should guide people?
R:I believe there is but I don’t follow it.
I:and what is it?
R:I believe that god has a plan for everybody.
I:so it comes from god?
R:yeah.
I:and you would know that how? How would you know what god’s moral and good?
R:I just heard it in church, ‘cause I grew up in church, and then when I was older I decided I didn’t want to go and I didn’t have to.
I:so church, preaching, teaching, the bible.
R:mhum.
I:so you think morality comes from there?
R:mhum.
I:and you’re not following it?
R:no.
I:and what do you think of that?
R:it’s not good .
I:I remember you said similar things before, you said I know god’s out there but I just don’t wanna get, go there, I’m not getting into that. That’s still kinda where you are?
R:.
I:would you say that you’re sort of actively rejecting that or running away from god or would you just say, you’re just doing what you want and whatever that is sometimes it follows god and sometimes it doesn’t?
R:yeah
I:and you know, being raised in church, that a lot of Christians would say “if you don’t follow god’s way it doesn’t just make god unhappy it’s also bad for you. There are costs.” What do you think of that idea? That it’s in your own interest to follow god, it’s not just something you’re made to do?
R:yeah, I don’t know, I just believe that everybody’s going to have to pay for what they’ve done. Everything comes bad, plus, I don’t really know.
I:are you saying you’re not sure if it affects anything on this earth, it’s all in the future?
R:well god affects it, I don’t think that, I don’t know, I don’t think that…yeah, maybe you are punished, I don’t really think about it that much, I guess you are punished for what you do. And also--
I:--but you’re not motivated to try to get back and live morally the way you think, or know, or think you know is the right way?
R:yeah, I just hadn’t had the effort to put towards it.
I:do you see yourself ever doing that?
R:yeah, eventually .
I:what do you think would, I’m not trying to push you in that direction, but what would happen that would make you turn that corner or what would it take?
R:I have no idea.
I:but you just have in the back of your mind, someday I’ll get on the straight and narrow or whatever?
R:yeah, I guess probably, I don’t know what I’m gonna do.
I:and you don’t really know what’s preventing you?
R:uhuh. I’m just not ready to do it.
I:okay. In your life does it feel like you’re making real significant decisions about right and wrong or do you feel like you’re just living in…whichever it is is whatever? Do you know what I mean?
R:yeah.
I:do you face choices that you know are moral or are you just living?
R:yeah I do.

column588: The respondent would use an inheritance to support their baby and save for the future, while also expressing concerns about their ex-boyfriend's manipulative behavior regarding financial support, and reflecting on their moral beliefs shaped by church teachings, despite not actively following them.
column589:
I:Okay, how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Mainly my gut instinct, I guess like if I feel like it’s wrong—
I:In your gut?
R:Yeah, I don’t, if you could convince me, by book knowledge or statistics in real life, I believe it, otherwise I'm not going to believe it if my gut instinct tells me it’s something bad.
I:In general, hard or easy is it for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Pretty easy.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the last 3 years?
R:Easier.
I:Do you have any reason why?
R:I think it’s because the older you get, the more knowledge you get and I don’t know, it’s just, been through a lot, learned a lot of life lessons, so.
I:Okay.  So have your views, your moral views changed much in the last 2-3 years?
R:Not really I don’t think, that I can think of right now.
I:What is it your think makes things right or wrong?  Where does right or wrong come from anyway?
R:I don’t know.  I guess it’s kind of a mixture between religion and society.
I:Tell me a little more about that.
R:Well society has their own views of what’s right or wrong as far as their morals, what most people believe in and religion is the same way.  They, you know, you go by the Bible and what’s in the Bible as far as what all is in the Bible—
I:So do those things actually make things really right or wrong or are those just sort of what people think is right or wrong.  Like if the majority of people decided some thing is wrong, it leads to nothing, can that truly be wrong or would that just be—?
R:It’s an opinion, opinion.
I:So what is it makes things like really right or wrong no matter what people think about it. Like people could be wrong that it is was right or wrong.
R:I don’t know, I mean the only way I know is if you do it and you find out that it’s wrong, if you see someone else doing it, I don’t know.
I:How would you find out it’s wrong, you mean if it has consequences?
R:Yeah.
I:Like some people would say rules or  or consequences or how it feels, God’s will, or these, are any of those how you think about why things are right and wrong?
R:I don’t know.  I don’t know.
I:Where, what makes it wrong, where does that come from?
R:Just um, if you hurt somebody, you would hurt somebody either by their feelings or physically.
I:Where do you think you have gotten your views about what are right or wrong things?  I mean you said in general, society and the Bible, is that what you mean for you yourself or your family, or?
R:Well I’ve kind of learned from past events which were I learned a lot of people that I don’t want to be like from my ex and his family, I learned who I do want to be like from my foster mom.  Mainly people around me that I’ve seen what happens and what could happen so I think about it before I do it.
column590: Mainly my gut instinct, I guess like if I feel like it’s wrong— Yeah, I don’t, if you could convince me, by book knowledge or statistics in real life, I believe it, otherwise I'm not going to believe it if my gut instinct tells me it’s something bad. Pretty easy. Easier. I think it’s because the older you get, the more knowledge you get and I don’t know, it’s just, been through a lot, learned a lot of life lessons, so. Not really I don’t think, that I can think of right now.  I don’t know.  I guess it’s kind of a mixture between religion and society. Well society has their own views of what’s right or wrong as far as their morals, what most people believe in and religion is the same way.  They, you know, you go by the Bible and what’s in the Bible as far as what all is in the Bible— It’s an opinion, opinion. I don’t know, I mean the only way I know is if you do it and you find out that it’s wrong, if you see someone else doing it, I don’t know. Yeah. I don’t know.  I don’t know.  Just um, if you hurt somebody, you would hurt somebody either by their feelings or physically. Well I’ve kind of learned from past events which were I learned a lot of people that I don’t want to be like from my ex and his family, I learned who I do want to be like from my foster mom.  Mainly people around me that I’ve seen what happens and what could happen so I think about it before I do it.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on gut instinct to determine right from wrong, influenced by life experiences and the advice of their foster mother, while also acknowledging the moral implications of living together before marriage and the societal expectations surrounding it.

column583:

R:Like when my parents grew telling me um, what I see, and the way I see the world and stuff.  Cause I don’t think really hard if I know something is right or wrong. Unless, there are situations where I think, I think it’s clear to what’s right and wrong.

R:Um, I don’t know.

R:(pause)
I:No?
R:Like I’ll try to do the right thing so.
