Unless, there are situations where I think, I think it’s clear to what’s right and wrong. Um, I don’t know. (pause) Like I’ll try to do the right thing so.
column585: The respondent primarily relies on their mother and friends for guidance in decision-making, believes that many people disregard right and wrong due to boredom or a desire for trouble, and feels that their moral views are shaped by their parents, while also expressing concern about a friend's drug use but recognizing that their advice had little impact.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I mean I think like if it’s going to interrupt school, if it was going to get in my way with school, in an inevitable way, then yeah, probably is bad.  I don’t know.
I:How do you internally know oh, this is bad, or this is wrong?
R:Kind of the way my parents raised, me too, you know?  Morals and stuff.  I would think like what if my mom sees me doing this right now.  If she would get made then I would think twice about it or, but if it’s something, my mom would be cool with me too, you know, she knows I'm a good kid.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I think it’s fairly easy.
I:Same, on the same lines, but once you’ve decided what you think is the right thing to do-is it ever hard to then take that step and actually do the right thing?
R:It could be hard.
I:And so what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
column590: I mean I think like if it’s going to interrupt school, if it was going to get in my way with school, in an inevitable way, then yeah, probably is bad.  I don’t know. Kind of the way my parents raised, me too, you know?  Morals and stuff.  I would think like what if my mom sees me doing this right now.  If she would get made then I would think twice about it or, but if it’s something, my mom would be cool with me too, you know, she knows I'm a good kid. I think it’s fairly easy. It could be hard.
column591: The respondent expresses a desire to use a hypothetical inheritance to help family in Colombia and others in need, guided by the moral teachings of their parents, while also acknowledging the complexity of right and wrong decisions influenced by social interactions and personal experiences.

column583:
I:Would I, could I ask would you look to certain standards of right and wrong, where do yours come from, if you have certain standards of what’s right and wrong where do those ideas come from?  Your own views that is.
R:Um…probably my parents and friends.  Just…I don’t know, growing up as a Christian I think it’s different.
I:Uh-huh
R:Not different, I think you deal with the same kind of stuff but…you’re pretty, I don’t know, you know the bible really well you would want to try to do what is right I guess.
I:So is your parents view of right and wrong ever at odds with your friends.
R:Yes.
I:And in what way and how do you work through those disparities?
R:Um…I think my parents view are more right than my friends sometimes just because they’ll say something and to me it feels wrong but to them it can feel totally right.  It’s sort of like maybe like hanging out with friends or going out and partying all the time.  I know my parent’s views on that are right and I disagree with that completely, I don’t think you should just go have fun and waste your life but some of my friends disagree with that, I you know, I try to be an example to them but it’s hard.
column584: Um…probably my parents and friends.  Just…I don’t know, growing up as a Christian I think it’s different. Not different, I think you deal with the same kind of stuff but…you’re pretty, I don’t know, you know the bible really well you would want to try to do what is right I guess. Yes. Um…I think my parents view are more right than my friends sometimes just because they’ll say something and to me it feels wrong but to them it can feel totally right.  It’s sort of like maybe like hanging out with friends or going out and partying all the time.  I know my parent’s views on that are right and I disagree with that completely, I don’t think you should just go have fun and waste your life but some of my friends disagree with that, I you know, I try to be an example to them but it’s hard.
column585: The respondent believes that moral standards are influenced by their Christian upbringing and parents, feels that many teenagers have lost a sense of right and wrong due to societal pressures, and generally tries to uphold their values despite peer pressure, particularly regarding activities like partying and substance use.
column586:
I:how do you decide or know what’s good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:growing up I think my parents gave me morals and like I live by certain morals and really it’s like, my Christian walk and I know what’s right and wrong and I know what I’m gonna do and what I’m not gonna do. So it’s kinda like, not my parents like enforced anything on me but as I got older and now I sort of enforce certain things on me and lines that I can’t cross.
I:and you said those are based on the morals that your parents taught you?
R:yeah.
I:in general is it easy or hard for you to decide what’s right and wrong?
R:it’s really easy.
I:has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:it depends on the situation. I think it’ll always be a challenge, but just from like pressure around my friends and stuff, but…
I:um, so a minute ago when I asked if it’s gotten easier or harder for you to decide between right and wrong, whether it is you said that it’s easy and just now you said that in some situations it’s gotten harder. I’m curious, could you elaborate on that a little bit?
R:well I know what’s right and wrong so it’s easy for me to decide what I want to do but when I’m in a group of friends and they’re really pressuring me to do something, it can be a challenge at times. So it’s easy for me to know what’s right and wrong but at times it’s a challenge to make myself do what I know is right.
I:what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:um, I don’t know how to answer that …um, I don’t know, I think for me it’s like what I believe and…I really don’t know how to answer that question!
I:well how do you know that what you believe is right? Why is what you believe right?
R:because like…I’m sorry.
I:it’s fine, I can…if you’re having a hard time I can sort of, we can move on a little bit, it might help you.
R:okay, what…I’m a Christian and I believe that that’s right and that there is a god because I truly believe that…like I’ve felt his presence and I know that he’s guiding me in every way. I’ll pray about something and just like have my prayer request written out and if I look back like months later I’m like wow, that’s amazing, god really answered those prayers, maybe not the way that I thought so but he answered them still and I’m not even worried about that situation anymore. And I know it’s right because I see god moving in my life and my family and my friends.
I:okay, so in a sense what you think makes something right or wrong is…god?
R:yeah.
I:are there any actions that are always wrong in and of themselves?
R:I’m not sure I understand what you mean by that?
I:are there any things that are just wrong no matter what, no matter of circumstances, regardless of anything, they’re just wrong?
R:yeah, I think so!
I:can you give me some examples?
R:um, I think like sex outside of marriage is really wrong. I have a really hard time when people like do drugs around me or smoke, I don’t think drinking is necessarily wrong but it gets to a point where it is wrong. Just like things you can do to hurt people, intentionally.
I:so intentionally hurting people is wrong?
R:yes.
I:so what makes these things wrong?
R:um, the consequences that you reap from them, I mean, like sex outside of marriage, you can get pregnant and you can have a kid and that might not be what you wanted. And if that happened to one of my friends I’d be like, well you were really wrong in that situation but I’ll still be there for you.
I:that’s fine. From where have you acquired your moral views, where have they come from?
R:my family and my faith.
column587: growing up I think my parents gave me morals and like I live by certain morals and really it’s like, my Christian walk and I know what’s right and wrong and I know what I’m gonna do and what I’m not gonna do. So it’s kinda like, not my parents like enforced anything on me but as I got older and now I sort of enforce certain things on me and lines that I can’t cross. yeah. it’s really easy. it depends on the situation. I think it’ll always be a challenge, but just from like pressure around my friends and stuff, but… well I know what’s right and wrong so it’s easy for me to decide what I want to do but when I’m in a group of friends and they’re really pressuring me to do something, it can be a challenge at times. So it’s easy for me to know what’s right and wrong but at times it’s a challenge to make myself do what I know is right.  um, I don’t know how to answer that …um, I don’t know, I think for me it’s like what I believe and…I really don’t know how to answer that question! because like…I’m sorry. okay, what…I’m a Christian and I believe that that’s right and that there is a god because I truly believe that…like I’ve felt his presence and I know that he’s guiding me in every way. I’ll pray about something and just like have my prayer request written out and if I look back like months later I’m like wow, that’s amazing, god really answered those prayers, maybe not the way that I thought so but he answered them still and I’m not even worried about that situation anymore. And I know it’s right because I see god moving in my life and my family and my friends. yeah. I’m not sure I understand what you mean by that? yeah, I think so! um, I think like sex outside of marriage is really wrong. I have a really hard time when people like do drugs around me or smoke, I don’t think drinking is necessarily wrong but it gets to a point where it is wrong. Just like things you can do to hurt people, intentionally. yes. um, the consequences that you reap from them, I mean, like sex outside of marriage, you can get pregnant and you can have a kid and that might not be what you wanted. And if that happened to one of my friends I’d be like, well you were really wrong in that situation but I’ll still be there for you.  my family and my faith.
column588: The respondent emphasizes the importance of family support in decision-making, guided by the morals instilled by their parents and their Christian faith, which shapes their understanding of right and wrong, although they acknowledge the challenge of social pressures from friends.
column589:
I:And how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Just like growing up as a kid, everyone has their own morals.  And I am a Christian, so just reading a Bible, I know what’s right and wrong.  Everybody does.
I:Ok.  In general, do you think it’s easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I don’t think it’s hard.  I think it’s pretty easy for me.
I:And do you think it’s gotten easier or harder over the last few years?
R:Easier.
I:Why?
R:I feel like in the last couple of years, I’ve really started to know who I really am and my faith has gotten a lot stronger.
I:Ok, that’s ok. We’ll just keep going.  So how about this, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  Like you said you just know, but what is it that you know?  What’s the difference?
R:Like do you want an example?
I:No, not necessarily, I mean if it, if it’s an example, that’s fine, but more so how, what is it that makes something the right decision .  Is it a feeling, is it a consequence?
R:I think it can be both, like for me, it’s just my beliefs and what I’ve thought up in my head is right and wrong, and I’m not going to go out and sleep with somebody before I get married, I’m going to save myself until I get married.  And if I were to do that, that’s wrong.  I know it’s wrong because my head and heart say it’s wrong.  And that’s what I believe in and I’m not going to go do that, you know?
I:So when your head and your heart tell you it’s wrong is it because of how it would make you feel, or because of the outcome, or because of your beliefs?
R:Everything.  All of the above.
I:And you just are aware of all of that .
R:Yeah, it’s just like I know it’s wrong right from the beginning, and that might be a struggle for me, like I don’t want to do that.  And it’s just like going to church my whole life, and having my parents tell me what’s right and wrong and like growing up like “This is bad for you, don’t do this.”  And growing up, I feel like I can make my decisions, but I feel like since my parents and I believe from the same level, we have the same belief level.  Like they taught me what’s right.  They taught me what they believed, that’s now what I believe.  So what they see as right and what they see as wrong, almost everything lines up with each other.  And so like I’m a Christian, I’m going to try to follow God’s Word, not my parents’ word, but what the Bible says.  And I’m not a stupid person, and I know when I’m doing something wrong, and I know what I’m doing.  I don’t always think like “Oh, this is the right thing.”  You know?  I don’t consciously think it’s just like walking down the street and just the decisions I make daily.
I:So your beliefs disagree with your parents?
R:No.  No they don’t.  Just like my relationship with God isn’t going to be the same as both of theirs.  They might feel really strongly about something, but I might take that in a completely different way.  I know that we all believe the same thing in general, but like…
I:Some of those specific…
R:Yeah.
I:And so a lot of, so this kind of internal sense of this is right or wrong is because of the church teachings and what your parents have taught you?
R:Yeah.

I don’t consciously think it’s just like walking down the street and just the decisions I make daily. No.  No they don’t.  Just like my relationship with God isn’t going to be the same as both of theirs.  They might feel really strongly about something, but I might take that in a completely different way.  I know that we all believe the same thing in general, but like… Yeah. Yeah.
column591: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on their Christian beliefs and values instilled by their parents, emphasizing the importance of following God's will, while also expressing a desire to help others without imposing their beliefs on them.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:My own views, my mother.
I:What makes something right or wrong?
R:What makes something right and wrong?  The effects, I think that it has on you, makes it wrong or right, I think.
I:The effects it has on who?
R:On you.
I:On you as a person?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay, can you go a little further with that?  Maybe give me an example?
R:Let me see, um, like, okay, you do something and you’re like, if you think it’s not wrong, then, why would you feel um, uncomfortable or something, but if you know it’s right, then you be alright with it, it’s how you feel about it.
I:Okay, okay, let’s say for example, um, hum.  Well, let’s say you felt it was okay to talk about somebody, like some people feel it’s okay to talk about other people, and it doesn’t bother them at all, I mean, is that, would that be, then that would be right for that person since they don’t feel wrong about it?  Or would it be wrong?
R:It would be, it’s wrong to other people, I think it would be wrong because you shouldn’t talk about people.  But, I mean, if she feel alright with it, what can she, what can other people do?
I:Okay.
R:Everybody don’t agree with the same thing.
column584: My own views, my mother. What makes something right and wrong?  The effects, I think that it has on you, makes it wrong or right, I think. On you. Yeah. Let me see, um, like, okay, you do something and you’re like, if you think it’s not wrong, then, why would you feel um, uncomfortable or something, but if you know it’s right, then you be alright with it, it’s how you feel about it. It would be, it’s wrong to other people, I think it would be wrong because you shouldn’t talk about people.  But, I mean, if she feel alright with it, what can she, what can other people do? Everybody don’t agree with the same thing.
column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are clear but acknowledges that people often choose to do wrong anyway, attributing their moral views largely to their mother's influence, while also feeling guilty about personal choices that conflict with her high standards and recognizing the social pressures from peers regarding drinking and drug use.

column585: The respondent has a clear sense of right and wrong, often guided by a "little voice" in their head, but admits to occasionally ignoring it due to social influences from friends, leading to regretful decisions, while also emphasizing that their moral views are shaped by their family, the Bible, and the consequences of actions.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what’s good or bad or right or wrong in life?
R:Since I’m religious, a lot of it comes from the Bible and then if it’s not, then just think about what’s involved. Are you hurting other people? What are the consequences, you know?
I:Consequences for them and for you?
R:Yeah, the consequences of each action. If the consequence is someone’s feelings get hurt, the consequence is you hurt yourself but the plus side is it feels good or it makes me happy or whatever, then it’s probably bad.
I:Would you say that, in general, it’s easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s easy for me to decide. It’s hard for me to do.
I:So that was going to be one of the next questions was, when you know what’s right and wrong, how hard or easy is it for you to actually do the right thing?
R:It’s very hard.
I:Why do you think?
R:Because I mean, you get very good justifications, you know what you’re doing is bad, but in your mind, you can always make up some reasons, some excuse why it’s okay.
I:Would you say that deciding between right or wrong has gotten easier or harder in the last few years?
R:It’s been harder.
I:Harder, why?
R:I didn’t make any decisions. I never made any decisions before, you know.
I:So your dad was making them? Or…
R:Yeah, I didn’t really have any input on anything. So now it’s like I have a bunch of decisions to make, so many decisions to make. And when I make those decisions, I have to sit through them all. It’s a lot harder to sit through the decisions than to have one option presented.
I:Yeah, where there’s no choice at all, right?
R:Yeah.
I:What is it you think that actually makes something right or wrong? Was is it about your action or whatever that makes something right or makes something wrong?
R:Intention and consequences, I think.
I:Say more about intentions. What do you mean?
R:Well, I have an idea about perspectives and perception, which is you ask somebody, if it’s okay to steal and they say no. And you ask the person, well; what if your family hadn’t eaten in a week, your son was going to die? There was a loaf of bread there, it didn’t belong to you, would you take it? Yes. So, well, you just stole. So I think that even the most rigid, judgmental or morally pompous people, if under the right circumstances or the wrong circumstances, would do something that they’d regret, do something they wouldn’t normally do, or do something they’d speak out against. So intention and then the circumstance have a lot to do, I think, with what’s right and what’s wrong.
I:You mentioned earlier consequences. You mentioned earlier this religious Bible. How do those things fit into knowing what makes something right and what makes something wrong?
R:A lot of people think that the Bible is like a very rigid kind of set of rules, and there are rules, but there’s also a lot of principles in it where if you look at it and say, okay, what’s the purpose behind it? Take for example, the most  example of the Sabbath. If you look at what the purpose of it was, okay, so it’s doing work on the Sabbath, it was for rest. It was for people to have a day of rest. But if you take it to the point where you’re not allowed to cook dinner because that’s work on the Sabbath, then you have to think about the principle behind it is.
I:The point as opposed to little tiny picky rules.
R:The point of it is you have a day of rest, not a day of starvation, day of rest. If you’re hungry, well, eat something because you’re not resting, if you’re actually starving all day.
I:And consequences, do you mean yourself? Or did you say that? I forgot exactly what you said.
R:Consequence is basically what’s going to be the reaction to your actions for anything that you do. Speeding, what’s the consequence? Okay, you can get a ticket. Okay, yeah, so that means you got to pay money but you could hit somebody, worst consequence. You could say, well, speeding doesn’t really hurt anybody so it’s not really wrong, but it potentially can and the potential con of speeding is a lot greater than the pay off of I get there three minutes faster. So you just have to weigh your decision carefully.
I:Where would you say that you’ve gotten your moral views from?
R:Bible probably, family.

Yeah, the consequences of each action. You could say, well, speeding doesn’t really hurt anybody so it’s not really wrong, but it potentially can and the potential con of speeding is a lot greater than the pay off of I get there three minutes faster. So you just have to weigh your decision carefully.  Bible probably, family.
column591: The respondent expresses a strong inclination to help others with money, influenced by their religious beliefs and the consequences of actions, while acknowledging the difficulty of making moral decisions and the impact of social influences, particularly from family and scripture.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?  How do you know what’s right and wrong?
R:Whatever I think is right and what’s wrong.
I:Yeah?  How did you come to think those things?
R:I don't know.
I:What are some things that you think might make something right?
R:I don't know.
column584: Whatever I think is right and what’s wrong. I don't know. I don't know.
column585: The respondent expresses uncertainty about right and wrong, citing social influences from their family and teachers regarding cheating and lying, while also referencing religious beliefs that inform their views on morality, particularly the idea that God dictates what is right and wrong.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide what’s good or bad or right or wrong in life?
R:From my mother.  My mother was always open with me from a young age.  I knew a lot about the family, just about everything that was going on.  Nobody else knew, not even my older cousins.  So when I got around to talking to them about it, they’re like, “Wow.  You know a lot.  Wow.”  So I guess I’ve just been wise for a while, because of my mother.
I:In general, how easy or hard is it for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It depends on what the right and wrong is.  I’m not gonna lie, when it comes to smoking weed, it’s harder for me, because that’s what I like to do.  But now with my daughter, choosing between right and wrong, that’s simple.  I know what I have to do.  I know when I’m not being a good parent and when I am.
I:How do you know?
R:Say I’m out with my cousin and we’re on the corner, sitting at the park, smoking or something,  or I could be at my cousin’s house, rapping with them, and I ask my aunt, “Oh, can you watch Kamalia* while I run to the store real quick?”  I went to the store; I went to the store.  But now I’m sitting with my cousins and we’re smoking.  And she calls me, “Okay, Maya*, you got to come get her, because I’m going somewhere today.  I got to get ready.”  Okay, I’m on my way.  And I’m not on my way.  I’m not leaving for about another 15 minutes.  That’s when I know I’m being a bad parent.  I’m putting things before her.  I start feeling guilty and I got to go.  I just tell them I got to go, I can’t do this.  Got to go get my baby, and I zoom home.  It’s hard.  I think I’m doing a good job.
I:Do you think deciding between right and wrong’s gotten easier or harder in the last couple years, or has it stayed the same?
R:It’s been easier, because before, I didn’t care.  My mother told me I was going to be like that because whenever she used to tell me about myself, I would say, “I don’t care.  Okay, ma, I don’t care, I don’t care, I don’t care.”  As I got older, I started saying, “I don’t give a blah.”  That’s what I would do.  I actually was showing I didn’t care, really, and that’s how it was.  I was doing whatever I wanted to do.  I want to stay out at a friend’s house for a week, and that’s fine with their parents, then that’s what I was going to do.  It didn’t matter if my mother said yes or no.  That’s what I’m doing.  Doesn’t matter if she has something planned.  I’ve gotten a lot better.  I know how to put my priorities first.
I:What changed?
R:Just the whole being in the system.  That hurts, being in the system.  You don’t have control over your life, you feel like somebody’s controlling your life.  It was like, I don’t know what my next move is.  It’s whatever the judge decides is my next move.  All I knew is I’m having a baby, I got to get it together, because somebody’s watching me now.  I got to look after her.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  What is it about things that are right that make them right?  What is it about things that are wrong that make them wrong?
R:Maybe in some cases the people you’re hurting.  If you’re hurting people, if it’s right or wrong.  That’s a lot of thing with me and Cory*.  Right from wrong, that’s how I can look at it with his situation.  The wrong thing hurt me.  If he did the right thing, I wouldn’t have been hurt.
I:Do you think people can do something that is right that also hurts somebody?
R:Yeah.
I:How so?
R:Telling the truth.  That’s right, but the truth does hurt sometimes.
I:What about the other way around?  Do you think somebody can do something wrong that helps somebody?
R:Yeah.  That’s how it was a lot.  That’s what the robberies was about, with me and my cousin.  It was something wrong, but it was to help out at home.  We didn’t have any money.  My mother wanted rent money from everybody.  Nobody had a job.  He’s 28, no job.  I’m 17.  I’m trying to help out some type of way.  How can we get some money quick?  We were thinking about robbing somebody.  Just a lot of different things.  The wrong thing, but we’re trying to do the right thing.
I:Where would you say your moral views have come from?
R:My mother.

All I knew is I’m having a baby, I got to get it together, because somebody’s watching me now.  I got to look after her.  Maybe in some cases the people you’re hurting.  If you’re hurting people, if it’s right or wrong.  That’s a lot of thing with me and Cory*.  Right from wrong, that’s how I can look at it with his situation.  The wrong thing hurt me.  If he did the right thing, I wouldn’t have been hurt. Yeah. Telling the truth.  That’s right, but the truth does hurt sometimes. Yeah.  That’s how it was a lot.  That’s what the robberies was about, with me and my cousin.  It was something wrong, but it was to help out at home.  We didn’t have any money.  My mother wanted rent money from everybody.  Nobody had a job.  He’s 28, no job.  I’m 17.  I’m trying to help out some type of way.  How can we get some money quick?  We were thinking about robbing somebody.  Just a lot of different things.  The wrong thing, but we’re trying to do the right thing.  My mother.
column591: The respondent prioritizes taking care of her mother and herself with any newfound wealth, bases her moral decisions largely on her mother's teachings, struggles with right and wrong particularly in relation to parenting, acknowledges the complexity of moral situations influenced by social contexts, and ultimately believes that God's guidance and personal responsibility shape her moral views, while also recognizing the impact of poverty on societal issues.

column583:

R:Yes. If they found out what they would think about it, what, I guess society would think about it.

R:My parents.

R:School.

R:My parents or my conscience.

R:Not really.

R:Just general.

column585: The respondent primarily relies on their parents' opinions and their own conscience to make decisions about right and wrong, believes that societal norms have blurred moral boundaries, and chooses to abstain from drugs and alcohol partly due to family influences, particularly their grandfather's negative experiences with alcohol.
column586:
I:How do you decide in life or know what’s good or bad, right or wrong?
R:Talking to my parents, talking to my fiancée, my conscience, just knowing in my heart that, what would other people think of me if I do this, what is right.  Am I going to feel guilty if I do this, knowing in my heart that it’s wrong.  Stuff like that.
I:And, in general, do you think it’s easy or hard for you to decide that you’re doing the right thing, right and wrong things?
R:I think it’s pretty easy.  It’s either right or wrong, and you know it.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the last couple years you think?
R:Probably easier.
I:Easier?  Why?
R:The responsibility, knowing that there’s repercussions for things you do bad, and you don’t want to even get close to having to deal with that.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:To me it’s mostly myself, just my conscience knowing that I’m going to feel bad afterwards.
I:And where do you think that comes from, this conscience, you know, that somehow out of yourself, you feel like you know what’s right and wrong?
R:I think my parents had a lot to do with that when I was growing up, just not being a shame on yourself, a shame on your family, and knowing that, just teaching me from right or wrong from when I was younger.
I:Excuse me.  And your moral views, the way that you think that the world works in terms of right and wrong, where do you think that comes from?
R:Probably my parents, yeah.
column587: Talking to my parents, talking to my fiancée, my conscience, just knowing in my heart that, what would other people think of me if I do this, what is right.  Am I going to feel guilty if I do this, knowing in my heart that it’s wrong.  Stuff like that. I think it’s pretty easy.  It’s either right or wrong, and you know it. Probably easier. The responsibility, knowing that there’s repercussions for things you do bad, and you don’t want to even get close to having to deal with that.  To me it’s mostly myself, just my conscience knowing that I’m going to feel bad afterwards. I think my parents had a lot to do with that when I was growing up, just not being a shame on yourself, a shame on your family, and knowing that, just teaching me from right or wrong from when I was younger.  Probably my parents, yeah.
column588: The respondent emphasizes the importance of saving for their daughter and making responsible decisions influenced by their parents and conscience, while also acknowledging the need to adapt moral views to societal changes and expressing a desire to be a good father and combat racism in society.
column589:

R:What I feel.

R:It’s first instinct, it comes pretty quick if it’s something you got to think about that much, it’s probably wrong.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder for you in the last couple years?
R:It hasn’t gotten harder, probably stayed the same I never followed crowds or stuff like that so it hasn’t been harder.

R:Probably the same.
I:What do you think it is that actually makes something right or wrong?  Where certain things change your feelings, what is that?
R:I guess more or less brought up with.  My parents, grandparents, shaped stuff and pretty much everything is right or wrong as far as society and stuff.

R:I don’t know values, something like that.  Not really religious just what society would think, my parents would think.
I:You said your morals primarily came from your family primarily your parents and other sources.
R:My grandparents probably.

Not really religious just what society would think, my parents would think.  My grandparents probably.
column591: The respondent believes that decisions about money should honor the intentions of the deceased relative, prioritizing family needs such as home improvements and college savings, and they rely on their intuition and upbringing from parents and grandparents to determine right from wrong, emphasizing the importance of considering consequences and the influence of societal values over religious beliefs.

Something right to do is like always be a helping hand to some folks and not charging anybody any money to do anything, just, just, just helping other people that’s not able to do things.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I just, a lot of times it’s just I have a gut decision.  Not a gut decision, but a gut feeling but that’s based on how I was raised and you just know what’s right.  You don’t, you treat people fairly and you do, yeah, you treat people how you’d like to feel or how you’d like to be treated and you try to leave the world better than you found it.  That’s, really if you have those two rules, the golden rule and that one, my Dad’s always said, you try and leave the world better than you found it.  So as long as you have that, you can pretty much make any decision.  Is this gonna leave things worse or is it gonna make things better.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I’d say it’s pretty easy.  There’s always like people that can concoct like a situation that they’re like you know, what would you do here, and I think you have to sit there forever but, for the most part, like the decision is pretty easy.  Like as soon as we heard that somebody got shot in the street over, I’m like, well, I’m gonna get you out of there.  It’s my girlfriend.  And ah, that’s just the obvious decision.  That’s not like a right or wrong decision, it’s just like, well it’s not safe, you know?  So that comes first.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past few years?
R:Harder, because the decisions are more serious.  Like I have to not fight my girlfriend’s Dad about how he’s, I mean, this is just between us but he calls her a quitter for not doing pharmacy school anymore.  She can’t take it, she can’t stand it, it’s like just too stressful.  She says no one should go through that much stress to get C’s or B’s and then like she’s got to apply to schools, like an actual pharmacy school and she applied this year, which is a year early, but then she went to talk to somebody and they said that you probably won’t get in next year because it’s just so competitive so she wants to go into something that’s less competitive, still almost as lucrative and I don’t really care about money, but she kinda does, her family does definitely and so her Dad calls her a quitter.  Like I would never, like that’s immature and an awful thing but it’s my decision that I should stay out of it.  I talk to her about it, but I would never say something to him unless it became like, I mean, if she came to me crying, like it just bothers her.  If it was really killing her, then I would do something.
I:So how did you decide to sort of stay out of it, what was that decision process like?
R:That was, I actually talked it over with my parents.  And then to be honest, I was going to do something.  And I talked to them and they’re like you know what?  You can’t.  And I never even thought about that I, that it was not my place.  It was just like if she feels terrible I have to change it, you know?  And that’s what my job is.  To make her feel good, so I wanted to change it and I talked to them and they’re like, no, that’s not your place.
I:What is it do you think that makes something right or wrong?
R:It always depends on the situation but I mean, if it’s going to harm someone, cause problems for people, if it’s selfish, if it’s, I mean obviously in terms of like the environment, if you’re, like I always just say, if you’re leaving the world better than you found it then it’s a good thing.  If you’re making things worse, then it’s a bad things.
I:Well where do you think, we talked about this, but where do you think your moral views come from?
R:Mainly my parents, my family.  But not just my parents, my whole extended family because things always come up and if you have a good family that you really care about and respect, not only are you like, when an issue comes up, like I have some family members that love to talk about like all the political stuff and when things come up, you really do learn from them just by talking about it.  And other than that, like it’s, you think about this whole family that you have, every time a decision like that comes up, even if you don’t think about it, it’s in the back of your head that like, this is a world that not just I live in, that my little sister lives in and my cousin Brendan and I don’t want them to grow up with this going on, so that a lot of times helps me make a decision.
column590: I just, a lot of times it’s just I have a gut decision.  Not a gut decision, but a gut feeling but that’s based on how I was raised and you just know what’s right.  You don’t, you treat people fairly and you do, yeah, you treat people how you’d like to feel or how you’d like to be treated and you try to leave the world better than you found it.  That’s, really if you have those two rules, the golden rule and that one, my Dad’s always said, you try and leave the world better than you found it.  So as long as you have that, you can pretty much make any decision.  Is this gonna leave things worse or is it gonna make things better. I’d say it’s pretty easy.  There’s always like people that can concoct like a situation that they’re like you know, what would you do here, and I think you have to sit there forever but, for the most part, like the decision is pretty easy.  Like as soon as we heard that somebody got shot in the street over, I’m like, well, I’m gonna get you out of there.  It’s my girlfriend.  And ah, that’s just the obvious decision.  That’s not like a right or wrong decision, it’s just like, well it’s not safe, you know?  So that comes first. Harder, because the decisions are more serious.  Like I have to not fight my girlfriend’s Dad about how he’s, I mean, this is just between us but he calls her a quitter for not doing pharmacy school anymore.  She can’t take it, she can’t stand it, it’s like just too stressful.  She says no one should go through that much stress to get C’s or B’s and then like she’s got to apply to schools, like an actual pharmacy school and she applied this year, which is a year early, but then she went to talk to somebody and they said that you probably won’t get in next year because it’s just so competitive so she wants to go into something that’s less competitive, still almost as lucrative and I don’t really care about money, but she kinda does, her family does definitely and so her Dad calls her a quitter.  Like I would never, like that’s immature and an awful thing but it’s my decision that I should stay out of it.  I talk to her about it, but I would never say something to him unless it became like, I mean, if she came to me crying, like it just bothers her.  If it was really killing her, then I would do something. That was, I actually talked it over with my parents.  And then to be honest, I was going to do something.  And I talked to them and they’re like you know what?  You can’t.  And I never even thought about that I, that it was not my place.  It was just like if she feels terrible I have to change it, you know?  And that’s what my job is.  To make her feel good, so I wanted to change it and I talked to them and they’re like, no, that’s not your place.  It always depends on the situation but I mean, if it’s going to harm someone, cause problems for people, if it’s selfish, if it’s, I mean obviously in terms of like the environment, if you’re, like I always just say, if you’re leaving the world better than you found it then it’s a good thing.  If you’re making things worse, then it’s a bad things.  Mainly my parents, my family.  But not just my parents, my whole extended family because things always come up and if you have a good family that you really care about and respect, not only are you like, when an issue comes up, like I have some family members that love to talk about like all the political stuff and when things come up, you really do learn from them just by talking about it.  And other than that, like it’s, you think about this whole family that you have, every time a decision like that comes up, even if you don’t think about it, it’s in the back of your head that like, this is a world that not just I live in, that my little sister lives in and my cousin Brendan and I don’t want them to grow up with this going on, so that a lot of times helps me make a decision.
column591: The respondent expresses a strong desire to give back to their parents for all they have done, motivated by gratitude and a sense of responsibility, while also emphasizing that their moral compass is shaped by family values and the importance of treating others well, guided by their father's teachings and a desire to leave the world better than they found it.

column589:
I:So how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:It’s kind of scary sometimes because I don’t know.  I just try to look at what I’ve learned and the experiences I’ve been through to decide, but I still do learn things every day and encounter different things every day that I guess sometimes you didn’t know.  But I guess if I’m unsure, I might talk to someone close about it, maybe a friend that’s a little bit older than me and might know.
I:So in general, would you say it’s pretty easy or pretty hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:In general, I think it’s pretty easy.
I:And do you think it’s gotten easier or harder in the past couple years?
R:I think it’s gotten easier.  I think I’ve learned a lot more.
I:So what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong, like what’s the reason it’s right or wrong?
R:I think that has a lot to do with there are obvious things that are right and wrong and it’s just kind of something that everyone knows.  And there are some things where you have to just go with your instincts, I guess.  I don’t know what the reasoning is.  I never really thought about it.
I:Well, like in the situation with the woman who ordered the drink while she was pregnant, what was, would you think – I mean it just sounds like you were weighing a lot of different – you know your manager was saying one thing, your instinct was telling you a different thing, and the law was saying one thing.  So what do you think, in all those things, was right?  I mean there was also what she was doing, too, so there’s sort of four different things to decide on.
R:It was right for her, a good decision that if she was going to drink with her friends, a good idea that she only had one, even though I don’t agree with having anything.  The law isn’t always fair or right, but you do have to abide by it.  So I guess that’s why I was asking if it was illegal or not.  The reasoning for me to serve it to her is because I kind of had to, even though I didn’t agree with it.  I don’t know.
I:So some people talk about kind of consequences to other people, like if it hurts someone, or they talk about the law or kind of just what someone else, someone they trust, tells them or things like that.  So what do you think?  If you had to pick sort of among those things, what are the ways that you typically decide what’s right or wrong?  Is it based on any one of those?
R:I guess I would want to go to someone to see what they think about it, but from there, I still have to make my decision.  I’m not just going to say, oh, well, this person said this, so that’s how I’m going to think.  I think that it is a good idea to talk to someone about it and see how they feel and maybe they can bring out some positive or negative things about it that you think, and then I just feel I can get a little bit more out of it and make my decision.
I:And so do you make the decision on how it would affect you, how it would affect others?  What’s the –
R:Well, in that situation, I was basing my decision on not me at all, but her baby because we do see way too many things go wrong with children when they’re born because of what their parents do.  That’s who I was the most concerned about.
column590: It’s kind of scary sometimes because I don’t know.  I just try to look at what I’ve learned and the experiences I’ve been through to decide, but I still do learn things every day and encounter different things every day that I guess sometimes you didn’t know.  But I guess if I’m unsure, I might talk to someone close about it, maybe a friend that’s a little bit older than me and might know. In general, I think it’s pretty easy. I think it’s gotten easier.  I think I’ve learned a lot more.  I think that has a lot to do with there are obvious things that are right and wrong and it’s just kind of something that everyone knows.  And there are some things where you have to just go with your instincts, I guess.  I don’t know what the reasoning is.  I never really thought about it. It was right for her, a good decision that if she was going to drink with her friends, a good idea that she only had one, even though I don’t agree with having anything.  The law isn’t always fair or right, but you do have to abide by it.  So I guess that’s why I was asking if it was illegal or not.  The reasoning for me to serve it to her is because I kind of had to, even though I didn’t agree with it.  I don’t know. I guess I would want to go to someone to see what they think about it, but from there, I still have to make my decision.  I’m not just going to say, oh, well, this person said this, so that’s how I’m going to think.  I think that it is a good idea to talk to someone about it and see how they feel and maybe they can bring out some positive or negative things about it that you think, and then I just feel I can get a little bit more out of it and make my decision. Well, in that situation, I was basing my decision on not me at all, but her baby because we do see way too many things go wrong with children when they’re born because of what their parents do.  That’s who I was the most concerned about.
column591: The respondent prioritizes using a hypothetical inheritance to support their mother's healthcare needs and their sister's education, while they navigate moral decisions based on personal experiences, social influences from friends, and a sense of instinct, ultimately acknowledging the complexity of right and wrong in various situations, including the legality and ethics of serving alcohol to a pregnant woman.

column583:
I:Okay.  Um, where, you mentioned that you have a pretty clear view of right and wrong and that other people do, as well, in general.  Where do you think views of right and wrong come from?  You said from teachers and parents, is that right?
R:Mm-mm, yeah.
I:So, um, have your parents and teachers, you know, I don’t know if you can give me any examples of ways that they’ve been able to teach you right from wrong, or does it just kind of happen in every day life?
R:Well, like um, we have something called the DARE program.  And it’s like, like not do drugs and stuff like that.  So, that kinda tells kids what’s right and stuff.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or that makes something wrong?
R:Um,--
I:When you have to make a judgment about those things.
R:Ah.    I think something that would be right is something that’s not harming anybody in any way.  And something that’s wrong would be something that is.
I:Okay.  And when you say something that’s right is not harming anybody, does that include the person’s self, or just other people you mean?
R:Um, everybody.
column584: Mm-mm, yeah. Well, like um, we have something called the DARE program.  And it’s like, like not do drugs and stuff like that.  So, that kinda tells kids what’s right and stuff. Um,-- Ah.    I think something that would be right is something that’s not harming anybody in any way.  And something that’s wrong would be something that is. Um, everybody.
column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are clear, primarily influenced by parents and teachers, and they view actions as right if they do not harm anyone, while also acknowledging that morality can be seen as relative.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Mm, I guess if it would cause harm with people or if it would cause harm to me.
I:Okay.
R:Then it would be something bad and I wouldn’t do it.
I:Okay, alright is it generally easy for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Pretty much, yeah.
I:Pretty much okay.
R:Pretty easy.
I:Pretty easy, do you think it’s gotten easier or harder in these past couple of years?
R:It’s kind of stayed the same.
I:Pretty much, okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t know, (long pause) um, well  I guess if something can cause harm to you or other people then it’s something that’s wrong.  If it doesn’t then it’s, then I think it’s something good.
I:Okay are there some kinds of harm that are okay?
R:No.
I:No, any kind of harm.
R:Uh no.
I:Any kind of harm is wrong.
R:Yeah I think so.
I:So if you go to the doctor and he gives you a shot, he’s doing something wrong?
R:Well, that’s kind of interpreting it a little.
I:Okay, okay.
R:You need to look at the situation and then determine it for yourself.
I:Okay.
R:You might cause, shots don’t really hurt that much and if you’re getting a shot and it’s something that can help you because they inject something, some medicine into them then that’s good but like harm that would like hurt, hurt someone like emotionally, physically that sort of thing, not, not like pain like in a shot, that doesn’t really hurt people.
I:Okay, well you said.
R:Do you know what I mean?
I:Well I’m just trying to work with you here, I mean you said that it’s based on situations, you have to look at the situation, um are there some kind of guidelines you would use in looking at a situation?
R:Um, I don’t know, I’ve never thought like that.  (long pause) Like what do you mean by guidelines, like rules that I would follow to look at a situation?
I:Maybe, I mean, I mean how would, I mean if I was an alien from another planet and you were telling me that um giving somebody a shot is not wrong but shooting someone is wrong, and I don’t know if you think that is wrong, I’m not sure yet but, I mean how do I as an alien understand how you’re making that decision on what’s right and wrong?
R:Well, shooting someone with a gun could kill them but a shot doesn’t.
I:Okay, what if the shot actually does kill the person just because it’s an over injection or something like that?
R:Oh, well then you’d have to look more off the situation, what was in the shot that caused the person to die, was it an accident or was it intentional, stuff like that.
I:If it was intentional what would make it wrong?
R:Because the person died.
I:Because the person died.
R:Or they got hurt, sick etc.
I:Alright, are there, so which actions or are there any actions that are in themselves always wrong?
R:Killing people?
I:Killing people.
R:MmmHmm (yes)
I:Okay.
R:Well, I don’t know.  You’d have to look at the situation because, dang, um, I think, hmm, um, I don’t think there are any things that are always wrong.
I:Okay, how about rape?
R:Rape, oh yeah, yeah that would be one that is always wrong.  I didn’t think of it.
I:Alright so why is that wrong?
R:Because that person doesn’t want it, they don’t want to have sex with the person and that’s just fine.
I:But killing a person can be okay?
R:Well, if it’s in self defense then I guess that would be okay.
I:Okay um, from where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Um myself.
I:Yourself.
R:Yeah.
column587: Mm, I guess if it would cause harm with people or if it would cause harm to me. Then it would be something bad and I wouldn’t do it. Pretty much, yeah. Pretty easy. It’s kind of stayed the same.  I don’t know, (long pause) um, well  I guess if something can cause harm to you or other people then it’s something that’s wrong.  If it doesn’t then it’s, then I think it’s something good. No. Uh no. Yeah I think so. Well, that’s kind of interpreting it a little. You need to look at the situation and then determine it for yourself. You might cause, shots don’t really hurt that much and if you’re getting a shot and it’s something that can help you because they inject something, some medicine into them then that’s good but like harm that would like hurt, hurt someone like emotionally, physically that sort of thing, not, not like pain like in a shot, that doesn’t really hurt people. Do you know what I mean? Um, I don’t know, I’ve never thought like that.  (long pause) Like what do you mean by guidelines, like rules that I would follow to look at a situation? Well, shooting someone with a gun could kill them but a shot doesn’t. Oh, well then you’d have to look more off the situation, what was in the shot that caused the person to die, was it an accident or was it intentional, stuff like that. Because the person died. Or they got hurt, sick etc. Killing people? MmmHmm (yes) Well, I don’t know.  You’d have to look at the situation because, dang, um, I think, hmm, um, I don’t think there are any things that are always wrong. Rape, oh yeah, yeah that would be one that is always wrong.  I didn’t think of it. Because that person doesn’t want it, they don’t want to have sex with the person and that’s just fine. Well, if it’s in self defense then I guess that would be okay.  Um myself. Yeah.
column588: The respondent plans to bank the inheritance and use part of it for a car and insurance, believes that actions are right or wrong based on whether they cause harm to oneself or others, and holds firm moral views that are self-derived, asserting that societal acceptance does not dictate morality, while also expressing concerns about the influence of religion on government decisions.
column589:
I:Ok.  How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad and right and wrong in life?
R:I guess instinct, what I feel about it.
I:What you feel about it, ok.  Like is it easy or hard in general for you to decide what’s right and wrong?
R:Fairly easy.
I:Ok, and has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder for you over the last couple years?
R:I think no difference.
I:Ok, pretty much the same?
R:Yeah.
I:and have your views changed in the last couple years at all in any way about what’s right and wrong?
R:No.
I:Ok.  what is it that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um,
I:Like some people say it’s just feelings, like it feels right and then it’s right, other people say it’s consequences, what’s got bad results then it’s probably wrong.
R:Yeah, I would think the consequences of it.
I:Consequences are more important?  Like what about rules?  Like some people say that there’re just some things that are wrong, you should never steal, you should never cheat somebody…  Are there things that are absolutely wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:Could you give me examples of what you think those might be?
R:Murder, probably.
I:Right.  So even if it has good consequences you would say it’s…?
R:See, I’m not a bad person.
column590: I guess instinct, what I feel about it. Fairly easy. I think no difference. Yeah. No.  Um, Yeah, I would think the consequences of it. Yeah. Murder, probably. See, I’m not a bad person.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on their instincts to determine right from wrong, believes that consequences are crucial in moral decision-making, feels a moral obligation to help others, and would prioritize personal happiness when uncertain about decisions, while also acknowledging that some actions, like cheating, are wrong despite knowing they are wrong.

column583:
I:Okay.  And what, where do your own views of right and wrong come from do you think?
R:Mm, I,  probably my older siblings.  Cause they probably made some decisions.
I:Okay, yeah.  Okay so you feel like you learn a lot from them, or?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.  What ah, what do you, what do you think makes something right or wrong?

R:I don’t know.   Can you repeat the question, again?
I:Yeah.  Can like, when I was, we were talking about ah, you know what makes something right or wrong and, and ah, you know and where you sort of get your own ideas of right and wrong from, can you give like an example of you know maybe, how, of a point, you know something you decide, try to decide or figure out like what’s right or wrong, you know?
R:Like maybe um, like if like you have to do, like, say you have work to do or something, and then you want, and then you have like friends or a friend that like calls you up or something and like there’s a decision or whatever.
I:Gotcha.  Yeah.  And how would you decide what’s right or wrong to do in that situation, do you think?
R:Probably just, I’d probably just like finish my work then go play or something.

R:Cause, cause you, you probably had your work first so then you gotta get that done, cause, cause you probably were asked to do that first.
I:Right, right, right.  You probably, what?
R:You were asked to do that first.  So then you’d have to pretty much finish that.
I:Okay.  Asked by?
R:Probably a parent.
I:Okay.  Yeah.  And why ah, and why would you sort of respect that over the desire to just head out?
R:Cause they’re your parents.  I don’t know.
column584: Mm, I,  probably my older siblings.  Cause they probably made some decisions. Yeah. Mm, the outcome pretty much.  Like, like whatever, like it would be pretty much wrong if like you’re gonna hurt somebody and like if you’re like gonna do something, so yeah. I don’t know.   Can you repeat the question, again? Like maybe um, like if like you have to do, like, say you have work to do or something, and then you want, and then you have like friends or a friend that like calls you up or something and like there’s a decision or whatever. Probably just, I’d probably just like finish my work then go play or something. Cause, cause you, you probably had your work first so then you gotta get that done, cause, cause you probably were asked to do that first. You were asked to do that first.  So then you’d have to pretty much finish that. Probably a parent. Cause they’re your parents.  I don’t know.
column585: The respondent feels that right and wrong are largely determined by personal conscience and the outcomes of actions, influenced by their older siblings and parental guidance, while also noting a lack of peer pressure and a belief that societal clarity on morality has declined.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t know, I just know I guess.
I:You just know, well let’s step back.  Do you think that there are certain things that are right or wrong, or good or bad in life?
R:Yeah.
I:Alright, so as you go about things in your life, do you ever come across situations and decisions where you have to confront choices around the good and bad right or wrong?
R:Sometimes I guess.
I:So how do you go about figuring that out?  Or how do you know?  What goes into?
R:I don’t know, I guess I just know whether it’s like, whether I’m supposed to do it or not.
I:Okay, and how do you think you know that?
R:I don’t know, my mom and dad had always taught me, you know.
I:Okay so, it’s  your parents?
R:Yeah.
I:And…church?
R:Yeah.
I:Friends?  TV?  Anywhere else?  Is it hard to- is it easy or hard to decide between right and wrong, to know which one to pick?
R:I don’t think so.
I:It’s not hard?
R:Not for me.
I:It’s easy?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay, has it changed in the last two or three years, gotten easier or harder?
R:No.
I:M3:Pretty much the same.  Can you tell me of any specific situation fairly recently when you’ve confronted a decision about doing the right thing or the wrong thing? What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  Why is anything right or wrong to begin with?
R:I don’t know.  I guess it’s just the different ways people are raised up or taught.
I:Okay, are there, is right or wrong, are things objectively right or wrong regardless of what people think about ‘em?  Like is it always wrong- like is it just wrong to steal or to just hurt someone with no reason no matter what if anybody believes about that, it just is?
R:Mm hmm.
I:Now why is that?  It’s gotta be more than just how they were raised.
R:Yeah it’s because it’s somebody else’s stuff and-
I:Like the stealing.  Any what if somebody said “I don’t care I want to make it my stuff.”
R:It’s still theirs though (laughs).
I:So, is it wrong because it breaks the law of the government?
R:Yeah.
I:Is it- something other than- what if the government changed the law and said “If you’re powerful you can steal.”
R:But still by the Bible we’re not supposed to steal, so.
I:So that’s something new, the Bible teaches?  Do you what the government puts into law reflects?
R:Sometimes.
I:So ultimately, what’s right or wrong, does it come from just whatever you believe?  Whatever society says?  What the Bible teaches?  What God says?  What the consequences are?  What, what makes something right or wrong?
R:The Bible, what God says.
I:And that’s the most basic.
R:Mm hmm.
I:So if God commands something and somebody else doesn’t agree with it, you would ultimately say- I mean you wouldn’t be obnoxious about it- but you would ultimately say “Well, they’re wrong.  They’re not understanding the truth.”
R:Yeah, yeah.
column590: I don’t know, I just know I guess. Yeah. Sometimes I guess. I don’t know, I guess I just know whether it’s like, whether I’m supposed to do it or not. I don’t know, my mom and dad had always taught me, you know. Yeah. Yeah. I don’t think so. Not for me. Yeah. No.  I don’t know.  I guess it’s just the different ways people are raised up or taught. Mm hmm. Yeah it’s because it’s somebody else’s stuff and- It’s still theirs though (laughs). Yeah. But still by the Bible we’re not supposed to steal, so. Sometimes. The Bible, what God says. Mm hmm. Yeah, yeah.  The Bible, what God says. Mm hmm. Yeah, yeah.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on their parents' teachings and the Bible to discern right from wrong, finds it easy to make moral decisions, and believes in a moral responsibility to help others, asserting that ultimate truth comes from God rather than societal norms.

column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Just what I think.

R:Easy.

R:Um, (pause) harder and easier I guess.
I:Can you tell me a little bit, in what ways?
R:Um, well quitting school was a big one.  I wasn’t sure which way but I decided to make myself happy.  Um, easier now cause everything is just going good.  I mean everything, and I guess there’s no conflict in my life, so everything that I’m making decisions on is going good, so.

R:Mostly what you’re taught.

R:Cause she’s the one person I saw for everything I guess.

R:Um, I don’t know.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Probably my mom.
I:Any particular ideas of where she got her views?
R:Probably her mom and teaching.

column588: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on personal beliefs shaped by their mother's teachings, emphasizing the importance of happiness and family, while also acknowledging the complexity of moral judgments and the influence of social situations like natural disasters on the obligation to help others.

column583:
I:Uh-huh... And where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:My mom influenced me.
I:Your mom... Uh-huh... What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:What?
I:What do you think makes something right of wrong?  Why is something good and something bad?
R:Well, I think one should take it, I don't know... like it best suits him, I don't know... As it is more convenient to him, you know.  This is good for me, it's a good thing.  This is not too convenient, it's something bad.
I:Well, I can say... if I have a son, I can say, "going out with my boyfriend is good for me", but... then is that good, to leave my children like that?
R:No, because there I think you should talk in the relationship, talk with your children and ask them if they approve it, and if not it all depends as well.
I:So, in general, what makes something good or bad, in general?  You said, you have to approve of it, but other people have to approve of it too, or what?
R:Well, I think it's how each one feels about it.
I:Uh-huh.
R:If you feel good, you know, the rest doesn't matter.  If you feel bad then you have to consider other aspects of, you know, life and all that.
I:Uh-huh... How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Well, for example, you can see in other people.  Consequences that you see in other people too.
I:Consequences... Uh-huh... Can you give me an example?
R:Well, there are people at school that skip classes, they don't go to class.  So they think oh well, I'm with my friends, or nothing is going to happen.  But they start to figure out, as time goes by... and when they get to... I've known people that get to the last grade, senior year and then they realize that what they've been doing is bad and sometimes they aren't able to graduate, or something like that.

column585: The respondent makes decisions based on advice from their mother and teachers, feels confident in their ability to resist peer pressure regarding drugs and alcohol, believes that many people know right from wrong but choose to ignore it due to social influences, and attributes their moral views to their mother's influence while emphasizing the importance of considering the consequences of actions.

column589:
I:So how do you normally decide or know what’s good or bad or right or wrong in life?
R:I don’t know.  To be honest, because all of this stuff has been going on in the world, I’ve been getting kind of scared.
I:Of what?
R:I don’t know.  Because like I hear people talk and – about the world coming to an end and that scares me.
I:So it scares you.  What does that have to do with the way you think about right and wrong or good and bad?
R:Because I’m – I want to do better, you know.  I don’t want to be in hell burning up.  I don’t want to be.  I know I probably sound crazy, but I don’t want to be there.  I want to be, you know, as they like to call it, “paradise,” you know.  So if it’s – if I don’t think that it’s something that God would want, I try not to do it.
I:OK.  So in general, how easy or hard is it for you to decide what’s right and wrong in life?
R:It’s not hard at all.  It’s not hard, I just think about it.  Or if I’m having trouble I’ll call my mom and ask her to help me out with it, like what does she think.  And if I can’t decide and she has an idea I’ll go with what she says.
I:So do you feel like deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or harder in the last few years or has it stayed the same?
R:Got easier, you know, I grew up.
I:It’s gotten easier in what way?
R:Before like I wouldn’t know what’s right or what’s wrong, too tough, or even if I did, you know, I didn’t care.  But, you know, now that I’m growing up, I guess I’m maturing more, and it’s easier, it’s like common sense, don’t do this, don’t do that.
I:OK.  So would you say your views about right and wrong has changed over the last few years or no?
R:Yeah.
I:In what ways?
R:For example, like – I’m trying to think of an example.  Like people that can say, “keeping it real.”  Keeping it real could hurt peoples feelings.  And before I didn’t care, I just would say it.  Well, now I’m more cautious, you know.
I:Is there any particular reason why you’re more cautious?
R:No, I don’t know.  I just changed.  I don’t know.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t know.
I:What about like rules or laws or consequences or how it feels or God or something else, like any of those things are what makes something right or wrong?
R:Yeah, no, you’re right.
I:No.  I mean which ones of those things do you think about, any of those things?
R:Well, God, you know, the law.  I don’t want to be sitting in jail, that has a lot to do with it.  Those two things.  Just those two things.
I:Why those things in particular?
R:Because I don’t want to do any wrong – anything wrong, you know, that I have to worry about not getting caught.  And if I do get caught, I don’t want to be sitting in jail for doing something stupid that I could have avoided.  Like even if I didn’t get caught, I still have to live with that.  And God watches everything that we do, you know.
I:What do you think would happen, like what kinds of things happen if you do wrong things?
R:What do you mean?
I:Like you were saying that you don’t want to worry about going to jail and stuff, and then like you know, so you don’t want to worry about other things happening when you do wrong things, what kinds of things happen, maybe wrong things?
R:I know a lot of people with guns, and stuff like that, and they just don’t care.  Everybody I know, not everybody, but just about everybody I know they’ve been in jail at least once or twice.  And I don’t want a life like that.  And even I don’t want my daughter growing up like that.  I don’t want her looking and, you know, thinking that’s OK.  Because it’s not OK.  So I have her to think about.  It’s not just me anymore.
I:What about your own ideas about right and wrong, where do you think they come from?
R:Some of it comes – some of them, like me and mom will talked about that and ask where it comes from.  Like I just listen to my mom say stuff, now that I think about it, I’m like oh, she’s actually right.  But some of it, you know, it’s just common sense.  A 12-year-old shouldn’t be holding a gun, or you shouldn’t be doing drugs, it shouldn’t be okay – like I was reading the newspaper a couple of weeks ago, I don’t know if you read it about the Latin king and gangs, bringing little kids into it.  They’re born in – because their parents are, you know, in the gang Latin King order, and they’re automatically born into it.  So they don’t have to fight over anything to get into it, but now they’re in the gang and they’re stuck, you know.  That’s wrong.  It shouldn’t be like that.
I:Why do you think it shouldn’t be like that?
R:Because they didn’t have a choice.  And even if they did, they’re just kids.
column590: I don’t know.  To be honest, because all of this stuff has been going on in the world, I’ve been getting kind of scared. I don’t know.  Because like I hear people talk and – about the world coming to an end and that scares me. Because I’m – I want to do better, you know.  I don’t want to be in hell burning up.  I don’t want to be.  I know I probably sound crazy, but I don’t want to be there.  I want to be, you know, as they like to call it, “paradise,” you know. Or if I’m having trouble I’ll call my mom and ask her to help me out with it, like what does she think.  And if I can’t decide and she has an idea I’ll go with what she says.
