Just those two things. Because I don’t want to do any wrong – anything wrong, you know, that I have to worry about not getting caught.  And if I do get caught, I don’t want to be sitting in jail for doing something stupid that I could have avoided.  Like even if I didn’t get caught, I still have to live with that.  And God watches everything that we do, you know. What do you mean? I know a lot of people with guns, and stuff like that, and they just don’t care.  Everybody I know, not everybody, but just about everybody I know they’ve been in jail at least once or twice.  And I don’t want a life like that.  And even I don’t want my daughter growing up like that.  I don’t want her looking and, you know, thinking that’s OK.  Because it’s not OK.  So I have her to think about.  It’s not just me anymore.  Some of it comes – some of them, like me and mom will talked about that and ask where it comes from.  Like I just listen to my mom say stuff, now that I think about it, I’m like oh, she’s actually right.  But some of it, you know, it’s just common sense.  A 12-year-old shouldn’t be holding a gun, or you shouldn’t be doing drugs, it shouldn’t be okay – like I was reading the newspaper a couple of weeks ago, I don’t know if you read it about the Latin king and gangs, bringing little kids into it.  They’re born in – because their parents are, you know, in the gang Latin King order, and they’re automatically born into it.  So they don’t have to fight over anything to get into it, but now they’re in the gang and they’re stuck, you know.  That’s wrong.  It shouldn’t be like that. Because they didn’t have a choice.  And even if they did, they’re just kids.
column591: The respondent prioritizes using a hypothetical inheritance to pay off their mother's bills and secure their daughter's future, driven by gratitude for their mother's sacrifices, while also expressing a growing reliance on religious beliefs to guide their understanding of right and wrong, influenced by fears of moral consequences and the desire to avoid a negative legacy for their child.

column583:
I:Okay.  Um, do you have, where do you think your own views of right and wrong come from?  I mean you said it’s where we’re raised, on, on our environment and so on.  Your own views of right and wrong?  Come from?
R:Um, I think they, they kind of come from like  maybe the, okay. Um, maybe they just come from like your perspective I guess.
I:So like, your friends, your parents, your church, whatever.
R:Like I think they’re influenced by like everything around you like I think first you’re influenced by your parents, so you only like think that one way of thinking, but then once you like talk to other people and you like see other things I think like that one opinion is like shaped and like it kind of changes from the first thing you thought.
column584: Um, I think they, they kind of come from like  maybe the, okay. Um, maybe they just come from like your perspective I guess. Like I think they’re influenced by like everything around you like I think first you’re influenced by your parents, so you only like think that one way of thinking, but then once you like talk to other people and you like see other things I think like that one opinion is like shaped and like it kind of changes from the first thing you thought.
column585: The respondent often grapples with moral dilemmas, influenced primarily by their parents' strict rules and the social acceptance of certain behaviors, leading them to sometimes justify actions like drinking or disobeying rules by considering the consequences and the fact that "everyone is doing it."
column586:
I:And you drive around with them.  I have some questions about morality.  Right, wrong, good bad, um, how, um, how do you go about deciding moral issues for yourself?  What informs how you think about good and bad and right and wrong and stuff?
R:Uh, probably just my parents influence.  I guess.
I:Do you think you reflect pretty much what they believe or have taught you?
R:Yeah.
I:Uh-huh.  Okay.  In general is it hard for you to know in different situations what is right and wrong to do and to be and think or do you pretty much know right and wrong?
R:No, I think I pretty much know right and wrong.  I’d say if I picked wrong I usually know, but,
I:You know when you’re doing the wrong thing.
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.  What about in, in that, um, when that happened, when you know right and wrong and you’re trying to decide what to do, is that a hard thing, or is it pretty much straight forward, like what you’re deciding about, what you’re going to do?
R:Uh, it probably depends on the situation I guess.  The consequences.
I:Okay.  Um, so, um, this whole idea of right and wrong, certain things that are wrong, bad, evil, some things are good, right, true, just, worthy, whatever.  That’s pretty common.  I mean not everyone lives up to it, but do you, what do you, what is it that makes anything right or wrong?  Where does right or wrong even come from?
R:Uh, I guess it comes from how you’re raised I guess.
I:Okay what if people are raised really differently?  Do they each have a separate morality?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay, so if somebody was in a really lousy, screwed up family, and their parents raised them, you need to cheat all you can, and steal whenever you have the chance without getting caught, and
R:Well if that was what I was told all the time growing up I would probably think that too.
I:Okay, but would you say that they’re wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:That those things are wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:That they’re misled?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay, so you have some standard that enables you to judge them as wrong, even though they think that way.
R:Yeah.
I:And where does that standard come from?  What makes them wrong even though they think that it isn’t?
R:Um, well because I think there’s some kind of overall moral standard and they’re not, which I would say that I live by more, more closely, and they’re kind of far away from that radar.
I:And is that overall moral standard, um, society’s invention?
R:Yeah.
I:Or is it just the way things are, does it come from God, where does it come from?
R:I guess it’s, I guess it’s society.  I mean I think that, that as time progresses or whatever it changes.  Depending on, I don’t know.
I:Is it possible that society on the earth could evolve so that murder is okay?  Stealing is okay?  And that would make it okay?
R:I mean not in my mind, it couldn’t, but, probably, I mean, 1000 years ago or whatever they probably didn’t think that having sex before marriage was okay and they probably didn’t think, well not the same as murder, but surely like, in their minds it was up there and people don’t give a second thought to it.
column587: Uh, probably just my parents influence.  I guess. Yeah. No, I think I pretty much know right and wrong.  I’d say if I picked wrong I usually know, but, Yeah. Uh, it probably depends on the situation I guess.  The consequences.  Uh, I guess it comes from how you’re raised I guess. Yeah. Well if that was what I was told all the time growing up I would probably think that too. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Um, well because I think there’s some kind of overall moral standard and they’re not, which I would say that I live by more, more closely, and they’re kind of far away from that radar. Yeah. I guess it’s, I guess it’s society.  I mean I think that, that as time progresses or whatever it changes.  Depending on, I don’t know. I mean not in my mind, it couldn’t, but, probably, I mean, 1000 years ago or whatever they probably didn’t think that having sex before marriage was okay and they probably didn’t think, well not the same as murder, but surely like, in their minds it was up there and people don’t give a second thought to it.
column588: The respondent primarily makes decisions influenced by their parents' teachings, recognizes the importance of consequences in moral choices, and feels a sense of guilt when cheating, while also acknowledging that they engage in underage drinking despite knowing their parents disapprove.
column589:
I:Well like when you’re trying to, how do you normally decide then what’s good or bad or right or wrong in life?
R:Um, I guess I mean I ask my friend’s opinion but in the end I probably go back to the morals that I learned when I was little, that whole thing.
I:So in general do you think it’s hard for you to make those decisions?
R:Yeah, I think it is hard.  I think it’s gotten easier for me-
I:As you’ve get older?
R:As I’ve gotten older.  And gotten more my feet on the ground and seen other people’s mistakes.
column590: Um, I guess I mean I ask my friend’s opinion but in the end I probably go back to the morals that I learned when I was little, that whole thing. Yeah, I think it is hard. column591: The respondent primarily relies on the moral values learned in childhood and the advice of friends and parents when making decisions, acknowledging the difficulty of acting on the right choice, while also recognizing the importance of consequences and the varying moral standards across cultures.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong now?
R:Just ‘cause other people doin’ it don’t mean you have to do it too, I think.
I:So how do you normally decide what’s right and wrong?  So it’s not based on what other people are doin’ for you?
R:No, I just sit there and think about everything.  I just decide.
I:Is it generally easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Easy.
I:It’s pretty easy?
R:Yeah.
I:And has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past couple of years?
R:Probably harder, ‘cause there’s more stuff I… since you get older.
I:Have your views changed at all in the past couple of years?
R:No.
I:For you what is it that makes something right or wrong?
R:I guess if you already know what is right you can know the wrong.
I:But is it rules or consequences or how it feels?
R:Consequences.
I:Consequences is what makes something wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:And what kind of consequences would make something wrong?
R:Prison, jail, stuff like that.
I:You’re talkin’ about legal consequences?
R:Oh yeah.
I:Any other consequences that might make something wrong?
R:I don’t think so.
I:Where do you think you’ve gotten your moral views from?
R:My parents probably.
column590: Just ‘cause other people doin’ it don’t mean you have to do it too, I think. No, I just sit there and think about everything.  I just decide. Easy. Yeah. Probably harder, ‘cause there’s more stuff I… since you get older. No.  I guess if you already know what is right you can know the wrong. Consequences. Yeah. Prison, jail, stuff like that. Oh yeah. I don’t think so.  My parents probably.
column591: The respondent plans to save half of an inheritance and buy practical items like car repairs and clothing, believes moral decisions are based on personal reflection rather than social influence, attributes their moral views to their parents, and prefers to seek advice from trusted adults when unsure about right and wrong.

column583:
I:And where do you think your own views of right and wrong come from? Like what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong, or good or bad?
R:I think it’s mostly from like what I’ve seen people do and the mistakes I’ve seen other people make and like how it will affect my own life, well- being or the well being of the people directly surrounding me.
I:And can you give any examples of like times you’ve decided, or things you’ve seen, like mistakes you’ve seen people make or anything like that?
R:Not really, no, not in my head.
I:What kind of stuff do you think would be wrong, like if you saw somebody involved in it?

Like I said like in that whole wedding, that whole marriage thing, that cheating seems more appealing than actually staying with that person, so even though they know it’s wrong, they’ll still do it just because they won’t, you know they’re selfish maybe and they want to do whatever they want. I, like I said I try to follow like my influences, my parents, church. Oh, like even like the whole cheating thing going on, uh, you know my parents have been married for 36 years, and they’ve instilled the fact that you know marriage is something that should be sacred and should be held and you know cheating isn’t the way to go.  Cheating is a wrong thing.
column585: The respondent relies on their instincts for decision-making, influenced by their parents and church teachings, while expressing concern that many people today have lost a sense of right and wrong due to selfishness, and they feel guilty about minor transgressions like cursing, which they attribute to their upbringing.

column583:
I:Uh-huh, Uh-huh, okay. Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:My religion.  Really my religion and how I feel, I think, I’m a very independent person, not, let me talk more about when it comes to my life, so, I just think I’m saying, you know, when it comes to ideas, I have really, I can stand on my own feet, I don’t lean on anybody, I think it really comes from my religion, though.  I think it comes from the fact that it tells you in the bible about what’s wrong and what’s right.  And you have to, I have to, you have to, people base their lives on their religions or if you don’t have religion, you base your life on that but, mine comes from my religion and it comes from the way I’ve been raised, which was by my religion.  And I think if I wasn’t raised like that, you could still tell what’s good and bad, you know what I mean?
I:Uh-huh, why do you think that?
R:Because you, you can, it’s not that hard to, to decide what’s good and what’s not.

Really my religion and how I feel, I think, I’m a very independent person, not, let me talk more about when it comes to my life, so, I just think I’m saying, you know, when it comes to ideas, I have really, I can stand on my own feet, I don’t lean on anybody, I think it really comes from my religion, though. column585: The respondent believes that people have lost a clear sense of right and wrong, attributing their own moral compass to their religious upbringing, while acknowledging their past wrong actions and the influence of friends in making decisions about conflict.
column586:
R:I already know.
I:How do you know?
R:Cuz it been instilled, instilled in me, since I was a kid.  You like, I think everybody knows who’s, what’s good from bad.  They should, I mean, there’s no reason you shouldn’t know that.
I:How was it instilled in you?
R:Cuz she taught me that since I was young.
I:You’re talking about your grandma?
R:Uh-hmm.
I:No, okay.  So overall, what do you think ultimately makes something right or wrong?
R:The outcome of it.
I:Okay, give me an example of what you mean.
R:Like if you know, if you know you’re in a building, and you’re playing with matches, you know what I’m saying? And the building catch on fire, that’s the outcome of that.  You know what I’m saying, you just don’t play with matches.  I mean, that’s just the outcome, you know what’s right and wrong.  Playing with matches is wrong, I mean, and I, I can’t even say that.  Cuz playing with matches is not wrong.  If you’re an adult, you can play with matches, but if you’re in a building and they got a whole bunch of bottles of chlorine, not chlorine, gasoline in it, and you playin with matches, that’s just stupid, you know, it’s wrong.  So, I mean, anybody should be able to tell what’s, difference between right and wrong.
I:What if um, let’s say, let’s say for instance you were doing something that somebody might think is wrong but it has no negative outcome on anybody, you know it has an advantage for you, maybe you, I don’t know, lied or something like that, but it doesn’t have any seeming negative outcomes, is it wrong then, or?
R:Um, I mean, I really don’t know, like, if I did something and somebody else thought it was wrong and I didn’t think it was wrong.  It really depends on like what, what it, what it was, like I can’t really give you like an answer to that.  It depends on what it was.

Cuz playing with matches is not wrong.  If you’re an adult, you can play with matches, but if you’re in a building and they got a whole bunch of bottles of chlorine, not chlorine, gasoline in it, and you playin with matches, that’s just stupid, you know, it’s wrong. Um, I mean, I really don’t know, like, if I did something and somebody else thought it was wrong and I didn’t think it was wrong.  It really depends on like what, what it, what it was, like I can’t really give you like an answer to that.  It depends on what it was.
column588: The respondent expresses a strong desire to support their grandmother by using a hypothetical inheritance to pay off her house, emphasizes that their understanding of right and wrong has been instilled by their grandmother, and believes that moral obligations exist to help others, while also recognizing the importance of family and a purpose in life centered around serving God.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:You just know what’s good and what’s bad.
I:You just know?
R:I mean, some things I do that’s bad but I know they’re bad. I guess anything I know I’d do that society would label as bad, I think I’d know it’s bad, I just don’t care.
I:Can you think of a time when you were confused or unsure of what was right and wrong?
R:No.
I:In general, how easy or hard is it for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Not hard.
I:Not hard?
R:No.
I:So do you think deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or harder over the last couple of years.
R:Easier, way easier.
I:How come?
R:Well, you don’t have to worry about what people would think. What you choose, if they were right or to become more aware, you know what I mean? Because a few years ago, I’d been at school so I mean if something’s wrong I care.  If it’s wrong then I care.
I:So let’s see, have your views on right and wrong changed at all in the last couple of years?
R:No, I don’t think so.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t know.
I:Let’s see, what do you think is it like, maybe rules or laws or consequences, how it feels, God’s will?
R:Yeah, consequences.
I:Consequences?
R:Consequences, yeah.
I:What kinds of consequences do you think makes something wrong?
R:Well, if you get in trouble for doing it, I guess it’s wrong. When I guess it’s wrong, society is going to view it as wrong.
I:Do you think there are things that are wrong that you wouldn’t necessarily have consequence for?
R:I’m trying to think of an example. But I’m going to say yes. But on one thing I’m going to say, probably yeah. I can’t tell you anything.
I:What about…like what if someone could do something wrong and not get caught? What do you think about that? Would that still be wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:How come?
R:Because it’s wrong. If it’s wrong, it’s wrong. Just because you don’t get caught doesn’t mean it is not wrong anymore.
I:What if someone did something wrong that didn’t hurt anyone?
R:Maybe it’s good.
I:Do you think that’d still be wrong?
R:Oh, it would still be wrong, yeah.
I:So where do you say your ideas of right and wrong, your morals, come from?
R:From where…I guess from where I was raised what I think, my personal opinion of things.

I guess anything I know I’d do that society would label as bad, I think I’d know it’s bad, I just don’t care. No. Not hard. No. Easier, way easier. Well, you don’t have to worry about what people would think. What you choose, if they were right or to become more aware, you know what I mean? Because a few years ago, I’d been at school so I mean if something’s wrong I care.  If it’s wrong then I care. No, I don’t think so.  I don’t know. Yeah, consequences. Consequences, yeah. Well, if you get in trouble for doing it, I guess it’s wrong. When I guess it’s wrong, society is going to view it as wrong. I’m trying to think of an example. But I’m going to say yes. But on one thing I’m going to say, probably yeah. I can’t tell you anything. Yeah. Because it’s wrong. If it’s wrong, it’s wrong. Just because you don’t get caught doesn’t mean it is not wrong anymore. Maybe it’s good. Oh, it would still be wrong, yeah.  From where…I guess from where I was raised what I think, my personal opinion of things.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on their religious beliefs as a guiding factor in decision-making, stating that they would choose to follow what God or scripture dictates as right, while also acknowledging the influence of their upbringing and personal opinions on moral judgments.

column583:
I:So where would you say your ideas of right and wrong come from, then?
R:My parents and like my family and stuff that I spend a lot of time around when I was younger.
I:You mean including grandparents?
R:Mm-mm, yeah.
I:So, what do you think, what it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I mean, I don’t really know, I mean, I just, like I said, it’s from what I’ve heard all my life from my parents, you know, you don’t do this, that’s just—
I:Like, what don’t you do?
R:Like you know, you never do drugs, and all this stuff, you know.  You don’t smoke, you know, when you’re with someone, you’re “yes sir”, you’re polite.  Everything like that, you know, that’s what I’ve always heard, cause that’s how I’ve seen my parents act and stuff, my parents don’t smoke, they don’t do drugs, they don’t drink or nothing like, my Dad, he’ll have a beer or something with a friend or something, but he doesn’t drink to get drunk or nothing, they’ll have a beer or two, but then he doesn’t go out and drive or nothing, it’s usually at the house or it’s usually at like a party or something like at a friend’s house or something that we’re going to be there for quite a while and my Mom, she usually doesn’t and then she, my dad never, I’ve never seen him do anything like drunk driving or anything like that, I mean, I’ve just always, my ideal comes from what I’ve seen and heard my parents do and say and everything.
I:So, most of the time you’re pretty sure you know what’s the right or wrong thing?
R:Yeah.
I:Some of the time you’re unsure?
R:Yeah.
column584: My parents and like my family and stuff that I spend a lot of time around when I was younger. Mm-mm, yeah. I mean, I don’t really know, I mean, I just, like I said, it’s from what I’ve heard all my life from my parents, you know, you don’t do this, that’s just— Like you know, you never do drugs, and all this stuff, you know.  You don’t smoke, you know, when you’re with someone, you’re “yes sir”, you’re polite.  Everything like that, you know, that’s what I’ve always heard, cause that’s how I’ve seen my parents act and stuff, my parents don’t smoke, they don’t do drugs, they don’t drink or nothing like, my Dad, he’ll have a beer or something with a friend or something, but he doesn’t drink to get drunk or nothing, they’ll have a beer or two, but then he doesn’t go out and drive or nothing, it’s usually at the house or it’s usually at like a party or something like at a friend’s house or something that we’re going to be there for quite a while and my Mom, she usually doesn’t and then she, my dad never, I’ve never seen him do anything like drunk driving or anything like that, I mean, I’ve just always, my ideal comes from what I’ve seen and heard my parents do and say and everything. Yeah. Yeah.
column585: The respondent generally feels confident about distinguishing right from wrong, attributing their moral compass to their parents' teachings, while acknowledging that they sometimes engage in behaviors they know are wrong, such as drinking with friends, but they prioritize respect for their parents and avoid actions that would upset them.
column586:
I:I’m interested in how you think about morality, good and bad, right and wrong, how to live.  How do you decide, how do you think about those things or how do you decide about them.
R:How do I decide like what’s right and wrong?
I:Yeah.
R:Lot of it has to do with my parents and how I was raised and everything.  I was raised, you know, try to be good, try to stay out of trouble, though every now and then it sort of backfires on me, but not too often anymore.  But I think a lot of that had to do with the age I was and everything like that.  I’ve tried to get older and a little more mature.
I:How would you describe how you were raised?  When it comes to morality.
R:Yeah, just very different, rights and wrongs, not really too much gray area in between, “well it could be…” you know.  I really can’t think of a way to really define it, but…
I:So what are things that are definitely in your house right or wrong?
R:Right, I always, be polite, you know.  Do what you’re supposed do, do what you’re told, help somebody out if they need help or somethin’ like that.  Wrong’s just, you know don’t be out in drugs, drinkin’, smokin’, anything like that.
I:What’s wrong with those things?
R:They just never, my mom’s never liked smokin’ or nothin’ like that.  Like my mom’s whole side of the family does and she never really has liked that at all.  Drinkin’ and just never really had a lot to do with that.  My dad, he’ll drink beer every now and then, but he don’t just sit around the house and get completely drunk all the time or nothin’ like that.  I’ve never seen my dad get drunk, I’ve seen him drink a few beers with his buddies, but that’s it.  I can only think of twice when he’s had more than just one beer at the house, just kind of sittin’ around, and that’s it.
I:Let me just put it this way, let’s suppose you wanted to push your parents on this.  I agree with this but tell me why.  What would the answer be?
R:They’d probably say cause that’s how we was raised, that’s how we were taught, somethin’ like that probably—
I:--but let’s suppose you were raised to believe you should never ever drink dr. pepper.  You might reach a point where you’d say “I know you were taught that, but there’s no reason…”
R:yeah.  I don’t really know.
I:So if you had to back it all the way up to sort of the ultimate basis for things, where you would go is to…god?  The bible?
R:Yeah.
I:Cause some people would say, that’s not it, that’s wrong, I mean, all it is is say, consequences, if somethin’ hurts somebody, then it’s wrong, but it has nothin’ to do with the ten commandments.
R:Yeah.
I:What do you think of that?
R:I mean if it’s wrong, you know it’s wrong, or at least you should know it’s wrong.  I just, I mean, conscious-wise, you shouldn’t be able to do it and it not just tear you up.
I:So do you think that people have consciences that are sort of accurately tuned to know when they’re doin’ the—
R:--not anymore!  Not a whole lot.  I mean, there’s quite a few people out there, I’m not tryin’ to generalize.  There’s a lot of people out there that really do, but it’s that, you know 1/10 of a % that makes everybody look bad, you know?
I:Okay.
R:And it’s all the bad stuff you hear about, you never hear about the guy that did this, did this good, or helped this person.  All you hear about is the person that robbed this or destroyed this or whatever.
I:So would you say you think most people are good?
R:A lot of people, yes.  I mean, especially ‘cause when I worked you know in Advance, you know you’re workin’ with customers, you had a lot of people that would come in there that were really genuine, you know.  You could just tell, I mean they would talk to you, tell you what was goin’ on.  You’d stand there and talk to somebody for an hour or better.  And then some of ‘em would just come in there and they’d catch you with your back turned and their buddy would come up there and talk to you, keep you busy, they’d go back there and get what they wanted and leave, and that was just…

I was raised, you know, try to be good, try to stay out of trouble, though every now and then it sort of backfires on me, but not too often anymore.  But I think a lot of that had to do with the age I was and everything like that.  I’ve tried to get older and a little more mature. Yeah, just very different, rights and wrongs, not really too much gray area in between, “well it could be…” you know.  I really can’t think of a way to really define it, but… Right, I always, be polite, you know.  Do what you’re supposed do, do what you’re told, help somebody out if they need help or somethin’ like that.  Wrong’s just, you know don’t be out in drugs, drinkin’, smokin’, anything like that. They just never, my mom’s never liked smokin’ or nothin’ like that.  Like my mom’s whole side of the family does and she never really has liked that at all.  Drinkin’ and just never really had a lot to do with that. I’ve never seen my dad get drunk, I’ve seen him drink a few beers with his buddies, but that’s it.  I can only think of twice when he’s had more than just one beer at the house, just kind of sittin’ around, and that’s it. They’d probably say cause that’s how we was raised, that’s how we were taught, somethin’ like that probably— yeah.  I don’t really know.  Yeah. Yeah. There’s a lot of people out there that really do, but it’s that, you know 1/10 of a % that makes everybody look bad, you know? And it’s all the bad stuff you hear about, you never hear about the guy that did this, did this good, or helped this person.  All you hear about is the person that robbed this or destroyed this or whatever. A lot of people, yes.  I mean, especially ‘cause when I worked you know in Advance, you know you’re workin’ with customers, you had a lot of people that would come in there that were really genuine, you know.  You could just tell, I mean they would talk to you, tell you what was goin’ on.  You’d stand there and talk to somebody for an hour or better.  And then some of ‘em would just come in there and they’d catch you with your back turned and their buddy would come up there and talk to you, keep you busy, they’d go back there and get what they wanted and leave, and that was just…
column588: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on the moral teachings instilled by their parents, emphasizing a clear distinction between right and wrong, which is influenced by their upbringing and religious beliefs, particularly the Ten Commandments, while also expressing a desire to enjoy life and help others when in need.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good or bad, or wrong or right in life?  How do you go about figuring out moral things?
R:What do you mean, by like, at this point now, it’s just like “‘Hey, let’s do this!’ ‘Dude, that’s not right, we shouldn’t be doing that.’”  It’s almost like “Hey, I could do this or do this…well this is wrong.” It’s kind of learned through development of you know, 22 years of stuff, and the way my beliefs are and the way I was raised and stuff like that.  “This is right, this is wrong.”
I:So you have a pretty clear sense of what’s right and wrong?
R:Fairly well.  Most of the time.
I:And so it sounds like sort of moral decision making and moral knowledge is pretty straightforward?
R:Pretty cut and dry.  It just comes naturally, I guess, it could be best put.
I:What is it do you think that makes something right or wrong?
R:Outside of what the rules are…
I:I mean really right or wrong, not just the law.
R:It goes back like I said to how you were raised, the morals you were raised with, stuff like that.
I:But some people, but people are raised all different.  Does that mean morality is all different?
R:Yeah, I think…
I:If somebody was raised in a completely different wacko family and they taught them “Steal and beat people up,” that would be right?
R:In their minds.
I:What about in reality?
R:It’s not, no, it’s not in reality.
I:Are there things in reality that are right or wrong no matter what anybody thinks about them?
R:I would guess so.  Well, I … That’s a really good question.  I mean, there’s no claims well like murder and stuff come to mind, but then again, when you think about some of these other countries, it’s not…, I really don’t know how to answer that.  I really don’t.
column590: What do you mean, by like, at this point now, it’s just like “‘Hey, let’s do this!’ ‘Dude, that’s not right, we shouldn’t be doing that.’”  It’s almost like “Hey, I could do this or do this…well this is wrong.” It’s kind of learned through development of you know, 22 years of stuff, and the way my beliefs are and the way I was raised and stuff like that.  “This is right, this is wrong.” Fairly well.  Most of the time. Pretty cut and dry.  It just comes naturally, I guess, it could be best put.  Outside of what the rules are… It goes back like I said to how you were raised, the morals you were raised with, stuff like that. Yeah, I think… In their minds. It’s not, no, it’s not in reality. I would guess so.  Well, I … That’s a really good question.  I mean, there’s no claims well like murder and stuff come to mind, but then again, when you think about some of these other countries, it’s not…, I really don’t know how to answer that.  I really don’t.  That’s what I base my focus, that’s what I was raised in.  That’s kind of the ultimate law.  You know, the Ten Commandments, and things like that. yeah, I mean there’s that’s just kind of the roll of the dice that is Life. Mostly likely.  That could be the right thing.  That could be the wrong thing, it’s like, I once read a quote in regards to religion that said “I’d rather live my life if there is a God, then die and find out there isn’t, then to live like there isn’t a God and find out there is.” And that’s kind of the way I take it. I mean I believe it, I’m not like “Well, maybe, maybe not,” but one of my co-workers thinks the Bible’s a fairy tale.  And he was raised in  really devout, Baptist family, I guess but to this day, he’s 30 years old and he’ll look at you and he’ll tell you it’s all a bunch of crap.  And I’m like, “Ok, Ray*!” No, I disagree completely, 100%.  I’m like, “Ok, Ray*!  That’s your thing, but have fun with that later on man!”
column591: The respondent prioritizes paying off debts and saving when receiving a windfall, bases their moral understanding on upbringing and personal beliefs, acknowledges the relativity of morality influenced by societal changes, emphasizes the importance of helping others as a Christian duty, and values the advice of parents or teachers over personal gain or happiness when faced with moral dilemmas.

column583:
I:Mm-mm, um, have you always held that view?
R:Mm,--
I:Or how did you get to that perspective?
R:Well I think a lot of it was the school debacle that I mentioned.  I just kind of got to see an interesting view of people that I hadn’t seen before.
I:Can you describe that some more, what, what side of people you saw?
R:Well just more the selfish angle, you know they didn’t have to do what is in their job description just because.  It made things easier for them.
I:So, they sort of sacrificed what was good for you just out of laziness—
R:For their own interests, yeah.
I:--or whatever, like that.  And so that caused you to see something that sort of shaped this way of thinking about morality?
R:Probably.
I:Mm-mm.  But did you, did you, did you think that way before then and that only solidified it or did that—
R:I think so.
I:--really sort of change your thinking.
R:I generally had a rather cynical outlook of life in general.
I:Would you say your parents have the same sort of cynical outlook?
R:Not really.
I:Why do you call it cynical, you might as well just call it realistic.
R:Well yeah, I think it was Oscar Wilde that said that um, the power of good observation is called cynicism by people who don’t have it.
I:Okay, um, so once I was hiking, this is a true story, once I was hiking in um, the Andes mountains and I got on a path that was much bigger and harder and longer that I expected it to be and was, what would people would normally call dying of thirst, I wasn’t about to die, but and I ran across this Australian with a canteen of water.  Well, let’s suppose I had got an impulse and said, well look, I’m really thirsty and this, I’m dehydrated, whatever.
R:And you look okay, gimmee!
I:Yeah, what if um, and what if I knew that there was nobody anywhere around, what if I would have just shoved him over a cliff and taken his water.  That would just be too bad for him.  There’s nothing immoral about that.
R:Yeah, probably.
I:There’s nothing morally?
R:I mean it probably wasn’t very nice and that there were possible alternatives.
I:Well let’s suppose I said, can I have some of your water and he said no.
R:Yeah.
I:Bug off, bloke .
R:Yeah .
I:Let’s suppose there were no alternatives, let’s suppose that was it.
R:Well you couldn’t just knock him down, versus off the cliff, because then you rather risk that the canteen will go off with it
I:Let’s suppose, let’s suppose he put his canteen down.
R:Okay.
I:I don’t know, I don’t know how to construct,--
R:Yeah, I, I understand what you meant 00:21:14
I:What I’m trying to get at is, well even if I had an easier alternative, what, what’s wrong with killing him, it just makes it simpler to get away, I don’t have to fight with him.
R:Yeah this is true.
I:There’s nothing wrong with that, I would never get caught, I would have my water.
R:Yeah.
I:Is there a problem with that?
R:Well again, it depends on your outlook but it wouldn’t be very nice, obviously.  But.
I:But depending on your outlook, nice could be irrelevant.
R:Yeah, just.
I:So but the outlook I’m pushing here is.
R:You just saw him and immediately didn’t like it, it’s not my problem.
I:But I’m saying if, if we take seriously this view of morality we couldn’t make a judgment that that was wrong.  In the strong sense of wrong, or immoral or that I would have to—
R:Right.
I:It’s just society would have discouraged it and punished me but society didn’t catch me so it was too bad for the Australian to be on the mountain with water.
R:Right, mm-mm, and I think a lot of it is society’s pressure to make you think what’s moral and what’s not.
I:So is it a correct implication of what you’re saying then that, um,--
R:Well I think it’s—
I:Most people act morally because society is set up to get them to do that.
R:Because of the peer pressure of society, yeah.
I:Why does society get them to do that, what does society?
R:Why does society do anything, I mean, you, you look around, I always thought it was rather wacky myself, but.
I:But people seem to have an interest in maintaining a certain order and getting people to behave in a certain way, why do you, why don’t, why don’t they just all realize, hey it’s those strong winds and—
R:I think it would be very interesting if we did but I think it’s not likely to happen just because of the peer pressure issue.
I:But peer pressure is driven by what you think is right or wrong and good and bad and so if people’s views of that change, then.
R:Well I mean, see now I would have said peer pressure is what other people think is good and bad,--
I:Yeah, that’s what I mean.
R:And make you think what is good and bad, yeah.
I:Have you ever read Friedrich Nitche, the german philosopher?
R:I have never, no.
I:Yeah, yeah I mean he basically said, look, we don’t believe in God anymore, God is dead, it God is dead then all things are permissible and this whole notion of human rights and dignity and taking care of the weak is BS, the strong should be triumphant and conquer the weak and it’s, and that’s beautiful.
R:Yeah I would probably roughly agree with that.
I:If birds of prey fly off with little lambs and tear them to shreds then that’s the way it is.  So you would go along with that.
R:Mm-mm, and there’s not a lot we can do about it, yeah.
I:Okay, and you’re comfortable living in that kind of universe?
R:I think so.
I:And so how do you make sense of this is a very interesting conversation.
R:Oh thank you.
I:How do you make sense of um, like say the Nazis in the thirties, I mean it was socially defined then, Jews are bad, we’re gonna get rid of them.
R:Yeah, it’s the way they thought.
I:And so do we stand in a position to condemn them or we just said that was a different time and place and that’s just the way it was.
R:Well yeah, you can’t necessarily make comparisons of different time periods just because there was an entirely different mindset.
I:So people that fought them and said this is the wrong mindset, even though they fought a losing battle, um, they were just wasting their time, waste, being naïve, they were, no basis for fighting the Nazis?
R:Well it did, they thought that, I don’t know if they thought that they could actually change their outlook and if by killing them changes their outlook it served your purpose, that’s one less person who is going to terrorize you with that anymore.
I:Okay do you think the logical conclusion of this view of things is life is a war of interest groups against all, and it’s just a quest for power, basically to dominate other…?
R:Probably, yeah.
I:And would you say, is that sad or is that just, there’s nothing to be sad about because it’s just the way it is?
R:I would have said it was just the way it was and chances are it isn’t going to change anytime soon.
column584: I’ve, I’ve always kind of had this philosophy that there are only ever two reasons anybody does anything. Is to avoid pain or gain some pleasure. Yeah.  Very pragmatic. Well if, if it was what they believe and if they really want it, you know, in their own way they’re bringing it about. If, if they think that it will make a difference. Well I mean, as you say not very anymore, people they, they don’t, if they, if someone martyrs it becomes news and they, they’ve done, got their message out by doing so. Yeah. Almost certainly. I generally had a rather cynical outlook of life in general. Not really. Well yeah, I think it was Oscar Wilde that said that um, the power of good observation is called cynicism by people who don’t have it. And you look okay, gimmee! Yeah, probably. I mean it probably wasn’t very nice and that there were possible alternatives. Yeah. Yeah . Yeah. Well again, it depends on your outlook but it wouldn’t be very nice, obviously.  But. Yeah, just. You just saw him and immediately didn’t like it, it’s not my problem. Right. column585: The respondent believes that morality is largely subjective and shaped by individual backgrounds and societal pressures, viewing actions through a pragmatic lens of self-interest and utilitarianism, while also acknowledging the influence of their father's perspective on the consequences of substance use.
column586:
I:Okay.  I have some questions about morality.  Right, wrong, just, unjust, etc., etc.  Um, tell me how you think about this subject.  What is it that makes things right or wrong, how do you think about morality?
R:Well I think a lot of it is that there ought to be intuitive, you know, killing people is wrong, hurting people is wrong, just because, it’s just, you know doing things that cause discomfort to other people is just not something that I think is a good thing for anybody to do.  But, I don’t know, that I have a whole overarching philosophy about it.
I:But you’re instinct or your intuition is that things that hurt others is wrong?
R:Pretty much.
I:Okay.  Um, why is that wrong?
R:Well just because, I mean causing harm to other people is just not something that anybody should do and you know, being harmed in serious ways is something that anybody should have to put up with.
I:But why?
R:Just because it’s just an uncomfortable experience.  It’s not good for anyone really.
I:What uh, let me play devil’s advocate.  What if, who cares about other people, what if I said, what if somebody said, well of course you don’t want to be uncomfortable, you don’t want to suffer, but if somebody else does, it’s not your problem.
R:Well maybe it’s not, maybe you shouldn’t have to think about it at all.  I mean it does seem like a lot of the reasons the world is the way it is now is because of that attitude.
I:And the way that it is now is,
R:Just, strife with horrible things.
I:So people had that attitude less, the world would improve to a better place?
R:Probably in small ways.
I:Why not um,
R:You know, it’s the all about me attitude, that has also caused many people to become zillionaires and M11:Well, see that’s the thing, is pretty much all attitudes can be rationalized to be you know, understandable, it’s, I don’t know whether it’s moral or not is an entirely separate question.
I:So,
R:Cause whether something makes sense and whether it’s moral are just not even in the same,
I:So is there something that makes things moral or is that just something we call something that we want to believe?  I mean moral in the sense of right or wrong regardless of how somebody thinks of it that way?
R:Yeah.  Yeah.  I don’t know.  I mean, you know, there were entire weeks of philosophy where someone tried to tell us, but there were never really one theory that I ascribed to over another.
I:Do you have a pretty clear sense of what’s morally right or wrong, or is it not that clear to you?
R:Well there’s always fuzzy boundaries in anything but, no I think in most situations I could just pick a side.  But then I think that almost anyone could do that, maybe fairly similar.
I:Earlier you said sort of intuition.  Would you say that the way you sort of view things is that people in their guts sort of know things, or they should,
R:Yeah, if they’re not psychotic in any way, probably.  It’s just whether people choose to follow that is their personal,
I:And that intuition comes from, sort of evolutionary development, or, or universal human something or?
R:I don’t know.
I:Okay.  Um, some teens I talk to say that the thing that makes something wrong is it’s consequences, it’s not that something’s right or wrong in itself, it’s that if it produces something bad or unpleasant.  Is that how you think about it, I mean you did talk about people shouldn’t suffer,
R:Yeah.  I don’t really know, I just, no, I don’t have cause to think about it much.
I:So this is not a particularly pressing,
R:No.
column587: Well there’s always fuzzy boundaries in anything but, no I think in most situations I could just pick a side.  But then I think that almost anyone could do that, maybe fairly similar. Yeah, if they’re not psychotic in any way, probably.  It’s just whether people choose to follow that is their personal, I don’t know.  Well I think a lot of it is that there ought to be intuitive, you know, killing people is wrong, hurting people is wrong, just because, it’s just, you know doing things that cause discomfort to other people is just not something that I think is a good thing for anybody to do.  But, I don’t know, that I have a whole overarching philosophy about it. Pretty much. Well just because, I mean causing harm to other people is just not something that anybody should do and you know, being harmed in serious ways is something that anybody should have to put up with. Just because it’s just an uncomfortable experience.  It’s not good for anyone really. Well maybe it’s not, maybe you shouldn’t have to think about it at all.  I mean it does seem like a lot of the reasons the world is the way it is now is because of that attitude. Just, strife with horrible things. Probably in small ways. You know, it’s the all about me attitude, that has also caused many people to become zillionaires and Well, see that’s the thing, is pretty much all attitudes can be rationalized to be you know, understandable, it’s, I don’t know whether it’s moral or not is an entirely separate question. Cause whether something makes sense and whether it’s moral are just not even in the same, Yeah.  Yeah.  I don’t know.  I mean, you know, there were entire weeks of philosophy where someone tried to tell us, but there were never really one theory that I ascribed to over another. Yeah.  I don’t really know, I just, no, I don’t have cause to think about it much. No.
column588: The respondent expresses a strong intuition that causing harm to others is inherently wrong, believes in the importance of helping those in need if it doesn't cause significant hardship, and acknowledges that societal conventions largely shape moral judgments, while also suggesting that individuals should enjoy life without imposing their beliefs on others.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what’s good or bad or right and wrong in life?  Do you even think there are things that are right or wrong?
R:I don’t know if I think in terms so much of right or wrong as things that you wouldn’t like them if they happened to you.  Well no, that’s not true.  You can look at something and say that is just… Well, it’s interesting you say that.  I don’t think in terms of this is wrong so much as that’s just not right.  I guess there is a lot of the, “Do unto others as you would have them do unto you” kind of thing.
I:Do you believe that is eternal maxim?
R:I do.  I don’t you know, repeat it in the back of my head everyday.
I:Why do you think that’s the case?   That that’s the general, rule-of-thumb to live by?  Why is it the case that that’s true?
R:Well I saw a poster once and it was basically that phrase in this kind of like sunflower shaped thing and on every petal was basically that phrase in various different religious books.  I guess it’s just one of those things.  You’d like for people to be nice to you.  You’d like for people to be forthright with you because the world is a very unpleasant place if you don’t.  It seems only fair I guess.
I:So it’s kind of an ?  Like I’m willing to behave in a certain way that puts demands on me in the expectation that other people should and hopefully will and then we’ll all have a nicer life together?
R:Pretty much.
I:It’s kind of a social contract theory.
R:I mean, they won’t necessarily, but you can give it a try.
I:That was my next question.  What about the people that are the proverbial assholes?
R:There are those people.  I talk to them on the phone everyday.
I:So they don’t play by that system.  They drag everyone else down.
R:Yeah.
I:So you’re doing work that they’re not being kind on.  What about them?  Does that mean that the system is still worth doing?
R:I don’t know that it really bothers me just because I have this code of conduct and I like it.  I don’t care if you don’t like it or don’t follow it.  It’s actually one of those about the insurance industry.  I’m a claims assistant so don’t make any decisions.  I could go be a claims examiner, but I don’t feel like I could emotionally in good conscious do that to people.  I couldn’t tell them, “You fell on the sidewalk instead of the parking lot so we’re not going to pay your twenty-thousand dollar hospital bill.”  I couldn’t tell people that.  In the insurance industry you could be like a bad guy.  There’s people and they call you and like an 80 year-old man who needs his inhaler and I can’t authorize it.  And it’s like, “Not cool man.  Bad day for you,” and I sometimes come home feeling horrible about that.
I:You mentioned this poster.  Did you already believe this general orientation before you saw the poster?  Did the poster just kind of solidify it for you?  So what is the role of the poster in the formation of-?
R:-It’s not really very important.  It was just one of the things when I think of that phrase I have a tendency to think about it because that’s really interesting and there’s a lot of people that do have respect for religion and look at all these religions that say basically exactly the same thing about this particular subject.
I:So even though you describe yourself as a hardcore atheist, the fact that other people sort of share that outlook from a religious perspective you view as “I could take that.”?
R:I view it as a thing you can do if you want to and it won’t hurt me in anyway.
I:And if people want to do something totally different?  Like, “I look out for myself.  I’ll be nice if it’s good for me and if not, I won’t be.  And that’s just the way it’s been and it’s the way it’s ever been”?
R:Yeah, pretty much.
I:There isn’t any sort of larger moral truth to appeal and to say, “Well that’s wrong.  We need to change in order to be more like this truth”?
R:I don’t really think so because you can’t have an independent arbor of those kind of things and if there’s nobody that can make that decision then… if there is literally nobody that can make that decision then it’s not necessarily a decision to be made.
I:When it comes to certain things the government tries to do that.  It doesn’t get too much involved in morality, but it certainly says, “Here’s how you’ll behave.  At this age you can and can’t do this” etc, etc, which has a lot of moral ramifications so at the very least you could say, “Well it’s legal.”  Then what’s the explanation of why something is legal or not legal?
column590: I don’t know if I think in terms so much of right or wrong as things that you wouldn’t like them if they happened to you.  Well no, that’s not true.  You can look at something and say that is just… Well, it’s interesting you say that.  I don’t think in terms of this is wrong so much as that’s just not right.  I guess there is a lot of the, “Do unto others as you would have them do unto you” kind of thing. I do.  I don’t you know, repeat it in the back of my head everyday. I guess it’s just one of those things.  You’d like for people to be nice to you.  You’d like for people to be forthright with you because the world is a very unpleasant place if you don’t.  It seems only fair I guess. Pretty much. I mean, they won’t necessarily, but you can give it a try. There are those people.  I talk to them on the phone everyday. Yeah. I don’t know that it really bothers me just because I have this code of conduct and I like it.  I don’t care if you don’t like it or don’t follow it.  It’s actually one of those about the insurance industry.  I’m a claims assistant so don’t make any decisions. I couldn’t tell them, “You fell on the sidewalk instead of the parking lot so we’re not going to pay your twenty-thousand dollar hospital bill.”  I couldn’t tell people that. I don’t really think so because you can’t have an independent arbor of those kind of things and if there’s nobody that can make that decision then… if there is literally nobody that can make that decision then it’s not necessarily a decision to be made.
column591: The respondent would use a hypothetical inheritance of $100,000 primarily to buy a reliable car and help a significant other with debt, emphasizing a sense of responsibility and honor in their relationship, while also reflecting on their tendency to feel overwhelmed by personal issues and the importance of treating others well, guided by a "do unto others" principle rather than strict moral obligations.

column583:
I:Okay, so what would you, what do you think ah, what do you think makes stealing wrong, then, or why do you think, just as an example, like why do you think that would be wrong?
R:I know it’s wrong because um, the reason I know stealing is wrong is because of like when I, when I was littler I used to take stuff from my Mom and Dad, then they chewed me out and I learned from that.  So I learned, I figured that out the hard way.
I:Like where, where do your own views of right and wrong come from like?
R:My own views?
I:Yeah.  Like where do your views of right and wrong come from, like how do you learn what’s right and wrong.
R:The right and wrong?  Like I, well what I said, when I was little I used to take stuff, but then I got a spanking for it.
I:Uh-huh
R:And that’s how I learned.
I:Like from your parents training you and punishing you?
R:Yeah.
I:So can you, can you give me some specific examples of like when you need to, when you have to decide what’s right and wrong given a situation?
R:Like I know this isn’t a real big deal, but like taking pencils from someone when you know that’s theirs and not giving it back.  I think that’s, I, I do it myself but then I give the pencil right back, but then like if, like one of my teachers, he buys about 10 packs of pencils, #2 pencils and people take them.
I:Uh-huh
R:I think that’s just wasting the school’s mon—the teacher’s money cause then every week he goes out and guys new pencils for us.  For tests and stuff, well then they still end up getting taken.
I:So do you think, do you think that would be wrong because, because it was wasting the school’s money or because it’s taking something that’s somebody else’s, like what do you think, what, what do you think is it that makes it—
R:I think it’s wrong because it, because it’s wasting the school’s money. Cause pencils for school aren’t very, aren’t that cheap.
I:And so it’s more, they’re kind of like stealing money from the school in that way.  Yeah, I gotcha.
R:I think that’s all it’s gonna do is just get you into more trouble.
I:Mm-mm.
R:Cause what happens if one of the kids caught you taking it and then they went and told the teacher.  You’d, anyway, that the teacher would find out yet, still.  But like if someone took the pencil and um, and no one caught them.
I:Uh-huh
R:That’s still a pretty, that’s still wrong.
I:Even though no one found out.
R:Yeah.
column584: Just the many years I’ve been around, I should know.  And what’s like right and wrong, like stealing, like if I were to steal this thing right here, I know that would be wrong.  Then if I were to give it back and tell that I took it I knew that would be the proper thing to do. I know it’s wrong because um, the reason I know stealing is wrong is because of like when I, when I was littler I used to take stuff from my Mom and Dad, then they chewed me out and I learned from that.  So I learned, I figured that out the hard way. My own views? The right and wrong?  Like I, well what I said, when I was little I used to take stuff, but then I got a spanking for it. And that’s how I learned. Yeah. Like I know this isn’t a real big deal, but like taking pencils from someone when you know that’s theirs and not giving it back.  I think that’s, I, I do it myself but then I give the pencil right back, but then like if, like one of my teachers, he buys about 10 packs of pencils, #2 pencils and people take them. I think that’s just wasting the school’s mon—the teacher’s money cause then every week he goes out and guys new pencils for us.  For tests and stuff, well then they still end up getting taken. I think it’s wrong because it, because it’s wasting the school’s money. Cause pencils for school aren’t very, aren’t that cheap. I think that’s all it’s gonna do is just get you into more trouble. Cause what happens if one of the kids caught you taking it and then they went and told the teacher.  You’d, anyway, that the teacher would find out yet, still.  But like if someone took the pencil and um, and no one caught them. That’s still a pretty, that’s still wrong. Yeah.
column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are clear and learned primarily through parental discipline and personal experiences, such as being punished for stealing, and while they acknowledge that people may still understand these concepts, they suggest that social influences, like peer pressure, can lead individuals to act against their better judgment.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:How do you decide it?
I:How do you decide or how do you know what is good and what’s bad?
R:Uh, by mistakes that we, by mistakes that I’ve did in my past.  I’ve corrected myself from it.
I:Can you tell me an example of one that’s happened?
R:Uh, I’m thinking.  Doing dishes, like because I never used to be able to get dishes clean, and now like I’m getting them clean after my parents told me to work harder at it, spend more time and now I get them clean because I spend too much time at doing dishes.  I usually spend about a half hour at the sink just doing them, like a couple pots and pans.
I:Why?
R:Well, I like playing in the water so.
I:In general, do you think you have a hard time or an easy time deciding what’s right and what’s wrong?
R:Easy time.
I:Why?
R:Because my parents have directed me in the right way and I have no problem with that.
I:Do you have any idea of what it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Do I have an idea of what makes something right or wrong?
I:Yeah, what makes something right and something else wrong?
R:Well, if you steal stuff, that’s not right.
I:Why?
R:I don’t know.  Well, I guess because if you didn’t pay for it—
I:So.
R:I have no idea how to answer that question.
I:Where to you think you’ve got how you understand right and wrong?  Where did you come up with these things?
R:Understanding right from—
I:The things that you just told me, where’d you come up with that?
R:Uh, because, like on a trip that we take to New Mexico every year, people in the winter, it took us five hours to get out of Michigan in time because someone didn’t obey the law and then we caught people stealing and then we’ve also caught, we’ve heard shootings going off.
I:Where?
R:Like where there’s not so many cops like, at the top of the mountain in Alma Gorda.
I:New Mexico?
R:Yeah, in New Mexico, they have like shootings up at the top of the mountain.
I:Why?
R:Because, I don’t know.
I:So but like, you talk about the speed limit and gun laws, I mean, how did you come to decide that those things are good?  I mean, who told you or where did you get your sense of right and wrong?
R:From my parents.
I:Anywhere else?
R:My grandparents.

Doing dishes, like because I never used to be able to get dishes clean, and now like I’m getting them clean after my parents told me to work harder at it, spend more time and now I get them clean because I spend too much time at doing dishes. Understanding right from— Uh, because, like on a trip that we take to New Mexico every year, people in the winter, it took us five hours to get out of Michigan in time because someone didn’t obey the law and then we caught people stealing and then we’ve also caught, we’ve heard shootings going off. Like where there’s not so many cops like, at the top of the mountain in Alma Gorda. Yeah, in New Mexico, they have like shootings up at the top of the mountain. Because, I don’t know. column588: The respondent would donate half of an inheritance to hurricane relief because they believe others need it more, and they make decisions about right and wrong based on past mistakes and guidance from their parents, emphasizing the importance of social influences in shaping their moral understanding.
column589:
I:Ok. How do you normally decide what’s good or bad or right or wrong in life?
R:mmm… well, my parents are right there… on me most of the time.
I:So they make sure you know or…?
R:Yeah, there’s some things I just get in trouble for at home cuz, either I don’t do it or, well, yeah, I just didn’t do it so, that’s basically the only thing I get in trouble for, is not doing it .
I:But in general do you find it easy or hard to decide what is right and wrong?  Are there things you struggle with?
R:There’s things I struggle with but… it’s… it’s just common sense, whether you should do it or not.
I:Do you think this has gotten easier or harder over the last couple of years? Or is it…
R:I think it’s gotten easier, but…like I said, I’m a senior this year, graduating, and these last two weeks have been just…off the wall, because… things going on at home, trying to get caught up in school and… our whole house is…just…it feels cluttered, just about.
I:Like with things to do, or with people around?
R:With things to do. And, it…honestly I can’t wait till I graduate because that will give…that will get that off the mind, and I don’t have to worry about other things to do.
I:Ok. What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong? What is it about something that… ?
R:Uh… that makes something right or wrong?
I:Yeah, like I mean, is it like maybe the consequences? Is it, you know, if it’s good results then it’s Ok? Or whether you feel right about it or… are there rules, laws?
R:To me it is more feeling right about doin it. And then also again it has to do with the laws. Like I said, there’s a lot of things I wouldn’t do.
I:Like what?
R:Like smoking. I know it’s not against the law but, it’s…it’s for my personal health. I don’t wanna die in 10 years, so… And then, drunk driving I would never do because I lost a friend to it. So, that’s taught me not to drink and drive. So…
I:So it’s your experience that…
R:Yeah.
I:Ok. Where have your moral views come from?
R:Probably just experiences. I don’t know if that really answers your question, but…
I:It does I guess, but are there particular, I don’t know…you say your parents are one influence? And you mentioned that you are a Lutheran a little while ago. So, how do those things affect your sense of morality?
R:Uh,… um, I really don’t know about how the religion comes into it. But, I know in the Bible it says that God gave up his son to… he died for us to forgive our sins. And basically, what that means to me is that if we die and we did, like, a bunch of things wrong, we’re still going to go up to heaven. To me, basically, if you did one thing wrong that you regret, and you die like the next day or something, you’re going to go to heaven no matter what. Because it’s all behind you.
I:Well, why would you do anything right then? Why not just do wrong things?
R:Ah, , no, I understand what you’re saying. It’s… I don’t know… it’s just how, like, kids are raised by their parents, depending on what they do in their life, whether they make the right choices or wrong choices. See for drunk drivers…kids that drink, they grew up with it; they might have grown up around it. So… it…that basically tells them, ‘oh it’s Ok to drink.’ So, for my friend that smokes, he grew up around smoking so, he thinks it’s Ok to smoke. So…
I:But I mean, can you decide on the outside? You can say that even though these people grew up drinking, they shouldn’t be drinking and driving right? Like you want to tell your friends that right?
R:Yeah.
I:Why do you think that’s right for everybody?
R:I don’t know.. .. I guess I’m more of a person that likes to see people live to the full extent, to succeed in life.
I:So there’s some things that will allow you to live fully and other things that will destroy you?
R:Yeah
column590: mmm… well, my parents are right there… on me most of the time. Yeah, there’s some things I just get in trouble for at home cuz, either I don’t do it or, well, yeah, I just didn’t do it so, that’s basically the only thing I get in trouble for, is not doing it . There’s things I struggle with but… it’s… it’s just common sense, whether you should do it or not. I think it’s gotten easier, but…like I said, I’m a senior this year, graduating, and these last two weeks have been just…off the wall, because… things going on at home, trying to get caught up in school and… our whole house is…just…it feels cluttered, just about. With things to do. And, it…honestly I can’t wait till I graduate because that will give…that will get that off the mind, and I don’t have to worry about other things to do.  Uh… that makes something right or wrong? To me it is more feeling right about doin it. And then also again it has to do with the laws. Like I said, there’s a lot of things I wouldn’t do. Like smoking. I know it’s not against the law but, it’s…it’s for my personal health. I don’t wanna die in 10 years, so… And then, drunk driving I would never do because I lost a friend to it. So, that’s taught me not to drink and drive. So… Yeah.  Probably just experiences. I don’t know if that really answers your question, but… Uh,… um, I really don’t know about how the religion comes into it. But, I know in the Bible it says that God gave up his son to… he died for us to forgive our sins. And basically, what that means to me is that if we die and we did, like, a bunch of things wrong, we’re still going to go up to heaven. To me, basically, if you did one thing wrong that you regret, and you die like the next day or something, you’re going to go to heaven no matter what. Because it’s all behind you. Ah, , no, I understand what you’re saying. It’s… I don’t know… it’s just how, like, kids are raised by their parents, depending on what they do in their life, whether they make the right choices or wrong choices. See for drunk drivers…kids that drink, they grew up with it; they might have grown up around it. So… it…that basically tells them, ‘oh it’s Ok to drink.’ So, for my friend that smokes, he grew up around smoking so, he thinks it’s Ok to smoke. So… Yeah. I don’t know.. .. I guess I’m more of a person that likes to see people live to the full extent, to succeed in life. Yeah
column591: The respondent primarily relies on parental guidance to determine right from wrong, values personal experiences and consequences, and expresses a Lutheran faith that influences their moral views, particularly regarding the importance of helping others and avoiding harmful behaviors like drunk driving.

column583:
I:Mm-mm.  Do you have ideas about like where your views of right and wrong come from?
R:Probably cause I grew up in the church, but, I still think people would have like something just, almost instinct, to know what’s really right and what’s really wrong, so.
I:Mm-mm. Yeah.  And um, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?  Like if, if you had to tell somebody how you decide what’s right and wrong, what would you tell them is the most important source of knowing right and wrong?
R:Um, one easy way to put it would be like if everybody knew you did it, what would they think.
I:Right, right, yeah so, okay, yeah.  And any ah, let’s see, any examples of um, of um, kind of situations where you had to decide right and wrong and it was difficult and?
R:No.
column584: Probably cause I grew up in the church, but, I still think people would have like something just, almost instinct, to know what’s really right and what’s really wrong, so. Um, one easy way to put it would be like if everybody knew you did it, what would they think. No.
column585: The respondent believes that people generally know right from wrong but often choose to ignore it, attributes their own moral compass to their church upbringing and instinct, and emphasizes that they avoid wrongdoing to maintain their parents' trust while feeling pressured by peers to conform to certain behaviors.
column586:
I:how do you know what’s good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:well, religion helps. You know, I mean, and then there’s just, there’s like an ingrained sense of right and wrong I feel in most balanced people, I think.
I:is it easy or hard for you to decide what’s right and wrong?
R:it’s usually pretty straight forward but sometimes even if you know it’s wrong it doesn’t make a difference in your decision.
I:so in terms of knowing what’s right and wrong you’ve got a pretty good sense?
R:yeah.
I:has that gotten harder or easier in the last couple of years?
R:I don’t know, not harder.
I:okay. So not harder, okay.
R:I don’t know, maybe a little bit.
I:what particular decision or types of decisions that have gotten harder?
R:well, I don’t know. I don’t know.

R:sometimes it’s hard to relate because they didn’t grow up with the background you did or whatever, so I don’t know how you would get it across without seeming like some sort of bigot, most of the time.

R:yeah.
I:but if you could, if they were the same religion you’re saying then you could tell them?

R:parents and church, yeah.

R:I try to know what’s right or wrong before I have to experience it, you know?

column588: The respondent emphasizes the importance of making money work for future security and charitable giving, while also highlighting that their moral compass is influenced by religion and parents, believing in a clear distinction between right and wrong despite societal complexities.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um…my church, my parents, my brothers, all my brothers and sisters.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um…how you’ve been taught.  Your understanding of the view of how it’s supposed to be.
I:Okay, can you give me an example of something that’s been taught…something, just one example?
R:Um, that you’re like not supposed to smoke or like have any drugs cause it’s harmful to you.
I:Okay, what if a person was taught by their parents that smoking was okay, what would you think of their morality, would that be okay for them to do if they were taught that?
R:Well that’s kind of the parents fault.  Cause they were taught by their parents and so, what you’re having an example to follow, you tend to follow.
I:So what if the parents, that’s their morality too, and part of their morality is that smoking is okay, is that not an acceptable morality for them?
R:No, they should know better because they are older and they should try to be a good example.
I:Okay, if people could be taught different examples, by their parents, by their churches, by their families, things like that, what is it that really makes something right or wrong, like in a sense, like how would you tell what, which of those teachings were actually right, and which were less right and wrong.
R:Kind of what you know and what you understand it to be and what you feel how it is, if it’s right or wrong.
I:What if people feel different?  What if some people feel, I don’t know, smoking is okay and others feel that smoking is not okay?
R:Well they don’t kind of have the full picture of what it’s supposed to be cause there’s rulings on how it’s unhealthy for you. M8:They don’t understand how life works, and what you’re supposed to do M8:and how you’re supposed to educate yourself to become the best you can be M8:to help others than yourself.
I:M8:Why is it important to help others?
R:M8:Because it’s just not right to concentrate on you alone, but to also help M8:others, giving and understanding others as well.
I:M8:What if someone didn’t care about others, they only cared about M8:themselves?
R:M8:Then they don’t feel, they’ll probably feel guilty, cause they don’t, M8:they’re just being selfish and not sharing how they are happy with those M8:who are less fortunate.
I:It probably sounds like I’m beating a dead horse, but I really want to understand this, so if a person wants to go talk to their parents, let’s say that they’re rich, they’re life is going to be all set by what they do.  Um…and uh…they, their parents just teach them their whole life, you just have to look out for yourself.  Don’t worry about other people.  They’re taught that from the day their born, all the way up, they just think they don’t have to look out for other people, that’s what they’re taught, that’s the example they see in their family.  Would they be wrong, or would they like feel guilty.
R:Well, they wouldn’t know it’s wrong to do that, cause their examples would teach them that.  So it’s the responsibility of them that they teach them a good example.
I:So let’s say this person turned 18 or whatever and the become, they meet someone who has a different philosophy, they meet someone who thinks it is important to help people, and this friend of theirs is always talking about how it’s important to help other people, how would that person decide whether their friend was right or whether their parents were right?  How would they make that decision?
R:Just try to figure, ask people, so that they can understand if it’s okay just to concentrate on yourself or to help others, um, to help them become like you are.
I:So what if the more people they talk to that helping others was good, like 60% of the people said it was good to help others and 40% said it wasn’t then they should decide to help others?
R:Yeah.
I:What if, what if they ran into something that was the other way around? What if 60% said you shouldn’t help others and 40% said you should help others?  How would they make that…would that be right?
R:Well, it would by what they have as a resource to have what you have, how people are supposed to do things.
I:Okay, so do you think there is any way for people to know what’s right or wrong apart from what they learn from other people?
R:Only if they’re taught it, they have to be taught by examples and there aren’t  many examples today.
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life personally?
R:What I feel is right and what other people have taught me and one I ask to see if they have any…direction to show.
I:What have been your most important influences in what you think of as right and wrong?
R:Um…my mother.
I:Why do you trust her to tell you what’s right and wrong?
R:Because she sort of, from my point of view looks at things from the right perspective, and it seems to go along with the perspective of other people I’ve seen and her life is happy, and they’re happier and so it seems that they’re doing what is right.
I:I have to ask you this, this might sound a little crazy, but let’s say an alien comes down from outer space and they only meet a couple people, and the people have totally different moralities, totally different, the world is just divided, what would happen, one half of the world is this you have to help people, and the other half thinks you should never help people, you should just look out for yourself.  How would this alien from outer space decide how, which one of these people are…cause on one half they were all taught it, the other half they were all taught it, and so they were raised that way they all trust it.  They all think their parents had the right perspective on things.  How would this person who sort of appeared out of nowhere, how would they choose which sort of camp to join?
R:Well they would kind of have to see which one has the better life and how they are.  Cause some people that don’t help others they just sort of feel, they want to be sort of secretive or they want to be just left alone.  And people that help others they kind of have a happier lifestyle, they are just easier to get along with, they’re nicer and they’re, just, great people.
