Um, that you’re like not supposed to smoke or like have any drugs cause it’s harmful to you. Well that’s kind of the parents fault.  Cause they were taught by their parents and so, what you’re having an example to follow, you tend to follow. No, they should know better because they are older and they should try to be a good example. Kind of what you know and what you understand it to be and what you feel how it is, if it’s right or wrong. Well they don’t kind of have the full picture of what it’s supposed to be cause there’s rulings on how it’s unhealthy for you. They don’t understand how life works, and what you’re supposed to do and how you’re supposed to educate yourself to become the best you can be to help others than yourself. Because it’s just not right to concentrate on you alone, but to also help others, giving and understanding others as well. Then they don’t feel, they’ll probably feel guilty, cause they don’t, they’re just being selfish and not sharing how they are happy with those who are less fortunate. Well, they wouldn’t know it’s wrong to do that, cause their examples would teach them that.  So it’s the responsibility of them that they teach them a good example. Just try to figure, ask people, so that they can understand if it’s okay just to concentrate on yourself or to help others, um, to help them become like you are. Yeah. Well, it would by what they have as a resource to have what you have, how people are supposed to do things. Only if they’re taught it, they have to be taught by examples and there aren’t  many examples today. What I feel is right and what other people have taught me and one I ask to see if they have any…direction to show. Um…my mother. Because she sort of, from my point of view looks at things from the right perspective, and it seems to go along with the perspective of other people I’ve seen and her life is happy, and they’re happier and so it seems that they’re doing what is right. Well they would kind of have to see which one has the better life and how they are.  Cause some people that don’t help others they just sort of feel, they want to be sort of secretive or they want to be just left alone.  And people that help others they kind of have a happier lifestyle, they are just easier to get along with, they’re nicer and they’re, just, great people.
column585: The respondent believes that morality is influenced by teachings from their church and parents, feels that many people have lost a clear sense of right and wrong due to rebellion against parental guidance, and emphasizes the importance of helping others as a moral obligation, while also asserting that lying is wrong regardless of whether parents find out, as it goes against their religious beliefs.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:How do know?
I:How do you decide, you know.
R:I think everybody knows what’s right and what’s wrong, it’s just whether they live by it or not.  So I think everybody has this same kind of moral standards, I think some might be different, but relatively speaking, I think everybody has some morals.  Whether or not they’re different or not.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:You mean like doing right and wrong?
I:Yeah.
R:I think it’s pretty easy to decide to do something good instead of something bad because, you know, if it’s something illegal, obviously, there’s always that you get caught or whatnot.  You get in trouble, you know, you don’t need to deal with that.  Then even if you  you know, you basically know you can get away with it, it’s just the fact you know ok, if someone did this to you, how would you feel?
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:I think it’s the same, same struggle really.  I mean, yeah, it’s certain areas, it’s gotten easier, but other areas, it’s gotten harder.
I:Like what areas?
R:More like areas  drugs, really that’s kind of gotten a little bit harder.  Because you know you shouldn’t.  Maybe you shouldn’t drink and drive, done it plenty of times.  But other than that, being good and whatnot, I think that’s easy, I think really, probably just alcohol and pot.  I could stop if I wanted to, but…
I:So what’s prevented you?
R:I don’t know, pot relaxes me, I smoke it and I just hang out.  I mean I don’t even really, I mean, we have fun we just chill.  It’s not like we’re out there, doing stupid things.  We just hang out.
I:Ok. What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t know dude.  I think it’s just a feeling.
I:So, describe to me that feeling.
R:I don’t know, you just kind of know what’s right and what’s wrong just by like, well, if it’s illegal, it’s obviously you know what’s right and what’s wrong.  But, even just other things like sometimes I guess maybe you get guilt.  If you get guilt, obviously you’re knew something was wrong and you did something anyway.
I:Ok.  So feeling guilty?  And the laws of the state?  So are all of the laws, I mean, are they all morally justified, or correct?
R:I don’t know.  I’d say most of them, but one that I know isn’t right, is I don’t agree with affirmative action.  And I think I have it right, I’m not sure, but I know they give people of different races money to go to college.  Why can’t you give a white kid money to go to college?  He needs to know how to do something too, right?  That’s, I don’t know, it just…
I:So is that morally wrong, in your opinion?
R:Yeah.  It’s the same, it’s instead of being racist, it’s a reverse racist.  Either way, you’re still bringing somebody up and putting somebody else down.
I:Ok.  So what would be the morally right thing to do?
R:The morally right thing to do is if you’re going to give some people money, give everybody else money.  But if you can’t afford that, then don’t give anybody money, or make it somehow… give a chance at least to somebody, a white kid, to get money for college.  Don’t just give it to everybody else.
I:Ok.  Ok.   From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:I think mostly myself, but at the same time some from I guess from religion, some from I guess parents.  But, I think for me to actually pick my views, I mean, it has to come from me.
I:So, if I have different world views than you, but I choose them myself, am I justified?
R:Aww man.  No.
I:Why not?
R:I don’t know. No.  Are you?  I guess, I don’t know.  Let me think.
I:So hypothetically, what if I…
R:I mean, like yeah, like you get them from like law, some.  Some from the law and like others, you know, parents from teaching kids how to respect other adults, you know whether or not they’re your parent and you know them or not, you should still treat them with respect.  Now some, I think as long as they’re not really big issues, then if you have so morals are different than mine, but they’re not like really major or dramatic, or I guess, extremist, then I don’t really think it matters.

So I think everybody has this same kind of moral standards, I think some might be different, but relatively speaking, I think everybody has some morals.  Whether or not they’re different or not. column591: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on personal happiness and intuition, believes in a general moral standard influenced by personal experiences and some religious teachings, and feels that while helping others is important, it should be limited to those truly in need, such as the handicapped, rather than those who do not strive to improve themselves.

column583:
I:Okay.  And where do you think your own views of, how do you decide whether something is right or wrong, where do your views come from?
R:Um, my religion.  Um, a lot of it, a lot of my choice making and decisions is like, I see how it’s gonna affect me and how it’s gonna affect my ability to go to the temple some day or something like that, so a lot of it’s my religious beliefs.
I:Okay, so when you say that, you mean there are specific teachings that tell you what’s right or wrong, or that I mean, how is it that?
R:No, it’s all, not really, um, it just kind of like for me that’s just kind of like how I make my decisions or you know, that’s, mostly cause my, my religion, um, just cause yeah like, like a lot, probably like you said a lot of it is like the teachings, but not so much like in our, like Sunday they don’t tell us like you know this is right and that’s wrong, but it’s more like you know, you can choose cause you know, but.
I:Do you think it comes more from the people in your church or from the like the scriptures or from the religious, the church’s rules or where does it come from?
R:It’s, it’s all of it, it’s just, it’s all mixed together.
I:Okay.  And so do you think that um, like the things that you decide are right or wrong, I mean, like for example I mean the, you said that um, there’s certain things you’d have to do, you know certain choices we make so for instance stealing, you know if you, if you think stealing’s wrong, um, but what if somebody else says they think stealing’s okay, is it okay?
R:Well see that is like one of those standards things like stealing’s wrong for everyone.  And I don’t, it doesn’t, I mean, it, I don’t think it matters like who you are like, you know that’s wrong.
I:So where do you draw the line, how do you decide what things are right and wrong for everyone and what things people get to choose whether it’s right or wrong for them.
R:Um, like the bad, like things that are big like murdering someone, you know stealing or you know raping someone or like things like that.  I think that’s like where you draw the, well probably there’s like other things, those are just like the big things that I can think of that are wrong you know, for like just standard like, everyone knows their wrong for.
I:And why are those wrong for everyone?
R:Because, well—
I:Where does that come from?
R:Because  because like some things have happened to like my Mom, like she was raped and like my uncle, he’s in jail for raping and killing people, I don’t know, I just think that you know, I don’t think anybody should have to go through things like that and I just think it’s wrong for anyone to even consider it, I guess.
I:When did that happen to your Mom?
R:Oh when she was young, when she was like um, probably my age or a little younger, that’s why she spent a lot of time with her grandma.
I:Okay and so do you think that, is there um, I mean what, I know it’s, these questions might be pushing a little bit but we kind of wanna see, see what people think.
R:Oh, it’s okay.
I:But, but what is it that makes it wrong?
R:Um, what if—
I:Like if you were, if someone would say what’s the criteria by which I could, you know like I mean, say someone came to our society and had no concept of right and wrong or you know, they come from another planet, what’s the, how would they know, what’s the criteria by which they decide something’s wrong?
R:Um, how would they decide what’s right or wrong?
I:Yeah, I mean what, what things should I, if someone says I’m you know, I know nothing, I have no social knowledge.
R:
I:How do I know whether something, if I do this what, okay murder, well what makes that right or wrong, you know, how would I tell or how would I, does that make any sense?
R:Um.  It does make sense, I’m just thinking of how I can answer that. Um.
I:It’s a hard question and if you can’t answer it, that’s okay, I’m just, I’m curious what you think about what, what is it about that that makes it wrong.
R:Um, well, probably what is it about it, just I guess I would, I don’t really know, um, just doing it like um, like you’re gonna have to sit there and think about it you know and you’re gonna have to, I don’t know like if they plan or whatever, but um, you know you’re gonna have to have some thought on it and like what you’re gonna, I would think you know, you would have to think about it and everyone has a conscience and you would think that would affect them, but.
I:So is it just our conscience, like is, your, is there sort of some, some, something that, that tells us you know, something outside of ourselves that tells us it’s wrong, or is it just our conscience or is it the consequences of it?
R:I think it’s probably ourselves like, because some, like you can tell someone that’s wrong but like you said that doesn’t necessarily, they aren’t gonna say it’s wrong, but um, I think a lot of it has to do with your better judgment and um, a lot of just yeah.

column586:
I:Okay.  How do you decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Um, I just, I don’t know.  Like, I, a lot of it, I base off my religion.  Because I believe in my religion with all my heart, so, if it does, if it like is bad, like the drinking and stuff like that, well that’s just common sense for me, like a lot of the stuff is just common sense, but like when it comes to like tough things, then I’ll just like compare it to my religion and if it like it goes against it, then I know it’s wrong or it’s bad, but if it doesn’t, then I know it’s right and it’s okay.
I:Is it pretty easy or is it difficult for you to figure out if something is right or wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy.
I:Yeah, so, has it gotten easier or harder of the last couple years?
R:Um, since I kind of started, well since like I got, I drank and lost my virginity, things like that, um, those things are like hard, I was like oh, that’s okay, you know I can do it once, even though I knew it was wrong at the time, but I just wanted to do it, but now I look back and I’m just like, oh, so stupid, because I know it was wrong.
I:So, maybe things have gotten a little more complex, or?
R:Yeah.
I:Good.  Um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:What did, what?
I:What makes something right or wrong?  Like what’s the criteria for whether something is right or wrong?
R:I don’t know, just what you feel, I guess?  If you feel that it’s wrong, you know, or, just, I don’t know, really.
I:So you said, you base a lot of things off your religion, so, is there something that you would say would be criteria within your religion that makes something right or wrong?
R:We don’t really have a criteria, just like the things we’re taught, you know, like it’s not like here, this is the criteria for, if this sounds like this, then you know it’s wrong, you know, it’s just really like, if we feel it’s wrong or if something we’ve been taught is you know, it’s different, than that’s really all.
I:Do you think it has anything to do with like, um, consequences or just how it feels or the laws or?
R:Oh, it has a lot to—probably all of it.  You know?  Like a law has like consequences because I mean, everything you do has consequences!    I don’t, you don’t have to be religious to know that!  But a lot of it is like consequences and how you feel and it’s a lot, it’s a little bit of everything, really.
I:Okay, so if something has bad consequences, does that make it wrong?
R:No.
I:No.
R:No.
I:Okay.  So, are there any actions that you think are always wrong?

R:Um, well, theft is just like, I don’t know, I think that’s, that is wrong, because you’re stealing, I mean, I don’t know.  It depends, like anything, you steal anything, I mean, someone could have like got that from a gramma that passed away or someone could have put a lot of money into that or something you know, it could be valuable or something you know, just wrong, why?  And then, like, the only reason why I say like guys hitting girls is because my brother hits his girlfriend all the time, and I can’t stand it.  And um, that’s wrong because guys should never lay their hands on girls, like.

R:Yeah.  Yeah, so he’s pretty bad.

R:She’s stupid and she stays with him and she allows it, pretty much, like she doesn’t, I mean, if a guy is gonna hit me, you’re not gonna hit me again.  Like you’re never gonna see me again, but she gets hit repeatedly, they’ve been together like a year, and I’ve just been there two months at my Dad’s and I’ve seen him like just like hit her, hit her, hit her and like one time it woke me up, from sleeping, he slapped her so hard and so she, and she’s stupid, she’s absolutely, I think any girl that stays with a guy that’s gonna hit him is absolutely stupid.  So.

R:Yeah, but she’s just like, I don’t know what to do.  She’s two-faced. column588: The respondent primarily relies on personal feelings and self-reflection to determine right and wrong, noting that their moral views have evolved over time due to personal experiences and social influences, particularly from peers, while emphasizing the importance of maintaining one's morals regardless of circumstances.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I usually think about is it something I want to tell other people I have done.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It is getting easier actually.
I:Why so?
R:As I am getting older, it is getting more clear-cut to me what is good and bad.  Whether it is something I should or shouldn’t do.
I:Have your views changed in the past 2 years?
R:No.
I:Can you talk a little more about that?
R:I don’t know I just feel calmer, more grown up.  When I look back I think that was stupid.  I just try to be more responsible for what I do and think.  If I am at a party, I might not be the drunkest person there anymore.  That is not me because I don’t want to be the person that my friends tell me “oh God do you remember doing this?”  I just decided that I want to tell people what I have actually done.  I don’t feel like lying.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:How it affects other people.
I:In terms of consequences or how it makes them feel?
R:In terms of both.  Like we will go back to the money falling from somebody’s pocket. We don’t know how badly they need it.  That could be the last of someone’s grocery money you just picked up and blew on a movie night.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Oddly enough from my parents.  I consider them one of the few people I have seen in life that have tried to do the best they can to do everything right, and also one of the few married couples I have seen that they have been married like 25 years and still really happy.  I think that can’t be a coincidence.

R:I’d say it’s pretty easy for the most part.
I:Why is that?
R:It’s just… I don’t know, I guess it’s just the way I was raised, if something’s wrong, you just don’t do it.  Obviously there’s some cases where things are wrong legally but I still do them.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:I don’t think it’s really changed one way or the other.
I:Have your views changed on what’s right and wrong in the past two years?
R:No.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I guess the way people view it or whether you feel guilty or not.  In one case when I first met my girlfriend, she was only 17 and I was older, so in that aspect, legally, it’s wrong.  But we got to hangin’ out and I didn’t even know how old she was until a couple weeks down the road.  So it was kinda… but her parents didn’t care about it.  So whatever.  It’s too far at this point, it really doesn’t matter.
I:So what made it in that situation right?
R:Just the kind of girl she is and the fact that her parents didn’t have a problem with it, with me being older and I guess… I don’t know, I think that’s about it.
I:So you’ve talked a little about how you were raised, any other places where you have acquired your moral views from?  Where do you think you’ve acquired your moral views?
R:Probably my parents and grandparents growing up.  They’ve instilled pretty good morals in me, taught me what was right and what was wrong.
I:So where do you think moral views come from?
R:I guess probably personal experiences and you get some of it… every generation, you get some of it from your parents and grandparents, but they change, each generation they change.  You’re gonna look at things a little bit differently than your parents do, you’re gonna have your own morals and look at things different than what their views of right and wrong are.  I think you kinda take their morals and change ‘em how the culture has changed, to your views.
I:So where do you think your parents and grandparents got their moral views from?
R:Probably their grandparents and parents and obviously their own lives.
I:Do you think that with each generation we kind of acquire better morals?  Is it always getting better?
R:I don’t know if it’s getting better.    Just different.

It’s just… I don’t know, I guess it’s just the way I was raised, if something’s wrong, you just don’t do it.  Obviously there’s some cases where things are wrong legally but I still do them. column591: The respondent primarily relies on their upbringing and gut feelings to determine right from wrong, acknowledges the influence of social pressures from peers and family, and believes that moral views are shaped by personal experiences and cultural context, while also expressing skepticism about the role of religious guidance in decision-making.

column589:
I:Now, how would you say you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Well, I think I was raised with a decent set of ethics and morals.  And I definitely know what the difference between right and wrong is.  I don’t ever try to go behind someone’s back or stab someone in the back.  I’m not that type of person.  I just - I know the difference between right and wrong.
I:Is it generally easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Pretty easy.
I:And has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past couple of years?
R:Easier.  You learn from your mistakes.
I:So you learn from your mistakes.  And have your moral views changed in the past couple of years?
R:No, not necessarily.  I wouldn’t say so.
I:Now, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Well, I think the impact it has on others and the impact it has on society.  I mean, I would never want to make a decision that would inflict harm or pain on anyone else in any way.  I mean, obviously you make decisions that benefit you and your life.  But you never want to make those decisions at the expense of somebody else.  So it’s weighing - it’s constantly weighing that balance and the tradeoff between the costs and benefits of a particular decision given a particular situation.
I:From where would you say you have acquired your moral views from?
R:My parents.

I don’t ever try to go behind someone’s back or stab someone in the back.  I’m not that type of person.  I just - I know the difference between right and wrong. Pretty easy. Easier.  You learn from your mistakes. No, not necessarily.  I wouldn’t say so.  Well, I think the impact it has on others and the impact it has on society.  I mean, I would never want to make a decision that would inflict harm or pain on anyone else in any way.  I mean, obviously you make decisions that benefit you and your life.  But you never want to make those decisions at the expense of somebody else.  So it’s weighing - it’s constantly weighing that balance and the tradeoff between the costs and benefits of a particular decision given a particular situation.  My parents.
column591: The respondent plans to donate a portion of an inheritance to charity and invest the rest in retirement, influenced by their understanding of finance and the belief that they have time to enjoy luxuries later, while also emphasizing that their moral views, shaped by their parents, guide their decisions on right and wrong, which they find relatively easy to discern but sometimes challenging to act upon, particularly in complex situations involving friends, where they seek advice from peers.

R:I think it’s just the way you view life, and.
I:What do you mean?
R:Like the way you depict something and.  A situation, for example.  Like, if, if something’s going on and I’m not sure what, but, you have like your own sense of feeling.

R:I just usually, I, I’m aware of things and.

R:Mm, figure it out as you go along.

R:Stealing.  Like some of my friends have stolen stuff before, but.  It’s not right.

column585: The respondent makes decisions based on their comfort level, influenced by their parents' teachings about right and wrong, and believes that many kids today lack a clear sense of morality due to parental neglect, while also acknowledging the potential benefits of certain risky behaviors despite recognizing them as wrong.

column583:
I:Mm-mm.  Where do you feel like your sense of right and wrong comes from?
R:Um, well I have to go back to my parents again.  Ah, just because I’m very close to them and ah, you know they were probably, they were definitely the biggest influence on me growing up, because I’m an only child and I had such a strong relationship with them that, you know I see a lot of myself or a lot of my, my parents in myself, a lot of, a lot of their influences.  Um, I, I notice affect me on a daily basis you know and they kind of shaped the person I am.  You know they had a, a big part of shaping the person I am.  Along with ah, the times.  You know along with my generation and what I’m, what I’ve experienced in my life.  I believe those are the two biggest factors.
I:Ah, what do you think it, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  Like how, how do you know those kinds of things, or, what in particular makes something right or wrong?
R:Well, um, let’s see, well I’d say ah,  whatever, ah, you know, what, what seems to, just, what seems natural, what seems, what just seems right to the person.  Um, I think you know, everyone has their conscience certainly and just ah, you know it’s just trusting your conscience.  I think you know, there’s some things that just are inherently right and some that are, like I said, are just inherently wrong and I think everyone, you know, their conscience will, will generally lead them in the right direction.  It’s just, it’s all about following, following you know what the voice inside of you is really saying.  You know and certainly people betray that voice often times or you know, they’re let down by their conscience I guess, you know or emotions, ah, occasionally.  But in general, I think going with your conscience is what determines what’s right and wrong.
I:Mm-mm, yeah, and the, that um, that--you have examples of cases where you had to go with your conscience and, ah, and it was difficult to figure it out but your conscience guided you?
R:Ah,  I can’t, right now, I can’t think of any specific examples.  I, I don’t know, I just, I have a bad memory for things, things like that, I mean, I, I’ve had, I’m sure I’ve had to make tough decisions, I mean, obviously nothing so tough that it’s really had a huge affect on my life, I mean I’ve, I’ve had a pretty good life, I’ve never had to make any really important decisions or life changing decisions so there’s nothing that really sticks out too much in my mind.

column585: The respondent makes decisions based on what feels natural and right to them, influenced significantly by their parents' values, while acknowledging that they sometimes act against their conscience due to peer pressure and social expectations, leading to feelings of guilt about their actions such as petty theft and academic dishonesty.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Just look at my ethics and my sense of right and wrong.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I think it’s easy for me to decide. I mean when something is really wrong, I know it’s wrong.
I:Has your thinking in that way changed in the past 2 years?
R:Have my morals changed?
I:Yeah, your morals or how you think about right and wrong.
R:No, I think my moral compass has been the same for a long time now.
I:Deciding between right and wrong, has that changed or gotten easier or harder?
R:It has probably gotten a little bit easier.  I think the more you live the more you experience, the more you are confronted with decisions you have to make where there is a clear right and wrong answer.  The more instinctive or the more easier it becomes to do the right thing.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I have always believed more or less in utilitarianism, the idea that you want to do what provides the greater good for the greatest number of people.  So that is what I try to follow.  I think that each situation is unique, but in general I try not to be selfish and to think about what’s good for everyone involved and I think you just try to evaluate your options and you decide what decision has the least harmful effect and try to make the decision.  Of course there are all kinds of variables that go into each situation and decision that you have to make.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Like who did I learn my morals from?
I:Yeah.
R:My parents I suppose.  Just living in the world and having to experience a lot of different things and meet a lot of different people and learn a lot of new things.  So I think its kind of something that accumulates over time that you build on your morals.
column590: Just look at my ethics and my sense of right and wrong. I think it’s easy for me to decide. I mean when something is really wrong, I know it’s wrong. Have my morals changed? No, I think my moral compass has been the same for a long time now. It has probably gotten a little bit easier.  I think the more you live the more you experience, the more you are confronted with decisions you have to make where there is a clear right and wrong answer.  The more instinctive or the more easier it becomes to do the right thing.  I have always believed more or less in utilitarianism, the idea that you want to do what provides the greater good for the greatest number of people.  So that is what I try to follow.  I think that each situation is unique, but in general I try not to be selfish and to think about what’s good for everyone involved and I think you just try to evaluate your options and you decide what decision has the least harmful effect and try to make the decision.  Of course there are all kinds of variables that go into each situation and decision that you have to make.  Like who did I learn my morals from? My parents I suppose.  Just living in the world and having to experience a lot of different things and meet a lot of different people and learn a lot of new things.  So I think its kind of something that accumulates over time that you build on your morals.
column591: The respondent feels a moral obligation to share wealth with charities and non-profits due to the injustice in the world, believes in utilitarianism for determining right and wrong, and acknowledges that their moral views have been shaped by their parents and personal experiences, while also expressing skepticism towards extreme religious beliefs that deny personal agency.

column583:
I:Do you have some idea, what is it that makes something wrong?  Or right?
R:Not really.
I:I mean, what’s wrong with killing somebody?
R:It’s wrong.  You’re taking somebody’s life.
I:So…
R:It’s bad.
I:That’s just bad, it’s obviously bad.
R:Yeah.
I:What’s wrong with having 1,000 girlfriends?
R:Uh, it’s like, it’s immoral, because you’re cheating, you’re lying to people.
I:Okay.  What’s wrong with lying?
R:Uh..
I:I’m not saying there’s anything right with it, I’m just asking, why you think it’s wrong?
R:I don’t know, cause you’re telling somebody one thing and you’re doing another.
I:Okay, some people would probably say, so what?
R:Well, I don’t know,…
I:What would you tell them?
R:I don’t know.
I:Okay, where do you think your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:My parents, other people, other things.
I:What they taught you.
R:Yeah.  Pretty much.
I:Okay.  So, like, as you’re going about living your life and you have different choices and different options and whatever, how do you go about deciding what’s right or wrong or what you’re going to do?
R:You listen to your conscience and listen to what other people around you say.
I:So, when you consider possibilities you have, your conscience tells you this would be right or wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:And, when you say other people, what do you mean?
R:Like, your parents, your friends, other adults.
I:So, you would ask them.
R:Yeah.
I:Or just sort of pick up.
R:I wouldn’t ask them, I’d pick up…
I:Just get a sense of what they think.
R:Yeah.
column584: Not really. It’s wrong.  You’re taking somebody’s life. It’s bad. Yeah. Uh, it’s like, it’s immoral, because you’re cheating, you’re lying to people. Uh.. I don’t know, cause you’re telling somebody one thing and you’re doing another. Well, I don’t know,… I don’t know. My parents, other people, other things. Yeah.  Pretty much. You listen to your conscience and listen to what other people around you say. Yeah. Like, your parents, your friends, other adults. Yeah. I wouldn’t ask them, I’d pick up… Yeah. Not really.
column585: The respondent has a clear sense of right and wrong, influenced primarily by their parents and peers, believes that most people generally know what is good and bad, and views drug use and lying as morally wrong, while also acknowledging that social influences, such as friends and parents, play a significant role in their decision-making process.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Basically from the Bible.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:You know if it’s bad, immoral, you know, it’s not smart.  Some things, just like people run from the police instead of stopping and getting the stupid ticket.  I’ve seen that over a stupid, I mean I saw what the other day. Stupid Behavior Caught on Tape.  A guy robbed a convenience store.  The guy pushed the alarm, shut the what, the cash register, you know shut that area off with a steel door.  And the guy ran into the door and was pushing the door as hard as he could, and he didn’t see the sign on the door, for dummies like him, that said “pull”.  He was doing something wrong and that’s basically, that’s what happens.  Crime doesn’t pay.  You know criminals crime does pay, drug dealers say crime does pay, crime doesn’t pay cause you know, you die at an early age, basically.

column585: The respondent makes decisions based on guidance from God and the Bible, believes in clear distinctions between right and wrong despite societal confusion, and credits their upbringing and family discipline for their moral compass, while also acknowledging past anger issues and a desire for more freedom as they approach adulthood.

column583:
I:Do you think that that’s…well let me ask you another question, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:What I, you know, past experiences, like I’ll see it, I’ll you know, they’ll have the classes at school not to do drugs and stuff like that and then I’ve pretty much made my mind up not to do those things, so basically it’s from school, school teaches me a lot of things, to you know to do it or not to do it.
I:What makes something right or wrong?
R:Uh, I don’t know, but um, if I think it’s a good idea then I’ll do it, but if I don’t think it’s a good idea then I won’t.
I:How does that, how do you, thinking of that and based on what you were saying earlier about your friends, that you like people that are good hearted and you know that don’t do bad things to people, how do you work that out, or if you think something’s good you’ll do it.  How do you make the decision if something’s good?
R:I don’t really know, it’s just sometimes, I just know.  I don’t know it’s instinct for me.  If I’ll kind of like see it, that put myself in another person’s position that would have done the thing and you know then I’ll make up my mind and say if it’s not good then I won’t do it, but if it’s okay then I will, you know based on what my instincts say.
I:Can you give me an example of something maybe?
R:Um…kids at my school, they smoke marijuana and they’ll ask me if I want to do it and I’ll think that most people say that yeah it’s a good think to do but I don’t want to do it right now cause I’m not ready for it, and I don’t’ really want to try it cause I don’t really care that much for it, so, I’m not gonna waste my time on it.  So.
I:What about something that might potentially hurt somebody else, or maybe it doesn’t hurt someone, let’s say someone gave you an opportunity to get an A in a class but it would be cheating, how would you know whether to make, whether to do that or whether to not do that?
R:Um…I…
I:And what would you think about to come up with the decision?
R:It would um…um…(pause) well, I would do it if I was suffering in that class and it was really hard for me to do it.
I:Suffering like you knew you would be getting a bad grade?
R:If I was getting a bad grade.  Like in math right now I have an F in that class and I usually have an okay grade, last time I had like a C, but you know, if I’m really suffering and it’s really hard for me to get out of that position, then I will go ahead and take the opportunity as long as everything is okay and nothing was going to happen.
I:Yeah, in that situation, but how do you know, could you follow, do you think you might be able to use that type of reasoning and…not at cheating but say something more serious, not doing drugs, but something that could potentially hurt somebody else, like somebody robs somebody or somebody kills somebody, how do you think, making that decision, moving from and individual oh I am or I am not going to do drugs, or I am or I’m not going to cheat where it’s more about you and it doesn’t affect other people, this way it would more directly affect other people, in terms of making a decision, that whatever you did, whether right or wrong would affect somebody or hurt somebody physically?
R:I wouldn’t because I know, I wouldn’t want to hurt somebody, and I wouldn’t do something to hurt anybody, I mean if it was only going to do something to me but not to anybody else, like to hurt somebody I wouldn’t do it, cause it’s really wrong.
I:Where do you, why do you think that’s wrong?
R:Because um, compared to robbing, like if it was going to hurt somebody physically you know or financially, um, it would be messing up somebody’s life, but as in getting a good grade in the class it’s only going to be affecting me and not the school, because they’re just going to be writing it down in a grade book and um, it could affect me in the long run, but um, if I had an A, you see teachers, they pay more attention to the kids in the higher grades at my school and at most of the schools that I’ve been to, so if I had an A and the teachers had put more responsibility on me I would work really good with that.  So I could probably keep the grade up and not drop down, you know stay down there.  But I have an F in this class because you know I was, when my mom split up I had the emotional problems and stuff like that.  So.

Uh, I don’t know, but um, if I think it’s a good idea then I’ll do it, but if I don’t think it’s a good idea then I won’t. I don’t really know, it’s just sometimes, I just know.  I don’t know it’s instinct for me.  If I’ll kind of like see it, that put myself in another person’s position that would have done the thing and you know then I’ll make up my mind and say if it’s not good then I won’t do it, but if it’s okay then I will, you know based on what my instincts say. Um…kids at my school, they smoke marijuana and they’ll ask me if I want to do it and I’ll think that most people say that yeah it’s a good think to do but I don’t want to do it right now cause I’m not ready for it, and I don’t’ really want to try it cause I don’t really care that much for it, so, I’m not gonna waste my time on it.  So. Um…I… It would um…um…(pause) well, I would do it if I was suffering in that class and it was really hard for me to do it. If I was getting a bad grade.  Like in math right now I have an F in that class and I usually have an okay grade, last time I had like a C, but you know, if I’m really suffering and it’s really hard for me to get out of that position, then I will go ahead and take the opportunity as long as everything is okay and nothing was going to happen. I wouldn’t because I know, I wouldn’t want to hurt somebody, and I wouldn’t do something to hurt anybody, I mean if it was only going to do something to me but not to anybody else, like to hurt somebody I wouldn’t do it, cause it’s really wrong. Because um, compared to robbing, like if it was going to hurt somebody physically you know or financially, um, it would be messing up somebody’s life, but as in getting a good grade in the class it’s only going to be affecting me and not the school, because they’re just going to be writing it down in a grade book and um, it could affect me in the long run, but um, if I had an A, you see teachers, they pay more attention to the kids in the higher grades at my school and at most of the schools that I’ve been to, so if I had an A and the teachers had put more responsibility on me I would work really good with that.  So I could probably keep the grade up and not drop down, you know stay down there.  But I have an F in this class because you know I was, when my mom split up I had the emotional problems and stuff like that.  So.
column585: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on personal instinct and past experiences, particularly influenced by a desire to avoid negative behaviors like drug use, which they associate with their father's struggles, while acknowledging that peer pressure complicates moral clarity for others.

column583:
I:Okay.  Where do you uh, where do you think like right and wrongs come from?   Or what makes something right and wrong?   Or right or wrong, rather?
R:Well, there’s two different types of people in this kind of world and those types are that believe that only strictly go by religious laws and there’s people that only go by laws that man created.
I:Okay.
R:And sometimes those laws do not agree with each other.  Um, I don't know if you watch Law and Order, but, um,
I:I haven’t seen it much, I’ve seen it a couple times.

R:That’s uh, you’d be breaking the law and that’s where those two different laws clash and have controversy.

I mean most laws that man’s created are common sense.  You know I’m not gonna go into a store and uh shoplift. column583:

column584: Just what’s right and wrong, I can’t explain it.  I just know what’s right and wrong.
column585: The respondent primarily relies on their mother's teachings to discern right from wrong, acknowledges the relativity of morality, feels guilty about past actions like smoking and drinking, and prefers to avoid peer pressure while expressing a desire for more parental supervision.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide what’s good or bad, right or wrong in life?
R:Just how I was raised.  Follow the law.
I:Like in terms of deciding between right and wrong on a every day basis?
R:Go with what would be socially acceptable,  what I believe.
I:Is it something that has gotten easier, or in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide what’s right and wrong?
R:Pretty easy.  I don’t have any decisions that go against the law, but it might be right.
I:And has it gotten easier or harder in the last couple years?
R:Stayed about the same.
I:Have your views on right and wrong changed in the last couple years?
R:No, not really.
I:What is it that makes something right or wrong?
R:Society.
I:So it’s what people generally believe and what?
R:Yeah.
I:Do consequences matter a lot?
R:They do.  Cuz I definitely was taking a risk with the underage drinking, but I don’t use drugs cuz I don’t want a mark on that for your record, and if a business employer sees it, that’s a big mark against you.

R:I guess there’s that.
I:Do you personally, does that come in play?

R:Yeah.

R:Yeah, there’s definitely, a lot of laws are laws for a reason.  There’re some that are grey areas.  I think drinking would be the biggest one for me.

R:Probably my parents mostly.
I:Do you remember how they would talk to you about right and wrong?
R:If it was right, I got a ‘good job.’  If it was wrong, I got a spanking or a timeout or something.
I:But it was just very direct?
R:

column589:
I:Okay.  How do you normally know what’s good or bad or right and wrong in life?
R:I know, like, some good – what’s good and what’s bad, so –
I:Like, how do you know that, though?
R:I guess it’s like, you just learn it when you smaller.  And it just develop in your mind, and you just keep focusing at it and just go on from what you have learned.
I:Okay.  And do you think it’s, in general, easy or hard to know what’s right and wrong?
R:Like, for me, I say it easy for me.  But for some people, they probably got, like, a disability or something, so that might make it harder for them.
I:Okay.  But you have no – I mean it’s not difficult for you to know what the right thing to do is in a situation?
R:Yeah, it ain’t difficult for me.
I:Has it gotten easier or harder the last few years?  Like, as you get older, do you think it’s getting harder to figure out what’s right and wrong, or is it easier?
R:It should be, like, easier as you go on.
I:Okay.  Do you have an example of – like, have your views about right and wrong changed in any way over the last few years?  Have you changed your mind about things that you used to think were right, now you think they're wrong?  Or you used to think were wrong, now you think they're right?
R:Not really.
I:Pretty much the same, then?
R:Um hm.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  Like, why would something be wrong?
R:Like something that could be wrong is, like – say, like, you steal something.  And then like give it away to somebody or something.  And then, like, the person you stole it from, they’d be looking for it.  Then you tell them a lie, like, “You probably lost it or something.”
I:Okay.  Why is that wrong?  What makes it wrong?
R:Because, like, stealing is wrong because you took – that’s somebody else property.  It belongs to them.  And when you take that from them, that’s stealing.  And it’s wrong.  And that’s uh… it’s like a sin, I think.
I:Yeah.  But why is it wrong?  Like, what is it about it?  Is it because, like, I mean you – because you feel bad about doing it?  Or is it because your actions are bad for that other person?  Or is it because God says it’s wrong?  Is it because there are some rules that you should never steal like that?
R:Right.  Like, when somebody steal something, they probably don't feel bad, like, probably the first time they did it or something.  But, like, as they go down the road, they’re going to feel bad about themselves.
I:Okay.  But is it because they feel bad?  Is that the reason it’s wrong?  Or is it wrong for another reason?
R:Like, for some people, they like doing it.  And they’ll keep doing it.
I:Would you say that’s wrong, even if they like to do it?
R:Yeah.  I mean you’re still wrong.
I:Okay.  Why?  Like, is it – like, is there a rule?  Like, it’s just that’s how reality is?  Stealing is always wrong? Is that – or is it because God says it wrong in the Bible or something?
R:It’s wrong because, like, you know it’s wrong, but you just doing it just to do it.
I:Okay.  Okay.  So there are certain things you think that are absolutely right and wrong?
R:
I:Okay.  But where do you think you’ve acquired your own moral views, like, in terms of your ideas about right or wrong?  Where’d they come from?
R:Like, probably when I was, like, little or something.
I:Like, did your parents teach you this, or your grandparents, or your friends?
R:Yeah.  Parents taught me.
column590: I know, like, some good – what’s good and what’s bad, so – I guess it’s like, you just learn it when you smaller.  And it just develop in your mind, and you just keep focusing at it and just go on from what you have learned. Like, for me, I say it easy for me.  But for some people, they probably got, like, a disability or something, so that might make it harder for them. Yeah, it ain’t difficult for me. It should be, like, easier as you go on. Not really. Um hm.  Like something that could be wrong is, like – say, like, you steal something.  And then like give it away to somebody or something.  And then, like, the person you stole it from, they’d be looking for it.  Then you tell them a lie, like, “You probably lost it or something.” Because, like, stealing is wrong because you took – that’s somebody else property.  It belongs to them.  And when you take that from them, that’s stealing.  And it’s wrong.  And that’s uh… it’s like a sin, I think. Right.  Like, when somebody steal something, they probably don't feel bad, like, probably the first time they did it or something.  But, like, as they go down the road, they’re going to feel bad about themselves. Like, for some people, they like doing it.  And they’ll keep doing it. Yeah.  I mean you’re still wrong. It’s wrong because, like, you know it’s wrong, but you just doing it just to do it.   Like, probably when I was, like, little or something. Yeah.  Parents taught me.
column591: The respondent believes that understanding right and wrong comes from childhood learning, influenced by parental teachings, and while they find it easy to discern morality, they acknowledge that others may struggle; they emphasize that stealing is inherently wrong, equating it to a sin, and feel a moral obligation to help others, citing biblical teachings, while ultimately prioritizing personal happiness in decision-making.

column589:
I:Okay.  How do you normally decide on what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Because of everything I either put myself through or have been through, and what I see through other people and the choices they make.  That’s pretty much how I notice bad and good.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:No.  It’s not easy because I always want to do the bad because bad is normally the easy part, and the good part is normally the hard part.  And I struggle between them because I want to do the easy one because I am still kind of lazy and rebellious, I guess you could say.  And the part of me that wants the best and the better for every – for myself – wants the good part, so I have always struggled with that.  But I always used to take the easy way, and not it’s I am choosing the good way.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:Harder because I am trying to do right now instead of letting myself do wrong, even when I knew that there was – should have done right.  But, I mean, it’s better this way.
I:Okay.  Have your views changed about what’s right and wrong the past two years?
R:No.  No.  I don’t think they ever will.
I:Okay.  Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Opinion.
I:Do you?
R:Yeah.
I:Whose opinion?
R:Anyone’s.  And it all depends who is in it – it all depends whether that person believes how much they trust the law.  I mean everyone, I guess, would have a set – a basic set or basic degree of right and wrong that would be generally the same as everyone else’s.  But other than that, that’s pretty much opinion.
I:Okay.  So what does this kind of basic set of right and wrong, where does it come from?  Like what are some of the things that it involves or includes?
R:Unrightful murder, theft, rape – well, I guess, yeah, rape, definitely.  I think that’s all I can think of right now.
I:Okay.  Okay.  So –
R:Anything to harm anyone else or bringing wrong or bad to someone else.
I:So where do those kinds of set of things that are always wrong come from?  I mean why is it that way?
R:People’s choices in life.  That’s pretty much it.
I:Okay.  What makes certain things ultimately right or wrong?
R:The impact that they have on everyone else.
I:Okay.
R:And the impact it has on yourself and the world, generally.
I:Okay.  So where did those ultimate rights and wrongs come from?
R:People.  People’s choices, what they see as, I guess – what they see as what should be done or what shouldn’t be done.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Just through what I see and have experienced myself.
column590: Because of everything I either put myself through or have been through, and what I see through other people and the choices they make.  That’s pretty much how I notice bad and good. No.  It’s not easy because I always want to do the bad because bad is normally the easy part, and the good part is normally the hard part.  And I struggle between them because I want to do the easy one because I am still kind of lazy and rebellious, I guess you could say.  And the part of me that wants the best and the better for every – for myself – wants the good part, so I have always struggled with that.  But I always used to take the easy way, and not it’s I am choosing the good way. Harder because I am trying to do right now instead of letting myself do wrong, even when I knew that there was – should have done right.  But, I mean, it’s better this way. No.  No.  I don’t think they ever will.  Opinion. Yeah. Anyone’s.  And it all depends who is in it – it all depends whether that person believes how much they trust the law.  I mean everyone, I guess, would have a set – a basic set or basic degree of right and wrong that would be generally the same as everyone else’s.  But other than that, that’s pretty much opinion. Unrightful murder, theft, rape – well, I guess, yeah, rape, definitely.  I think that’s all I can think of right now. Anything to harm anyone else or bringing wrong or bad to someone else. People’s choices in life.  That’s pretty much it. The impact that they have on everyone else. And the impact it has on yourself and the world, generally. People.  People’s choices, what they see as, I guess – what they see as what should be done or what shouldn’t be done.  Just through what I see and have experienced myself.
column591: The respondent makes decisions based on personal experiences and observations of others, struggles with the temptation of choosing the easier wrong over the harder right, believes in the importance of helping others regardless of their past actions, and combines various influences, including personal happiness, parental advice, and religious beliefs, to guide their moral choices.

column583:
I:Uh-huh.  What ah, what do you think makes something right or wrong?
R:Probably the law, if it says in the law you can’t do it, then you know it’s wrong mostly because you get in trouble for it.  What’s right is probably the opposite you know.  Like if it’s wrong to break out someone’s windows then the right is not to.  So basically the government.
I:So like you say, say if there wasn’t a law against breaking out someone’s windows would you think that it would still be wrong to do it?
R:Yeah, it would still be wrong to do it, but probably a lot more people would do it.
I:I mean, I mean, does what’s wrong depend on what’s defined as what’s law or does it depend on something else do you think?
R:Um, it depends on how your mom and dad raised you too.  If they raised you, you know, they bring you up, tell you what’s right and wrong.
I:Right.
R:You pretty much know what’s right and wrong from their beliefs.
I:Do you think what’s right or wrong for a person to do depends on how they were raised or is it the same for everyone even if people don’t know it’s the same?
R:I think it depends on how they were raised, cause I’ve never really been out of state really, but I hear a lot in Chicago, you know people do stuff and I don’t know if they were raised right or not, but a lot more crimes are down there.
I:Really.  Like if you think someone is raised wrong or raised different, raised a different way do you think that ah, like if they didn’t if they didn’t been raised to do something, but do you think it would still be wrong for them to do it like even if they had been raised differently?
R:Um, depending on what it was, like if it was religious, then it wouldn’t be wrong, but you know if their mom just didn’t really care about them and makes a child feel bad and they don’t really care so they do stupid stuff.
I:Right.
R:And they don’t, and their mom never really taught them right and wrong so they don’t know other than the law.
I:Right.  So you think they wouldn’t necessarily be responsible for it,
R:They’d be responsible for what they did yeah, but I don’t know I guess their moms should have, if they wanted to have a kid they should have raised it differently.

I think it depends on how they were raised, cause I’ve never really been out of state really, but I hear a lot in Chicago, you know people do stuff and I don’t know if they were raised right or not, but a lot more crimes are down there. Um, depending on what it was, like if it was religious, then it wouldn’t be wrong, but you know if their mom just didn’t really care about them and makes a child feel bad and they don’t really care so they do stupid stuff. And they don’t, and their mom never really taught them right and wrong so they don’t know other than the law. They’d be responsible for what they did yeah, but I don’t know I guess their moms should have, if they wanted to have a kid they should have raised it differently.
column585: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on the influence of peer pressure and the desire to avoid trouble with the law, while also considering the values instilled by their parents and the consequences of their actions, emphasizing the importance of doing the right thing as defined by both legal standards and personal upbringing.

I guess the laws, does a decent job of it. It is, if you got caught. Yeah. No.  TV. I don’t know.  Probably that, though.
column588: The respondent expresses a desire to gamble the inheritance for more money and indicates that their understanding of right and wrong is largely intuitive and influenced by societal norms, while also believing that moral obligations exist to help others, although they struggle to articulate specific moral principles or examples.
column589:
I:So, alright.  So, how do you normally know- decide or know what is good or bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t really think about it that much.  Whatever’s good’s good, I don’t really, I’m not really high on morality or any of that stuff.
I:Okay, what do you mean?
R:Unless you do something really horrible, you know, kill someone, it doesn’t really matter right or wrong.  Everything’s, do whatever you want.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to make decisions about things like that?
R:Easy, I don’t really think about it that much.
I:Do you think your views about morality, about right and wrong, have changed over the past couple years?
R:Uh, (pause) no.  I mean, it’s not like I analyze everything “Is this right?  Is this right?...”
I:Okay, so, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  You talked earlier about killing, or things like that.  What do you think it is that makes something wrong or right?
R:You know what, I’m not really too (pause) I don’t know if anything- I really don’t think there’s that much- I don’t put much value on what’s right what’s wrong.  Things have to be egregiously wrong for me to ask- it’s like nothing’s really right or wrong except stuff that’s really really bad.  Like, rape, killing, you know.
I:What about stealing?  Like your roommate came home and said “Dude, I stole ten games from you.  Do you care about that?
R:Oh, like if it wasn’t from me?
I:Well, what if it was for you?
R:No, if it wasn’t from me though.
I:Oh, if it wasn’t from you.
R:Yeah like he didn’t steal 10 of my games he stole them from the store?  Yeah, I wouldn’t care.
I:Would you think it was cool?
R:No, not really.  But would I care?  No.
I:What if he stole a car?
R:(laughs) Same thing, you know.
I:As long as he didn’t steal your car.
R:Right as long as he doesn’t steal my car.  Would I encourage it?  No, but- what people do really doesn’t bother me.  I don’t really care what other people do with their lives as long as it’s not me they’re stealing from.
I:Here’s a situation: let’s say that you were- I mean this is gonna sound a little crazy but I want to see what you’d think- so, let’s say like your roommate was seeing this girl or whatever, and she breaks up with him, and he goes and burns down her house.  What do you think about that?
R:Yeah that’s-
I:She’s not there, she’s away for the weekend.
R:Yeah, but that’s bad enough that it falls into the category of things that are really wrong.
I:So burning down someone’s house.
R:Yeah, you gotta go to  you know?
I:Okay, I just wanted to see where the line was.
R:But I mean like, if, let’s say, took a piss in her gas tank or something like that, that wouldn’t
I:What if like, he threw a brick through her windshield?
R:Depends on how bad it was like, if she banged like 10 other guys behind his back and all that over five years (laughs) then maybe the brick through the windshield would be justified.  If she was just like “Yeah well I want to get- you know I can’t stand this guy anymore” then it wouldn’t.
I:So you’re saying- so, if he was getting back at her for something really bad-
R:Yeah, but…
I:So where do you think you’ve gotten your views of right and wrong from?
R:I don’t know.  Being on this planet for 23 years.
I:Some people think that it’s sometimes okay to break moral rules if it works to your advantage and you can get away with it.  What do you think about that?
R:I mean, I don’t really have moral rules.

column591: The respondent believes that moral decisions are generally easy and not deeply analyzed, asserting that only egregiously wrong actions, like killing or rape, truly matter, while expressing indifference towards the actions of others as long as they don't directly affect him, and he acknowledges that morality can be subjective but maintains that certain actions, like terrorism, are universally wrong.

column589:
R:I don’t know I think there is a general, I think we’re all born with right and wrong, not because it’s in our brain, but because in the environment we grow up in, I grew up in an environment that taught me right and wrong and I believe that those things are truly right and wrong.
I:Do you feel like as you get older that deciding what is right or wrong has gotten easier or harder?
R:Harder.
I:Any reason?
R:I don’t know like made, like my friends are pressuring me to get a fake I.D.  Should I get a fake I.D.?  Well, in my standpoint, from their standpoint it’s not that big of a deal, from my standpoint it’s a federal offense.  If I get caught with it, I can go to jail.  So it’s tough for me to make that decision because they’ve never got caught with it, it’s no big deal to them, they don’t know anyone that’s ever been caught, there’s always that risk out there.
I:You feel like there’s more things like that as you get older?
R:Yeah.
I:In general, do you think for you it’s easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Pretty wrong.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right thing or a wrong thing?
R:I just think it’s ingrained in us.  we somehow know that what we’re about to do, there’s something inside of us all that says you’re going to get in trouble if you do this, there’s a risk you’re taking by doing this.  Is it a big risk or is it a small risk?  And that’s how you determine whether or not you’re going to do.
I:So do you think it’s the consequence, the end result of it, or something more internal?
R:More internal, but also the consequence has an affect on it, too.

R:Still feel bad about it, but depends what it is really.
I:Uh-huh.  And what do you think, what do you think makes that wrong?
R:Just like what if they did that to you, you’d feel bad.  It’s hurting somebody’s feelings.
I:Right.  So mainly is it kind of a golden rule type thing?
R:Yeah, kind of.
column584: Come from? Probably my parents and my friends. I learned a lot from my brother cause he did everything wrong. Both. Like he got a bunch of DUI’s and stuff and that kind of turned me away from drinking and he got bad grades and he could’ve had a soccer scholarship but his grades. Um,  I don't know.  Just the fact of being mean or the getting in trouble for it. Yeah. Still feel bad about it, but depends what it is really. Probably like, If some people think that it’s not bad to make fun of somebody or stuff like that. I think it’s wrong to make fun of somebody behind their back. Just like what if they did that to you, you’d feel bad.  It’s hurting somebody’s feelings. Yeah, kind of.
column585: The respondent generally relies on the consequences of actions, particularly the fear of getting in trouble, to determine right from wrong, acknowledges social influences from parents and friends, and reflects on personal experiences with a brother's poor choices to shape their understanding of morality.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide what is good and bad, or right and wrong?
R:I don’t know.  That’s a hard question to answer.
I:You don’t have any kind of ideas?
R:If it is going to be bad to somebody or it’s not morally right, it is probably wrong.
I:Do you have a hard time deciding between right or wrong?
R:No.  Not at all.
I:Has it gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Probably easier.
I:Why would you say that?
R:I was a little rebel when I was younger.
I:What would you say actually makes something right or wrong?
R:I guess it is personal belief.  Whatever somebody feels is right or wrong.  Just they way you’re raised, I guess.
I:So you would say that you got your moral beliefs from your parents?
R:Yeah.
I:So you would say that you got your moral beliefs from your parents?
R:From my parents and who I hang out with.
I:Who do you think is the bigger influence your parents or your friends?
R:I don’t know.  That’s a hard one.  Both about the same in different areas.
I:Do you think that has changed at all?
R:No.
column590: I don’t know.  That’s a hard question to answer. If it is going to be bad to somebody or it’s not morally right, it is probably wrong. No.  Not at all. Probably easier. I was a little rebel when I was younger.  I guess it is personal belief.  Whatever somebody feels is right or wrong.  Just they way you’re raised, I guess. Yeah.  From my parents and who I hang out with. I don’t know.  That’s a hard one.  Both about the same in different areas. No.
column591: The respondent believes in making decisions based on personal beliefs influenced by their upbringing and social circle, prioritizing happiness in their choices while acknowledging the importance of moral responsibility to help others, although they also recognize the complexity of right and wrong depending on circumstances.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, I, I think it comes from like, a Christian foundation and also sometimes just instinct.  And stuff, like personal conscience and things like that.  Like if I, if I, like if it’s, if it’s things like, okay, well do, do I go out and you know take the care and not come home until one in the morning or do I just stay at home and not do that, it’s like sometimes a personal instinct is that well of course that’s not the right thing to do and stuff.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think it’s, it’s how it affects both the person, that’s involved with making like, choosing and how it would affect everyone else. Like everyone else with the person.  Like, like, if it’s, if it’s constructive not only to you but also to everyone around you, like if you, if it’s, if it’s something like, okay well do I kill this person or not?  Well, killing them might be good for you because then you feel better but it doesn’t help, it doesn’t help everyone else because then if you get locked up or you get the death sentence and stuff, then all the people that care about you and stuff, it’s not going to be constructive for them.
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?   Are there a set of rules or is it just more of this kind of instinct and basic understandings or?
R:Uh, I, I just say that like the set in stone stuff I would say would come from the bible and, and uh, my foundation for faith.  And then sometimes like, sometimes people complain about how, like the bible doesn’t talk about listening to music and things like that, sometimes then, like I’ll try to find things that relate to the same thing, or that I’ll like go in, like, like I’ll analyze it and figure out which way it weighs and kind of think about what my conscience is saying so.
I:So do you actually sort of, uh reference the bible in terms of questions like that come up?
R:Yeah.
I:Whether it’s music or, are there other things besides music say, that, that might come up with?
R:Um, um, sometimes, let’s see.  I don’t know sometimes people like, like sometimes like I’ll hear people that will be like, well smoking and stuff isn’t talked about in the bible and things like that, so what do you do about that, and things like that.  Some of the things that like in the times the bible didn’t nec – didn’t really exist and stuff.

column585: The respondent has a clear sense of right and wrong rooted in a Christian foundation and personal instinct, believes that morality is not entirely relative, and feels guilty when not fully honest with their parents, while also expressing that their decision-making is influenced by the potential consequences of their actions and the importance of constructive outcomes for themselves and others.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good or bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Uh, well first thing I’d probably just look to what I know of the Bible, whether the Bible specifically talks about it or not.  Then, uh, probably, what I would like, think about what my parents would say about it.  And then, uh, I’d just try and weigh the pros and cons, uh, just kind of look at it, is this beneficial or detrimental, or is it beneficial to be but maybe detrimental to others.
I:And, do you think that in general it is easy or hard to decide between what is right and wrong?
R:Uh, for the most part I’d say it’s fairly easy for some of the more difficult questions.  Mostly stuff dealing with relationships, I mean where there really isn’t a right or wrong answer.  I mean, it’s just a lot harder just because, I mean, even if you ask people you will get a lot of different responses.
I:And, would you say that trying to make those kinds of rights and wrong decisions or decisions about right and wrong have gotten easier or harder over the last couple of years?
R:I would think easier just since I have had more time having to make decisions.  I have got a lot more precedence, not really that I record every time I have made a decision.  I have kind of set these railroad tracks to follow.  If something comes up that I have kind of experienced before, like if I didn’t do before I’ve got a better chance of not doing it because I haven’t done it before.
I:What is it that makes something right or wrong?
R:Uh, I’d say the biggest thing is how it affects someone personally.  How, what is really does to, to like, not really like your personality but like your character.  Uh, like, I mean if it’s like a question of do I steal this, just, is it something like are you basically going to become a person that is going to steal?  Is it going to be multiple times?  Is it later going to cause you trouble?  Is it, uh, is it going to give you a jaded view of everything?  Is it going to shift your perspective in many ways?  Just like this greater picture of, outside of this one event what are the implications and I would just say that, and that just compared with, comparing it to the normal ideas or right and wrong, as seen in the Bible.
I:Tell me about that.  Right and wrong as seen in the Bible.
R:Just, uh, if it hurts others, uh, more in a selfish way than in a just way.  Just because it’s impossible not to hurt some people.  Uh, if it’s, if it is in violation of, just good morals things like that.  Things like if it’s stealing or, or extensive lying or things that hurt your body like drugs…
I:So you would say, let me read this back to you and you say whether you agree or disagree with it.  The first time you said you’d be concerned with how it would affect the individual.  So, in terms of their character,
R:Right.
I:If they steal something they might continue on in that path.  It might erode at their character in some way.  There was another layer that says that there are certain things that are…
R:Right.
I:Right and wrong because that’s in the Bible?
R:Right.
I:Ok.  Um, and, so those would be just off the top of your head?  The general kinds of things like stealing, uh, you mentioned stealing,
R:Yeah, stealing,
I:What other kinds of things?  I mean, I don’t need an exhaustive list but,
R:I mean, a lot of things that are like criminal offenses, stealing, murder, uh, uh, like lying, ah, just the things that will hurt your body like drugs and drinking.  And just, yeah, a lot of thing in that field that that really in essence cause negative effects.
I:And, and, you’re sort of belief that these are wrong would be because of their effects of because they are prohibited in the Bible?
R:Uh, I would say both in the idea that they are prohibited in the Bible because of their effects.  And, ah, and in the case of things that aren’t mentioned in the Bible that is when you just look at the effects of them and say well how do these compare.
I:Um, where do your moral views come from?  Where have you picked those up?
R:Uh, I would say a lot of them are founded from the Bible just growing up in a Christian home and from various Christian schools.  That was definitely like the cornerstone of everything.  And then, uh, like learning to reason like growing up and being more knowledgeable.  Just, uh, building on that and uh, basically comparing everything to that.  Like, if it wasn’t specifically in the Bible, comparing it to something that might relate or trying to see how it relates and then just, uh, using my reasoning in that to figure it out.  And if it was ever anything really complicated than I would either talk to my parents or talk to someone I could confide in.
