And if it was ever anything really complicated than I would either talk to my parents or talk to someone I could confide in.
column588: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on their parents' advice and biblical principles, weighing the consequences of their actions, and believes that moral views should not change with societal shifts, emphasizing the importance of character and the impact of choices on oneself and others.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide what’s good or bad, or right or wrong in life?
R:Probably three main things I do is probably just – the first thing I’d probably do just naturally is think about it reflectively.  Just like, what do I think, what do I feel about this?  Is it a logical choice kind of thing?  But I’d probably consult – alongside that I’d probably then just consult the spiritual beliefs.  Is this religiously – does this have impact?  Is this against what I believe?  And the third one is probably just consult friends, and peers, and adults.  Since I do have close relationship with my parents I usually ask them a lot of questions, and I just like to just hear a lot of points of view.  Unfortunately, I did this when I was deciding to go or not go to grad school, and unfortunately about every other person had a different opinion.  So at the end of it, half of the people I consulted said to go, and half of them said not to.
I:So it wasn’t that helpful.
R:Yeah.
I:Is it usually very hard for you, or is it easy for you to figure out what’s right and wrong, to decide?
R:It’s usually pretty easy to decide.  It becomes harder than when I necessarily have to make a choice about which I want to do because sometimes – an easy example is I have – the meal plan at school offers me ten meals in the cafeteria, whereas I could easily just hop in my car and go to Burger King, and when I only have $40 in a bank account, the right choice is probably just to get the free meal that’s in the cafe, but I might not necessarily actually do that, so.  Other than – yeah, I’d say figuring it out is usually pretty easy.  I’d say the time decisions are hard is when there’s not necessarily a right answer.  Where it’s like, do I go to grad school, or do I just pursue a job.  Or neither of those is inherently wrong, so.
I:And has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the last couple years since we last talked?
R:It’s probably gotten easier just as – I probably cemented more of my beliefs, and just who I am.  So it’s probably a lot easier and more natural for me to kind of have a precedent of decisions that I’ve made in the past.
I:Have your views changed in the last couple of years?  About right and wrong issues?
R:If anything I’d say I’ve become more considerate and compassionate for other people, and not necessarily as judgmental as I have been about the decisions they make, so.
I:What do you think that comes from?
R:Some of it maybe just because the friendships I’ve had have grown.  I’ve had them for longer, and I know the people more, and I’m more, I don’t know, maybe in touch with their lives personally that I try to be more supportive in everything they do.  And part of it too might just be, like, my major’s a lot of working with people with disabilities either communication, or cognitive level disabilities, and even in that you learn a lot about multicultural issues, and different views, and I think part of that may have instilled kind of a sense of acceptance for all different people regardless of what they’re doing and who they are, so.
I:What is it you think there is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think the easiest – or maybe it’s not the easiest, but a good way to examine it I think is to compare it against just what the Bible says religiously.  Unfortunately with the evolution of society, the Bible doesn’t necessarily talk about everything that we deal with today.  And so I think in those instances it’s best to – even if it’s – if you can’t find anything explicitly corollary is to consult the scriptures, and then just kind of think about it logically, and retrospectively what is – what are the positive and negative affects of this particular action or decision, and then just kind of – and if that doesn’t even seem explanatory, just like at that point then saying, “Well, what other people do I know, or other people that have similar values of me, what kind of decisions have they made in the past in looking at are there precedence for other people that have gone through this.”
I:So in general, you would frame your decision making process in understanding what’s right and wrong that there's a standard out there, and you reference then the Bible, and then if that’s not clear because it’s not – it doesn’t give every possible connotation, then you might look to other people.  Do you ever – would you have conversation with the people about that?
R:Yeah, I would definitely talk to peers about it, especially for those more kind of gray areas.  I definitely would consult peers or adults that have more experience in life, and just be like, what is – “You might be able to see this in a greater spectrum than I can, so.”
I:And where do your moral beliefs come from?  Where’d you get your moral beliefs?
R:I’d say probably from four places.  Probably from – definitely from my parents and what – and how they raised me.  From just the Bible itself, and just what it said.  And then from – part of it would also be from just my own experiences in life, and what I’ve come to learn, and just what’s been revealed through personal experience.  And then the last one would probably just be just kind of those who kind of like in instance like education, but not necessarily schoolbook so much as just educators and mentors.  Either just adults that have come alongside me in life, or even teachers.

Is it a logical choice kind of thing?  But I’d probably consult – alongside that I’d probably then just consult the spiritual beliefs.  Is this religiously – does this have impact? Probably from – definitely from my parents and what – and how they raised me.  From just the Bible itself, and just what it said.  And then from – part of it would also be from just my own experiences in life, and what I’ve come to learn, and just what’s been revealed through personal experience.  And then the last one would probably just be just kind of those who kind of like in instance like education, but not necessarily schoolbook so much as just educators and mentors.  Either just adults that have come alongside me in life, or even teachers.
column591: The respondent emphasizes a decision-making process rooted in religious duty and social responsibility, prioritizing giving to charity and consulting spiritual beliefs and parental advice, while also reflecting on the importance of personal experiences and the influence of peers in understanding right and wrong.

column583:
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Huh?
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:(long pause) I don’t know.  I guess if my parents told me it was wrong it would be wrong.  But I don’t know what would make it wrong.
I:So just like…
R:I’ve just been taught that things are wrong.
I:Right, right, so what if your parents told you something was wrong and someone else’s parent’s told them something different was wrong.  Would there be different –
R:I’d have to respect my parents. I’d have to respect my parents and follow what they thought was wrong.
I:Right.  Do you think the other persons parents were wrong or is it more kind of relative to them or?
R:No.  Some of my friends are like that.
I:So, some of your friends that you’re talking about, their parents smoke weed for example.
R:A couple.
I:So their parents probably don’t think it’s wrong to smoke weed?
R:(silence)
I:No.  So for your friends would it be wrong?
R:Mine says it is because she’s in church.  If she wasn’t in church it would be like a 90 out of 100 that she would end up letting me, that she wouldn’t care, that she would let me.
I:How do you know in general what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Just what my parents tell me.
I:There’s more than that isn’t’ there?  I don’t know.
R:Like what do you mean?
I:Like, I don’t know, cause it sounds like, you said you try different stuff to see what it’s like…
R:I do but, marijuana, there’s stuff that can do to you first time.  I don’t know, uh, if I ever went back to lacing a cap I’d go to cocaine again because it was more like spaced out.  So I’d probably do that again, but other than that, no other stuff.
column584: I know smoking is wrong (laughs) I know smoking is wrong.  Like, I know back mouthing my parents is wrong, I don’t know, drinking’s wrong.  I don’t know.  Stuff like that. It’s against the law.  And you got to be able to drink when you’re 21. No, not if the law didn’t say that. I don’t know.  Cops don’t follow it.  They’ll sit there and roll a fatty in their car. (Laughs).  I had a couple friends that a cop, a black cop and a white cop took a sack off of him and gave him a dime back.  They didn’t question him or nothing.  They just Flint cops. Huh? Cops sell too.  My buddy TJ was buying stuff off a cop for a while. Huh? (long pause) I don’t know.  I guess if my parents told me it was wrong it would be wrong.  But I don’t know what would make it wrong. I’ve just been taught that things are wrong. I’d have to respect my parents. I’d have to respect my parents and follow what they thought was wrong. No.  Some of my friends are like that. A couple. (silence) Mine says it is because she’s in church.  If she wasn’t in church it would be like a 90 out of 100 that she would end up letting me, that she wouldn’t care, that she would let me. Just what my parents tell me. Like what do you mean? I do but, marijuana, there’s stuff that can do to you first time.  I don’t know, uh, if I ever went back to lacing a cap I’d go to cocaine again because it was more like spaced out.  So I’d probably do that again, but other than that, no other stuff. What do you mean? Uh-huh. No, it shouldn’t be the same for everybody. Everybody has a different ways of living.  So they go by what they feel comfortable with.
column585: The respondent believes that their understanding of right and wrong is primarily shaped by their parents' teachings, acknowledges the influence of laws on their moral judgments, and feels that societal perceptions of morality can vary, particularly regarding issues like drug use, which they view as less harmful than other substances.

column583:
I:Where, ah, where would you say your views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, a little bit from my parents I guess and just from things in society I guess.  And—
I:Like, okay, keep, keep going, sorry.
R:Um, I don’t know and just from miscellaneous parents and stuff and people and I don’t know, just certain things and people.
I:Okay but we, can, can you give me of an example of a situation where you know, you had, maybe a tough choice and you weren’t sure of what was right or wrong to do and kind of how you made up your mind?
R:Um, ah, if I should um go somewhere after school with my friends even though my parents told me I couldn’t and so I decided that just going and then getting, being grounded for a couple days would be the better choice for me cause it was like a big event, event and I had fun.
I:Right.
R:And that’s it.
I:Okay.  So, that, okay, so most of the things you come up are, you know whether your parents want to do, whether your parents give you permission or not, that’s kind of the?
R:Well mostly my parents do give me permission but sometimes I’m not allowed because I have to go somewhere or I’m grounded and so like the one time I was just talking about, I was um, my Mom just wanted me to come home, I don’t know why, just stupid reasons so I decided just to go, I only got grounded for like a day so it wasn’t that big of a deal.
I:So you think it was worth it.
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.
R:And then I wasn’t supposed to go to the next day, too, but I still went cause my Dad didn’t know that I, cause he drove me, he didn’t know that I wasn’t allowed to go cause my Mom didn’t talk—
I:He didn’t know you were grounded?
R:Cause my Mom was away and she didn’t want me going.  And so, he didn’t know I was grounded.
I:What, what, what, what was the thing that your Mom didn’t want you to go to?
R:Um, a basketball tournament, not for me for, or, yeah, my friends were all going and so I wanted to go.
I:Yeah, just to watch.
R:Yeah and to have fun, we usually, and we went over to the mall, just hung out, went to the library and stuff like that.

And— Um, I don’t know and just from miscellaneous parents and stuff and people and I don’t know, just certain things and people. And that’s it. Yeah. And then I wasn’t supposed to go to the next day, too, but I still went cause my Dad didn’t know that I, cause he drove me, he didn’t know that I wasn’t allowed to go cause my Mom didn’t talk— Cause my Mom was away and she didn’t want me going. Yeah and to have fun, we usually, and we went over to the mall, just hung out, went to the library and stuff like that.
column585: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on what is fun and beneficial for them, often considering the potential consequences on their relationships and parental permissions, while acknowledging that their views of right and wrong are influenced by their parents and societal norms.

R:‘cause you should know what you look at and how you choose it, what you do with your life, whatever you see and you know it’s wrong, then you know it’s wrong.

R:sometimes it’s easy, most of the time it is easy ‘cause you know what’s wrong and what’s right.
I:tell me an example of when it’s hard?
R:probably one of them days when you don’t feel like going to basketball practice, you just wanna go home and go to bed, but you gotta look into your life and see if this is really one of the things you want to do, you better go. That’s probably one of the hardest ones I had, or an essay you had to do, that one day and you only had two days to do it and you waited till the last day to do it, knowing you should have done it before.

R:in between easy and hard ‘cause you have classes, well when I was in high school where if you didn’t do it that day, you might as well say forget it you’re not graduating, so it had to be hard for me to say, I’m gonna do it right now.

R:no I said . So.

R:no.

column583:
I:Okay, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, I guess from on my own, just thinking of what’s right or wrong, nobody’s ever told me nothing, this, something that’s always right or something’s always right or wrong, it’s just, it’s just something that I figured.
I:Um, so how do you decide or know what’s good and bad, right and wrong?
R:Um,
I:This might help if you have examples.
R:Let me see, um,  say, say it again?
I:Yeah, um, we’re talking a lot about like what’s right and wrong,
R:Uh-huh (yes)
I:So when you decide like what’s, how do you know or decide like what’s good and bad or what’s right and wrong, like if you can give me examples of times in which you’ve had to make decisions like that or that you just knew.
R:Um, I know one time, my mom, we was at this park and my mom tells me that, we had, I had my bike at the park, my mom told me that but um, going to this area where a big street was, and me and my friend, we went to that busy area and we, we got hit by a car.  And so I think, you know,
I:You both got hit by a car?
R:Yeah, we was on the same bike.  And so um, I think you know, I knew what was right, I knew what she had told me, but I still did what was wrong.
I:Why?
R:Um, I don't know, you know, it’s just, I think, I think that was half way normal, too, I don’t, I, I, I mean I knew it wasn’t good, but I think it was, we all go through, I know we all go through something like that, you know, we do things we weren’t supposed to do.  And then I, I had to deal with the consequences.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good or bad or right or wrong in life?
R:I go with my intuition.  Whatever I’m feeling, if it feels right, go for it.  If it doesn’t…
I:And you find that pretty reliable?
R:I do, I do.
I:So how easy or hard is it for you to decide, “this is right,” or “this is wrong?”
R:It’s very easy, very easy.  I mean, and I’m not saying that when I know something is wrong, I may still do it.  And I kind of love that I’m at the point that I can be able to know that, say that, and still do the wrong thing and be able to do the wrong thing and still stand behind it and be like, “I messed up, I knew I messed up.”  I’m not saying that I’m perfect.
I:Where do you think your intuition comes from?
R:My experiences.
I:Like, for example…
R:Like, when I moved to Rich Square* my stepfather was a hard worker, so he expected me to be a hard worker.  He expected me to get up in the morning, do my chores, do what I had to do around the house.  And that had a lot to do with what I think is right and wrong with that.  Now I can’t lay in the bed.  I feel like a man period.  This is something I feel.  A man should get up, in the morning, and do something.  So most of the time my experiences, the things I’ve been through, you know, I just try not to make the same mistakes twice.  If I feel like it’s right, then I go with it.
I:Now, how, by the way, did you get along with your stepfather in general?
R:We get along.  I was young and I was lonely for a male role model, so, I don’t think he was the person for the job, but…
I:Because, why not?
R:I don’t think he was a good person.  I don’t think, I mean, he had his values, his work ethic.  That’s what I took from that experience.  Him as a person, he just, you know, he was mean, you know, and I didn’t think he was a good person at all.
I:And did he and your mom eventually divorce?
R:He died.
I:He died, oh my.
R:That’s what brought us back to Greensboro.
I:Okay, has it gotten harder or easier in the past 3 years to decide between right and wrong?  Or is it the same?
R:It’s definitely gotten easier.
I:Why is that?
R:I guess because I kind of, I guess, growth and maturing, kind of now realize, now I realize I am who I am.  And there’s nothing I can do about that or anyone else, so I walk with my head up, and I could care less what you think, what the next person thinks, I could care less.  So that makes it easy to make decisions.
I:So you just do what you think is right and you don’t care what others…And when you’re younger it’s different than that?
R:When you’re younger you do what you think is acceptable to who you think is important.  And right now I’m not saying I’m a rebel without a cause, I’m a do me whatever, whatever.  It’s just that I feel like it’s important for a man, if he’s going to say something, if he’s going to do something, be man enough to stand behind that, rather than, if it’s wrong and you find out it’s wrong, be man enough to apologize and accept that you messed up.  But you have to, I think that’s the problem that with my generation, we don’t stand behind, we’re not responsible.  We don’t stand behind our responsibility, that’s why you have a bunch of single women, raising sons, because these men are not standing behind their responsibility with that.  And I feel like that’s the issue.  So, right or wrong I try to stand behind what I do.  That’s not to be overly confident, that’s just trying to be responsible.
I:And how did you think you come to that, that’s a pretty mature understanding.  What brought that to you or how did you learn that?
R:Once again, my experiences.  Coming up, I just always though a man was weak if they would do something and wouldn’t own up to it, you know what I’m saying.
I:Did you have specific negative role models.  Like people you saw doing that?
R:I did.  Like my father.  He wasn’t around.  He had responsibilities.  I always thought he was weak for that.  And my stepfather, he would do things, you know, and he would act like it was right when I felt like it was obvious that it was wrong.  And just that showed me what I need to do.
I:So we’ve been talking about moral right and wrong.  What is it that actually makes things right and wrong?  What ultimately is the source of morals?
R:Speaking for myself?
I:What do you think?
R:It’s for me, for me, it’s what God, what the bible says.  What I feel like “Would this make God happy?”  That’s how I judge my life.
column590: I go with my intuition.  Whatever I’m feeling, if it feels right, go for it.  If it doesn’t… I do, I do. It’s very easy, very easy.  I mean, and I’m not saying that when I know something is wrong, I may still do it.  And I kind of love that I’m at the point that I can be able to know that, say that, and still do the wrong thing and be able to do the wrong thing and still stand behind it and be like, “I messed up, I knew I messed up.”  I’m not saying that I’m perfect. column591: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on intuition shaped by personal experiences, particularly influenced by a strong work ethic instilled by their stepfather, while also emphasizing the importance of moral responsibility to help others, guided by their belief in God and the Bible, despite expressing a reluctance to identify strictly as a Christian due to concerns about the authenticity of some who label themselves as such.

column589:
I:and do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong?
R:You know like it’s just a feeling that you get, if you know it’s wrong. You know it might be some bad consequences.  You get that feeling, you know you’re about to do something wrong.  That’s how I know.
I:And in general is easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Sometimes it’s hard, it’s the temptation, like sometimes, I like want something and I might have to do the wrong thing to get it and it just might be a battle between should I do it or shouldn’t I do it.  Sometimes it’s hard.
I:and has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the last couple of years?
R:I think it got easier because I don’t want to go to jail or nothing like that, so like when I was younger, I need to just think because I’m gonna do a certain thing.  I’m just gonna go ahead and do it because I wanted something.  Now that I’m older though I know that there are a lot of bad consequences to some of the decisions we make.  So I make ‘em wisely.
I:And so, you mention that consequences are basically what makes something right or wrong? What kinds of consequences makes something wrong?
R:If you could go to jail for what you want, then what you’re doing in wrong.
I:ok, and are there any other situations where maybe you wouldn’t go to jail for it, but you feel like it’s still wrong?
R:Not really, well, if you’re doing something wrong, most likely you won’t go to jail for it.  Just something major.
I:Ok, and from where have you acquired your moral views?
R:My mother.

That’s how I know. Sometimes it’s hard, it’s the temptation, like sometimes, I like want something and I might have to do the wrong thing to get it and it just might be a battle between should I do it or shouldn’t I do it.  Sometimes it’s hard. I think it got easier because I don’t want to go to jail or nothing like that, so like when I was younger, I need to just think because I’m gonna do a certain thing.  I’m just gonna go ahead and do it because I wanted something.  Now that I’m older though I know that there are a lot of bad consequences to some of the decisions we make.  So I make ‘em wisely.  If you could go to jail for what you want, then what you’re doing in wrong. Not really, well, if you’re doing something wrong, most likely you won’t go to jail for it.  Just something major.  My mother.
column591: The respondent makes decisions based on a mix of intuition regarding right and wrong, influenced by their mother's moral teachings, and considers the consequences of their actions, particularly the potential for jail time, while also expressing a belief in the importance of helping others without looking down on them.

column583:
I:Where do you think you get your ideas about what’s right and wrong?
R:Of what my family is gonna think about me.  That’s how I got mine. And like if I do this, my family is gonna think I’m a failure and along that line. (interruption) oh, there’s my sister.
column584: Of what my family is gonna think about me.  That’s how I got mine. And like if I do this, my family is gonna think I’m a failure and along that line. (interruption) oh, there’s my sister.
column585: The respondent struggles with moral decisions, often prioritizing family perceptions over honesty, feels guilty about lying to their mother regarding an injury, believes in clear distinctions of right and wrong influenced by family expectations, and reflects on the consequences of actions like cheating and substance use while maintaining a sense of independence from parental supervision.
column586:
I:Okay.  How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I look at the pros and cons.  Like, okay, this is gonna put me in this situation, this will put me in a better situation.  I just do the pros and cons and what the consequences are with them.
I:Okay, so do you think you’re pretty good about taking time and thinking things through like that, or do things happen pretty quickly and—
R:I take time, sometimes if I know that it’s not gonna hurt me, I’ll take the risk, like with the boyfriend status thingy, I kind of took a risk with Eric* and it’s been going good so far.  I just kind of said, okay, well I’ve known you for a while, I know the pros and cons and what you have and haven’t done, so.  That was, that was one of the jump thingys that I took, but that’s the only one, so far.
I:Okay, how hard or easy do you find it, to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s more easier to decide the right, because of the way I was raised.  I was, instead of getting yelled at and spanked, my Mom always sat, my Mom and my Dad always sat me down and explained to me why this was wrong, why this was right.  So, that’s.
I:So you think you have the tools to work things out?
R:Because they always told me and explained why this is bad and this is good.
I:Do you think deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or harder over the past couple years?
R:Lately it’s gotten easier, but like six or seven months ago, it was really hard for me.
I:What was the difference?
R:Um, I was with a different person and he was always like controlling me and I couldn’t make my own decisions and I had to struggle with them and now it’s more like, okay, Eric* lets me think my own way and I let him think his own way.  And he tells me if it’s right or wrong or not, so.
I:Yeah.  What do you think it was that kept you in that relationship?
R:Um, his little sister kept me in that relationship.
I:How so?
R:Because every time that I leave, she wouldn’t eat for two or three or four days, nobody could get anything down her.
I:How old is she?
R:She’s five.  And nobody could get anything down her and then when I came back, she’d just eat and eat and eat, so that’s what kept me there for two and a half there, in that relationship, was his little sister, so.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, if it’s going to hurt somebody or help somebody, I think, is right and wrong.
I:Okay.  Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Yes, there’s always something wrong with, I think, always something, there’s always gonna be something you, small or big, always gonna be something a little wrong with the decision that you make.  Like it hurt somebody else but helped another person.  Or lately that’s how it’s been with me.  Because of leaving Curtis* it hurt his little sister.  Getting together with Eric* hurt Curtis* and made things better for me, so.
I:So, how do you decide then, when you have things that have a little bit of wrong in them?
R:I look at the pros and cons more, I thought, okay, well my life with Eric* is gonna be better because he’s not gonna call me, he’s not abusive, no matter what, he’s the type of person that opens doors and doesn’t let you spend any money but his, but lately we’ve been using both of ours to fix his car, but that’s what, that’s how, what made my decision to get together with him.
I:Okay.  From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Um, looking at, looking at my older siblings and what they’ve done right and wrong in life.  Because I’m the baby of the family and watching them go through their struggles and their problems, made me like choose a different path than theirs.
I:Can you give me some examples of specific problems you’d seen them in, and you’ve stayed away from it?
R:My brother um, became an alcoholic and my sister hasn’t worked in 25 years and has really done nothing.  So I stayed away from those two things.  And those were the two biggest issues.  Especially the alcoholic one.  I’ve never, I drink sometimes, like maybe I don’t know, once every three months or something, with good friends or a birthday party or something, but that’s about it.  Nothing else.  I don’t do any drugs or.  My brother got into drugs and my sister started popping pills and I haven’t done, I’ve stayed away from that.
I:What do you think is wrong about that, makes it wrong in your mind?
R:It could hurt, it makes you wrong in your mind, and it also can hurt your body, physically and mentally.  Because I know it hurt my brother really mentally, until recently, until he got off of it.  And my sister, I think it hasn’t, her not working and spending everybody else’s money but hers has made her, like if I don’t get this money I can’t, I can’t live.  Why can’t you go out and make your own money and use your own?  That’s the way I figure it.
column587: I look at the pros and cons.  Like, okay, this is gonna put me in this situation, this will put me in a better situation.  I just do the pros and cons and what the consequences are with them. I take time, sometimes if I know that it’s not gonna hurt me, I’ll take the risk, like with the boyfriend status thingy, I kind of took a risk with Eric* and it’s been going good so far.  I just kind of said, okay, well I’ve known you for a while, I know the pros and cons and what you have and haven’t done, so. And nobody could get anything down her and then when I came back, she’d just eat and eat and eat, so that’s what kept me there for two and a half there, in that relationship, was his little sister, so.  Um, if it’s going to hurt somebody or help somebody, I think, is right and wrong. Yes, there’s always something wrong with, I think, always something, there’s always gonna be something you, small or big, always gonna be something a little wrong with the decision that you make.  Like it hurt somebody else but helped another person.  Or lately that’s how it’s been with me.  Because of leaving Curtis* it hurt his little sister.  Getting together with Eric* hurt Curtis* and made things better for me, so. I look at the pros and cons more, I thought, okay, well my life with Eric* is gonna be better because he’s not gonna call me, he’s not abusive, no matter what, he’s the type of person that opens doors and doesn’t let you spend any money but his, but lately we’ve been using both of ours to fix his car, but that’s what, that’s how, what made my decision to get together with him.  Um, looking at, looking at my older siblings and what they’ve done right and wrong in life.  Because I’m the baby of the family and watching them go through their struggles and their problems, made me like choose a different path than theirs. My brother um, became an alcoholic and my sister hasn’t worked in 25 years and has really done nothing.  So I stayed away from those two things.  And those were the two biggest issues.  Especially the alcoholic one.  I’ve never, I drink sometimes, like maybe I don’t know, once every three months or something, with good friends or a birthday party or something, but that’s about it.  Nothing else.  I don’t do any drugs or.  My brother got into drugs and my sister started popping pills and I haven’t done, I’ve stayed away from that. It could hurt, it makes you wrong in your mind, and it also can hurt your body, physically and mentally.  Because I know it hurt my brother really mentally, until recently, until he got off of it.  And my sister, I think it hasn’t, her not working and spending everybody else’s money but hers has made her, like if I don’t get this money I can’t, I can’t live.  Why can’t you go out and make your own money and use your own?  That’s the way I figure it.
column588: The respondent plans to use an inheritance for college, influenced by their grandmother's assurance of a college fund, and makes decisions based on pros and cons, personal experiences, and the desire to help others, particularly their nephews, while reflecting on the moral lessons learned from their upbringing and relationships.

column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are clear-cut, influenced by their upbringing and religious teachings, but they sometimes choose to act against their better judgment for social acceptance or personal enjoyment, reflecting on the consequences of their actions and the importance of not causing harm to others.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:A lot of times I use the whole idea of the whole golden rule, I think do unto others what you do unto yourself and what you would want done to you.  That’s pretty much the basis of everything for me in terms of morality.  And that kinda used to be black and white for me, but now not to make exceptions, but there are a lot of circumstances.  I think there are three things that are never okay in any circumstance.  Things like murder, murder or rape; heavy stealing, not like I'm stealing this bread because I'm starving, but someone kidnapping or something like that-that’s never okay.  But I guess I can understand, like I would say murder is the same all the time.  If somebody robs you and has a gun to your head and you find yourself murdering in self-defense,  whereas a few years ago I probably would have said that’s the same thing.
I:So killing someone in self-defense would be peripheral.
R:Right.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy. I just kinda go by feeling.  And I decide if I don’t-I mean a lot of times, I guess I think about it with myself, but it’s my gut feelings, like if I feel that this is going to do something then I know it will be wrong if you do it.  A lot of times I do it anyway, but I know it’s wrong.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:I think it’s gotten easier.
I:Why?
R:Experience I guess, I feel I’ve had more experience of things over time.
I:Have you views changed in the past few years?
R:Between right and wrong?
I:Yeah.
R:Yeah, I think so. I think I’ve become more open to other possibilities of right and wrong, I don’t think it’s always one thing or the other.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Again, to go back to the whole idea, if I wanted to do whatever the action is, what I would do is think if that would cause anybody else an injustice for whatever reason.  That’s how I would decide, I guess.
I:What do you mean by injustice?
R:I guess wrongful, but anything that would hurt them physically or emotionally.  And be resolved in something, like an idea or a thought or whatever that wasn’t reasoned or decided upon as being the
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:I guess it’s kinda a combination of my upbringing, religious views and other people, like not my knowledge of other people’s religious views and their upbringings.
I:Do you think that God is the source of morality?
R:I think, yeah I do, but I think that there isn’t just like god is symbolic of pretty much… I think that every people in every culture and religion has, even polytheistic people, have that Father god figure, like that Father figure and I guess it doesn’t have to be male, but just that one head honcho guy and that is god.  So there’s one god for Christians and one god for Jewish people, even Hindi and even Buddhists they have that Buddha and that’s the big figure.  I think that even the Christian god is just a coalition of all those gods, like all those figures come together, so yeah I agree that morality comes from god.

column591: The respondent would use an inheritance of $100,000 to pay off loans and support their parents due to a sense of obligation, while their moral decision-making is guided by the golden rule, gut feelings, and a belief that morality stems from a universal connection to a higher power, with a strong emphasis on the importance of helping others and the need for mutual tolerance among diverse groups.

column583:
I:Uh-huh and where do your views of right and wrong come from?
R:I guess like church and my family, or and just common sense, I mean, you know if you go to the store and you’re like man, I could take this.  Then you’re like but is it really worth going to jail over it, I mean like common sense just tells you not to do stuff, too, but a lot of it is my morals from church and even my family morals like things that they taught me like you know I said I wasn’t raised in a church family, but at the same time, my parents were very big on you know this is right and this is wrong and just save yourself the hassle.  Don’t do it.
I:Uh-huh.  You’ve talked some about right and wrong in terms of the consequences and knowing what’s going to happen.  Is there anything else that makes something right or wrong?  Or maybe tell me more about those consequences, what, how they,
R:Well like, I guess with my dad, like it was always think about your consequences before you make a decision.  Like he would always tell me that because no parent likes to punish their kid, but you have to get punished when you do something bad, you know it’s just the way it goes, so as I got older and you know the older you get, the bigger your decisions become and then the bigger your consequences are gonna be.  So you know like if I chose to cheat on a test and I got caught or if I chose to go off and not come home until an hour and a half later, then I would get grounded, and you know like the more I would push the envelope, the bigger my consequences were, and you know the more stuff that would be taken away from me, and I guess, you know as I’m getting older now and you know I’m getting closer to an age where I do get caught doing illegal stuff, then my parents can’t bail me out, so,
I:Uh-huh, okay, um, any examples of how you decide or how you know what is good or bad, right or wrong in life?
R:Well like if I go to a party.
I:Uh-huh.
R:And I’m hanging out with all my friends and like I, I will never do drugs.  Like I don’t care.  You could chase me around a room with anything and I’m just not gonna do it.  I’m very set in my ways there.  But I’m offered it all the time.  And I think it’s just how you deal with that that lets people know that hey, I’m serious.  So, you know for me, when somebody offers, it may be tempting because they all look like they’re having a lot of fun, but I’ll just be like no, no thanks.  And they’ll leave me alone because I’m not you know like you shouldn’t do that, you know it’s their choice, but I know inside my head, I’m like no, you know don’t do that or I’ll, you just get that gut feeling like man, if I do this, something bad’s gonna happen and so I just decided to go with that.
I:Uh-huh.
R:I don’t always go with that like I know that sometimes I screw up but I try my best.

column585: The respondent makes decisions based on a combination of intuition, moral teachings from their family and church, and the consideration of consequences, while also acknowledging the influence of friends and the importance of standing up for their beliefs despite social pressures.

R:Yeah.

Yeah.
column585: The respondent navigates moral dilemmas primarily by trying to avoid conflict with peers, relies on childhood teachings from their mother about right and wrong, and feels guilty when not reporting friends' wrongdoings, while also acknowledging that societal expectations around morality can vary among different social classes.

column585: The respondent primarily relies on advice from close friends and guidance from parents to navigate moral dilemmas, believes in absolute right and wrong due to religious convictions, and feels guilty about actions that conflict with parental expectations, though they do not personally feel bad about some actions deemed wrong by their parents.

column589:
I:And um, how do you usually decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um, I think back a lot about what my parents have taught me over the years.  My mom taught me a golden rule; treat others the way you want to be treated.  That’s pretty much my entire life, that’s how I do everything.  I always treat people the way I want them to treat me.  That’s kind of what we say our religion is, so that’s kind of how I differentiate between what’s right and wrong.  You know, how to treat people, how to act in society.  Mostly I just know like stealing is bad.  Not stealing is good.
I:So do you feel like for you personally that that’s easy or hard for you to do?
R:It’s easy.
I:And as you get older do you think it gets easier or harder?
R:I think it gets easier.  I mean there are some gray areas on the law and what’s right and wrong and everything but for the most part, once you’re an adult you should know you don’t kill people, you don’t, you try not to screw other people over you treat them the way you want to be treated.  That’s it, that’s all life should bring.

That’s it, that’s all life should bring.
column591: The respondent expresses that they would use an unexpected inheritance to secure housing, invest, and support their boyfriend's business, while they make decisions based on their parents' teachings about treating others well, and they recently faced a dilemma regarding inappropriate behavior at work, seeking advice from family to navigate the situation.

column585: The respondent believes that while they have a clear understanding of right and wrong, they feel that many people today know the difference but do not care about the consequences of their actions, attributing their own moral views largely to their parents, and expressing guilt over past wrongdoings like cheating and shoplifting, while also acknowledging the influence of peer pressure in their decisions to engage in drinking and drug use.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I go by religion a little bit.  Religion, and sometimes I’ll just go by, like I look at the consequences.  The consequences are, look like they’re going to hurt someone, then I’m not going to do it.
I:Tell me what you mean by like you go by religion?
R:Like religion will say like uh, you know like, you can’t use certain words in vain or something like that.  I can’t use God’s name in vain, or you can’t lie against your brother, so I go by religion.
I:And in terms of consequences, what do you mean by that?
R:Like if I know something is going to make my mom mad, I won’t do it.  Or if it’s going to make one of my friends hurt, I won’t do it.  So I look at the consequences first.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s easy, but sometimes it can be like real hard.
I:How can it be hard?
R:Like, cause like, sometimes I don’t really trust like what religion says.  Cause like, I feel like, like, I don’t know it seems like a lot, like it’s supposed to be like a sin to go to Las Vegas, but then like gambling, so I feel odd about certain things like that.  I feel like some things are twisted a little bit.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:I think harder.
I:Harder?
R:Yeah, cause like religion, now that I know what’s wrong in religion, I’m kind of using religion a lot more, so the things that like I used to do before I don’t do now because of religion.  So it’s like, I feel like things are changing.
I:So it’s harder because you, cause your religious involvement is telling you that certain things are wrong even though there’s things that you used to do, and now it’s telling you that some of those things are wrong and you might want to choose to do those anyway even though religion
R:Yeah cause I did it before and it didn’t, there was no problem.
I:Yeah.
R:But now it’s like bad for religion, so I’m like, oh, okay.  I’m not sure if it is right or wrong, so I just try to go on.
I:So you try to not do the things that your religion says are wrong?
R:Yeah, try to go with religion.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  You’ve talked about consequences, you’ve talked about religion, what is it about the certain things that make them right or wrong?
R:Um, well, like when we hurt someone, or if they’re bad for you, I know that like, I think the thing that’s always coming up is like drugs.  And I look at that, it can hurt me, it can hurt me a lot.  I can die from it, so, I look at it like that.  Like what it can do to me, and what it can do to other, like it will make my mom real, real mad.  It can change our relationship by a lot.  So I avoid that.
I:Do you think it’s mostly the consequences that makes something bad or is it something else?
R:Um, I know it’s against the law, but lately I haven’t really been worried about the law.
I:Yeah.
R:So I’d rather worry like about my mom than the law.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?  Some things that no matter what are always wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:Like what?
R:Like stealing.  I think stealing is like real bad.  Stealing or cheating or, doing drugs.
I:What is it that makes these things wrong?  Stealing and cheating and then those sound a little bit different than taking drugs, but tell me why those things in and of themselves would be wrong?
R:Well to me stealing is like real, it hurts, it hurts when it happens to you and it makes another person feel good, and I think if it makes you feel good and it takes away some control from someone else, it’s like, it’s wrong.  And I don’t know I go by religion on that too you know.  Cause like, it says like you can’t steal from other people you know.
I:Where do you think you’ve gotten your moral views from?
R:Um, I think from my mom and from this religion.
column587: I go by religion a little bit.  Religion, and sometimes I’ll just go by, like I look at the consequences.  The consequences are, look like they’re going to hurt someone, then I’m not going to do it. Like religion will say like uh, you know like, you can’t use certain words in vain or something like that.  I can’t use God’s name in vain, or you can’t lie against your brother, so I go by religion. Like if I know something is going to make my mom mad, I won’t do it.  Or if it’s going to make one of my friends hurt, I won’t do it.  So I look at the consequences first. It’s easy, but sometimes it can be like real hard. Like, cause like, sometimes I don’t really trust like what religion says.  Cause like, I feel like, like, I don’t know it seems like a lot, like it’s supposed to be like a sin to go to Las Vegas, but then like gambling, so I feel odd about certain things like that.  I feel like some things are twisted a little bit. I think harder. Yeah, cause like religion, now that I know what’s wrong in religion, I’m kind of using religion a lot more, so the things that like I used to do before I don’t do now because of religion.  So it’s like, I feel like things are changing. Yeah cause I did it before and it didn’t, there was no problem. But now it’s like bad for religion, so I’m like, oh, okay.  I’m not sure if it is right or wrong, so I just try to go on. Yeah, try to go with religion.  Um, well, like when we hurt someone, or if they’re bad for you, I know that like, I think the thing that’s always coming up is like drugs.  And I look at that, it can hurt me, it can hurt me a lot.  I can die from it, so, I look at it like that.  Like what it can do to me, and what it can do to other, like it will make my mom real, real mad.  It can change our relationship by a lot.  So I avoid that. Um, I know it’s against the law, but lately I haven’t really been worried about the law. So I’d rather worry like about my mom than the law. Yeah. Like stealing.  I think stealing is like real bad.  Stealing or cheating or, doing drugs. Well to me stealing is like real, it hurts, it hurts when it happens to you and it makes another person feel good, and I think if it makes you feel good and it takes away some control from someone else, it’s like, it’s wrong.  And I don’t know I go by religion on that too you know.  Cause like, it says like you can’t steal from other people you know.  Um, I think from my mom and from this religion.
column588: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on the consequences of their actions, influenced by their religious beliefs and the desire to avoid hurting others, while also reflecting on the impact of social influences from family, particularly their grandmother.

column583:
I:Okay, where do you think your own views of what’s right and wrong come from?
R:I don’t know .
I:Where did you, where did you learn that certain things and certain things are wrong?
R:By listening to my parents.
I:Your parents.
R:Yeah.
I:Anything else?
R:No.
I:Mostly your parents?
R:Yeah.
I:So, um, what do you think it is that would make something right or wrong?
R:I don’t know.
I:Like um, if you, if your parents tell you something’s wrong, why do you think it’s wrong?
R:Cause it is .
I:Okay, do you, do you have any way of knowing how you would decide what’s good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Yeah.
I:How would you go about deciding?
R:Just like think about it.  I don’t know how, I don’t know really .
column584: I don’t know . By listening to my parents. Yeah. No. Yeah. I don’t know. Cause it is . Yeah. Just like think about it.  I don’t know how, I don’t know really .
column585: The respondent makes decisions by thinking things over, primarily influenced by their parents' teachings about right and wrong, and believes that while people generally know what is right and wrong, they often fail to think critically about their actions; they also expressed a belief that cheating and substance abuse are wrong due to the potential consequences, and they feel adequately supervised by their parents.
column586:
I:Okay.  So, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:I think it over.  Just decide.  Like my parents always say I’m more mature for my age, because I always think of what’s going on before I do it.
I:Okay.  So, in general would you say it’s hard for you to decide between right and wrong?  Or is it pretty easy?
R:It’s pretty easy.
I:Okay.  And has it gotten harder or easier over the last couple years?
R:It’s gone easier.
I:Easier?  Why is that?
R:Because I know what’s going on, I understand the stuff.
I:Okay.
R:And I’ve usually seen it happen to one of my friends or my family so it’s like I basically know what to do.
I:So, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Well, I’m not sure.  I’m just, I kind of understand it, like, like if I want to go out and I don’t tell my parents, then I have to think it over.  Like, my parents are usually understanding about that stuff, so I can usually come to them and ask them and they usually say yes, so stuff like that.
I:Okay, so if somebody said, hey let’s go do this, and you said, no I don’t want to do that because I think it would be wrong, what would it be that was making it wrong?  Would it be, like because it’s against rules, or is it about whether or not you’d get caught, or how your parents might feel, or? What do you think helps you think through whether something is right or wrong.
R:Well, it’s about all those.  It’s like the rules and stuff.  I usually follow them.
I:Is there any one of those that takes priority for you?
R:Well, it’s just knowing if it’s bad or wrong and stuff like, because of school and stuff, like they’ve given us examples about what happens if, when like you don’t do it and you do do it, so yeah.
I:Okay.  So, are there any actions that you think are always wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:Like what?
R:Like drugs.
I:Drugs are always wrong.
R:Yeah.
I:And why would drugs be wrong?
R:Because, like if you do something that’s like not good for your body then it can really mess you up.
I:Okay, so because, they’re wrong because they might hurt you?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay, is there any other, is that what makes them wrong, in the fact that they have the potential to hurt you?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.  So where do you think you have acquired your moral views of?
R:Family and like family experiences that have gone on.
column587: I think it over.  Just decide.  Like my parents always say I’m more mature for my age, because I always think of what’s going on before I do it. It’s pretty easy. It’s gone easier. Because I know what’s going on, I understand the stuff. And I’ve usually seen it happen to one of my friends or my family so it’s like I basically know what to do.  Well, I’m not sure.  I’m just, I kind of understand it, like, like if I want to go out and I don’t tell my parents, then I have to think it over.  Like, my parents are usually understanding about that stuff, so I can usually come to them and ask them and they usually say yes, so stuff like that. Well, it’s about all those.  It’s like the rules and stuff.  I usually follow them. Well, it’s just knowing if it’s bad or wrong and stuff like, because of school and stuff, like they’ve given us examples about what happens if, when like you don’t do it and you do do it, so yeah. Yeah. Like drugs. Yeah. Because, like if you do something that’s like not good for your body then it can really mess you up. Yeah. Yeah.  Family and like family experiences that have gone on.
column588: The respondent plans to use an inheritance of $100,000 to buy a car to secure a job, influenced by their parents' lack of transportation, and believes that moral decisions are guided by personal reflection, family experiences, and societal norms, while also acknowledging the relativity of right and wrong.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right or wrong in life?
R:I don’t know I guess from experience would be the way to do it.
I:Personal experience?
R:Yeah, for the most part.
I:Do you think as you get older that it’s easier or harder to decide the right thing to do?
R:I think when you get older it’s easier because your parents aren’t there to constantly criticize you and your friends are always there for you and stuff so it’s easier, I think, as you get older.
I:Okay and um, so for you personally do you feel like it’s an easy or a hard thing to make those decisions?
R:I think it’s probably easier, depending on the subject.  Like if it was relationships it probably be kind of hard but if it was like schooling and stuff it would probably be easier.
I:And what is it that you think makes something right or wrong?
R:I'm not sure, I guess probably what it is and stuff like, I don’t know.
I:Like do you think it’s consequences or laws or?
R:I don’t know, I really don’t know.
column590: I don’t know I guess from experience would be the way to do it. Yeah, for the most part. I think when you get older it’s easier because your parents aren’t there to constantly criticize you and your friends are always there for you and stuff so it’s easier, I think, as you get older. I think it’s probably easier, depending on the subject.  Like if it was relationships it probably be kind of hard but if it was like schooling and stuff it would probably be easier.  I'm not sure, I guess probably what it is and stuff like, I don’t know. I don’t know, I really don’t know.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on personal experience to determine right from wrong, faced a dilemma regarding a racially different partner influenced by parental views but ultimately chose to follow her own feelings with support from siblings, and believes that as she matures, decision-making becomes easier due to less parental criticism and more support from friends.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:I think from my parents, they’ve helped me a lot to see you know, what’s right from wrong, and see the difference and stuff like that.  Like when I make decisions, I kind of think of them and my family, you know, and how it’s going to affect them as well, not just myself, like I try not to think just of myself, you know like I’m not just like oh my god, if I do this, my dad’s gonna be embarrassed, it’s just like I know it’s gonna hurt my dad, you know not those kinds of things, not really like oh, it’s gonna embarrass my mom and stuff like that you know.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:The consequences.  Like how it’s done, too, like, if you’re doing something like say I was like most students like, most teenagers know like the difference between like right and wrong, you know I think they do, they just don’t follow it, it’s like, if there’s, there’s a lot of teenagers that smoke that smoke weed and stuff like that you know do drugs and stuff like that and they do it and they know the consequences, they know they’ve heard the stories, you know they’ve seen it, their friends do it, maybe someone else is doing it you know in their family and stuff like that they’ve seen the consequences, I don't know , I think they just want to like be, like I don’t know why it’s considered cool doing it or whatever, but they obviously got that image of it in their mind and they’re like oh, it’s cool to do it, I’m gonna do it, where it’s right or wrong, you know and I just, I don't know , I don't know.
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I just think of the consequences of it, like if I know it’s gonna do me wrong, like it’s gonna do me wrong, then I just won’t do it.
I:Like you shoplifted, and-
R:Yeah, I know  that was a bad mistake.
I:That had bad consequences.
R:That was a bad mistake.  I don't know what I was thinking, but yeah, I did it.  I knew it too, but I was like, I won’t get, I won’t get in trouble.  I just had that, I was like ah, I won’t get in trouble, I won’t I won’t.  Cause she kept telling me, it’s not, it’s not gonna be, yeah, you’re right.  I’m not gonna get in trouble.  I’m not gonna get caught.  What are the chances of me getting caught in this big old store, you know? Yeah, but ah, yeah, I got caught.
I:Pretty high, I guess.
R:Yeah  now I know.

column585: The respondent reflects on a past experience of shoplifting influenced by a friend's suggestion, acknowledges the consequences of that decision and the embarrassment it caused, and emphasizes that her understanding of right and wrong is shaped by her parents' teachings, while also expressing feelings of guilt for not being completely honest with them about her actions.

column583:
I:Okay and where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Uh, what do you mean?
I:Where do you, how do you know what’s right and wrong?  And where do those, what tells you that what’s right and what’s wrong.
R:Oh, I grew up with a lady that always told me what’s right and what’s wrong.  It was my Aunt Luenda,
I:Uh-huh.
R:She always told me that you can always see someone’s right and wrong. If you see someone getting messed up or someone’s abusing someone, you know it’s wrong.  And sometimes it’s, it’s just obvious.  It’s just, in your heart you know it’s right or wrong.  And when you see something you know it’s right or wrong.
I:And how do you know what’s right or wrong for you?  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Something that’s just odd.  Like if a kid is getting abused and you know he’s going to school hit, even though he didn’t do something wrong, it’s kind of wrong.  Because punishment shouldn’t always be through pain. That’s what I think.  I think that’s wrong.
I:And so, so it’s about…
R:It’s about other people getting afflicted by something.  It’s that, oh I say that no one should be punished really.  I don’t like,
I:So you think it has to do with hurting other people or something like that?
R:Yeah, if it’s hurting someone else it’s wrong.  If it’s hurting anyone else it’s wrong.
I:And why is that?
R:Because people don’t really, most people don’t deserve to get hurt.  I don’t see people getting hurt is right no matter what.
I:What makes, what is it that makes hurting someone else wrong do you think?
R:The fact that, I can’t really explain that but I would know if someone really hurt me, it would really hurt me emotionally, and I think that’s wrong because I know how that feels and I wouldn’t want anyone else in the world to feel that way.
I:Okay.  Um, can you give me some examples maybe from your life that you’ve seen maybe something that you thought was really wrong?  Or maybe experienced?
R:I’ve seen lots of uh, fights at school that I think is wrong.  Kids get picked on, and you know they get stuff stolen.  I think a lot of stuff that goes on at school is wrong.
I:What school do you go to?
R:Uh, Glen Curtis.
I:It’s a middle school?
R:Yeah.
column584: Uh, what do you mean? Oh, I grew up with a lady that always told me what’s right and what’s wrong.  It was my Aunt Luenda, She always told me that you can always see someone’s right and wrong. If you see someone getting messed up or someone’s abusing someone, you know it’s wrong.  And sometimes it’s, it’s just obvious.  It’s just, in your heart you know it’s right or wrong.  And when you see something you know it’s right or wrong. Something that’s just odd.  Like if a kid is getting abused and you know he’s going to school hit, even though he didn’t do something wrong, it’s kind of wrong.  Because punishment shouldn’t always be through pain. That’s what I think.  I think that’s wrong. It’s about other people getting afflicted by something.  It’s that, oh I say that no one should be punished really.  I don’t like, Yeah, if it’s hurting someone else it’s wrong.  If it’s hurting anyone else it’s wrong. Because people don’t really, most people don’t deserve to get hurt.  I don’t see people getting hurt is right no matter what. The fact that, I can’t really explain that but I would know if someone really hurt me, it would really hurt me emotionally, and I think that’s wrong because I know how that feels and I wouldn’t want anyone else in the world to feel that way. I’ve seen lots of uh, fights at school that I think is wrong.  Kids get picked on, and you know they get stuff stolen.  I think a lot of stuff that goes on at school is wrong. Uh, Glen Curtis. Yeah.
column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are clear and derived from personal experiences and teachings from their Aunt Luenda, emphasizing that actions causing harm to others are wrong, while also expressing a strong opposition to war and drug use based on the consequences they have observed.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good or bad, or right or wrong in life?  Oh there goes the trash.
R:Oh, I’ll get it after.  I’d say a little bit of gut feelings.  Sometimes – it’s hard to explain, but you know – without anyone telling you, you know what feels right or wrong.  Even if you have to lie sometimes, you know it would bring about a better conclusion.
I:And how do you – in general, how hard or easy is it for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I’d say it’s very easy.  I’m quick to do what’s right.  And I usually – if I know I’m doing something wrong, I hesitate more than once.
I:And has that gotten easier or harder over the last few years?
R:It’s gotten really easy.  I feel like the more nicer things I do, the more things I do that are right, that the outcome is a lot better.  I never have anything – nothing ever comes bad out of doing something right.
I:And is that why it’s gotten easier?  Because over the past, the result –
R:Yeah.  Because I know that will happen, so I have no problem doing the right thing.
I:Has your views about right and wrong changed over the last couple years?
R:I feel a little bit more like those who do wrong almost get closer to their goals than those who do right.  But I’m still for doing right.
I:What do you think it is that actually makes something right or wrong?  Kind of like, how do you get that gut feeling?  What’s that all about?
R:I think it’s – well, the gut feeling comes from the fear of something bad happening.
I:To you or to someone else?
R:Or to someone else, yeah.  Because it’s been the times where it’s been, like, do I do this?  And I try to imagine, can it hurt me?  It’s okay if it hurts me as long as if things don’t get out of control or if, I think, no one gets hurt.  It’s that type of – it is a gut feeling, but it’s mostly based on a good outcome.  If the outcome is very good, you know, I’ve gotta kinda weigh it.  If I don’t do it, things can get bad.  But if I do it, things can get good.  And if it weighs out pretty well, then I’ll do it.
I:Are there specific kinds of things?  Or is it just, you know, physical or emotional hurt?  Or what is it in terms of what happens to you or somebody else that would be bad?  What do you mean by that?  Just, you know, maybe an example or two.
R:Well, I know, like – well, a recent example, I’ve had a friend, she was very distressed.  And people feel like when someone’s in distress, just leave them alone.  And I feel like she was going into her own little cave and, you know, just crying.  And I kind of confronted her, and people didn’t want me to confront her.  They are like, “You are just gonna make things worse.”  But I felt like it was a gut feeling that to confront her and find out what was wrong with her was right.  And I confronted her, and she let it out.  And she – it was almost immediately as she let it out, she got better.  And things like that.  It’s almost like you feel like you should do it, then I just – if I feel like I should do it and it’s right, then I gotta do it.
I:Where do you think you’ve gotten your moral views from?
R:We always – we talk about that as a family topic.
I:Really?
R:And we – no one knows.
I:Really?
R:Yeah.  Because my mom is very – she is very aggressive.  And my stepdad is a little bit sneaky sometimes.  So it’s like, who did he get it from?  And it’s like I guess I learned from watching the right things to do the wrong – I mean I learned from watching the wrong things to do the right things.
I:Okay.  So it’s sort of a – I don't know what to call it – maybe a negative example.
R:Yeah.
I:That’s interesting.  So in terms of values that you have, you know, what you know is right and wrong, you watch what your mom and stepdad do.
R:Uh-huh.
I:How does that – what do you think about – is that the same or different in terms of how you actually view things?  Or –
R:Yeah.  Because I know my mom is a fight first type of person.
I:Yeah.
R:She’d rather not talk it out.  If she has the chance to, she will hit somebody.  And she – I have seen her, you know.  So I know, like – it’s almost like the negative examples, completely.
I:Yeah.  Yeah.
R:And same thing with my stepdad.  He won’t – I don’t think he likes to think twice.  He’ll just, “Yeah, that looks right.”  And he’ll do it.  And I’ll think for – it’s almost like I’ll think, how come he didn’t do that?  And he’ll be like, “Oh, how come you didn’t tell me?”
I:Yeah.
R:And it’s like, oh, I thought you thought that already.  So it’s almost like I learned from them bad –
I:Yeah.
R:Not bad examples, but the things that they do that can be negative –
I:Yeah.  Yeah.
R:To do the right thing.

Even if you have to lie sometimes, you know it would bring about a better conclusion. I’d say it’s very easy.  I’m quick to do what’s right. column591: The respondent believes that if they inherited money, they would donate a portion and use the rest for family and education, driven by their religious belief that money is inherently evil and can negatively change people, while they also rely on gut feelings to determine right from wrong, emphasizing the importance of selflessness and the consequences of actions, which they learned from observing negative examples in their family.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, my parents most of the time, they will teach me what’s right and what’s wrong, and they’ll tell me not to do drugs and try to stay away from sex until you get married, and they pretty much, they pretty much teach me what’s right and wrong and some of it I learn on my own, you know through trial and error, what’s right and wrong, you know, they teach me a lot and I learn a couple things on my own.
I:In recent years…or where do you think rights and wrongs come from?
R:I think, I don’t know, from trial and error, from what other people’s mistakes were, what was right and what was wrong and just how to set an example, I don’t know.
I:An example for what?
R:I have no idea.  Like, that way, to set an example for somebody else not to make.  Like if you had a little brother and sister or you were a younger kid, and you were the older one you’re supposed to set and example, like don’t tease your brother and stuff, even though you’re going to do it but you try not to cause you know you want to set a good example of for them not to do tease anybody cause it’s going to be wrong and it’s going to hurt peoples feelings sometimes.
I:Gotcha.
R:So, that’s one thing I guess.
I:And why do you think it would be bad to hurt people’s feelings?
R:Nobody likes getting their feelings hurt man, that’s not a good thing, so.
I:So is it uh…kind of a golden rule sort of thing?
R:Yeah, I guess you could say that.
I:Is that kind of what you’re thinking or?
R:Yeah, golden rules you know, do unto others something…Don’t do things to others that you wouldn’t want done to you so, yeah.
column584: Um, my parents most of the time, they will teach me what’s right and what’s wrong, and they’ll tell me not to do drugs and try to stay away from sex until you get married, and they pretty much, they pretty much teach me what’s right and wrong and some of it I learn on my own, you know through trial and error, what’s right and wrong, you know, they teach me a lot and I learn a couple things on my own. Yeah, I mean that, if you think something’s, if you think something’s wrong then you should try to do something about it to try and make it right. I mean you take responsibilities for your own actions, so if they burned, if they put these people in the gas chamber, that’s their responsibility, you can’t say oh somebody told me to do it.  So what, I mean you’ve got to take responsibility for your  own actions, so yeah there is a lot of universal right and wrong but most of it….yeah. I think, I don’t know, from trial and error, from what other people’s mistakes were, what was right and what was wrong and just how to set an example, I don’t know. I have no idea.  Like, that way, to set an example for somebody else not to make.  Like if you had a little brother and sister or you were a younger kid, and you were the older one you’re supposed to set and example, like don’t tease your brother and stuff, even though you’re going to do it but you try not to cause you know you want to set a good example of for them not to do tease anybody cause it’s going to be wrong and it’s going to hurt peoples feelings sometimes. So, that’s one thing I guess. Nobody likes getting their feelings hurt man, that’s not a good thing, so. Yeah, I guess you could say that. Yeah, golden rules you know, do unto others something…Don’t do things to others that you wouldn’t want done to you so, yeah.
column585: The respondent reflects on their moral development from adolescence, influenced primarily by their parents' teachings about right and wrong, acknowledges the importance of personal responsibility and the consequences of actions, and expresses a belief in universal morality while recognizing the varying moral standards among peers.

column589:
I:Take it little by little.  So how do you normally decide or know what is good or bad, right or wrong in life?
R:Just probably gut feeling, which I know is established from other factors and things.  I think it would just generally be kind of a value on greater social good than anything else that probably dictates a lot of those things and not so much with – there’s no scripture or anything like that that I would refer to.
I:In general, do you find it easy or hard to decide what is right or wrong in life?
R:I find it a little bit easier, but it can get very complicated.  For instance, research.  You can get very complicated easily.
I:Do you feel like as you get older it is easier or harder?
R:I think it’s harder because things get more complicated.  There’s a lot more factors.  It may be that things were as complicated, but you’re just aware of more things.
I:What do you think it is that actually makes a situation right or wrong?
R:I think it would be the effect that it has on people.
I:Where do you think you’ve gotten your moral views from?
R:Probably my parents.
column590: Just probably gut feeling, which I know is established from other factors and things.  I think it would just generally be kind of a value on greater social good than anything else that probably dictates a lot of those things and not so much with – there’s no scripture or anything like that that I would refer to. I find it a little bit easier, but it can get very complicated.  For instance, research.  You can get very complicated easily. I think it’s harder because things get more complicated.  There’s a lot more factors.  It may be that things were as complicated, but you’re just aware of more things.  I think it would be the effect that it has on people.  Probably my parents.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on gut feelings shaped by social values and parental influence to determine right from wrong, believes in a moral obligation to help others, and would choose to follow what makes them happy when unsure of a decision, despite acknowledging the complexity of moral dilemmas as they age.

column583:
I:Mm-mm.  And where did your, where do those views of right and wrong come from?  Um, like for you, like how do you, how do you know?
R:Um, I don’t know, I guess it’s just my conscience, I have, this, have a very strong conscience

R:I was always told what’s right and what’s wrong when I was little, but I mean, even then, I didn’t really pay attention to it, so, I don’t know .

But I didn’t really say anything.

column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are clear-cut, attributing their strong moral compass to their upbringing and conscience, while also recognizing the influence of social norms and peer pressure in situations involving alcohol and drugs, which they actively avoid despite opportunities to engage in such behaviors.
column589:
I:Yeah.  How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um.  I have a very good sense of what’s right and wrong from my parents teaching me.  I’m pretty lax about it actually now, because they were so strict with me.  I kind of was just like “Oh, okay, well, I’m just gonna chill.”  Or whatever.  Because I was just so sick of everything was judged, and examined, on whether or not…like they would sit me down and I would verbally have to explain to them why something was right or wrong.
I:Really?
R:I mean, like, they were seriously into it.
I:That must have been tough.
R:Yeah, I mean, everyday.  Yeah.
I:So, do you still though, so that’s influence.  Do you still think things through?
R:Yes.  I do.  I think things through.  I mean, sometimes I know that my parents would think that it would be wrong, but my opinions are different.
I:Where do you get your opinions?
R:Um, just as a collaboration of everything that I’ve learned over the years with how strict my parents were and how I can see that other people were too lax with their kids.  And how I can see that my siblings, since I’m the youngest, I guess watch all six of them before me screw up all their lives and try and fix them.  And then fix them.  And then something went wrong again.  I guess I can see all their problems pan out in front of me and how they dealt with them.
I:Yeah, that’s helpful.
R:…and so, it’s a lot easier, actually, to watch everyone else make their mistakes so I can say well I’m not going to make the mistakes Kim* did, I’m not going to do the one’s Brad* did…   Cathy* was okay, she did alright…  I could kind of follow her path.
I:Yeah, that makes sense.  In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s easy.
I:It’s easy?
R:I don’t really have a problem with it.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:It’s stayed pretty much the same, actually.  I don’t find it much different.
I:Okay. What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um.  Your conscience.
I:Your conscience?
R:Ah, it’s…it is set wrong and right, but…you have to decide for yourself.
I:So, what kind-
R:--It’s just the laws of the world that make it right or wrong.  Like there are things that are morally correct and morally incorrect.  Like, you shouldn’t kill babies before they’re born, I mean that’s like morally…
I:So there are moral absolutes?
R:Yeah.
I:Where do they come from thought, because some people would see things differently.
R:People, unlike animals, have consciences.  We have souls, we have understanding.  Animals just kind of go about.
I:So, there’s like an innate…
R:Yeah.  We can realize the absolutes that are right and wrong.  Animals just can’t.  It’s not that we’re deciding them, it’s that we realize them.
I:Okay.  Right.  So there are moral absolutes that people have the capacity to realize.
R:Yeah.  It’s not that, it’s that people can understand them.  I don’t know.  People can understand them, animals can’t.  We’re a higher being than animals are, so we can realize that there are absolutes that you can’t break.
I:So, when people do violate those sorts of things, do you think they know that they’re doing something wrong?
R:I think so.
I:Yeah.
R:I think so, your conscience doesn’t lie to you.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Um, collaboration of my parents, the world, experiences all that together.
I:Okay, have your views about right and wrong changed over the past few years? … we’ve asked you this already.  Okay…and you said no.    Um, some people think that the world is always changing and we should adjust our views of what is morally right and wrong to reflect those changes.  What do you think of that view?
R:Um, I think it’s true to an extent.  The world changes…but like I said, the absolutes never will change.  But I think you have to change with your generation.  And you have to adapt to the way of living that’s going around, right now.

People, unlike animals, have consciences.  We have souls, we have understanding.  Animals just kind of go about. Yeah.  We can realize the absolutes that are right and wrong.  Animals just can’t.  It’s not that we’re deciding them, it’s that we realize them. Yeah.  It’s not that, it’s that people can understand them.  I don’t know.  People can understand them, animals can’t.
