column591: The respondent makes decisions based on a strong influence from their parents' teachings about right and wrong, their own observations of family dynamics, and a personal moral compass shaped by religious beliefs, emphasizing the importance of conscience and the distinction between moral absolutes and subjective interpretations of morality.

column583:
I:Okay so what would think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t think anything makes it right and wrong it’s just if you, if you do something wrong and you get in trouble for it, like by the cops or something like that then that, that’s wrong and I guess if you do something right and it helps you succeed in life like get into a sport or something like that, that could get you going somewhere then I guess that’s right.  If it’s something that, doing something for your community, or something like that.  But I mean if like you start selling drugs or something like that you should know the sense that it’s wrong and if you just, just go with it then you should be okay.  Like if you start selling drugs you should pretty much just stop doing it and pay the consequences if you get caught.
I:Mm-mm, right.
R:Like for a good thing is just getting into sports, cause sports can get you somewhere in life, so.
I:Right.  What, you know, let’s say someone, you know say you’re talking to some, you know, some kid and maybe your age from ah, you know lives in inner city Cleveland and he, you know and he sells drugs and he says well it’s not really wrong, I need to do this to get by you know what, what would you tell him?
R:I would say that’s no way to get by, if you want to get by, get a job and support your own habit.  Like don’t, when you get a job you’re, you’re making your own money, you’re working for it, once you’re selling drugs and stuff you’re pretty much messing up in life cause someone gives it to you and if you don’t sell it you should, could get shot or something like that, so it’s kind of not worth doing it.  And if you miss a day at work you just get docked some pay.  If you miss a day at work in Cleveland for selling drugs you could get shot.  So, I would say just get a job and just make your way, make an honest living.
I:Right, cause you think it’s too dangerous to, you know, to you and other people, too.
R:It’s too dangerous to mess with any, any day now, so.

column585: The respondent primarily relies on their parents for guidance when unsure about decisions, believes that societal norms around right and wrong have diminished, emphasizes the importance of personal responsibility and consequences for actions, and maintains a strong commitment to sports over engaging in risky behaviors like drinking or drug use, while also helping peers make better choices.
column586:
I:Okay.  How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Well, I basically, whatever feels right.  And if I it don’t I don’t do it.  I just get a bad feeling sometimes.
I:What is that feeling like?
R:Uh, when it’s a yes, like, I don’t know I just don’t feel that it’s wrong.  But if it feels that it’s wrong I just don’t do it.  It’s hard to explain.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy, cause I don’t get in trouble or nothing.  I do what just seems right at the time.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:It’s gotten easier.
I:What do you
R:Cause now I know the consequence if I do something wrong and I don’t want to do anything wrong, so I think about it a lot more, and I already figure out a way to do it right instead of wrong.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:That makes something right or wrong?
I:Uh-huh.
R:Well, if you do something wrong, then, um,  there’s a lot of different things that can happen to you, like you can go to jail or something like that.  And if it’s right then, uh, just right and you cant get in trouble for it.
I:What if there was something someone could do and they knew that they could never get caught, would that make it okay?
R:No, it would still be wrong.
I:Why do you think that?
R:Cause they know they did something wrong, even if nobody else knows about it they know that they did something wrong and it will catch up to them eventually.
I:What kinds of consequences do you mean when you say there are bad consequences, what do you mean?
R:Well there’s jail or die or get shot or something, or anything really.
I:What uh, earlier you said you felt, things that are right or wrong you said you could sort of feel, where do you think those feelings come from?
R:I really don’t know.  But it’s hard to tell from right or wrong and I don’t really know where they come from.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:I don’t think so.
I:For example, would stealing be always wrong?
R:Not always wrong.  Like if you, if you support a family or something, or if you have a little baby and the only way to get formula or something and you don’t have enough money and you steal I could see, but not just to steal for the fun of it.
I:Okay, what about lying?
R:Lying can be bad, but sometimes it can be good. Like if you do something bad, like cheat on your girlfriend or something like that and you lie about it, it wont hurt her but it will hurt you a little bit.  But yeah.
I:Is that what would make the lying wrong that it would hurt you?
R:It would make you realize that you don’t want to do it anymore.
I:Why wouldn’t you want to do it anymore?
R:Because you’d think about how you lied the first time, like if she would have found out about it a little bit after you had done it, then it could have got worse.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:From mom and dad.  They taught me a lot of what’s right and what’s wrong and how I should handle both of them.

column588: The respondent primarily relies on intuition to determine right from wrong, influenced by their parents' teachings, and acknowledges the consequences of their actions, while expressing a desire to support their family and a belief that societal changes should be reflected in moral views, despite recognizing the negative impact of drugs in their community.

column583:
I:Um, do you feel like you have, you kind of know what that line is, like how do you decide what’s right and wrong?
R:I just, I guess I just kind of go by like what I think.
I:Uh-huh, where do you think that comes from?
R:How my parents raised me, probably like most of it.
I:Most of it, from your parents?
R:Mm-mm (yes).
I:Okay, um, let’s see, what do you think makes something right or wrong? Like what do you think it, makes something one or the other?
R:Like the consequences of it, because if you take drugs and stuff then there’s the, you know, your parents find out and they get in trouble, and the police and like if it’s a good thing then no bad consequences will come from it.
I:Okay, um, do you think that’s always the case?
R:Um, no probably not.
I:No that’s fine, um, let’s see, so is there anything else other than consequences do you think, that is a kind of a indicator of what makes something right or wrong?
R:I mean, it’s like all listed like in the Bible, of course, like you know, that’s like how you’re supposed to know but a lot of people don’t go by that, so.
I:Do you think the Bible is always right or do you think that sometimes it’s wrong, or do you think that it’s all up to interpretation or what do you think about that?
R:Um, I guess since it was like written a long time ago that it can be like interpreted a little bit differently.
I:Okay.
R:But mostly it’s like, that’s what’s right and that’s what’s wrong.
I:Okay so you think the Bible is a pretty reliable source for knowing what’s right and wrong?
R:Mm-mm (yes).
I:Okay.  Let’s see, um, when you’re faced with a situation where it’s tough to know what’s right and wrong to do, how do you decide what to do?  Do you do anything in particular or think anything in particular?
R:Well, what would my Mom say .  Um, usually like what my parents would think or what my really good friends think cause I have some friends that like are really good Christians and what would they say of me doing this or.
I:Do you think your religious beliefs influence how you decide to do things a lot, or, or not so much?
R:Yeah, I would think so, because I wouldn’t go out and do some things because it’s just, it’s just wrong.

column585: The respondent believes that their sense of right and wrong primarily comes from their parents' upbringing and religious teachings, acknowledges the influence of friends on their decisions, particularly in situations involving temptation, and feels guilty about actions that contradict their moral beliefs, often seeking advice from non-judgmental friends.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good or bad, right and wrong in life?
R:How do you decide what’s good and bad, right and wrong?
I:Mmhmm
R:I think from how you’re brought up is a lot of it.  What your parents tell you and how your friends say you act and it’s just social norms of where you live and stuff like that.
I:in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I would say it’s pretty easy.
I:And has deciding between right and wrong, gotten easier or harder for you in the past couple of years?
R:I think it’s gotten a lot easier.  It’s harder maybe in high school, there’s so many people that are wanting to pull you in the wrong direction and don’t care about you enough and as you get older you just learn to pick friends who really care about you or want you to do well and want you to succeed.
I:Have your views about what’s wrong or right changed in the last few years at all?
R:I don’t think so, not a lot.  Just making the right decisions more, not caring as much for what other people think.  But I don’t think that my views have been totally skewed, I don’t think that they’ve changed that much over the past couple of years.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think a little bit of your own personal beliefs, but a lot with, I mean obviously the law defines that for you.  And for some people, religion defines that for them. I think all of that society, kinda tells you what’s right and wrong.
I:So is it rules and laws then that define right and wrong in general?
R:To a point, yes, but there are some things that of course, that you can only decide what’s right and wrong. And of course the law tells you not to go out and steal, obviously stealing is wrong. But there are certain things, personal things, that you may think are right and wrong and that’s up to you.
I:How do you know?
R:I think that it just, just the way you’re brought up, just the way you yourself are.  I think that only you can decide what’s good for you. So I dunno exactly how you decide, I think it’s really up to your conscious.
I:so if something is a positive influence—does it have positive or negative consequences? Is that how you decide?
R:I think so to an extent, but sometimes doing the right thing will get you in trouble, so I don’t think you can purely define it on that .
I:Ok,
R:that’s a hard question—that’s a deep question.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Mostly from my parents, I would have to say. Yeah, my family.

I don’t think so, not a lot.  Just making the right decisions more, not caring as much for what other people think.  But I don’t think that my views have been totally skewed, I don’t think that they’ve changed that much over the past couple of years.  I think a little bit of your own personal beliefs, but a lot with, I mean obviously the law defines that for you.  And for some people, religion defines that for them. I think all of that society, kinda tells you what’s right and wrong. To a point, yes, but there are some things that of course, that you can only decide what’s right and wrong. And of course the law tells you not to go out and steal, obviously stealing is wrong. But there are certain things, personal things, that you may think are right and wrong and that’s up to you. I think that it just, just the way you’re brought up, just the way you yourself are.  I think that only you can decide what’s good for you. So I dunno exactly how you decide, I think it’s really up to your conscious. I think so to an extent, but sometimes doing the right thing will get you in trouble, so I don’t think you can purely define it on that . that’s a hard question—that’s a deep question.  Mostly from my parents, I would have to say. Yeah, my family.
column591: The respondent believes that decision-making is influenced primarily by upbringing and social norms, values sharing with family and friends, and recognizes the importance of personal happiness while also considering the opinions of loved ones, ultimately emphasizing a moral obligation to help others and the relative nature of morality shaped by societal influences.

column583:
I:Okay, so let’s see, where do think your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:In large part from my parents.  Um, from when I was younger.  But the older I get, the more it becomes what the Marine corps believes.  What they believe is what I believe.  Because, in the Marine corps it’s God, country, corps.  You eliminate God since I don’t believe in that and it’s country, corps, family.  If it’s good for the Marine corps it’s good for me.  And that is my society, that’s the society that I’m going to be a part of, and I just want to make sure that we’re taken care of, as a whole.
I:Okay, do you think that this causes any problems for you, not believing in God and being a part of the Marine corps, or?
R:Um, no, I really don’t, because I can do anything for God whether he exists or not, it doesn’t matter.  If the Marine corps tells me to do it, I can do it, it doesn’t matter what I believe.  You have to put that aside for the better good, or the bigger good of everyone.
I:So do you think the Marine corps is the best group to belong to as far as morals go?
R:I guess that depends on who you are.  For me, yes.  For other people, probably not.  For those that are extremely opposed to war, I definitely don’t recommend the military at all.
I:Um, so how do you, how do you negotiate those things, with lots of people, say, disagreeing with you?
R:I don’t.  It causes a lot of trouble.  Um, that’s one reason I choose to associate with Marines.  I don’t even really hang out with people that are in other branches of the military because it causes problems.  You get into the whole ego trip of who’s better.  Who’s right and wrong depends on who you are and what you believe.  I think, there again, right and wrong depends on the person.  Someone who is totally opposed to war, I can understand where they’re coming from, doesn’t mean I agree with it.
I:Okay, so you talked a little bit about what’s right for you and what’s right for greater society, for you personally, what do you think makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, I know it sounds very brainwashed, and regimented, but there again, if it’s good for the Marine corps, it’s good for me.
I:Can you think of some things, some examples of what would be good for the Marine corps, what kind of rules?
R:Of course, more money, better equipment, means that my job’s gonna be easier.  Better equipment means that less of my brothers and sisters, less Marines will die, fewer will die in war.  Um, God forbid there be a war.  If it’s good for them, it’s good for me.  If we get more money, then pay increases, I get more money, I can retire sooner.  Just, things like that.  Of course it’s about me getting ahead, but on the whole it’s about the Marine corps, getting ahead and doing well.
I:Okay.  Um, let’s see.  So what do you think about war, considering that, it’s, it’s a group that you feel very close to that’s put at risk by war, the act of war.
R:War in itself isn’t necessary but by human nature, it is.  Because we are selfish and we’re mean spirited and we’re not all good.  We’re just not.  I am an American through and through, I am blue-blooded American, and I want my country to be safe.  I want my people to be safe and I want my grandchildren to live in America, the way I know it.  A good place. Anybody that threatens that needs to be dealt with and that’s what I think. If it’s by force, by war, then so be it.
I:Who do you think has the right to make those kinds of decisions, on whether something is threatening enough to go to war over?
R:It doesn’t really matter who I think is, who I know is, is the President of the United States.  He is the Commander in Chief of all military branches and so he’s gonna make the final call.  I, at this point, agree with him, I think that we need to go in and deal with the situations that are happening right now.  But there again, I hope it can be done for the right reasons and not for maybe reasons that people think he’s doing it.
I:Okay, so do you think that um, you have trust in the position of being, of being president, or do you think there could be presidents that you would not agree with, or that you don’t necessarily trust to make the right decision.
R:There probably, are I can think of a lot of people that I would not want to be President of the United States of America.  But if they were and me being in the Marine corps, I would still follow those orders because it comes down to who writes the check and there you go, that’s who writes it.

column585: The respondent believes that while individuals often know what is right and wrong, they may choose to ignore it for personal happiness, attributing their moral views largely to their parents and the Marine Corps, emphasizing the importance of societal good over personal desires, and reflecting on their past drug use as a learning experience rather than a moral failing.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I guess it’s just what my mother has taught me along the way and my whole family and it kind of goes back to the “If your grandmother wouldn’t like it, then maybe you shouldn’t be doing it.” You just know, I don’t know how you know. I guess it depends on how you’re raised but I know what’s right and wrong because I believe that what’s right and wrong is the same as what my mother and grandmother have taught me and if they both agree on whether something is right or wrong then I know that they’re right.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Easy.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:Easier.
I:Why?
R:I’ve always known what was right or wrong. It was just whether or not I was going to choose to do the right or wrong thing. Three years ago, I wouldn’t have cared if it was right or wrong, I would have known but I still would have done what I wanted to do. Now I’m with the opinion that I know if it is right or wrong and if it is wrong then I am not going to do it.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:It kind of—there are just some things that aren’t laws of the land that are wrong or right, because no one said they were wrong or right, they just are one or the other, and then there are other things that maybe are regional, cultural or just depending on your family and how you were raised. So aside from those laws of the land I think that just are or are not, my family and the way I was raised to determine what is right and wrong.
I:So for the things that are sort of like set in stone, wrong and right, how do we know like, which things are those and which things are the relative things?
R:I don’t know, you just know. I don’t care who you are or where you live, if you murder someone for the sake of killing them for no good reason, that’s wrong. I don’t think anyone unless they have a mental, you know, instability or probably mentally disagree with the fact that killing someone for the pure pleasure of it is not the right thing to do but I guess one of those gray areas is when someone is breaking into your house and they’re trying to rape your wife or hurt your children or you know, hurt you, and you kill them, that’s not murder, that’s defense so, is it right to kill someone? No, it’s not right but it is more right to protect your life and your family but then it’s wrong to stop someone form hurting you.
I:So do you think when people like, if somebody were to murder another person, do you think that they’re like broadcasting knowledge they know is right and wrong or do you think that some people just like …
R:I just think that’s unfair, they don’t care.
I:Do you think everybody knows those things?
R:I do. I think so and I think it’s just total apathy and they just don’t care, they’re going to do what they want to do even if they, you know, they’re pleasure principle, do what feels good or do what you want to do, just because.
I:Do you think it’s the consequences of something that makes it wrong?
R:No. Because I know as a teenager, and as the younger adult that I am now, consequences didn’t matter, you know, when I lived at home as a teenager, if I did this then I would get in trouble, but it didn’t matter because I would do it anyway and I’d just say, well if I do then I’m going to have to suffer the consequences and if it’s worth it, yeah, do it anyway. I don’t think consequences—they’re what you do to try to either rehabilitate so the person doesn’t do it again or just prevent them from doing it again but I don’t think that they directly relate, really.
I:So do you think it’s like, your feelings about whether something is right or wrong,  like discriminate or … how do we know?
R:I thinks it’s just born into us like … we know we have to eat to  live, nobody tell us that, you just know, you have to breathe to stay alive, there are some things that are innate, they are born through, you know, generations that just aren’t what they are.
I:But do you think that there’s something that are culturally relative?
R:Yeah, definitely. It just depends. Some things that I think wrong other people might not. An example of that is using the word “GD”. I don’t like that word, I won’t get it at all, I think that that is not a good thing to say. Is it because I’m religious and I believe in God? Yes. If you don’t believe in God or you are not religious then that is just another word like any of the other four-letter words that we have there. So I believe that for any—I guess for any Christian that is a wrong thing to say, for anyone else that they’re not, then it doesn’t directly pertain that they’re if don’t believe the same things that I do.
I:At the end of the day, like how do you make the distinction between the culturally agreed and the absolute right and wrong things. Is it hard to tell the difference?
R:I don’t try to tell the difference, you know, I don’t worry about whether this is one of those things that just is throughout the world or whether or not it’s something that my mom taught me when I was a kid because what matters to me directly is whether it’s right or wrong, not why it’s right or wrong or who said it was. It’s just whether or not it is.
I:Where did you acquire your moral views?
R:My mom, my family.

It’s just whether or not it is.  My mom, my family.
column591: The respondent makes decisions based on the teachings of her mother and grandmother, believing that right and wrong are clear-cut and rooted in her upbringing, while also emphasizing that doing the right thing, even when difficult, is essential for personal integrity and that she would rely on her mother's guidance in uncertain situations.

column589:
I:Okay.  So how would you say you normally decide or know what’s good or bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I guess you just know what not to do and your conscious makes you have to think about it.
I:So you just know?  Is it like, you know it, like there are rules that you know in your mind, or is it a feeling, or –
R:I guess it’s a feeling that you get, that you know.  Like I know this is not right.
I:So in general, how easy or hard is it for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Pretty easy.
I:Okay.  Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the last two years?
R:No, not really.
I:Okay.  Have your views about what’s right and wrong changed in the last two years?
R:No.
I:So what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong, like what about it?
R:What about –
I:What about something that makes it right or wrong?
R:I guess the outcome.
I:Okay.  And what kinds of like outcomes would you say makes something wrong?  Can you give me an example?
R:I would say if you’re going to do something and you know it was wrong, the consequences.  Like, if you’re going to do something, like, say if you’re going to hop the train, and you know you’ll get a ticket for it but you do it anyway.  Or –
I:Why would that be wrong, to hop the train, what if you didn’t get caught, would it still be wrong?
R:It wouldn’t be wrong if you didn’t get caught.
I:Okay.  So you think that it’s the getting caught that makes something wrong?
R:Yes and no.  It depends on the situation.
I:Any idea what it might depend on?
R:I guess, given a situation, I mean, something as simple as a train, they charge too much anyway, so it’s not nothing to hop a train.
I:Okay.  Can you think of a situation where it would be wrong even if you didn’t get caught?
R:I would say, I guess, lying.
I:Okay.  How come that’s wrong even if you don’t get caught?
R:Because you know it’s wrong.  I mean, you might not have or have a guilty conscious, but other person believes it’s the truth.  So you deceive another person.
I:Okay.  How come that’s different from jumping the train, any idea?
R:You’re not deceiving no one by jumping the train.
I:Let’s see.  Where would you say you have gotten your views on what is right and wrong?
R:My mother.
I:Okay.  Is there any particular like place or person you feel like she got her ideas about right and wrong from?
R:My grandmother, my grandfather.
column590: I guess you just know what not to do and your conscious makes you have to think about it. I guess it’s a feeling that you get, that you know.  Like I know this is not right. Pretty easy. No, not really. No.  What about – I guess the outcome. I would say if you’re going to do something and you know it was wrong, the consequences.  Like, if you’re going to do something, like, say if you’re going to hop the train, and you know you’ll get a ticket for it but you do it anyway.  Or – It wouldn’t be wrong if you didn’t get caught. Yes and no.  It depends on the situation. I guess, given a situation, I mean, something as simple as a train, they charge too much anyway, so it’s not nothing to hop a train. I would say, I guess, lying. Because you know it’s wrong.  I mean, you might not have or have a guilty conscious, but other person believes it’s the truth.  So you deceive another person. You’re not deceiving no one by jumping the train.  My mother. My grandmother, my grandfather.
column591: The respondent would use an inheritance of $100,000 to save for emergencies, support their mother as a thank you for her care, move out to Harlem, buy a car to gain independence, and potentially start a business, while their moral decision-making is influenced by a feeling of right and wrong, shaped by their mother and grandparents, and they believe that morality is relative to upbringing and circumstances.

column583:
I:Okay.  Ah, can you give me some specific examples of what you think is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um,--
I:You talked about drugs.  Is there anything else that you would consider like, that you think would be bad, or anything that you would consider that would be good.
R:Bad, ah, I think maybe sports, athletes get paid way too much, I mean, give the kid, Labraun James $90 million before he even steps on the court, the court is, wow, that’s like, astonishing nowadays.  But, but if you have that ability to do that, but.  What’s right and wrong?
I:Yeah, like morally right and wrong.
R:Drugs, I guess.  Drugs would be morally wrong for me and ah, right and wrong…doing the right thing—can you repeat that?
I:Yeah um, like, like we’ve been talking about you decide what is good and bad and like where your values are centered, like from your parents and religion, so like can you give me some examples of things that you would think would be morally good, or morally bad, other than drugs.
R:Morally good, I think morally good would be ah, focusing straight on my education, I mean, that’s, I mean nowadays I heard you cannot barely, if you have a high school diploma you can barely get, I don’t know a 30-some thousand dollar job or twenty, not even that.  Or I think ah, one of the, education is the number one morally, I guess morally good thing, and to go to college and do what I can, like to be ah, like my Dad always says, I’ve ah, just be something like, be better than what he is and, and that’s something, I mean he has a really good job, but he never finished high school and he wants me to go, I think I’ll be the first one in my family to go to college, from my  grandparents, yeah I will actually, and there’s a lot riding on that.  Morally wrong, I guess would be like not going to school.

Morally wrong, I guess would be like not going to school.
column585: The respondent primarily relies on their father's guidance and personal experiences to discern right from wrong, acknowledges the influence of media and peer pressure on moral decisions, and feels a strong sense of guilt for not helping others, particularly their sister, while also recognizing the importance of education and their religious beliefs in shaping their values.
column589:
I:Interesting.  How do you normally decide, or know, what is good or bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Morally?  I guess that’s something that I was raised with.  I go with my instinct.  And not only that, if my decision, if it’s going to hurt somebody, I don’t want to, I mean, I’ll make the right decision.  I don’t like hurting people.  I don’t like, I like, I want people to, I mean, be happy, and I feel bad for a lot of people.  Especially I’m a waiter, a bartender, and I see a guy sitting by himself eating dinner, you know, I feel bad for that guy.  I wish I could go over there and eat with him, you know?  I just like to make sure people are comfortable and are taken care of.
I:So generally would you say it’s easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I think it’s easy to decide between right and wrong.  Yeah.
I:Now, has deciding between right and wrong gotten harder or easier over the past two years?
R:I think it’s gotten easier the past two years because I’ve found more of who, I’ve grown up a little.  I’ve gotten this new truck, and I got a more responsibilities, about to enter the workforce.  You’d think that would be harder for me, but I think it’s easier because I’ve grown up, like I said.
I:Have your views changed in the past couple of years?
R:About?
I:Like your moral views?
R:I guess yes and no.  Morally this is wrong, morally, I used to think, like I say, I used to go out and just have fun, do things.  But I’ve kind of grown up about that I guess you could say.
I:To you, what is it that makes something right or wrong?
R:What makes?
I:Yeah.
R:What was that again?
I:What makes something right or wrong?  How do you know if something is right or wrong?
R:I guess just the instinct you have as a human.  You know this is right, this is wrong.
I:I mean is it the way it feels?  Or is it rules or law? Or is the consequences of that action?
R:I think it’s the consequences and the effects that will happen.  To me, I think a guy upstairs is watching me all the time.  And I think it’s being noted, “Oh he stole this, or this happened.”  I think it’s the consequences.  If I go ahead and, if I go ahead and do something will I get arrested for it or, you know, I’m always thinking two steps ahead, I’m always trying to look out for myself.  I think it’s consequence-wise.  The effects, yeah.
I:Where do you think you’ve acquired your moral views from?
R:Mmm…
I:Where do they come from?
R:From my parents.  I grew up in a, I grew up in a great household.  If I ever make it big one day as an actor.  All these actors have all, “Oh man, my mom, and my this, and…”  I’m not going to lie, I grew up, I told my parents, like a year ago, you did a great job raising us.  They took us to, they took us on vacations, they gave us, I mean everything, we had a great childhood.  I think I was raised great, I mean morally, I mean, don’t take for granted what you do have, but, I mean, live life really.  To the fullest.
column590: Morally?  I guess that’s something that I was raised with.  I go with my instinct.  And not only that, if my decision, if it’s going to hurt somebody, I don’t want to, I mean, I’ll make the right decision.  I don’t like hurting people.  I don’t like, I like, I want people to, I mean, be happy, and I feel bad for a lot of people.  Especially I’m a waiter, a bartender, and I see a guy sitting by himself eating dinner, you know, I feel bad for that guy.  I wish I could go over there and eat with him, you know?  I just like to make sure people are comfortable and are taken care of. I think it’s easy to decide between right and wrong.  Yeah. I think it’s gotten easier the past two years because I’ve found more of who, I’ve grown up a little.  I’ve gotten this new truck, and I got a more responsibilities, about to enter the workforce.  You’d think that would be harder for me, but I think it’s easier because I’ve grown up, like I said. About? I guess yes and no.  Morally this is wrong, morally, I used to think, like I say, I used to go out and just have fun, do things.  But I’ve kind of grown up about that I guess you could say.  What makes? What was that again? I guess just the instinct you have as a human.  You know this is right, this is wrong. I think it’s the consequences and the effects that will happen.  To me, I think a guy upstairs is watching me all the time.  And I think it’s being noted, “Oh he stole this, or this happened.”  I think it’s the consequences.  If I go ahead and, if I go ahead and do something will I get arrested for it or, you know, I’m always thinking two steps ahead, I’m always trying to look out for myself.  I think it’s consequence-wise.  The effects, yeah.  Mmm… From my parents.  I grew up in a, I grew up in a great household.  If I ever make it big one day as an actor.  All these actors have all, “Oh man, my mom, and my this, and…”  I’m not going to lie, I grew up, I told my parents, like a year ago, you did a great job raising us.  They took us to, they took us on vacations, they gave us, I mean everything, we had a great childhood.  I think I was raised great, I mean morally, I mean, don’t take for granted what you do have, but, I mean, live life really.  To the fullest.
column591: The respondent would give half of an inheritance to his parents out of gratitude for their support, and he bases his moral decisions on instinct and the desire to avoid hurting others, influenced by his upbringing and a belief in consequences and divine oversight.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:How do I decide, I don’t know whatever is inside of me, that you know—
I:So what would you call it, like instinct or intuition, or?
R:Yeah, I mean instinct, uh, you know, I wouldn’t um; I wouldn’t say I follow any set guidelines.  You know, just instinct.
I:Do you feel like that’s an easy thing or a hard thing for you?
R:I think it’s an extremely easy thing.  Most, you know, I guess I’ve made enough decisions by now that I'm, kind of know where I stand on most things and what I think is right and what I don’t believe is right.
I:Do you feel like it’s gotten easier or harder in the last couple of years?
R:Easier.  You know, with uh, especially in the last year, year and a half, just it just seems, most decisions seem simple, you know?
I:Have your views about sort of moral things, have they changed in the last 2 years?
R:No.
I:Yeah, okay what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Actually makes something right or wrong?  I really don’t know; that’s a tough question.  Uh, if something is right I guess it doesn’t, uh, hurt anyone else physically, emotionally, financially.  If it’s, if, you know if it’s not hurting anyone then it’s a plus.  So I’d say it’s probably right, if you know your actions hurt something else, then that’s probably wrong, you know?
I:Were would you say you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Um, you know I’d have to, and I’ve heard that, had that question before, and you know I would say that growing up in the church didn’t hinder me at all, but uh, you know a lot of it’s just my parents, event though they weren’t religious they still, you know, there’s still that core value of you know not hurting any, or not making decisions that’s going to hurt anyone else, you know?  and the company I worked for, for three or four years in high school, the owners of that were in the same way and I saw how, by example, I saw how he dealt with customers and how he ran his business and how he treated people and I think a lot of that, that had a lot to do with it and my senses now.  Especially in the way that I run my business.

column586:
I:Okay, um, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Um, just the way I’ve been raised, like, my parents told me, this is bad, this is good and then you just kind of have to learn through mistakes, too.
I:Okay.  In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between what’s right and wrong, or good and bad?
R:Um, it’s always been pretty easy for me.  I don’t like getting in trouble.
I:Okay and has it gotten easier or harder over the past two years, to decide what’s right and wrong, or good and bad?
R:It’s gotten easier.
I:It has.  Any reason it’s gotten easier for you?
R:Um, I just think I’ve kind of grown up a little bit more and just learned some lessons. Um, I think just how it makes you feel—
I:How it makes you feel?
R:--inside and then like if it, if it affects other people.
I:Okay.  When you say, how it makes you feel, could you describe that a little bit for me?
R:Um, just kind of like a gut feeling, just like you can, it feels like a little voice in the back of your head saying like you know you shouldn’t be doing it.
I:Okay, and where does that voice come from, do you think?
R:Um, in my religion, we, it’s called like the Holy Ghost.
I:Okay, and then you also mentioned its affects on other people, makes something right or wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:And what, what type of affects on other people are you thinking about there?
R:Just cause like some of your actions like they have consequences and they don’t always affect you, they affect the people around you, too.
I:Okay.  So, in other words, the things you do should be influenced by that kind of gut feeling or that voice in the back of your head that you were talking about, but also the consequences they have for other people, it sounds like.
R:Mm-mm (yes).
I:Anything else?
R:Um, not that I can think of.
I:Okay.  Are there any actions that you think are just wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Um, like you shouldn’t do them at all?
I:Correct.
R:Um, you probably shouldn’t like kill people and I don’t think you should cheat on your spouse, I think those two.
I:Okay.  I mean, I, this may be begging the obvious and I hope it’s not, but what is it that you think that makes these things wrong, these particular things that you’ve mentioned?
R:Um, well, it’s just like some  commandments in our church and then they’re just, they’re just not right.
I:Okay.  From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Um, I believe from my parents and then some of my friends and then the church.

column585: The respondent often relies on their intuition to guide their decisions about right and wrong, acknowledges the influence of friends and family on their choices, and grapples with feelings of guilt stemming from their upbringing and moral beliefs, particularly in relation to their mother's differing values and their own Christian principles.
column586:
I:how do you decide what’s good or bad, right and wrong in life?
R:well the things I’ve learned from like my parents and like, I guess actually from my dad, he’s a very honest person so he’s taught me a lot about you know, right and wrong, like what’s, what you, you know, he always tells me you have to follow you know, your heart, what really you feel.  Like sometimes you don’t actually feel like this is right or wrong but it’s like, they, my parents, especially my dad has really guided me in that direction.  So I judge how, I just have a kind of natural, you know instinct, oh I don’t think this is right so I do it or don’t do it.
I:is that hard for you or easy, generally?
R:no it’s pretty much, cause especially the things that I know are wrong but I want to do anyways, it’s hard.  Yeah.
I:has it gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:definitely harder.
I:really?
R:cause there’s a lot more things now that I’ve been exposed to.
I:just feeling more like an adult and you have bigger decisions to make?
R:yeah, a lot more freedom, a lot more things I could do, you know, are you kidding me?  I’ll be going to *Manhattan like all last semester when I had my semester.  Every night my friend Megan and I would go clubbing, get drunk, meet guys, we’d all come back to my apartment and crash, I mean crazy!  We’d get drunk every night, it was great!
I:in hindsight…what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:oh, that’s a good question.  Um, hmmm.  Probably, I mean, I think if you feel in your gut that you shouldn’t do it, then it’s wrong, but if you feel like, you know, like you have like innate, I think really do have an innate feeling of know what’s wrong but you want to do it anyways, and you do it, whether, depending on your personality too, if you really wanna just do it, you don’t care, you just do it, but I think deep down you really do know,  you have a feeling about it.  So.
I:are there any actions that are always wrong, in themselves, or not?
R:see, I don’t think, I really don’t think like that, you know.  Maybe probably taking advantage of somebody or like, you know, like taking advantage of somebody is, yeah, that’s probably wrong all the time, or you know, cheating somebody out of money or something, yeah.
I:so what makes these things wrong?  Is it that somebody else’s involved or…?
R:I think it’s just totally dishonest.  So, yeah.
I:so where have you acquired your moral views?
R:my dad, especially my dad.  And somewhat, you know my mom.  But I tried a lot to just take my own influence, I mean, I get a lot of different views on things about what’s right and wrong from like, I went to a private catholic high school, I went to all public and then to high school.  So I had influence from there, from my parents, and we got all these different views on what’s right and what’s wrong and, so I just took them in but then I think to myself, what do I really think?  So I kind of just judge, I try to base it on what I think.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Well especially probably what my parents taught and everyone grows up differently so different values are important or les important.  That and generally what my first initial thinking is.  It’s weird, especially like informed consciousness that is a big part in like Catholicism and we have it informed conscience which I think is kind of a little bogus, but at the same time I do base it on what I generally think is good, and then also what I have been taught as well.  I just put those together to make as best a decision as I can.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Generally easy, it has gotten easier, because before I used to know what was right but not want to do it and now that I have more discipline and I know what is right I just do that.  And then I do it.
I:And so you say it has gotten easier for you, why has it gotten easier for you?
R:I am trying to be less selfish, I can definitely be a selfish person, so I try to be less selfish and not do what I want, but actually do what…most of my decision making I honestly do think my dad taught me and he is the most amazingly honest person I have ever met in my life so he taught me a lot of good values and important things to be an overall good person.  You don’t need to lie and do all those things, and so I really follow a lot of what he says.
I:Do you think that your views changed besides moving away from being less selfish…your views have changed on things the last couple of years?
R:Slightly, I would say a whole lot.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Usually it is an initial feeling.  I think everyone has their initial feelings about something and usually those first feelings are right.
I:What kinds of feelings like repulsion or an unsettled feeling or what?
R:Yeah, I think sometimes you get like a…initially your first reaction to something isn’t always…I know that sometimes I thought wrong about someone and found out later as things go on, but initially I guess you could think something is right or wrong by not feeling very good about it.  Like maybe a deep feeling that is kind of like something seems off to you, that I will sometimes base it on that.
I:And in your view where do you think those feeling come from?
R:I think some of my mom’s influence too.  She has pretty good…
I:Like religious beliefs and that, or…?
R:Yeah, a lot of religious influence for sure.
I:Is that what you were talking about earlier about conscience development?
R:Yeah.  Like informed consciousness, but it is not completely that, it is like a unique combination of that and values from like my dad and my step mom that they have taught me over the years.
I:So tell me a little bit, why do you think the way you grew up made you think that?  It sounds like your mom gave you pretty much this is the way the church or the Bible or God or whatever…and you need to act this way, and your dad and step mom gave you this general moral guideline.
R:I have actually thought about this before, say my dad and my step mom weren’t even around and say that they passed away and it was just living with my mom, then more than likely I would probably think like she does and I am actually glad that I didn’t have that because I like the combination  of thinking both ways, and I think you are who you hang out with or who you are around but everyone honestly has their own personal opinions and ideas and so those are awesome so  yeah, if I had grown up thinking a little bit differently it would have been different decision making and morals.
I:Now would you say that primarily your moral views come from your mom and dad or from some other source in addition to them?
R:I think other sources in addition because actually all my best friends growing up, I was really close friends with their parents too and they contributed a lot to my life as well so I like to take a little bit of everything and bring it together, and not everybody does.  Everyone takes what they have been taught differently and approach things differently.  They are a unique individual person, so I actually do believe that things can be very relative to situations.

column591: The respondent primarily bases their decision-making on the values instilled by their parents, particularly their father's honesty, and their own initial feelings about situations, while also considering the influence of their mother's religious beliefs, which together guide them towards making moral choices that avoid harming others and promote helping those in need.

column583:
I:Okay, um, let's see, here, so where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, a few of them are religious based on the religion that I have had. Um, but most of them are morals, just I guess what I’ve always lived by, I guess, and I guess I got that from my parents.
I:Okay.
R:So, like I said on right and wrong, it’s just a feeling, I think.
I:So um, how do you decide or know what’s good and bad, right and wrong in life?  Like can you give me some specific examples?
R:Um, like what, like?
I:Um, situations in which you, okay, this is something that was right for you and this is something that was wrong and how you decided that.
R:A decision that I have made?
I:Uh-huh, I’m sorry.
R:Oh, um,
I:Examples from your life, yeah, in your past, like the past year.
R:Um, decision not to have sex is a decision that I made, um, like I said the decision for college, um, and just decisions like um, I guess when you get with a group of friends and they’re not doing things, they’re doing things that you may not, you know agree with and you don’t do it or I don’t do it.
I:Have you been in a situation like that?
R:Uh, yeah.
I:Can you tell me about that one and how you decided not to do it or to do it?
R:Um, we were, um, it was graduation night and um, we there was a group of friends that were in a hotel room, um, they were smoking and drinking but I mean I didn’t do it that’s just cause I’ve never done it and I don’t want to, I guess.
I:Why not, like what do you, why not, what factors into your mind when you think about that?
R:Um, I just know that it really won’t help the, it won’t help anything, um, I wouldn’t do it just for fun because I would think okay, I guess I would think about the consequences.
I:Okay.
R:Um,
I:Consequences of how like it would affect you or what?
R:Yeah.  Say I got drunk, um, I wouldn’t want to come home drunk, so,
I:Okay, why not?
R:Um, I'd get in trouble with my mom and dad.

column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are clear and based on personal feelings and upbringing, particularly influenced by their parents and religion, and they emphasize the importance of considering the consequences of their actions, such as avoiding alcohol and drugs due to fear of negative outcomes and a desire to adhere to their moral beliefs.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I guess it…I don’t know. I just think it’s…I just decide. I don’t think if you’re asking about more religion I think it’s not…
I:Yeah, I just mean it in general, not necessarily religious but …
R:I mean, it definitely has something to do with it but I just kind of - whatever I feel is right.  Well I guess, I would probably fit in lots of people, I’d probably see how it will affect them, you know, affect me in the future, that type of thing. So I guess there is a thought process to it.
I:Is it generally easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Right and wrong, I guess I’m indecisive, more indecisive, but when it comes to what’s right and wrong I mean I can de decide pretty quick on that.
I:Has it gotten easier or harder in the past couple of years?
R:No, I think.
I:Have your moral views changed in the past couple of years?
R:No.
I:Now, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t know. I think it’s actually that individual’s - individual’s decision. I mean it’s definitely based on how they were raised in the faith, what’s right or wrong or their beliefs and all that good stuff of things, you know, what they feel is right and wrong.
I:So where do you think you’ve acquired your moral views from?
R:Definitely parents. Not necessarily anything that was spoken but more seeing. You know, observing how they acted maybe, or behaved or whatever spoke this and that. So definitely parents, people I’ve come in contact with, friends, discussions with people.

column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on personal intuition and the potential future consequences of their actions, influenced by their upbringing and observations of their parents, while also considering social input from peers and the moral obligation to help others, although they acknowledge that moral views can change based on individual circumstances.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Just, like, gut feeling.  If it feels wrong, you know, don’t do it, but.
I:And is that easy in general, or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I would say it’s easy.  Like, if I hear something, I just – I’ll be honest.  Like, that’s a bad idea.  Let’s not do that.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the last couple of years?
R:I’d say easier.
I:Okay, how’s that?
R:It’s kind of easy to get caught up in trying to have fun, like, any means necessary, but just got a little older and it was like, I don’t know.
I:Okay, like, examples maybe?
R:Just, like, hopping on a train to get across town, but just running up and grabbing onto the damn thing and taking it for a ride to get over to a party or something.  It’s a really bad idea.
I:You used to do a lot of that when you were younger?
R:Just – yeah, dumb stuff like that.
I:Have your views about right and wrong changes over the last couple of years?
R:I suppose just trying to stay away from dumb stuff like that I guess, but. The main stuff is always like – that’s just set in stone.  You can’t really change, like, the important things.  I suppose the little stuff has a bit…
I:Can you give examples again of what’s?
R:Just, like, that whole, you know, just in any means necessary having fun, like, just dumb like someone’s got a CD, and you want his CD, and you just take it.  Just dumb little menial…
I:Okay, so the big stuff, you’re saying, is –
R:Yeah. That’s simple.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I would just – I think right and wrong, everyone uses their opinion, like –
I:Like, is it maybe just consequences of your actions, or is it how you feel about it, or is it, like, laws, or rules?
R:What do you mean?  Like, are those, like, those factors?
I:Yeah, like why would something be wrong, and in that case that you were in that car, and what?
R:Mostly the repercussions of what would happen if we were to get stopped or something.
I:Okay, so maybe the consequences you’d say are the –
R:Yeah.
I:Okay, and what kinds of consequences makes it – you know, is it just because it’s legal, or are there other kinds of –
R:In that particular situation it was a legal factor, like, and my safety was a factor, but I don’t know.  Each situation really has its own particular factors that determine how it’s –
I:Do you think the consequences are probably the most important factor?
R:That would really depend on the situation too because, like, the consequences, like, falling down because you had too many drinks.  That would be, like – but other things – factors more than that.
I:What sort of other…?
R:Not really sure.
I:Where have you acquired your own moral views from?
R:Just from everywhere.  Just from what I – what you read, and what you find to be interesting or something, like, if you read a book, and you really – you know, it really catches you, and you’re gonna pick a little bit of that up, and it’s gonna shape you, you know. Pretty much everything’s about – people you talk to or something that really had, like, a meaningful conversation with you.  It would just stick with you, and shape you, and –
I:Are there any examples you have, like, in your own life, the things that have changed you, people, or books, or events, or ideas?
R:Offhand, I really can’t think of one.  I know they are, but I just can’t.
I:M8:That’s all right.  If it comes to you, let me know.  Some people believe that it’s sometimes okay to break moral rules if it works to your advantage and you can get away with it.  What do you think about that?

That would be, like – but other things – factors more than that. Not really sure.  Just from everywhere.  Just from what I – what you read, and what you find to be interesting or something, like, if you read a book, and you really – you know, it really catches you, and you’re gonna pick a little bit of that up, and it’s gonna shape you, you know. Pretty much everything’s about – people you talk to or something that really had, like, a meaningful conversation with you. column591: The respondent primarily relies on gut feelings to determine right from wrong, acknowledges the influence of peer pressure in decision-making, and believes that while moral views can be shaped by various experiences, ultimately, personal happiness guides their choices over external advice or religious teachings.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide what's good or bad, right or wrong in life?
R:Just things like, I’ve experienced in life, just certain things I won't do, morals.
I:How do you, like in terms of deciding what's right and wrong, is that generally easy or hard.
R:It's usually pretty easy. I guess it all depends on the person, you know. For me, it's pretty easy to. I guess it just depends on what it is.
I:In general, in the situations that you've found yourself in, the last few years, maybe last two, three years, has it been easy or hard, has it been getting easier, or getting harder to figure out right and wrong?
R:Easier.
I:Why would you say? Do you never find yourself struggling, or anything to do the right thing?
R:I guess, it's becoming easier as I'm getting older to get in less trouble. I guess there are situations where I do the wrong thing, but afterwards, I guess, you know, it wouldn’t be a situation of what you should have done.
I:Cool, so you feel like you’re learning?
R:Yeah, it's all kind of a learning thing.
I:Have your views of right and wrong changed over the past couple of years?
R:Probably. Like, I got in big trouble with drinking and driving, and I never really paid attention to that. And now, that's definitely an issue in my life. Definitely  learning.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I guess it's a person's background, things you've been taught. You can be taught something wrong, and think it's right. And then, it kind of goes by...
I:How do you figure out, if you're taught something that's wrong, how do you come to find out that it's wrong? What is it about it that's wrong?
R:I don't know. I guess you wouldn't know it was wrong, if you were taught that all of your life.
I:We live in a society with different people, with different ideas about what is right and wrong, how do we... Some people would say it’s consequences, is it the result of an action, if it makes things work out with you, then it's right?  Other people say it's how you feel, it's how you feel about it, and that's all that matters.
R:A mix of both, it can advance you, but it's wrong, and it could advance you, but maybe if you do it. Go on what you're feeling, but try and do for yourself in a way, but not to hurt anybody.
I:Some people said that there were rules and principles that were absolutely wrong?  You think that's possible?
R:Probably. There's definitely a lot of things you shouldn't do.
I:Do you have an example?
R:Drinking and driving. Treating other people bad. Pretty much, like, hurting other people.
I:Why is that wrong?
R:I don't want to be messed with.
I:You wouldn't want that to happen to you?
R:Yeah.
I:Do you have any idea of where you acquired your moral views from?
R:Probably my parents, and their parents.
I:Do they talk to you a lot about, when you were growing up or now, about how to figure out right and wrong, about what you should and shouldn't do?
R:Not anything specific, I guess. I don't know. I'd say that... I don't really know any specific moments.
column590: Just things like, I’ve experienced in life, just certain things I won't do, morals. It's usually pretty easy. I guess it all depends on the person, you know. For me, it's pretty easy to. I guess it just depends on what it is. Easier. I guess, it's becoming easier as I'm getting older to get in less trouble. I guess there are situations where I do the wrong thing, but afterwards, I guess, you know, it wouldn’t be a situation of what you should have done. Yeah, it's all kind of a learning thing. Probably. Like, I got in big trouble with drinking and driving, and I never really paid attention to that. And now, that's definitely an issue in my life. Definitely  learning.  I guess it's a person's background, things you've been taught. You can be taught something wrong, and think it's right. And then, it kind of goes by... I don't know. I guess you wouldn't know it was wrong, if you were taught that all of your life. A mix of both, it can advance you, but it's wrong, and it could advance you, but maybe if you do it. Go on what you're feeling, but try and do for yourself in a way, but not to hurt anybody. Probably. There's definitely a lot of things you shouldn't do. Drinking and driving. Treating other people bad. Pretty much, like, hurting other people. I don't want to be messed with. Yeah.  Probably my parents, and their parents. Not anything specific, I guess. I don't know. I'd say that... I don't really know any specific moments.
column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on personal experience and morals, finds it easier to discern right from wrong as they age, acknowledges the influence of their parents on their moral views, and believes that ultimately, happiness should guide their choices, even when considering the consequences of actions like drinking and driving.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:How it would affect someone else.  If it would affect someone else negatively or positively, that’s how I would determine what’s good or bad.
I:Um hm.  In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:For the most part, it’s pretty easy.
I:Ok.  So what makes it easy?
R:Just because – I mean, like I said, I was brought up really well.  I was raised really well, so being in a situation – it doesn’t really take long for me to understand what I need to do to make a positive impact rather than, like, go do something wrong or something bad.
I:Is deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:It’s gotten easier.
I:Why is that?
R:Just because I’ve matured a lot more, so I don’t really have to think twice about doing something or reflecting on something.  I just kinda know instinctively what I need to do.
I:Have your views about right and wrong changed much in the past two years?
R:Not really.
I:Ok.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:What makes something right or wrong?
I:Yeah.  Tough question, I know.
R:Yeah.  I guess, like, what I was talking about before – whether or not it has a good impact or negative impact, how it affects me, how it affects someone else –
I:Um hm.  So what would be a good or a negative impact?  Like, what would be a good impact?  What would be a negative one?
R:A good impact if it makes someone else happy, if it makes myself happy – a negative one would be just the opposite.  If it hurts someone in any way or if it’s detrimental to my health, my well-being, things like that.
I:So in the party situation – I don’t know.  You giving a guy your number – what would be the positive or negative impact?
R:I mean, positive I guess would be that they’re not getting rejected.  Negative would be just the fact that I’m, I guess, opening myself up to someone who I don’t really know that well.  And I mean, people are – you can’t tell what type of person someone is by having a 20-minute, 30-minute conversation with them.  So I guess in the long run, that might hurt me.  But for the time being, I kinda adjust.
I:Ok.  From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:My parents, my religion and I guess people who I’m around.
column590: How it would affect someone else.  If it would affect someone else negatively or positively, that’s how I would determine what’s good or bad. For the most part, it’s pretty easy. Just because – I mean, like I said, I was brought up really well.  I was raised really well, so being in a situation – it doesn’t really take long for me to understand what I need to do to make a positive impact rather than, like, go do something wrong or something bad. It’s gotten easier. Just because I’ve matured a lot more, so I don’t really have to think twice about doing something or reflecting on something.  I just kinda know instinctively what I need to do. Not really.  What makes something right or wrong? Yeah.  I guess, like, what I was talking about before – whether or not it has a good impact or negative impact, how it affects me, how it affects someone else – A good impact if it makes someone else happy, if it makes myself happy – a negative one would be just the opposite.  If it hurts someone in any way or if it’s detrimental to my health, my well-being, things like that. I mean, positive I guess would be that they’re not getting rejected.  Negative would be just the fact that I’m, I guess, opening myself up to someone who I don’t really know that well.  And I mean, people are – you can’t tell what type of person someone is by having a 20-minute, 30-minute conversation with them.  So I guess in the long run, that might hurt me.  But for the time being, I kinda adjust.  My parents, my religion and I guess people who I’m around.
column591: The respondent emphasizes the importance of helping their parents due to their upbringing, relies on the impact of their actions on others to determine right from wrong, acknowledges the influence of their parents and religion on their moral views, and expresses a belief in the necessity of personal happiness over strict adherence to religious doctrine when making decisions.

column583:
I:Well how do you know what’s right and what’s wrong?
R:How do I know what’s right and what’s wrong, um, that little voice in my head is just kind of like telling me this is not good.  Um, the way I do it is I think okay, if my mom was here, would I want to do this.  Would I want her to see me doing this.  Because I want my mom to trust me and respect me and so I don’t want,
I:You don’t want to do anything that’s gonna let her down.
R:Yeah.  Or let myself down.
I:So what makes one thing right and another thing wrong, would you say? How, what’s the dividing line?  How do you know?  You had a feeling, there’s a little voice inside, but what I want to know is where that voice comes from.
R:How do I know, um,  I, well, I try not to do things that I, I mean, ever since after that, you know, I haven’t been in a situation like that or I mean as big as that, but if I’m trying to make a decision between right and wrong I’m sort of like okay, how am I gonna feel about myself after I do this.
I:Right.
R:And that’s how I decide.
I:And you said earlier how’s your mom gonna feel?
R:And now it’s like how am I gonna feel about myself, you know after I do this, am I gonna feel like a bad person like I shouldn’t have done that, am I gonna go home and be like why did I do that or am I gonna feel good about myself after doing this, like was this a good thing to do, I’m glad I did or didn’t do that.
I:Do you think you were born with that instinct, do you think you learned it from the people around you or from something else, from what you were taught?
R:Um, I mean I’m sure I was taught it early on, I mean it feels like I was born with it but I think, I mean I was always just a really, when I was a little kid, I was always just a real well behaved little kid, I didn’t throw like a lot of temper tantrums on stores and stuff and so I’m guessing that’s just something I was born with, I mean I never wanted to embarrass anyone or make a scene or do anything wrong.
I:You said that you thought you were taught it early on, okay,
R:But now that I think about it I probably wasn’t because I mean,
I:So you think your parents would just allow you to be who you unfolded into being?
R:Yes.  My mom has always said, you know I don’t want to mold you, I don’t, cause I think her mom tried to kind of like make her into someone that she wasn’t and um, she’s always saying I don’t want to make you into someone you’re not, I want you to just be who you are and do what you want to do, but, yeah, I think my parents just let me kind of become who I want to be.
I:And so their ideas of right and wrong are based on how, what you think is right and wrong?
R:Um, I guess, yeah.
I:Give me a few things that you’d say are wrong.
R:Um, teasing people.
I:Teasing people.
R:I really don’t like it when people tease people.
I:Why?
R:Because it’s mean and no one deserves that.
I:Why is it bad to be mean?
R:Why is it bad to be mean?  Um, because I know what it’s like for people to be mean to you, um, I mean I’m not like a target for like people being mean to me but I’ve had people, you know talk about me behind my back and it feels really bad and I wouldn’t want anyone else to go through that.  I don't know why it’s mean, it just is.
I:You don’t want other people to feel bad.
R:Yeah.  I mean,
I:Why not?
R:I mean, I guess if they have a reason, I mean I think it’s different when, if someone’s, if something’s, if someone’s done something to you, then I think it’s fine for you to be a little bit confrontational with them, and say excuse me, why did you do that, I don’t appreciate this.  But just random, I mean if it was just a random person that you know you have like this biased opinion about you know this like first impression and you, I mean there’s no reason for you to go be mean to them and make judgments about them before you know them.
column584: How do I know what’s right and what’s wrong, um, that little voice in my head is just kind of like telling me this is not good.  Um, the way I do it is I think okay, if my mom was here, would I want to do this.  Would I want her to see me doing this.  Because I want my mom to trust me and respect me and so I don’t want, Yeah.  Or let myself down. column585: The respondent reflects on their decision-making process, noting that they often rely on their intuition and the desire to avoid disappointing their mother, which led them to regret a reckless decision involving throwing objects off a rooftop, ultimately emphasizing the importance of considering the consequences of their actions and the influence of their upbringing on their moral compass.

R:Probably my parents.
column584: Probably my parents.
column585: The respondent's views on right and wrong are primarily influenced by their parents, and they acknowledge peer pressure as a factor in moral decision-making, while expressing discomfort with their past involvement in gang fights and a desire to avoid the negative outcomes seen in their parents' lives.

R:Morals and beliefs from both what I’ve seen.
I:Uh-huh?
R:Um, cuz of the area I live in, it’s just a really bad area.
I:Okay.
R:Um, and, me and my friends call it the “Wanna Be War zone,” which is actually worse than the actual war zone.
I:Okay.
R:Um, cuz they try harder.  And um, and pretty much my beliefs like Christianity.
I:Okay, um, in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s generally easy.  Sometimes it’s hard, but generally, it’s easy.
I:Can you give me an example of sometime maybe when it was hard?
R:Um.
I:Or the kinds of things that it’s bitter hard?  Maybe you just gotta?
R:Just, I can’t really think of any instances right now, but like in the past, it’s cuz I use to have an anger issue and that always used to come into a, effect and it’s always been hard to kind of control area.  I did it not really well.
I:Okay, um, has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:It’s gotten easier.
I:Why is that?
R:Cuz um older and I’m mature and I know why, why I think it’s right and why I think it’s wrong instead of being told what’s right and being told what’s wrong.
I:Not recently, okay, um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Cause and effect, pretty much.
I:What do you mean by that?
R:If like the consequence, will it have consequence to it, stuff like that, like, I’ll go back to like we’ll go back to drugs and sex for instance, you know, the reason that I think, you know doing that is bad doing drugs is bad is because you lose control over your actions and you don’t, you’re not able to control what you do.  Sex you know, that that goes a long way, you know, you, there’s the whole fact of pregnancy, there’s the whole fact of, uh, disease, there’s the whole, that whole fact.  Like, I said cause and effect.
I:So, you, you also mentioned sort of consequences, I’m curious, so, what kinds of consequences would make something wrong, like is there, are there certain kinds of consequence?
R:Actually, that’s a good point to bring up because some good things bring consequences, but it’s, it’s mostly, does it help you and help other people, or does it hurt you and hurt other people?
I:Okay, so, when you say that um, the kinds of consequences that make something wrong would be if it hurts you or hurts other people.
R:Yeah.
I:Okay, are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:I don’t, can you repeat that one more time?
I:Sure, are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves?
R:In my eyes, yes, but then again there’s always the fact of that what is the word I’m looking for, that there’s that, always that fact of like, there’s things that it can help people, like, like I said, for drugs, you know, let’s take marijuana for example.  Some doctors give it out as a prescription for pain.  Is that wrong?  I don’t know, I don’t know if I have the right to say or not cuz I’ve never had that.
I:Well, so a second ago you said in your eyes, yes, there are things that are always wrong in and of themselves, so what some examples of those kinds of things, just for you like, tell me what you think.
R:Well like sex before marriage and I think personally like I said with drugs, they’re bad.  Um, and the reason that  I’m so strong on, on, I don’t know if you can tell but the reason I’m so strong on it is cuz I see how it’s messed up my dad. And my uncle, cuz they’re twin brothers and they were in, they were in the penitentiary for awhile and they, now that that’s you know, doing all of the heavy stuff, they’ve, have heart trouble, they have just stuff like that that’s really bad.  And I just see that and that’s why I think, that’s why in my eyes, I see that it’s always wrong.
I:Always, to kill.  What makes that wrong?
R:Because who are you to take anoth-, to take person’s life?  To take something that doesn’t belong to you?
I:So is it kinda like theft in that sense?
R:Yeah.
I:So what makes, what makes theft wrong?  I mean is it, I mean.
R:Because, because who are you to take what doesn’t belong to you.
I:Do you think that it’s wrong because of the consequences or do you think it’s wrong for some other reason?
R:I think it’s wrong for a number of reasons, but mostly consequence for you and that person.
I:In, in what terms, what?
R:In terms as I don’t know I’ll just use terms as financial wise.  Let’s say that this person paid I don’t know, let’s say $50,000 on the computer.  You take that computer, they spent all their saving on it.  Now they have no money.  Consequence is for you, you could be caught cuz it is illegal. Consequence for them, they might be not be able to get another one.

R:Well I consider I’ve seen what, I’ve seen a lot of stuff that I think is right and a lot of stuff that I think is wrong just that’s, I built it from actions I’ve seen and consequences I’ve seen and.

column588: The respondent expresses a strong sense of responsibility towards their mother by planning to share the inheritance with her, emphasizes the importance of saving for the future, and believes that their moral compass is shaped by personal experiences and Christian beliefs, while also recognizing the influence of their environment and the consequences of actions in determining right and wrong.

column583:
I:Okay and that’s what—where, where do you think your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:I’d say my parents.
I:Okay.  Um, and what do you, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, how, like it would impact your future.
I:How it would impact your future.
R:Whether near or far future.
I:Okay.  And so how would you, how do you decide what’s a right or wrong impact on your future?
R:Is this gonna hurt me?  Is this gonna um, you know, maybe make my chances of succeeding in life harder?  What’s gonna happen, you know.
I:Okay.  What if, um, what if there’s some, so somebody decides this is, um, you know, it’s good for me to, to do this because it’s gonna help me in the future, but somebody else might be hurt in the process, is that still okay because it’s beneficial for your future?
R:Mm, you have to take into like consideration other people’s futures, too, you can’t, you can’t just say oh this is great for me, sorry you know, you who, you know, lost out.
I:So how does that work, the balance with someone, why, why is it important to take in consideration someone else’s future?
R:Um, because if you do something that affects them then they have to counteract that and it’s gonna come back to bite you.
I:Okay so because it might come back to bite you.  Is there any, any sort of, beyond just making sure you don’t get repercussions, is there any other reason why, I mean, is that the only reason you shouldn’t hurt someone else or is that, that the primary reason?
R:Um, well if you’re gonna you know, mess up their life forever, you kind of take into consideration, well, I, you know, I could have done something else and they would have been fine and I would have been fine, so that has to be taken into consideration.
I:Okay, um, why, you had said earlier you, that you know, that morality is relative, it’s whatever’s right for you, so why do you think what, can you explain your thinking behind that, why do you, why would you say you agree with that statement?
R:Um, well, if you do one thing and it helps you but it doesn’t help someone else, obviously that thing wouldn’t have been good for them.  So, it’s kind of like ah, you know, I don’t know, um, kind of a paradox, but, um.
I:So if someone, I mean if someone decides, well I think that, I think it’s right for me to steal this car, so I’m gonna go ahead and steal it cause I think that’s right, is that okay?  Or is that a problem?
R:It’s a problem because it’s affecting the car owner.
I:Okay.
R:Who would not have benefited from that, I mean.
I:So do you think there’s any limits on it, whatever’s right, the, so whatever’s right for you?
R:Yeah.  If it’s gonna hurt someone else.
I:Okay.  So if it hurts someone else, then it’s not right.
R:Right.
I:Okay how, how would you decide whether some thing is gonna hurt someone else?
R:Um, well you think, what would be the consequences if I was in that person’s shoes, what would happen to me?
I:Okay.  So how, how do we know which consequences are good and which consequences are bad?  I mean what makes us, what makes a certain consequence bad?
R:Um, it’s back to the whole, if it’s harmful to you.  You know, if um, your life is affected by it negatively.

column585: The respondent believes that while morality is relative and shaped by parental influence, decisions are primarily based on the potential impact on their future and the consequences for others, emphasizing the importance of honesty and the avoidance of actions that could harm others, such as cheating or lying.
