column589:
I:Okay, how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I just think of something, um, you know deep down inside it has to do with what you’ve been raised, what you’ve been taught as you’ve been raised.  I think that’s a big part, that can you know, I’ll be in a situation and I’ll recall something my mom told me when I was five years old or six years old and that will still come back to me today. And I think it’s those teachings from when you’re younger that stay with you and then they help form your thoughts and beliefs and um, yeah, beliefs about what’s right and wrong when you’re older as an adult.
I:Can you give me something, an example of something your mom told you when you were little that still comes back to you sometimes?  Like what sorts of things?
R:It may be silly but just um, when it comes to like friendships, when I was younger and you still teach your child about you know you don’t exclude this person because of this, you include everybody and accept everybody for who they are.  So you know, as I would meet new people I would keep that in mind.  Not so much now but when I was in middle school and even in high school, I would always keep that with me and I learned from that so I treat people with respect and I treat people the way I would want to be treated and like that.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s usually easy.
I:And has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:It’s gotten easier, the past two years?
I:Mm-hmm .
R:Yeah, it’s gotten easier as I’ve become more mature.  Um, .
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Morals.
I:What do you mean?
R:Um, I think right or wrong has to do with respect to, um, others as well as yourself.  Yeah, I think it comes down to respect, um, if you um, have a friend that you’re talking bad about her behind your back, that’s disrespectful to that person.  if you have a boyfriend who is cheating on you but you continue a relationship with him, that’s disrespectful to yourself, so it would be wrong for you to stay with that person, not treating you right.  I think that’s how you know what’s right and wrong.

R:Um, I kind of think it’s, all right but I’m not quite sure on all, everything.

R:Yeah.

column585: The respondent primarily relies on their mother's opinions to guide their decisions, acknowledges the influence of friends over parents in shaping their moral views, believes that morality is subjective and varies among individuals, and feels guilty when they yell at their mother, indicating an internal sense of right and wrong despite sometimes engaging in behaviors they deem wrong, such as fighting and cheating, while also recognizing social pressures related to drinking and drug use among peers.

column583:
I:Okay.  Where would you say your own view of right and wrong came from?
R:It’s just what my parents taught me, it’s just kind of what I’ve learned.

column584: It’s just what my parents taught me, it’s just kind of what I’ve learned. I don’t know…it’s…uh, I’m not sure. It’s just kind of common sense I guess.
column585: The respondent makes decisions primarily by consulting their parents for guidance on right and wrong, believes that societal standards of morality are relatively clear but often ignored, and attributes their understanding of right and wrong to common sense and parental teachings, while also expressing a strong stance against cheating, lying, and substance use due to their illegality and harmful effects.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um, I don’t know, just values that my parents taught me from when I was a kid.  Stuff I picked up from books and whatnot.
I:Like what kind of books?
R:Uh, I read a lot of science fiction, fantasy kind of books.
I:And, give me an example of some sort of, how do you pick up morality from that?
R:I guess it’s just the kind of choices I’d make or something.  Just reading about different characters kind of show you different ways that people think that people would react.  So,
I:What kind of science fiction?
R:Uh, generally fantasy.
I:Like Star Wars?  Or like Lord of the Rings?
R:No, I like the Lord of the Rings stuff
I:You do.
R:Yeah.
I:Did you pick up morality from that?
R:Not from Lord of the Rings.  I tried to pick up that book, I got through about the first 50 pages, and it was too boring.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:I think it’s gotten harder, just cause there’s just so much, that people feel is right but that it’s known that it’s wrong.
I:Give me an example if you can.
R:Just like people smoking or drinking.  Like people know they can do it, and they think it’s fun, but
I:Is it wrong to do those things?
R:Yeah, cause it’s against the law.  Since we’re not 18.
I:Is that the only reason it’s wrong?
R:Yeah, and just cause it’s bad for your health and that kind of stuff.
I:So let’s say, you already said you didn’t smoke, right?
R:Yeah.
I:18, going to pick it up?
R:No.
I:It’s not going to be illegal anymore.
R:Right.  But it’s bad for your health.
I:What about drinking, do you drink?
R:Uh, I’ve dranken a couple times but,
I:Drank a little bit, or drank and got drunk?
R:I drank a little bit, not too much.
I:Um, say you’re 21, I mean drinking isn’t necessarily bad for your health.
R:I think drinking is fine as long as it’s not done in excess where your judgment is impaired,
I:Is it bad to do that?
R:Yes, cause then you
I:Is it wrong to do that?
R:I don’t think it’s that wrong, but I think it’s something that shouldn’t be done just because of the harmful effects that it can have.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think it’s more of just the person deciding just how they view things.  I think only a person can decide what’s right or wrong for them.
I:So something could be right for one person but wrong for another person?
R:Yep.  Well the person that’s looking at it, they might think that something’s wrong, it all depends on who’s making the choices, and who’s doing it, that kind of stuff.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Uh, well obviously like killing a person or something.  That’s wrong, no matter how you look at it.
I:Okay.  What else?
R:Just like stealing and anything else that’s harmful to everybody including yourself.  That puts people at risk for getting in trouble and whatnot.
I:Well some people could say well lots of things could be harmful to people and not even know it.  Um, your neighbor could be doing drugs and some, and bring the drug trade to your neighborhood, and so it didn’t actually harm you but eventually it’s going to cause a problem, is that right?
R:Well like drugs and stuff, they do hurt people cause everyone who takes the drugs their decision making is going to be impaired.
I:So drugs would always be wrong.
R:Yeah.
I:So where do you get your moral views from?
R:Uh, I don’t know, just what I decide on.  What I get from what I observe and,

column588: The respondent plans to use an inheritance primarily for college expenses, values strategic financial planning influenced by their upbringing, and believes that moral decisions are shaped by personal values and societal influences, while acknowledging the complexity of right and wrong in contemporary society.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Mostly just gut feeling. Feels wrong, I don’t do it.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to figure that out?
R:Uh, I find it pretty easy.
I:And has it changed in any way over the last couple of years? Has it gotten easier or harder?
R:Uh…I’d say it’s a lot more fuzzy. Just.. a little more hard to determine what’s right or what’s wrong.
I:Ok. Now what do you think it might be that makes something right of wrong? Why is something wrong?
R:Uh…well I think that one goes back to religion. I think a lot of … what we think is right or wrong is based in how you were raised and what kind of religion you grew up in.
I:Is it just because the religion gives you these rules and that’s what determines it?
R:I would say so. I think the Ten Commandments has a lot to do with it. Just the Bible.
I:Ok. Where have you gotten your own moral views from?
R:Well, everything I read and watch on tv and… that kind of stuff. Tend to pick up a little bit from everything.
I:And have they changed in any way, your ideas of right and wrong, over the last 3 years?
R:Uh, I’d say they’ve gotten…a little bit looser. I don’t worry about stuff quite as much.
I:Any examples of what kind of things?
R:Uh, just…like drugs and…underage drinking and that kinda stuff. Just…doesn’t tend to bother me that much anymore.
I:How come?
R:Uh…callous I suppose. Seen too many people doin ‘em.
I:Ok. So your morals you say come from reading and watching TV and…
R:Right.
I:And also your religion you say? So it’s a combination of these things?
R:Pretty much.
I:Are they ever in conflict with each other? Like does your religion tell you something and then a book you read tells you something different?
R:Uh, not typically. Generally they match up pretty well. Especially ‘cause…from my religion,  and that kinda stuff.
I:And you find that it’s commonsensical almost?
R:Pretty much.
I:What about when…like do you have friends who disagree with you on your morals?
R:Uh…sometimes. Friends…most of my friends tend to be…a little less morally obstinate  than me. They’ll take the sleazy way and…worry about the consequences later.
I:Ok. But you think that’s wrong? You don’t agree with that?
R:I don’t like doing that. I don’t…. I don’t like having consequences catch up with me.
I:Ok. Have you had examples of when that’s happened to you or?
R:Uh, not really. Keep myself out of those situations usually.
I:Ok. Because some people might say, well, ‘you’ve got your morals and they’ve got their morals; why are they wrong?’ something like that. How would you respond to that?
R:Uh…
I:Like have you ever tried to persuade a friend that what they think is right is really not right?
R:Uh, generally I try to leave my friends to what they wanna do. So long as it doesn’t … pull me in, I’m fine with whatever they wanna do.

column591: The respondent primarily relies on gut feelings to determine right from wrong, believes their moral views are influenced by religion and media, and prefers to follow friends' values over parental guidance, while acknowledging the importance of helping others when it doesn't require undue effort.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Good or bad in life.  I come up like with a decision, like it’s gonna clear right, right off the bat, if it’s a good idea or a bad idea, I still might think about it, still like, will I regret doing it, or will I gain something from it, you know.  Yeah, I’d still think about it.
I:Okay so it’s mostly just a kind of a, you just kind of feel it, you just kind of know it?
R:Instinct.
I:Instinct, okay.  Do you feel like it’s gotten easier or harder in the last couple years for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Oh, it’s easier.  In college, they got, in high school people do a whole bunch of different stuff and I’m like nah, I ain’t gonna do it this time, I just, just ya’ll handle it and I just watch or whatever, I ain’t gonna participate.
I:Would you say that it’s in general easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s easy.
I:Okay.  What would you say it is that actually makes something right or wrong?
R:It’s right or wrong, like if you have, if you have to have some consequences, like going to jail or being arrested or that’s considered being bad, so like I ain’t trying to break the law or nothing like that.  So that’s hard to determine, you got some dude breaking the law like not as bad, I ain’t gonna mess with.
I:Okay, so consequences.  Anything else.
R:No, that’s all.
I:Is that how, so you got your views on morality from like your parents growing up, they taught you?
R:Yeah, common sense too like, want to do the right thing.
I:Okay.  Anything else, like any other place you got your views of right and wrong?
R:Yeah, just my parents and I’ve been around them like, me and my friends be doing stuff in the neighborhood and like nah, that’s wrong, we shouldn’t even do that, situations.
I:Do you feel like most of your friends kind of agree with you about the way things, like would they be, thinking about right and wrong in similar ways?
R:Yeah, like I can always tell them what’s right and wrong, it’s not up to me if they gonna do it or not, you know, I’ll probably like me and my roommate, we probably the oldest around now, they probably look up to us, they see me doing wrong, they might be doing wrong someday, I just tell them they need to mellow out or whatever, and get your head straight so you know you can get up out of here.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, my parents really, like you know they tell you when you’re young, like you know this is right and this is wrong, so it’s supposed to stick to your head, in your head, like you know and like somebody might tell you when you’re younger, but then it might come up when you’re older, like you know in your head it’s wrong, like it’s been in your head, you know, you hear from like your parents, your aunts, your uncles that’s wrong and it should stick in your head.  Now if you make the decision to do it, that’s your own mistake, you know hopefully nothing bad will come of it.  You’re taking a chance there.
I:What is it fundamentally that you think makes something right or wrong?
R:I think that if it’s like something like with the drinking, if you know you’re drinking and you’re gonna get drunk cause you can’t really control your liquor, you need to like take it back and like you know get with your friends and sober up before you leave anywhere, you know you want to get drunk on your own time in your own house, don’t go out and go bother someone, and like you know you shouldn’t curse, you know what’s right and wrong, it’s-
I:So what I’m hearing you saying maybe is that cause you affect other people, so what if I just want to sit by myself in my room and get hammered or you know, and I’m not gonna drive, I’m not gonna do anything, is that wrong?
R:It’s still wrong.  You shouldn’t be drinking.
I:Okay, so what is it that makes that wrong?
R:Um, it’s the fact that you know drinking, you should know from health class that drinking is bad for your health, but some people just don’t care, like you know they figure you know I hate it when people say do you smoke cause you think it’s cool?  Some people smoke cause they just like smoking, it’s as simple as that, so.
I:So, so, if you had to define supposed you were writing a dictionary, you would say wrong.  Define the word wrong.
R:Wrong is something that does bodily harm and harm to other people and it’s not good for you.
I:Okay, I can live with that.  For wrong, that’s a good definition.  A succinct definition. How do you decide in your life, you’re trying to make a decision, you know from anything you’re like, do you want a hamburger to do you want to cut class, I mean, you know there’s a process that goes through your head.  Take me through that process, and how you say, okay, out put, this is wrong, this is right?
R:With like serious matters, like that might like you know what to do with my future wise, I would have to consult my parents and people, like I like asking people’s opinions of things.
I:Uh-huh. Okay.
R:But like with a hamburger, it’s either you want a hamburger, or, I might be on the line and there’s a decision like hamburger, chicken or hamburger, if I have a hamburger the other day, I’m having chicken the next day, so you know, so some stuff is like you know simple, you know like make up your own mind.  But other things that affect your life, you maybe should consult somebody with.

column585: The respondent makes decisions based on a strong moral compass instilled by their parents, avoids peer pressure from friends, and feels guilty about potentially disappointing family members, which influences their choices and actions.
column589:
I:Ok.  So how do you normally decide or know what’s good or bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Sometimes you kinda go on guy feeling.  Like, sometimes, I have, like, a really bad feeling about certain things, so I’m like, “I’m not gonna go through with that.”  And other times, I do ask for advice from a parent, friend.
I:Um hm.  So in general, would you say that it’s easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:No, right and wrong is not a problem.  It’s in between issues – the gray area – that I get advice on.  The right – usually, I’m pretty good with, “This is right, and this is wrong.”  And if I feel like – if I’m undecided, that means it’s wrong.  Like, some things should be clearly right and wrong.  Now, if I’m undecided about it, maybe because it’s wrong.
I:So do you think that deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or harder?  Like, are there more or less gray area things for you?
R:I feel like when you’re younger, it’s less gray areas.  Like, it’s either right or wrong.
I:So in the last couple of years?
R:I think there’s more gray areas – more gray.
I:Can you think of any reason why?
R:I feel like because as you grow, you kind of – you’re supposed to, like, build into your own person and, like, know who you are.  And so I’m thinking I’m still developing that.  So a lot of times, I’m like, “I’m not sure if I should.”  Yeah.  “I’m not sure what to do in this situation.”
I:Ok.  So would you say your views on anything dealing with right and wrong has changed over the last few years?
R:My view on things being right and wrong?  I wouldn’t say – it probably has because if you – I guess it depends on the situation that you’re in.  And therefore, I may view it differently.  And you have people who view things differently in certain situations and other situations.
I:No, like, particular –
R:Not everything you view is coming out –
I:So let’s see.  What do you think it is that, like, makes something right or wrong?
R:I think just your basic knowledge on what you think is right and wrong.
I:Like, is it, like, a feeling?  Or is it a belief?
R:Yeah.  A belief – sometimes it’s a belief or your moral values or – makes things right and wrong.
I:So where do you think most – like, where these kind of beliefs about right and wrong come from usually?
R:For me, probably my parents.  Like, influences in my life – past experiences.
I:Ok.  What about – let’s see.  What do you think about right and wrong generally?  Not just for you, but like, in kind of an abstract way?  Like, what makes something right or wrong, do you think?
R:I feel like – things that makes things right or wrong.
I:It’s kind of a hard question, so take your time.
R:I think what makes things right and wrong – kinda like, if you have – if you’re gonna have doubts about doing something afterwards, then you know it’s right or wrong.  Like me, I – like, my conscience is real guilty sometimes.  So, like, if I know – if I do something whole-heartedly, and I don’t feel bad afterwards, then I know I did the right thing.  If I feel like – I have issues afterwards, I know it was the wrong thing to do.
I:Ok.  So like, where do you feel like those, like, feelings about right and wrong come from?  Anywhere in particular?  Or any source?
R:I don’t know.  Probably like our adrenaline.  Like, I get, like, real – my stomach starts hurting.  My heart starts beating.  And all physiological things start happening.  So that’s where I get it from mostly.
I:So thinking about right and wrong generally, not just for you – who or what do you think has kind of the authority to decide, like, what’s right and wrong?  Who would you, like, trust to decide what’s right and wrong for you or what?  Anything in particular?  Or is it really more like a feeling?
R:I think a lot of it is more of a feeling.  I would say more of a feeling is a thing to go on, as well as – it could also be whether or not it’s – I – to me sometimes, also, like, just going back into, like, my childhood and, like, knowing what my parents have said – that also – I could go on based on whether that was right or wrong.  Although my parents should not be the ultimate decider, they probably still are.
I:Ok.  So where would you say your ideas about what’s right and wrong have come from?
R:I would say mostly, like, young influences.  And also going back to that gut feeling and – just in terms of, like, following rules and things like that – probably whatever has been set forth, like, whether or not it be governmental laws – but just knowing what’s right and wrong because you will get penalized for that.  So just following that kind of basis.

No, right and wrong is not a problem.  It’s in between issues – the gray area – that I get advice on. So just following that kind of basis.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on intuition and gut feelings to navigate decisions about right and wrong, often seeking advice from friends and parents, while acknowledging that their understanding of morality has evolved over time, particularly in recognizing gray areas in complex situations.

column583:
I:What, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Ah, what was the question?
I:where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Where do my views come from?
I:Yeah.
R:My Mom.  My family, my grandfather.  My Uncles, stuff like that.
I:And what would say makes something right or wrong?
R:Let’s see, makes something right or wrong…knowing you’re wrong when you do it, that’s what makes it right or wrong.
I:Okay, so where, where does the kind of, where you know come from?
R:Um, well you’ve been told not to do that, you know, you’ve seen on TV don’t do, you know, they have those anti-drug commercials and when you’re doing it wrong, and you know it’s wrong and you’re doing it, that’s when you know it’s wrong.
column584: Ah, what was the question? Where do my views come from? My Mom.  My family, my grandfather.  My Uncles, stuff like that. Let’s see, makes something right or wrong…knowing you’re wrong when you do it, that’s what makes it right or wrong. Um, well you’ve been told not to do that, you know, you’ve seen on TV don’t do, you know, they have those anti-drug commercials and when you’re doing it wrong, and you know it’s wrong and you’re doing it, that’s when you know it’s wrong.
column585: The respondent reflects on their decision-making process, emphasizing the influence of their family's values on their sense of right and wrong, their struggle with peer pressure at parties, and feelings of guilt associated with actions like making fun of others or lying to parents, while also noting the negative examples set by relatives regarding substance use.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong thing to do in life?
R:By religion.
I:So what about religion tells you or helps you to know that?
R:A lot of times they tell you what is wrong and what is right in church so that is what I use.
I:Ok, and in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s easy.
I:You feel like it is not a hard thing?
R:No.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:You know, it has been pretty much the same.  Steady.
I:You feel like it hasn’t changed at all, or?
R:Maybe a bit easier.
I:Ok.  It’s gotten easier to decide?
R:Yeah.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Just church, I mean, like I said you know if in church it is wrong…
I:So is it rules or laws?
R:Oh, laws as well; yes, society laws.
I:Ok, so and religion
R:Yes.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:My mom and step dad.
I:Have your views about right and wrong changed over the past few years, or stayed the same?
R:They’ve stayed the same.
I:So you haven’t really had any big differences?
R:No.
column590: By religion. A lot of times they tell you what is wrong and what is right in church so that is what I use. It’s easy. No. You know, it has been pretty much the same.  Steady. Maybe a bit easier. Yeah. They’ve stayed the same. No.  Just church, I mean, like I said you know if in church it is wrong… Oh, laws as well; yes, society laws. Yes.  My mom and step dad.
column591: The respondent would share an inheritance with siblings due to their shared struggles, relies on religious teachings to discern right from wrong, believes moral views are shaped by parents, and thinks that while everyone has their own opinions on morality, he personally prioritizes religious guidance to avoid negative consequences.

column589:
I:In terms of morality, how do you normally decide like what’s good or bad or right and wrong?
R:You’re saying how do I –?
I:Yeah, like if you – say you’re in a certain situation and you kind of don’t know whether it’s the right thing to do or the wrong thing to do, how would you make a decision?  How would you decide if it’s good or bad?
R:I think I’d ask around.  I’d ask somebody I think that knows something about it or the  older or something right there.  So that would be a good thing for me to ask.
I:Ask like friends or older people?
R:Yeah, older people, friends, take everybody’s advice.
I:Would you say that, in general, it’s easy or hard to decide about right and wrong?
R:It be hard.
I:It’s hard.  Would you say that in like the last two or three years it got easier or harder to decide about right and wrong?
R:I think it got kind of easy to come now.  I’m older and wiser.
I:Just like through life experience?
R:Uh, huh.
I:What would you say it is that actually makes something right as opposed to wrong?
R:You be asking an awful lot of questions, man.  I don’t be knowing what you’re talking about there, so can you like break it down to me?
I:Yeah, so like a lot of people that we talk to say that, like, it’s the consequences that make something wrong, so if you’re going to break the law, you know it’s wrong.  Or some people say if it makes – you know if it’s gonna hurt somebody else, then it’s wrong.
R:Yeah, that how I be, you know what I’m saying?  If you hurt somebody, that would be wrong.
I:What about, like, other people might say that if it makes them happy, then it’s right.  Would you agree with that?
R:Yeah. From my momma.
I:Just growing up?
R:Just growing up.
column590: You’re saying how do I –? I think I’d ask around.  I’d ask somebody I think that knows something about it or the  older or something right there.  So that would be a good thing for me to ask. Yeah, older people, friends, take everybody’s advice. It be hard. I think it got kind of easy to come now.  I’m older and wiser. Uh, huh.  You be asking an awful lot of questions, man.  I don’t be knowing what you’re talking about there, so can you like break it down to me? Yeah, that how I be, you know what I’m saying?  If you hurt somebody, that would be wrong. Yeah.  From my momma. Just growing up.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on the guidance of older individuals and friends when making moral decisions, acknowledges the difficulty of distinguishing right from wrong, and ultimately believes that decisions should align with God's teachings, indicating a strong influence of religious values in their decision-making process.

column583:
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um,
I:What defines what’s good and bad?
R:(pause) Uh, well like, hm, (pause) that’s a tough question, um, hm.  Can we skip that one?
I:Sure.
R:Cause I just don’t know how to answer that one.
I:Well, let’s somebody, um, let’s talk specifically.  Let’s not talk abstractly.  If somebody, um, stole, if one of your friends went in and stole something, is that wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:What make, why?
R:Because you’re supposed to pay for it.  You’re not supposed to steal it, it’s not yours.
I:And if your friend says I don’t agree with that.  Are they wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:Is it wrong because they’ve broken the law or is it wrong because besides the law it’s wrong?
R:Uh, both I guess.  They know it’s wrong but they’re going to do it anyways.  Even if they don’t want to spend the extra money for something I guess.
I:Is it wrong because it hurts somebody or is that not really the issue?
R:Yeah, that’s not really the issue.
I:Is it wrong because it hurts the person that’s stealing or is that not the issue?
R:That’s not the issue.  I think it’s wrong well because you’re not supposed to be stealing stuff, you’re supposed to be paying for that stuff.
I:How do we know that, how do we know what we’re supposed to do and what we’re not supposed to do?
R:(pause)
I:I mean the law tells us, here’s what you can’t.
R:Yeah.
I:But is morality just whatever the law says?
R:(pause)
I:Again, you can skip, you can skip out of this if you want to, I don’t want to push you too hard.
R:Yeah, I’ll skip that one.  I know the answer I just don’t’ know how to say it right.
I:Well some people would say, well morality comes from God, I mean the Bible teaches right from wrong and that’s the basis for it. Would you agree with that?
R:Yeah.
I:Do you think that applies for people that don’t even believe in God?
R:What do you mean applies?  That they could follow it?
I:It’s right or wrong for them even if they don’t believe the basis of it.
R:Yeah, like if they were mad at somebody and never forgave, that was wrong.  So.
I:So you have a pretty good sense of right and wrong it seems.
R:Yeah.
I:Where do you think that came from in your own life?
R:My parents.  They taught me well.
I:Your parents taught you.
R:Yeah.
I:Besides them anything?
R:Uh, church I guess.  School.
I:They teach moral, right and wrong at school?
R:Uh, no.  I just, well I learned this stuff basically from my parents, but sometimes at school and some times at church.
column584: Um, (pause) Uh, well like, hm, (pause) that’s a tough question, um, hm.  Can we skip that one? Cause I just don’t know how to answer that one. Yeah. Because you’re supposed to pay for it.  You’re not supposed to steal it, it’s not yours. Yeah. Uh, both I guess.  They know it’s wrong but they’re going to do it anyways.  Even if they don’t want to spend the extra money for something I guess. Yeah, that’s not really the issue. That’s not the issue.  I think it’s wrong well because you’re not supposed to be stealing stuff, you’re supposed to be paying for that stuff. (pause) Yeah. (pause) Yeah, I’ll skip that one.  I know the answer I just don’t’ know how to say it right. Yeah. What do you mean applies?  That they could follow it? Yeah, like if they were mad at somebody and never forgave, that was wrong.  So. Yeah. My parents.  They taught me well. Yeah. Uh, church I guess.  School. Uh, no.  I just, well I learned this stuff basically from my parents, but sometimes at school and some times at church.
column585: The respondent often relies on their parents' guidance and biblical teachings to navigate moral dilemmas, expressing a clear sense of right and wrong while acknowledging societal confusion about morality, and they avoid risky behaviors like drug use due to health concerns and a desire not to disappoint their family.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong, in life?
R:From religion.  I would say that, I’m a sinner like everybody else, but you always try to you know, as I hate to say this just because it’s got so annoying, but WWJD? Saying.  Seriously you look at it sometimes and… or just or an analogy I like to use or just something to think about like, “What you do around your friends and what if God was one of them?  Would you say in front of Him?”  So I would say a large part definitely.
I:Did you wear a WWJD? Bracelet?
R:No, I never bought into that fad.
I:In general is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I’d say both.  Sometimes there’s just clear cut things where, I won’t name examples, but I just know, “No, I’m not going to do this.  This is just isn’t who I am,” but sometimes as far that stupid pool hopping thing or something, it’s hard because part of me doesn’t want to let my friends down, but also part of me doesn’t want to just do something outside of character or also, just to do it to like prove myself to my friends because I feel like I have nothing to prove.  If they don’t like me, they would have left me ten years ago because I’ve known them forever.
I:Can you give us some examples of some of the easy things too?
R:Like, not that I’ve been offered, but stuff like, “Wanna smoke a cigarette?” or something like that.  “Wanna do any kind of drugs?”  “No because they ruin your life,” and I’ve talked to, I know some people that have, well one guy that I work with actually I was friends with him in my elementary years, my 4, 5, and 6th grade years and he lived in my neighborhood.  He… I didn’t talk to him for a while, but I met him at work again and I was surprised to see him there because a couple months ago he was driving drunk and a guy ran into the middle of the street who was also drunk and he hit the guy and killed him so he’s awaiting jail time probably from what he’s told me and alcoholism as well as, he told me he got expelled from high school because he did it, not expelled, but suspended the last two weeks of his senior year, didn’t get to walk the graduation because he was busted for smoking pot so I know, I won’t say from like I’ve seen people doing drugs or stuff like that, but that’s just an easy thing for me.  It’s just stupid.  Why would you want to mess up your brain like that?  That’s another type of person you wanna stay away with:  drug addicts or alcoholics or people addicted to cigarettes, or something like that.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:Oh definitely harder, definitely.  Just because more opportunities arise to do things for me outside of my nature and I’ll just say, it’s definitely been harder.  And that’s expected I guess because you figure as you grow older more opportunities are presented to you and you need to make decisions as far my claim of I’m 18, I’m trying to be independent, well that’s true.
I:Have your views on what’s right and wrong changed in the past two years?
R:No.  They’ve always remained.  Maybe I would they’ve changed a little bit because, I don’t know how to say this, at times they’ve changed a little big like, “Well this seems kind of stupid so I’ll do this” and then I’ll rethink it and I’m like, “Wow, what was I thinking?”  Maybe it’s changed a little, but it always goes back to where it always was.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:A:  if it’s against the law.  There are set rules in place and we’re all old enough to know that we’re not allowed to do drugs.  We’re not allowed to drink if you’re under 21 or something like that.  So definitely the law comes first and then B, would say:  parents as far as if they would be alright with it because some of us and I’ve fallen guilty to this as well, simple example would be the pool hopping example that we want to kind of start making our own decisions and they’re idea of fun, our parents’ idea of fun, isn’t the same degree as our level of fun now in this day and age.  That’s A and  B I guess, the law and then the parents, as far as the parents, “Oh no, you can’t do that.”
I:So in addition to the Bible, from where to you acquire your moral views?
R:I would say my parents.  Through the Bible I guess, they’ve formed their own, not their own, but theories that they want to embed in me and want me to follow, and parents and certainly church, I feel like I’m repeating myself like crazy, but certainly church as well.  To a degree my school, not as large as a degree as my church definitely just because it’s not as set Christian culture as the church is because the school it’s largely Christian, but there’s definitely a mix of like, you can tell that some kids definitely aren’t where you are.

Seriously you look at it sometimes and… or just or an analogy I like to use or just something to think about like, “What you do around your friends and what if God was one of them? column591: The respondent would use a hypothetical inheritance of $100,000 to repay their parents for their support, save for college, and donate to their church, emphasizing the importance of family and religious values in their decision-making, while also reflecting on the influence of their upbringing and the moral guidance they derive from their faith.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Gut feeling, I would say just what seems fair.  And like just instinct.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:No.  I would say it’s easy.  It’s easy for me to.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the last couple of years?
R:The same.
I:It’s stayed the same.  Have your moral views changed in the last couple of years?
R:Not really.  Not completely, so.  I’m trying to think of any big things that it would, um, I’d say pretty much the same.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think it just depends on the situation, I can’t really, I don’t know how to answer that directly.  I would say it would have to depend on the situation.  Just between two people, which it usually is, or between different parties, I would say it’s just being fair to the other person.
I:Okay has it, I mean, do you sort of base your situation on what’s right or wrong on rules, laws, consequences of the action, how it feels?
R:All of that.  Like I think all of the laws, you know, laws aren’t really meant to be broken, laws are put in place for a reason.  Some laws can be bent, but like you know, I’m big on respecting the law.  And rules are put in place, also, they’re not really meant to be broken.  They’re put there for a reason and sometimes there’s even stupid rules but I think if you, even if you did start breaking stupid rules, it’s not a good precedent to set because then you can start breaking other rules and stuff and then redefining what’s a stupid rule.  And then outcomes, long term outcomes.  I think long term is the most important thing.
I:Where do you think you’ve acquired your moral views from?
R:I guess, I don’t know.  Just myself, what kind of a society, I’m a little bit more conservative than most people but, I don’t know.
column590: Gut feeling, I would say just what seems fair.  And like just instinct. No.  I would say it’s easy.  It’s easy for me to. The same. Not really.  Not completely, so.  I’m trying to think of any big things that it would, um, I’d say pretty much the same.  I think it just depends on the situation, I can’t really, I don’t know how to answer that directly.  I would say it would have to depend on the situation.  Just between two people, which it usually is, or between different parties, I would say it’s just being fair to the other person. All of that.  Like I think all of the laws, you know, laws aren’t really meant to be broken, laws are put in place for a reason.  Some laws can be bent, but like you know, I’m big on respecting the law.  And rules are put in place, also, they’re not really meant to be broken.  They’re put there for a reason and sometimes there’s even stupid rules but I think if you, even if you did start breaking stupid rules, it’s not a good precedent to set because then you can start breaking other rules and stuff and then redefining what’s a stupid rule.  And then outcomes, long term outcomes.  I think long term is the most important thing.  I guess, I don’t know.  Just myself, what kind of a society, I’m a little bit more conservative than most people but, I don’t know.
column591: The respondent feels a moral obligation to donate a portion of an unexpected inheritance to charity while prioritizing personal financial growth, believes in making decisions based on gut feelings and fairness, and emphasizes the importance of long-term consequences and a clear conscience over immediate benefits, while also expressing skepticism towards certain religious beliefs and the moral implications of societal norms.

column589:
I:How do you generally know what is good and bad, or right or wrong in life?  Like moral good and bad?
R:I don’t know how to answer that, really.  I think I have a pretty good sense of what’s right or wrong.
I:Do you think that there are some things that are right and some things that are wrong?
R:Well yeah.
I:I won’t assume anything.  How do you know that?  How do you know which is which?
R:I don’t know.  Probably it’s just something inside of me.
I:Were you taught?  Did your mom raise you morally, teach you this is wrong, this is right, and here’s why, or you just picked it up along the way.
R:I think I just picked it up along the way more than anything.
I:In general, how easy or hard for you to decide right or wrong in your life?
R:Pretty easy.
I:So, what are examples of things that are wrong in your view?
R:It’s wrong to rob people or damage property or just be mean to people in general.
I:What is it that makes things right or wrong?  You think that certain things are right and wrong.  You know what they are.  What makes something wrong or right?
R:I guess it’s all in my head.  Whatever I happen to justify, it makes it right or wrong, I suppose.
I:If it’s wrong, earlier you said it would be wrong to just hurt people.  Why?
R:Why would it be right to hurt people?
I:Some people enjoy it.
R:I’m not just one of those people.
I:Some people benefit by the expense of others.  Stealing, or…
R:I’m not one of those people.  I’m too sensitive and nice of a person.
I:So you said that it’s just in your head, but what if somebody else you meet says, well, I have different things in my head.  Would you say they’re equally right?  Is morality objectively true, regardless of what we think, or is it just whatever we think?
R:No, I would probably think in my head that they were wrong, but I wouldn’t voice my opinion because I’m not anyone to be able to judge anyone.  I don’t really have an say…
I:Why shouldn’t anybody judge anybody?
R:I don’t know, because I just don’t think that’s right.  I don’t think it’s anyone’s place to judge anyone else.
I:Somebody’s acting like a, if somebody’s hurting somebody.
R:Well, then yeah, maybe.
I:You say, hey, that’s wrong.  Stop it.
R:Well yeah.  I would too, well if they were bigger than me.
I:But that’s judging them.
R:That’s true, but it’s still, I’m a hypocrite.  It’s still not right.
column590: I don’t know how to answer that, really.  I think I have a pretty good sense of what’s right or wrong. Well yeah. I don’t know.  Probably it’s just something inside of me. I think I just picked it up along the way more than anything. Pretty easy. It’s wrong to rob people or damage property or just be mean to people in general.  There is, I believe, there is a God.  Maybe God.  I don’t really know. I don’t really know.  I can’t really answer any of that because I don’t know. I do believe in karma, yeah. Yeah. I guess it’s all in my head.  Whatever I happen to justify, it makes it right or wrong, I suppose. Why would it be right to hurt people? I’m not just one of those people. I’m not one of those people.  I’m too sensitive and nice of a person. No, I would probably think in my head that they were wrong, but I wouldn’t voice my opinion because I’m not anyone to be able to judge anyone.  I don’t really have an say… I don’t know, because I just don’t think that’s right.  I don’t think it’s anyone’s place to judge anyone else. Well, then yeah, maybe. Well yeah.  I would too, well if they were bigger than me. That’s true, but it’s still, I’m a hypocrite.  It’s still not right.  I think I just picked it up along the way more than anything. I’m not sure where that really came from.  I think probably from my mom. Yeah, I believe so. Yeah.  I believe it though because I can remember times when I’ve done the wrong thing and lot’s of bad things have happened to me.
column591: The respondent plans to save most of an inheritance for long-term financial security, believes in karma as a guiding principle for moral decisions, and acknowledges that their sense of right and wrong has been shaped by personal experiences and social influences, particularly from their mother.

column583:
I:Okay, and where do your own views of right and wrong come from, do you think?
R:Um, my mom.
I:Like what she taught you?
R:Yeah.
I:What has she taught you about right and wrong do you think?
R:Um…that like um…(pause)…I’m trying to think (giggles)
I:Take your time.
R:Like um, no matter what if you think it’s wrong don’t do it, stuff like that.
I:Okay, and how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life do you think? Like how do you decide?
R:Most of it is like because my mom has told me about it and the others I just take a chance.
I:And how do you decide if it’s not something that you all have talked about?
R:I just go with my instinct.
I:Okay, and what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t know.
I:Do you have any examples of stuff that you think are like right or wrong or?
R:(giggles) Um…I don’t know.
column584: Um, my mom. Yeah. Um…that like um…(pause)…I’m trying to think (giggles) Like um, no matter what if you think it’s wrong don’t do it, stuff like that. Most of it is like because my mom has told me about it and the others I just take a chance. I just go with my instinct. I don’t know. (giggles) Um…I don’t know.
column585: The respondent believes that their sense of right and wrong primarily comes from their mother's teachings, trusts their instincts in uncertain situations, and feels that while they agree that morality can be relative, they recognize the importance of honesty and the consequences of actions such as cheating and lying.

column583:
I:Right.  And where do you think, like if you had your, if you had to use a, to an extent that, you know there is this sense of right or wrong that you have, like where does that come from?
R:You’re getting your gut instinct.
I:Mm-mm, yeah so it comes, yeah so you have an idea that in the situation. Okay um, is there anything in particular that makes something right or wrong or?
R:Um,  like an example?
I:Um, well let’s see, I suppose you could, some people might say um, well it depends on how it affects other people or it depends on you know, whether it’s consistent with my religious beliefs or you know, people would say things like that, or like you’re saying, you mentioned um, you know if you have a sense of what’s right or wrong, like in a particular situation, like would that be um, what would make something right or wrong?
R:Mm-mm (yes).
I:Okay.  Yep.  So primarily they’re—okay.  And um, all right.  Any, any examples of how you decided um, how you knew or how you decided what was right and wrong in life?  Um, you know you said you relied on your gut and any examples of that where you had a particular hard choice or whatever?
R:Um,  like none that I’ve, ever happened to me, but I mean, I can tell you some.
I:Mm-mm.  Like what, what would be—
R:You can—like if somebody, one time somebody approached my friend and asked me, asked him if they wanted some ecstasy and they turned it down cause they had, their sister had ended up in the hospital.
I:Right, so it was clear what the consequences were--
R:Mm-mm (yes).
column584: You’re getting your gut instinct. Um,  like an example? Mm-mm (yes). Um,  like none that I’ve, ever happened to me, but I mean, I can tell you some. You can—like if somebody, one time somebody approached my friend and asked me, asked him if they wanted some ecstasy and they turned it down cause they had, their sister had ended up in the hospital. Mm-mm (yes).
column585: The respondent often relies on gut instinct to make decisions, sometimes acting against their better judgment to rebel against parental expectations, while acknowledging that some wrong choices can lead to positive outcomes and expressing a belief that morality is relative.
column589:
I:How would you say you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:You just gotta think about past choices and future choices and where you’re headed, and then just think about the decision that you’re about to make.
I:So would you say that it’s generally easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy.
I:And has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past couple of years?
R:Easier.
I:Why would you say it’s gotten easier?
R:Just ‘cause I’ve matured more.
I:Have your moral views changed in the past couple of years?
R:Not really.
I:What do you think it is that makes something wrong or right?
R:Just you gotta think about what’s gonna happen after you’ve done… if it’s a bad decision, if you know that it’s gonna end up in a bad consequence, then you should just know that it’s gonna be wrong.
I:So basically consequences, what happens afterwards?
R:Right.
I:Now what kind of consequences for you would make something wrong?
R:If it’s gonna hurt yourself or someone else.
I:Then it’s wrong?
R:Mmhmm.
I:Where do you think you’ve acquired your moral views from?
R:From elders and people around me, like parents, and just their lessons being taught.
I:What lessons being taught?  You talking about what your parents teach?
R:Mmhmm.
column590: You just gotta think about past choices and future choices and where you’re headed, and then just think about the decision that you’re about to make. It’s pretty easy. Easier. Just ‘cause I’ve matured more. Not really.  Just you gotta think about what’s gonna happen after you’ve done… if it’s a bad decision, if you know that it’s gonna end up in a bad consequence, then you should just know that it’s gonna be wrong. Right. If it’s gonna hurt yourself or someone else. Mmhmm.  From elders and people around me, like parents, and just their lessons being taught. Mmhmm.
column591: The respondent prioritizes paying off debt and moving out if they inherited money, believes moral decisions are based on past experiences and consequences, acknowledges the influence of parents on their moral views, and ultimately chooses to do what makes them happy when unsure of the right course of action.

column583:
I:Where do your views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, I guess just what I was taught as a child, and also, I guess that before I think a lot, it’s just instinct.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, it’s affect on society, um, if it’s going to hurt the uh, greater overall well-being of society, then it’s wrong, and if it’s,
I:Can you give me some examples of that?
R:Uh, I guess any basic crime, robbery, um, murder, anything, um, if it hurts a person in the long run, it’s going to hurt society as a whole.
I:What about things that aren’t necessarily breaking laws, like cheating on your spouse, or something like that?
R:Um,
I:What makes that wrong?
R:I don't know, just um,
I:Or isn’t it?
R:It’s wrong, um, I would just, it goes against the accepted norms of society, and I think if you can’t follow a set path, that it’s wrong, even though that sounds bad, cause I’m one for thinking outside the box, but there’s also times when you need to conform to society.
I:Why are you one for thinking outside the box?
R:I think that you just get better results and that humanity wouldn’t exactly be where it is if everybody followed the uh same path.
I:How did you decide to think outside the box?
R:It’s just, I don't know, I think that’s just part of my personality, I couldn’t say that it was just something I decided to do.
column584: Um, I guess just what I was taught as a child, and also, I guess that before I think a lot, it’s just instinct. Um, it’s affect on society, um, if it’s going to hurt the uh, greater overall well-being of society, then it’s wrong, and if it’s, Uh, I guess any basic crime, robbery, um, murder, anything, um, if it hurts a person in the long run, it’s going to hurt society as a whole. Um, I don't know, just um, It’s wrong, um, I would just, it goes against the accepted norms of society, and I think if you can’t follow a set path, that it’s wrong, even though that sounds bad, cause I’m one for thinking outside the box, but there’s also times when you need to conform to society. I think that you just get better results and that humanity wouldn’t exactly be where it is if everybody followed the uh same path. It’s just, I don't know, I think that’s just part of my personality, I couldn’t say that it was just something I decided to do.
column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are instinctively known and shaped by childhood teachings, emphasizing that actions are judged based on their societal impact, while also expressing a preference for thinking outside the box despite recognizing the importance of conforming to societal norms.
column586:
I:how do you decide or no what’s good or bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I guess a lot of it is, I don’t know. Just, I guess, simply society’s rules decides what’s right and wrong, and I’ve always, you know, what is generally approved of, what would my parents think is okay, what would, what’s not, I don’t know. I mean, somehow I think most things are pretty well defined what’s good and not, so.
I:what defines something as good or not?
R:uh, society. I don’t know. Just…I don’t know, just basic ethics. I don’t know what makes something right or wrong.
I:in general is it hard or easy for you to decide what’s right or wrong?
R:not really—
I:--not really which?
R:it’s not really hard. I mean, like I said, I think things are pretty well defined so…I don’t know.
I:what about the consequences? Do the consequences of something make it right or wrong?
R:I guess so, I mean I guess that’s one of the primary deciding factors I guess.
I:is it the law?
R:law, yeah, has a lot to do with it, society’s rules, I don’t know—
I:--are there things that are legally wrong, no, legally okay, but are still wrong?
R:um, legally okay but still wrong? I’m sure there are some but not that I could personally name right now and say, I don’t know, I don’t think so.
I:one example would be, let’s say your dad cheated on your mother. There’s no law he’s breaking, is it wrong?
R:yeah. Um, uh…yeah. I mean, I guess cons—
I:--is it only wrong because your mother would be upset?
R:I guess. I mean I guess it’s wrong because it’s going to hurt not just my mom but the entire family.
I:what if nobody was upset? Oh dad, you know, would it be alright then?
R:I guess it’s alright if nobody’s hurt, but I don’t know, I don’t see it ever being that way. I guess it’s okay if no one’s hurt.
I:here’s another example. What if your mother, not to belabor this point, but I’m trying to figure this out. What if your mother and father said, jointly, let’s both cheat on each other, mutually agreed. Is that fine? Some people do that actually.
R:I don’t, I mean I think it’s still going to, I think it’s not good for the kids—
I:--what if the kids don’t know?
R:uh, I don’t know, even if they didn’t know I think it’s still going to have effects on the relationship with everybody at home. It’s going to be more or less evident, it’s gonna have, like you said, consequences that wouldn’t have happened. I don’t know if it’s, I don’t know, I mean I still think, I guess it’s wrong.
I:what about your neighbors? The ones that don’t have kids? Is it okay for them?
R:I guess. I mean, part of me wants to say no, that there’s a moral code that we’re supposed to follow, but if nobody’s hurt in the process and it’s a mutual decision and there’s no real consequences, then I guess it’s not necessarily wrong.
I:is there a moral code?
R:I don’t know. If there is, I wouldn’t know what to say it is. I wouldn’t say it’s the bible or anything like that. It’s just, I think there’s an innate part of humans that know what’s good or wrong or evil.
I:where did you come to think like that?
R:I don’t know, right now, putting the two together. I don’t know, it just…I think you have to,  you have a certain responsibility to other people to not only take care of yourself but do what you can for them and for society as a whole, so I think not, I think it goes beyond just what you want for yourself. Which I think—
I:--where does this responsibility come from?
R:I don’t know what decides it. Or where it comes from, I think it’s just, I think that’s the more or less the idea of society, that everybody agrees to these rules and wants to support each other so they have to all follow them. And I think that as a group they have this responsibility.

Just, I guess, simply society’s rules decides what’s right and wrong, and I’ve always, you know, what is generally approved of, what would my parents think is okay, what would, what’s not, I don’t know. I don’t, I mean I think it’s still going to, I think it’s not good for the kids— uh, I don’t know, even if they didn’t know I think it’s still going to have effects on the relationship with everybody at home. It’s going to be more or less evident, it’s gonna have, like you said, consequences that wouldn’t have happened. I don’t know if it’s, I don’t know, I mean I still think, I guess it’s wrong. I guess. I mean, part of me wants to say no, that there’s a moral code that we’re supposed to follow, but if nobody’s hurt in the process and it’s a mutual decision and there’s no real consequences, then I guess it’s not necessarily wrong. I don’t know. If there is, I wouldn’t know what to say it is. I wouldn’t say it’s the bible or anything like that. It’s just, I think there’s an innate part of humans that know what’s good or wrong or evil.  I don’t know, right now, putting the two together. I don’t know, it just…I think you have to,  you have a certain responsibility to other people to not only take care of yourself but do what you can for them and for society as a whole, so I think not, I think it goes beyond just what you want for yourself. Which I think— I don’t know what decides it. Or where it comes from, I think it’s just, I think that’s the more or less the idea of society, that everybody agrees to these rules and wants to support each other so they have to all follow them. And I think that as a group they have this responsibility.
column588: The respondent would use an inheritance to pay off student loans and save responsibly, guided by societal norms and parental approval to determine right from wrong, while acknowledging the complexity of morality and the importance of helping others, ultimately believing that happiness and positive contributions to society are key to a good life.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I think it’s pretty much a … maybe there’s kind of a inherent ability, to know what’s good or bad. I don’t know if you just base on past experiences or … but it’s rare that you would think you know, am I doing the right thing? Am I doing the wrong thing? Or if there’s confusion let’s say, you know. If I’m doing something good, I usually know that this is the right thing to do, or if I do something wrong, whatever that may be, this probably isn’t … I’m not … it’s rare that I go back and say, “Well, you know what? I though I was doing the right thing at the time” or you know, or I don’t know. That’s not right. Because I mean, there are situations where I thought I was doing the right thing at that time but I thought I was doing a good thing, it turns out to be you know … I think given your situation, I think people, the circumstances you know, what you know at the time, I think you know whether it’s a good or bad thing, or it turned out to be true after you discover more things or after consequences happen. That can be different.
I:So you would say it’s pretty easy to decide between right and wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the last couple of years?
R:I don’t know. I can’t say that it’s gotten harder. I can’t really say it’s gotten easier either but they stay the same. If I had to choose between right, or easier or harder I would lean towards easier but I can’t really say why.
I:Have your moral views changed in the past two years, in the past couple of years?
R:Probably.
I:How so?
R:Again, I think I really kind of rediscovered or found, you know, Christianity I guess, in the past two or three years, that’s definitely had a significant impact on. I don’t think it’s made me realize more things are right or wrong. I think it’s just made me aware of, you know, of more. I don’t know. It’s hard to give an example, but you know. I have a moral obligation to help people in need that I may not have recognized before that. But I don’t know. I think I have… my morals may have increased.
I:Now, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Okay, what makes something right or wrong? Again, I think you kind of just, I think … Okay, if something’s right, there’s a … I think for something to be right it can’t hurt someone else. I’m not saying as to help everybody in the situation but if it hurts somebody, maybe it’s not the right thing to do.
I:So are you talking about then the consequences of an action or something else?
R:I guess it’s the consequences. Not necessarily just for the people involved but on a greater scale, the consequences for or the general consequences for everybody. If I help this person, not only how will I help them but what will happen to the people around the person. I think all of that has to be considered.
I:And what kinds of consequences would make something wrong?
R:Again, I mean anything, and I use the term “loosely” that hurts, whether that would be physical or mental or emotional, that strips somebody in such a way that, or negatively impacts somebody. I think it’s kind of a broader commission, I think it’s important but it’s broad that if anything that hurts somebody, it’s wrong. I don’t know what makes right or wrong.
I:Where have you acquired your moral views from?
R:I don’t know, I think it’s just … I think you kind of, I mean I’m sure they are learned. I’m sure my parents are responsible for a majority of them, I’m sure my faith is responsible for some of them, I can’t … I mean I don’t know, I can’t say if this is where they come from but I think it’s a combination of teaching and experiences that define that.

I don’t know if you just base on past experiences or … but it’s rare that you would think you know, am I doing the right thing? Am I doing the wrong thing? Or if there’s confusion let’s say, you know. column591: The respondent emphasizes the importance of making responsible choices, guided by a combination of personal happiness and moral obligations influenced by their Christian faith and parental teachings, while acknowledging the complexity of moral decisions and the consequences of actions on others.

column583:
I:What kind of stuff do you think is wrong, like what makes something wrong?
R:Um, like I, like I said, there’s no way to make stealing, cheating or lying right, I mean, doing drugs of any kind, I don’t see as right at all, um, drinking excessively, you know, I don’t agree with a lot of today’s popular sexual habits and stuff, being able and, doing whatever you want and whoever you want and stuff, I don’t agree with a lot of things like that.
I:Okay, um, and how do you decide usually like what, what makes something right or wrong?
R:I go with what I’ve been taught, growing up and whatnot, or my gut feeling or what, basically what I’m comfortable with, if not, if I’m not comfortable doing it then it’s probably wrong.
column584: Um, like I, like I said, there’s no way to make stealing, cheating or lying right, I mean, doing drugs of any kind, I don’t see as right at all, um, drinking excessively, you know, I don’t agree with a lot of today’s popular sexual habits and stuff, being able and, doing whatever you want and whoever you want and stuff, I don’t agree with a lot of things like that. I go with what I’ve been taught, growing up and whatnot, or my gut feeling or what, basically what I’m comfortable with, if not, if I’m not comfortable doing it then it’s probably wrong.
column585: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on gut feelings and guidance from trusted figures like their mother and grandmother, emphasizing a strong moral upbringing that instills a clear distinction between right and wrong, particularly regarding issues like drug use and dishonesty, while feeling guilty about not being able to change the behaviors of friends involved in drugs.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I go by what I was taught, my grandparents taught me the most I think, cause when, in your teenage years that’s when you’re really exposed to the world, you’re not babied any more, you don’t see the world as playgrounds and classrooms, you get to really see the world.  And they just taught me to stand up for myself and stick to my guns and just don’t let anybody get me down kind of thing.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s not very hard for me at all.  I’ve just always gone by what I’ve been taught through school and through my grandparents, and so far it’s gotten me alright, so I just keep sticking with what I’ve been taught.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Um, it depends on the subject.  When it comes to actually dealing with people it’s hard to determine what’s the right or wrong thing to say, cause you never really know what might offend somebody.  But when it comes to like stealing, drugs, typical crimes, it’s very easy for me to decide what’s right and what’s wrong.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, I think for somebody, beliefs, it’s the way you were raised.  If your parents raised you to have respect for authority, whether it be the police or family, I had a general respect for authority.  I saw the police as my hero’s I didn’t see them as somebody who’s just going to stick me in handcuffs.  Whereas more kids today they just see them as someone they need to run from.  I was always taught that you go to the police if you need help.  And I just think that what’s right and wrong just comes strongly from how you were raised and what your parents teach you.
I:What about actions, what makes an action right or wrong?  Not necessarily for a particular person?
R:Really if it hurts somebody.  I mean, whether you say something wrong and hurt someone’s feelings, or if you physically throw something and it physically hurts somebody or you drive incorrectly and you crash into someone and it hurts them, it always leads to someone getting hurt.
I:So do you think there are things that are wrong that don’t hurt people?
R:Um, I don’t, I don’t, I think there are probably things that you think don’t hurt people and whatnot.  But if you steal, you’re costing that company money, which makes them drop wages, which makes somebody not able to pay their bills. So yeah, there’s some things that don’t appear to hurt people, but physically maybe not, but there’s always some way that’s going to damage somebody’s life.
I:Do you think there are things that might hurt people that are right?
R:Not in particularly.  Unless that person being punished might help somebody.  Like yeah, putting someone in prison hurts that person that’s being put into prison but they did something to be put there.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Um, I believe there are many actions that are always wrong.  Like any kind of abuse.  Drugs, abusing somebody, any kind of abuse no matter what is always wrong.
I:Okay, why do you think that’s wrong?
R:Because if you abuse a drug, you’re only going to hurt yourself, if you abuse verbally or sexually, or uh, physically abuse somebody, you’re going to hurt that person.  So I mean, I don’t know really what else to say.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Um, things I was taught when I was younger.  Maybe some of the things I observed on TV.  My parents were always a big fan of watching America’s Most Wanted, Cops, the more reality shows, not the real fake cartoons where they get away with whatever.  So I was always raised that those things were wrong.  And if I did something that I thought was right and it was wrong, I was always told no, that’s wrong.  So.
I:So you mentioned that most of your ideas of right and wrong were taught to you.  Where do you think those views came from for those people that taught them to you?
R:The ones I, that I learned from my parents, they were probably values that they learned from their parents, and on down the line as generations went along.  A lot of it was taught to me through school, from you know, when they get the kids together in an auditorium and they teach them that kids are bad or drinking’s bad, and that’s probably something, it’s just, they see that a crime is being committed more and more, you know, through the town, so they think they need to let the kids know what they’re doing and why it’s wrong.
I:Why do you trust the history in your family and the people in school to tell you what’s right and wrong?
R:Uh, I was just always taught to respect what my parents said, what my teachers said, what the police officer says, I think it’s a respect issue.  If they’re going to tell you that, I think you should listen to it.

column588: The respondent emphasizes the importance of education and financial stability for themselves and their partner, attributes their moral compass to teachings from their grandparents and parents, and believes that actions are right or wrong based on the potential harm they cause to others, while also reflecting on the influence of peer pressure and the need for parental guidance in shaping values.
column589:
I:That makes sense.  How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I basically go back to what I was taught as a kid.  I mean, I think a lot about what my parents - what would my parents think a lot.  And sometimes, I do that too much, and a lot of times, I’ll be like, “Well, what would Toby* think if I did this,” too because I mean, he’s the person I live with and I share my life with.  If he’s not gonna be happy with it because it’s something - a wrong - possibly a wrong decision, then that’s the consequence I’ll have to deal with everyday.
I:Right.  Yeah.  In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Normally, it’s pretty easy.  I feel I have a pretty good judgment, and I don’t normally - really don’t have to put myself in that situation very often to actually contemplate what’s right or wrong.  I normally know, “Ok.  Not going there,” if I’m gonna do something.
I:Yeah.  Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:Probably a lot easier because as you grow up, you get more experiences and you learn a lot more about how people react to the things that you do.
I:Um hm.  Would you say your views about what is right and wrong have changed in the past two years?
R:Not, like, ethically - like, as far as the easier stuff to talk about like drinking and alcohol - stuff like doing drugs - stuff like that.  I - they haven’t changed.  I’ve always felt the same way about those.  But I’ve had - I’ve changed jobs a few times, you know whether or not to give a notice, how to treat those in management positions, how to and how not to treat people underneath you, how close to get to them as friends and still keep that professional environment - stuff like that, I’ve had to deal with, but it’s - I definitely learned a lot.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:That’s a hard question to actually put into words.
I:Yeah, I know.
R:Just basically the way it affects people and the people around you.  You have to think about that and the way it’s gonna affect yourself.
I:So it’s, like, certain types of consequences make something wrong?
R:Yeah.  Like, if you do drugs, not just are you looking at, like, jail - possible jail time and things like that, but you’re actually gonna be doing nothing by hurting your body.  Like, you’re gonna have to deal with it later.  So it’s like, “Ok.  Well, there’s a reason you’re not supposed to do that because not only are you gonna go to jail, but you’re gonna cause brain damage, or you’re gonna cause damage to your mouth or whatever,” depending on what drugs you’re talking about and stuff like that.  And then the same thing with alcohol.  Not only can you lose control of yourself and your thinking and have dramatic consequences that night, but if you keep doing it, you could eventually end up losing a liver at 40 years old or something like that.  So you definitely set your limits and know when it’s time to stop and know when it’s time to not do something at all by what you’re gonna be facing in the future.
I:Right.  Ok.  Do you think it’s wrong when people do things that just hurt themselves?  Or does it have to have, like, adverse consequences on those around them?
R:I think no matter what, if you hurt yourself, it’s still gonna have consequences with people around you.  I think people that think they can do things to themselves, “Oh, it only hurts me.”  But they’re very selfish, and they don’t realize that hurting yourself does hurt people around you, as well.
I:Ok.  Yeah.  That makes sense.  From where would you say you’ve acquired your moral views?
R:A lot of them have been from my parents and my grandparents.  And also just from the basic influence of people I’ve kept around me, watching - I had cousins and things like that that did a lot more, got into - they could have gotten into a lot more trouble if their parents knew more about what was going on, and I watched what they did and how they would stress out over whether or not their parents knew and stuff like that.  So I kinda - I watched - I paid a lot of attention to the people around me, and also took - I also took heed a lot to what people were telling me.

So I kinda - I watched - I paid a lot of attention to the people around me, and also took - I also took heed a lot to what people were telling me.
column591: The respondent plans to use an inheritance of $100,000 to pay off debts, pursue education, and potentially donate to animal shelters, while their decision-making is heavily influenced by their upbringing, the opinions of their partner, and a belief in the consequences of their actions, emphasizing the importance of considering how choices affect both themselves and others.

column583:
I:Where do your, where do your views of right and wrong come from?
R:My parents, um, my church, a little from school and society in general. Things like drug and alco—drugs and alcohol are really being looked down on in society a lot more now, I think, or at least in schools they’re like, that’s bad, you know.  So.
I:Mm-mm.  Yeah.  And um, is there something, what, what can you think, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  What, what kind of determines whether it’s right or wrong?  Is there some fundamental?
R:
I:Ah, yeah, something fundamental that, a fundamental principle that sort of helps us know, you know what is right or wrong.  What, what is the foundation for right and wrong. Whether it helps.  You know if it, if it’s right then it’ll have something good that it does.  If it’s wrong, it’ll have a negative.  It’s really that simple. So how do you decide or how do you know what is good and bad, right or wrong in life?  I mean, when you’re faced with these decisions, what do you do, how do you know, how do you think about it?
R:I use my best judgment, ___________________ .  So.
I:Any examples of that, where you had a difficult situation, um, figuring out what’s right and wrong to do?  And how did you, how did you get it sorted out?
R:I don’t know.  There’s things like um, I don’t, I broke up with my girlfriend like a week ago, just cause ah, it was getting a little too close you know.  She wanted more, and I was just like, yeah, I’m not gonna have sex with you.  And I broke up with her and she didn’t understand at all, but you know, I knew that was for me the right thing to do.  That was my, the right decision for me, it’s just,  I’m not gonna get involved in that, and ah.
I:So she, she was ready to get very close, very emotionally connected, um, and for her it made sense that if you’re emotionally connected you’re ah, also involved in sex and that kind of thing.
R:Yeah.
I:And you felt that that wasn’t, you felt that that wasn’t right.
R:Yeah.
I:And kind of, what, what was the basis for knowing that, was that something that you got, that you knew was something that, because of your religion, or because of your family or because of the consequences or what you hope to do or be sometime?
R:Um, religion, is part of it.  And then just the consequences that I know can follow.  I have a good imagination for what could go wrong in that sort of situation, and so, it’s a little of each, I think.  It’s mainly just religion, like that’s something I said I would never do before marriage.  So then all __________ .
I:And something that’s taught at your church?
R:Yeah.
I:Does your church talk about that quite a bit, like pressures facing teenagers and what to do about it?
R:They do.
I:What’s right and wrong?
R:They do, um, a good amount and.

Things like drug and alco—drugs and alcohol are really being looked down on in society a lot more now, I think, or at least in schools they’re like, that’s bad, you know.  So.
