I have a good imagination for what could go wrong in that sort of situation, and so, it’s a little of each, I think.  It’s mainly just religion, like that’s something I said I would never do before marriage.  So then all __________ . Yeah. They do. They do, um, a good amount and.
column585: The respondent believes that people generally know right from wrong but often choose not to follow it, attributing their moral compass to influences from parents, church, and societal norms, while also emphasizing the importance of consequences and personal judgment in decision-making.
column589:
I:In terms of morality, how do you decide what’s good or bad, right and wrong and the like?
R:Well, I mean, my religion plays a huge part in that. And so, like specific things, a lot of things are just pretty clearly black and white. That, especially within my church, like “this is a yes or no, this not a grey area”. And then for things that are kind of, that fall into the grey area, the one thing that I usually do if I’m, if it’s something important. Like if it’s not terribly critical and I don’t think it’ll have a big effect I’ll just choose one way or the other. If it’s something I think will have an effect for a while, I’ll usually try and find time to pray about it and ask God.
I:So generally you feel like it’s sort of easy or hard to decide what’s right and wrong?
R:Generally, I think it’s pretty simple. Like if it’s something that I personally can’t seem to decide, usually praying about it, I’ll be able to get a pretty clear answer one way or the other.
I:In the last two or three years, do you think it’s gotten easier or harder to decide?
R:I think it’s gotten easier. And part of that is I’m used to asking now, and used to receiving answers, and it makes it a bit easier. But also I think I know better who I am, so that helps me to be more clear-cut about what I do and do not do and why, like personal decisions.
I:So you mentioned praying about it and the, like do you feel like you always get an answer about that?
R:Not always. And occasionally it’s not the answer I want. It happens. And sometimes I don’t get an answer right away, or it’ll take a day or two. Or I’ll just get an answer like “it doesn’t matter.” I’ve had that happen, where I just get a distinct feeling that it’s like, it’s really not that important. Just “do what you want” sort of thing. And so, like, you know it varies depending on my needs.
I:Can you talk about what that’s like? Feel a sense or, I’m not sure what the language you would use to get an answer.
R:Well it’s, it’s one of those things that seems to be pretty individual to the person. You know, some people say that they feel more than they hear a voice or anything like that. Personally, when I pray about a question, usually I, it’s kind of hard to express. It’s not like I hear a voice out loud, but kind of in my thoughts, I generally will feel or “hear” sort of, you know, an answer or response. And it’s kind of that same voice that a lot of people call their conscience, which is referred to in my religion as “the Holy Ghost”. And generally when I pray and ask about a question, sometimes it is something really powerful. But generally it will come as more of a feeling or, it’s a, the call it a “burning in the bosom”, kind of like a really warm feeling in your chest. But with other more delicate questions, often I more like hear a voice in my thoughts that tells me what to do or not.
I:In the last couple of years do you feel like knowing right or wrong has gotten easier or harder?
R:Didn’t you ask that?
I:What would you say it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Generally speaking, it, I would say that there’re a couple of things that factor into it. Number one is God’s opinion on the subject. You know, if He says something is wrong, then it’s wrong and there’s no denying or arguing with that. And that’s just based on the fact that, well He knows a lot more than we do, and so we just need to trust Him. And then the other part of that is, I think, a little easier for people to see, is the effect that it has on people, participated or affected by it. You know, does this thing make you feel good? Does it make you happy? Or does it just make a situation worse? So that’s, yeah.
I:So you mentioned religion as one source of your moral views. Any other sources for your ideas on morality?
R:I imagine my environment’s played a pretty big role in it. I mean that’s kind of hard to see, having, having lived there. But I would say that, yeah my parents, my family, my church, of course, and the people in it have all played a role as well as the people, like teachers in my school and friends I had, and stuff like that.

I mean that’s kind of hard to see, having, having lived there. But I would say that, yeah my parents, my family, my church, of course, and the people in it have all played a role as well as the people, like teachers in my school and friends I had, and stuff like that.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on their religious beliefs to determine right and wrong, often seeking guidance through prayer, while also considering the consequences of their actions and the influence of their family and community in shaping their moral views.

column583:
I:Okay, so where do your views of what’s right and wrong come from?
R:Um, probably my religious beliefs, yeah.
I:Um, what, so what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, well like, the 10 commandments type things, and then also like you know, what’s in the Bible, but then it’s also my parent’s rules, so those affect, like, sometimes my parent’s rules, you know it’s more for protection than like morality issues, but the, it still kind of applies under the same things.
I:Okay, so when you’re thinking about a certain situation, um, what, what, what do you use to determine that something is right and wrong?  You, you mentioned the bible and then your parents,--
R:Yeah.
I:--is there any other?
R:Um, not really.  I mean, I don’t like, I don’t like, I don’t check through everything but, but just kind of assess, yeah, like when comparing it against my beliefs, I guess.
I:So would you say that the Bible, then, would be, would you consider that the authority on what’s right, on moral dilemmas?
R:Yeah, yes.
I:Okay, um, how, can you give me some examples of things that you’ve had to decide whether something was right or wrong or good or bad?
R:I haven’t really, like most of my friends they’re really good kids, so I really haven’t had like.
column584: Um, probably my religious beliefs, yeah. Um, well like, the 10 commandments type things, and then also like you know, what’s in the Bible, but then it’s also my parent’s rules, so those affect, like, sometimes my parent’s rules, you know it’s more for protection than like morality issues, but the, it still kind of applies under the same things. Yeah. Um, not really.  I mean, I don’t like, I don’t like, I don’t check through everything but, but just kind of assess, yeah, like when comparing it against my beliefs, I guess. Yeah, yes. I haven’t really, like most of my friends they’re really good kids, so I really haven’t had like.
column585: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on their religious beliefs and parental guidance, assessing situations for potential danger, while also acknowledging social influences from friends and the moral implications of actions like cheating and lying, which they view as fundamentally wrong despite occasional pressures to conform.

R:Um, definitely religion.

column588: The respondent primarily bases their understanding of right and wrong on religious teachings from the Bible and their upbringing, believes that moral truths are absolute despite societal changes, and emphasizes the importance of helping others while recognizing the complexities of moral decisions in life.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um, well I go off, I mean I do go off the Bible and then I don’t know, like that’s a funny question because knowing, deciding, that doesn’t mean action of, just deciding?
I:No, that’s a separate question.
R:So, yeah, so I’d say the Bible then, with that.
I:And in general, do you think it’s easy for you, personally, to decide between right and wrong?
R:It really depends on what it is.  I'm pretty indecisive, if it’s clear-cut, then yes, but life has a lot of sticky situations, and those, no.
I:When you’re not sure in a situation like that, what do you usually do?
R:I typically call my friend, Jackie* .
I:Okay, that’s good.
R:Or talk to other people.
I:Just to get their perspective?
R:Yeah, to find out.  Because typically it’s the kind of thing like there might not be a clear right or wrong so I mean, what’s the best course of action?  So I like other’s opinions.
I:Do you feel like deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:It’s definitely gotten harder.
I:Any reason why?
R:Oh, just learning to tolerate more gray.  Like you, I think it’s kind of typical because you start as a kid and everything is right, it’s pretty black and white and so then you progress out of that and so at this point like I'm able to understand that there isn’t going to be a clear answer for a lot of things and so I see that in a lot of things and so it’s gotten harder because I'm more able to comprehend that things are more complicated.

column591: The respondent primarily relies on the Bible for moral guidance, acknowledges the complexity of moral decisions, often consults friends for perspectives, believes in a moral responsibility to help others, and wishes for a world where everyone understands God to improve lives.

column583:
I:Okay.  Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:I think my parents, mostly.  And uh, church, too, that’s—
I:How from church?
R:Well just by like what’s in the Bible and stuff, you know I don’t really believe the Bible word for word, cause that’s, that’s how my parents have raised me that the Bible is not word for word, it’s meant to be interpreted, so just like with, there’s some stuff—
I:What does that mean?  Word for word?
R:Like, like where it says the earth was created in seven days, that’s, I mean like, scientists prove that’s not true, so.  Me and my Dad talk about that, actually, somewhat frequently about Bible and like what it means and like—
I:Do you?  Tell me about those conversations.
R:Well we just usually, ah, I don’t know, I usually bring it up.  And we just talk about it, he just, we just talk about like views from other religions and stuff, too.  And then we just talk about our view, too, we don’t like say, oh that religion’s wrong, we just say what we believe and we compare to other religions somewhat.  And like he talks about what he believes is how like it’s supposed to be interpreted and you find out, and like he reads and like doesn’t believe it word for word but he like, what the real meaning is supposed to be.  That’s what, that’s how he looks at it, and he’s kind of put that into me.
I:What do you think of that?
R:I think, I think he’s right.  I think there’s some stuff in the Bible that scientists prove is not true, but you’re just meant to interpret it.
I:Like what?
R:Like well as I said before, the earth created in seven days, Adam and Eve, I don’t believe in that.  And like that, it just appeared and just, there’s other things, I’m not—
I:How did it happen?
R:I’ve never read the Bible.  I don’t know, I’m—
I:What do you mean you’ve never read the Bible?
R:I’ve never like read the entire Bible, word for word, like I’ve listened to passages in church and stuff like that.  And like oh, how do I think that like the earth came, then?  I’m not exactly sure, I’m, I guess the one that makes most sense to me is the big bang theory, that’s my, that’s what I think, I guess, is right.  And then evolution, I don’t—
I:So what does your church say, do you know?
R:I’m not exactly sure what my church says about, I don’t, I know that they say the Bible is meant to be interpreted, not word for word, I know that’s what it is, but I’m not really sure what they believe about, we’ve talked about it in Sunday School before like and we shared our own views about how the earth was created.  And people just had different opinions about it, but I’ve never, I don’t really know what—
I:So are that, is everybody right or is, is there one correct?
R:I’m not, I’m not sure, though, I just think what I believe, but that could be wrong, so.  I’m not sure.
I:So you bring up these conversations most of the time?
R:Mm-mm (yes).
I:Why?  Do you think that you do?
R:Um, just on my mind, and me and my Dad are driving to a hockey game or something like that, I just talk to him about it.
I:What kind of questions would you ask?
R:Like I don’t really talk to my Mom about that stuff, I talk to my Dad about that.
I:Why?
R:I don’t know.  It’s just on my mind, I just wonder, I’ve always asked a ton of questions, my Dad said that’s just always how I was, I’d ask a million questions a day.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t really know how to describe that, I mean, like I’ve just thought things, some things are right and some things are wrong, I just, I don’t really know how to describe it.
I:That’s okay.  How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong?
R:I think about what my parents have told me, what’s right and wrong, like what I believe is right and wrong from like what I’ve learned and then I think about what the consequences will be if I do it or not.
I:Would you ever, would your parents ever disagree with what you believe was right or wrong?
R:They probably would.  I can’t really think of anything in particular, but they’ve probably had a couple things they disagree with me on.

column585: The respondent believes that their views on right and wrong primarily come from their parents and church teachings, acknowledging the influence of social norms and personal consequences, while also expressing a belief in absolute moral truths despite the changing nature of societal morals.
column589:
I:right. How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:uh, that’s a tough question. I would say intuition, but I think it’s a lot more than that. I think a lot of it has to do with the way I’m raised, the way I was raised by my parents  as much as I’d like to think I’m different from my parents, I wouldn’t even like to think that.  I know that I’m really similar to my parents and that it’s always, I think I go on a lot of what my parents raised me, what was right and wrong and treating other people with respect and all those sorts of things.  Basically being a kind person and I think my parents beat that into me pretty well and I think I would feel weird doing otherwise.  I think I draw a lot on my upbringing and I would say I still draw a lot on my experience with this religious group of friends and I would still consider myself more of a secular Christian and at least in terms of social justice, following Christian teachings, like putting others before yourself, I think that’s still something that’s pretty important to me even if I might not believe the religious part of it, I still believe in the secular part of doing good and leaving the world a better place than you found it.
I:ok.  has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder in the past couple years?
R:I wouldn’t say it’s gotten harder, I would say it’s something I spent time examining and just become a little more, become more difficult, there were some things that I did before I became a Christian for these two years which I then thought were wrong and now I think were right. So I still spend a lot of time, I’m still trying to figure out what my moral code is, but I would still say except for a little I basically follow the Christian teaching at least in terms of social justice, it hasn’t been harder it’s just been,  it’s been harder in the sense of figuring it out, but I wouldn’t say it’s been difficult, it’s just been complicated.
I:in general is it easy to decide between right and wrong?
R:no I think I generally have a pretty good sense of if something’s going to be slightly off.  I usually judge that by asking is this harming anyone else or harming myself in a way that I really know I shouldn’t be doing it.
I:what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I would say like I said before, if it harms another person or night, whether that be not only physically, but emotionally or spiritually.  Anything that causes another person distress or whatever or makes them seem uncomfortable.  Then it gets difficult and you get into situations where it hurts more than one person and who do you think is right, but I think generally it’s whether or not it’s if you’re gonna do this it’s gonna hurt somebody.  And of course you can get into philosophical arguments about whether you know you’re hurting other people and when it’s okay, but I think as a general guideline that usually what I rely on.
I:ok, from where have you acquired your moral views?
R:I would say a lot of my parents and just outside reading too like reading the Bible and once I touched a philosophy class the beginning of junior year in high school that time got me hooked on it and really interesting subjects, so just books I’ve read and my friends all make fun of me because I read textbooks for fun, so but it’s something I enjoy so I would say outside reading and my upbringing really.

I think a lot of it has to do with the way I’m raised, the way I was raised by my parents  as much as I’d like to think I’m different from my parents, I wouldn’t even like to think that.  I know that I’m really similar to my parents and that it’s always, I think I go on a lot of what my parents raised me, what was right and wrong and treating other people with respect and all those sorts of things. I wouldn’t say it’s gotten harder, I would say it’s something I spent time examining and just become a little more, become more difficult, there were some things that I did before I became a Christian for these two years which I then thought were wrong and now I think were right. I usually judge that by asking is this harming anyone else or harming myself in a way that I really know I shouldn’t be doing it. Anything that causes another person distress or whatever or makes them seem uncomfortable.  Then it gets difficult and you get into situations where it hurts more than one person and who do you think is right, but I think generally it’s whether or not it’s if you’re gonna do this it’s gonna hurt somebody.  And of course you can get into philosophical arguments about whether you know you’re hurting other people and when it’s okay, but I think as a general guideline that usually what I rely on.  I would say a lot of my parents and just outside reading too like reading the Bible and once I touched a philosophy class the beginning of junior year in high school that time got me hooked on it and really interesting subjects, so just books I’ve read and my friends all make fun of me because I read textbooks for fun, so but it’s something I enjoy so I would say outside reading and my upbringing really.
column591: The respondent would use an inheritance of $100,000 primarily for education and social justice initiatives, influenced by a sense of obligation to help others and support their sister's social work in Kenya, while also acknowledging their upbringing and religious teachings as key factors in their moral decision-making.

column583:
I:Uh-huh.  Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, reading the bible and listening to my parents and other people talk.
I:Uh-huh.  What is it at a fundamental level that makes something right or wrong?  Is it taking something away from somebody else or is it hurting somebody, or is there something else that’s going on do you think?
R:I think that if something hurts you or somebody else, it’s wrong.  You can’t hurt somebody.
I:And that’s because…
R:Um, there would not be a point to it not being wrong if, it didn’t hurt somebody.  That’s why you’re not allowed to do things.
I:Okay.  And can you give me a recent example in your life where you’ve had to make a decision about something that was right or wrong.  Either like you said before like where you have the chance to think about it beforehand or if you’re in the middle of it and you kind of have to do some sort of moral reasoning to decide what you will or won’t do.
R:Um,
I:Maybe an example of, of how you decided to go conservative, that, that would be good.
R:Okay.
I:(chuckles)
R:Just so you know I lead a very sheltered life. (giggles)
I:(chuckles)
R:I haven’t been able to do most of the stuff that the other kids in my school have been able to do.
I:Uh-huh.
R:Thinking.  Thinking.  (pause)
I:Even something little like at home or school or like that where you know that it would probably be wrong if you went one way or that you decided to go another way.  Or that you go ahead and,
R:Well like the girls, the girls in my class have some serious boy problems. We’re going home from a varsity football game.  They sit one person to every seat.  So that the boys have to sit next to a girl!  So I sat next to a girl.
I:Okay, so to keep away from kind of the boy problem issues?
R:Yeah.
column584: Um, Because that’s what our society is based on.  That we have these rights. It’s not in the Declaration of Independence, it’s, um, it got written down on paper for the first time and that was important but it’s um, you know, everybody has these rights and if you take somebody’s away you’re taking it away, you can’t do that. Yeah. It would be a mess.  We would look like Africa.  People would be running through the streets killing each other. Um, reading the bible and listening to my parents and other people talk. I think that if something hurts you or somebody else, it’s wrong.  You can’t hurt somebody. Um, there would not be a point to it not being wrong if, it didn’t hurt somebody.  That’s why you’re not allowed to do things. Um, Okay. Just so you know I lead a very sheltered life. (giggles) I haven’t been able to do most of the stuff that the other kids in my school have been able to do. Thinking.  Thinking.  (pause) Well like the girls, the girls in my class have some serious boy problems. We’re going home from a varsity football game.  They sit one person to every seat.  So that the boys have to sit next to a girl!  So I sat next to a girl. Yeah.
column585: The respondent makes decisions about right and wrong by consulting trusted individuals like their father and pastor, bases their moral views on biblical teachings and parental guidance, believes that actions causing harm to others are wrong, and reflects on the consequences of actions such as stealing music, while also expressing concern about friends engaging in risky behavior.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what’s good or bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Basically I’m very well set in what I believe the Christian world views based on theology are, and so I compare things to that and decide.  And if I can’t figure out something myself, I’ll ask about it.  But I kind of am of the opinion that if you’re asking about it, you're probably asking about it because you know the right answer and you just want to follow through with it.
I:.
R:You want permission to do something else.
I:Hoping somebody gives you permission.
R:Yeah.
I:So you would say it’s generally easy or hard for you know between right and wrong, decide between right and wrong?
R:It's generally easy for me.
I:Because of that grounding you say you have?
R:Yeah.
I:And as deciding,
R:And so I’m also – my personality type, I was most conscientious voted in my class when we graduated, and that’s out of 20 people.  And my best friend came up to me after we wrote everything down, and she’s like, “I can’t tell you what I put, but it’s perfect for you.”  So they were very correct.  I’m a very conscientious person, so.
I:So you're always thinking about doing the right thing, and that’s your intent most of the time?
R:Yeah.  It tends to drive people crazy though too.
I:Would you say that that’s gotten easier or harder for you over the past couple years?  This doing or thinking about right or wrong?
R:Easier.
I:Easier?  Why so?
R:I think I’m more comfortable asserting myself, and being like, “This is what I think, and I’m going to do something else just because the situation, or whatever.”  So I also think in some ways kind of an interesting question.  Like, how many times we actually confronted the choosing to do something right or wrong is like this major issue, as opposed to just like, the sign says, “No parking,” but I’m only going to be here for five minutes, or it’s only a little lie.  You just kind of – I’ve never had to probably in many years now, choose I’m going to do this because it’s right, and this is a huge major decision, so.
I:Now, tell me what it is that you think makes something right or wrong?  What is it about whatever the thing is that’s right or wrong?  Don’t give me big philosophical thing.
R:That’s asking for a big philosophical thing there.  I will, the discourses of power tell us that.
I:I mean, when you really think about that, why is something right or why is something wrong?
R:I mean, I believe there are basically, like, moral principles set forth in the Bible.  And I guess if you don't want a big philosophical answer we better leave it there.
I:That’s okay, but I mean, in some way essentially yet at some level there's a structure of rules and laws and guidelines that say what is or isn’t morally, what’s right and what’s wrong.
R:Yeah, in some ways though, okay, I’m literally thinking about philosophy here.  I mean, you look at arguments of, like, is this morally wrong?  If you change this law, then would it now be morally right?  If God came to you and said, “It’s okay to do this,” but you think it’s wrong morally, you probably think it’s wrong morally not because God’s saying it, but because it’s morally wrong.  Which of course the usual things that we use to kind of like, if God walked up to you and said, “You can rape this person,” it’s still morally wrong.  Just because God said he changed his mind, it’s still morally wrong.  So in some ways there's some kind of transcendent set of morals that are right and you can’t go past them.
I:And you think that those are, that they’re just there, or they’re there because of the consequences?  It’s like, the right or wrongness is because those transcendent rules are out there and you just can’t go past them, or the transcendent rules are out there because maybe there’s consequences that happen that can be bad.  Or do consequences make any difference?  It's like it’s either right or wrong regardless of the consequences?  Because it sounded to me like on your rape example, that the nature of the consequential sort of thing, doesn’t make that sort of required, and you were saying that would be wrong because of that.  Are you, but I don't know if you’re saying that.  I’m just asking.
R:Are you saying that I’m saying that consequences don't matter, or that I’m saying that consequences do?
I:Are they the basis for right or wrong?
R:No.
I:It’s the transcendent rules, or guidelines, or whatever you want to call those.
R:Yeah, kind of like, trying to remember who came up with it, but it’s a question like, if you can do something wrong, but the only reason that you can think of that it's wrong is because it will hurt somebody, and you can guarantee that nobody will ever find out, then is it – well, I know what the argument is.  It’s like, if you cheat on your wife, but she’s never going to find out, then is it more wrong that you cheated on her, or more wrong that you told her that you cheated on her?  Because it only has bad consequences if she finds out, so if you just never tell her, and make sure she never finds out, then it was okay.  Then the question is, was it really wrong for you to cheat on your wife or not?  And I would say, yeah, it was wrong for you to cheat on your wife, even if she’s never actually going to feel any pain from it, so.
I:It’s the principle that’s wrong.
R:Yeah.
I:Its transcendent principles are out there about what is and isn’t ok.  And where would you say your moral views have come from?
R:Reading the Bible, and reading the Apologetics, and taking philosophy classes, and getting A’s in philosophy classes.
column590: Basically I’m very well set in what I believe the Christian world views based on theology are, and so I compare things to that and decide.  And if I can’t figure out something myself, I’ll ask about it.  But I kind of am of the opinion that if you’re asking about it, you're probably asking about it because you know the right answer and you just want to follow through with it. You want permission to do something else. Yeah. It's generally easy for me. Yeah. And so I’m also – my personality type, I was most conscientious voted in my class when we graduated, and that’s out of 20 people.  And my best friend came up to me after we wrote everything down, and she’s like, “I can’t tell you what I put, but it’s perfect for you.”  So they were very correct.  I’m a very conscientious person, so. Yeah.  It tends to drive people crazy though too. Easier. I think I’m more comfortable asserting myself, and being like, “This is what I think, and I’m going to do something else just because the situation, or whatever.”  So I also think in some ways kind of an interesting question.  Like, how many times we actually confronted the choosing to do something right or wrong is like this major issue, as opposed to just like, the sign says, “No parking,” but I’m only going to be here for five minutes, or it’s only a little lie.  You just kind of – I’ve never had to probably in many years now, choose I’m going to do this because it’s right, and this is a huge major decision, so.  That’s asking for a big philosophical thing there.  I will, the discourses of power tell us that. I mean, I believe there are basically, like, moral principles set forth in the Bible.  And I guess if you don't want a big philosophical answer we better leave it there. Yeah, in some ways though, okay, I’m literally thinking about philosophy here.  I mean, you look at arguments of, like, is this morally wrong?  If you change this law, then would it now be morally right?  If God came to you and said, “It’s okay to do this,” but you think it’s wrong morally, you probably think it’s wrong morally not because God’s saying it, but because it’s morally wrong.  Which of course the usual things that we use to kind of like, if God walked up to you and said, “You can rape this person,” it’s still morally wrong.  Just because God said he changed his mind, it’s still morally wrong.  So in some ways there's some kind of transcendent set of morals that are right and you can’t go past them. Are you saying that I’m saying that consequences don't matter, or that I’m saying that consequences do? No. Yeah, kind of like, trying to remember who came up with it, but it’s a question like, if you can do something wrong, but the only reason that you can think of that it's wrong is because it will hurt somebody, and you can guarantee that nobody will ever find out, then is it – well, I know what the argument is.  It’s like, if you cheat on your wife, but she’s never going to find out, then is it more wrong that you cheated on her, or more wrong that you told her that you cheated on her?  Because it only has bad consequences if she finds out, so if you just never tell her, and make sure she never finds out, then it was okay.  Then the question is, was it really wrong for you to cheat on your wife or not?  And I would say, yeah, it was wrong for you to cheat on your wife, even if she’s never actually going to feel any pain from it, so. Yeah.  Reading the Bible, and reading the Apologetics, and taking philosophy classes, and getting A’s in philosophy classes.
column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on Christian theological principles, asserting that understanding right and wrong is generally easy for them due to their strong moral grounding, while also acknowledging the importance of seeking advice from others when uncertain, but ultimately prioritizing what they believe God or scripture dictates as right.

column583:
I:Okay.  What is it that makes them in and of themselves wrong, do you know, I mean, what, what is it that makes stuff right and wrong?
R:They know the consequences, when they’re doing it, and they know that smoking is illegal underage, that’s what makes it wrong, for doing it.

R:Yeah.

column584: Sex before marriage. Smoking. Like underage. Um… Yeah. They know the consequences, when they’re doing it, and they know that smoking is illegal underage, that’s what makes it wrong, for doing it. Yeah. Yeah the— The Bible. Yeah. You can just, you kinda have a feeling that you know what’s wrong or right.  You can tell. And you listen to the adults. Yeah. I’m not really sure.
column585: The respondent shared a past experience of feeling unsure about the right decision when offered marijuana by older peers, ultimately choosing to leave the situation, and emphasized that they rely on their intuition and guidance from adults, including their belief that the Bible informs their understanding of right and wrong, while also expressing a clear stance against cheating and lying, and a general disinterest in peer pressure regarding drugs and alcohol.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:If I feel guilty about doing it, I usually won’t do it.
I:You’ll know ahead of time that you would feel guilty?
R:Yeah, I’ll know ahead of time, like for, I would never get in the car and drink.  I wouldn’t ride with anybody because I know that if my mom said that-
I:So you have kind of a guilt meter?
R:Guilt meter kind of thing.  If I knew, for example, if I'm doing something and I know if I get caught it could be prison time-not doing that.  If I did something and they said it was bad, if God was up there just shaking his head looking at me, not doing that either.  Just something I won’t go that far and do.
I:So it’s partly sort social consequences and it’s partly sort of religious?
R:Yeah, I'm still kind of keeping in my religious morals.  I mean I may have strayed a bit, but.
I:So in general, how easy or hard is it for you to figure out right and wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy for me.
I:Has it gotten easier or harder in the last three years?
R:I’d say it’s gotten easier.  Back in high school I guess it’s just a confusing time, you’re hanging out with different people.  First time I drank I was maybe a junior, about to graduate, about to go to summer of junior year and somebody asked me if I wanted to go to a party and I went and I basically the first time you ever open a beer and at that age you kind of feel bad about it but the next day you’re kind of just thinking everybody else does it.  I mean it’s not really that peer-pressure thing, but I’d say there’s a lot, I mean nowadays if I don’t want to drink, I don’t drink and nobody can tell if I want, like if I'm going to.
I:So in high school the main sort of moral issue do I gather is whether to be drinking or not?
R:Yeah whether you’re going to be drinking-
I:What was more confusing back then to you?
R:Whether to be drinking, have sex, whether to do any, basically the typical teenage stuff, drinking, smoking, having sex.  That was probably the most difficult of things because once you hit college, if you’re still a virgin, guys will be like what?  Girls love it because I'm still a virgin to this day, girls love it.  Guys, they’ll kind of look at you like what kind of thing.  But nowadays I don’t care what they think.
I:Why do girls love it?
R:I guess they like the fact that, I guess they’re hoping that they’ll be your first.  Or they just love the fact that you’re not running around with girls, kind of thing.  My girlfriend is a virgin, I'm a virgin, that’s why we usually get along really well.  We’ll talk about it sometimes.
I:What about other possible moral issues in high school, like cheating in school or lying to parents or stealing something, are those issues?  Or not issues?
R:Never been a thief.  Never stolen.  Lying-
I:But I mean in terms of temptation.
R:Temptation, I was never tempted to steal anything.  Sure I was tempted every now and then on a quiz in Spanish, we would, I would sit next to my friend and he’d be like dude, what’s this?  And I’d be like here, I don’t care.  I mean it was just an  we had to take.
I:So what do you think is it that makes, we talked about this a little bit already, but I just want to make sure I understand, what is it that makes something right or wrong?  Where does right and wrong come from?
R:Personally for me right or wrong comes from, I'm not going to say the Puritan Christian values, but like contemporary, I just set my life by the teachings of Christ.
I:So are you saying the Bible or what your church teaches, or?
R:Basically the Bible.  Denominations and church, this sounds bad, but if I followed the church, my church is no drinking, this is going to sound worse, be a Republican, kind of thing.
I:It actually teaches that?
R:My church particularly doesn’t, but that denomination, I went to my girlfriend’s church, she’s an independent Baptist, and it kind of ticked me off because when the preacher got up there he did this little thing about, he talked about Iraq, and he said a lot of people want, all the politicians think we should just pull out but this country was founded by fighting for what we believe in and you have to do this and I was just kind of like what?
I:Oh my, so you’re saying specific churches teach what you think are too restrictive or narrow so you’re taking Christianity and the Bible not a specific church?
R:Yeah, I think of Christianity as basically my interpretation of it, what I know right from wrong, what I read; anything from that.

column591: The respondent plans to use an inheritance to attend college, influenced by their mother's positive experiences at Appalachian State, and they navigate moral decisions primarily through a "guilt meter" shaped by social consequences and religious values, emphasizing the importance of adhering to Christian teachings while also recognizing the complexities of right and wrong in various situations.

column583:
I:Um, where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:The bible.
I:The bible?  What is it that you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:You think about if it hurts other people if you want to be done to yourself or not.
I:And why is it wrong to hurt other people?
R:I don’t know.
I:What makes hurting other people wrong or hurting yourself wrong?
R:Uh, I don’t know.  It’s not good.
I:Does it really make any difference if someone else gets hurt as long as you’re able to get what you wanted?
R:No, it’s not right.
I:How do you decide in your life what is right and wrong, or good and bad?
R:I think about it.
I:Uh-huh.  And then what do you think about?  Like maybe give me an example of when you had to make a decision of something that was right or wrong.
R:I don’t know.
I:I don’t know, maybe something that you mentioned earlier, that if your mom wants you to do something, that since she’s your mom maybe it would be right to do it whether you wanted to or not.  How do you make the decision to do it or not to do it?
R:Think about it for awhile and then make a decision.
I:What do you base the decision on?
R:What’s right and wrong.
column584: The bible. You think about if it hurts other people if you want to be done to yourself or not. I don’t know. Uh, I don’t know.  It’s not good. No, it’s not right. I think about it. I don’t know. Think about it for awhile and then make a decision. What’s right and wrong.
column585: The respondent makes decisions based on random thoughts or coin flips when unsure, believes morality is defined by the Bible, feels guilty about bad actions, and acknowledges parental influence in decision-making, particularly regarding right and wrong.
column589:
I:That’s not a bad idea.  How do you normally decide or know what is good or bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t know.  That’s one of those hard questions.
I:Well, is it generally easy or hard for you decide between doing the right thing, and doing the wrong thing?
R:Well, it’s been easy until you come up with a decision where either way doesn’t really make much of a difference.  When it’s like either – because – let me think, knowing the difference between right and wrong.  Well, you can always give the examples like if it doesn’t hurt anyone, or I think the church, that’s good.  It’s got a bunch of rules.  I’m trying to think, and then I’d say the why, I should obey the law.  Yeah, and then let me think.  Then of course something’s like speeding that’s wrong, we know everyone does it.
I:Would you say that deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or harder for you over the last couple years?
R:It’s probably gotten easier.
I:How come?
R:Because well, I think I’m a little bit more mature because like for example when you’re little it’s like – or when you’re younger it’s sort of like, “Hm, I want to do this,” and it’s like, “Huh, maybe it’s not so wrong.”  Then as you get a little older you realize that “I shouldn’t be doing that.”
I:Yeah.
R:And then maturity, it helps out a little, and now it does actually does give some logic of why certain things are wrong.  You know like –
I:Now, what is it you think that makes something right or wrong?  And you said – you mentioned a few different things, but let’s talk about those.  So one you mentioned if it didn’t hurt anybody.  If it hurts – I’m assuming you mean that if doesn’t – if it hurts somebody it would be wrong.
R:Yeah.
I:Secondly, you said something about the church gives you rules and stuff like that.
R:Yeah.
I:You said stuff about laws.  Well, what is it?  Is it all those, one of those, other stuff?  What is it that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t know.  It’s a hard – I have a friend, I don’t know if you want to interview him, but man, he’d give you – anyway.  I’ll have to think about this.  Because I know sometimes it’s hard to categorically say certain things about – because let me think if I can give a – because one example – well, I have an uncle that totally hates Microsoft.  So categorically anything they come out with he will hate.  So – but then one of my programming professors is like, “It’s not good to categorically say something about something.”  Because I’m reminded of – okay, it reminds me of computer science.  See, we have – what is called?  It’s called FiniteMap, that’s the not the right, no, DiscreteMap.  Basically you can have like a certain number of situations, and then each situation would require a certain rule of what’s right and wrong, but of course, trying to apply a general rule to everything that might come into some problems.  So I know it sounds like a pain, having to enumerate every little thing which is what our laws seem to do.  So let’s see, so that’s – it’s hard to say what makes something right or wrong.  Let me think.  When – because hurting people, or maybe not just – maybe the potential to cause harm.  Like you can give the example of having sex before you’re married, having a baby, or even just – there's laws that say you’re not supposed to speed down the highway because even though you might not hurt anyone, there's a potential that you could hurt someone.
I:So you say it’s like what would happen because you did something wrong.  So what – how does that then – because you were talking about lots of rules, or laws, or whatever, how does – do you think that the rules – this is what I think I’m hearing and tell me if I’m right or wrong.
R:All right.
I:That the rules or laws work to keep bad things – if you follow them, will keep bad things from happening.
R:Pretty much, yeah.  They’re sort of a heuristic.
I:Sort of what?
R:They’re kind of a heuristic because they won’t always work.
I:Okay, but they’re sort trying to think ahead.  It’s okay if you do – this is a bad thing because bad things will happen, so you need to follow that so,
R:Yeah.
I:Okay, but the rules and the laws are sort of intended to keep the bad consequences from happening.
R:Pretty much.
column590: I don’t know.  That’s one of those hard questions. Well, it’s been easy until you come up with a decision where either way doesn’t really make much of a difference.  When it’s like either – because – let me think, knowing the difference between right and wrong.  Well, you can always give the examples like if it doesn’t hurt anyone, or I think the church, that’s good.  It’s got a bunch of rules.  I’m trying to think, and then I’d say the why, I should obey the law.  Yeah, and then let me think.  Then of course something’s like speeding that’s wrong, we know everyone does it. It’s probably gotten easier. Because well, I think I’m a little bit more mature because like for example when you’re little it’s like – or when you’re younger it’s sort of like, “Hm, I want to do this,” and it’s like, “Huh, maybe it’s not so wrong.”  Then as you get a little older you realize that “I shouldn’t be doing that.” And then maturity, it helps out a little, and now it does actually does give some logic of why certain things are wrong.  You know like –  Yeah. Yeah. I don’t know.  It’s a hard – I have a friend, I don’t know if you want to interview him, but man, he’d give you – anyway.  I’ll have to think about this.  Because I know sometimes it’s hard to categorically say certain things about – because let me think if I can give a – because one example – well, I have an uncle that totally hates Microsoft.  So categorically anything they come out with he will hate.  So – but then one of my programming professors is like, “It’s not good to categorically say something about something.”  Because I’m reminded of – okay, it reminds me of computer science. Basically you can have like a certain number of situations, and then each situation would require a certain rule of what’s right and wrong, but of course, trying to apply a general rule to everything that might come into some problems.  So I know it sounds like a pain, having to enumerate every little thing which is what our laws seem to do.  So let’s see, so that’s – it’s hard to say what makes something right or wrong.  Let me think.  When – because hurting people, or maybe not just – maybe the potential to cause harm.  Like you can give the example of having sex before you’re married, having a baby, or even just – there's laws that say you’re not supposed to speed down the highway because even though you might not hurt anyone, there's a potential that you could hurt someone. All right. Pretty much, yeah.  They’re sort of a heuristic. They’re kind of a heuristic because they won’t always work. Yeah. Pretty much.
column591: The respondent plans to save most of an inheritance, give 10% to the church based on biblical teachings, and believes that understanding right and wrong has become easier with maturity, emphasizing the importance of not causing harm and adhering to moral standards set by the church and laws, while also expressing a belief in absolute truths over relativism and a moral obligation to help others in life-threatening situations.

column583:
I:What are your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:My discipline as a child and the way I was brought up.
I:By, by whom?
R:By my mother and my grandmother, mainly.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Things that’s right, they help, help you in a positive way and wrong things are usually, have severe consequences like being in jail or even things like just getting a whoopin’ or something.
I:Do you get whoopin’s at your house?
R:No.
I:Ever?
R:Used to.
I:Used to, when, what, did that change at a certain age, or?
R:I think I haven’t had a beatin’ since I was like 9, 10.
I:What do you think changed the form of discipline?
R:I guess I was the youngest and they just decided to just treat me differently and I wasn’t really into too much.
column584: Well, if I, if I know I’m getting myself in trouble with the law, I definitely don’t want to do it and if I get in trouble with my parents, it all depends on the severity of the situation and what I’m doing.  Like, most of the time I wouldn’t do it, especially if I felt like I would get, if I would get caught and in trouble. Yeah. My discipline as a child and the way I was brought up. By my mother and my grandmother, mainly. Things that’s right, they help, help you in a positive way and wrong things are usually, have severe consequences like being in jail or even things like just getting a whoopin’ or something. No. Used to. I think I haven’t had a beatin’ since I was like 9, 10. I guess I was the youngest and they just decided to just treat me differently and I wasn’t really into too much.
column585: The respondent makes decisions based on the potential consequences of their actions, particularly avoiding trouble with the law and their parents, and attributes their understanding of right and wrong to the discipline instilled by their mother and grandmother, while also acknowledging the influence of peers in their choices regarding drinking and smoking.
column586:
I:Okay, how do you decide what’s good and bad and right and wrong in life?
R:Um, the things that I feel that are good and bad, I kind of decided on how it makes me feel.  Like if I’m, if I feel good about something that I’ve done I’m thinking about doing, it’s good and if I’m, I’m like conscious about it and it’s constantly bothering me, I feel like it’s a bad thing.  Especially when I know that it puts somebody else in jeopardy or in pain.
I:Okay, and then in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Generally it’s easy but there’s always times when you don’t really have that clarity.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or more difficult over the past couple of years?
R:It’s probably gotten a little difficult but only in one area of my life.
I:And what’s that?
R:In my relationship with my girl.
I:Can you elaborate a little bit?
R:Well, like I always, I never wanted to lie to her and I never wanted to not be faithful but, on two different occasions it happened but like I said how when I know something is bad, I hear it, it’s like a conscious thing, it’s never, it didn’t bother me.
I:So how did you decide what to do?
R:I didn’t.  I acted, I just acted with the flesh you know what I mean.  I followed with my what I wanted to do.
I:Okay.  And then, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think its point of view that makes something right or wrong, but for the most part it’s society you know, cause the majority of the people are the ones who makes the laws and tells you what’s right and wrong but, I believe it’s point of view.
I:Can you tell me more about like what do you mean by point of view?
R:Like, if you see me shoot somebody down in the street you automatically assume that I’m wrong without but, for me, I could be right because the same person that I just gunned down in the street killed my brother or they threatened my family or something, so that’s my reason, that’s my point of view.  And the same way, then you gotta deal with the same thing in the court room.  If the jury may say that I’m wrong because they threatened my family the didn’t hurt them, or they did hurt my family but it was years ago and I can’t prove it but I, for me I know who it was, so point of view, that’s how I feel about it.
I:And then are there any actions that you think are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:No, I don’t.  I think it always depends on the situation.  Always.
I:Alright, and from where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Um--
I:You know, where do they come from?
R:Um, I’m really not sure cause it’s like, it just, I’ve just changed.  My views have changed over time, cause, you know, my parents try to instill in me what was right and wrong, and then from there I just grew into what I felt was right and wrong as I got understanding for more, cause, you know, they tell you what’s wrong and what’s right but they never tell you why, and as I started understanding that why, and thinking of other possibilities, that’s how I developed my own version of right and wrong.
column587: Um, the things that I feel that are good and bad, I kind of decided on how it makes me feel.  Like if I’m, if I feel good about something that I’ve done I’m thinking about doing, it’s good and if I’m, I’m like conscious about it and it’s constantly bothering me, I feel like it’s a bad thing.  Especially when I know that it puts somebody else in jeopardy or in pain. Generally it’s easy but there’s always times when you don’t really have that clarity. It’s probably gotten a little difficult but only in one area of my life. In my relationship with my girl. Well, like I always, I never wanted to lie to her and I never wanted to not be faithful but, on two different occasions it happened but like I said how when I know something is bad, I hear it, it’s like a conscious thing, it’s never, it didn’t bother me. I didn’t.  I acted, I just acted with the flesh you know what I mean.  I followed with my what I wanted to do.  I think its point of view that makes something right or wrong, but for the most part it’s society you know, cause the majority of the people are the ones who makes the laws and tells you what’s right and wrong but, I believe it’s point of view. Like, if you see me shoot somebody down in the street you automatically assume that I’m wrong without but, for me, I could be right because the same person that I just gunned down in the street killed my brother or they threatened my family or something, so that’s my reason, that’s my point of view.  And the same way, then you gotta deal with the same thing in the court room.  If the jury may say that I’m wrong because they threatened my family the didn’t hurt them, or they did hurt my family but it was years ago and I can’t prove it but I, for me I know who it was, so point of view, that’s how I feel about it. No, I don’t.  I think it always depends on the situation.  Always.  Um-- Um, I’m really not sure cause it’s like, it just, I’ve just changed.  My views have changed over time, cause, you know, my parents try to instill in me what was right and wrong, and then from there I just grew into what I felt was right and wrong as I got understanding for more, cause, you know, they tell you what’s wrong and what’s right but they never tell you why, and as I started understanding that why, and thinking of other possibilities, that’s how I developed my own version of right and wrong.
column588: The respondent plans to invest the money from a distant relative's inheritance primarily to support his brother's real estate ambitions and help his parents, emphasizing a sense of gratitude towards them, while he bases his moral decisions on personal feelings and societal influences, acknowledging the complexity of right and wrong shaped by perspective and upbringing, particularly in relation to his relationship challenges, and ultimately aspires to raise a good family that contributes positively to the community.
column589:
I:Ok.  How do you normally decide or know what’s good or bad or right or wrong in life?
R:From my parents.  I mean, my family’s just - they’ve always kinda guided me towards what’s right and what’s wrong.  And after a while, you kinda just get a sense for it.  Like, you don’t need somebody to tell you, especially if you .  You just kinda know, like, this ain’t the right thing to do.
I:Yeah.  I mean, I understand what you’re saying.  You sort of acquired your moral views from your parents and the people bringing you up.  So you feel like after a while, you just kinda know.  Do you think that we all know?  Or just from experiencing it?  Or what?
R:Well, I guess for me, I would say kinda like how you mold yourself to think.  Like, I always - I kinda look at myself as the good guy.  I don’t really do the wrong thing.  Like, people ask me - even now, people ask me to do certain things, like they want me to ride around with them in a stolen car or something that’s not so crazy.  This guy wanted me to help him do a fight club, and he just wanted me there just to, like, help patch people up and stop the bleeding and stuff like that.  And to me - yeah, it sounds cool.  But at the same time, like, nah.  Like, the cops run in there, you’re all getting picked up.  So it’s like, when they ask me things like that, I kinda laugh at them like, “Yo, you know I’m a good guy.  I’m not gonna do that, man.  You know I don’t do stuff like that.”
I:So in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I say now, it’s easy.  Now, it’s easy.
I:And has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier over the past couple of years or harder?
R:It’s gotten easier.  I guess I’m comfortable with doing what I feel is right.  And it’s been keeping me out of trouble this long, so -
I:Now, have your moral views changed in the past couple of years?
R:No.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Well, that’s basically - you can look at it two ways.  Either you can look at it from a moral perspective, like whether you personally think it’s right or wrong, or you can look at it as socially accepted.  Because a lot of what people say is right and wrong, it’s just what people say as a majority.  Like, a lot of people don’t think polygamy is acceptable because that’s just how most of the societies, especially here in America - everybody has one wife.  But, like, in Africa - that it’s normal.  If you have the money to pay for that - I mean, support your family, then it’s ok.  So it’s more like the society that you’re in.
I:Ok.  So for you, what makes something right or wrong is - and I understand what you’re saying about right and wrong.  It’s some kind of dictated by society.  But for you, what makes something right or wrong?
R:For me, it’s more so, like, how I was taught and for me morally because as far as the society says, I’m more, like - I’m open-minded.  So like, as far as polygamy goes or homosexuality, that stuff doesn’t affect me at all.  It’s not really a big deal.
I:All right.  So you feel it’s like the rules or the laws, the consequences, how it feels God’s will, a combination of those things?  I don’t know.  I mean, what do you think?
R:Well, it’s a combination.  I mean, when you look at the laws and stuff, I mean, they were all made up by a few people.  And this is what these few people together thought was right or wrong.  Like I said, it goes back into, like, the social thing because over here, it may be wrong to kill somebody after they invaded your home or they did something to your family, but somewhere else, like in Africa - if they accuse you of raping somebody - a female - they’ll tie the guys up to the pole and use a big boulder whip and beat all of them and whoever gets grabbed up into the situation, and that’s ok for them.  That’s how their laws are.  That’s what they decided was right.  That’s how they felt like they should deal with the situation.
I:Now, you said - you talked a little bit about where you get your moral views - from your parents.
R:Yeah.
I:Is there any other influence you find on your moral views?
R:Just how - I guess my conscience.  Like, if I feel like I’m gonna do something, and I’m constantly gonna keep thinking about and possibly have regrets about it, then I won’t do it.  Like, somewhere along the line, I think that this view that I don’t wanna live my life with any regrets, so I try not to do anything that I think I’ll have regrets about in the future.

column591: The respondent would invest the $100,000 left by a distant relative rather than spend it frivolously, as they believe it is important to learn from mistakes and build wealth, and they generally make decisions about right and wrong based on guidance from their parents and their own moral compass, which has become easier to navigate over time, although they acknowledge the influence of societal norms and personal conscience in shaping their views.

column583:
I:And where do your views from right or wrong come from?
R:Like, I don’t know, what I base them on?  I don’t know, just like from what my parents have taught me and like what I learn in church and youth group and stuff.
I:So how do you decide or know what is good or bad or right and wrong? Like maybe a specific example that wasn’t in the Bible, like you know, killing or something, you know, new experience for you, take me through the thought process that you go through when trying to decide whether something’s right or wrong.
R:Um, I don’t know, usually everything’s pretty clear to me, but, I don’t know, I can’t really, I don’t know, it’s like I either know it’s right or wrong, cause, like I don’t know, just like a feeling I get, you know?  And it’s like, I don’t know, I really don’t know.
I:So you usually trust that sort of gut feeling that you get?
R:Mostly, yeah, cause if I know it’s wrong, I like get a, that feeling in like your stomach that you’re like oh man, I’m gonna do something wrong, you know, and I just think, I’m like okay, if my parents would see me doing this, what would they think, and I’m like, hey, if they wouldn’t like it, then it’s probably wrong.
I:Right, well how about something like, like lying to you know, your friend ask you, do I look fat, you know, yes, maybe she does, you know, and you know, you don’t want to hurt her feelings, so, you know, you lie, oh no, you know, something like that, where it’s—
R:I’m pretty about those things.
I:But would you think it’s okay to lie in that situation?  It’s not?
R:No.
I:No, okay.
R:Like, I wouldn’t be like, hey, yeah, you look fat, but I’d be like, I don’t know, you could wear something better.
column584: I can’t really say that there is, no, there is, yeah, there is a right or wrong, cause like I don’t think it’s right at all, so, for abortions, I don’t know, cause like in the Bible it says like you shouldn’t kill people or anything, you know, and so then like, that’s what you’re doing, you know, you’re killing the baby. And the death penalty?  You know, I just think that’s horrible, I think it’s wrong, because it’s like the government’s like telling you like not to kill people and then like to justify the killing that’s going on in the world, they kill.  You know?  It’s just really, I don’t know. Like, I don’t know, what I base them on?  I don’t know, just like from what my parents have taught me and like what I learn in church and youth group and stuff. Um, I don’t know, usually everything’s pretty clear to me, but, I don’t know, I can’t really, I don’t know, it’s like I either know it’s right or wrong, cause, like I don’t know, just like a feeling I get, you know?  And it’s like, I don’t know, I really don’t know. Mostly, yeah, cause if I know it’s wrong, I like get a, that feeling in like your stomach that you’re like oh man, I’m gonna do something wrong, you know, and I just think, I’m like okay, if my parents would see me doing this, what would they think, and I’m like, hey, if they wouldn’t like it, then it’s probably wrong. I’m pretty about those things. No. Like, I wouldn’t be like, hey, yeah, you look fat, but I’d be like, I don’t know, you could wear something better.
column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are clear, attributing their moral views to their upbringing and religious teachings, while expressing regret for past actions like drinking and sex, which they feel were influenced by a rebellious phase and peer pressure, and they now feel guilty for leading friends into similar behaviors.
column589:
I:Ok.  And another switching gears, but how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t know.  I guess, like, I’m just - I just know.  Like, there are just some things that you just don’t do.  If it’s against the law, you don’t do it.  Well, for the most part.  Like, I guess I drank before I was 21 even though that was against the law, but I still did it.  But if it’s gonna harm somebody, obviously that’s wrong, and I wouldn’t do that.  Like, that’s the main thing.
I:So, like, the first consequence of it –
R:Yeah.
I:Are what you’re talking about?
R:Yeah.
I:How - in general, how easy or hard is it for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Pretty easy, I would say.
I:And has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:It’s exactly the same.  I’ve never really had a problem doing the right thing, so -
I:Ok.  Have your views about right and wrong changed in the past two years?
R:No.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Just the consequences.  If you’re gonna hurt somebody or someone’s property or, like, upset anybody else, and if it has, like - if anybody else can get, like, hurt, it’s wrong.
I:What if you’re not affecting anybody else’s life?
R:It’s ok.
I:All right.  Where have you acquired your moral views from?
R:My parents.  Whatever they’ve taught me, I guess, and I’ve gone from there.
I:What do you mean you’ve “gone from there”?
R:Just make up my own mind.  Like, they told me sex before marriage was wrong, and I decided for myself.  For a while, I believed that.  Then I just, like knew everything, and then I decided I don’t really see why it’s wrong, as long as you’re serious with the person that - you know?  It’s not just, like, going out and having sex with everybody often or something.
I:Do you think your friends influence, like, the decisions you make?  Or is it just sort of a common sense thing?
R:It is more common sense.

It’s not just, like, going out and having sex with everybody often or something. It is more common sense.
column591: The respondent makes decisions based on their own sense of right and wrong, which they attribute to common sense and parental teachings, emphasizing that actions are deemed wrong primarily if they harm others, while also acknowledging that they prefer to follow their own happiness rather than external influences or religious guidance.

column583:
I:Okay, um, where do your own views of right and wrong come from do you think?
R:Mostly from my parents and from my friends and what they’re doing and it’s basically been in me since I was little, it’s like don’t touch that, it’s hot, that’s wrong, or don’t color on the walls, that’s wrong, don’t eat that, it’s wrong.  And then it’s like study hard, that’s right.  And sometimes you’re just kind of like, no, I don’t feel like doing that and it’s wrong not to but at the same time it’s like I don’t feel like doing that.
I:Okay, um, so what do you think makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t know.  I think  I think it just depends on the situation, and that um, I don’t think there really is a wrong thing, I think you make it to be a wrong thing, like cause if you’re gonna sit there and do it and you should be able to justify it and say I think it’s right, I, it shouldn’t be like you have to defend what you do.  So.
I:Okay so um, how in general do you decide what’s like good and bad in life?
R:After it happens.
I:It, so is it like an outcome thing?
R:Yeah I think as soon as it’s over with, and I get yelled at or I get praised for it or whatever, then I finally am like, mm, that was a good thing or that was a really bad thing, don’t do that again.
I:Okay, um, can you give me some examples of things that, that in your life are really ah, good or bad.
R:It’s like—
I:Decisions you’ve made, or?
R:Not to go up to the lake, cause I know I’m gonna get in trouble when I do that.  And then it’s like lying to your parents about it if you do it anyway. That’s not good.
I:What makes that not good?
R:It’s just the whole yelling thing, it’s not good.
I:Um, so how do you think that that’s gonna change when you’re no longer living at home with your Mom and Dad?
R:I think I’ll be a lot more independent and I’ll probably think about it a whole lot more cause I’ll be like how is this gonna look, what if my parents are there or I’ll be out drinking or something and my parents, and I’m like mm, I’m not supposed to be there.
I:Okay so you think that later on—
R:I think there’ll be the whole Mommy and Daddy are watching, you know that’ll be a little weird.
I:Still kind of think about what they would think?
R:Mm-mm (yes).

And then it’s like study hard, that’s right.  And sometimes you’re just kind of like, no, I don’t feel like doing that and it’s wrong not to but at the same time it’s like I don’t feel like doing that. I don’t know. So. After it happens. Yeah I think as soon as it’s over with, and I get yelled at or I get praised for it or whatever, then I finally am like, mm, that was a good thing or that was a really bad thing, don’t do that again. It’s like— Not to go up to the lake, cause I know I’m gonna get in trouble when I do that.  And then it’s like lying to your parents about it if you do it anyway. That’s not good. It’s just the whole yelling thing, it’s not good. I think I’ll be a lot more independent and I’ll probably think about it a whole lot more cause I’ll be like how is this gonna look, what if my parents are there or I’ll be out drinking or something and my parents, and I’m like mm, I’m not supposed to be there. I think there’ll be the whole Mommy and Daddy are watching, you know that’ll be a little weird. Mm-mm (yes).
column585: The respondent makes decisions impulsively, often relying on social influences from friends and parents, and experiences guilt primarily when disappointing their parents, particularly after engaging in behaviors like drinking, which they recognize as wrong but still partake in for fun.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I guess I just go with like heart and head decisions first.  And you know if that’s wrong then just kind of learn from that.
I:What do you mean by that, the heart and head?
R:You go with what your head, like with what you think and then with what your heart says you should do.  And then, I mean cause if you don’t have your heart in a decision, then there’s no point in doing it anyway.
I:And when you say heart, do you mean the way you feel about things?
R:Yeah, the way that I feel.
I:Okay.  In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s usually pretty easy, there’s some where I know I should do something, or I shouldn’t do something but it’s hard because it’s what’s acceptable and what’s not.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Pretty easy, cause I’ve eliminated a lot of stuff in my life that I don’t need to be doing.  That I know I don’t need to be doing.
I:Do you think that doing the right thing comes kind of naturally or is it kind of hard?
R:Sometimes its kind of hard, but sometimes you just know.
I:So why would you say it’s gotten easier?
R:Because there’s a lot of stuff that I used to do, I used to do so, like I was into so much, like bad things, and I just decided one day, like this isn’t, this isn’t right for me, so.
I:So like bad things like partying a lot?
R:Yeah, I was big into that.
I:Okay, so like drinking or doing drugs?
R:Yeah, stuff like that, and then I just decided that this isn’t me.  So.
I:Anything else that you did at parties in general?
R:Not, I guess it was just that.  It was just the drinking and the drugs, and then I would like drive home and I was like 14 and 15 driving home.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I guess there’s like a set right and wrong that society puts on you.  And then it’s what you think is right and wrong.  I mean if they clash, then sometimes it’s society saying you shouldn’t drink, you shouldn’t have sex, you shouldn’t do this, but if you fee that’s right for you, there’s nobody that can sit there and tell you, no that’s wrong because such and such says.  Cause the world says it’s wrong. So you just kind of have to go by what you think.
I:So what kind of feeling or thought, how do people come to conclusions about what’s right and wrong.  Where do you think those feelings come from?
R:I guess it’s just how you were raised.  Like my parents raised me how to think of right and wrong, how to be my own person, not to rely on a set of rules or whatever to go by.  So you get a lot of it from your parents or the people you’re around, the friends you choose.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:I don’t think, I guess it all depends on the person.  It might be wrong, but for you it might be the perfect thing.  You know what’s right for them.
I:So why do you think that?
R:Because everybody’s different, there’s not a set person that is duplicated in the world.  I mean there are people who believe different things than I do but I’m not saying they’re wrong, they’re not bad people.  But it’s just not the right thing for me, it’s just different things for different people.
I:Okay.  What about things that are always right, do you think there are actions that are always right in and of themselves?
R:No.  I mean, that’s hard, because I cant sit there and be like, it’s right and it be completely wrong for someone else.  But I guess it just depends on the person.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:My parents, and my parents friends.
I:How would you say you’ve gotten your sense of right and wrong from them?
R:They just, it’s like when you’re little.  They’re like, don’t do this, don’t do that, no, no, no.  Just stuff like that, they let you know if you’re doing right or wrong.

You go with what your head, like with what you think and then with what your heart says you should do. column588: The respondent makes decisions based on a combination of intuition and rational thought, acknowledges the influence of their upbringing on their moral views, recognizes the relativity of right and wrong depending on personal experiences, and expresses a desire to help others and make a positive difference in society.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know ?
R:My parents taught me when I was younger.
I:And in general is it easy or hard for you for you to do?
R:Very easy.  It hasn’t .  Easier because now I don’t have my parents to tell me, “You can’t do that because it’s wrong” and then me be like, “Watch it, I’m about to do it anyway,” and now I live by myself and I’m just kind of like, “You know maybe not such a good idea.  Maybe not so good.”
I:So have your views on what’s right or wrong changed much over the last few years?
R:I don’t think they’ve changed like what I think is right and wrong, but I think it’s made me more aware of what’s right for me may be wrong for someone else or what’s wrong for me may be okay for somebody else.  I think it’s made me more aware of other people’s feelings about things.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think it’s your own personal belief system.  I don’t think it’s anything, like social norms or anything like that.  I think it’s just what you think.  I don’t think there’s a book that says smoking is wrong and not smoking is right.  I think it’s dependent on each person and their own beliefs and what they think is right or wrong.
I:What kinds of consequences would make something wrong?
R:If it’s illegal.  I don’t think that stealing is, definitely getting caught stealing is definitely wrong because you’re going to get in trouble.  You’re gonna have to pay fine and you could go to jail.  Probably just the legal-ness of it I guess, that’s not even a word, but…
I:From where do you acquire your moral views?
R:I guess like my parents and growing up I guess.
column590: My parents taught me when I was younger. Very easy.  It hasn’t .  Easier because now I don’t have my parents to tell me, “You can’t do that because it’s wrong” and then me be like, “Watch it, I’m about to do it anyway,” and now I live by myself and I’m just kind of like, “You know maybe not such a good idea.  Maybe not so good.” I don’t think they’ve changed like what I think is right and wrong, but I think it’s made me more aware of what’s right for me may be wrong for someone else or what’s wrong for me may be okay for somebody else.  I think it’s made me more aware of other people’s feelings about things.  I think it’s your own personal belief system.  I don’t think it’s anything, like social norms or anything like that.  I think it’s just what you think.  I don’t think there’s a book that says smoking is wrong and not smoking is right.  I think it’s dependent on each person and their own beliefs and what they think is right or wrong. If it’s illegal.  I don’t think that stealing is, definitely getting caught stealing is definitely wrong because you’re going to get in trouble.  You’re gonna have to pay fine and you could go to jail.  Probably just the legal-ness of it I guess, that’s not even a word, but…  I guess like my parents and growing up I guess.
column591: The respondent expresses a desire to spend an inheritance on personal indulgences like shopping and paying off debts, influenced by their mother's refusal to buy them a car, while also reflecting on their moral decision-making shaped by parental guidance, the complexity of right and wrong in personal contexts, and the belief that morality is subjective and influenced by potential harm to others.

column583:

R:God.
I:Where does it—from God?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay so morality comes from God.  And how, how do people know what’s right and wrong, from God?  Where do they learn that, or how, how could you know?
R:God gives you your conscience.  You know?
I:So, conscience?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.
R:And like if you read your Bible you know, he says, he, you know what I mean?  It says, it gives you rules, 10 commandments.
I:Okay so the Bible—so it comes from God—
R:Honor your father and mother, that doesn’t happen a lot, you know? Like.
I:So it comes from God and it’s known through the Bible and conscience.
R:Mm-mm (yes).
I:Is that what you’re—
R:That’s what I think.

R:Well I think also that you, you need to follow your parents, you know? So when they set guidelines for you, if you don’t follow them it’s right or wrong.  So.

R:Yeah it’s either, I think it’s either conscience, parents, morals, or God.

You know?  And I just like walked off, it’s like, it’s not as hard as—

R:Mm-mm (no)
