column585: The respondent believes that people inherently know right from wrong due to their conscience and upbringing, particularly emphasizing the influence of God and the Bible, while also noting that social pressures and peer influences can lead individuals to ignore their moral compass.

column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um, you know when you’re little, I was taught the 10 commandments and stuff, so now I know them, so now it’s just instinct whether I know what’s right or wrong.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy.  There’s a couple things that you know, I might have to think a little bit but I still know when I’m done.
I:Like what kind of things?
R:I don’t know, just um, if I should watch something or not, um, uh, copying homework.
I:Okay.  So what do you do in those situations?
R:Just think about it.  And I usually know, like I’ve been taught about all the morals or something so I just have to think about it and I pretty much know just about anything, can I take that bite and not be stealing, no I cant do that.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Napkin, no here it is.
I:I don’t need any, I haven’t learned any civilization.
R:Uh, probably easier, I wouldn’t say it’s gotten harder.
I:It’s about the same?
R:Yeah.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Just, well the Bible pretty much says what everything is, so that, that’s the final say on it.  But um, I don’t know, your conscience I think.  As long as you haven’t killed it by that time.  Your conscience pretty much just lets you know.  Would it be okay to take this person’s money or if I find this on the floor, I probably should turn it into lost and found.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Uh, I don’t think there really is.  Like rape, I don’t think you could justify that that would be right, but as for things like lying and stuff like that, there are some situations, like if during World War, (waitress interrupts), like during World War II, if a Nazi knocked on your door and asked if you had any Jews in there and you did, I’m pretty sure it would be okay to lie for that situation.
I:Right.
R:So I’d say there are situations, extreme situations where you could do it or not do it and it wouldn’t be wrong.
I:So like you mentioned rape as something that would always be wrong.  What makes that wrong?  Why is it wrong?
R:I don’t know, it’s just wrong.  It’s just, it’s just violates stuff, it’s committing adultery, it’s forcing something on someone that they don’t like.  It’s abuse, it’s just that conscience thing again, that just says it’s wrong, it’s not really a specific reason.
I:Okay, so what if a person just didn’t have that, didn’t feel that, and thought it was okay?
R:Well then you know, I don’t know what person you’d be able to find that, but if there was a person,
I:Like a psychopath, a sociopath.
R:But then you have to think of the other person, you know, do you think he liked that.  And if he did, then you wouldn’t report it to the cops, but obviously that would be,
I:But apart from getting caught, why should the person who doesn’t care, care about what the other person thinks about at all, do you think?
R:Well, the Bible says do unto others as you would have do unto you.  And I do believe that at the end of, when everybody dies you’re going to go up into heaven and God’s going to judge you and you know, and then all these things you’ve done will be told and weighed in front of you.

column588: The respondent plans to use an inheritance primarily to pay off debt and save for college, influenced by their father's promise to match savings, and expresses a strong moral framework based on the Bible, stating that right and wrong are instinctual and reinforced by religious teachings, while also acknowledging the complexities of moral decisions in certain situations.
column589:
I:Okay.  In general, how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I usually just know, but I would say why I know is based on my upbringing which is based off of what my parents learned from the bible.  But, yeah, I don’t actually like research every decision, I just kind of, if someone says do you want to do this and I’ll usually know from my conscience or what I feel is right or wrong, but I would say that comes from upbringing and what I’m learning daily and stuff like that.
I:Okay.  And do you find that that’s generally an easy thing for you to do, to make those kinds of decisions?
R:Yeah.
I:And what about as you get older, do you think that it’s easier or harder as you get older, to make--?
R:Probably easier.  I realize like, the older I get, I realize there is more gray areas where like, just issues like maybe poverty or like the death penalty or like complicated things like that, like there are some gray areas where it’s hard to call what you think.  But as far as like life decisions where people, me living my life, I find that actually getting easier where I don’t know if it’s through experience, but your, usually I can tell definitely what I feel is right or wrong.

column585: The respondent reflects on a time in seventh grade when peer pressure led him to play a risky game that resulted in a three-week punishment, emphasizing that his decision was influenced by friends rather than his own judgment, while also expressing that his understanding of right and wrong is shaped by teachings from various adults in his life, including his parents.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Umm most of the time I just, I just think about like if my parents was there would I do it.  Or if like somebody, somebody really close to me was there would I do it.  And that’s what lets me know if it is right or wrong.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy.  When I was younger it used to be hard, I was like there aint nothing wrong with doing this alright. It’s doing this, it’s just doing that. It’s pretty easy to decide right and wrong now.  I guess cuz like when I was younger I always kind of like psyched myself out of believing some of the things I do was wrong just because it seemed fine at the time.
I:So over the past couple of years you feel like it’s gotten easier to decide between right and wrong?
R:Yah I wouldn’t say deciding has it’s gotten easier to do the right things cuz I mean I think it’s pretty easy for anybody to decide right and wrong but the hard part is deciding whether you are going to do the right thing or not.
I:Now why do you feel that has changed for you actually because you are talking about actually doing right versus doing wrong not actually deciding what’s right and wrong?  Why do you think that’s gotten easier?
R:Maturity and uhh starting to hang out with more like more calm people than what I used to cuz I used to hang out with a rough and rowdy crowd like for a while.  Umm I know like I used to, I used to stay out really late and everything and I had friends that like if you want to do it, like a lot of my friends had the mind set of if you want to do it, do it.  It’s I mean basically it’s your life, can’t nobody run you.  I used to hang out with those kind of people.  And like now, now like I hang out with people whose got more, like more responsibility and so like I know it’s like that cuz now I have more responsibility and so I guess it’s like me, I have maturity and responsibility.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Umm probably like morals and ethics behind it.
I:What do you mean by that?
R:Like if uhh somebody or some people might think that like uhh say like if, like if somebody, like if somebody looks at your girlfriend or what ever.  Some people like some people actually might think that it’s right to you just, to confront that person and like you know just get violent with them just because  you know they looked at your girl.  You’d be like she’s my girl you shouldn’t be looking at her.  I think, I think that’s in-moral cuz there is actually no logic behind it. And umm so and with the ethics like ethics if it’s I say like if something is really un-ethical like you do something just to do it, like say like people, people be like nobody got hurt from it, nobody that you know got hurt from it.  Nobody that’s in like your immediate little circle got hurt from it.  Like you could be, say like if you say that like you horse playing around you’d break a window they are like nobody got hurt from it, aint nobody get hurt, nobody had to go to the hospital or nothing so people are like it wasn’t wrong and we were just playing around and it happened, that’s not right either, somebody has to pay for the window.  So you can’t say nobody was hurt from it.  Cuz that hurt somebody’s finances right there.
I:O.k. so now you are talking a little bit about the consequences of like peoples actions right cuz that’s a consequence of something you did,  uhh because before you were talking a little bit about you know the moral and ethical side of it and now you are talking about so consequences to make something wrong or?
R:Yah,  cuz if it like, basically if nah cuz you can’t even say if, if uhh if somebody benefits from it than it’s right.  Cuz somebody can rob a bank and I mean you benefit from it cuz you end up with a lot of money but it’s not right.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:From my mom and uhh basically it’s like little shit that I have learned or acquired over the years.
I:Through?
R:Experience.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Excuse me, how do I know what is good-I trust my heart and my conscience.  I have a fairly strong conscience I think just from growing up in a, um, I mean some people say sheltered life, which it has been, but just strict and stuff, so I usually go with my gut feeling and it’s most of the time right.  If I don’t know what is right or wrong or what I should do, I pray about it, or ask my parents in their wisdom, what would you do?  and I don’t always agree with what they say, so I guess that’s opinion type stuff and then it will kind of be up to me to weigh the options, well they said this but I don’t really feel right about it, so what do I feel?
I:Okay, so when you have prayed do you feel like you get an answer?
R:Most of the time, yeah, like for me, like this job transition I didn’t know what to do because I was already planning on quitting my job when I got back from India because I just need to move on, I’ve been working at Goodwill for too long and then this opportunity came up so I was like what do I do?  Like my new boss will let me take the time off to go to India and come back, he goes to my church actually and so he’s supportive of missions and stuff.  So I was praying about it and for me I prayed that if it wasn’t a good switch, that I would feel really uneasy and just really hesitant about it, but if it would be a good switch and that if I should, um, change jobs and stuff, that I would just be completely at peace about it and like everything would work out, like talking to my boss and giving my notice and stuff like that and everything just worked out so smoothly, like I could not have worked out those details as perfectly as they happened so I give God all the credit and I'm trusting that he lined everything up so that’s what I feel.
I:And about how often do you pray?
R:All day long , a lot.  I don’t think I could really count how like many times, but I do pray throughout the day, not just for meals or whatever but if I have some time to myself or even like at my job while working and I’ll just be talking to God.
I:So it’s like it, it’s more like a conversation?
R:Yeah, like my relationship with God is not like, I don’t know I guess it’s not all official like have to be this big thing about praying to God, it’s just talking to God, like it’s a relationship like me talking to you and um, and it is two ways, so yeah, it’s just like okay God I'm having a really tough day, just help me through it, just I need some encouragement, send me something along the way, help me keep going, so yeah.
I:And so do you feel like you’re, as you get older that deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder?
R:I think that I would actually say that it’s getting a little bit harder.  Um,  I'm trying to think how I would explain that.  I think because I’ve, I'm kind of like now on my own, light out from underneath my parents’ wing, like belief-wise, I'm not just like my parents say this so I do it, so it’s more like I mean whether you’re talking about faith and religion or not, it’s just like the way I live my life so I don’t always have them to fall back on, I have to make my decisions myself and like I said sometimes I don’t like to ask my parents because I want to figure it out by myself so I guess it’s been tough and sometimes I’ve made the wrong decision and I learn from it and stuff, so but it’, I think also just growing up, having more options anywhere you go, where, I don’t know, anything you do, should I go to the mall or not today, that’s not a right and wrong thing, but um, yeah just in general.
I:Okay, a little harder?
R:Yeah.
I:What do you think it is that makes something a right or wrong thing?
R:For me I have to in my own life line it up against the Bible, like what God says is right or wrong.  I guess, um, but some people will say like well he doesn’t say in the Bible do not smoke, but for me it’s like well I know he says to keep a clean and pure body so why would you pollute it with something like that so that’s kind of what I base my decisions off of, it’s like what, I mean yeah they have like those bracelets like: what would Jesus do?  But it is kind of do, would Jesus seriously be doing this?  Would God be happy if he walked in the room and I'm sitting here doing this?  Would he be proud of me or not?  So, yeah.

column591: The respondent prioritizes helping others, particularly their parents and friends, and bases their moral decisions on their conscience and prayer, often seeking guidance from God and their parents, while expressing a desire for everyone to know Christ and emphasizing the importance of character-building through difficult decisions.

column583:
I:Okay, and where do you think those feelings come from of knowing what’s right and wrong?
R:Um, well on me I don’t know I could just feel it in my stomach or I could just, I know when it’s wrong I don’t know how to describe it, it’s wrong.
column584: Um, well on me I don’t know I could just feel it in my stomach or I could just, I know when it’s wrong I don’t know how to describe it, it’s wrong.
column585: The respondent reflects on a time when they faced a decision about going out against their parents' wishes, ultimately choosing to seek their parents' approval, while expressing a belief that many people today lack a clear sense of right and wrong due to insufficient communication from parents, and emphasizing that their own moral compass is guided by intuition and a desire to avoid negative consequences for themselves and their friends.
column586:
I:Right.  Okay.  How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:My instincts, and of course what I’ve heard and that goes back to my instincts.  What I’ve been taught.
I:Okay when you say what you’ve been taught, what do you mean by that?
R:Well, if I’ve been taught a certain thing’s wrong, if I think it’s wrong you know, I, I don’t know, sometimes it’s what I’ve been taught, sometimes it’s what I feel, but I mean it’s mainly I feel what I’ve been taught if that makes sense.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Easy.
I:It’s easy.  Okay.  Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:I really never thought about that.  I’m going to say harder.
I:Harder, why?
R:I don’t know, it’s just,
I:When you said harder, was there something that came to mind that made you think of that?
R:I’m going to say like going out, you know, there’s been times when I’ve spent the night at a friends house, and she’s like “let’s go to a party, we’ll be right back.”  And I’m just like I really want to go but I know I shouldn’t.  But you know, so like stuff, you know.
I:So you feel like there’s almost more opportunities for you to do bad things so it makes it harder?
R:Yeah, like, and they’re like we don’t even have to drink, we can just go just to be there and to have fun.  And I’m like, I don’t know.  Well, that’s what I mean by harder.
I:So it was hard.  I just want to make sure.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:(pause) What do I think it is that makes something?
I:Uh-huh.
R:Uh, I think what you feel.
I:What you feel?
R:Uh-huh.
I:And what do you mean by that?
R:Uh, like if I’m going somewhere, or I’m doing something you know and it feels wrong you know, then I know I shouldn’t be doing it.
I:So when you say feels wrong, is there a sort of particular thing that it sort of feels?
R:It’s like in the back of my head.
I:Okay, where do you think these feelings come from in your view?
R:If I’ve been, like not to disobey, I’ve never really went against my parents wishes.  There has been a few times when I have and you know, I feel bad, just I don’t know where it comes from, it just feels bad.
I:Okay, that makes sense.  So based on a feeling, that’s exactly what you’re saying.  So um, push on this a little bit more.  Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Any actions that are always wrong in themselves?
I:Yeah, like are there any things that someone might do, or that you might do, that would always be wrong?
R:Go against my parents wishes.
I:Go against your parents wishes, that’s always wrong?
R:No, okay, never mind (giggling).  I don’t know.
I:You don’t know?
R:I don’t know. Um, oh I have an answer for that last question.
I:Oh you do?  Okay.
R:Um, doing harm you know, to someone you know?  That’s always wrong.
I:Okay, hurting someone is always wrong. Okay.  So um, from where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Um, parents, grandparents, um, just people I look up to.
I:So just people in your life.
R:Yes.
column587: My instincts, and of course what I’ve heard and that goes back to my instincts.  What I’ve been taught. Well, if I’ve been taught a certain thing’s wrong, if I think it’s wrong you know, I, I don’t know, sometimes it’s what I’ve been taught, sometimes it’s what I feel, but I mean it’s mainly I feel what I’ve been taught if that makes sense. Easy. I really never thought about that.  I’m going to say harder. I don’t know, it’s just, I’m going to say like going out, you know, there’s been times when I’ve spent the night at a friends house, and she’s like “let’s go to a party, we’ll be right back.”  And I’m just like I really want to go but I know I shouldn’t.  But you know, so like stuff, you know. Yeah, like, and they’re like we don’t even have to drink, we can just go just to be there and to have fun.  And I’m like, I don’t know.  Well, that’s what I mean by harder.  (pause) What do I think it is that makes something? Uh, I think what you feel. Uh-huh. Uh, like if I’m going somewhere, or I’m doing something you know and it feels wrong you know, then I know I shouldn’t be doing it. It’s like in the back of my head. If I’ve been, like not to disobey, I’ve never really went against my parents wishes.  There has been a few times when I have and you know, I feel bad, just I don’t know where it comes from, it just feels bad. Any actions that are always wrong in themselves? Go against my parents wishes. No, okay, never mind (giggling).  I don’t know. I don’t know. Um, oh I have an answer for that last question. Um, doing harm you know, to someone you know?  That’s always wrong.  Um, parents, grandparents, um, just people I look up to. Yes.
column588: The respondent would use an inheritance of $100,000 to help children at the daycare they work at, driven by a sense of maternal instinct and the belief that they should care for those in need, while their moral decisions are primarily guided by their instincts and teachings from parents, leading them to feel conflicted about social pressures and the consequences of their actions.
column589:
I:Okay so how do you normally decide what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Morals, the morals that I grew up with.
I:So you mean like your Catholic upbringing?
R:Yeah and also, I just I know what I want. I know how it makes me feel.   I:  Okay so in general is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong? Easy.
I:Do you think it’s gotten easier or harder over the last few years?
R:I’m gonna say both.  Easier because I’ve grown up more, but in some ways it’s also gotten harder so I guess it’s a little of both.
I:So what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  Like how do you know?
R:I, like me personally?
I:Yes.
R:I don’t know.  I guess it’s just a gut feeling.  You just know.
I:Well okay, so where do you think that feeling comes from?  What is it that triggers the gut feeling?
R:I don’t know.  I just feel it.  I just know it’s right.
I:Yeah, definitely.  So from where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Family, growing up, religion.
column590: Morals, the morals that I grew up with. Yeah and also, I just I know what I want. I know how it makes me feel.   I:  Okay so in general is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong? Easy. I’m gonna say both.  Easier because I’ve grown up more, but in some ways it’s also gotten harder so I guess it’s a little of both.  I, like me personally? I don’t know.  I guess it’s just a gut feeling.  You just know. I don’t know.  I just feel it.  I just know it’s right.  Family, growing up, religion.
column591: The respondent makes decisions based on their Catholic upbringing and morals instilled by their family, prioritizing the well-being of others and the importance of not jeopardizing relationships, while also relying on their intuition and gut feelings to discern right from wrong.

column583:
I:Okay, that’s fine.  Um, let's see, where would you say your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Probably my parents and school, stuff like that.
I:Uh-huh, um, what do you think makes something right or wrong?
R:If it’s bad for you, um, if it’s illegal, um,   if you won’t want your parents to know that you’re doing it and stuff like that.
I:Okay, um, let's see, so do you think everything that is illegal is morally wrong?
R:Not everything cause there’s some kind of stupid laws, like once before, my brothers, they built a tree house in the backyard and we didn’t know there was a law where you couldn’t have a tree house where we live, so they made us take it down, so that’s a dumb law.
I:Okay. Um, so um, let's see, so how do you know um if something is like bad for you then that makes it right or wrong, then, do you know?
R:I don't know, I suppose if you could get hurt or sick or, like probably if you could get hurt by it or something like that.
I:Okay.  sorry.
R:It’s alright.
I:M11:Um, let's see, so how badly would something have to hurt you to make it M11:wrong?  Like would you say smoking cigarettes is wrong?
R:M11:Yes.
I:Um, what about something that’s not quite as um risky, like speeding?
R:Um,
I:Would you think that’s morally wrong or?
R:Um, I don't know I don’t think it’s morally wrong.  You shouldn’t do it cause you could get in an accident, but I don't know a lot of people speed, so,
I:Okay, so um, let's see, so what would you do if you were unsure how if something was right or wrong like if you weren’t sure if it would hurt you or not?
R:Um, I'd probably ask my parents or something like that.
I:Okay, um, so how do you decide like what’s right or wrong or good and bad in life, would you say?
R:Um,
I:Take your time.
R:Probably if it’s bad for you and like if my parents told me not to do it and if it was illegal and those kinds of things.
I:Do you think your parents are always right when they tell you something’s right or wrong?
R:Uh, yeah, kind of.
I:Has there, can you think of a time where they might have been wrong?
R:I don't know I think really sometimes like cause we have a town curfew, if they make you come in before that, like if you go to the movies, like through the week cause there’s no school in the summer and the curfew here is like 10:30 on the weekdays and if you go to see like a movie that starts at like 9:00 you probably won’t be home by 10:30, so I think that’s stupid.

Not everything cause there’s some kind of stupid laws, like once before, my brothers, they built a tree house in the backyard and we didn’t know there was a law where you couldn’t have a tree house where we live, so they made us take it down, so that’s a dumb law. Um, Probably if it’s bad for you and like if my parents told me not to do it and if it was illegal and those kinds of things. Uh, yeah, kind of. I don't know I think really sometimes like cause we have a town curfew, if they make you come in before that, like if you go to the movies, like through the week cause there’s no school in the summer and the curfew here is like 10:30 on the weekdays and if you go to see like a movie that starts at like 9:00 you probably won’t be home by 10:30, so I think that’s stupid.
column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are clear, primarily learned from parents and school, and while they acknowledge some actions as wrong due to parental guidance, they also express a desire to engage in activities their parents disapprove of, indicating a conflict between fun and moral teachings.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Probably, I don’t know. I think at a certain age you just kind of know what you should do and what you shouldn’t do but I don’t know sorry…
I:In general, how easy or hard is it for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Not too hard.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:I’d say easier. When I was younger I was more likely to be influenced by friends of what they thought was right or wrong, but now I kind of have my own.
I:Have your views about what was right and wrong changed in the past two years?
R:Probably not too much. When I was younger, we talked really goofy things, Halloween egg stuff or something like that. Now I would say, “No, I shouldn’t do that because someone’s got to clean it up tomorrow.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Okay, I would say everyone has their own values so that’s kind of hard to answer. I would say, as long as it’s not, it’s illegal, it’s probably wrong. But other than that, I don’t know. Everyone has their own beliefs, but I kind of believe, you know, you know if there are things that are wrong, like stealing, lying, stuff like that. But somehow people do lie for good reasons; I will say that, nothing, it’s right to lie…
I:So if they lie for good reasons, could it be okay?
R:Oh, that’s a tough one. I would say it depends on a situation maybe, but it kind of still is wrong. Lying is wrong. But if you’re … I don’t know, it still is probably wrong but maybe you think it’s the right thing to do at the time. Yeah, like that.
I:So it depends on being like, people acting like right and wrong or is it always like depended upon the context?
R:I think it depends upon the context, maybe. But I don’t know.
I:That’s a tough one.
R:Yeah.
I:I understand. So what kinds of consequences would make something wrong?
R:Making everyone mad at you, upset with you, making everyone and the one you love and care about and think you did the wrong thing, or going to jail.
I:It should sort of … if something is right, it’s a jive with what other people think is right.
R:Usually yes, but not always because sometimes you can have a crappy group of people that think something’s right when it really is wrong.
I:Yeah and how would you know?
R:I don’t know. The people I’m close to, I pretty much know they’re all good people, so they wouldn’t usually tell you to do something that’s definitely wrong, especially like my mother or something like that.
I:How do you think your mother knows what’s right and wrong?
R:Probably religion. That’s all I would say is, probably she’s very influenced by religious beliefs. So sometimes, her right and wrong is different than mine because she’s very, very influenced by religion and I’m not so much. A little bit but not as much as her.
I:Yeah. That makes sense. From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Probably somewhat my mother but I’m not as  not as bad as she is. I’m not strict with views and stuff like that as she is, probably more from her than my dad.
column590: Probably, I don’t know. I think at a certain age you just kind of know what you should do and what you shouldn’t do but I don’t know sorry… Not too hard. I’d say easier. When I was younger I was more likely to be influenced by friends of what they thought was right or wrong, but now I kind of have my own. Probably not too much. When I was younger, we talked really goofy things, Halloween egg stuff or something like that. Now I would say, “No, I shouldn’t do that because someone’s got to clean it up tomorrow.  Okay, I would say everyone has their own values so that’s kind of hard to answer. I would say, as long as it’s not, it’s illegal, it’s probably wrong. But other than that, I don’t know. Everyone has their own beliefs, but I kind of believe, you know, you know if there are things that are wrong, like stealing, lying, stuff like that. But somehow people do lie for good reasons; I will say that, nothing, it’s right to lie… Oh, that’s a tough one. I would say it depends on a situation maybe, but it kind of still is wrong. Lying is wrong. But if you’re … I don’t know, it still is probably wrong but maybe you think it’s the right thing to do at the time. Yeah, like that. I think it depends upon the context, maybe. But I don’t know. Yeah. Making everyone mad at you, upset with you, making everyone and the one you love and care about and think you did the wrong thing, or going to jail. Usually yes, but not always because sometimes you can have a crappy group of people that think something’s right when it really is wrong. I don’t know. The people I’m close to, I pretty much know they’re all good people, so they wouldn’t usually tell you to do something that’s definitely wrong, especially like my mother or something like that. Probably religion. That’s all I would say is, probably she’s very influenced by religious beliefs. So sometimes, her right and wrong is different than mine because she’s very, very influenced by religion and I’m not so much. A little bit but not as much as her.  Probably somewhat my mother but I’m not as  not as bad as she is. I’m not strict with views and stuff like that as she is, probably more from her than my dad.
column591: The respondent feels that while the right decision with a hypothetical inheritance would be to donate to charity, they would likely invest it for future needs, reflecting a shift towards future-oriented thinking influenced by personal experience; they also acknowledge that their moral views have become more independent from peer influence over time, often seeking advice from family, particularly their mother, who is guided by religious beliefs, while recognizing that moral perspectives can vary and evolve with societal changes.

column583:
R:That’s against the law.
I:Well then but it raises the question, why is it against the law?
R:Yeah, because people mostly think that’s wrong.  And I think people who do it, too, probably think it’s wrong in some way.  Like generally wrong, but, they don’t care.
I:What about, go to an extreme, just murdering somebody.  Is that wrong?
R:Obviously I think that’s wrong!
I:Why?
R:Because it’s taking someone’s life.  Who, because it is  because I’ve been told it’s wrong?
I:Well I mean, there are people that don’t think it’s wrong, I mean they’re a different, Saddam Hussein, you know other—
R:He, he wasn’t—
I:Other people that think, who cares?
R:He wasn’t raised to think it was wrong, the kind of environment he probably lives in and grew up to be in.
I:So is he right or is he wrong?  Or is it?
R:To me he’s very wrong.
I:Or is it for him he’s wrong—right, but for you?
R:For him he’s right and for me it’s very wrong.
I:So which one of you is right?
R:Me.
I:Because?
R:Because I think I’m right, so I’m right to me .
I:So is it just get down to the assertion of will?  Who, whoever has the most power will determine who’s right and wrong?
R:Yeah, I mean if the government, who had the police force was saying murder’s okay, then it would be okay, pretty much, even if people, other people thought it was wrong, it’s whoever has the most power, that happens everywhere, it happens in schools, that happens in the whole…
I:So morality is nothing beyond, I just want to make sure I understand, you’re saying morality is, there’s nothing to morality or behind morality other than just what people can agree on?
R:Yeah, and like people can agree on and people end up learning their morals from other people, you can’t just pick them up, like you could, but people don’t.
I:So what is it that, what if, so if everyone came to agree um, on what, stealing other people’s babies and torturing them was just acceptable entertainment, then that would be the case?
R:I hope not  but—
I:Or is there, or is there—
R:But it would be the case, they would think it was acceptable entertainment.
I:Right, right.  So for example, some people would say, well there’s just a natural law in the universe of right and wrong, and other people would say it comes from God.
R:Most of that’s been made from, I was gonna say, mostly that’s, that view of well there’s just a natural right and wrong, comes from religion, which is also why I think religion’s a good type of thing to have but I don’t, like without religion, probably society would never have evolved in the way it does cause people need reasons for things to make, oh, well, God says that was right, da da da, people obviously—I think the people who originally made religion didn’t actually, probably made it for some of them, made it to control and yeah, to control, that’s my theory.
I:But if people no longer believe in God or religion, then why should they believe in the morals that that religion produced?
R:Cause they don’t think, they probably wouldn’t think of them as morals from a religion?  They would think of them as social morals, cause that’s what they’ve turned into, but they came from that, if, the idea of natural right and wrong, came originally from religion, I mean, the constitution came from religion, that’s how our whole government is run.
I:Right, so let me, just so I understand this, let’s suppose um, by the time we’re senior citizens, some sort of racist fascist dictatorship comes to power in this country and says if you’re not beautiful, if you don’t have nice genetics and if, if you’re not wealthy, we’re gonna dispose of you.  We might say for us, that’s objectionable, we don’t agree with that, but we, we couldn’t, you’re saying we couldn’t make the claim this is in and of itself regardless of what anybody thinks, just wrong.
R:We could.  The people who think it was wrong could very easily say it’s wrong.
I:But based on what, though, we would say it’s wrong for us but beyond that?  If everyone else has changed their mind then we just say?
R:There’s pretty much nothing you can do about it unless you can get enough people to change, or get them away.  That’s just the way things work.
I:All right, okay.  Um, all right.  Now, bringing it back down from philosophical stuff!
R:
column584: That’s against the law. Yeah, because people mostly think that’s wrong.  And I think people who do it, too, probably think it’s wrong in some way.  Like generally wrong, but, they don’t care. Obviously I think that’s wrong! Because it’s taking someone’s life.  Who, because it is  because I’ve been told it’s wrong? He, he wasn’t— He wasn’t raised to think it was wrong, the kind of environment he probably lives in and grew up to be in. To me he’s very wrong. For him he’s right and for me it’s very wrong. Me. Because I think I’m right, so I’m right to me . Yeah, I mean if the government, who had the police force was saying murder’s okay, then it would be okay, pretty much, even if people, other people thought it was wrong, it’s whoever has the most power, that happens everywhere, it happens in schools, that happens in the whole… Yeah, and like people can agree on and people end up learning their morals from other people, you can’t just pick them up, like you could, but people don’t. I hope not  but— But it would be the case, they would think it was acceptable entertainment. Most of that’s been made from, I was gonna say, mostly that’s, that view of well there’s just a natural right and wrong, comes from religion, which is also why I think religion’s a good type of thing to have but I don’t, like without religion, probably society would never have evolved in the way it does cause people need reasons for things to make, oh, well, God says that was right, da da da, people obviously—I think the people who originally made religion didn’t actually, probably made it for some of them, made it to control and yeah, to control, that’s my theory. Cause they don’t think, they probably wouldn’t think of them as morals from a religion?  They would think of them as social morals, cause that’s what they’ve turned into, but they came from that, if, the idea of natural right and wrong, came originally from religion, I mean, the constitution came from religion, that’s how our whole government is run. We could.  The people who think it was wrong could very easily say it’s wrong. There’s pretty much nothing you can do about it unless you can get enough people to change, or get them away.  That’s just the way things work.
column585: The respondent believes that individuals have their own sense of right and wrong shaped by social influences, such as their upbringing and peer interactions, while acknowledging that morality is often subjective and can be influenced by power dynamics, and despite feeling guilty about minor wrongdoings, they generally make decisions based on personal reasoning rather than strict adherence to societal or religious norms.

column583:
I:Okay.  Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Uh, my mom and step dad what they taught me, and what school’s have taught me.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:What kind of consequence you’ll get for it.  You know, if it’s something bad you know you’ll get arrested or grounded or pulled over then it must be bad but you know, if you know that nothing is going to happen or that no one is going to say anything or you might get a reward for doing that then it must be good.
I:Okay.  Um…kind of a different question, but similar, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in your life?
R:Uh, kind of like what I just said previously, if you get in trouble for it then it must be wrong you know, and if you don’t then you get a reward or a pat on the back or something then it must be right.
I:Okay, can you give me some specific examples of some things that you think are right and some things that you think are wrong?
R:Uh, stealing you know, stealing is probably wrong.  Stealing is wrong. Um…let’s see…helping people out when they need help is right, you know. And uh…and that’s basically all I can think of right now.

And uh…and that’s basically all I can think of right now.
column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are determined by the consequences of actions, acknowledges the influence of their parents on their moral views, admits to having acted against their better judgment in the past, and expresses a lack of guilt over their wrongdoings, while also recognizing that societal norms shape perceptions of morality.
column586:
I:Yeah.  Okay.  So, how do you your, how do you, yourself, decide or how do you know what’s good or bad or right and wrong in life?
R:Um.  I usually just say what I think and what I know is bad or right.  I mean, there are things that other people like I guess police or the law would say is bad, was wrong, but I wouldn’t and there are some things that I think is right that shouldn’t be right.  So, I don’t know, I just, I follow my own ways, usually, which is risky, but.
I:Okay.  So, where do you think it comes from, um, when, I don’t know how to put this.  How, you said that you kind of decide what’s right or wrong for yourself.  Do you have any sense how you decide, like where, what you base it on?  Are there kind of general principles that guide you in terms of what you think is right or wrong?
R:Just what I’ve learned from, like, my friends or older brother and what I’ve experienced myself and what I think I shouldn’t have gotten in trouble for something I did, or ah, just, basically.
I:Okay.  So you mentioned this older brother, do you talk to him much and get advice from him and?
R:No.  He’s in jail.
I:Okay.  So, what’s he in jail for?
R:Um.  Some people he was hanging out with drugged him and ah, basically he had a gun and he shot at some people and almost killed someone but didn’t, but since he was drugged, he didn’t get attempted murder, because he wasn’t in a right mind for him or whatever, and so ah.
I:Have you been in touch with him too, while he’s in jail?
R:No, because they keep moving him around, so I don’t know where he’s at.
I:Yeah.  Well, do you typically think it’s easy or hard to decide what’s right or wrong?
R:Easy.
I:It comes pretty quickly?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.  Has it gotten any harder or easier over the last couple years, do you think?
R:To what?
I:Deciding between right and wrong.
R:Oh, it’s gotten easier, I think.
I:Why do you think that is?
R:Ah, just because, I don’t know, just like conscious music that I be listening to, like ah, I don’t know, I’ll be listening to like hip hop music, revolutionary music and stuff, so, that, you know, informing me about stuff that I didn’t really know about, that the government tries to hide, just like, where drugs really come from and all this, who really brings everything in and what the government does behind people’s back, you know, things they don’t want you to know but are true.
I:Okay.  So you feel like there’s a lot of messages in the music that you listen to that are helping you kind of form what you think is right or wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something either right or wrong?
R:Ah.  I’m not sure.
I:I guess, sort of back to that, are there general principles, like do you think about the consequences or is it just how it feels or do you take it from what other people say or?
R:It’s like consequences, but like depending on what the situation was, because, with some things, there could be a situation where it could be bad consequences but you know, I don’t think that I’m doing like something like graffiti, as an example, like I mean, if I go, like I see maybe not getting, not doing graffiti on like a building that is running and working, but going down to abandoned buildings and you know freight trains and you know do something, and not just like, just like gang stuff, like actually do something that’s an art form you know, comes from the heart or whatever, you know, I know that’s highly illegal, but I don’t think people should get in trouble because it’s not like I’m just tagging whatever, you know, I’m doing something that looks nice and you know, and brings, it brings to, I don’t know, some people think that, some people find that stuff highly interesting and I think it looks highly  nice and you know, it’s a type of creativity.

column583:
I:Okay.  Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:My head.
I:What do you mean?
R:Like, I’ll know if something is right or wrong.
I:You will know.
R:Like beating somebody up and taking the money, I know that’s wrong.
I:Why?  Why do you know that’s wrong?
R:Cause they work for their money and they should be able to keep it.
I:So why do you do it?
R:For money.
I:So does that, I mean, pardon me, but it sounds like you’re saying that you don’t like what you do, because they have a right to their money but then you say, no I have a right to their money and I’m going to take it from them.
R:They have a right to keep their money but I’m going to do it anyways, cause I have no way to get money.  And it’s the easiest way to get money.
I:Why not do something, you know, why not work for money?
R:I can’t find a job.
I:Have you tried?
R:Yeah.
I:Let’s say you found a job, would you stop doing those things, or not?
R:Um, (pause), most of them yeah, but extra money, it’s nice to have.
I:What do you do with the money?
R:I spend it.
I:What do you buy?
R:Like if I have money, like I used to have a job, and I used to spend like $300 a day.
I:That’s a lot of money.  On what?
R:Like I’ll go shopping, buy a pair of shoes, some clothes, I’ll buy some weed, a couple bottles of liquor, and then, do the same thing the next night.
column584: My head. Like, I’ll know if something is right or wrong. Like beating somebody up and taking the money, I know that’s wrong. Cause they work for their money and they should be able to keep it. For money. They have a right to keep their money but I’m going to do it anyways, cause I have no way to get money.  And it’s the easiest way to get money. I can’t find a job. Yeah. Um, (pause), most of them yeah, but extra money, it’s nice to have. I spend it. Like if I have money, like I used to have a job, and I used to spend like $300 a day. Like I’ll go shopping, buy a pair of shoes, some clothes, I’ll buy some weed, a couple bottles of liquor, and then, do the same thing the next night.
column585: The respondent acknowledges knowing the difference between right and wrong but often chooses to do wrong for financial gain, influenced by their upbringing and peer pressure, while expressing a belief that many others have lost their sense of morality.
column586:
I:okay. How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:good bad right wrong?
I:yeah.
R:bad is something that’s gonna get me arrested and that’s pretty much it. Right and wrong I don’t really understand that.
I:you don’t understand that? What do you mean you don’t understand that?
R:some things that I think are right and shouldn’t be a problem, everybody else thinks are a problem.
I:like what?
R:anything. Smoking weed, that’s a problem, they’ll yell at you for that. Drinking, that’s a problem.
I:so how do you decide when something is right or wrong? How do you decide?
R:if it’s gonna get me in trouble with the police…
I:then it’s wrong and if it doesn’t then it’s right?
R:yep.
I:do you think it’s easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I mean I can decide between right and wrong but I do some things that are wrong as well as some things that are right.
I:okay, but it’s easy for you to tell the difference you just don’t always do the right thing?
R:yeah.
I:do you think deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or harder over the last two years?
R:easier.
I:why is that?
R:‘cause I know better now. I’m smarter than before.
I:so what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong, you kinda talked about this before.
R:what makes something right or wrong? It depends. I don’t know really what’s right and what’s wrong. I guess I can say I really don’t understand.
I:is it rules or laws, is it the consequences, is it the way you feel, is it what god says?
R:pretty much it’s the consequences of things.
I:so what kinds of consequences would make something wrong?
R:jail time.
I:anything else?
R:no. no other consequences would really bother me. It’s not as hefty as sitting in jail.
I:not like if somebody gets hurt or somebody gets killed, those things don’t make something wrong?
R:well in some cases. Sometimes people need to get hurt. They do bad things, if nobody, if they’re not doing nothing wrong and somebody just runs up and starts beating them up then that’s wrong.
I:what makes that wrong?
R:‘cause they didn’t do anything. But if the guy that they happen to beat up was somebody that had robbed ‘em or did something that he shouldn’t a done to somebody then it’s right because he shouldn't’a done what he did.
I:so if somebody came and beat up some totally innocent person, why is it wrong? What makes that wrong?
R:because the other person, if they were just minding their business and didn’t even know them, wasn’t affecting their life in any way, they shouldn’t even matter, they should leave them alone and do what they’re doing.
I:do you have a feeling of why that is that people shouldn’t mess with people that aren’t messing with them?
R:‘cause it’s not right!
I:you don’t know? You don’t have a sense of why?
R:that’s pretty much the answer. ‘cause if everyone ran around doing that then shit would be crazy!
I:okay. That makes sense. Do you think there are any actions that are always wrong in and of themselves?
R:actions that are always wrong? No.
I:where do you think you’ve gotten your ideas about morality, about what’s right and wrong?
R:um…I don’t even know what’s right and wrong just—
I:--just, if you think about the things that you think are right and wrong, where do you think you got those ideas from?
R:I couldn’t even tell you, I’ve had ideas in my head since I was a little kid. There were bad things, so right and wrong pretty much didn’t matter. Started being bad when I didn’t know better and it stuck with me.

column588: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on the consequences of actions, particularly avoiding legal trouble, and believes that morality is relative, shaped by personal experiences and societal norms, while also expressing a pragmatic view that prioritizes financial stability and personal well-being over moral absolutes.
column589:
I:Okay.  How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Good or bad?  I don’t know if there really is a good and bad.  I mean, yeah, there is.  Certain things are bad, I mean inhumane, some things.  But other than that, basically the world is built on corruption so bad - really it’s a fine line.  But right and wrong, I mean wrong?  You’ll go to jail for it.  You’ll get killed over it.  You’re gonna - something that’s gonna effect you in a negative way.  It’s wrong.  Don’t do it.  But that’s about it, you know?
I:Okay.  So what are some of the kind of inhumane things you were talking about that are just wrong?
R:I mean like rape.  People are out here raping people, killing people.  I mean that’s unnecessary.  But other than that like things that people say is bad.  I smoke weed and people say that’s bad.  But it’s like, it’s not that big of a deal really.  It’s not much different than alcohol at all.  Just because they want to say, “Okay, it’s bad.”  I’m saying.  But, no, I don’t think that that’s bad at all.
I:Okay.  So what in your mind is just wrong about rape?  I mean why is that bad?
R:It’s just because it’s a violation.  Nobody should have, you know what I’m saying?  Nobody is in any position to be snatching another person up and doing whatever they want with them.  It’s just not right.
I:Okay.  In general is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s easy.  Yeah, it’s pretty easy.  I know what I’m gonna get in trouble for, what’s gonna fuck my life up if I do it.  So I pretty much stay away from stuff like that.
I:Okay.  Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:Easier, a lot easier.
I:Okay.  Why?
R:Just being in jail, just knowing the consequences makes it a lot easier.
I:So you’ve been to jail recently?
R:Yeah.  July of last year.
I:How long were you in jail?
R:Just a few months.  But -
I:Do you mind telling me what for?
R:Some bullshit.  Some bullshit.  Got arrested for no reason.  Actually I was and trying to sue the police department because I got arrested for no reason.  I was on probation, and when you’re on probation if you get arrested again it’s a violation of your probation and they can keep you in jail with no bond.  So I couldn’t even bond out of jail.  I had people, my family was there, like, “How much is his bond?”  My bond was $50,000 cash.  And I was in there for disorderly conduct.
I:So what did they say you did?  Just -
R:Disorderly conduct.
I:Okay.  So have your views of what’s right and wrong changed in the past two years?
R:Uh-huh.
I:In what ways?
R:Well, actually, between right and wrong?  No, actually they haven’t changed too much.  But - no, they haven’t really changed too much between what’s right and wrong.  I mean if I’m gonna get in trouble for it, if it’s gonna mess my life up, then I’m really not trying to do it, and I pretty much have been this way for a while.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:What make makes something right or wrong?  To me what makes it right or wrong is how it’s gonna affect you and what ways it’s gonna affect you.
I:Okay, so like outcomes?
R:Right.
I:Okay, from where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Where have I acquired my moral views?  Basically from my dad.  You know, I could have been doing a lot worse.  Could’ve spent more time in the streets, but because of him basically I got the morals down because I didn’t want to get in trouble.  You know what I’m saying?  Coming up, I was getting my ass whooped.  I’m saying, if I was fucking up in school I’d get my ass whooped. Said some  get my ass whooped.  So really when it came down to making a choice, man if do this I’m gonna get my ass whooped, so -
I:By your dad?
R:Right.  So that really made me think that way.

But other than that, basically the world is built on corruption so bad - really it’s a fine line.  But right and wrong, I mean wrong?  You’ll go to jail for it.  You’ll get killed over it. column591: The respondent plans to use an inheritance of $100,000 to buy a house and a reliable car to create a stable life away from negative influences, particularly the police, while reflecting on their moral views shaped by their father's teachings and the consequences of their actions, which have become clearer after recent jail experiences.

column583:
I:What do you think, is it, do you think that there’s anything other than the government that would make something right or wrong?
R:Yeah, I mean like everyday life, you know what, you know if you mom tells you it’s wrong to grab that cookie, then you know it’s wrong.
I:Right.  What about uh, I mean what about, say, say you weren’t learning it from somebody, or say you know, you didn’t, you didn’t know a certain law about uh, I don’t know just say you just go up and kick someone’s ass, like uh, but you ain’t learned that’s wrong anywhere, would it still be wrong?
R:I see wrong in it, but I don’t see it being wrong.
I:Can you explain that a little more.
R:Well, cause if you didn’t know it was wrong but nevertheless in society it’s wrong I don’t think you should be the one considering it be wrong, it’s, it’s other’s people’s wrong since you didn’t know it was wrong.
I:Okay.  So do you think, do you think, aside from who would be responsible for it then, do you think it would still be wrong or not?
R:Yeah.  It all depends on what, why you whoop his ass too thought.
I:Yeah, say you, say you wanted his girl.
R:Yeah, I’d whoop his ass (laughs)
I:Now what, now would you think that to be wrong or…
R:Yeah it’s wrong.
I:Okay, and would you think that, even if there weren’t a law saying that would it still be wrong, or?
R:Yeah.

R:My brain’s not working yet.

R:About doing something wrong, how do I feel about it?
I:Yeah, uh-huh…
R:Pretty bad.

column585: The respondent reflects on their decision-making process, often relying on their initial instincts despite knowing the potential consequences, acknowledges the influence of laws and societal norms on their understanding of right and wrong, and expresses guilt over leaving their family behind, indicating a desire to break the cycle of their parents' neglect.

column589:
I:Okay and how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?  So how do you know those things?
R:I base them off my own morals.  Like if I feel something is bad then, not, I’ll try to not do it, try to not do it, but if it’s good, if I feel that something is good then I will go with it.  And also, the society rules, as well.  Law.
I:Okay, laws?
R:Yeah, I abide by laws to see what’s good and bad, as well.
I:And where do you think your morals came from?
R:Probably growing up, my mother and when I used to go to church and study religion.  And then life experiences, as well.  That helped me to see what’s morally right and what’s wrong.
I:Okay, and do you feel like as you get older, that deciding what’s right or wrong gets easier or harder?
R:Harder.
I:Harder, okay, any reasons?
R:Because when you’re older you have more experience and you’re aware of more things so there’s a lot of things that come into play when deciding what’s right and what’s wrong, because you also have to like negotiate or balance or even compare things to see if it’s right or not.
I:Well, it worked out in the end.  So, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong, then.  Like what is it that is the ultimate determination?
R:Your conscience.
I:So it’s something internal?
R:Yeah, it’s definitely something internal.
column590: I base them off my own morals.  Like if I feel something is bad then, not, I’ll try to not do it, try to not do it, but if it’s good, if I feel that something is good then I will go with it.  And also, the society rules, as well.  Law. Yeah, I abide by laws to see what’s good and bad, as well. Probably growing up, my mother and when I used to go to church and study religion.  And then life experiences, as well.  That helped me to see what’s morally right and what’s wrong. Harder. Because when you’re older you have more experience and you’re aware of more things so there’s a lot of things that come into play when deciding what’s right and what’s wrong, because you also have to like negotiate or balance or even compare things to see if it’s right or not.  Your conscience. Yeah, it’s definitely something internal.
column591: The respondent makes decisions based on personal morals influenced by their mother and church upbringing, acknowledges the complexity of right and wrong as they age, and believes that ultimately, one's conscience determines morality, while also recognizing the impact of societal norms and the media on values.

column583:
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Makes something right or wrong?  I’d just think about my role models or just my standards and think is this something that’s right and if it doesn’t match up I’m not going to do it.
I:Where do you think your standards come from?  Like how you think about right and wrong?
R:Um, a lot from my religious beliefs, but a lot from my home beliefs too. You know I have my religious standards set down and then I have my family standards set down and I see where those lie and I say okay I can’t do this or I can do this, so.

You know I have my religious standards set down and then I have my family standards set down and I see where those lie and I say okay I can’t do this or I can do this, so.
column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are influenced by their religious and family beliefs, feels guilty about minor actions, opposes swearing among friends, and maintains a strong stance against drugs and alcohol due to personal observations and moral standards.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Um, mostly from my, my church values, a lot of it comes from there.  And like I can’t drink coffee, you know, ah, or caffeine and that kind of stuff or you know we don’t drink, we don’t smoke, but um, as determining on a daily basis what’s right and wrong, I take from my church values and then what I believe is right and wrong and is immediately, you know, right or immediately wrong, you know, so, I guess that’s how I determine.
I:Where do you think your beliefs about right and wrong come from?
R:My parents and my religion.
I:Okay.  In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Pretty easy .  But um, you know, like I have a sister is not really, she doesn’t really go to our church anymore and she does things that we don’t believe in, you know, so it’s really pretty easy for me to see what’s right and wrong cause I just look at her life, and I’m like okay, that’s not what I’m supposed to do and so I just, you know, so it’s actually, I mean it’s not a good thing but it’s, it actually kind of is sometimes because I have that bad example, so I can see, you know.
I:Yeah.  Do you worry about her?
R:Yes.  A lot.  Yeah.
I:Does she live around here, then?
R:Yeah.  Yeah, she, um, is just, it’s hard because sometimes she ah, I, I kind of act older than her except for she’s older than me and so I’ve been worrying about her ever since we were kids and so it’s like, I kinda wish I could stop taking care of her, but I can’t really, so.
I:Yeah.  Why do you think she believes differently?
R:I think that she is just openly defiant against my Mom, I think my Mom kind of pushed her a little too hard sometimes and so she’s, went completely the other way.  I’m not saying it’s my Mom’s fault or anything, I think my Mom was doing the right thing with her because she’s always been really just experiment-ive  and always wanted to see what the wrong thing was, ever since she was a kid, she’d always do the wrong thing, so.
I:Okay.  What about the past couple years, do you think it’s gotten easier or more difficult to decide about what’s right or wrong?
R:More difficult.  Because as you get older, you think you have more freedom and so you’re like, oh, I could do that, and then you’re like wait a second, that’s not what I would do a couple years ago, or, you know that’s not really my beliefs and then you kind of stop yourself and be careful what you do.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:What was the question?
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, based on your beliefs and just kind of the gut feeling you get, you know.  I mean, I base a lot on that, like how I feel, when I’m about to make that decision, I guess.  And just think, you know, if, if my Mom was standing right next to me, would she be approving of what I’m doing or not, so.  That sort of thing.
I:Okay, so you keep talking about your beliefs and basing what you do on your beliefs, where do you think those beliefs come from, they just kind of come from nowhere and so you’re supposed to do what they say?  Or what’s the reasoning in mind for why you would follow those?
R:No, um, well cause like in my religion we have prophets, so based on what they say, what the scriptures say, what God’s revelation has given to us, um, and then what my parents think you know, right or wrong, there’s not, you know, there’s not certain definite things like should you drink herbal tea, you know, like we don’t know whether we should or not, but my parents think it’s fine, so then I do.  That kind of, so it’s just that kind of stuff, there’s the little pinpoint things that then I go with what my parents have decided on, when it’s the little things that maybe it doesn’t say in the Bible or something like that but when my parents have put a rule, you shouldn’t wear black um, black nail polish, you know, I want you to only get like, we’re only supposed to get one piercing, but you know it’s not set in stone so my parents, I don’t want you to get another piercing or a tattoo, you know, so that kind of stuff is, so I just base it off what my parents tell me.
I:Okay.  Why do you think it’s a good thing to follow what your parents say or what the church says?
R:Because I want to spend the rest of my life with them, in my life, you know I want them there, when I get married and when I have kids and stuff like that so it’s like, if I wanted to have a good relationship then I kinda wanna do what pleases them and what will make me happy.
I:Okay.  So do you think there are any actions that are always wrong?
R:Any actions that are always wrong?  Like, like what?  Like, like?  Like drugs or drink, yeah, drugs, drinking, having sex before you’re married.
I:Okay, so there are some absolute wrong things in any situation for anybody.
R:Yeah.

column588: The respondent primarily bases their decisions of right and wrong on church values and parental guidance, finds it easy to discern morality through personal beliefs and examples from their sister's life, and believes that the purpose of life is to be a good person, help others, and ultimately be a mother and wife.

column583:
I:Okay, so, so why, what makes something wrong?
R:Hurting people for no apparent reason.
I:Okay, but if there’s a good reason it’s okay?
R:If it’s gonna save more people, I think so.
I:So, what, what, what’s a good enough reason to hurt, like you saying how, the war will hurt people but it will save more people in the end, so, you think that’s, that’s obviously to you a good enough reason to hurt people, but what, what would be, what makes something a good enough reason.
R:Not a good enough reason?
I:Well, maybe you can give me an example of something that’s not a good enough reason to hurt someone, and then what would be a good enough reason?
R:Oh, well not a good enough reason would be shooting someone just so you can take the car.
I:Okay, so, and what would be, so where, how, at what point does hurting somebody become okay?
R:When you’re hurting someone so they stop hurting another person.
I:Okay, so if they’re hurting somebody else it’s okay.
R:Right, like Ward Weaver, right over there, he’s gonna die eventually, you know, and that’s okay because he hurt other people, I mean, to take someone like that away.
I:Right.  But, does somebody have to be hurting other people in order to justify hurting them?
R:I think so.
I:So that’s sort of, that would be how you would decide whether something was, whether it was okay to hurt somebody.
R:Right.
I:If they were hurting somebody else.  Okay.  Where do you think your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, what I’ve been told.
I:By who?
R:My parents.
I:Okay, so is that the main place where it comes from is your parents?
R:And other influences around, like my brothers and sisters and things.
I:Where do you think it comes from, I mean, where do you think your parents figured out what was right and wrong?
R:From their parents, I guess.
I:From their parents.
R:Yeah.
I:So, have you thought about where, where it, where the right and wrong comes from?
R:Just from what people believe.
I:From what people believe.  Just down through history.  What, so is it okay, like if your parents say one thing’s right and somebody else’s parents say it’s, or your parents tell you something’s wrong and someone else’s parents tells them it’s right, how do you decide which is the case, or is it?
R:What I really think.
I:Is it okay for you to think something’s wrong and somebody else to think it’s right?
R:Yeah.
I:That’s okay with you, that doesn’t bother you?
R:Not at all.
I:So if somebody said, it’s okay to hurt somebody even if they’re not hurting anyone else, would you agree or disagree?
R:Just as long as they’re not doing it to anyone I know.  Or me.  If I don’t see it, then, out of sight out of mind.
I:Okay.  So, how do you decide what’s good and bad in life?
R:Um  it’s just kind of a feeling you get, you know, you can tell if it’s right or wrong.
I:Okay.  Can you give me any examples of a time where you’ve had to decide whether something was right or wrong and how you figured it out?
R:Um, kinda, like  I took money from my Mom once.  And you know, I knew it was wrong, but I did it anyway cause I wanted to buy a firecracker for my friend, so.
I:Why was that wrong?
R:Because it’s taking things from my Mom for no better good except for my own personal enjoyment.
I:Okay, so, someone’s own personal enjoyment isn’t a good enough reason to do something.
R:I don’t think so.
I:And so you knew it, you could just tell it was wrong, based on how you felt?
R:Yeah.
I:And, let’s see here.  But what made those things wrong?  Do you think they were wrong?
R:I think that burning down the garbage can was.
I:Okay.
R:And I think that the selling of the mushrooms could have potentially been wrong, but the only wrong it’s considered wrong is because it’s against the law to buy what somebody said.  If it would have possibly harmed the kid, his name is Martin, then it would have been wrong.
I:But because it didn’t harm the kid, do you think it was wrong?
R:I think it could have potentially been wrong, but it ended up not harming him, so.
I:So, something would be wrong, in that, that sounds like the consequences have something to do with whether something’s wrong or not?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.  So, if it was, if it wasn’t against the law and it wouldn’t have hurt him, it wouldn’t have been wrong.
R:I don’t think so.
I:Okay, what if something, so if something’s against the law, does that make it wrong?
R:Well, it matters on what it is, like murder, I think that’s wrong, unless the motive is something like, you know, hurting other innocent people.  But, um…
I:But what do you think, does the law always make some, if it’s against the law does that always make it wrong?
R:In my opinion, no, no.
I:No.  So, there’s something outside the law that determines whether it’s right or wrong.
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.  Just being against the law is that enough to make something right or wrong?
R:Not in my opinion.

column586:
I:--what is your sense of right and wrong?
R:well…let’s see. I don’t really have an overall view, I usually make the decisions one at a time by situation by situation, I wouldn’t say I have a set ideology or—
I:--okay, what guides you. Faced by a particular question of what should I do in this situation?
R:um, let’s see, it’d be better if we could set up a scenario.
I:back to this topic of morality that we were talking about earlier. So can I ask the question, what do you think makes something right or wrong or do you not really even think like that?
R:um, it’s up to the person, it’s up to the person—
I:--totally? Like you could lean over and bop me on the nose and that would be okay because it was fine with you?
R:well it wouldn’t be fine with you so you could just bop me right back. So there’s not, in that seems it seems like there’s not a right, it’s just whatever produces the least amount of harm.
I:alright, does law make something right or wrong?
R:to me, absolutely not.
I:why?
R:I don’t think it’s up to anyone else to decide.
I:what about consequences, do consequences, sort of the fallout of an action, make it right or wrong?
R:no, it just makes it the fallout of what you did, no, I don’t think so.
I:what about the way something makes you feel, does that make it right or wrong?
R:I guess to that individual, yeah, I guess. If you really want to call that right, but is feeling good right? You know? I mean—

I don’t think it’s up to anyone else to decide. no, it just makes it the fallout of what you did, no, I don’t think so. I guess to that individual, yeah, I guess. If you really want to call that right, but is feeling good right? You know? I mean—
column588: The respondent believes that moral decisions are subjective and situational, guided by personal feelings and social influences, such as their mother's opinions, rather than universal truths or laws, and they express a general skepticism about the concept of right and wrong, suggesting that actions are often judged based on their consequences and personal perspectives.
column589:
I:How would you say you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um, like…  I guess what it is is I just try to maintain good relationships with the people I know.  And I just, I don’t know, I wouldn’t say like I’m altruistic, like I do good things just to do good things, because I feel obviously you wanna like benefit yourself, but I don’t really have like, I don’t know how I like derive my morals, ‘cause I don’t really believe in like a universal right or wrong, it’s just different for every person.
I:Ok.  Now in general would you say it’s easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Well I mean, there’s… it just depends.  There’s sometimes when you make a decision as to what you think is right and it ends up hurting yourself or someone else and you just learn from experience really.  You just judge by the decisions you’ve made in the past and where they got you.
I:And would you say deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or harder over the past couple of years?
R:I guess easier because you just have more life experience.
I:Have your views changed in the past two years would you say?
R:I mean, yeah probably, I think I was probably… especially when I was around eighteen or nineteen, I guess I was a lot more self-centered than I am now.  I guess it took a really traumatic event to humble me, kind of.  And I mean, realize it’s not all about me, like… I used to be kind of self-centered, looking out for number one kind of guy.  I wouldn’t really say I’m like that as much anymore.
I:And you kind of attribute that to your father passing away?
R:Yeah.
I:Mmhmm.  And how do you usually decide what, I mean, how do you decide what to do?
R:Man, you’re just making me feel ignorant because I don’t really think about too much.
I:Oh, no, no, no, it’s fine, I’m not trying to make you feel ignorant.
R:No, no, no, I’m not saying, no, it’s just like realizing this about myself, like now, I’m like am I just like wandering around with my life or what?  ‘Cause it’s just hard to think of specific events because it’s just so instinctual, I guess.
I:Sure, ok.  That’s fair enough.
R:I usually work better off examples, and I can’t think of one myself.
I:Right, yeah, so what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I couldn’t tell you, man, I don’t claim to know, I don’t think, probably there’s not even a real answer to that.
I:No just for you, I’m not saying sort of more generally but I mean, how do you… I mean you already touched on this a little bit, saying you sort of learn by experiencing what happens.
R:Yeah.  I think, I don’t know.  ‘Cause I just, I don’t know, the words right and wrong, there’s, to me like, ok say if I just got up and slapped you in the face or something.  Yeah that’s wrong but like really in the big scheme of things, a thousand years from now, is it really gonna matter that I did that?  You know?  Like that kind of thing.  It seems like there’s immediate, kind of like… sort of like trivial right and wrong and I don’t believe in like, in general.
I:I got you.  So, I mean, for you do you think it’s like rules or laws or consequences that make something wrong or how it feels?
R:Yeah, again, it’s just whatever violates like the social contract is wrong, whatever you’ll get punishment for and negative actions for is wrong, and whatever you get rewards for is good.  So that’s, yeah.  ‘Cause you know there’s authority that keeps you in check, so.
I:Like authority, you mean like legal authority?
R:Yeah, yeah.  Or if you… not even that, if you just treat people like shit then eventually that’s how… it’ll come around to you because you’re just a negative person, so.

And I just, I don’t know, I wouldn’t say like I’m altruistic, like I do good things just to do good things, because I feel obviously you wanna like benefit yourself, but I don’t really have like, I don’t know how I like derive my morals, ‘cause I don’t really believe in like a universal right or wrong, it’s just different for every person. column591: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on the advice of parents or teachers, valuing their life experience, while also reflecting on past experiences to determine right from wrong, and acknowledges a shift from self-centeredness after a traumatic event, indicating a more responsible and frugal approach to handling money and life choices.

column589:
I:And, how do you normal decide what's good or bad?
R:It's all about feelings I guess. When I know it's wrong, then I don't do it. I know, I just get this gut feeling, and what I was brought up on, and how my parents raised me.
I:And, in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Easy.
I:And, has it gotten easier or harder in the last few years?
R:Um, I guess a little harder, because in college, you have a lot of peer pressure to do some stuff. But, if you know who you are, and you stay strong to it, to your beliefs, I guess.
I:And, so what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don't know.
I:Like, when you get the gut feeling, what do you think it's about?
R:It's just like, I don't know how to explain it. You just kind of know you're not supposed to do it, like you could get in trouble. It's not right for you to do.
I:And, so, is one of those things that you're thinking about then whether or not you're going to get in trouble?
R:Well, yeah, consequences is one of them, yeah.
I:And, so what kind of consequences make it wrong?
R:It doesn't matter what kind. If it's wrong, it's wrong, like if it has a consequence. I don't know.
I:Okay, so from where do you acquire your moral views?
R:My parents.
