Um, I guess a little harder, because in college, you have a lot of peer pressure to do some stuff. But, if you know who you are, and you stay strong to it, to your beliefs, I guess.  I don't know. It's just like, I don't know how to explain it. You just kind of know you're not supposed to do it, like you could get in trouble. It's not right for you to do. Well, yeah, consequences is one of them, yeah. It doesn't matter what kind. If it's wrong, it's wrong, like if it has a consequence. I don't know.  My parents.
column591: The respondent would give the majority of an inheritance to their parents, relies on gut feelings and parental upbringing to discern right from wrong, acknowledges peer pressure in college, admits to lying to their mother about a friend's whereabouts, believes in moral responsibility to help others, looks up to their strong mother and sisters, and would prioritize personal happiness in decision-making over other influences.

column589:
I:And um, how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Well, I like to go by the motto, living on experience.  So that’s how I know what to do, what not to do, just off experience, whether it’s my experience or my friends’ experience.  Take it like that.
I:So what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong then?
R:Um, I mean that’s up to each person, yeah.  That’s, yeah.
I:Who do you think has had the biggest influence on your decision making, on things like that?
R:My mother.
column590: Well, I like to go by the motto, living on experience.  So that’s how I know what to do, what not to do, just off experience, whether it’s my experience or my friends’ experience.  Take it like that.  Um, I mean that’s up to each person, yeah.  That’s, yeah.  My mother.
column591: The respondent prioritizes ensuring the well-being of a deceased relative's children, relies on personal and friends' experiences to determine right from wrong, feels influenced by their mother in decision-making, believes in a moral obligation to help others, particularly the homeless, and prefers following the advice of respected adults when uncertain about ethical dilemmas.

column583:
I:Like what, what things do you think are just morally wrong or right?
R:Uh, for instance if someone would get in to a fight, it will be wrong to fight someone younger than you and smaller cause you know you’re gonna win, but then for one person it may be right cause they the same size, they have the same fighting skills, so it will be right for them to fight and not right for them other two to fight.
I:So you have sort of rules that you live by?
R:Yeah.
I:You could kick somebody’s butt who’s older than you or your same size but you never beat up somebody younger than you.
R:Yeah.
I:Um, so where do you think that your views of right and wrong come from?
R:Mainly my parents.
I:Like what do they do?
R:They tell me what was right and what was wrong, if somebody messes with you, you don’t back down from them, but try to walk away from it.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Mainly what you believe in.
I:How do you decide or know what’s good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Me, I decide for how I feel about it, I wouldn’t want somebody to do that to me, so I’m gonna leave it alone.
I:So can you give me an example, like when you decided something was good or bad?
R:I can’t think of one right now.

Yeah. Yeah. Uh-huh (no) Cause when I was going to AV, I see weird fights, I see juniors and seniors fighting freshmen.  It was way uh- Cause they want to keep their power and everything, they don’t, cause when the freshmen came in, we was doubting them and everything, (00:28:37)  we let  won’t nobody, cause the seniors, we won’t let them cut in front of us, yeah, so we was really standing up to them and they didn’t like that. Mainly my parents. They tell me what was right and what was wrong, if somebody messes with you, you don’t back down from them, but try to walk away from it. Mainly what you believe in. Me, I decide for how I feel about it, I wouldn’t want somebody to do that to me, so I’m gonna leave it alone. I can’t think of one right now.
column585: The respondent's decision-making process is influenced primarily by their parents' guidance on right and wrong, and they rely on their feelings about a situation to determine morality, while also acknowledging that many peers disregard moral considerations in favor of personal desires.

column583:
I:Wow.  So for you, what is it that makes something right or wrong? Where does right and wrong come from?
R:I just, it comes from the bible, yeah.
I:So, and the Bible comes from God or is it?
R:Yeah, I guess it’s inspired by God.
I:Um, okay.  Um, so for yourself are you saying what, you’re trying to learn right and wrong, you would read the Bible?  You would--
R:Yeah.
I:Okay.  Um, how, do you find the Bible to be pretty clear in teaching you about what’s right and wrong, and good and bad?
R:Yeah, sometimes you have to study into it and you know like a word stuff.
I:Uh-huh.  Are there any things that you’re interested in understanding about right and wrong that you think that you don’t know what the Bible teaches, or you think it’s not clear?
R:Ah, not really right now.
column584: I just, it comes from the bible, yeah. Yeah, I guess it’s inspired by God. Yeah. Yeah, sometimes you have to study into it and you know like a word stuff. Ah, not really right now.
column585: The respondent often grapples with moral dilemmas, such as witnessing cheating during a test and choosing to confront peers instead of reporting them, while also expressing that their sense of right and wrong is heavily influenced by their Christian beliefs and the teachings of the Bible.

column583:
I:What is it that you think, this is a little philosophical, what is it that you think makes things right or wrong?  How do we know what’s right and wrong?
R:Well there are, I guess some people go by scientific, that is where they dissect things, they take a look at what’s right, what’s wrong with it, and then there are others where it’s trial and error, really.
I:Um, do you, so a lot of people think it’s wrong to kill somebody without a good reason, do you agree with that?
R:I think it’s not good to kill someone at all.
I:But why is that?
R:Because you’re just taking away someone’s life, someone’s, whatever they want to do, freedom, basically.
I:So what?
R:It’s, some, something that shouldn’t be taken away because unless for like, I don’t know, they killed someone else and something.
I:Why shouldn’t it be taken away?  Why does their life matter?
R:Because they’re one individual of a society.
I:But some people would say, some people have said, well one individual, who cares, big deal, we won’t miss them.
R:Other people that care about that person will miss them.
I:So it could hurt some other people.
R:Yeah, other people.
I:Um, what if the person was an orphan, had no other relatives or nobody knew them, would it be wrong to kill them?
R:Yeah, because it would just be taking away someone’s life, someone’s freedom, someone’s choices, for nothing.  You don’t gain anything from it.
I:What if you got, what if you could steal $2,000 in their wallet?
R:I don’t think money is really a virtue about things, if, if you really need the money, somehow it will be the, you’ll get it, I mean, who, who—
I:So what you’re saying is there’s something wrong with taking someone’s life, intrinsically, like in and of itself wrong?
R:Uh-huh (yes).
I:And, and what is that, that’s, why is it in and of itself?  I mean there have been dictators that have killed millions of people and they didn’t think anything was wrong with that.
R:Well they don’t have the views, they just think every—cause they’re the dictator that they can set the laws up how they want it.  And that they’re not physically killing them, they’re sending out their troops or whatever.
I:But they’re responsible.
R:Yeah, they’re responsible.
I:So then you would say the dictator is morally wrong?
R:Mm-mm (yes).
I:Okay.  What about um, what about if you came across a wallet on the sidewalk and picked it up and there was a lot of money in it and nobody saw you get it, do you think that it would be wrong to keep it instead of returning it to the owner?
R:Yeah.
I:Or just keep it?
R:I, it goes both ways, I mean, like I’d want the money, I’d want to keep it, but then I’d feel guilty because someone might really need that money, and—
I:What if you feel, but is it, should, is it mor—is it, is it, is it the right thing in and of itself to return it, regardless of who needed it, or what if, maybe you needed it more than they do?
R:It would still be wrong because you’re taking something from someone, even though they left it where it could have been taken.
I:And what makes it wrong?
R:That someone doesn’t know that it’s lost, or they don’t know where it is and you’re just sort of picking it off of them and keeping it.
I:Now what if I said well it was their stupid fault for losing it.
R:It, it would still, it would still mean, like I, at least I would, I’d have the guilt of taking someone’s money.
I:You would feel bad.
R:Yeah.
I:Your conscience would bother you.
R:Mm-mm (yes).
I:Because you think there’s something wrong about stealing, or not being honest.
R:Whatever it is, yeah.
I:Yeah.  Um, where do you think your own views about what is right and what is wrong have come from, how is your conscience been formed?
R:It’s, I don’t know really where it’s been formed from.
I:Do you have any idea where you’ve gotten your ideas?
R:Ah, I guess from watching my parents deal with things.  Thinking about it and I guess analyzing it, what’s right and wrong and in and of itself.
column584: Well there are, I guess some people go by scientific, that is where they dissect things, they take a look at what’s right, what’s wrong with it, and then there are others where it’s trial and error, really. I think it’s not good to kill someone at all. Because you’re just taking away someone’s life, someone’s, whatever they want to do, freedom, basically. It’s, some, something that shouldn’t be taken away because unless for like, I don’t know, they killed someone else and something. Because they’re one individual of a society. Other people that care about that person will miss them. Yeah, other people. Yeah, because it would just be taking away someone’s life, someone’s freedom, someone’s choices, for nothing.  You don’t gain anything from it. I don’t think money is really a virtue about things, if, if you really need the money, somehow it will be the, you’ll get it, I mean, who, who— Uh-huh (yes). Well they don’t have the views, they just think every—cause they’re the dictator that they can set the laws up how they want it.  And that they’re not physically killing them, they’re sending out their troops or whatever. Yeah, they’re responsible. Mm-mm (yes). Yeah. I, it goes both ways, I mean, like I’d want the money, I’d want to keep it, but then I’d feel guilty because someone might really need that money, and— It would still be wrong because you’re taking something from someone, even though they left it where it could have been taken. That someone doesn’t know that it’s lost, or they don’t know where it is and you’re just sort of picking it off of them and keeping it. It, it would still, it would still mean, like I, at least I would, I’d have the guilt of taking someone’s money. Yeah. Mm-mm (yes). Whatever it is, yeah. It’s, I don’t know really where it’s been formed from. Ah, I guess from watching my parents deal with things.  Thinking about it and I guess analyzing it, what’s right and wrong and in and of itself.
column585: The respondent believes that moral decisions are largely individual choices shaped by personal analysis and parental influence, and while they acknowledge the existence of peer pressure regarding substance use, they maintain a strong sense of guilt associated with dishonesty and taking advantage of others, regardless of the circumstances.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I guess almost my common sense, on how I was raised with knowing what was good and what was bad in my life.  My parents, they were really good at, just raised proper with manners and everything like that and if I know something’s bad and it’s going to get to me in trouble, I’m not going to do it.  It’s just not worth it to me at this point in my life.  Maybe when I was younger, and I was a little less careful, but I’m 20, I’m not a teenager anymore, I’m an adult, I could in a lot of trouble for whatever these actions might do.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s easy.  There’s no, it’s not a very fine line for me.  So what I think, you know, I know what’s right and wrong.  If someone wants to do something destructive, or something like that to someone else, I know it’s not a good idea.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:It’s probably easier,  I’m a little more mature.  And I know what is right and what is wrong and I’ll continue to increase my knowledge as I get older.  Because I think when you’re younger, you’re a little bit more naïve.  And you don’t think that there might not be the same repercussions.
I:Have your views changed in the past 2 years?
R:Not really.  I mean, like I’ve just gotten better input on what I should be doing and not doing.
I:Right. What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:What makes it?  Ahh…As I was talking before, if it’s going to have any negative repercussions, if it’s going to harm anyone.  Are you doing this just because you want to, or do you need to?  It’s a tough decision, I guess, and to explain how you’d say what’s right or wrong, I guess, just knowing.  I guess, instinct or what you were raised with, with what morals, what you were raised with and how you were raised.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:My parents.
I:Any place else?
R:Grandparents.  Maybe society as well.  What people view right and wrong as well.  What would other people may view.  I’ve taken my own views, it’s primarily my parents though.  Parents, family.

And you don’t think that there might not be the same repercussions. Not really.  I mean, like I’ve just gotten better input on what I should be doing and not doing.  What makes it?  Ahh…As I was talking before, if it’s going to have any negative repercussions, if it’s going to harm anyone.  Are you doing this just because you want to, or do you need to?  It’s a tough decision, I guess, and to explain how you’d say what’s right or wrong, I guess, just knowing.  I guess, instinct or what you were raised with, with what morals, what you were raised with and how you were raised.  My parents. Grandparents.  Maybe society as well.  What people view right and wrong as well.  What would other people may view.  I’ve taken my own views, it’s primarily my parents though.  Parents, family.
column591: The respondent plans to invest a $100,000 inheritance for future needs, emphasizing the importance of common sense and parental guidance in distinguishing right from wrong, while also acknowledging the influence of personal experiences and societal views on their moral decisions.

column583:
I:He, he.  Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:How my own view?  To do something?
I:Yes... if... if you believe, as you said, that to kill someone is wrong, where do your thoughts about what is right and what is wrong come from?
R:Well, the thoughts depend on the person, right?
I:Uh-huh.
R:If the person wants or doesn't want to attack.  That depends on how he or she was brought up as a child, right?  If he or she is aggressive.
I:Yes, but you, when you think about something...
R:When I am in a situation... if I fight or don't fight?
I:No, when you have thoughts about things that are wrong.  You...
R:Yes.
I:You believe that to kill is wrong?  Right?  Yes or no?
R:Yes.
I:Okay, but, where did that thought come from?  From your parents? Your ideas of what is wrong or right.  From your church?  From where?
R:Those thoughts come from the home, right?
I:From the home?  Okay.
R:From the home.  Because it depends on how you were brought up.  "Not that." "That is wrong." "It's right."  Parents themselves instill this on kids.
I:Yes, and you and your parents...?
R:My mother brought me up well.  I mean, when sometimes... I told my mom about the hooky party and she told me:  "No, not that.  Don't even think about going".  I told my father and: "NO, NOT THAT"  My father because that is his way of talking, loud, right?
I:Yes, yes.
R:Then they advise me on the right way.  "There are two ways", they tell me, "there is a narrow one and a wide one".  People choose to enter the narrow one, and many go on the wide one.  Because it's wide and all those who to discotheques and liquor go there.  There you go faster because it is easier. But on the narrow way...
I:Uh-huh.
R:... there are few people that go there or are used to going there... because it is the people who try hard, right? that push ahead.  Whereas here, no, here they prefer drugs and they see this way as easier than the other one.
I:The other is more difficult.
R:Yes.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Eh...  The way that... the thing I'm doing, right?  I see it is right or wrong...
I:Uh-huh.
R:That it will lead me to something good, or it will lead me to something bad.  What are the consequences that can result from doing what isn't right.
I:Ah... And in general... consequences for you, consequences for someone else?  Why is something wrong?
R:For example, to fight here.  The consequences will take me to prison.
I:Uh-huh.
R:I'm going to lose classes.  Maybe I stay in prison as they say that now they consider minors as of age.  At 18 you can go to jail.  Then the consequences will be that I will not be able to study any more.  I will stay there, in jail.  And, what will my future be?  Nothing, I have no future.
I:Then, when you are thinking on whether something is wrong or right, do you think about the consequences?
R:Yes, on the consequences that may come.
I:And do you think about other things as well, or only on the consequences?
R:And... what is left, right?  I stay behind and don't move forward anymore.
I:Uh-huh.  Hmm...  How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right or wrong in life?
R:Eh...
I:In addition to the consequences and others?
R:How do I decide, right?  I decide... by... I look at the examples that people give me and then I decide, right?  People were like this, and they overcame.  Then I have to decide to follow the examples they give me.
column584: How my own view?  To do something? Well, the thoughts depend on the person, right? If the person wants or doesn't want to attack.  That depends on how he or she was brought up as a child, right?  If he or she is aggressive. When I am in a situation... if I fight or don't fight? Yes. Yes. Those thoughts come from the home, right? From the home.  Because it depends on how you were brought up.  "Not that." "That is wrong." "It's right."  Parents themselves instill this on kids. My mother brought me up well.  I mean, when sometimes... I told my mom about the hooky party and she told me:  "No, not that.  Don't even think about going".  I told my father and: "NO, NOT THAT"  My father because that is his way of talking, loud, right? Then they advise me on the right way.  "There are two ways", they tell me, "there is a narrow one and a wide one".  People choose to enter the narrow one, and many go on the wide one.  Because it's wide and all those who to discotheques and liquor go there.  There you go faster because it is easier. But on the narrow way... ... there are few people that go there or are used to going there... because it is the people who try hard, right? that push ahead.  Whereas here, no, here they prefer drugs and they see this way as easier than the other one. Yes. Eh...  The way that... the thing I'm doing, right?  I see it is right or wrong... That it will lead me to something good, or it will lead me to something bad.  What are the consequences that can result from doing what isn't right. For example, to fight here.  The consequences will take me to prison. I'm going to lose classes.  Maybe I stay in prison as they say that now they consider minors as of age.  At 18 you can go to jail.  Then the consequences will be that I will not be able to study any more.  I will stay there, in jail.  And, what will my future be?  Nothing, I have no future. Yes, on the consequences that may come. And... what is left, right?  I stay behind and don't move forward anymore. Eh... How do I decide, right?  I decide... by... I look at the examples that people give me and then I decide, right?  People were like this, and they overcame.  Then I have to decide to follow the examples they give me.
column585: The respondent often feels unsure about right and wrong, particularly in academic situations, and relies on parental guidance to clarify decisions, while also reflecting on the consequences of actions and the influence of peers in social contexts, ultimately valuing the lessons instilled by their parents regarding moral choices.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide what’s good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:You got to go with your guts like because if your guts like, “Don’t do it.” You don’t do it because I’ve had times where my mother says, “Don’t do it.” I’ve done it and I got arrested so I just follow my instincts now.
I:So you feel like your instincts there are pretty good judge of what’s right or wrong?
R:Uh-huh.
I:Would you say it’s generally easy or hard for you to decide between what’s right and wrong?
R:It usually is pretty easy because usually you know what’s right and wrong. It’s just are you still going to do it or not. So I know what’s right and wrong. It’s just sometimes I do the wrong thing.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier over the past couple of years or harder, would you say?
R:It has gotten a lot easier.
I:Why would you say that?
R:Because my eyes are open more. I see the world, how it’s. So it has just made them kind of decisions easier.
I:Have your views changed over the past couple of years about what’s right and wrong?
R:No. It’s just like because there is that little gray area but to me that gray area has gone littler. There is still stuff in that gray area like if your wife is sick, would you go steal medicine for her if you can’t pay for it? Just stuff like that, I would do. It’s wrong to steal but you got to do what you got to do sometimes.
I:What do you think is it that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t know. I could not tell you, just you know what’s right and you know what’s wrong. That’s it.
I:But is it generally, would you say it’s how it made you feel or is it like rules or laws or is it the consequences of what happens?
R:It’s a little bit of all that. It’s like in your heart, you know like say you shoot somebody. You know that’s wrong but you did it. And then like, it’s just stuff like that. You know what’s right and wrong. Like people, “I didn’t know it was wrong.” “Yeah, you did.” They still did it. So now, just pay up.
I:So for you it’s sort of a combination of things.
R:Yeah.
I:It’s not maybe one particular thing. It’s not necessarily just how it makes you feel or if it’s God’s will or not or if the consequences serve…
R:Yeah, it’s all of it. It’s like…
I:And where would you say you’ve gotten your moral views from? Where did they come from?
R:From my feelings, my mom, just life experiences.

R:I think it’s not right to kill somebody cause, well for one it’s a sin, and I just, I don’t think I could.  I mean you could say oh I hate, I just want to kill her.  I don’t’ think I would actually go out and do that.  I don’t’ think so.

I was so if I don’t’ put it back you’re going to tell?  And she was like no, she told my mom, and my mom was really upset you know, and she was really sad. And I think it really hurt my mom so.  Um,

It’s like about school, about sex, anything, you know.  They know about it, you know cause like we have communication.

column585: The respondent often relies on their intuition and the guidance of their parents when making decisions about right and wrong, while also considering the consequences of their actions and the influence of friends, ultimately prioritizing communication and personal integrity over peer pressure.

column583:

R:Um, um, it’s in the way I’ve been raised you know it’s wrong to steal, it’s wrong to do certain things and, my Mom and Dad used to always say that you know what’s right and wrong if you, if you feel that it’s wrong, don’t do it, if you know what’s right, do right, if you know it’s wrong, don’t do it.  You know.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, make something right and wrong.  Um, um, well, I don’t know. Um, right and wrong.  Right and wrong.  I don’t really know.
I:Okay.
R:Um, I mean.

column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are clear and rooted in their upbringing, acknowledges the influence of a strict Christian acquaintance's views on morality, and reflects on personal experiences with wrong actions, such as viewing pornography, while emphasizing the importance of personal choice and the consequences of one's decisions.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Gut feeling, conscience.  I mean my dad used to always tell me if you know what’s right, do what’s right.
I:How do you know what’s right?
R:(sighs) I just, I mean, I just have, everyone has I think a gut feeling where it’s like you know if you’re doing something wrong.  Like true when you’re an infant it might not be, but when you’re a grown up you have a sense about you, to that point where you know, if you steal something you know that’s wrong, if you hurt someone you know that’s wrong, so, I mean that’s usually.
I:Let me object here.  Lots of people are stealing.
R:Yeah.
I:Is that wrong?
R:We actually just talked about this today in school in my ethics class.  Um, yes, in theory it’s wrong to steal, but I mean what I said was, you have stores and grocery shops with food and stuff right?  The food is going to go spoil if nobody takes it, and the clothes are probably ruined,
I:Why would you steal ruined clothes?
R:Well I mean, we were watching a video clips, and this girl has shoes, and this guy goes you know that’s wrong, right?  And the girl goes yeah, but we’re going to be walking and we don’t need things cutting our feet when we walk.  And it’s like they have a need for something, I mean it’s like yeah, it’s wrong but it’s kind of hard you know?  It’s like, you kind of feel for them, it’s to the point where yeah, it’s wrong, but it’s like they need certain things to survive.  They need food, they need water,
I:Ten shirts?
R:What?
I:Ten shirts?
R:Maybe they have a big family.
I:Three pairs of shoes?
R:Well it’s like this one guy, he walked out with a big TV, you know, it’s like that, that’s wrong.
I:Why?
R:You don’t need a TV to survive through a big hurricane, you need food, clothes.
I:Okay.
R:Yes, I’m sure.  Yes a lot of people are stealing and most of them are doing it out of necessity but I’m sure some of them are doing it to hoard stuff, but,
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Um, I don’t know, I mean.
I:For you.
R:For me?  I don’t think it’s gotten easier or harder, I think it’s just stayed the same.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Oooh, uh, uh, (pause) I don’t know how to answer that.
I:Okay.  Does something being against the law make it wrong or not necessarily?
R:Um, yeah, I mean.
I:Like you have school rules I’m assuming.
R:Yeah.
I:If you break a school rule, have you done wrong or have you just break a school rule?  Are they arbitrary?  Do you just have to put up with them?
R:The rules?  No, you break rules you can get in deep, we have things called reprimands, kind of like demerits and if you get 5 of them, then you have to pay $5.  But uh,
I:Is it wrong to break school rules or is it just you’ll pay the price if you do?
R:I think most people at my school would say if you break a school rule then it’s wrong, oh well.  I guess.
I:Okay.
R:Some of these questions are kind of hard to answer.
I:Alright.  Is what God says, does that make something right or wrong?
R:Um, yeah, I mean, yeah.
I:What if God says one thing but the law, or the norm, sort of the way people act in a place is another thing?
R:Well as far as how other people act, it’s you know, that’s how they’re acting, just cause that’s how their acting it doesn’t make it right.  As far as the law of the land, it says that we’re supposed to follow the law, the bible says that we’re supposed to follow the law of Caesar, but you don’t have to follow that, but you also have to follow the law of God, so.
I:What if they contradict each other?
R:Well I don’t know, so.

column588: The respondent expresses a strong inclination towards altruism, stating they would donate half of an inheritance to charity, particularly for orphans and disaster relief, influenced by a sense of moral obligation and the belief that helping others is the right thing to do, while also acknowledging the importance of personal relationships and a desire to improve their own spiritual life.
column589:
I:Okay.  Now, how do you normally decide what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t know.  My dad used to always, I guess the best way to describe it, my dad used to always say, ‘Quinn* if you know what’s right, do right,’ because I feel like most people, you know, people have a general conception of what is right and wrong.  You know that if you’re hurting someone, that’s bad.  And if you’re, if it’s, if you’re physically or, you know, emotionally hurting someone that’s usually a bad thing.  Like, that’s usually how I do it.  It’s like people, in my opinion, I think that they have a basic knowledge of what is right and wrong.
I:So is it generally easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s like, if I know I’m doing something illegal, or against the law, or wrong, I know.  And if I do it, it’s because I know I’m doing it.
I:Over the past couple years, has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder?
R:It’s been a little bit more clear for me.
I:What’s right and wrong?
R:Yeah, it’s been like, like I’ve always known what’s right and wrong but now it’s more or less like, I know this is right, I know this is wrong and I usually stay away from doing the wrong thing because it’s like that’s not beneficial to me.  Like I used to steal a lot, and, for instance I got caught stealing and so now I don’t steal anymore because it’s like although, like, my opinions on stealing and stuff may be different, I’m not going to do it anymore because I can’t afford tickets and it’s bad for me.  So it’s like I know, it’s kind of like more or less like I don’t know.
I:Sure.  Have your views changed in the past couple of years, like of what’s right and wrong, or pretty much stayed the same?
R:Yes and no.  I’m, I feel like on some things like, I used to think that, you know, like you shouldn’t have sex until you’re married.  And that was wrong if you had sex before you were married.  That’s changed, like I don’t feel like you literally have to be married to do that.  Like, if you love the person, wholeheartedly 100%, then I don’t feel like that’s a bad thing.  Like just like one example.
I:Alright. What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Usually it’s based off of if it’s hurting someone I don’t need to be doing it.  So, an instance like drugs, that’s been hurting my mom, that’s my relationships with my friends, so I’m not going to do that anymore.  Same with drinking.  That was hurting me, like it was bad.  I went on a year long alcoholic streak where I was drinking heavily every night.  It’s like, I don’t need that, I just need to be able to be clear in my head so I can know what I’m doing.
I:Do you feel it’s like the consequences or something else?
R:I don’t know.  There’s a, like I said, usually like inside I can feel whether or not this is good or bad, and like when I was drinking and doing drugs, like I knew inside that I shouldn’t be doing this.
I:So it’s not just consequences.
R:Right.  Like consequences, I mean, I, people have told me I have a really high tolerance for pain, whether it be physical pain, like emotional pain, or whatever like I can handle it, so I don’t really know if it would be like consequences because like I said, I can, like tickets and stuff like that, it’s kind of like, ‘it’s money, I’ll get it, it’s whatever.’  So it’s more or less a feeling and sense of this isn’t good and I shouldn’t be doing it.
I:In your view where do those feelings come from?
R:Most of it’s from, I would feel like my upbringing.  Like what my dad always told me as a kid, ‘if you know what’s right do right.’ If you know what’s wrong, you know. So just do it. Others might be, I guess they could be tied in religiously that like I feel like what I’m doing isn’t good for me, like, more or less like spiritually, I guess you could say.  I guess it’s a little bit of both.
I:And where do you think you acquired your moral views from, I mean as they were changing?
R:Like I said when I was younger I got my moral views from my parents. Whenever I went through that whole like anti-establishment thing that was more or less a, like a searching out of what I felt was, I’m still like searching for what I believe and stuff like that, but at that point I was, you know, it’s just, the last 2 of those were more or less just myself, you know, wondering and searching for what I thought was right and wrong.  I guess they were more like self-taught about what, self morals.

column591: The respondent expresses a desire to use a hypothetical inheritance for education to relieve their parents' financial burden, reflects on their moral decision-making influenced by their father's teachings and personal experiences, acknowledges the importance of compassion towards others, and believes that moral choices should consider the well-being of oneself and others, while also recognizing the complexity of morality and the influence of upbringing and religion.

column583:
R:Yeah.
I:Um, but how would you convince somebody if they didn’t think that it was wrong?  What would you say?
R:(pause) If somebody believed lying, it didn’t matter, I would kind of reverse it back to them, like if people lied to you what would you do? Maybe.
I:Yeah.  Yeah.  Yeah, um, and so, where do your own views of right and wrong come from? I mean you have views that some things are right and some things are wrong and everyone should know that
R:Yeah.

If they want to know what’s right or wrong um, they should kind of go to the family traditions or go to their church or whatever and learn it.  Or is there something else that makes something right?
R:Conscience.
I:Conscience?  Okay.  So you know it, people know it.  It’s kind of individuals know what’s right and wrong, they’re kind of born that way?
R:Yeah.  Kind of innate.
I:Okay.  So, yeah.  So it’s innate.  So and um, let’s see then, just to follow up then, if you have to decide what’s good and bad or right and wrong in life, then you look to your family and you look to your religion, and perhaps there’s a conscience as well?
R:Yeah.

column585: The respondent makes decisions based on careful thought, considers the opinions of family and friends, and believes in absolute moral truths grounded in family, religion, and conscience, while feeling guilty when they act against these values, such as lying or being involved in behaviors like drinking or drug use, which they avoid due to their desire to live healthily and their parents' guidance.

column583:
I:Okay, where do you think your own views of right or wrong come from?
R:Definitely my church, my family, books that I’ve read, television, things like that.
I:Okay, so what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:How it affects other people and yourself.
I:Okay, do you, tell me a little bit more about that.
R:You know, mow someone else’s gas for free, I mean, that’s gonna help someone out, that’s definitely a good thing, chop down the tree in front of your neighbor’s house because you don’t like it but maybe they have a treehouse or something, the kids are gonna be really sad you know, maybe they liked it there, just because it helps you, doesn’t help everybody else, so.
I:Okay, so if something, if something doesn’t help someone else, does that mean it’s wrong?
R:No, because you know, there’s just some stuff that are different, but if it helps someone else it’s kinda good, but if it’s like, it helps a whole group of people but it doesn’t hurt anyone, as long as it doesn’t hurt anyone, any animal, anything like that, that’s kind of what makes it right or wrong.
I:Okay, so if it doesn’t hurt anyone, then it’s, then it’s okay.
R:Doesn’t hurt anyone, and it helps, and it, yeah, yeah.

Doesn’t hurt anyone, and it helps, and it, yeah, yeah.

R:And, general knowledge, like would this hurt people, would it help people and is it morally right or wrong.
I:Okay, so do you think, is it in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong, or do you sometimes have a hard time deciding what’s right or wrong?
R:It’s easy for me.
I:Has it gotten harder or easier in the last couple of years for you to distinguish between what’s right and what’s wrong?
R:Um, probably, they’re probably, it’s just more, it’s more different weight, where I have to decide what’s right and wrong.  Like in the past, it was you know, is it right to skip out on chores, now it’s more is it right to go over to my friends house when my parents think I’m at like school uh, uh, park or something .
I:Okay.  And so, what is it that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, again it’s just like morally right, I don’t want to do anything that would hurt anybody.
I:Okay so basically just the consequences of something determines whether something is right or wrong?
R:Right.
I:Anything else that might, when you say morally, what do you mean by that?
R:Um, sometimes society might be wrong
I:Okay.
R:It’s more like, it’s hard to explain, like what is truly right, um, for instance like, I don’t believe in the death penalty
I:Okay.
R:Because morally I just think that we shouldn’t be deciding who lives and who dies.  Cause I don’t know, I just think it’s wrong, and eye for an eye kind of thing, type of deal
I:Right.
R:And that’s the other way I decide if something’s right or wrong.  And um, is what I’m doing going to like, if it’s doing something because of something, is it, if it’s sort of, if it’s something against something else then it’s like, the punishment fitting the crime sort of deal, but if it’s with the situation, is what I’m doing going to be okay with what just happened.
I:Okay and is there any particular standard of right or wrong that you follow or is it just each situation you kind of just figure out what’s right and wrong?
R:Each situation is different.
I:Okay. Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Um, now, I wouldn’t say that something is completely wrong, there can always be an alternative to something.  That would, I mean, like killing for instance, although I don’t believe in the death penalty, I think if someone is an immediate threat to a, like if someone is in jail and you don’t have them or anything and somewhere where they are an immediate threat to a lot of people, you might tell them, that I would render them unconscious, and take them
I:Right.
R:But I can see why someone would think that they had to kill them,
I:Emergency stand off or something like that?
R:Right, I’m thinking that big political picture or something like that.
I:Right.
R:Like if someone had a weapon of mass destruction or something you know, and they were about to push the button,
I:Right.
R:Shoot them.
I:Right.
R:I couldn’t shoot them, but someone else could shoot them.
I:Right, so in other words, killing someone is not always wrong, cause there are circumstances where it could be justified.
R:Well the other thing is that you shouldn’t murder a person, but you maybe, murder is different from killing.
I:Okay.
R:Like for instance the ten commandments the actual translation is thou shall not murder, not thou shall not kill.
I:Right.  Okay.
R:So.
I:And so, sort of a difference of intent and reason behind it.
R:Right.
I:Okay, and um, from where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Um, some from church, some from my family.  Um situations that I’ve seen, and things like that.  Like seeing my friends and what happens to them, and like seeing what’s right.

column588: The respondent plans to use an inheritance primarily for education and retirement for family, believes moral decisions are based on their consequences and societal norms, and emphasizes the importance of helping others while expressing frustration over parental restrictions on driving, indicating a strong influence from family and a desire for independence.
column589:
I:And how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I look at if it’s going to hurt someone, then obviously that’s bad.  And I look at, basically I rely on my own morals and I look at the situation and every individual situation and I try to figure out, you know, what, what is good, what is bad, and then beyond that because something that is bad, this is going to sound really twisted, but something that is bad can still be better for society, if you would, like you know killing a mass-murdered.  I don’t agree that we, that there should be capital punishment, but then I see it as a societal necessity that you know, so I kind of look at it on two different levels, like morally is it right or wrong and then for general for like most amount of people, does it, is it good for them or bad for them, so.
I:In general, do you think that it is easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:If presented with all the information, I think it’s pretty easy for me to look through.  In general I’ll discuss it with someone who I think knows a lot about what’s going on and that’s anything from drama with friends to how I'm going to vote on a measure.  I discuss with my dad a lot about the recent measures that we voted on here in Oregon.  I think it’s pretty easy if you’re presented with all the information.  I wish more people would take the time to stop and look at all the different aspects of something before they made that initial, this is what we’ll do!
I:Do you think that as you’ve gotten older that it’s become easier or harder for you to make those types of decisions?
R:I think it’s become harder, but I think my decisions have been better.  So you know, as a kid you can make the decision real quick, this is good, this is bad.  But then, you know, I think the little bit more difficulty for looking at something from different angles gives me a better perspective and a better decision-making process.
I:What do you think it is that makes something either right or wrong, like what’s the actual?
R:I think mostly it has to do with whether it works for the, the benefit or if it hurts, you know, people or an animal if it’s that situation or you know, whatever.  If it does, if its results are beneficial or not or I don’t know, then how do you judge whether it’s good or bad?  I don’t know, I think it can change from person to person, you know?  Like if you go back to the capital punishment argument that will be argued for centuries, and has been argued for centuries, to the mother of that person, you know, that you’re doing harm; to that person you’re doing harm, to society you’re doing good.  Well you’re hurting on person; does that outweigh doing good for a lot of people?  It’s difficult and it will be argued for a long, long time.

column586:
I:So, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um, it, first it was because you know your parents said it was right or wrong, but then you kind of come into my own, saying no, this is what I really need to do and I don’t want to do it.  So probably just what I came up with my parents and what they instilled in me, morals and stuff.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Um, in general it’s easy to decide, it’s harder to do it.
I:Okay.   Why do you think that is?
R:Cause usually the right thing is something, is not the easiest kind of.  So it takes more guts to stand up and actually do it.
I:Okay, so do you think deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Um, it’s gotten easier cause I’ve gotten to know more myself more, just knowing what’s actually right and wrong, cause I can talk myself into things really easy.  So I think it’s gotten easier.
I:Okay, any particular reasons why?
R:Um, probably cause I know what I need to do, now it’s not like, well nobody will find out and you don’t need to do this, cause if someone does find out you’ll be in trouble.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, huh, that’s a tricky one.  Um, well the law you know is right and wrong but it’s just, it, I guess it’s just personal cause you know some people believe it’s okay to live together you know before marriage, sorry, do you live together?
I:Oh, no, it’s okay
R:But then others are completely, I don’t know I guess it’s just, what was the question again, I’m sorry I was just thinking about that.
I:No, just about what makes something right or wrong.
R:Oh, um probably just your beliefs and your religion, beliefs and stuff like that.
I:Okay.  Um, so who or what do you think has the power or authority to determine what’s right and wrong?
R:Um, I would like to say from like the Bible, cause it all comes from, it all comes from God eventually, so as long as you get your rules from the Bible then you’re good.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not really?
R:Oh, I think like lying and cheating and like murder and all that stuff is completely wrong, no matter what you do.  I mean people talk themselves out of like little lies and stuff like that, but you know, if you have to lie, you shouldn’t be doing that.

R:Um, my mom got hers from her family.  But my dad got his from anti-his family.  Cause his family is really messed up.  So whatever he saw, he kind of did the opposite of, so that’s where he got his.

column589:
I:How do you decide what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:probably based on the value system that my parents instilled in me, I mean if I have questions about things I’ll bounce it off of them. But in my gut I kind of know what they’re going to say.
I:so it’s like based on things that you were taught?
R:Yeah. Mmhmm. My mom’s very black and white with certain things so it was a tough age, she’s a tough love kind of woman.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide what is right and wrong?
R:In general, it’s easy. Sometime’s you know what’s right but you’ll get a gain somewhere else if you kind of use a grey area sort of thing.  But in my gut I know it’s right and wrong.
I:Do you think that right and wrong has gotten easier in the last two years?
R:I think it has.  Because I’m not afraid to tell people that I’m not going ot do something because I think it’s wrong, it’s made me more comfortable not to be like  ‘oh they’re not gonna like me.’ And I’m not gonna move to the cliques anymore. Things kind of like that.
I:Do you think when you were younger it was just harder to be sure?
R:Definitely harder to be sure.  Especially in college where you have these kind of clique-y sort of things and once you’re in a group and like you know you have to stay popular in that group.  It was really hard to say no to certain things then because I just didn’t want to be excommunicated.
I:so what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I guess that would depend on… hmm… I think that someone when you’re talking about if you can say it to their face or if it’s something that can be published in the front page of the newspaper and you’re not ashamed of it.
I:So it’s kind of consequences or …
R:It’s they’re open, if  it’s something you would do in or something you would you’re not ashamed that everyone else would know.  That it’s something like, I wouldn’t want this person to know,  I don’t want a lot of people to know that I’m doing this.  Then it’s something you shouldn’t be doing.
I:so where do you think you acquired your moral views?
R:More from my mom than my dad.  Probably both, but more my mom’s side.
I:And have your views about what’s right and wrong changed in the past three years.
R:Probably more strong and more things that I’m willing to step up and say.  I  think you have to keep forming your ideas and what’s right what’s wrong and once you get up to it all you have to be the one to sort of sit through, because your parents aren’t there to do all the dragging for you.
I:Do you think it’s like a growing up thing?
R:Oh definitely.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Am I gonna be able to sleep at night.  If I can’t sleep, then I know it’s not something, my conscience, sitting well in my conscience.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Generally easy.  I hurt a lot of people in the past and I just don’t want to do it anymore.
I:Would you say it’s gotten easier over the past couple years or harder to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s gotten a lot easier.
I:Why would you say it’s gotten a lot easier?
R:I’m clear-headed more now.
I:Then before?  Compared.  Would you say your moral views have changed in the past couple of years?
R:Yeah.  I would.
I:How so?
R:In a way it’s like I never really put others before me and then now I’m to the point of even if it’s stupid as letting somebody get on an elevator before me or just getting somebody in the grocery line who has one thing and I have a whole bunch, well why don’t you just, things like that, like I’ve just really became more aware of my surroundings and of other people.
I:For you, what do you think makes something right or wrong?
R:Are there negative consequences of it?  Like, if I do something bad, am I gonna absolutely regret it.  How many people am I gonna hurt, am I gonna hurt myself, so.
I:Where do you think that regret comes from, like?
R:Because I regret some of the things I did, some of the bad decisions I made.  But it does not mean I wouldn’t do them again.
I:Where do you think you’ve gotten you moral views from?
R:Experience.

column591: The respondent prioritizes paying off debts and supporting loved ones over material purchases, bases their moral decisions on conscience and the potential consequences of their actions, acknowledges the influence of their parents' advice in decision-making, and expresses a desire to emulate their mother's strength and resilience.

R:I would say it’s probably gotten easier just with experience. I can’t really think of a concrete example of that, but you know I cant think of how it would have gotten any harder.
I:ok have your moral views changed in the past two years?
R:no I don’t think so.
I:and what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I guess I would say I expect other people yeah I think that’s what I think about the most in deciding because I could just do whatever I wanted to do but usually where I stop is where it might still be good for me, but not good for somebody else.
I:so where would it be that you draw the line and hurt other people too much, to say we’ll stop here?
R:I would say it’s like when anyone assumes there’s any kind of negative effect on somebody else I would stop.
I:what would be an example of that?
R:I would go with my speeding ticket, if there were somebody else in the car, I never would be going that fast, you know I was doing it and I knew that it was wrong, but I wanted to get home quickly and when my parents found out about it they kinda made me realize that something did happen that didn’t just affect me or them and that’s when I really started to feel bad about it.
I:why did you know it was wrong at the time?
R:uh
I:what made it wrong?
R:on one hand, you know, I’m driving by signs that say the speed limit and normally that wouldn’t concern me very much because I was going 40 in a 15 I wouldn’t have thought that seriously about it, but going that fast, horrible things can happen is when… there’s probably a reason why they don’t want you to go this fast.
I:ok so what is morally wrong about violating the speed limit?
R:morally wrong I would say you could hurt other people around you and also clarifying that when I was doing this it was Sunday afternoon and there was nobody around so I just thought I’m not gonna hit anybody, it’s a highway there’s nobody crossing the street or anything, so that’s why I would say I didn’t feel morally wrong about it, I mean if I was going through a school zone when they were getting out and going 60 miles an hour when they were just getting out, I would feel morally wrong about it and not do it, but it didn’t really hit me until later when I talked to my parents about it that you know its just probably not smart but not morally the right thing to do.
I:so it’s mostly to your parents that it’s morally wrong?
R:yeah that’s what I mean, if I were to get in an accident or get killed some of my close friends, if I had a girlfriend or anything like that you know I would think about them as well, but mostly my parents, my family, my grandparents.
I:so where have you acquired your moral views? Where do they come from?
R:I’m not sure, if I had to guess it would be my parents and just growing up there were consequences if you did something wrong and I guess I just figured what was wrong and the severity of the punishment, figured out what was really wrong or what was not that bad.  I guess my parents taught me and punished me I guess.
column590: um…  I’m not sure, it’s just if I think about it you know I’ll just know.  Cause this is wrong and this is right and I’m not sure how I come to that decision, maybe just the way that I was raised or you know normally I don’t really consult anybody or anything except myself and I usually figure it out and I usually think that I’m right. pretty easy, I dunno, like I said, I can usually just tell right away, don’t have to think about it very hard, you just know. column591: The respondent expresses a desire to use an inheritance to pursue happiness by moving to the beach, relies on personal intuition shaped by upbringing to discern right from wrong, acknowledges the influence of parents on moral views, and believes in the importance of personal responsibility in helping others while recognizing the complexities of moral absolutes.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I trust my intuition. I feel like I’ve seen enough of what is good and I’ve seen enough of what I think is bad or what people I respect think is bad that I can determine enough based off of what I feel in a different situation or from talking to someone or whatever it is.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I think when it’s obvious it easy for me to decide. I think that all of times, there is no necessary right or wrong. Like when I was deciding for college for example or different jobs. I don’t think that there is necessarily a right and wrong. I could have stayed out of school and gotten to the same goal that I wanted to get to. It just would have been different from going to school. I think there are a lot of situations that I’m realizing now that I’m getting older where there isn’t necessarily a right and wrong.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Harder. I think because I’m seeing different situations in different perspectives and in a different light now then when I was younger. Also, there are more options for me now that I’m older.

column591: The respondent primarily relies on their intuition and the advice of respected individuals to navigate moral dilemmas, emphasizing the importance of long-term consequences and social responsibility, particularly in supporting their community and helping others, while also reflecting on the complexities of right and wrong as they gain new perspectives with age.

column585: The respondent believes that their understanding of right and wrong is primarily shaped by their parents and grandmother, acknowledges feeling guilty for actions like making bad grades or going where they weren't supposed to, and recognizes that while they have engaged in some wrong behaviors, they don't feel pressured by peers to partake in drugs or alcohol.
column589:
I:So how do you normally decide or know what’s good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:I guess I know what’s gonna get me in trouble and what’s not.
I:So based on the consequence?
R:Yeah.
I:And in general is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It could be easy and it could be hard, but I would say it would be more easy.
I:And has it gotten easier or harder in the last few years?
R:Harder.
I:Why?
R:Because the prices of everything is going up so high.
I:And how does that affect what’s right and wrong?
R:Oh, oh. Trip. Right and wrong, I mean - me getting older.
I:Makes it harder?
R:Makes it a lot harder?
I:Okay, can you give me an example?
R:Like - I guess when you get older you can get in more trouble with - start getting tickets and stuff like that.  I got a ticket last night.
I:For what?
R:He said loud music.
I:And - playing at your house, in your car?
R:I was turning into a parking lot and my speaker box they came undone, and when my speaker box came undone it made a big boom, and he said that it was a loud boom box ticket or something.  They just seem to stop my car like every week, same cop, for something.
I:The same cop pulls you over week?
R:Just about every week.
I:And so what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:That makes it right or wrong?
I:Um hm.
R:I mean something that makes it right or wrong.  I guess it depends on the situation and - I don’t know what makes something right or wrong.
I:Well, you mentioned earlier a consequence.  Is that kinda how you decide, or?
R:Yeah.  Because I wouldn’t do nothing to get me in serious trouble.
I:In legal trouble.
R:Yeah.
I:So what about if something doesn’t really have anything to do with the law?
R:Like?
I:I don’t know, just something that might make you have to make a decision about what is the right thing to do.
R:I’m not really into doing wrong wrong things.
I:Ok. So it basically it comes down to legal and not legal?
R:I mean I’m not really a bad person, so I don’t really do a lot of bad stuff.
I:Okay.  And from where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Just growing up.  From - from life itself I guess.
I:M8:So on your own?  Growing up, okay.  So some people believe that it’s sometimes okay to break moral rules if it works to your advantage and you can get away with it.  What do you think about that?

column591: The respondent would put an inheritance in the bank and spend it on necessities and family because it wasn't their money, and they generally determine right from wrong based on the consequences of their actions, influenced by their experiences and the rising costs of living, while also acknowledging a moral responsibility to help others when needed.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, Ana Mae.
I:Where?
R:Ana Mae.
I:Ana Mae?
R:Yeah.  Pretty much.
I:Explain that.
R:It’s like um, my friends tell me that I’m really good with analogies, and I’m pretty much since Ana Mae’s pretty much work like epics.  Like someone who has an extreme characteristic of the ideal person pretty much. And so it’s like I try to relate some of the situations sometimes and sometimes I can see what’s morally right and what’s morally wrong.   And a lot of Ana Mae’s is pretty much about that.
I:So they’re big morality plays?
R:Yeah.  So if they’re always like is this really the right thing, and that’s really like the common question that they put up there.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Opinion.  Opinion.
I:Tell me what you mean?  Like some individual’s opinion?
R:Yeah.
I:So in the case of your example of Hitler and World War II and that, was even though you say he did something wrong, it came out good for certain parts of that population, was what he did morally right or wrong?
R:Yeah.  It’s just, it depends on your opinion.  Or in that case propaganda. Propaganda, will weight the decision.  Like the Germans at that time were just doing what they thought was right.  They say Germans are evil, da, da, da, da, they thought they were doing the right thing.  They thought that by killing Jews they were helping the better good.  And so,
I:How would you view that like from your perspective in history, like this is 2003 and that was 1930’s, what’s your, how would you view that on a moral basis?
R:Like what?
I:Having access to propaganda and some sides said yeah, and some sides said no, whatever, your perspective in history in 2003 as a 15 year old, living now, having read this stuff and understanding whatever from history, how would you vie it morally, right or wrong, that Hitler offed all these people but it benefited people not just himself?
R:I think he probably could have, it was wrong how he did it.  He probably could have done it a lot less sloppy cause he really didn’t need to do that. He didn’t really need to kill the Jews but since he was a racist he just did that.  But boy he, I mean like he could have like right now, um, they take, they enlist black people, they didn’t enlist minorities first to the army.  He could have done that. He could have enlisted all the Jews into the army and had them fight for his cause.  He could have done that.  He didn’t really need to go that far.
I:Okay if you think that what makes something right or wrong is based on opinion, how do you decide what’s right and wrong in life?
R:Just put it to past experiences and see.  It’s just like, it’s just, I don’t know, it’s hard to explain that.
I:Can you give me an example of maybe sometime when you had to make a decision and then what you based that decision on?
R:Um, like um, like when I first started taking my honors classes they said you won’t be able to handle this class.  But then I figured I just said whatever repercussions happen, whatever, just go along with it.  Um, just go for it.  And then later, um, wanted to ask my girlfriend out.  And I was thinking what if she says no, what if she says yes, just take the repercussions, just go for it.  What the hell, what could you lose, you know.
I:So those are, but, so in any situation where you have to decide if something is morally right or morally wrong, good or bad, would you be the same sort of thing you would just sort of, you pool information and you said, okay I’m going for it, no matter what and I’ll stand up to the repercussions?
R:Yeah, pretty much just, cause like, it’s pretty much just like whatever I feel is right.  Because my opinion is based on my personality.  And my personality is affected by my experiences.  So I just take it as whatever I feel is right or wrong, is just based on those experiences.  So I take it for granted that it’s already, the facts have already been analyzed as some other thing.
I:Okay, so, and I’m not trying to gun you here, I’m just trying to make you articulate what you mean, so I understand it.  Are there limits to what you would and wouldn’t do morally?  Um, would you cheat, would you hurt somebody, would you lie?  Would you lie, cheat and steal?
R:Pretty much all three.
I:What would be your deciding factor in whether you would lie or cheat or steal.  Would there be some situations where you wouldn't?
R:Um, yeah there would be some situations,
I:Such as what do you think?
R:I don't know, probably, like I said, things, the opinion of right or wrong is motivated by greed, so I would probably steal if it’s like something, like if someone left a Game Cube, like I was at Target or something and only my friend was there and he was a security guard and he turned off all the cameras or something I’d probably walk out with a Game Cube or something like that.
I:So would your question be on reducing the repercussions then?
R:Yeah.
I:So if the camera was turned off and it was your friend that was there it would be less likely that you would get caught and you would have to deal with whatever?
R:Yeah.
I:Okay so in most cases do you think it’s about good and bad might happen to you or something?
R:Yeah, look at religion too, it’s like most people do good things just to avoid hell.  To avoid the repercussions.  And same thing when you raise kids.  You teach them right from wrong by spanking them when they’re bad and rewarding them when they’re good.  So it’s all about repercussions.
I:If that same Game Cube was in somebody’s hands,
R:No.
I:Would you jump them and take it from them?
R:No,
I:Why not?
R:Cause there would be greater repercussions.  They might come after me or something.
I:But it’s a little geeky guy.  And you’re kind of a big guy.  You’ve got ten pounds from the history class.
R:(laughs) Actually, now that you bring it up, I don’t know, I think it’s conditioning too, cause when you’re little your parents condition you to do stuff like, I’ve bought like a little car thing.  And it was like $18.  I gave him a $20.  The guy gave me $1 and a $20 back as change.  And then I still told him, I was like hey you gave me a twenty back, so I don’t know it’s kind of complicated. It’s like you could probably have a philosophy class on that, I don’t know.

column585: The respondent often relies on friends for advice when unsure about right and wrong, acknowledges the complexity of moral decisions influenced by personal experiences and societal norms, and believes that opinions shape morality, while also recognizing the repercussions of actions and the conditioning from parents regarding moral behavior.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Uh, recently pretty much if Everett* would do it, it’s probably wrong.  Uh, I don’t know I don’t normally go with religion, I just more go like, like who would be hurt with this?  And if anyone would be hurt, like really badly then it’s just, then that’s pretty much how it’s wrong.  If uh, if uh, a lot of times, if no one would notice, like data theft, like I don’t really think that’s wrong cause like, uh, you leave it there, it’s like, say if I wanted to steal a song from your computer, I copy the song, you still have your song, I just have it too.  So, it’s an invasion of privacy, but if you don’t know, then no one’s violated, nothing’s hurt.
I:In general, is it easy for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:M3:Uh, for the most part, just a lot of times, well, recently cause we’ve started that feud between me and Everett*, well like he started it, he started, yeah, he started like shouting out crap in class, like telling my ex-girlfriend, like, to grab him in the middle of class, and so then when I would do crap back to him, that was the only time I had trouble deciding whether it was right or wrong, cause it’s like, cause it is wrong, cause I am hurting somebody, but then, he’s asking for it, so I had trouble with that.  And it’s also like if he doesn’t learn now, because he said he gets away with everything, so it’s like if I don’t humble him now, then he’ll do it to other people, and so it’s like if I have the ability to correct it, and I don’t then all those other people that he hurts are on me.  And so that’s wrong, for not acting.  And so I just, that was like one of the hardest years because of that.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, for the most part if it hurts someone then it’s probably wrong, and if it’s, if it makes someone feel good, then it’s probably right.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, regardless of the feelings and hurting somebody?
R:Um,
I:Something could be right or wrong in and of itself?
R:In and of itself?  Uh, I don’t know I think everything’s more abstract.  Anything that’s right could be turned into something wrong.  And vice versa.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Uh, my dad, my friends, and anime probably
I:Anime?  There’s moral lessons in those cartoons?
R:Yeah, a lot of times there are, yeah.

column588: The respondent primarily decides what is right and wrong based on the potential harm to others, influenced by personal experiences and social interactions, particularly reflecting on conflicts with peers and moral lessons learned from family and anime.
column589:
I:In general, how do you normally decide what’s good or bad, or right and wrong in life?  I know you mentioned this earlier.
R:A lot of it’s, sorta, will it screw you up personally, and also will it screw up somebody else?  That’s pretty much the end of it.  Like leaving crap on your table.  You’re making someone else do more work, so it would be right for you to clean it up and it would be wrong to make someone else have to work harder.  So it’s just sort of that.
I:Why would you say – why is it wrong?  Why would that scenario be wrong, to make somebody else do more work?  Who cares?
R:That’s a good question.  I don’t know.  I think the reason I – I don’t know.
I:I’m not trying to undermine your morals, I’m just asking for the reasoning behind it.
R:Yeah, I know.  Trust me, I’ve got into fights with people where I was doing the same thing.  I’m, like, “Why is this?”  They’re, like, “Why are you attacking my deeply held personal beliefs?”  It’s like, “I’m not.  I’m just curious.”  The thing is, now you’re making me realize.  It seems like that was just something that was a belief that was just fed to me and I never questioned.  It was just sort of accepted in there.  So I don’t think I can answer that one.
I:Is it sort of a consequence side or is it more sort of it comes from a larger issue?  I don’t know.  Maybe the consequence would be if somebody does it to you, then you wouldn’t appreciate it, so you don’t do it to others.
R:Yeah.  I think it’s more of a – yeah.  I think it’s probably more of an empathy kind of thing.  You don’t want people doing a bunch of crap to you, so it’s just sorta like a pay it forward kinda thing.  If you bus your table, then if you get a job at a restaurant of something like that, then those people will – other people will bus their tables.
I:Would you say that, in general, it’s easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Generally, it’s pretty easy for me.
I:Has that sort of, making those kinds of decisions, gotten easier for you?  It’s easier to make that decision – over the last couple of years, easier to make that distinction.
R:Yeah.  A couple of years ago, it was pretty bad.  I would think I was morally justified or whatever.  Looking back at it, I’m, like, “I regret that.  I was douche bag.”  Now, I find that it’s fairly easy to do it.
I:So what do you think ultimately it is that makes something right or wrong?  This is sorta about lying or about busing the table.
R:I’d say it’s probably more just the culture that decides what’s right or wrong.  Because, I mean, if you compare different cultures, then that decides what’s right or wrong.  What’s it called?  Damn  it.  I usually have so many examples for this.  Now, I’m a blank.  I’ve just been taking several anthropology classes.  Oh, there’s this one tribe in Africa.  They’re actually two tribes and they war with each other back and forth.  And the women don’t fight at all.  However, when someone, like, as a young girl, whenever someone would get killed, someone close to them, like a brother or father, then they would remove one of her fingers.  That was to teach her to appreciate the deaths of the men.  There, it was kinda shameful if you don’t remove the fingers.  It’s, like, “She’s not going to grow up to be the right type of person.”  If you’re a mother who didn’t remove their daughters’ fingers, then you were a horrible mother and you were raising someone who would be a detriment to society.  Then, of course, to our society, that’s, like, “Oh, my God.  How are you going to do this?  How are you going to remove fingers?”
I:So ultimately you believe that it is sorta culturally driven?
R:Yeah.
I:Culturally relative to what’s defined as right or wrong?
R:Right.
I:Where do you think that your view on moral issues comes from?
R:Probably a combination of my dad and literature, but probably mostly literature, I think.
column590: A lot of it’s, sorta, will it screw you up personally, and also will it screw up somebody else?  That’s pretty much the end of it.  Like leaving crap on your table.  You’re making someone else do more work, so it would be right for you to clean it up and it would be wrong to make someone else have to work harder.  So it’s just sort of that. column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on the potential consequences for themselves and others, influenced by empathy and cultural norms, while also acknowledging the importance of seeking advice from trusted individuals when unsure about moral dilemmas.

column583:
R:Um, you didn’t like work for it so like you shouldn’t be able to just take something.
I:Why not?
R:I don’t know.
I:I’m not telling you stealing is right, I’m just—
R:Well yeah.
I:What, I mean, if somebody, like, like I left this here when I came to find you downstairs, so what if somebody came and said hey, nice little Jukebox 3, and took it.
R:Well I mean I think it’s like different things, if someone’s like, reports it or something and then no one like comes to claim it then you can keep it but like if you just walk into a store or something and take something off the rack or something and stick it in your pocket, then I think that’s wrong.
I:What makes it wrong.
R:Because—
I:What if you, what if somebody walked out and said hey I have something for free, it’s great.
R:Well still, I mean, isn’t that what money is for?  To pay for something so you can buy it?
I:Yeah, so but what if a kid, what if somebody said fine, now I have the money and the thing.
R:I don’t really know.
I:Okay.  All right, I’m not trying to give you a hard time here. Um, where do you think, I mean you clearly have a sense of certain things are right and wrong, where do you think those, your beliefs about right and wrong came from?
R:Ah, my parents, pretty much.
I:What you were taught.
R:So your parents would have taught you this is right and this is…any other source? Teachers pretty much, too.
I:Okay.  Um, so when you think about right and wrong, you pretty much rely on what you were taught by parents and teachers or.
R:Mm-mm (yes).
I:Do you ever question whether what you were taught makes sense or if it’s really true or anything like that?
R:Mm, yeah, sometimes.
I:Like what would be an example of it, maybe you’ve doubted or not sure about, or?
R:Um, well, when I was littler I was doubting like being Christian for some things, like some things don’t sound like right, but I just get along with them now I guess, pretty much.
I:How old were you when you were doubting that?
R:Um, I was like 10 or 11.
I:Do you remember what you were doubting?
R:Um, --
I:There, what were the things that didn’t make sense.
R:Ah, yeah there’s just things that didn’t make sense, I can’t remember what, what they were.
I:Like specific beliefs?
R:Yeah.
I:And did you resolve in your head that now they do make sense or do you not really care whether they do or not, or is?
R:Well I just haven’t really taken the time to think you know like, they’ve been written that way, so, it might be true, I don’t know.
I:Okay.  You mean like things like miracles or hell or Jesus raised from the dead?
R:Like stuff in the Bible, yeah.
I:Okay, so you’re just not sure still.
R:Not, yeah.
