column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are generally clear, attributing their moral beliefs to their parents and teachers, while expressing some doubts about religious teachings from their childhood and maintaining a strong stance against cheating and stealing, influenced by the consequences they have observed.
column586:
I:cool.  One of the things we’re talkin’ with everybody about is sort of morality and moral decision making and how people know things are right or wrong, good or bad.  Do you have any general thoughts about morality?  What’s moral, what’s right or wrong?
R:I don’t know really.  I do what I think is right.  If something seems wrong to you, you can usually sense, me I always, I can, if something’s wrong, you know not to do it.
I:so the way you usually know, it’s like an intuition, it’s automatic?  Or it’s just a feeling or your conscience?
R:well I don’t know, it’s a little bit like all of that.  I mean, if you find a wallet on the ground and your first instinct for me is “oh you should go return that to the police station.” Not just like take it.
I:why not take it?
R:cause, I don’t know, because I spend a lot of time working for things that I want and I’d be like kind of sad if I’d lost a bunch of my stuff I’d hope that someone would do the exact same for me.
I:alright, I’m not trying to change your moral view but just for the sake of argument let me play devil’s advocate.  So you work really hard, and you pay enough attention not to lose your wallet.  If someone else is dumb enough to lose their wallet, then you benefit from it, that’s their problem.  What would you say about that?
R:well, I guess it all depends on your background and where you grew up or whatever.  I was raised, I guess really strict, that if something is wrong you shouldn’t do it.  And my step dad, even though he’s really sick he really enforces doing the right thing to do so, we learned I guess how to be—
I:--where do you think that strictness comes from?  Why are your family strict?
R:my step dad, I got a lot, I learned a lot from him I guess.  Because he grew up by himself because both of his parents abandoned him and he had to learn how to do stuff on his own, so basically he had us do like sort of what he did, but not to the extreme of not having parents, but basically being able to take care of yourself because when you get out of high school it’s a lot easier if you know what to do and you’re already capable of taking care of yourself and you don’t need to be helped by your parents.
I:what do you think it is that makes things right or wrong?
R:um, I don’t know.
I:I mean, I presume, the way you are talking it sounds like you think certain things are right or wrong to do.  Why?  I mean, other than that you were told that in how you were raised.
R:um, the way people act I guess.  In a way, if someone is getting harassed by someone else for no reason other than for how they act, I mean, I don’t think that’s right.  It might not be their fault, they might have a problem at home or something like that.  There are a lot of things that can be a factor for why someone acts the way they act.  But then there’s a lot of ways people act for no reason at all, just because they can because they think that they’re better than everyone else.  And I think that sort of feeds into what’s right and wrong.  Because they’ll make different decisions about what’s right and wrong based on how they grew up and what kind of life they were accustomed to.  Like I guess, if you were rich and your parents were really powerful authority figures than you could get away with a lot more because they’d always be there to bail you out.  So they go and they do things that normal people wouldn’t feel sorry about and wouldn’t have like good moral conscience and all that kind of stuff.  like when someone who’s not as wealthy might grow up and couldn’t buy things, they know that, they know what it’s like to not have anything so they can, they make good decisions and sometimes bad, but it all depends on your situation.
I:so, but is the basis for a bad action or the good action is it just what people decide, what a society thinks, does it come from where?  How do you know what’s right or wrong, I mean you say it’s your conscience or your feelings.  What informs that?  What tells your conscience what makes things right or wrong?
R:I don’t know, just like how you grew up and everything like that.  I don’t really know, you just know it’s wrong so you should try and fix it.
I:if there was a tribe in some other society where people were vicious and eat each other up and slap their wives around and kill people from other tribes, would you say “that’s wrong” or would you say, “well, for them that’s fine?”
R:well, it wouldn’t be right, but if it’s the way that their culture learned to live like a system of how people live their lives I guess, I don’t think violence is good, I think you could like replace it with something else that’s not like mean, to that extent.  But I mean, cultures are gonna be different and they’re gonna have their own traditions and they’re gonna act the way they’ve been acting and you can’t really change that—
I:--but can you judge it?  Can you say “certain things in different cultures and in our own culture are morally wrong?”
R:yeah you could, it all depends on where you stand like, I guess republicans and democrats have different views on the same topic, they think about them differently.

column588: The respondent expresses a strong passion for filmmaking as a creative outlet, guided by intuition and a strict upbringing that emphasizes moral decision-making, leading him to avoid potentially harmful situations and prioritize helping others while recognizing the complexities of morality shaped by personal and cultural backgrounds.
column589:
I:how do you normally decide or know what is good or bad or right or wrong in life?
R:I think the media, people around, just how I was raised, what my mom and dad taught.  There were basic principles that my parents taught me and so I just go with my gut instinct and I feel like as long as I don’t get sucked into anything that’s too bad, I will be okay.
I:so what do you think it is that makes something wrong or right?
R:well all individuals, everyone has their own different morals, so that’s why there’s so much controversy because every different person thinks different things and I think what I think, but it’s not my part to say if another is doing right or wrong, I can only speak with myself.
I:so are you saying that morality is mostly about a system that’s needed to help people get along in society or is there actually an objective universal moral truth or structure of standards?
R:well… I don’t know and I think it’s mostly pragmatically needing people to get along with each other.
I:so it’s essentially relative to what works and there aren’t any moral standards?  For example if certain individuals have their own moral beliefs, is it possible to ever judge their moral beliefs or decide that they’re wrong if somebody believes something that’s really crazy, can you say that’s morally wrong, or are you stuck with just saying that’s what they believe?
R:well you have to draw the line somewhere or you just end up with total anarchy.  So the government creates broad parameters and then individuals do what they want within them, so the government explains at the farthest outside here’s what you can’t do.  And that’s in the form of laws, but then within that, individuals can do and think what they want to, as long as they’re not too extreme.  People should not be too extreme.
I:so is there anything that guides what people should believe within those parameters?
R:it’s all on an individual basis, you can’t tell somebody else if they were raised differently.  They could have been raised in a totally different situation than you.
I:so what if somebody believed that it was okay to hurt other people in various ways?
R:well, it’s wrong to hurt people.  Especially if the person being hurt didn’t choose it.  And anyway, hurting people goes against the government’s laws.  We have certain amendments, and freedoms, and rights, and liberties, and protections in our society that you can’t violate.
I:so if somebody wanted to date rape somebody, a girl who was drunk, would that be wrong, or would it not be wrong if the person could get away with it and they could advantage of her?
R:no that would definitely be wrong because it wasn’t that person’s choice and the underlying principle is that everyone has different underlying principles, but there is an underlying principle of decency that you should treat other people right and you should let them make choices about their life and not force things on them.  And I think this principle of decency is just common-sense, we’ve come a long way and people should just know that you should treat other people decently.
I:so what if you found a bag of $10,000 that was dropped out of a bank security truck, would you keep the money or would you return it to the bank because the name of the bank was on the bag?  Would it be immoral to keep the money?
R:well what country is the bank from?
I:United States.
R:It would be wrong to keep the money in the United States, but it would not be wrong to keep the money in say an African government that was totally corrupt or totalitarian.  It would be justified because that government’s a bad government anyway and if you could keep the money, then that would be a way of resisting the government, but then again, you might want to not keep the money because such a government would think nothing of hurting you badly if they found out that you kept the money.
I:but in the United States, it would be wrong to keep the money?
R:yes.
I:why? What exactly makes it wrong?
R:well it’s just not yours and people should have to work for what they get, people shouldn’t steal and private property is important.

And I think this principle of decency is just common-sense, we’ve come a long way and people should just know that you should treat other people decently. well what country is the bank from? column591: The respondent plans to use an inheritance for education and filmmaking, makes decisions based on parental teachings and gut instinct, believes morality is relative but acknowledges the need for societal laws, and emphasizes the importance of hard work and community involvement while recognizing that individuals have different moral beliefs.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?  How do you know what’s right and wrong?
R:Well I’m pretty sure my parents played a role in what’s right and wrong.
I:Okay.
R:And then as you get older you develop your own sense and your own minds.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:(pause) I really, I don’t know.
I:Okay.  When your parents are saying this is wrong, this is right.  Do you, is there any logic behind that?  Do you know of any reasoning as to why something would be wrong? I mean why is it wrong for someone, why is it wrong for you to make someone feel scared or harass them?
R:Well (sighs) it’s wrong because you’re belittling that individual.  When really they’re just as equal as you.  So, you really have no right to harass them either.
I:Why should you care what happens to somebody else?
R:Well I guess that’s right back down to morals.
I:Okay.
R:I guess, so.  I mean you’re right, you don’t have to care.  But I don’t know as a person you should.
I:Okay.  And you think that everybody should, that the standards are the same for everybody or do you think that people have, okay that’s right for him or
R:No, I think it should apply to everybody.
column584: Well I’m pretty sure my parents played a role in what’s right and wrong. And then as you get older you develop your own sense and your own minds. (pause) I really, I don’t know. Well (sighs) it’s wrong because you’re belittling that individual.  When really they’re just as equal as you.  So, you really have no right to harass them either. Well I guess that’s right back down to morals. I guess, so.  I mean you’re right, you don’t have to care.  But I don’t know as a person you should. No, I think it should apply to everybody.
column585: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on gut feelings and believes that right and wrong are clear, attributing their moral understanding to their parents while also acknowledging the influence of peer pressure and the importance of not imposing negative consequences on others.

column583:
I:*Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Taught to him by mom & dad when younger.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:“What you do should determine what’s right or wrong. If no trouble then it’s right.”  Ex. Cheat on test or steal answers, told them don’t do.
column584: Taught to him by mom & dad when younger. “What you do should determine what’s right or wrong. If no trouble then it’s right.”  Ex. Cheat on test or steal answers, told them don’t do.
column585: The respondent believes there are definite rights and wrongs, which were instilled by his parents, and he feels guilty if he does something wrong, while also noting that social influences, such as friends misguiding children, contribute to a general loss of moral clarity in society.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I usually make a judgment first about what I think is right or wrong, just saying about like what I believe my own moral code. I ask like for people’s like opinions a lot though on it. But it’s funny that I do because eventually I usually just go with what I believe anyway.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:In general, like big things like obvious things like should I kill or should I not, that’s easy. Little things like how like if I have a problem with like somebody that I don’t want to talk like how I should go about doing it like…I just like…like still…like what would be the right way to handle it, I had trouble with things like that, in more specific things like that.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past two years?
R:About the same, I think.
I:Have your views about what’s right and wrong changed in the past two years?
R:Yeah, kind of on little things. Kind of like…like is it wrong to…like is it wrong to…I used to be strictly against things like pot or would not and now I don’t necessarily think it’s wrong. I think it’s wrong if you like…like smoke a lot of pot and then like start to drive but I don’t there’s anything wrong with like smoking. It’s very similar to alcohol or better actually. Things like that…I mean, I obviously don’t think like slaughtering someone is good or raping.
I:So, why the change with regard to pot. What made the difference?
R:I think it was just when I tried it and like I found out what it is more about I guess, yeah.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:That’s a good question. I guess, wrong, I guess it’s like evil in a way or whatever and I guess good is keeping a good balance in life like harmonious balance between like you and your surroundings and the people in your surroundings. I know like evil people find happiness in like killing people but isn’t like…isn’t harmonious with his surroundings and other people. It’s just more like pleasing himself. I guess, good is more…I guess, good is more worrying about other people than yourself but I could be wrong.
I:So, it might come from a higher power you think?
R:Yeah. It could just you know like it may not be on a slab like the new Ten Commandments but like it’s…it’s in like somebody’s soul I guess.
I:So, are there other things that in our soul, morally speaking?  So not raping, what else?
R:Yeah.
I:What else do you think?
R:Just like how you should treat people I guess, how people should be treated, treat people the way you want to be treated, stuff like that. That’s a soul type of thing.
I:So, the Golden Rules?
R:Yeah, yeah, I guess.
I:Anything else?
R:The treating people thing actually kind of like covers a lot of things. Treating people couldn’t be like…like how you treat like your family or whatever like looking out and who you should look out for like over yourself and stuff like that. I guess it just kind of goes underneath that thing.
I:What about rules or laws?  I mean, technically, pot is against the law.
R:True.
I:But it seems like you’re okay with it?
R:Yeah.
I:So, do you think its okay to break the law?  Is that morally wrong?  Was it morally right to do that? What do you think?
R:If you break the law, I guess like, you can automatically assume that a person like isn’t trustworthy because they break the law, I mean, what else could they break. But I also believe kind of like if—I don’t remember who said it, I think it’s Malcolm X or maybe…yeah, I think its Malcolm X. It was like if…if you don’t believe in a law, you should like break it whatever you can to try to like…like show that it’s wrong but again, he had a point with the, like…like if you’re breaking a law, like what else could you think is right and to like…like change. I know, that’s where I would like. That’s where I would draw the line. But I know a lot of people wouldn’t. But I guess you could say it’s morally wrong to break the law but I don’t think that should be against the law. So…
I:So, if you think that something shouldn’t be you know the law, that it’s okay to…
R:Do it…no, like I don’t think you should kill people if you think it’s…it’s against the law. It’s kind of like again it’s part of the moral code, like knowing what’s right and wrong but some people don’t have obviously. Sociopaths…
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:I feel they kind of just like…I have a strong conscience, I’ve noticed. I don’t know if that was just like programmed, like, I’m probably like my conscience is probably too strong. I don’t mean like…like I’m a perfect person because I’m not. I do a lot of stuff wrong but I know like whenever I do something wrong, like I usually know about it and I will go like the world may know it like…just like I will like self loathe for like a couple of days because like depending on how bad it was. I’m just like…like, “Oh, why did you do that?  You’re such a…you’re such an asshole” and I don’t think you learn that. I mean, that kind of just like comes with who you are. It’s also shaped by experience I’m sure.
I:Where do your morals come from?
R:Morals…come from I mean, again, like I said, you don’t learn them but they could come in part from your…from your like upbringing, your family or what not, like the genetic code, what your parents believe and stuff like that. It just…I think you acquire them like everything…everything you go through when you grow up, it’s like it shapes you, I think.
column590: I usually make a judgment first about what I think is right or wrong, just saying about like what I believe my own moral code. I ask like for people’s like opinions a lot though on it. But it’s funny that I do because eventually I usually just go with what I believe anyway. In general, like big things like obvious things like should I kill or should I not, that’s easy. Little things like how like if I have a problem with like somebody that I don’t want to talk like how I should go about doing it like…I just like…like still…like what would be the right way to handle it, I had trouble with things like that, in more specific things like that. column591: The respondent would prioritize paying off debts to their parents and essential expenses before considering charitable donations, indicating that their moral code is influenced by personal beliefs and social opinions, while also acknowledging a shift in their views on issues like marijuana after personal experience, and expressing a belief in inherent moral guidelines shaped by upbringing and conscience.

column589:
I:Now how would you say you normally decide what’s right and wrong, good and bad in life?
R:I can get a situation?
I:Sure, yeah, you go ahead and use one.  I just meant how do you normally decide between like right and wrong?  But if you want to use a situation that’s fine.
R:I truly can’t say… I know I have done some bad things, but… and I knew it was the wrong thing to do, but I still did it.  My mother’s teachings.  That’s what I can say.  What my mother taught me was right and wrong.
I:Would you say it’s easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Easy.
I:And has that gotten easier or harder over the past couple years?
R:Easy.
I:It’s gotten easy?  Why would you say that?
R:‘Cuz I’m like a real quick thinker.  I think on my feet.
I:Have your moral views changed in the past couple of years?
R:Yes.  ‘cuz like, well I say I like quit my sports.  Stopped thinking about myself all the time.  I like help my family out.
I:What sports were you playing?
R:Basketball and football.
I:So what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  Like what makes something right, what makes something wrong?
R:The outcome.
I:The outcome?  The consequence of it?
R:Yeah.
I:What kind of consequences make something wrong?
R:Make something wrong?
I:Yeah, like you said the outcome.  What kind of outcome makes something wrong?
R:Like if somebody get hurt or anything.  Like emotionally, physically, mentally, whatever.
I:And that makes it wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:What if no one gets hurt?  Can it still be wrong?
R:It still could be wrong ‘cuz different people have different feelings.
I:Okay and where do you think you’ve gotten your moral views from?
R:My mother.
column590: I can get a situation? I truly can’t say… I know I have done some bad things, but… and I knew it was the wrong thing to do, but I still did it.  My mother’s teachings.  That’s what I can say.  What my mother taught me was right and wrong. Easy. Easy. ‘Cuz I’m like a real quick thinker.  I think on my feet. Yes.  ‘cuz like, well I say I like quit my sports.  Stopped thinking about myself all the time.  I like help my family out. Basketball and football.  The outcome. Yeah. Make something wrong? Like if somebody get hurt or anything.  Like emotionally, physically, mentally, whatever. Yeah. It still could be wrong ‘cuz different people have different feelings.  My mother.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on their mother's teachings to determine right and wrong, believes that the consequences of actions define morality, and prefers to make decisions that benefit their own advancement rather than adhering to religious or parental guidance.

column585: The respondent often feels unsure about right and wrong, particularly when influenced by peers, and tends to make decisions based on minimizing trouble, while also considering the potential consequences of their actions on others and acknowledging their parents' expectations.

column583:
I:Okay.  Where do you think your ideas of right and wrong come from?
R:They come from your intuition and from your mind.  Basic instincts should tell you if you do something whether it will hurt somebody or whether it won’t.
I:What if somebody had a mind that said “well it doesn’t matter to me if it hurts somebody, I think it’s still okay” is that all right?
R:I think it’s just going to come right back up then, they’re going to get hurt one day and they’re going to see what they did was wrong.
I:Okay.  So does it have to – does, does consequences make something wrong or…you know, what is it that – where does right and wrong come from, how do we know what’s right and wrong?
R:The outcome of it.
I:The outcome?
R:Yeah.
I:So how do you decide whether it’s a good or bad outcome?
R:Well you can kind of figure out cause if…say…I don’t know how to put this…you can kind of tell by the personality of the person.  Like if you play a prank on someone that is really sensitive, they’re going to get hurt, but if you play, if you do a prank on somebody that’s really, that likes pranks and laughs a lot, then it’s going to be funny and you won’t hurt them or anything.
I:Okay.  So um, it’s just a matter of trying to figure out if someone would be hurt or not?
R:Yeah, basically.
I:Okay.  How do you usually decide what’s right or wrong?
R:Um, (pause)
I:Are there things that guide or influence your decisions?
R:I usually think, I usually try to figure out what’s the point in doing it, I mean what, what would I get out of doing it.  And then I would think of the consequences, and then I would think of how people would react to it.
column584: If it’s against the law and if it will hurt somebody, and if it will cause you to get in trouble or get hurt, or stuff like that. Yeah, basically, and if it will hurt somebody I think it is wrong. (pause) Nobody wants to be hurt, I mean you wouldn’t, if somebody did the same thing to you and it hurt you, you would say it’s wrong. So why would you say it’s okay to hurt somebody else? They come from your intuition and from your mind.  Basic instincts should tell you if you do something whether it will hurt somebody or whether it won’t. I think it’s just going to come right back up then, they’re going to get hurt one day and they’re going to see what they did was wrong. The outcome of it. Yeah. Like if you play a prank on someone that is really sensitive, they’re going to get hurt, but if you play, if you do a prank on somebody that’s really, that likes pranks and laughs a lot, then it’s going to be funny and you won’t hurt them or anything. Yeah, basically. Um, (pause) I usually think, I usually try to figure out what’s the point in doing it, I mean what, what would I get out of doing it.  And then I would think of the consequences, and then I would think of how people would react to it.
column585: The respondent believes that people's sense of right and wrong has diminished, attributing this to a lack of care for consequences, while their own moral compass is guided by intuition and the potential harm to others, and they feel guilty about conflicts with their mother, indicating a strong conscience.
column589:
I:Okay.  And so how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I’m not really sure.  I guess I just go with my instinct.  If it doesn’t feel right then I won’t do it.
I:Okay.  And so in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I guess it depends on the situation but I think mostly it’s kind of easy because if I don’t feel okay with it, and if I don’t feel that whatever I’m about to do is all right, then I just won’t do it.
I:Okay.  And has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Probably easier.
I:Why do you think that is?
R:I’ve just had  a lot more life experience with people who try to influence you and you just kind of start to see through the, I’m not sure what word to use, you start to see things easier, I guess.  Especially if it’s happened in the past.  You’re like, okay, I did this last time and it ended up badly, so maybe I should do it a different way.
I:Okay.  And so what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  Or what’s the, you said you go with your instinct, so what is it that your instinct tells you to do?
R:I’m not really sure how to describe it.  I just, if something feels wrong, then it feels wrong to me.
I:And would it feel wrong because of consequences, or?
R:I think, maybe, for just like my personal beliefs on things or my opinions on some things.  Because I guess some consequences are influence, but, also, mostly, it’s just like my personal beliefs and feelings on the subject.
I:And is there a particular type of feeling? Are you able to describe the feeling?
R:No.
column590: I’m not really sure.  I guess I just go with my instinct.  If it doesn’t feel right then I won’t do it. I guess it depends on the situation but I think mostly it’s kind of easy because if I don’t feel okay with it, and if I don’t feel that whatever I’m about to do is all right, then I just won’t do it. Probably easier. I’ve just had  a lot more life experience with people who try to influence you and you just kind of start to see through the, I’m not sure what word to use, you start to see things easier, I guess.  Especially if it’s happened in the past.  You’re like, okay, I did this last time and it ended up badly, so maybe I should do it a different way.  I’m not really sure how to describe it.  I just, if something feels wrong, then it feels wrong to me. I think, maybe, for just like my personal beliefs on things or my opinions on some things.  Because I guess some consequences are influence, but, also, mostly, it’s just like my personal beliefs and feelings on the subject. No.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on their instincts to determine right from wrong, influenced by personal beliefs and past experiences, while also expressing a desire to help others but recognizing that many people do not step out of their comfort zones to do so.

column583:
I:Okay.  Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, my religion and my parents.
I:Okay.  Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think, if it’s right you’ll feel good about it and it won’t be hurting anyone else, you know,
I:Okay.  Yeah.
R:And if it’s wrong, you’ll feel guilty or you know inside that it’s not the right thing to do.
I:Okay.  Okay.  Do you have a time where that has happened to you where you have um, kind of felt um, where you knew that it was something, like maybe at that moment that you had to make a decision of whether it was right or wrong and you kind of based your decision on how you felt or?
R:(pause)  Um,
I:Let me rephrase that question.  When you, do you make decisions based on how you’re feeling about something?
R:Most of the time.
I:Most of the time?  Okay.  In recent years, have you been involved in any things that you think are wrong?
column584: Um, my religion and my parents. I think, if it’s right you’ll feel good about it and it won’t be hurting anyone else, you know, And if it’s wrong, you’ll feel guilty or you know inside that it’s not the right thing to do. (pause)  Um, Most of the time.
column585: The respondent often relies on their mother or sister for guidance in uncertain situations, believes that morality is relative and shaped by their religion and parents, feels that right actions are those that do not harm others and leave one feeling good, and acknowledges the social pressures of popularity among peers while maintaining a personal stance against excessive drinking and drug use.
column589:
I:So how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:I talk to a lot of people, and I get a lot of support that way, and especially older people, and I pray about it.
I:And so in general is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s usually pretty easy.
I:And do you think it’s gotten easier or harder in the last few years?
R:Easier.
I:Why?
R:I think I’ve grown a lot.  Yeah, I’ve definitely grown a lot, so yeah, I usually can tell when something’s right or wrong immediately.  But yeah.
I:So what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I mean there’s so many situations where you can use that.  I don’t know, in what kind of situation?
I:Well how about… you were saying that you rely on thinking through what Buddhism has to tell you about.  So what is it that Buddhism has to tell you about what a right decision would be or not?  You were kinda talking about it before.
R:Right, right, right, right.  So in Buddhism, I don’t know… let’s say drinking or something, or doing drugs or something.  There aren’t any specific rules as to what… there aren’t any you know, you’re not supposed to drink or you’re not supposed to do drugs or whatever, but I think the main point is, whether you’re doing something that’s good for your life or you’re doing something harmful to your life, so I was kinda saying with the relationship thing, as long as you’re growing as a person, and as long as you’re reflecting on yourself and changing the negative things in your life, then I think it’s fine.  I think it’s also not bad to have fun, so if you wanna drink every once in a while, or moderately or whatever, then that’s fine ‘cause it’s not in the way of you really developing yourself as a person.
I:And where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Through my Buddhist practice.
column590: I talk to a lot of people, and I get a lot of support that way, and especially older people, and I pray about it. It’s usually pretty easy. Easier. I think I’ve grown a lot.  Yeah, I’ve definitely grown a lot, so yeah, I usually can tell when something’s right or wrong immediately.  But yeah.  I mean there’s so many situations where you can use that.  I don’t know, in what kind of situation? Right, right, right, right.  So in Buddhism, I don’t know… let’s say drinking or something, or doing drugs or something.  There aren’t any specific rules as to what… there aren’t any you know, you’re not supposed to drink or you’re not supposed to do drugs or whatever, but I think the main point is, whether you’re doing something that’s good for your life or you’re doing something harmful to your life, so I was kinda saying with the relationship thing, as long as you’re growing as a person, and as long as you’re reflecting on yourself and changing the negative things in your life, then I think it’s fine.  I think it’s also not bad to have fun, so if you wanna drink every once in a while, or moderately or whatever, then that’s fine ‘cause it’s not in the way of you really developing yourself as a person.  Through my Buddhist practice.
column591: The respondent would give half of a hypothetical inheritance to their parents and save the rest for travel or charity, relies on discussions with older people and prayer to determine right from wrong, finds moral decisions easier due to personal growth and Buddhist teachings, believes in the importance of helping others as a moral responsibility, and prefers to follow Buddhist teachings over parental advice when unsure about right and wrong.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Probably my parents.  It’s kind of crazy how everything reflects on your parents isn’t it?
I:I’m not going to comment.
R:I know, um, yeah.
column584: Probably my parents.  It’s kind of crazy how everything reflects on your parents isn’t it? I know, um, yeah.
column585: The respondent acknowledges being influenced by friends in decision-making, expresses concern over the declining moral standards among youth, attributes their views on right and wrong to their parents, and feels guilty about selling steroids while rationalizing that the decision to buy was ultimately the buyers'.
column586:
I:So um, generally speaking, how do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Right or wrong.  I guess how, how, I’m going to affect myself, affect, just anything?
I:Yeah, just generally speaking, when you need to decide between right and wrong, how do you do it?
R:Going with what um, I don’t know, just going with, I don’t know, how do I think about it?  How my heart feels about it?  How I feel about it, how I feel about it after, I don’t know
I:So you go by just how it feels to you?
R:Yeah, how it feels.  How it might affect somebody else.  How I’d feel if I was that person.
I:Okay. in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:In general?  Yeah, I’d say it is and sometimes it is.
I:It, so do you think it’s easy or hard?
R:Easy.
I:It’s easy?
R:Yeah.
I:Do you think deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Easier.
I:Why?
R:Cause I’ve gotten smarter.  I’ve gotten in trouble.  I’ve realized right and wrong, how it can affect other people.  When you think you’re right, but really you’re wrong and you do something stupid, you can affect other people by it.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Makes some thing wrong.  I don’t know.  How you feel after you’ve
I:Like what kind of feelings do you mean?
R:Feel bad about the decision that you made.  I don’t know.  Feel good about the decision that you made.  I have no idea.
I:Where do you think these feelings come from?  Like how you feel, if you feel bad about something or feel good?
R:If I made a bad decision.  If I um, did something stupid, I’d feel bad about it.
I:How do you know?  I mean what do you think makes you feel bad about it?
R:What makes me feel bad about it?  I don’t know.  Um, making a bad decision?  I don’t know, like what would make you feel bad about it?
I:Like um, well let’s try another question.  Do you think that there are any actions that are always wrong in themselves?
R:In themselves are wrong?
I:Yeah.
R:Hm, (pause), well yeah, there’s always, yeah.
I:Can you give me some examples?
R:Actions that are always wrong (sighs).  Killing, ha, that’s an action that’s always wrong.
I:Okay so killing
R:Murdering somebody
I:So
R:Rape’s always wrong.
I:What makes these things wrong?
R:Uh, what makes these wrong?  Murdering someone?
I:Yeah.
R:Cold blooded, why would you do that, ha, I don’t know, yeah, you must have no feelings if you could do something like that.
I:Well like, um,
R:What makes it wrong?
I:Yeah.
R:You’re killing somebody.
I:Why is that wrong?
R:Cause you’re taking somebody’s life, you’re not, you’re affecting so many other people than just them, and I don’t know, I think it’s just wrong to kill somebody.  Why would you kill somebody?  I don’t know, do you not think that’s wrong? (laughs)
I:I’m just asking the questions.
R:I know.
I:So where do you think that you’ve acquired your moral view?  Where do they come from?  Like this view of what you think are right and wrong?
R:I guess, um, the way that I’ve been brought up.  Some, you know, what I’ve learned from, you know religion class obviously plays a role too. I’ve never really been a religious person but at the same time I did learn things that, I had really good teachers.  They taught me.  Formed a base for me pretty much, and if, I don’t know what I believe as far as religion goes, but definitely told me what’s right and wrong.  And the same with my parents.

column588: The respondent plans to save the hypothetical $100,000 to start a business after school, influenced by their desire to follow their passion, and acknowledges the potential to donate to charity, particularly motivated by their mother's involvement in breast cancer fundraising, while they generally make decisions based on how they feel and the impact on others, reflecting on past mistakes and the lessons learned from them.
column589:
I:Okay.  How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Just what I believe.  I mean, what I, if I have a feeling that something’s going to be wrong I don’t do it. I feel it inside, that’s about it.
I:Is it easy or 	hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s easy.  I can, I know when I’m doing something wrong.
I:Okay.  Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Easier.
I:Why?
R:Because I have a clearer, my mind is clearer and I can make better decisions, more rational decisions.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, what makes something right or wrong?  Just something that I, how I feel, how I feel about the situation, I mean, if you get a gut feeling inside you that, you know when something’s right or wrong, I mean, it’s all obviously based off of our, how we were brought up and what morals and values that our parents instilled in us, but I think we all have a good idea of what’s right and wrong when we make a decision.
I:So what kinds of consequences would make something wrong?
R:Bad consequences.  What would be a bad consequence?
I:Yeah.
R:I don’t, um, you’re hurting somebody, in any way, I mean you could hurt somebody financially, physically, mentally, you’re hurting yourself .
I:Okay.  Earlier you were kind of describing that gut feeling, like you just know what’s right or you know what’s wrong, so where do those feelings come from?
R:Like I said, I think that when you’re growing up you’re instilled with your parents values that they have, you know, themselves and they sort of base everything off of that and those values, but, I don’t know, it’s just a gut feeling, that’s it, I mean, you know whether or not something’s right or wrong.  I really don’t know what that feeling means or why I have the feelings, I’m guessing that what it’s from though, just the values that I learned growing up.
I:Where do you think maybe those values come from?  I know, I know you said your parents, right, um, I mean are those values just something that has evolved over time, do they come from someplace else, I mean is it just kind of your own, your parents’ opinion, you’re just following after them?
R:Yeah but, I mean, I know that, I know that they’re all values and a lot of them are based off of religion, like that’s how, that’s where everyone gets their values from, I mean, if you see a lot of people that don’t have religions start off obviously some of them end up bad, unless their parents are like some sort of ridiculous philosophers or something, like, they’re going to end up bad, but the thing is is that like I think that everybody has, can be put, have the values instilled in them and everybody can develop their own ideas from them, and that’s what it’s all about.  So I’ve developed my own ideas what right or wrong is and I don’t know, sometimes I just get that feeling I don’t know whether or not that feeling’s, it’s usually the right feeling.
I:Okay.  Um, are there any other places you get your moral views from?  You said your parents, religion,
R:My philosophy ethics class, no, I mean I don’t know, I mean, I’ve learned a lot so I’ve just growing up I’ve learned a lot.
I:Was that class useful?
R:Yeah.
I:Did you just try to pass and get by or did you really get into it?
R:I liked it a lot.  It was an awesome class.  My teacher was awesome, he was a very good teacher and talked a lot about a lot of different issues, many different issues that were, did a lot of critical thinking, so it was, I liked it a lot.  Yeah it was a cool class.
I:Did it help you kind of with these issues at all or did it change your perspective at all?
R:Yeah, somewhat, I mean we learned about different theories and just kind of helped shape my ideas a little more I guess, but didn’t really influence anything too drastically to where I, ‘this is what I’m going to believe’ or ‘this is what I’m going to believe’, but it kind of helped shape my ideas instead.

column591: The respondent makes decisions based on their gut feelings and the values instilled by their parents, believing that right and wrong are clear to them, and they prioritize following the advice of respected adults over personal happiness or religious guidance.

column583:
I:Okay, and where do your own views of right and wrong come from? Like what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong, and what do you think?
R:I really don’t think there is.  I mean, you know, it’s really up to the person, you know, if they want to live, you know, I don’t want to take anyone on a guilt trip you know but if someone does something wrong, what I think is wrong it could be right to someone else.  They have a different point of view so one person’s right could be another person’s wrong.
I:And where do your own views of what’s right and wrong come from do you think?
R:Um, just you know, just having to make different choices and you know, well thinking if I did this or that then it would be a better outcome.  But either way you know, in a way some decisions you make you always come to the same end.  Whether it takes you longer to get to that place or not. Well a lot of times you can think everything is the right decision and then, and then something will happen and then it will seem so wrong.  So.
I:Do you have any like examples of times something might be right for one person and wrong for another person or?
R:Um, um,
I:Or seem right and be wrong?
R:Like when I first began dating I was very blind as to how to treat my boyfriend you know, whether like he’d ask me oh who else do you like and things like that and you know I didn’t think it was right for me to lie to him and say you know well I don’t like anyone but then again it was wrong for me to tell him too cause you know he is my boyfriend and it wasn’t exactly the right thing to do.  So you know, I made a choice to tell him and eventually our relationship ended, not that it was going to last forever, but you know I do regret doing that, but then again I don’t.  So you know it gives you a different decisions that I made, like especially with dating you know I’ll look back on different things that maybe if I did this or that you know I’d still be going out with them. But then again I wouldn’t be going out with this person, you know, so it’s kind of like that.

column585: The respondent often relies on friends for different perspectives when making decisions, feels guilty about past actions that contradict their principles, and believes that morality is subjective, shaped by personal experiences and social influences, particularly from parents and friends.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:My parents.
I:Um, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I don’t know it’s, just, just what are the consequences of each action, whether they would be good or bad.
I:Do you think you think of consequences for a lot of people, or yourself, or?
R:It’s like, no, other people first.
I:What makes it wrong, do you think, to hurt other people or have bad consequences for them, some people would just say usually just look out for yourself and do what’s best for you.
R:When it’s purposeful or when it’s, like I mean, if it’s well deserved there’s a difference between, like, giving someone what they deserve and just being an asshole, so, I think there’s a big difference.
I:So why do you think it’s wrong to be an asshole?
R:Well I think it’s, just to be a jerk as it, like for no reason, but if you have a problem with somebody or you don’t get along with them, there’s no reason you should pretend like you get along with them, but I mean, if you’re just, don’t know somebody and you just like, rude to them or something like that, for no reason then it’s just, it’s not right.
column584: My parents. I don’t know it’s, just, just what are the consequences of each action, whether they would be good or bad. It’s like, no, other people first. When it’s purposeful or when it’s, like I mean, if it’s well deserved there’s a difference between, like, giving someone what they deserve and just being an asshole, so, I think there’s a big difference. Well I think it’s, just to be a jerk as it, like for no reason, but if you have a problem with somebody or you don’t get along with them, there’s no reason you should pretend like you get along with them, but I mean, if you’re just, don’t know somebody and you just like, rude to them or something like that, for no reason then it’s just, it’s not right.
column585: The respondent primarily bases their sense of right and wrong on the consequences of actions for others, influenced by their parents' values, while expressing a belief that morality is not entirely relative and acknowledging a tendency to prioritize the well-being of others over their own.
column586:
I:Okay.  (pause) How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:You can usually tell.  But on difficult decisions I usually consult people.  And there’s the two heads are better than one.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Well it all depends on the situation, like,
I:Just kind of day to day, do you feel like you spend a lot of energy thinking about kind of choose what is right or wrong or not?
R:Yeah.  But I have like a wandering mind.
I:Yeah?
R:Like when I’m working, I don’t think about my work, like my mind wanders, I don’t think about my work.  So yeah, I do, I think about it a lot actually.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Easier to tell what’s right and wrong.  But harder because the choices become more complicated.  When I was a kid things were like, do this or don’t do this, but now it’s like throw some other things in there, and it becomes more complicated.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:It’s hard to tell.  It’s how you feel about it.  But some people have no conscience, so.
I:How do you think they get that way?
R:It’s like an animal, not like an animal like that, but they just do things to get by, they don’t think of the consequences or anything.  They don’t have the forethought.  I don’t know if that’s the right word, but they don’t have any like, planning, they just do like crazy things just for the minute that’s why they get in trouble.  But I think that’s how they were raised though.  It has a lot to do with how you were brought up.
I:Okay.
R:Cause most of the people that I know like that, you can look at their families and you can see what’s going on.  I think the family is like the key to see why people are the way they are.
I:Yeah.
R:Like if you know someone really well, and you see them interact with their family, you can kind of get a glimpse into their life.  Cause people don’t, no matter who you are but you’re their friends, but no one ever acts the same way in front of their family as they do with their friends.  I think you can fairly say that.  And like your family is like who you’re closest to, you might hang out with your friends, but your family, they affect you the most, so you can just see how you are and how your family interacts with each other and stuff like that.
I:Yeah.  So those feelings you were talking about, like the feeling that something’s right or wrong, where do you think those feelings come from?
R:(pause) How it affects other people.  How it affects you.  You know, whether it’s like physically, emotionally, some other way that’s hurting somebody.  I mean usually if a lie’s involved you can usually tell what’s going on.  If you have to lie in the sequence, you can tell what’s going on.
I:Do you think we all just naturally have something in us that makes us feel one way or another?  Or where do you think that comes from?
R:I think you do.  It depends on who you are.  Some people just lie like crazy, they just say whatever, but some people don’t.  They don’t ever say anything like that.  And it just goes back to how your family was.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Yeah.
I:To everyone?  What kind of things?
R:(pause)  Killing people, like out of like, just killing people just like that.  Stealing usually.  Other stuff, like drugs, I’m not sure about.  I mean that goes basically where you grow up not who you think, your perspective on things like that.

column588: The respondent would share some of an unexpected inheritance with their parents, invest part of it, and spend a significant amount on extravagant experiences, emphasizing the importance of enjoying life, while also reflecting on their decision-making process regarding right and wrong, which involves consulting others, considering the consequences of actions, and recognizing the influence of family upbringing on moral perspectives.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right or wrong in life?
R:Intuition. Usually, my personal conscience.
I:And is that, in general, easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Usually pretty easy.
I:And has the deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder in the last couple years?
R:Harder.
I:How come?
R:Just too many decisions and things to decide upon.
I:What, such as?
R:More I mean, when you get older you get in more responsibilities in making decisions. Frequently. And there’s the…the implications of your decisions are like harder so.  It’s just like a, a sliding scale of difficulty .
I:Have your views right and wrong changed in the last couple years?
R:Maybe on minor points, but definitely not on, with my whole…my whole driving .

R:Circumstances

R:Yeah.

R:Sometimes.

R:No.

I would probably have more fun just sitting at home, well maybe I wouldn’t have but, the point is I just went.  They were right.  I more fun doing it, but not even that. column591: The respondent primarily relies on intuition and personal conscience to determine right from wrong, acknowledges the influence of their parents and community on their moral views, and believes that decisions should consider the consequences for all parties involved, while expressing a desire for personal advancement and a recognition of the importance of helping disadvantaged individuals, particularly within the family.

column589:
I:So how do you normal decide or know what is good and bad or right and wrong then?
R:Well, I just question myself like well, whether I would, like, regret doing this later or whether, you know, it’s like, seen good in the eyes of God or something like that, or whether like my parents would’ve done that, or whether I would feel like, you know, just a dismay if I did it or not.  But that’s all I’d say.
I:So in general is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Sometimes it’s not as easy as I would think it would be.  So yeah.
I:And do you think it’s gotten harder or easier in the last couple years?
R:I mean it’s gotten easier cuz I’m older, and I know more of the consequences, you know.
I:Ok.  And so what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  Or like you mentioned consequences, what kinds of consequences make something right or wrong?
R:Well like, you know, getting pregnant too early or maybe like smoking or something, driving, getting arrested, or drinking and driving, you might kill someone, or like, you know, fighting, you know that could end up with you in jail or something like that, so.
column590: Well, I just question myself like well, whether I would, like, regret doing this later or whether, you know, it’s like, seen good in the eyes of God or something like that, or whether like my parents would’ve done that, or whether I would feel like, you know, just a dismay if I did it or not.  But that’s all I’d say. Sometimes it’s not as easy as I would think it would be.  So yeah. I mean it’s gotten easier cuz I’m older, and I know more of the consequences, you know.  Well like, you know, getting pregnant too early or maybe like smoking or something, driving, getting arrested, or drinking and driving, you might kill someone, or like, you know, fighting, you know that could end up with you in jail or something like that, so.
column591: The respondent makes decisions based on the potential regret of their actions, the moral implications as viewed through the lens of their religious beliefs, and the influence of their parents, acknowledging that while they sometimes struggle with right and wrong, they ultimately value the advice of experienced individuals over personal happiness or self-advancement.

column583:
R:Mm, you want an example?
I:Sure.
R:Like in um, like it’s really follow the laws, well if you, for example, well, for example, if you leave a baby in the house by itself that’s wrong, if you follow the laws, that’s right.

column585: The respondent believes that people generally understand right from wrong but often fail to act accordingly, relies on their own reasoning rather than social influences for moral decisions, and acknowledges that while cheating is wrong due to potential consequences, lying to parents can be situationally acceptable.

column583:
I:Okay, alright.  Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:My mama.
I:Your mama, okay, okay.  Can you tell me about that?  Is there, when did you ever,
R:Cause when I was young, she always, she would, you know the Ten Commandments, she told me about the Ten Commandments.
I:Yeah.
R:So I live my life over that because in every law, it’s all about the ten commandments, if you look at all the laws in each state, it’s basically up on the ten commandments, that’s how I see it, if it wasn’t for her teaching me and showing me the books and stuff, I really wouldn’t know right from wrong.

column585: The respondent believes that a sense of right and wrong is inherent in everyone, attributes their moral understanding primarily to their mother's teachings about the Ten Commandments, and acknowledges the importance of personal choice in moral decisions, while also reflecting on the consequences of actions and the influence of peers in their life choices.

column591: The respondent would use an inheritance to pay off debts and secure their children's future, emphasizing the importance of making morally sound decisions based on consequences and personal morals, influenced by their experiences on the streets and a strong belief in doing what is right according to God rather than seeking personal gain or happiness.

column585: The respondent expresses a strong belief in a clear distinction between right and wrong, asserting that cheating and lying to parents are always wrong, although they are unsure about the origins of this moral clarity and do not recall any personal experiences of wrongdoing or opposition to friends' actions.

column589:
I:how do you normally decide what is good and bad, or right and wrong?
R:I think my own feelings are pretty reliable
I:your insights you would say or some sort of gut feeling?
R:well I guess gut feeling when it comes down to things that I'm not—I mean I try to think about things thoroughly, I try to think of everything thoroughly but if I cant, if I come to a limit, that’s when I have to, but I wouldn’t like to.
I:so generally you trust your feelings you would say?
R:well not my initial feelings, I have to think about it for awhile before I know what to think about and I realize that my initial reaction, my gut feelings are usually unreliable
I:and in general do you find it easy or hard to decide what is right or wrong?
R:I think it’s hard, I think it’s always hard.
I:and has this become easier or harder over the past couple of years?
R:probably harder, just because I think about it a lot more now than I did before.
I:and have your views of right and wrong changed over the past couple years?
R:maybe a little bit.  I guess not really, I never really bought into anything, I mean if somebody told me something that I dunno, I can’t really think of anything in particular.
I:what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:well, I guess I'm more like utilitarian in that sense because I think it’s kinda arbitrary what we think of as right or wrong.  I don’t think there’s a set rule book to tell us what right or wrong is but we kinda have to take, add up the bad and the good and see which one overpowers the other.
I:would you say it’s consequences? That overall the consequences benefit a lot of people is that generally how you say it?
R:yeah, well the biggest criticism against utilitarianism is that a really fortunate person, like a really rich person, say, was going to have a lot of pleasure by inflicting small discomforts to a lot of really poor people, and if his pleasure was bigger than a discomfort than he inflicts then it’s moral to support him.  But I think if you think of utilitarianism thoroughly, if you don’t just dismiss it I think that’s—why else would we do things?  I just don’t see how you can define what is good and what is bad in any other way.
I:Apart from consequences, benefits?
R:and I mean there has to be a benefit, you don’t do things because they hurt you, it makes sense, but people don’t understand when people say why do people, say, smoke.  We are getting something out of it.  They are getting something out of it, that’s why they do it, they don’t do it because they want to kill themselves.
I:what about feelings?  Some people say what’s right is what feels right to you and that’s about it regardless of consequences?
R:Regardless of consequences? I wouldn’t feel right if the consequences weren’t good, so I guess it is feelings if you think of it that way.
I:what about rules or laws or are there things that simply are wrong absolutely.
R:things that are absolutely wrong? I couldn’t think of anything that was absolutely wrong, just because I can always think of some really obscure theoretical situation where that would be excusable and you could say that rape is absolutely wrong and for all intents and purposes I would agree with that, but you can always set up a situation where a whole country is going to be destroyed unless you rape somebody and if you rape somebody then the country gets saved, but you know, I don’t think anything’s absolutely wrong.
I:where do you think you’ve acquired your moral views from, where do they come from?
R:I think they I guess I could say they come from myself, but I guess that wouldn’t be very accurate because I think I’ve been influenced by a lot of other things, I'm influenced by a lot of things it’s not just all from me.
I:are these from your parents?
R:yeah a little from my parents
I:what from you parents or what from maybe your friends or other people or a combination?
R:yeah it would probably have to be, but from my parents, I don’t know. I don’t really talk to them about this a lot I kind just accept that they can believe whatever the heck they want no matter how crazy it is as long as it doesn’t have anything to do with me. I mean to me it just seems that they believe whatever Catholicism as long as the Pope says its law, the Pope changes his mind, they change their mind, too.  I don’t really know what to say.
I:so you wouldn’t say that they’re not much of an influence on your morals? I think you said that utilitarianism is right, but when did you acquire that idea or what influenced you there?
R:probably in high school, I just thought about it and I read about it.

I wouldn’t feel right if the consequences weren’t good, so I guess it is feelings if you think of it that way. things that are absolutely wrong? I couldn’t think of anything that was absolutely wrong, just because I can always think of some really obscure theoretical situation where that would be excusable and you could say that rape is absolutely wrong and for all intents and purposes I would agree with that, but you can always set up a situation where a whole country is going to be destroyed unless you rape somebody and if you rape somebody then the country gets saved, but you know, I don’t think anything’s absolutely wrong.  I think they I guess I could say they come from myself, but I guess that wouldn’t be very accurate because I think I’ve been influenced by a lot of other things, I'm influenced by a lot of things it’s not just all from me. yeah a little from my parents yeah it would probably have to be, but from my parents, I don’t know. column591: The respondent would invest a hypothetical inheritance in education, influenced by the belief that it would provide long-term benefits, while also acknowledging that their moral decisions are primarily guided by personal feelings and utilitarian principles, despite recognizing the complexity of right and wrong and the influence of their parents' beliefs.

column583:
I:Okay, all right.  And where do you get your own views about what’s right and wrong from?
R:I get my views from what’s right or wrong from how I feel.  How, how I see other people react to such things, such as murder, when an innocent gets killed and they have five kids left by their-self.  That’s why, that’s how I view what’s right and what’s wrong.
column584: I get my views from what’s right or wrong from how I feel.  How, how I see other people react to such things, such as murder, when an innocent gets killed and they have five kids left by their-self.  That’s why, that’s how I view what’s right and what’s wrong.
column585: The respondent makes decisions based on their intuition and feelings, often influenced by their mother's guidance, and believes that many people have lost their sense of right and wrong due to self-centeredness, while also emphasizing the importance of confronting wrong actions in others and feeling guilty for not standing up for friends.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good or bad, right or wrong?
R:From the way I was raised.
I:OK.
R:If I was younger and I was told not to do that, then when I’m older it reflects on me. That’s it, I guess. You can’t say certain things, so that’s on me now. Like, when I was younger, you weren’t allowed to curse. So it’s like really in my system that if I do curse, I know that it was bad for me to curse. It’s just like a conscience thing.
I:Do you ever feel a point where you feel kind of like, there’s a gray area where you didn’t really know what to do? Have you ever had a situation like that?
R:No.
I:So, what do you think makes something right or wrong?
R:Umm, the consequence afterwards.
I:Ok. Give me an example of the kind of consequence you might get after.
R:Well, if you save a baby, you’ll be praised. You know, you don’t get in trouble for it. But if you shake a baby, you get in trouble for it. It depends on what happens afterwards. What is the outcome. Or how you feel.
I:What if you didn’t know that it was wrong to shake a baby?
R:It’s still wrong; you just didn’t know that it was. So your mind frame, it doesn’t depend, it’s still wrong.
I:So let’s say, you shook the baby and the baby got injured in another (??) no other consequences.
R:It’s very wrong. Yeah, because that’s a consequence, because the baby got injured. That’s a consequence; the outcome is that the baby was hurt, so it’s still wrong.
I:Even if nobody else thought it was wrong?
R:No
I:What if the baby didn’t get hurt?
R:I still feel like it was wrong because that’s, basically that’s child abuse. Because it’s a baby. You don’t do that to a child. You don’t do that to anybody, but it’s still a child. You have no reason to shake a baby. You have no reason to hurt a baby. Because they’re just babies, they don’t understand, so.
I:I’m trying to think of an example of something that could be potentially wrong, but not because of consequences. I mean, you can think of things where, let’s say that you lie to someone. And nobody got hurt.
R:I still feel like that’s wrong because you’re supposed to tell the truth.
I:So if there were no consequences, why was it wrong?
R:It’s the moral of it. It’s really basically the moral, that you know you’re not supposed to lie. You know you did something, you should tell. If your acts, you should tell the truth.
I:Ok, so I gave an example of one. Are there any other behaviors, actions, incidents, thoughts, or whatever that you think would be wrong regardless of consequences that you can think of? Regardless of what happened afterwards, nothing would happen to you or anyone else. (pause). Not off the bat, you can’t think of one? (pause) Ok. Some people say that there are no final rights and wrongs. That everything is relative and that morality is simply what people make of it. Do you agree or disagree with that?

It’s very wrong. Yeah, because that’s a consequence, because the baby got injured. That’s a consequence; the outcome is that the baby was hurt, so it’s still wrong. No I still feel like it was wrong because that’s, basically that’s child abuse. Because it’s a baby. You don’t do that to a child. You don’t do that to anybody, but it’s still a child. You have no reason to shake a baby. You have no reason to hurt a baby. Because they’re just babies, they don’t understand, so. You know you did something, you should tell. If your acts, you should tell the truth.
column588: The respondent's understanding of right and wrong is primarily shaped by their upbringing and personal conscience, emphasizing that actions are judged based on their consequences and moral implications, while also acknowledging the influence of social observations on their decision-making.
column589:
I:Yeah. How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:How I feel.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide?
R:Sometimes it’s hard.  But usually, it’ll be easy because if I feel like it’s wrong, then I won’t do it.  But when it involves other people that you love, and their opinions, it’s a hard decision.
I:Right.  Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Harder.  Because – were you going to ask because?
I:Yeah.
R:It’s gotten harder because as you get older, your choices and your decisions that you have to make, become greater.  When I was 12, or when I was in 10th grade, I had to decide what to wear to school, or what phone I wanted.  Now I have to decide on what career’s going to be best for me.  I have to decide on how am I going to make my life better for me and someone else.  I have to decide on whether or not the person that I’m planning to live the rest of my life with, is the person that I should be with for the rest of my life.  So my decisions get a little harder because… whether it’s easy or hard, gets a little harder because the decisions or the choices become a little different than what they used to be.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:The reasons behind it.
I:What do you mean?
R:I mean what makes something right or wrong is the reasons why you do it.
I:Ok.  So people’s intentions?
R:Yes, your intentions of why you’re doing it.  Like, I think using drugs is wrong in any case, but it’s right if it’s going to help you live.  But as for, you know, like people who use drugs just because they want to reach a high, or people who kill theirselves because they feel like they can’t get by, I feel like that’s wrong, because you didn’t even give yourself a chance.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:My family.  My mom and my grandma.

But when it involves other people that you love, and their opinions, it’s a hard decision. Harder.  Because – were you going to ask because? It’s gotten harder because as you get older, your choices and your decisions that you have to make, become greater.  When I was 12, or when I was in 10th grade, I had to decide what to wear to school, or what phone I wanted.  Now I have to decide on what career’s going to be best for me.  I have to decide on how am I going to make my life better for me and someone else.  I have to decide on whether or not the person that I’m planning to live the rest of my life with, is the person that I should be with for the rest of my life.  So my decisions get a little harder because… whether it’s easy or hard, gets a little harder because the decisions or the choices become a little different than what they used to be.  The reasons behind it. I mean what makes something right or wrong is the reasons why you do it. Yes, your intentions of why you’re doing it.  Like, I think using drugs is wrong in any case, but it’s right if it’s going to help you live.  But as for, you know, like people who use drugs just because they want to reach a high, or people who kill theirselves because they feel like they can’t get by, I feel like that’s wrong, because you didn’t even give yourself a chance.  My family.  My mom and my grandma.
column591: The respondent primarily relies on their feelings and intuition to determine right from wrong, finds decision-making harder as they face more significant life choices influenced by their parents, and is currently grappling with the moral dilemma of whether to keep their child, ultimately leaning towards taking responsibility for their actions despite initial thoughts of abortion.

column583:
I:Okay.   Where do your own personal views of right and wrong come from?
R:My mom.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:(pause) I think it’s, if you have a conscience it’s the way you feel after you do it, or it’s what it’s telling you to do.  Cause it’s pretty, I think conscience is pretty much a conditional response that you learn from your parents that is passed on.  And that it’s basically one of the best things to tell you if it’s right or wrong cause it pretty much gives you the gut feeling of it, what the overall tone is.  And you can’t do that.  And you can argue anything, but you can’t argue against your conscience.  You can’t argue against your gut feeling.
