Because I don’t like to hold onto one thing for too long. Kind of like I think I jump around really quickly, I think if something is wrong I get annoyed. I just go with what my gut says.  It’s usually right. And then if you get too involved with the principles of things, like, if you follow everything like to the letter of the law, like if you do something wrong, like the abortion issue, you can kill someone.  But it’s wrong, it doesn’t matter.  The courts says it’s legal.  If your gut tells you it’s wrong it’s wrong. I think it’s actually ingrained in you, but that’s just a reaffirment. I think it’s pretty much as your conditioning as a child.  You know that helps conditioning, your religion. Pretty much.  Except for the religious fundamentalist, cause those are the people that are getting us all killed.  If people think that things are justified by religion, bombing people isn’t going to justify anything.  It’s just gonna, it’s gonna require retaliation, which they will retaliate, and then you’ll be on a downward spiral to hell. Yes. Yes.  Just because something is written about in the Bible or the Koran or any of those religious texts, it doesn’t mean that that’s what the message is.  I mean they’ve stone, they used to stone people for prostitution, we don’t do that anymore, cause it’s morally wrong.  The whole message, once Christianity came or anything, you just moved passed that and you forgive people. What do you mean by that?  Like how people get the wrong judgment or? Because you don’t look at the whole picture. You just look at they stoned her, that’s not going to teach you anything. It’s like ooh, we can, we can take it, see in the Bible they stoned people, see we can kill people, that’s not anything.  That’s not the point of this.  The point is to move past it and to forgive. My mom. (pause) I think it’s, if you have a conscience it’s the way you feel after you do it, or it’s what it’s telling you to do.  Cause it’s pretty, I think conscience is pretty much a conditional response that you learn from your parents that is passed on.  And that it’s basically one of the best things to tell you if it’s right or wrong cause it pretty much gives you the gut feeling of it, what the overall tone is.  And you can’t do that.  And you can argue anything, but you can’t argue against your conscience.  You can’t argue against your gut feeling.
column585: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on gut feelings and social influences from friends and parents, while also acknowledging the importance of moral teachings from religious texts, and expresses guilt over not standing up for others when they should.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I figure, I take a rational approach to it.  Cause like, the problem with like your conscience and feeling, that’s good, but it can get distorted.  Rationality does not get distorted.
I:What do you think rationality comes from?
R:It comes from discerning right from wrong, thinking about it, and choosing the right path.  When applied to right and wrong.
I:Okay.  In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It depends on the situation.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:Harder.
I:Okay.
R:Cause there’s actually more and more shades of gray.
I:Because you’re getting older or because the world’s changing or?
R:Because I’ve gotten older.  You start seeing things differently.
I:Okay.
R:You get over the whole super hero complex, and just look at the big guys, and some people are gray, it’s just confusing.
I:Well how do you typically, personally make these kind of decisions of what’s right and wrong?
R:Think about it, ask people, get information, shop on the internet, look around.  Call the schools, visit them, stuff like that.  Gather as much information as possible.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Oooh, now we’re going into deep philosophy.
I:Yeah.
R:Well I wouldn’t say a consequentialist or an intentionalist or a naturalist, I’m probably a combination of the three, where I believe that the intentions matter but so do the consequences.  That things should follow the natural course, so it’s like, it’s really weird, you go into some deep philosophy there.
I:Yeah.  So do you feel that you try to apply those ideas when you like,
R:I think you naturally apply them when you read.
I:Okay.
R:Like if someone did evil and there were good ends, the ends are sort of the x evil and if there were good intentions and have evil ends, is the affect to the tribe any good?
I:Yeah, good question.  So do you have any sense of what you’d put more weight on the intentions or the consequences or?
R:No. You see, the thing is if the killer goes out to kill the biggest serial killer ever, then that’s a good thing, but he did it for evil reasons.  What’s if someone believes that there’s terrorist and they go out and kill them, they had good intentions to keep people from getting hurt, but they kill people a lot.  And let’s say that these people were sanctioned by the government, and then what?  That’s where it gets tricky and I really don’t have an answer.
I:Yeah.  You said one of the things you like to talk to people about and debate is the war in Iraq, so how do you feel, do you feel that that’s morally right or wrong?
R:I think it’s about oil and nothing more.  If it was about something more than oil, then we’d be in Rwanda and Sudan right now where there’s ethnic cleansing going on.  But we’re not, so I actually know it’s about nothing more than oil.
I:Okay.   Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Probably abortion. Things against innocent people, that’s always wrong.
I:That was going to be my next question was why is that always wrong, but is that one of your principles that hurting innocent people is always wrong?
R:Yeah.  Even if sanctioned.
I:Okay. From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:My siblings, my older brother, and my parents.  The TV, just joking.
column587: I figure, I take a rational approach to it.  Cause like, the problem with like your conscience and feeling, that’s good, but it can get distorted.  Rationality does not get distorted. It comes from discerning right from wrong, thinking about it, and choosing the right path.  When applied to right and wrong. It depends on the situation. Harder. Cause there’s actually more and more shades of gray. Because I’ve gotten older.  You start seeing things differently. You get over the whole super hero complex, and just look at the big guys, and some people are gray, it’s just confusing. Think about it, ask people, get information, shop on the internet, look around.  Call the schools, visit them, stuff like that.  Gather as much information as possible.  Oooh, now we’re going into deep philosophy. Well I wouldn’t say a consequentialist or an intentionalist or a naturalist, I’m probably a combination of the three, where I believe that the intentions matter but so do the consequences.  That things should follow the natural course, so it’s like, it’s really weird, you go into some deep philosophy there. I think you naturally apply them when you read. Like if someone did evil and there were good ends, the ends are sort of the x evil and if there were good intentions and have evil ends, is the affect to the tribe any good? No. You see, the thing is if the killer goes out to kill the biggest serial killer ever, then that’s a good thing, but he did it for evil reasons.  What’s if someone believes that there’s terrorist and they go out and kill them, they had good intentions to keep people from getting hurt, but they kill people a lot.  And let’s say that these people were sanctioned by the government, and then what?  That’s where it gets tricky and I really don’t have an answer. I think it’s about oil and nothing more.  If it was about something more than oil, then we’d be in Rwanda and Sudan right now where there’s ethnic cleansing going on.  But we’re not, so I actually know it’s about nothing more than oil. Probably abortion. Things against innocent people, that’s always wrong. Yeah.  Even if sanctioned.  My siblings, my older brother, and my parents.  The TV, just joking.
column588: The respondent makes decisions primarily through rationality, influenced by their parents and siblings, and acknowledges the complexity of moral issues, particularly regarding euthanasia and abortion, while expressing a belief in a moral obligation to help others within the community.

I:So normally how easy or hard is it for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s pretty easy.
I:Do you feel like deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the last couple years at all?
R:Uh, nope.
I:Okay, do you feel like your views about right and wrong have changed at all in the last couple years?
R:Yeah, probably a little bit.
I:How so?
R:Well just, I tend to, you know I tend to make judgments about situations and I’ll wait and evaluate and then make a decision, um, but I think I’ve, I think I understand more now that I have to look into each individual situation before judging an action that somebody else does and look, you know, understand that person, that individual person, what, the reason that they did that.  so I have a little more, and I, before evaluating a situation I will have a little more leeway, I’ll give somebody else a little more maybe credibility before saying what they did was wrong.
I:Any particular reason why you think that’s changed?
R:Yeah, I think I had, there was an event where my, at my high school, they call it Beach Week where all the seniors go to the beach for a week after graduation, basically do a lot of drugs and buy drugs and they start um, they did a lot of drinking and I was there and I was just very, um, I was very displeased with the whole situation because I thought it was too excessive and it was too excessive.  But these kids were basically like you know we’re your friends and you have to understand kind of what we’re doing here and how this is a week thing and I just said well this isn’t just going to be a week thing, you know you’re going to start developing habits here and sure enough they do it while it’s there and they go off and so they’re having major issues at school now.  But, but I still had to, I couldn’t make the immediate judgment, I had to kind of understand and go through for each individual person, the reason they were doing things.  So I think there just need to be more thought in a situation.
I:So this is just generally, kind of an abstract question, but what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Uh, you’ve got me, that’s a good question, I don’t know the answer to that one.
I:Do you think that maybe rules or laws or consequences or how it feels or anything like that may have something to do with it or is it not necessarily that clear?
R:No, I don’t think there’s a clear answer to what is right or wrong.
I:So would you say that that is something that’s unclear, um, to a lot of people or do you think that it’s unknowable like in a general sense? Or how would you describe how, in what way is it unclear is what I'm asking you?
R:Well I think for a lot of people I think they rely on religion as a guidance but religion doesn’t have all the answers, it just has a philosophical and you know uh, rules that people kind of developed over time that they’ve learned, they bring down to these groups and they decided that’s what we want.  So I don’t, I don’t know—can you say the question again—?
I:That’s okay, I was just asking if you thought that knowing kind of what makes something right or wrong is just something that’s confusing and hard to know for most people including like yourself or do you think it’s something that’s ultimately unknowable to people?
R:Yeah, we— okay, I think it’s very confusing and I think it’s something that people don’t know.  people try to come up with ways in which they can guide themselves and religion is one of those ways that is a way to provide a stable guide because it’s hard, it’s very hard for an individual to say , it’s hard for an individual to sit there and think and, and not have some guidance, you know, because then you can feel lost if you don’t have a certain, you know if you don’t have a guide.
I:So where would you say your ideas about morality or right and wrong have come from or what has influenced you the most?
R:I don’t know, I guess my education probably and my number one, my first, um, base for judgment there.  And family and discussions with people and books that I’ve read by I can’t even think of a specific book that would affect that.

column586:
I:I love that question.  How do you know what’s good and bad and right and wrong in life?
R:I guess just morals I’ve been taught since I’m little on how it would affect people.
I:in general is it easy or hard for you to decide what’s right and wrong?
R:pretty easy, I think.
I:has it gotten easier in the past couple years or has it gotten harder?
R:um, I think it’s always been pretty easy, I’ve always known what I thought was right, I mean there are some things that are on the borderline but not that they don’t really affect people as much, that means like if they really could affect people I’d know pretty easy.
I:what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong, you were talking a little bit about science and religion…?
R:I think it’s the individual who thinks it’s right or wrong.  I know that some things I think are right but other people think something else is right and nothing really IS right, you don’t know.  It’s just what you think so I can’t say it’s right for that person, but I know it’s right for me.
I:so what kinds of feelings when you get that something is like right for you?
R:um, I guess just what I believe and what I think, my thought process I guess, like what I actually think it could be.  It could be right, yeah, I don’t know, it’s just something you know.  Yeah.
I:I know, it’s a really hard question.
R:it’s just something you know inside I guess, yeah.
I:are there any actions that are always wrong no matter what?
R:well, yeah.
I:so what are those?
R:actions that are always wrong?  Well anything that can hurt people, in bad ways, anything that would be harmful to others or yourself.  Yeah, and like, I mean…I mean, I don’t think of it as the commandments, but the commandments are the reason that, they’re called the commandments for a reason, like most of those things are wrong, so just because morally they’re wrong.
I:so are there gray areas like you’re not supposed to, like thou shalt not kill, but is war okay and what do you do in situations like that?
R:well in self defense of course.  It would be nice if you didn’t have to use self defense because other people shouldn’t be attacking you in that situation, but if you have to then it’s alright, it’s right I guess, well it’s not right but it’s what you have to do.  War…war is of course an iffy issue.  I’m not that political in war stuff, I don’t, I’m not really that political at all, I’m pretty liberal though too, I mean I would like peace of course and sometimes yes, war helps promote peace but I’m not really a huge fan of certain wars .
I:so generally your rule of thumb seems to be what’s gonna happen to other people?
R:yeah, yeah.
I:from where have you acquired your moral views, where have they come from?
R:I guess just growing up, what your parents teach you and then you always, you question it of course, but there are certain things that you don’t even need to question if you just know that it is right or wrong.  Um, I mean, most people, unless…yeah, I don’t know—
I:--so your parents taught you most of…
R:well like your parents, school, the public, like what you see, what you learn about, like the news.  Yeah.
I:but it seems like you interact with that too, like you make your own…
R:you make your own…it’s relative, but there are certain things that yeah…

column588: The respondent plans to use the hypothetical $100,000 inheritance primarily for education and living expenses, reflecting a strong sense of responsibility towards their parents and future stability, while also acknowledging the influence of their upbringing on their moral decision-making, which they believe is guided by personal beliefs rather than religion, emphasizing the importance of considering the impact of actions on others.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I think just morals.
I:Where do your morals come from?
R:Personal morals.  Personal morals, what I believe based on my beliefs.  I guess it comes from your parents a little bit, and from school and from just common knowledge.
I:Okay.  So do you know other people who have similar situations to you who have different morals?
R:Yeah, I probably have separate morals.
I:How do you think that's - how do you think you have different?  How did that come about?
R:I think it's just personal stuff, like everybody has their own personal feelings towards things.  I'm probably a little more open-minded than some people, and I'm also not as - I'm outgoing, but not crazy outgoing.  So maybe something that they would do that they think is fine, I might not.  I think it's just personal.
I:So generally is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Easy to decide between right and wrong, hard for me to decide between right and - right number one and right number two.
I:Okay.  And what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:How you feel about it, I guess, and obviously if it's completely illegal and immoral, that's another situation.
I:So how do you decide what's immoral?
R:I think how it affects other people, and how it affects yourself.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:This maybe very big but I get kind of a gut reaction, that may have to do with things my parents have said, experiences I’ve had in the past where I’ve realized I’ve done something wrong after them and now if I am in a similar situation I can correct it from my previous mistakes.  You know, I use the basics, like lying, cheating, being nasty, like I just, I think interacting with so many different people at Penn shows me what I consider wrong and what I dislike and so I just know, red flag comes up when something similar happens and I could be in the place to do the same thing and I think back to it and think do I really want to end up like that because I didn’t like how that ended up?  I really just put it through my like sifting system.
I:And do you feel like that’s usually pretty easy or difficult?
R:Yeah, I think I really have an easy time knowing what’s wrong and right.  I think I'm a good judge of that.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, I mean I would have to say right or wrong, the basic religious fundamentals that I’ve learned growing up.  My, you know, Jewish ethics and such, and also my parents’ values and that what they consider to be right and wrong and tolerable and intolerable has really affected me.  I think it’s a nurtured thing, a lot more nurture than nature and that you’re growing up, if you grow up with a certain system of values or beliefs, that it’s very unique what you may believe to be right and wrong.
I:So you said you acquired your moral views from your parents, from religion, any other factors you think there?
R:Probably my friends, too.  I think a lot of my friends have similar moral and some have religious views so I find that to be comforting and I surround myself with people who do feel the same way.
I:Have your views about right and wrong changed over the past three years, or not?
R:I would say they have with probably specific to college, like um, um, more like socially related, drug-use, alcohol-use, more so actions related to those that I may have deemed inappropriate in the past and found that in certain situations I find it tolerable and okay.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide what is good and bad and right and wrong and why?
R:I think I have a really strong set of standards for what’s right and wrong, and maybe that’s from my parents.  But also, I don’t know, I think that you should always kinda be kind to people or benefit other people in some way.  But not, I mean, not being self-destructive at all.  So I think I make my decisions based around that.
I:So helping people without crossing over into hurting yourself?
R:Yeah.
I:Is this usually pretty easy or a hard thing to do, to decide either what is right and wrong or to do right and wrong?
R:I think I’ve always been a really quick decision maker.  Making decisions has never been hard for me, so in terms of wrong and right, it kinda clicks in my head.
I:So what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?  You said you have a really strong kind of sense of that.  Where does that come from?
R:I mean, that comes from analyzing things a lot and I’ve always been somebody who really thinks a lot about things.  I guess that thinking and processing in my head makes me automatically decide what’s right and wrong, because I like that better than what I’ve thought before, even if it’s not related to -
I:To a particular decision.  So what if that goes against things that you felt before or general wisdom or something?  What would you do if those were in conflict?

R:I haven’t been so involved in it lately.

column589:

R:Probably more difficult just because the decisions have gotten really difficult so.

column591: The respondent plans to donate 10% of an inheritance to charity and invest the rest in a house, guided by the belief that one should allocate a portion of their income for charity, while also relying on intuition and parental advice to navigate moral dilemmas, particularly in a confusing roommate situation, and ultimately values good intentions in decision-making.

column583:
I:Okay.  So what, um, where do you think your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um partly just from general society and partly from what I just think I guess.
I:Okay.  How do you, um, if, there’s, you know if right and wrong is just up to the individual person, how do you personally decide what’s right and wrong?  What is it that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, I don’t know.
I:Okay.
R:Um, what I think, maybe if it’s about somebody else, what would you feel if you were that person, things like that.
I:Okay.  And how, if um, where, you said that there are some things that are right and wrong for everybody?  Where do those come from?  What’s the criteria on something that’s right or wrong for everyone?
R:Um, I think it’s kind of like rules for society. Like killing or stealing or raping or something.
I:Right.
R:But I think other than the common like, this is wrong in this circumstance, like you should never kill anyone really, or you should never rape somebody.  I think that’s up to the individual.
I:What if a whole society decided, or we as a society decided that it’s okay to kill people.  Would that be all right?
R:No.
I:Why not?
R:Because killing is bad.
I:But what makes it bad?
R:You are, hurting another person.  No, well they don’t feel it after they’re dead.  Uh, I have no idea.

column585: The respondent believes that while certain moral absolutes exist, such as the wrongness of killing, individual perspectives on right and wrong are influenced by societal norms and personal reflections, and they emphasize the importance of hard work and fairness in academic integrity, while also acknowledging the role of friends and parents in shaping their decisions.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide what is good and bad or right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t know. I think I have some sort of… I think it just comes from internally and I think much of that comes from my parents but I think it just like big belief in my common sense like I think that that rules a lot of stuff.
I:Is it generally pretty easy for you to figure out what’s wrong or right?
R:Yes, mostly because I’m many times a very black and white person but also it’s not always good. And in so many cases, it does help. I just know I don’t want to do it so I don’t do it.
I:Do you think it has gotten easier or harder the past couple of years?
R:I think for a little bit, harder and maybe now a little easier because I’ve kind of tested the waters a little and I’ve decided what, you know you kind of decide what you want to do right and wrong in your own life. After you try some stuff, you decide, it didn’t really feel good or like… I think it might be inherent. I think if it’s something you would feel good about at the end of the day, if it’s something you feel, if it’s something you’re not going to second guess and it’s definitely right but I think you sometimes second guess things that are right anyway. You may think a lot of times things that are right are really hard and I also think sometimes things that are right aren’t necessarily the thing that you should you know like things sometimes what people think of as right are really restricted and then they end up doing something else that’s way off the other way.
I:Do you have something you’re thinking about in particular?
R:I just I mean I know people that grew up in very sheltered households where like you know like I have a friend who’s like very, very Catholic and her family, she grew up in this household where she didn’t know any other way and she got to college and she kind of went crazy but she also like doesn’t feel good about going crazy because it’s wrong and there’s like this whole mishmash going on in her head. She just doesn’t know what’s going on and I feel like having something being so set as right and wrong it’s like kind of like heavy basis.
I:So from where have you acquired your moral views?  Who has influenced you?
R:My parents. I think my friends. I mean I think I can talk about some of that stuff with my friends and maybe some of my teachers and a lot of it is just based on what you see and what you experience. Much of the time you see something that you don’t like and you decide you don’t want to do it.
I:Have your views about right and wrong changed in the past three years? Two years?
R:Yeah, I would say a little bit.
I:How so?
R:I think if you go back three or so years, I was much more sheltered like a lot of things teenagers did were like wrong and I think it was just because I think they were like scary and foreign to me and I think now I realize that they’re not so wrong that they can be fun instead of dangerous.
I:You mean like drugs, alcohol, that type of stuff or…?
R:I think yes, I think that alcohol for one is definitely the case. I think I used to think it was this really big deal scary thing, like it can be obviously.
I:Yeah, abuse, yeah.
R:But not really you know like especially when the teenagers use it like, yes, some people are unhealthy but like it really is okay and like very commonplace. It can be fun and make me a little happy.
I:Is there anything that you wont compromise morals-wise, in terms of morality?
R:Yes, I mean most drugs. I have  like many. I don’t even really like smoke marijuana but like sometimes. Other than that, I won’t touch a thing. I think that there’s a certain level of like feminine self integrity that you need to hold.

column591: The respondent makes decisions based on a combination of personal intuition and common sense influenced by their parents, expressing a desire to support their family financially, while also acknowledging the complexities of right and wrong shaped by personal experiences and social influences, particularly in relation to their friends and moral views that have evolved over time.

column589:
I:And how do you normally decide or know what is good or bad, right or wrong in life?
R:Well, like I think I was raised well enough to be able to figure it out pretty quick.
I:And so is it something that you think comes easy to you or is it difficult ever?
R:I mean, sometimes it’s difficult, but everyone makes wrong decisions at some point in their lives, so.
I:And do you feel like as you get older that it gets easier or harder?
R:In some ways, both.  Because you learn more about people, sometimes it makes it more difficult to decide, it makes a bigger gray area between it.
I:That’s a good decision.  And so what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong then?
R:What makes something right or wrong?  How you feel about it in the end.  If you feel that, if you feel good about it then it’s probably the right decision, but if you don’t feel well, if you don’t feel that it is a good idea then you made the wrong decision.
I:And you said, so where do you think like those notions of right or wrong came from, for you, you said.
R:Probably my parents.
column590: Well, like I think I was raised well enough to be able to figure it out pretty quick. I mean, sometimes it’s difficult, but everyone makes wrong decisions at some point in their lives, so. In some ways, both.  Because you learn more about people, sometimes it makes it more difficult to decide, it makes a bigger gray area between it.  What makes something right or wrong?  How you feel about it in the end.  If you feel that, if you feel good about it then it’s probably the right decision, but if you don’t feel well, if you don’t feel that it is a good idea then you made the wrong decision.  Probably my parents.
column591: The respondent would use a $100,000 inheritance to pay for medical school due to its high costs, believes their understanding of right and wrong stems from their upbringing by their parents, and trusts their parents' guidance when unsure about moral decisions, while also recognizing that morality can be relative and emphasizing the importance of helping others.

column583:
I:Well, say a little, you said that you didn’t really question what was right and wrong.  Where do your ideas of what’s right and wrong come from for you?
R:Right and wrong, uh, I suppose a combination of society, my parents, my own personal moral views, which are basically made up of how my parents raised me in the end, I mean.
I:What makes something right or wrong?
R:Right and wrong?  I mean how it’s going to affect me and how it’s going to affect you know, the people around me, I suppose.
I:And so if you’ve got a choice that you have to make, what are the things you look at to make the right choice?
R:I mean, if I did it could I get in trouble, would I be disappointed in myself if I got caught, like would my parents be disappointed in me or mad at me, uh, I don’t know, uh.
column584: Right and wrong, uh, I suppose a combination of society, my parents, my own personal moral views, which are basically made up of how my parents raised me in the end, I mean. Right and wrong?  I mean how it’s going to affect me and how it’s going to affect you know, the people around me, I suppose. I mean, if I did it could I get in trouble, would I be disappointed in myself if I got caught, like would my parents be disappointed in me or mad at me, uh, I don’t know, uh.
column585: The respondent acknowledges a clear understanding of right and wrong, influenced by societal norms and parental guidance, yet admits to sometimes choosing to engage in activities like drinking, which they know to be wrong, primarily due to the immediate enjoyment and peer acceptance, while also feeling guilt over minor transgressions and recognizing the impact of their actions on others.

column588: The respondent would prioritize saving the money for their mother's needs and college expenses rather than making big purchases, relying on their intuition about future regrets, and believes that their moral compass is shaped by personal feelings and upbringing, emphasizing the importance of helping others while maintaining their own well-being.
column589:
I:Okay, how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I guess it’s kind of a gut feeling.  I don't know, I just - like you have your - yeah, if it feels right.  I guess, I mean, afterwards you kind of know because - or I guess, you can look at it like, “Am I going to regret this later?”
I:Regret, okay.
R:But I mean, I think it’s kind of just a “shoot from the hip” kind of thing.
I:Is that generally pretty easy to decide what’s right and wrong?
R:Yeah, I don’t tend to struggle over decisions too much, so.
I:Okay, and has that changed over the past couple years?
R:No, not really.  I think I’ve always been that way.
I:Okay, that’s fair.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Well, I guess, it’s like how you feel after it’s done.  I mean, there's always the social concept of it.  How does society look at it, but I guess, I’d be more concerned with how I can live with it, and whatnot.
I:So what if somebody was to go around saying, “It really feels great to me to stab other people at the bookstore.”
R:Yeah, I mean, obviously that’s wrong because even if it feels good to you it obviously sucks for somebody else.  So I mean, yeah, that’s pretty crappy.  But I’m a big believer in do whatever you want in your life so long as it doesn’t adversely affect other people.
I:Okay, so harm could be say, wrong.
R:Yeah, exactly, yeah.
I:So what about war?
R:I mean, you know, I definitely believe that there are times or places, it’s like - it’s, yeah, not the right thing to do, but it’s not the wrong thing to do.  It’s unavoidable.  I don’t believe that everything can just be talked out.  Sometimes it just comes to force, so that answers the question.
I:So maybe that’s a grey area in there?
R:I mean, yeah, it’s kind of a grey area, and it’s kind of something that people have to - large groups of people obviously have to decide together to do.
I:Okay, so from where have you acquired your moral views?  Who’s influenced you?
R:Probably my dad more than anything.
I:And why your dad?  Like, why not your mom, I guess.
R:Well, I don't know, I mean, we were always like, I mean, we obviously - we’re a pretty close family, and it’s not like we’re not close with my mom.  And this - I mean, this really does kind of go with, for all three of us, but we were just so extremely close with my dad.  He was like in a lot of ways, he’s your dad, but my best friend kind of too.  So I mean, that just had like -
I:It’s not a flaw of your mom, it’s just that you were close to your dad.
R:Yeah, exactly.  Well, he was kind of - because he did the same thing I do now actually.  He owned his own business, so when we were sick he was a lot times the one that stayed home with us.  He took us on fieldtrips for school.  I used to go on trips with him sometimes.  We would go - we went to Palm Springs a couple times, went golfing, just the two of us.  And he did little trips with all three of us individually, and then sometimes just, yeah, he would take us.
I:So you had a lot time to talk about things.
R:Yeah, exactly.  We were just like really, really close.  And it’s kind of funny because my friends were pretty close with him.  And so were my brother’s and sister’s friends, so he’s like, yeah, because he was one of those, like, he never missed any kind of sport’s thing because he could make that kind of time.  So he was always around.

R:Um mine come from my parents, you know, they taught me what to do and what not to do from an early age, so.

R:Um, well just from what I’ve been taught in school and from my friends and everything, I know that you know what, what I should do, should I come and face problems, but, just from parents and growing up and everything.
I:Okay um, and, can you give me any examples of something that might be right or wrong, or?
R:Um, I guess I mean, it’s never happened to me, but I mean like to be offered something like alcohol and you know that, you’ve been raised to know that you shouldn’t have it, I think just to say no, you’ve been taught to say no.

column585: The respondent believes that their sense of right and wrong primarily comes from their parents' teachings, and they make decisions by considering the potential consequences of their actions, while also noting that they have not faced significant peer pressure or moral dilemmas in their experiences.
column586:
I:Okay.  How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Um, well I know because I, I go back to my beliefs, what is right and wrong and things that I’m not sure about, even with my beliefs, I definitely pray about, I talk to my family about, so if I’m ever not sure, I talk to people who are closest to me about it.
I:Okay.  In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s easy just, I mean, for the most part.  There are always the problems where you’re not quite sure what you should be doing, but I know like by gut instinct what feels right in situations, so.
I:Where do you think that gut instinct comes from?  Do you think it’s just some natural thing we all have?  Does it develop somehow, what’s going on?
R:Um, I think in some cases it’s a natural instinct.  You know, like when you’re in a situation if you should be there or not, just a feeling that you get but also I think that it, it comes from my certain beliefs sometimes.  Like I have to think, would this be something that I would want to do, and be proud of doing, just those kind of things.
I:Okay.  Do you think deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or more difficult over the past couple of years?
R:Um, I believe it’s gotten easier, overall.  I mean, the problems that I’m dealing with, trying to figure things out with, have changed, just because of the different environments that I’m involved in now.  But I think that it’s become easier because I’ve seen different things, gone through different experiences, no longer in the drama of high school and everything.  So it’s definitely changed.
I:Okay.  What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think if it’s, I guess bottom line good or bad for you, I mean if it comes out and it’s something that you really shouldn’t have done and definitely it was the wrong thing to do it, but I mean if it feels right, if it’s right for you at the time, then I think it’s the right thing to do.
I:Okay, so for you personally, what are some of your guidelines for what makes things right or wrong?
R:Um, I just, I have very strong morals so if it goes along with my faith, my beliefs, my morals then it’s the right thing for me to do, and that’s just something that I know right away.  Like, going back to the drinking and party thing, I just, it’s something I’m not interested in doing, it goes against what I’ve been taught by my parents and my faith, so it’s just not something I want to do.
I:Um, yeah, it sounds like you have some really strong guiding principles in terms of your beliefs and morals and things.  Do you have a sense for, um, do you just kind of follow those to follow them, because you think it’s important to follow rules or do you also think about kind of the, what’s behind the rules, like why they’re good to follow them, do you know what I mean?
R:Yeah, definitely, and like I think of, of course, consequences and everything but also it’s, like I said earlier, it’s something like will I later think of it and still be proud of my actions, it’s something that, it’s more like will you want to do the things that you give into, is it that big of a temptation.

It’s easy just, I mean, for the most part.  There are always the problems where you’re not quite sure what you should be doing, but I know like by gut instinct what feels right in situations, so. column588: The respondent emphasizes the importance of strong morals and beliefs, shaped by family and faith, in guiding their decisions about right and wrong, while also relying on gut instincts and the desire to help others, particularly in light of current global issues.
column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I just kind of base it off of what I’ve been taught, religiously and also morally.  I know in my heart if it’s something that I’m just not comfortable doing.  If I’m not sure, I always talk to family, friends, trusted parents’ opinions, and that base itself.  Just things that I would feel uncomfortable doing in my heart.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:I would say it’s pretty easy.  I have kind of a gut feeling with some things.  Of course, there are issues that I would struggle with deciding, but overall, it’s pretty easy to trust my own instincts.
I:Do you think it’s gotten easier or harder over the last 2 years?
R:I think it’s gotten easier just because I’ve kind of settled into my life, and I was finishing up school, wasn’t dealing with all the things I maybe dealt with in high school.  I found that college was a very different time.  So I think it was easier to make those independent decisions.
I:Do you think your views have changed a lot in the last couple of years?
R:I would say so.  They might have changed in maybe in the political sense, or just moral sense, become more open to hear the other opinions of people and other outlooks people can have, other perspectives.  So probably, just become more open, more accepting.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think it’s people’s own opinions, their upbringings and what they’ve been taught religiously, or by their parents or stuff they’ve been taught by their own lifestyle decisions.  I think it’s more just personal decisions, personal choices that people make.
I:So when you make a choice, is it based on consequences, or a feeling that you have?
R:I think it’s based on all of that.  I do consider consequences of some of the actions, I consider how I feel instinctively.  Just how I want to be presented to society, things like that.  All those kind of issues. (00:22:17)
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?
R:I think partly from upbringing, and partly from my religion(s).  Things that I’ve talked about in church, things that I’ve read about, I think I can base a lot of those decisions off of my religion, but also things that I’ve talked about with my family, how have I’ve been raised, what kind of beliefs to have, what kind of morals to have, things like that.d

column591: The respondent emphasizes the importance of family and religious teachings in their decision-making process, stating they would help their family financially and donate to charities if they received a large sum of money, while also acknowledging that their moral views have evolved to be more open and accepting over time.

column583:
I:Where do your own views of right and wrong come from?
R:Um, probably my parents’ religion.  Um, I don’t know, teachers maybe? Little classroom skits and stuff, I don’t know.
I:Okay.  Ah, what, what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, if you feel good about it, I guess, like if you don’t feel guilty doing it.  You know.  Like if you, if you can have a clear conscience afterwards, then it’s right.
I:Then it’s right.  So how, how is it that you decide or know what is good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:Um, I don’t know.  I usually just kind of know.  Like it’s pretty obviously for most things.  Like you know if you’re gonna go, if somebody offers you drugs, obviously the right thing is to say no, I got that kind of from commercials, but, um,  I don’t know.
I:Okay if you, if, um, just, just to sort of see what you mean by this, um, so if you, if somebody can do something with a clear conscience and it’s up to them to decide what’s right and wrong, how do we know, how do they know where to draw the lines, I mean, for example, somebody might cheat on a test, or might do drugs or might even hurt somebody else,--
R:Yeah.
I:How do, ah?
R:I don’t know.
I:Yeah, if they feel okay about it.  You know they don’t, they don’t feel guilty about it.
R:Well I guess if they’re fa—actually, well cheating on a test is probably wrong even if they think it’s right because it’s against the rules, like in school but like if it’s, if there’s like no rule about it and then you still feel good about it, I guess, then it’s okay.
I:So, so there’s some sort of legal rule or, or maybe not necessarily legal but legal as well as school say, rules, or whatever, then those would say what’s right or wrong.
R:Yeah.

column585: The respondent generally makes decisions by consulting trusted friends, believes that moral understanding is influenced by upbringing and peer behavior, and feels that guilt arises from self-imposed standards rather than external pressures, while also acknowledging the role of their parents' religion in shaping their views on right and wrong.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I have no idea.  I just, sort of based on my morals that I grew up with, my parents taught me, like Judaism, what I learn in school, I don’t know, what my friends say that kind of thing.
I:In general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Generally pretty easy, like to know right from wrong.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder over the past 2 years?
R:I think in some areas it’s gotten easier and in some areas it’s gotten harder, like I know in terms of like doing things that are bad, it’s gotten easier, but in terms of like drugs and alcohol and that kind of thing, it’s gotten harder, just cause a lot of my friends are doing it now, and so it’s sort of like, well they’re not dying like they said they would in DARE, they don’t have lung cancer yet, like, harder.
I:Yeah, so it’s partly availability and partly that nothing bad’s happened.
R:Yeah.  Exactly.  I know somebody who smoked pot every day for like 8 months straight and he got an 800 on his SAT’s in math, so it’s like, okay, well if you can sound so stupid in real life and still get an 800 on your math then they’re not really telling us the whole story.  Like that kind of thing.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, how it affects other people and how it affects, or how it could affect myself.  And how it affects people near me, that kind of thing.
I:So what kind of affect or consequences do you have in mind?
R:Um, getting to a judiciary at school.  If you get caught you go through a judiciary at school and they decide your punishment and it goes on your college transcripts and the ultimate consequence is getting kicked out.  Um, having teachers not like me.  Because that’s a big issue too.  You know, I need teacher recommendations and I don’t want to be like the hated person on campus.  And having my parents not trust me, having my friends not like me anymore, having them think that I’m like a horrible person, those are.
I:Are there any actions that are always wrong in themselves, or not?  Or do you think that most things are wrong, all things are wrong because of the consequences that you’re talking about?
R:Um, some things are wrong like stealing something, but a lot of it is influenced by the consequences that you know could arise from it.
I:Why would something like stealing be wrong?  I mean obviously there’s consequences, but is it wrong in itself?
R:Just because it’s not, I don’t know you’re hurting other people, so I guess it’s like a consequence thing.  But you’re stealing from other people, if you’re stealing from a store, then the owners of the store will either have to raise their prices or somehow have to compensate for it.  That’s not fair to them.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?  You mentioned earlier family,
R:From my parents a lot, and, Judaism, and I don’t know, I guess the media a lot.  Sort of like, they sort of portray what’s right and wrong, like what a bad person would do and what a good person would do on TV shows.
I:So more like TV shows kind of thing.
R:Yeah.

column588: The respondent plans to invest a hypothetical inheritance primarily for future needs, influenced by their parents' support and a desire to avoid unnecessary spending, while their moral decision-making is shaped by their upbringing, social influences, and a focus on the consequences of their actions, particularly regarding peer pressure around drugs and alcohol.
column589:
I:And how do you normally decide or know what’s good and bad, or right and wrong in life?
R:I don’t know. I guess it goes back to sort of like, do I have the same values as my parents. I think they sort of like gave me a good set of values. It’s sort of like going off whether or not I feel good about what I, like the action, I don’t know. I have a very like, sensitive… like I guess sensitive, like right and wrong; like I feel bad really easily about things. Like for example, I was at a stoplight yesterday or two days ago, and the light turned green, the person in front of me wouldn’t go. I waited like five seconds, I don’t know a long time, so I said “This is really weird” so I honked. And like three seconds later an ambulance drove by and I felt miserable. I still feel bad about it, which is like not… Yeah, exactly, but I couldn’t see the ambulance and I also had my like radio on so I couldn’t hear it, and I mean, it’s really not something that I should feel that bad about, but I still feel so bad that I like honked at this person and there was like an ambulance coming.
I:So you try to make them do something bad unintentionally?
R:Yeah, exactly.
I:Would you say that it’s generally easy or hard for you to know, to decide between right and wrong?
R:I think it’s generally easy for me to decide what’s right and wrong. Even if it’s something that’s like, even if the wrong path is like an easier path, I still know what’s wrong and I feel that you should…
I:And would you say that deciding between right and wrong has gotten easier or harder for you over the past two years?
R:I think it’s gotten easier. I think it’s because I sort of made more decisions in the past three years that I have, I don’t know, it’s just sort if like easier to choose the right path, I guess. I don’t know.
I:But do you think your views or ideas about right and wrong have changed in the past two years?
R:I mean, I guess they have matured so I’ve been more like, I guess, adult perspective, so I like, three years ago I thought drinking was a terrible thing and like, “Oh, my God you’ll die if you do it” kind of thing, but now like I’ve been in college for a year and I don’t really think of it as like a bad thing. So I guess in sort of those things have changed, but like morally, my core values, haven’t changed.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:I think it sort of like how it affects other people and then also how, I don’t know, it’s sort of like a benefits versus loses thing, so like cheating may benefit you but it hurts other people because they don’t have the same advantage as you. So I guess sort of comparing that.
I:So bad consequences for other people?
R:Yeah, or just like unfair advantages, maybe.
I:What about something that wouldn’t affect anybody else, theoretically anyway but might be bad for you as consequences? Would that still be a wrong thing to do or… but it’s enjoyable so…
R:I guess, well if there are bad consequences for you, then probably it’s still a bad choice—like doing drugs, I guess, is good. I don’t know. Like people enjoy it… I suppose they just like people continue to do it but there’s still like bad consequences in the end.
I:Where do your moral views come from? Where do you think you have gotten your moral views from?
R:I think I’ve gotten them from, I guess, my parents, and then also like Judaism is sort of morally enriched as a religion, like a lot of the laws I learned about I guess in Jewish day school, had to do with how to treat others and then probably a lot from my peers too. My peers are usually pretty morally enlightened.

Yeah, exactly. I think it’s generally easy for me to decide what’s right and wrong. I guess, well if there are bad consequences for you, then probably it’s still a bad choice—like doing drugs, I guess, is good. I don’t know. column591: The respondent primarily makes decisions based on their values instilled by their parents and Judaism, emphasizing the importance of feeling good about their actions, while also acknowledging the influence of social perspectives on morality and the responsibility to help others, particularly those who are unable to help themselves.

column583:
I:so how do you um, so how would you say that you, you um, think of right and wrong, like what makes it, makes something right or wrong for you?
R:Well what makes something right is like when you think of the outcome of what that is and if that’s, if that’s something that you want.  Then it’s the right thing to do.
I:Okay, are there um, are there other kinds of things that make something right or wrong?
R:Um, probably like, probably like how society looks on you based on what you’re doing.  Like if you do something and society looks down on you because it’s probably the wrong thing to do.
I:So how do you decide or know what’s, what’s right and wrong or good and bad?
R:Um, usually I just look at what other people have done and see how they’ve ended up and like use that to make my own decision.
I:Okay, can you give me some examples of stuff?  Like that?
R:Um, like if somebody did drugs and like the outcome was that they got caught and they went to jail or if somebody snuck out of the house and then the outcome is like their parents caught them then that’d be the wrong thing to do, but.
I:Okay, um, so let’s see, um, can you think of anything that might be um, wrong to do but that would, that, in which the outcome would still be okay, though?
R:Um, I’m trying to think.    There’s a lot of things like you could do that the outcome would be okay but like still like your conscience would be really bad, I can’t really think of anything specifically.
I:Okay, so what do you think a feeling of conscience comes from?
R:Um, probably just like you feel guilty like if you like stole your, like stole some money out of like your sister’s piggy bank and she never found out but you’d feel really guilty because like maybe she couldn’t like buy something that she was saving up for.
I:Okay,  sorry.  Um, so what do you think feelings of guilt like that come from, in general?
R:Um, they probably come from like you seeing what happened to the person because of what you did to them, and that makes you feel bad.
I:Because you care about the person, or because it’s kind of just bad to do that kind of thing.
R:Probably a little bit of both, like even if it’s somebody that you don’t care about, you still know it’s like a bad thing to do to that person.
I:Um, how, how do you think most people would know that?
R:Um, I think most people would know that because they’ve seen like other people do it and they wouldn’t want it to happen to them.

Um, probably just like you feel guilty like if you like stole your, like stole some money out of like your sister’s piggy bank and she never found out but you’d feel really guilty because like maybe she couldn’t like buy something that she was saving up for. Um, they probably come from like you seeing what happened to the person because of what you did to them, and that makes you feel bad. Probably a little bit of both, like even if it’s somebody that you don’t care about, you still know it’s like a bad thing to do to that person. Um, I think most people would know that because they’ve seen like other people do it and they wouldn’t want it to happen to them.
column585: The respondent believes that right and wrong are generally clear, often relying on societal perceptions and the outcomes of actions to guide their decisions, while also acknowledging the influence of friends and feelings of guilt when faced with moral dilemmas.
column586:
I:How do you decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:Well I just, I mean I just have like that feeling that tells you what’s right or wrong.  And usually your friends can help you with a decision if you’re having trouble making a decision they can help you.
I:Okay in general has it been easy or hard for you to decide what to do?
R:Its been pretty easy, like I can usually like tell. If it’s something that you cant tell your parents then it’s usually not right.
I:Okay, so do you think that’s gotten easier or harder for you in the last couple of years?
R:I think it’s gotten harder cause like they’re more complex than just right and wrong, you actually have to think about it.  But like overall they haven’t been that hard to tell.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Well, usually it’s like something about morals.  Usually you can know if it would be right or wrong, like drugs or alcohol.
I:Okay and you say you’ve been taught, who’s taught you?
R:Um, just like school and some things are just like kind of like known or like from your religion.
I:So do you think that school and religion are some things that makes something right or wrong?
R:Well school it like helps you teach right and wrong.
I:Okay so what do the rights and wrongs come from?
R:Um, they come from your personal belief, like everyone believes some things differently.  But there are some morals that like are well known, there are things that you just shouldn’t do.
I:Can you give me some examples of some actions that are always wrong?
R:Um, like murdering someone, murder.
I:Okay why do you think that?
R:Um, I think that it’s wrong just because that to take someone’s life away from them, it doesn’t matter what the case is it’s just wrong.
I:Can you give me some examples of something that’s wrong in and of itself?
R:Um, like stealing?
I:Always wrong?
R:Yeah.
I:What about things that are always right, can you give me some examples?
R:Um, like helping someone in need or um, like giving to charity, things like that.
I:What do you think it is that makes those right?
R:Um, well you know that you’re helping people and doing good for society.
I:From where have you acquired your moral views?  Where do they come from?
R:Um, well they come from my religion and my parents and my school.

column588: The respondent primarily relies on intuition and moral teachings from their religion, parents, and school to navigate decisions about right and wrong, while acknowledging that social influences, particularly from friends and parents, play a significant role in their decision-making process, especially when faced with complex situations.

column585: The respondent faced a moral dilemma when a colleague offered her stolen money, ultimately deciding to turn her in after discussing the situation with her parents, who helped her recognize the manipulation and the importance of doing what was right for the broader community rather than just for herself.
column586:
I:And in general, like how do you decide or know what is good and bad, and right and wrong in life?  Like, how do you know?
R:I’m sure my parents have taught me, and they’ve set a role model, a good model.  Yeah.  And just growing up, I was surrounded by really good people and I’m sure that their example has really worn off on me.
I:Is it easy or hard to figure out?
R:It’s easy.
I:For you.  Okay.  And you attribute that to family influence?
R:Mm-mm (yes).  Family and friends and teachers.  Yeah.
I:Has it gotten harder or easier in the last 2 years?
R:Ah, the decisions have gotten bigger.  Um, how to study for a test, do I have to study for a test, um, that kid’s cheating, should I hit him?
I:
R:Um, actually, there was a problem at work, maybe that was, that might have been before we talked last time, where somebody was stealing a lot of money, a lot of money from our stand and I had to decide what I was going to do and it turned out that the management knew that somebody was stealing and I actually, I didn’t find that out until I turned her in.  And that was a really hard decision because we had worked together for about six months beforehand, but she was stealing about $100 a day and um, then she offered to like start paying me.  I didn’t, I didn’t know that she was stealing until she, I saw her and I was like what are you, I asked her what she was doing and then she offered to give me half, so.
I:M3:And how do you, in that situation, like how do you decide what’s right or wrong to do?  What’s the process you go through?
R:M3:Well, the, I guess I was lucky because I knew right away what the correct thing to do was, that I should turn her in and that was obvious, but the problem was that I didn’t want to do that.  So, it’s not a matter of right and wrong, really, it’s a matter of what’s easy, sometimes.  And just it’s really helped, my parents have always helped me realize that the easy thing, the right thing is rarely the easy thing, and so I’ve always remembered that.
I:And what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Um, its effects, its broader effects on people.
I:And what kinds of effects, especially?
R:If um, if it’s going to hurt anybody or if it’s just going to detract from anybody’s happiness in a substantial manner or somebody is going to be badly influenced by it, then that’s what I would consider.
I:Are there any actions that you would see as wrong in themselves, or not?
R:Um, just inherently wrong, like murder and some crimes, but um, there, I feel like there’s always, as much as I believe in absolute right and wrong, well some absolute right and wrong, I think that there’s always a gray area because, especially as I’ve gotten older, I realize that there is always a background story, there’s always more to somebody’s decision than what’s on the surface.
I:Okay.  Anything that makes something wrong, in itself?  Is there a particular thing that makes it wrong?
R:Um, intentionally doing something to hurt somebody else, that has, that will not benefit you and you’re just doing, malicious intent.  That is wrong.
I:Okay, uh-huh.  And where would you say you’ve gotten your moral views?  Like, where do they come from?
R:From like ah, parents and just society, what I’ve kind of observed, of course in movies and books and um, but I think that they’ve really been instilled mostly by close family members and people that I’m in contact with.

column588: The respondent makes decisions primarily based on the values instilled by their parents, emphasizing the importance of helping others, and acknowledges the influence of family, friends, and teachers in shaping their understanding of right and wrong, while also recognizing the complexity of moral dilemmas and the necessity of context in evaluating actions.
column589:
I:So how do you normally decide or know what is good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:I think about things really carefully. I really consider all my options really carefully and hopefully right and wrong would be kind of instinctual, and instinctive. I mean things of—but if its ambiguous I would probably talk to my parents.
I:So in general, is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:Pretty easy. I mean, of course, that good thing that would come about from having had—I think the really difficult to determine problem. I never had to decide whether or not to kill somebody, I guess. So it might be relatively easy decision making period but it is fine.
I:And then, do you see that getting easier or harder over the next few years?
R:Perhaps easier but, like I said I had never had any real big problems, I guess, had to determine the right course.
I:What do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:If it affects some other people. If you make a decision that is going to negatively affect others then it’s probably wrong.
I:So what are some examples of things you’ve seen recently?
R:Just to continue with this example, if I wanted to…I don’t know, not to work for the next two years, if I decide to take the next two years off, and investigate sleep patterns and then I would probably, I’d be relying on my parents, I’d be relying on my fiancé for finances or support and it would be the wrong decision. I mean, of course, it would be the wrong decision for me too because I’d be dumb and lazy but, definitely the wrong choice.
I:So something is wrong if it hurts other people.
R:Yeah.
I:And from where have you acquired your moral views?
R:Probably my parents provided the framework and then I have my experience and my friends kind of filled in the edges, just thinking about it.

column591: The respondent makes careful financial decisions by saving money and helping their fiancé with college loans, relies on instinct and parental advice to determine right from wrong, believes that morality is relative and shaped by their parents and experiences, and emphasizes the importance of helping others while acknowledging that those who do not help themselves may deserve less assistance.

column585: The respondent acknowledges that while they have not faced clear dilemmas of right and wrong, they believe many people know what is right but often disregard the consequences of their actions, attributing their own moral understanding primarily to their parents' teachings, though they sometimes disagree with them; they also express a commitment to honesty and a desire to positively influence friends who may be making poor choices.

Like it’s like, this dude had a sick wife and she was dying and can’t afford the medicine and can’t just look at everything that’s black and white.  Oh I don’t know.  Probably TV or something. Teachers, mom, dad, friends, family, anyone who would yell at me on the streets.
column591: The respondent expresses a desire to spend a hypothetical inheritance on personal pleasures and travel, acknowledges the complexity of moral decisions influenced by social context and personal experiences, and ultimately values parental guidance over religious or self-serving motivations when faced with uncertainty about right and wrong.

column589:
I:How do you normally decide or know what’s good and bad, right and wrong in life?
R:It’s just something that I know.  I have a feeling that it’s bad and it might impact my future I don’t do it.   Or if I can tell that it’s something good, I feel that’s something good and it might help me I’ll do it.
I:Okay.  In general is it easy or hard for you to decide between right and wrong?
R:It’s easy.  It’s just something that I do.  If other people don’t like me for it, they don’t like me for it.
I:Has deciding between right and wrong gotten easier or harder in the past two years?
R:Easier.
I:Why?
R:I’ve had to make more choices between right and wrong and so as I keep making the right ones and maybe one or two wrong ones it just gets easier and easier to keep doing.
I:Have your views changed about what’s right and wrong in the past few years?
R:No.
I:So what do you think it is that makes something right or wrong?
R:Is it really stupid or not?  Could it hurt someone else or that person?  And will it effect them later on in life?
I:So is it really the consequences of…?
R:Umhmm.
I:… the actions?
R:Yeah, the consequences.
I:From where do you acquire your world views?
R:Parents, grandparents, teachers.
I:Where do you think kind of world views in general come from?  Not just specifically influences from your parents or grandparents, but where do they come from, like why, you said murderers are not good people, I mean, where does that come from?
R:I think it’s just passed along and with basic perception of people we can get most of the time what’s right and wrong.
I:So it’s something that humans just learn on their own?
R:Umhmm.  For a basic age you learned that sharing was good, not to take from other people and as we keep growing up we learn through experience the difference between right and wrong.  If we do something good we’re rewarded, if we do something bad we’re scolded as a young age.

column591: The respondent makes decisions based on a mix of personal intuition regarding right and wrong, influenced by their parents and teachers, and believes that while some actions are universally wrong, moral judgments can vary by context, emphasizing the importance of consequences and the obligation to help others when possible.
